title: Johnson Is Named Coach Of Delaware's Harriers
description: Edgar Johnson, a 1967 grad uate of the University of Dela ware, has been named Blue Hen crosscountry coach.

title: RULE ON ALCOHOLISM SET FOR U.S. WORKERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Alcoholism among Federal employes will be treated like any other illness under guide lines issued this week by the Civil Service Commission.

title: E. Germany Wins 5 Titles In World Junior Rowing
description: BLED, Yugoslavia, July 31 (AP)East Germany captured five first places in the finals of the fiveday world junior rowing championships that con cluded today.

title: Dance
description: IT is one of the character istics of ballet history that its development has almost always been a mat ter of transplantation from one national culture to an other. Theatrical dance start ed in Italy, moved to France, from France to Denmark and Russia, and from Russia to Britain and the United States. It moved partly by dancers going to work in different countries, but it also moved rather more effectively via choreographers, balletmas ters. and. dancing teachers. And sometimes political events have also played their.

title: West German Women Set World Relay Mark
description: LUBECK, West Germay, July 31 (AP)  A West Ger man women's team smashed Britain's 3,200meter relay world record by 8.2 seconds today with a clocking of 8 minutes 16.8 seconds.

title: Kouwe and Green Share Ouimet Golf Lead With 72's
description: AUBURNDALE, Mass., July 31 (AP)Bob Kouwe of New ark, N. Y., and Torn Green of Brockton, Mass., fired par 72's today to share the firstround lead of the fourth annual Fran cis Ouimet Memorial golf tour nament.

title: Lucille Lewis Is Betrothed
description: Lucille Lewis Is Betrothed Mr. and Mrs. William Ben nett Lewis of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucille Grigware Lewis, to Tracy Lewis Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Bernhard John son of Appleton, Wis. The wedding is planned for Oc tober.

title: TV Camera Directed From Earth Follows Action of Men on the Moon
description: As the Apollo 15 astronauts went about their work on Hadley Base, the unblinking eye of a television camera watched them. Through it, so did the world. The camera, carried on Falcon, was used first atop a tripod on the landing zone and later on a unipod aboard Rorer. While on the lunar vehicle, it acted on command from the Houston Manned Space Center. It is planned it will record Falcon's liftoff tomorrow.

title: ORIOLES WIN, 40; DOBSON: 12 IN ROW
description: BALTIMORE, July 31 (UPI) Paf Dobson pitched a five hitter for his 12th straight vic toryfour short of the Ameri can League recordas the Balti more Orioles defeated the Kan sas City Royals, 40, tonight.

title: Antifraud Chief Named
description: Salvatore F. Sangiorgi, a Fed eral Trade Commission attorney since 1956, was appointed by the agency yesterday as an as sistant regional director for the agency here. He will also head a special 15member task force against retail frauds in the inner city.

title: Patrolman, Target of Attacker, Saved by Gun's Empty Chamber
description: A policeman on his way home early yesterday after complet ing his antiorime patrol on the Upper West Side was fired at, point blank, by a man with a sixshot revolver, but was un harmed as the weapon's ham mer hit the only empty cham ber in the gun.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., July 31 (UP)The New Orleans Saints dealt Don Talbert, an offensive tackle, to the Dallas Cowboys today for Doug Mooers, a defensive end, and an undisclosed draft choice.

title: CHEVRON FLIGHT TRIUMPHS IN MONMOUTH'S SAPLING
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 Caesar Kimmel's Chevron Flight established himself as the sea son's big 2yearold today by winning the $117,550 Sapling Stakes on a sloppy track at rainswept Monmouth Park.

title: Station Wagon Overturns, Killing Three in Family
description: MYSTIC, Conn., July 31 Three members of a Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., family were killed early today when their station wagon rolled over sev eral times on Interstate High way 95.

title: 106 JUDGES RESIGN IN PROTEST IN KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 31 total of 106 judges resigned this week in protest against al leged interference by prosecu tors, plunging the judiciary into a serious crisis.

title: Arieto Captures Final Race of N.Y.Y.C. Cruise
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 31A local sloop named Arieto chose the final day of the New York Yacht Club cruise to en ter a race and then sailed away to win the Commodore Vincent Astor's Cup from 61 other boats.

title: SelfService Gas Stations Spreading Over U.S.
description: NORTH HAVEN, Conn., July 31  One of the fastest growing features on the Amer ican road is the selfservice gasoline station.

title: Lindley Greenough Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter B. Greenough of New York have announced the engage ment of Mr. Greenough's daughter, Miss Lindley Gree nough of Roselle Park, N.J., to Paul Bridgewater Thomas set, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul August Thomasset of Chat ham, N.J.

title: Somebody, at Least, Finally Loves Loser
description: UTICA, N. Y., July 31 (AP) Utica Free Academy offi cials have admitted to the existence of a monetary award for the student who graduates each year with the lowest standing in his class.

title: Stamps
description: BRITISH COLUMBIA en tered the Canadian Confederation 100 years ago. On July 20, Canada celebrated the event postally with issu ance of a 7cent stamp whose basic design features multi colored initials B and C, which, according to the de signer, E.R.C. Bethune, prof fers a now lookrainbow ribbons of color forming the letters. Mr. Bethune says his design stems from boyhood memories of parades in which bicycle wheels were deco rated by strips of colored paper.

title: Criminals At Large
description: If there has been one un touchable thing in the British mystery story, it is Scotland Yard. Scotland Yard is pure and honest, diligent and noble, efficient and purposeful. No breath of scandal has ever touched it and its dedicated, hardworking personnel. But now comes G. F. Newman's SIR, YOU BASTARD (Simon & Schuster, $5.95), and it has done for the Yard what Jim Bouton's Ball Four has done for organized baseball. Scot land Yard may never recover.

title: Hempstead Rescues a Wildlife Service
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 31 A lastminute decision by officials here has saved a popular wildlife rescue serv ice in Baldwin that was to close because of a zoning violation.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: I READ with much interest David L. Shirey's review of the exhibition, Sum mer Loan 1971, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. His comments on the section devoted to paintings and sculptures from our collec tion were of course of par ticular interest, since the opinions of an outside critic are often of value to a col lector.

title: Miss Lori K. Kreitchman Is Affianced
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Mor ton Kreitchman have made known the engagement of their. daughter, Miss Lori Karen Kreitchman, to Steven Harold Klinghoffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Kling hoffer.

title: The Last Word: New American Review
description: In the four years since its first issue in Sep tember, 1967, New American Review has become a welcome literary presence. NAR 12 is now upon us. It contains two long, glamourous and highly intelligent personal essaysone by A. Alvarez on Sylvia Platt's life and work, the other by Norman Mailer on the theory and practice of his film Maidstoneplus such other notable features as a first excerpt from a new Donald Barthelme novel, a play by Robert Coover, an uncharacteristically toughminded eulogy for his fatherinlaw by Rich ard Brautigan, an admirably downtoearth descrip tion of the late Mark Rothko at work on the paintings for the Rothko Chapel in Texas, and a fine bit of countercultural musing by Michael Rossman on the virtues of building your own geo desic dome. On balance, number 12 is one of NAR's best issuesworthy of comparison to such celebrated numbers as NAR 3 with pieces by Philip Roth, Barthelme, Leonard Michaels, George Denni son and Paul West, or NAR 7 with pieces by Kate Millett, Rosalyn Drexler, L. Woiwode, Michael Herr, William H. Gass and Richard Howard. NAR is surely remarkablebut what exactly is it?

title: Stephen Stills Plays at Garden In His First Solo Concert Here
description: Stephen Stills, noted for his work with Buffalo Springfield and Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, gave his first solo performance here Friday eve ning before 21,000 people at Madison Square Garden.

title: Jo and Edouard were just too desafinado
description: It's a story they would tell with some relish at a Hollywood Hills cocktail party or on the terrace of a Roman superattico; it smacks of worldly ironies and exudes hard sa lubrious truths. This is the way we are covetous, lustful, forever seek ing out the unworthy object. It's the real love story of this and any year; the one that doesn't work, or as Henri Clouzot put it in La Verit: we love one another hut, alas, never at the same time. Benjamin Constant, Proust and Sagan have explored its subtleties; now the authentic voice of George Hayim gives it to us straight in his original variation on the theme: a 40/20 merciless vision (the love of a possessive, neurotically compulsive sybaritehysteric of 40 named Jo for an insolent, proudly ruthless, indifferent animal of 20 named Edouard) framed in an exquisite sadomasochistic battle of wits, a chiaroscuro of mutually inflicted pain: as it is for those whose notion of love is thus defined in the late nineteensixties jetset crowd.

title: FREDERIC ELTON, HELPED DISABLED
description: Frederic Garfield Elton, metropolitan district chief of the State Education Depart ment's vocational rehabilitation division from 1921 to 1952, died Friday in New York Polyclinic Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived at 333 Carpenter Ave nue, Sea Cliff, L.I.

title: METS DEFEAT CUBS, 52;
description: July finally ended, which was probably news enough for the New York Mets, who lost 20 of the 29 games they played during the month. But they escaped the siege with flour ishes yesterday by defeating the Chicago Cubs, 52, for the second straight time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There has been much discussion in recent days regarding our declining international trade position and our chronic balanceofpayments problems. In this context, it is curious to note that the Federal Reserve has opposed recent initiatives in Congress which would improve exportexpansion pro grams and insure a better balance be tween public and private sector fi nancing facilities.

title: VARIED CONCERTS OFFERED IN PARKS
description: The traditional summer sound of a brass band play ing in the park has been replaced this year in eight parks scattered through Brooklyn and Queens by a mixture of musical styles ranging from German bands dressed in lederhosen to rock groups.

title: RENTAKID AIDS YONKERS YOUTHS
description: YONKERSMyles Morse, 18 years old, got a job taking care of 25 pedigreed Doberman pinschers, two cats, four boa constrictors and a cage full of mice for Miss Elizabeth With row. Angel Del Pinto, 17, a high school dropout, was unemployed for several weeks and then got a job scraping paint off the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ira Ross.

title: Our Night on the Grease Rack, Or, Akron by Accident
description: I HAVE never thought that the scene of a wife hearing the car make a funny noise was at all comical, and neither did James Thurber, who once, in a story called A Couple of Ham burgers, told of a wife who said some thing in the car was making a noise like a lot of safety pins being jiggled around in a tumbler. The husband as serted that nothing that goes wrong with cars sounds like that, but little good did it do him, finally, in Thur ber's' grim account of an unrelenting marital squabble. My own wife, whose name is Ce, said that what she heard sounded like peanuts rattling inside waffle iron.

title: Convictions and Deterrents Cut Bank Robberies in Area
description: The soaring increase in bank robberies last year in Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island has been followed this year by a soaring increase in another categorythe collar ing and conviction of bank robbers operating in the area.

title: J. S. Ellison to Marry Miss Jane E. Auerbach
description: RYE, N. Y., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Auerbach have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Auerbach, to James Stuart Ellison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Elli son of Wilmington, Del. A January wedding is planned.

title: KY STILL SEEKING TO OPPOSE THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky played tennis today while his campaign workers were out drumming up support. But his chances of appearing on the presidential ballot in Octo ber appeared to be diminishing.

title: 3 U.S. Sailors to Seek Europe Star Class Title
description: Portugal has a rich tradi tion in sailing the seas. Prince Henry founded a school of navigation 500 years ago at Sams. On this southwest ern top of the land, Henry gathered together the best astronomers, nautical experts and geographers of the day. Among the pupils were Vasco da Gama and Christopher Co lumbus. The famous tower of Belem in Lisbon marks the site from where da Gama began his epic voyage that was to take him around the Cape of Good Hope, the first European to sail to India.

title: Count Bask Gets a Lift
description: COUNT BASIE and his Orchestra; Afrique (Flying Dutchman). The Basle band has been living on its smoothness and gloss for so many years, both on records and in con cert, that this disk arrives as a stimulating, invigorating reassurance that the band can really be something more than a mechanically swing ing machine. Oliver Nelson, who arranged and conducted the session, and Bob Thiele, who produced it, have lifted the band out of its glib rut by providing it with fresh material and a few fresh ac cents that enhance the band's best points  its ensemble blend and Basie's distinc tion as a soloistwhile, at the same time, its horizons extended

title: FULLSCALE SEARCH FOR BOY, 8, IS ENDED
description: NEWCOMB, N. Y., July 31 (UPI)The fullscale search for 8yearold Douglas Legg, miss ing in the rugged Adirondacks near here for three weeks, will end tomorrow evening, the state police announced today.

title: Bavarian Roads Jammed
description: MUNICH, Germany, July 31 (A13)  Streams of travelers, heading south on vacation created traffic chaos today in Bavaria and other sections of West Germany.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  There are, generally, two explanations for why a member of Congress votes as he does on any given issue. There is the explanation he of fers, which is most often quite simple and plausible. And there is the truth: His vote is deter mined by a frequently conflicting set of factorshis own ideologi cal beliefs, the interests of his constituents back home, the wishes of his party, to name three.

title: PENSION REVISIONS. EXPECTED IN 1972
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  It does not appear likely that legislation covering private pen sion plans will be passed by Congress this year, but 1972 could be the year for such a bill, according to Washington observers.

title: U.S. SCORES TWICE IN PANAM GAMES
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31 Frank Shorter, who said he was ready to run, and Pat Matzdorf, who was almost too ill to jump, recorded the first gold medals for the United States at the Sixth PanAmerican Games; tonight.

title: Passenger Runs to Chatham On Penn Central End Today
description: The Penn Central will dis continue passenger service be tween Chatham and New York City today, the railroad said, yesterday.

title: CITY IN MICHIGAN RESTRICTS AUTOS
description: DETROIT, July 31City of ficials in Highland Park, birth place of the automobile assem bly line and headquarters of the Chrysler Corporation, be lieve the automobile is ruining the quality of life in their community.

title: Thais Sentence 2 Americans
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 (Reuters)A Thai military court has sentenced Paul Nagoles and Richard Jentile, both of New York, to 18 months in prison for illegal possession of heroin, police sources said to day.

title: Medicine
description: An anonymous stonecutter carved the date 1767 in the portals of Columbia Univer sity's College of Physicians and Surgeons to mark its founding. But, inside the sandstone skyscraper at 168th Street and Fort Washington Avenue, you will find today a brand new medical school.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, July 31While President Nixon's dramatic announce ment that he will visit America some time next year is still reverberating happily through this tired old world of ours, the intricate staff work that must precede any such historic Presi dential mission is already well ad vanced at the White House.

title: Letters to the Editor
I.T.T. WILL GIVE UP LARGE HOLDINGS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has agreed to divest itself of sev eral of the largest corporations that it has acquired over the last few years, the Justice De partment announced today.

title: Rep. Chisholm Declares That She May Run for President in 1972
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 31  Representative Shirley Chis holm, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today she was considering running for President in 1972 and that a committee of backers had been formed to test sup port for her in 27 states.

title: Jets Rookies Beat Bridgeport, 277, As Stoddard Stars
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31 Vernon Studdard returned a punt 54 yards for a touchdown tonight and Bob Davis collabo rated with Gary Arthur on touchdown passes of 22 and 42 yards as the New York Jets' rookies defeated the Bridgeport Jets of the Atlantic Coast Foot ball League, 277. A crowd of 9,000 saw the game at Kennedy Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mr. Costikyan's realistic and interesting article points up the faot that while poli ticians know what is happen ing they are only willing to be quoted when they are no longer in office.

title: U.S. to Risk 5 Titles
description: The United States will de fend five team championships in the PanAmerican Games in Cali, July 30 to Aug. 13. They are baseball, men's basketball, men's and women's, volleyball, and water polo.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The need is not to regu late dune buggies, as was suggested in your article on these vehicles (Travel sec tion, July 11), but to ban them. Highways are for motor vehicles. Beaches, desert and woodland are for walking and quiet con templation. Just because some people have become so jaded or desensitized that they must speed along the ocean's edge for their kicks does not mean that those of us who enjoy cooperating with nature must indulge them.

title: Horse Show News
description: Mrs. Alan Robson of West Chester, Pennsylvania, scored a rare triple last year by win ning the American Horse Shows Association's high score awards in two divi sions and trying for the championship in another. Still, Mrs. Robson has not realized her main dream in the equine world. That as to win the fine harness stake at the Ken tucky State Fair show in Louis ville, probably the leading saddle horse event in the country.

title: A South African at N.Y.U. Joins World Jurists' Unit
description: GENEVA, July 31The Inter national Commission of Jurists has announced the election to its ranks of Joel Carlson, South African lawyer now at New York University Center for International Studies.

title: City U. Growth Seen as Threat To Future of Private Colleges
description: Fears were voiced last week that the City University might develop into a monolithic highereducational system, with private institutions of higher learning swallowed up.

title: Ne Win to Visit China
description: HONG KONG, July 31 (Reu ters)Ne Win, the Burmese leader, will pay an informal visit to China in August, the Peking radio announced today. Relations between the two countries became strained dur ing 1967, but ambassadors were reinstated in the last year.

title: Hunt Sets Mark, Expos Win
description: MONTREAL, July 31 (AP) Ron Hunt of the Expos tied a modern major league record to day when he was hit by a pitch for the 31st time this season. The occurrence also keyed a fourrun fourth inning spurt that carried Montreal to a 64 triumph over the Houston Astros.

title: Pattisson Duo Takes Lead In Flying Dutchman Sail
description: LA ROCHELLE, France, July 31 (AP)Rodney Pattisson and Julian Brooke Houghton of Britain, the defending cham ions, took the lead today after the fifth of seven heats in the Flying Dutchman yachting championships.

title: MISS SHARP TAKES HORSE SHOW PRIZE
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 31Penny Sharp, a 16yearold junior at John Jay High School in Katonah, N. Y., captured the Youth Activities championship today at the opening session of the Orange County horse show.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Twin Time, $32.40, Victor
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31  The East Acres' Twin Time, taking the lead with a little more than a quarter of a mile remaining was forced to rally again in the stretch to win the $57,300 Minuteman Handi cap at Liberty Bell Race Track today.

title: Strikes: a Mediator's View
description: WASHINGTONThe rail roads: On strike again.

title: Brooklyn Boxer Removed From Games With Injury
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31 (AP)An American boxer, Joe Riviera of Brooklyn, was with drawn today from the Pan American Games with a frac tured nose, wiping out the United States' hopes in the featherweight division. Each nation is permitted one entry in each weight class, with no substitutions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:One, wonders if SALT (Strategic Arms Limitation Talks) II, involving China, the Soviet Union and the United States, could develop in the environ ment created by the President's China trip. Such an arms control meeting would offer several mutual advan tages:

title: Mrs. King Is Upset by Mrs. Masthoff of Germany in Venice Tennis Semifinal
description: VENICE, Italy, July 31 (UPI) Mrs. Helga Masthoff of West Germany upset Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., the topseeded player, 26, 64, 76, today in the $4,400 Venice women's open tennis tourna ment.

title: PEKING
description: PEKING, July 31China's attitudes and tactics toward the United States are obviously changing, but her strategy and principles remain the same. This is the main impression of a reporter here.

title: KLANSMAN MEETS CAROLINA BLACKS
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 31 C. P. Ellis didn't really want to go back to work Thursday, The president of the Durham chapter of United Klans of America had other things on his mind when he reported back to duty in the maintenance department at Duke University.

title: 2 Jockeys Hurt in Spill In Del Mar Turf Race
description: DEL MAR, Calif., July 31 (UPI)Don Pierce and an ap prentice, Raul Ramierez, were injured today during the run ning of the fourth race at Del Mar when their mounts fell.

title: Frederick Beinecke, 84, Dead; Gave Rare Manuscripts to Yale
description: Frederick William Beinecke, a director and former president of Sperry and Hutchinson Com pany, trading stamp concern, who possessed one of the largest private collections of books and manuscripts on Western Americana, died Fri day at his summer home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 84 years old and Lived at 888 Park Avenue.

title: Television
description: FROM time to time people stop me on the street and ask what was like to write for Johnny Carson's Tonight show. They also ask what it's like to tattoo the words of Just a Closer Walk With Thee on a belly dancer's navel. Since I've only experienced the former (my agent is working on the latter) I can talk about that.

title: NETS WILL MEET CELTICS, BULLETS
description: The New York Nets will play an eightgame exhibition sched ule this fall.

title: 76ERS' HOME OPENER OCT. 20 IN SPECTRUM
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (UPI)The Philadelphia 76ers will play the most consistent home schedule in their National Basketball Association history during the 197172 campaign.

title: Prostitutes in Nevada to Test Drug to Fight Venereal Disease
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., July 31A Nevada state health of ficial has announced that wom en working in houses of pros titution in the state will be used in a drug experiment to fight the growing national epi demic of veneral disease.

title: Photography
description: IT is 10:30 in the muggy night of July 15. We are crowded around the TV set in a SoHo loft, wait ing for the 11 o'clock news on Channel 4. Richard Nixon is telling us that he will go to Peking. I am fantasizing him running on a peace tick et in the upcoming election. Harvey Stromberg is saying, I'm perfect for this kind of thing.

title: A New Populism Emerges in Mississippi's Democratic Primary
description: PHILADELPHIA, Miss., July 31Andrew W. Sullivan, can didate for the Democratic nom ination for Governor in next Tuesday's primary, sounded angry.

title: A Roller Derby Team Will Skate in Garden
description: The International Roller Derby League has announced plans to franchise a Roller Derby team in the Northeast next winter with a base of operations at Madison Square Garden.

title: Like listening to a Golden Oldie record
description: Gilbert Highet once was almost unavoidable; he published 11 books between 1949 and 1962, and their neat blending of easy scholarship and reassuring skepticism about the pretensions of artistic modernism made him a prominent landmark in the middle latitudes of Eisenhower culture. For the BookoftheMonth Club audience there was Highet the urban but not intimidatingly brainy belleslettrist, the ideal professor they wished they'd had in college; for academic people uneasy about their own credentials, Highet was the guide, philosopher and friend who in The Art of Teaching pointed the way toward the civilization that had somehow been left out of their edu cations. To a Philistine realm, that is, Highet came as the emissary of a comfortable AngloAmerican academ ic mandarinism, to say that we weren't quite so hopeless as we feared. Modernism was mostly a hoax; the old verities still held water; with just a bit more style and grace we could hold our heads up in any company.

title: SOVIET BLOC HEED LAGGING ON TALKS
description: Recent talks between repre sentatives of Atlantic alliance and Warsaw Pact Governments have shown that the Soviet Union and its allies lag behind the Westem powers in specific preparations for a European security conference to deal with reduction of forces.

title: the traveler's world
description: CHICAGO  It was back in 1953 that what apparently was the first airport hotel in the United States, if not in the world, was built at Los Angeles International Airport by Hyatt Von Dehn. People thought he was crazy to put up a hotelSO rooms and a coffee shopfar from downtown and next to the airport, but Von Dehn ran at capacity from opening day and added 70 rooms within a year. For the next eight years he operated his 150room establishment at 98 per cent occupancy, an alltime world record for the hotel business.

title: Argentine Oarsmen Capture First Gold Medals of Pan  American Games
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31 (AP) Led by its world champion sculler, Alberto Demiddi, Ar gentina swept to three gold medals in rowing today and gave a Latin tempo to the open ing of competition in the sixth PanAmerican Games.

title: CUBAN WOMEN'S FIVE LOSES TO U.S., 6362
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31 (UPI)  A substitute, Janis Beach of Wayland Baptist Col lege, scored her only basket of the game with 10 seconds re maining to give the United States women's basketball team a 6362 victory over Cuba in the opening game for both in the PanAmerican Games.

title: Toll in Afghan Landslide Revised Downward to 100
description: NEW DELHI, July 31 (Reu ters)The death toll from a landslide Wednesday in Afghan istan is believed to be just over 100 persons, not 1,000 as orig inally feared, the Bakhtar News Agency quoted officials as hav ing said today.

title: Movies
description: SOPHIA LOREN is en tering a convent. But not for long. In her next film, The Sin, she will play a nursing nun who falls in love with a pas sionate Communist patient. The Italianlanguage movie, to be released by Columbia, will be directed by Alberto Lattuada and will co  star Adriano Celentano as Miss Loren's wayward lover. It will be producedstarting this September in Milanby Carlo Pond, the man who re cently produced Miss Loren's Mortadella. He is also the man who was lucky enough to marry the luscious Loren.

title: Miss Gunster Wed To Louis J. Tullio
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 31 Miss Grace Eileen Gunster and Mayor Louis Joseph Tullio of Erie, Pa., were mar ried here this afternoon in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. R. Stanley Berg of the Glad Tidings Tabernacle in New York performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Salvatore Mitchell, of the Good Shep herd Roman Catholic Church in West Middlesex, Pa.

title: What's a Nice Boy From Staten Island Doing in Hollywood?
description: WHEN Elia Kazan required a location that looked like a lusterless, 1920 Kansas hamlet for sequence in Splendor in the Grass, he selected my hometown, Travis, on Staten Island. crashed the set by wearing two beatup cameras around my neck and telling the guards I was from The Herald Tribune. I managed to chat with Natalie Wood, Warren Beatty, Joan Collins and Robert Wagner (the latter two visiting the set), but I didn't do too well with Elia Kazan.

title: Brandt on Defensive
description: BONN, July 31 West Ger many's conservative opposition succeeded in putting Chancellor Willy Brandt's SocialistLiberal coalition on the defensive this week through disclosures of se cret diplomatic papers concern ing the Berlin problem.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Why does the oddtotter continue to unload stocks at such a remarkable rate?

title: Eastern Grass Tourney Saved
description: Tennis fans who follow tournaments have finally been given the answer to a puzzle the Eastern grass champion ships, contrary to reports, are not dead.

title: E. J. HOLUB FACES 10TH OPERATION
description: KANSAS CITY, July 31 (UPI) E. J. Holub, the star Kansas City Chiefs center, will under go the 10th operation of his football career Monday and the outcome will determine whether he remains in the sport or calls it quits.

title: Books:
description: BASICS FOR BUYERS. By Somerby R. Dowst. Cahners. 211 pages. $10.95.

title: Steel Union Votes to Defer Strike Deadline 24 Hours
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The United Steelworkers of America voted tonight to extend con tract negotiations for 24 hours, moving back a deadline for a strike against the nation's steel industry to midnight tomorrow.

title: Pele and Santos Face Deportivo Cali Here Today
description: Pel, who has retired from the Brazilian national team but is still active with his team, Santos of Brazil, will ap pear before New York fans at Yankee Stadium today when Santos meets Deportivo Cali of Colombia in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Andrea Arms Bride Upstate
description: PORT LEYDEN, N. Y., July 31  Miss Andrea Alexandra Arms, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Arnold Arms of Geneva and Turin, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Marvin Jack Rudnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Philip Rudnick of Oneida.

title: The Nation
description: The view of the black commu nity held by many a social sci entist is by now familiar: a dis aster area plagued by social disorganization, family disinte gration and a host of conditions that breed emotional pathologies. It is a view based, in large meas ure, upon the statistics published periodically by the Bureau of the Census and the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: LETTERS
description: David Rockefeller (July 18) cited an example of the social concern of banksa bank consortium loan of $75 million for the Waterside housing project.

title: Alcohol Called Big Factor in Hungarian Suicides
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31The significance of alco holism and family conflicts as causes of suicide has doubled since before World War 11 in Hungary, which has the world's highest suicide rate.

title: Brooklyn Art Museum Showing Varied Works
description: The Brooklyn Museum Art School will exhibit art works by its alumni and faculty members in the museum's Blum Galleries beginning Wednesday through Sept. 30.

description: Miss Elizabeth Kelly Piper, a member of the Cherry Lane Theater Workshop, and Samuel M'Cheyne Glasser, a lawyer with Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher, will be married Oct. 9 in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: THREE GOVERNORS TRY TO BAR DAMS
description: BOISE, Idaho, July 31The Governors of Oregon, Wash ington and Idaho have joined conservationists in an attempt to prevent construction of hy droelectric dams in the last wild stretch of the Snake River in Hells Canyon.

Spassky Prefers Fischer As Chess Title Opponent
description: VIENNA, July 31 (Reuters) The world chess champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, says that he will prob ably defend his title against compatriot, Tigran Petrosian, but that he would prefer to play against Bobby Fischer, the American grandmaster.

title: Receptionists to Be Used In 7 More Police Precincts
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yester day the expansion of the pre cinct receptionist program to seven more precincts in Man hattan and Brooklyn.

title: CHILE MIDDLEMEN TARGET OF A DRIVE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 31 Minister of Economy Pedro Vuskovic Says that food short ages and price speculation re quire fuller state control of marketing to knock out the middlemen.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: My experience with im porting personal goods bought abroad under the $100 allowance for custom free entry may be a warning to others. On my way to Spain in search of 15thcen tury documents, I stopped in Switzerland and bought there a small, plastic filing cabinet for my desk, which I had sent back to the United States. On my return, I pro duced my foreignpurchase declaration totaling $52 (well below the allowance), which included $18 for the filing cabinet, but the cus toms officials informed me that items sent by mail were not eligible for dutyfree entry if they exceeded $10. It was a case of ignorance on my part, but I shared this ignorance with many friends who travel abroad every year.

title: Letters:
description: To The Editor:

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: It is a real disgrace that New York and Montreal, the two largest cities of the Unit ed States and Canada, have no rail links anymore. Lack of communications between nations may be one of the causes of war. I love to travel by rail and used to go to Montreal many times by train. Now all that is left is a bumpy bus ride or an air plane trip for those of us who do not have an automobile.

title: Senators Down Brewers, 43
description: MILWALUKEE, July 31 (AP) Dick Billings's single in the eighth inning today drove in Larry Biittner with the tie breaking run and gave the Washington Senators a 43 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: The Nation
description: I slept sounder than ever remember to have done in my life . . . when I awakened. . . I attempted to rise, but was not able to stir: for, as I happened to lie on my back, I found my arms and legs were strongly fas tened on each side to the ground. From a Voyage to Lilliput in Gulliver's Travels

title: Dengals Deal Lineman
description: WILMINGTON, Ohio, July 31 (AP)Mike Wilson, a defensive lineman, and a graduate of the University of Dayton, was traded today by the Cincinnati Bengals to the Los Angeles Rams for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: CANADIANS EAGER TO USE CHINA TIES
description: OTTAWA, July 31  The ar rival here this week of Huang Rua, first Ambassador to Cana da from the People's Republic of China has made the Cana dian Government more deter mined than ever to press the advantage of being in on the ground floor.

title: CHINA NOW FAVORS COMMON MARKET
description: PARIS, July 31  Communist China has expressed approval of Western European integra tion on the ground that it is weakening the imperialistic forces of both the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Kristine Olson Fiancee Of Jeffrey L. Rogers
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Olson of Shelter Island and Plandome have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kristine Arline Olson, to Jeffrey Langston Rogers, son of Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Mrs. Rogers of Bethesda, Md.

title: FERRIGNO'S SLOOP WINS 15MILE SAIL
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31  Anthony R. Ferrigno's 38 foot sloop, Secret, was the correctedtime winner by 1:43 of Black Rock Yacht Club to day i the opening race of the annual Easter Connecticut area cruisigyacht championship re gatta of he Yacht Racing As sociation of Long Island Sound. A second race, scheduled to morrow, will complete the event.

title: Why They Fled Pakistan And Won't Go Back
description: THIS is my third visit to the IndiaPakistan border 60 miles east of Calcutta. The country side has not changed. It is the same lush, emerald green of the paddy and the darker green of the jute, the stretches of swamp with snowwhite egrets hunting for frogs and the limpid ponds encircled with hyacinth or bright with pink water lilies. It is the same avenue, flanked on either side by massive banyan and rain trees loud with the chatter of mynas and the dulcet notes of magpie robins. The only evidence of conflict on this peaceful, drowsy landscape is slo gans painted on tree trunks: Long Live Mao, read some, and Long Live Indira, the others.

title: Mrs. Meir Admonishes Critics of Domestic Policy
description: JERUSALEM, July 31 What has happened to us in the last year? What has hap pened to our understanding? To our good sense? To our self discipline?

title: School Band at Pro Game
description: The BridgewaterRaritan High schoolEast Minuteman Band will provide the musical enter tainment at the 10th annual Jaycee charity football game between the New York Giants and Philadelphia Eagles on Sat urday, Aug 28, at Palmer Stadium in Princeton, N.J.

title: Good Wail Mission
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31  The sixth PanAmerican Games finally has begun, and officials are breathing a heavy sigh of relief, hopeful that competition will replace complaint as the order of the day.

title: In Washington, You Just Don't Not Return a Call From Abe Forte
description: WASHINGTON. HOW does America handle its pariahs? When last heard from, Alger Hiss was a printing and stationery safesman, Charles Van Doren was editing for the Encyclo paedia Britannica, Sherman Adams was keeping his own counsel in New Hampshire and Abe Fortes . . . What ever happened to Abe Fortes?

title: HUGHES ALLEGES MORE CORRUPTION
description: Three new instances of al leged official wrongdoing one involving a case in State Supreme Court and two involv ing state government outside the courtshave been brought up before Governor Rockefel ler's office by the chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

title: Chile Gets Rebuilding Loan
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 31 (Reuters)The InterAmerican Development Bank will lend Chile $15million to help repair damage caused by the earth quake on July 8. The loan will be repaid over 25 years at 3.5 per cent interest.

title: TV Picture Quality Surprises Networks
description: This oughtta give the folks back home something to look at.

title: Pennsylvania Archer Captures World Title
description: YORK, England, July 31 (AP)John Williams, an 18 yearold archer from Cranes ville, Pa., won the world championship tonight.

title: Legal Program Started in Philadelphia With O.E.O. Funds to Protect Rights of Poor and Aged Sick
description: PHILADELPHIA  A funda mental legal program has been started here to assure the rights of the poor and aged sick.

title: Stamps
description: THE Bailiwick of Jersey in the Channel Islands has turned to its famed artists for designs for four stamps to appear on Oct. 5. The multicolored stamps, being produced by Courvoisier, the Swiss stamp printers, will reproduce a painting by each artist. Three were born on Jersey, the fourth was the son of Jersey parents.

title: For Young Readers: In American terms, 40 million war victims
description: In the past 25 years, from the French naval bombardment of Hai phong harbor, in November, 1946, to the daily American bombings in Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos, west ern peoples have been killing, maiming, devastating Asian peoples in one of the most savage wars in history. In this quartercentury, to tal casualties in killed and wounded have reached almost two million, while four million Vietnamese have been uprooted from their homes and villages. The terrible toll of the war has thus directly struck at some six million individuals, almost one out of every five inhabitants of Vietnam. In comparable American terms that would mean 40 million war victims, if ever the United States were to be hit as hard as we have hit the suffering people of Vietnam.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:One can't help being rather disappointed that such an in formative and entertaining article on Martha's Vineyard (Travel section, June 27) was accompanied by a picture of the Chappaquiddick Dike Bridge. This seems unfortun ate because the article's open ing paragraphs rightly de plore the fact that the tragic incident has attracted so many of the usual morbid sightseers who appear to de light in visiting sights of sad events and purchasing me mentos of them. No wonder Vineyard onislanders are becoming turned off by this kind of tourist and that their hackles are rising.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In his Point of View article For Housing Realism [July 18] Edward Costikyan joins the growing number of New Yorkers who believe that their city is doomed unless drastic remedial action is taken.

title: U.S. WINS 3 MEDALS AS WHEEL GAMES END
description: STOKE MANDEVILLE, Eng land, July 31 (UPI)The 11 man United States team won three gold medals today on the final day of the international Stoke Mandeville Wheelchair Olympics.

title: Celtics to Meet Bucks Twice ln 41Game Home Schedule
description: BOSTON, July 29 (AP)The Boston Celtics have announced a 41game home schedule for the 197172 season, beginning Oct. 3.

description: SEATTLE, July 31A group of young doctors got a taste of their own medicine as they ate lunch in a dining room at the University of Washington Hos pital.

description: ALEXANDRIA, N. H., July 31Miss Sara Ames Wheeler. was married here this after noon to Dieter Forster in the Alexandria Village Church by the Rev. Lewis Toppan, A Congregational minister.

title: 45 HEALTH PLANS HELD INADEQUATE
description: None of the 45 bills before Congress incorporating the Nixon Administration's plan and 13 other major plans for reorganizing delivery of health care in the United States is adequate, a specialist in medical economics has asserted.

title: Anyore For the Hydraulis?
description: THE concert auditoriums are rela tively quiet these days, although Philharmonic Hall will begin re sounding tomorrow night with the Mostly Mozart Festival. Musicmaking is up to the ballet orchestras, the many ensembles that tour the parks or the festivals that flourish in the country side. This department is left bemusedly contemplating an instrument called the hydraulis that was built in 228 A.D. The reader is forewarned.

title: The World
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan Bodyguards dandled sub machineguns in the anterooms, and in his office the Sudan's strong man, Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, glanced down at his bare muscular forearms from time to time as if for reassurance.

title: Miller, Watson Post 284's For Medal in Western Golf
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., July 31 (AP)Two recent col lege  graduates who intend to turn pro shared medalist hon ors today as the field was pared to 16 for the beginning of match play in the Western amateur golf tournament.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONThe closing days of July have seen a staggering amount of politically damaging economic news coming out of the Nixon Administra tion. No wonder the Democrats despite their own responsibility for much of the situation  believe the economy will be their big gun against the President next year.

title: National Notes
description: Gotham State?

title: The Electronic Computer's Inventors
description: A group of World War II buddies are getting together Tuesday in Chicago for a re union.

title: UNICEF Centers in India
description: CALCUTTA, India (AP), July 31To stave off the threat of widespread deaths from mal >nutrition among refugee chil dren from East Pakistan, the United Nations Children's Fund is opening 1,000 centers in eastern India on Aug. 15 to dis pense highprotein foods. nutrition among refugee chil dren from East Pakistan, the United Nations Children's Fund is opening 1,000 centers in eastern India on Aug. 15 to dis pense highprotein foods.

title: Diana Balooka was an unregenerate manaddict
description: There is a toomuchness about try ing to live now, an overload of stim uli and data, which is reflected in the structures of fiction: they frac ture, expand, implode, in an effort to encompass and order (to compre hend) the chaotic. There are no con ventions yet, only assays; here is a first novel by a poet which relies primarily on language to make it both include and cohere. Walking Papers both delights and frustrates by its inclusiveness and its fragmentariness. I was dizzy with admiration for Sandra Hochman's ability, first to name so much and then to bring remarkably much of it to more than linguistic life. It is the novel's prob lem that these are sometimes two separate processes. When they are one, when life and language intensify each other, it becomes clear that Miss Hochman has enough of a novel ist's gift, which is, in a sense, the gift of giving lifeto have taken on a little less and made more of it.

title: Taliaferro Stars in Drill
description: AMHERST, Mass., July 31 (AP)Mike Taliaferro threw touchdown passes of 30 yards to Ron Sellers and 27 yards to Tom Richardson today during a controlled scrimmage by the New England Patriots.

title: 7 Charged in Drug Sales To U.S. Sailors in Naples
description: NAPLES, Italy, July 31 (Reu ters)The police arrested sev en young men here today and charged them with possessing and selling drugs to United States sailors of the Sixth Fleet.

title: Not so much a story as an exhibition
description: It isn't every day that we're offered a tephramancy (divination by means of ashes, especially from an altar or ruined temple), least of all one interrupted by vaudeville shows that temper the vatic emphasis with fes tive wit. The Promisekeeper is all of that, its title page bearing not only the subtitle Divers Narratives on the Economics of Current Morals in Lieu of a Psychology . . . Here Embodied in an Approved Text Working Often in Spite of Itself, but also announcements about the interruptions to come. We are even promised Hearty FamilyType Fare, Modern Decor and Free Parking. It's not so much a title page as an ad for a prankish dis position which, like a mancarrying Montgolfier balloon, is about to ascend on its own homegrown ther mal and maybe explode.

title: Rainstorm Passes but Remnants Shower City Area
description: The torrential rainstorm that disrupted travel, telephone service and electrical systems here Friday gave way yesterday to patches of sunshine and scattered thunderstorms that were expected to continue through today.

title: U.S. Patrol Reports 3 Killed in Ambush In Hills at Danang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 1 (AP)  North Vietnamese troops ambushed a United States patrol in the coastal hills south of Danang yesterday, killing three Ameri cans and wounding eight, the United States command report ed today.

title: Laura Stratton Fiancee Of Henry F. Thoresby
description: Dr. Julius Adams Stratton, board chairman of the Ford Foundation and former presi dent of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Mrs. Stratton of New York have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Laura Adams Stratton, to Henry Fielding Thoresby, son of Mrs. James Thoresby of London and the late Dr. Thoresby, a physician.

title: Anglers to Stress Ecology
description: CHICAGO (AP) When the American Fishing Tackle Manu facturers Association holds its show here one of the features will be an ecology action center. The dates are Aug. 8 to 11.

title: Diane Pease Seeking Olympic Berth
description: Diane Pease has been clear ing hurdles since she was 8 years old and her latest achievements may give her a clear run to realize her greatest ambitionrepresent ing Australia at the Olympic Games in Munich, West Ger many, next year.

title: Laos Reports Gains
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 31 (UPI)  Laotian Government troops were reported today, to have recaptured the enemy stronghold town of Ban Nhik in heavy fighting and to be ad vancing on the road junction of Pak Song in southern Laos.

title: Namath and Ewbank Operating On Same Wave Length for 1971
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 31When the Jets open their exhibition schedule against the Detroit Lions in Tampa, Fla., next Saturday night, Joe Namath will be their starting quarterback. I assume I'll play the first half, Namath said, but I haven't talked to Weeb about it.

title: Defunct College Is Given New Life by Evangelist
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 31  Mackinac College, dead for more than a year, be gan throbbing with life this month, transformed into the Rex Humbard Christian Devel opment Center dispensing va cations with inspiration to 300 men, women and children a week.

title: Bergman an Bibi: A Touch of Soap
description: SWEDEN'S Ingmar Bergman, who recently made his first Englishlanguage film, The Touch, makes his first appearance on an American talk show tomorrow night. The di rector, and actress Bibi Andersson, will be the only guests on The Dick Cavett Show, starting at 11:30 on ABC. In this excerpt from the 90 minute interview, taped in Stockholm in May, Bergman and Miss Anderssonwho costars with Elliott Gould in The Touchdo a bit of remi niscing about how they met.

title: Negroes Held Oppressed by the Law
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 After a year of study, a promi nent black lawyer has conclud ed that the criminal process is being used across the country to contain blacks and the poor.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Why did Robert Jacobs go ahead and design a project and a building if he was so much against it?

title: Alice Auchmoody Bride in Bay State
description: OLD STURBRIDGE. VIL LAGE, Mass., July 31Miss Alice Arlen Auchmoody and Charles Ludington Johnson 3d were married here today at the Meetinghouse by the Rev. Jerry Clausen of the Congregational United Church of Christ.

title: 6 INJURED IN BRAWL AFTER RIVER CRUISE
description: A woman and five policemen were injured and seven persons were arrested early yesterday when a quarrel between two women swelled into a brawl among people returning from a moonlight cruise on the Circle Line and debarking at the pier at the foot of West 42d Street.

title: Mary P. Davis A Jersey Bride
description: HADDONFIELD, N.J., July 31Miss Mary Patricia. Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward E. Davis, was married here this afternoon to Craig M. Oettinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer D. Oettinger of Stamford, Conn.

title: Leaving War to Civilians
description: McLEAN, Va. The soulsearching evoked by publication of excerpts from the McNamara report has pro duced a new rash of criticism of our Vietnam venture. Where did we go wrong? is the question of the hour.

title: The Monarch Who Couldn't Stop Marrying
description: CHARLES LAUGHTON belched and threw bones over his shoulder. Robert Shaw towered golden and raging in the role. Richard Bur ton, for reasons best known to himself, chose black for the color of his beard and attempted a portrait somewhere between the lovable Laughton and the unpredictable Shaw. Which is the true picture of Henry VIII, or are all the pictures true? He has long been a fas cinating puzzle to scholars and the read ing public, and yet the image of the fat, redbearded monarch from the Hol bein portraits is as well known as that of any king, and the fact of his six mar riages is remembered by schoolboys from Hampton Court to Tallahassee.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your coverage of Morocco since the abortive army coup rightly stresses the link between corruption and the revolt. It also raises sober questions about American policy toward autoc racies like Morocco.

title: Miss Cushing To Wed Oct. 23
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Cushing have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Hedges Cush ing, to Henry Mueller Hul shizer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hulshizer of Rumson.

title: Son for the Pettibones
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. John S. Pettibone Jr. of McLean, Va., on July 3 in the Columbia Women's Hospital in Washington. The child, whose mother is the former Miss Susan Woodall of Weldon, N. C., is named Walker Whiteside. He is grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Pettibone of Middleburg, Va. worth. The future bridegroom's father is vice presi dent and general manager of the Newark Newsdealers Sup ply Company.

title: Music Mailbag
description: Perhaps a clue to Pierre Boulez's conflict with the Philharmonic audience, which finds his programing of 20th century works hard to take, lies in the fact that during his fiveweek stay in New York he attended no films, shows, galleries, or large parties and spent only three evenings with friends. He devoted himself only to music and things went intensely. It is, I slip pose, understandable that

title: Summer in Washington: Less Formality, More Plain Fun, But Politics as Usual
description: WASHINGTONShortly after dawn the haze hangs heavily over the na tion's capital. It's still, but for only while. Washington, like the sun, is an early riser.

title: Gardens
description: SHORTLY after Mrs. Mario Ciullo acquired her town house on Bos ton's historic Beacon Hill, she re alized she could not have a flower garden. Space was limited, there was little sun and the tall house and the high brick walls meant poor air circulation.

title: Helene Hollis Duncan Bride Here of Peter Durfor Dilks
description: Miss Helene Hollis Duncan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. Duncan of New York, was married here yes terday afternoon to Peter Durfor Dilks, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hyland Dilks of Philadelphia.

title: Clowns Cavort for Central Park Crowd
description: Clowns of all sorts cavorted in the Sheep Meadow in Cen tral Park yesterday afternoon in celebration of the art of the pratfall, the cutup and the greasepaint smile.

title: Carol P. Quinlan Is Betrothed to Soldier
description: MANHASSET HILLS, L. I., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Maurice D. Quinlan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Patricia Quinlan, to Pfc. Theodor Charles Sauer Jr., U.S.A. son of Mr. and Mrs. Sauer of Garden City. The wedding will take place on Sept. 12 at Candlewood Lake, Conn.

title: Policeman Kills 2 Pursuing a Robber
description: Two brothers who ran a Spanish grocery in uptown Manhattan were shot to death in the street early yesterday by an offduty policeman as they were chasing a third man who had allegedly held up their bo dega.

title: Ulozas Ousts Siderowf and Brooke to Gain Semifinals in Metropolitan Golf
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 31Dick Siderowf of the Golf Club of Aspetuck at Easton, Conn., Who had won the title (three straight times, was elim inated from the Metropolitan amateur golf championship to day when he was beaten on the 20th hole in the third round by James Ulozas of the Tamarack (N. J.) G. C.

title: 2 From City Killed Upstate
description: WHITEHALL, N.Y., July 31 (AP)Two New York City men were killed today when their car turned over on Route 22, crashed through bridge railings and slid 180 feet into Lake Champlain, according to the state police. The victims were identified as Frank M. Gnolfo, 22, of 6610 60th Place, Ridge wood, Queens the driver, and Gerard Stoecker, whose age and address were not available.

title: SOFTCOAL CONTRACT TO EXPIRE SEPT. 30
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The United Mine Workers of America has served formal notice on the nation's soft coal industry that it will term inate contracts for 80,000 miners Sept. 30 and that we intend to negotiate a very sub stantial wage increase.

title: The World
description: LONDON  A convenient clue to the state of mind of the British Labor party is the Establishment left  wing weekly, The New States man. It is edited by Rich ard Crossman, former Labor Cabinet member, vigorous opponent of British entry into the Common Market and professional iconoclast. He represents no one except himself, but he does give a flavor of the hothouse of politics at Westminster.

title: OncePopular Convertible Is a Victim of Progress
description: DETROIT, July 31  No more will that girl driver cross the golden prairie, with her hair blowing wildly in the wind. No more will the young lovers lean back in the car and take in the stars.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: When I read the excel lently written and objective article New School Com plements Old Armory Wall [July 18] my first reaction was Thank God. They left something standing. Then got to the point of Children Yes, Polo No. The implica tion is clear: This was gentleman's club, silkstock ing type, where the members rode horses, watched polo, danced until dawn and had no concern whether the pop ulace ate cake whatever.

title: E. Stroudsburg Names Bovel
23 Yachts Get Off Slowly In 390Mile Michigan Race
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., July 31 (AP)  Twentythree yachts got off to a slow start today in 3 to 4knot winds at the opening of the 390mile transSuperior sailboat race.

title: MONGOOSE TAKES EASTOFRYE SAIL
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 H. Franklin Bloomer Jr. sailed Mongoose to a Soling Class victory by 48 seconds and 80 yards on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club to day.

title: Music
description: As a woman musician, must say that it's rath er nice that the New York Philharmonic is hiring members of my sex these days. Since 1966, the Philharmonic has judged four women competent enough to be employed as permanent members of the ensemble, and a fifth will start this fall. think that's fine. But as a black woman musician, I'd like to ask a question:

title: J. E. McGinty Marries Sarah Myers
description: MAPLEWOOD N. J., July 31  Miss Sarah Elizabeth Myers was married here to day to John Edward McGinty. The Rev. Albert 0. Judd per formed the ceremony in St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: Mrs. Hart to Defend Jersey Golf Title
description: Many important tournaments, both junior and amateur, are on the golfing schedule for August.

title: Shore of Buffalo Victor In Lightning Class Sailing
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 31 (AP)  Bill Shore of the Buf falo Canoe Club won the World Lightning Class sailing cham pionships today despite a third place finish in the final race.

title: Eastern Kentucky Anger Rises As StripMining of Coal Grows
description: WHITESBURG, Ky., July 30 After a few relatively quiet years, the resistance to coal stripmining is growing again in the hills of eastern Kentucky as stripping itself grows  by almost 100 per cent in the last year.

title: Filipinos Stand Fast in Brooklyn
description: This is a big day for the Filipino community in the Navy Yard district of Brook lyn. For this is when families give up all other activities for the annual picnic of the Filipino Social Club of New York, held in Linden, N.J.

title: Presidents of 25 Airlines To Meet on Atlantic Fares
description: MONTREAL, July 31 The presidents of 25 airlines have been called to Montreal Tues day to try to unsnarl what airline officials say is one of the most bitter disputes over transAtlantic air fares in his tory.

title: Red Sox Triumph, 60
description: CHICAGO, July 31 (AP)  Jim Lonborg pitched nohit ball for 6 innings and Duane Jo sephson drove in four runs with a homer and a double as the Boston Red Sox ended the Chicago White Sox' sixgame winnig streak, 60 today.

title: Mrs. Linda L. Hurley Wed to R. L. Schmalz
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 31  Mrs. Linda Lovelock Hurley of Weston and Robert Leslie Schmalz of Westport were married here this after noon at the Ridgefield Com munity Center by Justice of the Peace Gordon Walsh.

title: Nasram Was the First
description: Nasram, in 1964, was the first Americanbred horse to win the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes at Ascot. How ell E. Jackson of Bull Run Stud, Middleburg, Va., is the breeder of Nasram, who was foaled in Kentucky. It was incorrectly stated in a dispatch from Ascot July 24 that Paul Mellon's Mill Reef was the first American bred horse to win the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE IS FIRST TO FINISH
description: COWES, Isle of Wight, July 31 (UPI)  American Eagle, sailed by Ted Turner and not rated good enough to make the United States team for the Admiral's Cup series, was the first to finish today in the 210 mile channel race.

title: Hawaii Park Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) Bryan Harry, a longtime for estry and conservation special ist, has been named superin tendent of Hawaii's Volcanoes National Park. The announce ment was made here by Sena tor Hiram L. Long, Republican of Hawaii.

title: Great selfinflicted desecrations of the soul
description: Men wondered whether real feel ings were ever put in rime or meter or any artificial arrangement of words. Some wondered whether real feelings belonged in words. When Othello became angry his lady won dered this way: I understand a fury in your words/But not the words. She might have said real feelings were put in a derangement of words. But she was suffocated, and the sub ject continued to excite theoretical interest until Freud explained that everyone is really devoted to say ing what he doesn't feel. Writers most of all. Of course some writers pre tend to say only what they feel, and other writers pretend to say nothing; but then they are saying they have nothing to say. In any case, old questions surrender to new questions.

title: Buster Keaton's FiveStar General
description: IN his introduction to Bus ter Keaton's The Gen eral, which will be shown on Channel 13 without interruptions (com mercial or public service) at 9 o'clock Tuesday night, Or son Welles, the program's host, conies right out and says it: The General is masterpiece. It's not a small masterpiece, or a minor mas terpiece, or a halfbaked mas terpiece, or a shallow master piece, or any of those other kinds of qualified master piece that all critics, includ ing myself, discover from time to time, and so label to indicate our admiratkm, without committing our selves to a position from there is proud exit.

title: SENATE SETS VOTE ON LOCKHEED BILL
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The Senate broke its impasse on legislation designed to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy by agreeing today to vote Monday on a Houseapproved bill that would guarantee $250million in loans to the company.

title: At Newport, the Costume Gala Was the Tradition of Elegance
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 31Mrs. John Nicholas Brown, a woman of command ing presence, formidable influence and blunt speech, said she wasn't a bit sur prised at the happy state of affairs here. The social season is booming.

title: Mailbox:
description: I find Prof. Simeon Berman's mathematical analysis [N. Y. Times July 25] of the maximum trajectory of Reggie Jackson's AllStar Game home run to be quite accurate in terms of a mathematical exercise. How ever, when it comes to the physical realities of the event, I'm afraid that the professor's analysis would have been better suited to the golf drives of Astronaut Alan Shepard on the moon.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Two years ago, Robert H. Kenmore, chairman of the Kenton Corporation read in a ParkeBernet catalog that the famous gallery planned to sell a 69carat diamond to the highest bidder. Seeking to enhance the image of one of Kenton's subsidiaries, Cartier, Inc., he called together Ken ton's top executives and its directors and obtained their approval to bid $1million and maybe a little more for the giant gem.

title: ENVOY TO GREECE RETURNS TO U.S.
description: ATHENS, July 31  The United States Ambassador, Henry J. Tasca, after a round of talks with leaders of Greece's militarybacked Gov ernment and its main political opponents, flew to Washington yesterday for crucial testimony before the House Foreign Af fairs Committee next Tuesday.

title: Headliners
description: While searching with some other children for a lost table tennis ball two weeks ago, nineyearold Kevin Dye, mentally retarded and epileptic, wandered into the woods on rugged Casper Mountain near his home in Wyoming and was lost. For 10 days hundreds of searchers tried to recover the child, catching sight of him on at least two occasions, only to lose him when he disappeared deeper into heavy timber crossed by cliffs and canyons. Finally, as hope for his survival was fading, the boy was found last Wednesday morning, lying beside a small stream in a ravine. Wary scaring him away, the man who found him approached carefully and said softly: Hi, Kevin. Do you want to go home? Do you want to see your parents? To each question Kevin, weak but otherwise well, answered quietly, Yes.

title: 1st Woman General Hailed On Retirement From Army
description: ANNISTON, Ala., July 31 (AP) The Army's first woman general, Brig. Gen. Elizabeth Hoisington, retired today in ceremonies at nearby Fort Mc Clellan.

title: You Ought to See What the Apaches Are Up To Now
description: WHITERIVER, Ariz.  Each spring, the White Mountain Apache Indian Tribe sets up a promotional booth at the Los Angeles Sportsmen's Vacation and Travel Show in an attempt to lure southern California vacationers to the Fort Apache Indian Reservation in east ern Arizona. A few people, evidently not sure the Indians have been subdued, invariably ask:

title: Mexican Leader's Trips Seek Voice of the People
description: SAYULITA, Mexico, July 31 On a hot beach in the Pacific coast village of Sayulita, Presi dent Luis Echeverria Alvarez stared out to sea as five student leaders denounced corruption and injustices in the state of Nayarit. The grayhaired Gov ernor of the state, Roberto Gmez Reyes, stood nervously beside the President until his turn cameto answer the charges.

title: Princeton Tennis Coach Is Retiring
description: PRINCETON, N. J.One of the most successful coaches in the history of Princeton University is retiring even though he claims his job has been getting easier.

title: L.I. TOWN MOVES TO CONTROL WASTE
description: MANHASSET, L. I., July 31 The problem of the dis posal of such solid wastes as newsprint, nonreturnable bottles and cans is consid ered by Supervisor Michael J, Tully Jr. as one of the main concerns facing the 234,000 residents of Nassau County's smallest town, North Hempstead.

title: ECOLOGIST SCORES ARMY ENGINEERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The former chairman of the envir onmental advisory board to the Army Corps of Engineers has accused the corps of failing to respond to the urgency of change to meet critical envi ronmental needs.

title: Some like them cooked
description: You don't have to be a vegetarian to love these recipes. Cooking changes lettuce and radishes radically. It turns lettuce greener along the veins and transmutes it from crisp to silky. It colors radishes pink and alters their tex ture to something like that of water chestnuts. Raw cauli flower, on the other hand, is a crunchy surprise when its flowerets are dipped in crioli, a garlic mayonnaise.

title: Trains Are Scheduled For GiantJet Game
description: Special trains to the New York GiantsNew York Jets football game in the Yale Bowl on Sunday, Aug. 22, will be run again this year by Penn Central from Grand Central Terminal.

title: PHILS BEAT CARDS IN 16TH INNING, 64
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (UPI) Bobby Pfeil, a pinchhitter, drew a walk with the bases loaded in the 16th inning to night to force In the winning run as the Philadelphia Phillies defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 54, in the longest National League game this year.

title: Say It Isn't So, Mr. resident A conservative looks at Mr. Nixon's record so far and asks, Is he one of us?
description: THE scene is the White House, May, 1969. The guest of honor is John G. Gorton, Prime Min ister of Australia. He stands in the receiving line next to the President, who himself introduces the guests, after they have been presented to him by the chief of protocol. It was my turn, but the lady just ahead of me had caught the special attention of Mr. Gorton, who ventured beyond the formal greeting and was speaking to her. Mr. Nixon, finding an unan ticipated second or two on his hands, leaned over and whispered to me, his eyes on the Prime Minister, He's one of us.

title: ILL WILE A LEGACY OF UGANDA STRIFE
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30 The intertribal fighting that broke out within the Ugandan Army in recent weeks has reportedly left many soldiers dead and a legacy of fear and ill will among members of two minority tribes.

title: The World
Art
description: ALTHOUGH a member of the perceptive minor ity of residents who know that New York is at its best in summer, I succumbed last week to pro fessional lures extended by the William A. Farnsworth Library and Art Museum and spent a day in and around Rockland, Maine, where it is located. The immediate at traction was the museum's Edward Hopper exhibition, which turned into the first half of a doubleheader when it wits pointed out after I ar rived that the Olson house, where the late Christina Ol son of Andrew Wyeth's Christina's World spent her life, was only 15 miles away and should be visited. As a result I saw not only an ex cellent Hopper show but what struck me (for special rea sons) as the best Wyeth show of the lately.

title: Press Ban in Tose Case Weighed by Higher Court
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., July 31 (UPI)  The State Supreme Court decided today to order a halt to a hearing on incompe tency charges against the Philadelphia Eagles owner, Leonard Tose, until it could decide whether the press should be admitted to the hearing.

title: The World
description: CAIRO  The gathering of Arab leaders in Libya late last week, in response to a virtual summons from the Libyan revo lutionary leader, 29yearold Col. Muammar elQadaffi, underlined the emergence of the oilrich but luxuryshunning Libyan re gime as the activist of the Arab world  contemptuous of the compromises, sloganeering and evasions of conventional Middle East politics.

title: DR. RALPH BOWN, 80, BELL LAB. OFFICIAL
description: MILLBURN, N. J., July 31 Dr. Ralph Bown, a retired vice president of Bell Telephone Laboratories, who was known for his research and advance ment of communications engi neering, died Thursday at the Hospital Center of the Oranges. He was 80 years old and lived at 85 Pine Street.

title: Jeremy Gibson, A Banker, Weds Nancy R. Luria
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., July 31 Miss Nancy Rebekah Luria, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Luria, was married here this afternoon to Jeremy George Gibson Allen, an as sistant treasurer of the Mor gan Guaranty Trust Company of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George .C. Allen of Lewe, England.

title: Woman in Safety Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Josephine P. O'Brien has beer appointed as the first woman safety inspector in the Department of Labor's new Oc cupational Safety and Health Administration

title: MARGARET FORSYTH, EXY.W.C.A. AIDE, 76
description: Margaret E Forsyth, who headed the foreign division of the Young Women's Christian Association from 1944 until her retirement in 1959, died Thurs day at her home, 56 Seventh Avenue. Her age was 76.

title: Rethinking the Squeeze
description: Under a prod from some of the nation's largest banks, Federal banking agencies are taking a new look at one of the oldest financing devices  the bankers' acceptance.

title: Miss Eva Kroyer Is Married To A. J. Mannion Jr., Lawyer
description: Miss Eva Kroyer, whose father, Haraldur Kroyer, is Iceland's Ambassador to Sweden, Finland and Aus tria, was married in Stock holm yesterday to Arthur J. Mannion Jr. of New York, associate general counsel of American Export Industries here. The ceremony was per formed in the Marie Bebad else Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Donald Dietz.

title: Van Nostrand, Sack Gain
description: MANHASSET, L.I., July 31 King Van Nostrand of Bright water, L.I., and Lester Sack Jr. of Clarksdale, Miss,, eliminated the two topseeded players to reach the final of the United States Men's 35years and over clay court tennis championships today at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club.

title: Spartan and Shaman Register Triumphs On Little Neck Bay
description: William Borst's Spartan won both races on corrected time in the first cruising division and David Knickerbocker's Shaman swept a pair in the second han dicap division as Bayside Yacht Club opende its 33d regatta on Little Neck Bay yesterday.

title: Space
description: HOUSTON  Yesterday two solitary men, sealed into space suits and riding an oddlooking vehicle, began exploring what may be a reasonable facsimile of the earth in its earliest infancy, before it began the internal convulsions that changed its face and released the gases that became our atmosphere.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE portable hand vacu um cleaner illustrated at right is designed to work on either of two different voltages12 volts or 110 volts. Thus, in the home it can be plugged into a standard household outlet; in the family automobile, (or boat, mobile home or camp er) it can be plugged into a 12  volt cigarette lighter outlet. Equipped with a long cord and a standard plug that will fit conventional h6me outlets, this dualvoltage vacuum converts to 12volt use by simply plugging into a special adapter and then plugging this adapter into a standard automobile ciga rette lighter receptacle.

title: Youths in Chinatown Open Health Fair
description: Youths in Chinatown opened a health fair yesterday to bring the examining room into the community and to show their elders that they are socially responsible.

title: Expert Observers on the Earth Share Moon Explorers' Glimpses Into the Past
description: HOUSTON, July 31No oth er geological survey in history has as many expert partici pants as the one that ranged across an extraordinarily com plex and diverse region of the moon today.

title: Urban League Is Shifting Its Emphasis
description: DETROIT, July 29The Ur ban League, said James A. Mack, a black delegate to the organization's annual confer ence held here this week, has moved from the business of being a recruiting, screening and selecting agency for white firms looking for the good nigger.

title: McGovern Cites Advice To Ellsberg on Papers
description: Senator George Mc Govern says it was he who suggested that Daniel Ells berg make the Pentagon papers available to a re spectable newspaper.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: The skirtlength dilemma is still unresolved on Seventh Avenue and manufacturers arc probing, observing and questioning consumer reac tion to get an accurate read ing of what is going to sell in the coming months.

title: Canadians Retain Laurels In Rowing Championships
description: LUNENBURG, Nova Scotia, July 31 (AP)Canadian teams successfully defended their dory rowing championships at the Nova. Scotia fisheries ex hibition yesterday by turning back teams from Gloucester, Mass.

title: Elaine Hansen Is Wed
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., July 31 Miss Elaine Leslie Hansen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Axel Hansen of Locust Valley, and Stephen Wright Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Wright Johnson of Sauquoit, N. Y., were mar ried this afternoon in St. John's of Lattingtown Epis copal Church by the Rev. Graham ButlerNixon, the curate. The couple are gradu ates of Cornell.

title: Discipline Begets Real Freedom
description: BLOOD, SWEAT & TEARS: B, S & T 4 (Columbia). Does corn mercial success end hand's creative contribution to music? Sometimes yes. In the case of Blood, Sweat & Tears, emphatically no. Yet the selfappointed guardians of hip, who cheered B, S & T's coupling of a rockstyle rhythm section with a jazz oriented horn section in 1967, jeered two years later when the public turned Spinning Wheel into the first of many million sellers. Ignoring the underground clamor for noise and flash, the ninemember band has continued to map out their own territory, a territory where musicianship alone counts.

title: Townsend's 270 Takes Swiss Open by Stroke
description: CRANS  SUR  SIERRE, Switzerland, July 31 (UPI) Peter Townsend of Britain rallied from two strokes be hind with a finalround 70 today to win the $24,000 Swiss open golf champion ship by a stroke.

title: Alicia Silva Jersey Bride
description: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N. J., July 31Miss Alicia Silva and Daniel Goodhue Ritchie were married here this afternoon in Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Thomas Norton.

title: Atoms Win Junior Track; Miss Tummings Sets Marks
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 31 Led by 17yearold Lorraine Tummings, the Atoms Track of Brooklyn won the junior na tional women's track and field title today at the A. I. du Pont High School field.

title: Judge Supported on Prostitution
description: A Criminal Court judge who three weeks ago held without bail two women accused of prostitution and startled the courtroom with an angry out burst, asserting that prostitu tion was spreading a plague of venereal disease and crime in the city, has been inundated with congratulatory mail and telephone calls.

title: Announcements
Angels Top Lolich in 12th
description: DETROIT, July 31 (UPI) Gerry Moses's runscoring double with two out in the 12th inning today voided a 14 strikeout performance by Mickey Lolich of Detroit and gave the California Angels 32 victory over the Tigers.

title: Senator Buckley Warns Nixon on Support by Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON, July 31  Senator James L. Buckley warned today that the suspen sion of support of the Nixon Administration by leading con servatives had serious impli cations for the President's re election chances next year.

title: AROUND THE
description: Last call to apply fertilizer to evergreens; new growth must harden well before cold weather.... Divide daylilies and iris.... Sevin, malathion or diazinon will control earwigs; spray outdoor areas around the house.... Do not prune now.

title: McCarthy Asks Recognition Of Independent East Bengal
