description: LONDON, July 31  Eugene McCarthy declared support to day for an independent state of Bangla Desh and reproved the United States Government for being unresponsive to the urgency of the Pakistan crisis.

title: Mrs. Cornwallis Returns $8.40 in Florida Triumph
description: MIAMI, July 31 (AP)Mrs. Cornwallis, who upset Cute Sketch in the Santa Rosa Stakes two weeks ago, repeated the performance today in the $7,500 added Roman Brother Stakes at Calder Race Course.

title: I.O.S. Revisited
description: PARISOne by one they are fading out of the picture after a dazzling decade of financial pyrotechnics.

title: Letters
description: Permit me to add, as modest expansion of Sol Stern's article on Angela Davis (The Campaign to Free An gela Davis ... and Ruchell Magee, June 27)if the case must be thrashed out, while it still is sub judicethe follow ing series of questions and answers:

title: Sonny Says Quick Wins Rackette and Pays $3.20
description: SALEM, N. H., July 31 (AP) Peter Fuller's Sonny Says Quick justified her 3to5 odds by romping to a fivelength victory today in the $10,975 Rockette Stakes at Rockingham Park.

title: RAMS TOP OILERS IN FAME CONTEST
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 31Los Angeles beat Houston, 176, to day in the annual Pro Football Flail of Fame preseason game that marked the competitive start for two new head coaches, Tom Prothro of the Rams and Ed Hughes of the Oilers. The contest was played in Fawcett Stadium next to the Hall of Fame before a capacity crowd of 19,384.

title: ROWE AND MULLEN YACHTING VICTORS
Navy Man Weds Kathleen Hageman
description: HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 Miss Kathleen Anne Hage man was married this after noon to Petty Officer 3/C Stuart Russell Hancock Jr., U.S.N. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the cer emony in the Rye Presbyte rian Church.

title: Bomb Explodes in London At Trade Minister's Home
description: LONDON, July 31A bomb exploded today at the London apartment of John Davies, Min ister for Trade and Industry.

title: Governor Announces a Fall Conference on Alcoholism
description: Governor Rocicetener an nounced yesterday that he would convene a statewide conference this fall to call at tention to the seriousness of the problem of alcoholism.

title: Stewart Stays at Pole Today For German Grand Prix
description: ADENAU, Germany, July 31 (AP)Jackie Stewart of Scot land stayed twotenths of a second ahead of Jacky Ickx of Belgium today and won the pole position for the German, the Formula One race will be run tomorrow over the 14,2 mile Nuerburgring circuit.

title: On the Mound: It's Superman Broberg!
description: Pete Broberg, the Washing ton Senator's rookie right hander, warms up with a Superman Tshirt under his uniform and believes that he is pitching in Fantasyland.

title: Giants Outlast Pirates, 1511, as Kingman's Grand Slam Keys 7Run Seventh
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 31 (AP)  Dave Kingman's grand slam home run and Bobby Bonds's tworun double marked a sevenrun seventh inning that earned the San Francisco Giants a 15.11 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today. Willie Stargell of Pittsburgh hit two home runs and drove in five runs.

title: Gol. Troubles
description: PARISIt's not whether it would happen, but when. This was the way many Euro pean authorities were talking about devaluation of the dollar.

title: A deft jumble of cultural correlatives
description: Extraterritorial Papers on Literature and the Language Revolution. By George Steiner. 210 pp. New York: Atheneum. $7.95.If critics were to be turned into parlor games, George Steiner would be Monopoly. I don't intend this to be an unkind comment, because I enjoy the game. Unlike Steiner, how ever, I'm inclined neither to confuse a game with reality nor chess with Monopoly. When he asks what else exists in the world besides chess? he has already rather startlingly as sociated himself with Lenin, of all people, and dizzied himself with the possibility of 318,979,584,000 moves. Moreover, he has also connected chess with Nabokov's art, and sug gested an analogy between chess combinations and the disinterested combinatorial fertility of linguistic universals as described by Noam Chomsky and Ludwig Wittgenstein. Such an onthespot virtuoso accumu lation is Monopoly, in which symbols of property and construction fully engross winning players without real ly tying them down. The better and luckier the player, the more the rules seem to favor him. Steiner is a bill liant gamesman whose career and many rolls of the dice have finally won him control of the board, a posi tion he calls the language revolution.

title: Mailbox:
description: I read with interest the letter of Richard Korn in last Sun day's Times. It is similar to a number of letters which I re ceived myself.

title: The Frank Sharp Affairs: Vast Scandal Stuns Democrats in Texas
description: HOUSTON, July .31 Reper cussions from the collapse of a $100million insurance and banking venture promoted by Frank W. Sharp, a Houston real estate developer, have bad ly shaken the Democratic party of Texas.

title: 20 Million Italians Take to the Roads For August Holiday
description: ROME, July 31Nearly 20 million Italians began their an nual summer holiday exodus today.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Persistence of unemploy ment is probably slightly more painful to the newly jobless than inflation psy chology is to the planners. (July 11, Washington Report.)

title: PEKING REVIVING INTEREST IN PAST
description: HONG KONG, July 31Pe king has reported a series of important new archeological discoveries in an article signal ing a resurgence of official in terest in China's heritage.

title: Anne Daly and Paul Barabas Married
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., July 31Miss Anne Christine Daly and Paul Andrew Barabas were married here at noon today.

title: Speirs, N.Y.U. Track Star, Will Join Rutgers Next Fall
description: Ron Speirs of Paramus, N. J., a promising prospect in the mile run, has announced that he will transfer to Rutgers University next fall.

title: Lawyer to Wed Susan K. Lins, 1966 Debutante
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Lins of New York and Buck Hill Falls, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Kings bury Lins, to W. Newton Jackson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson Jr. of Salisbury, Md.

title: Michel SaintDenis, Director and Producer, Dies
description: LONDON, July 31 (AP) Michel SaintDenis, the French born director of the Royal Shakespeare Theater in Strat ford and an influential producer in both England and France, died here today at the age of 74.

title: YOUTHS PLANNING A PEOPLE'S PARK
description: Equipped with shovels, rakes and brooms, 50 young people in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn took over a large va cant lot yesterday and, with businesslike efficiency, proceed ed with a plan to build a peo ple's park for neighborhood residents.

title: How Would You Like to Buy, Sight Unseen, an Antique Stone Cottage in Lower Slaughter, Which Is Near Upper Swell, and Get to Know the Ironmonger and the Dustman by Their First Names (Alf and Jim), Oh, Wouldn't It Be Loverly?
description: LOWER SLAUGHTER, England  At the end of another frustrating trip to Wales in pursuit of a big hen salmon several springtimes ago, my wife and I awarded ourselves a consolation prize by taking a leisurely potluck drive through the English Cots wolds. As things turned out, we ac quired something more than memories.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONHell, no, we won't go, they sayand around the nation the last few years the number of young men ac tively resisting the draft has been steadily increasing. So it was that, when Congress failed to extend the Draft Law by the deadline of June 30, many ex pected that the draft resistance movement would mushroom, that expiration of the President's authority to induct would inspire large numbers of young people to refuse to register.

title: Child to the L. H. Roths
description: A daughter was born here on June 18 to Dr. and Mrs. Laurence Roth of Hartsdale, N. Y., in Doctors Hospital. Mrs. Roth is the former Miss Rona Teitelbaum. The child, whose father is a dentist, has been named Amy Karen.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONIt is astonishing what an extraordinary influence on interna tional affairs sparsely populated and backward Libya has had during the past month. It has successively inter vened in Morocco (where it endorsed an aborted coup d'etat against the King), in Malta (where it is encour aging the Mintoff Government to squeeze out NATO), and Sudan (where it did everything possible to help Premier Gaafar alNimeiry oust a pro Communist putsch and launch an antiMarxist purge).

title: Behind bars: A Goad Time of theater
description: playwright

title: Embryo Transplant Between Two Cows Brings Healthy Calf
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. July 31 (AP)A healthy heifer calf has been produced through surgical transplant of an embryo from one cow to another on a Ma rietta, Okla., ranch, The Kansas City Star said in its Sunday issue.

title: Blue Cross to Begin Testing Outpatient Coverage in Dayton Area
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 31 Blue Cross of Southwestern Ohio has agreed to grant the same reimbursement for out patients at Kettering Memorial Hospital here as it would for hospitalized patients, effective tomorrow.

title: Alarm Concern Accused of Fraud Fails
description: A $3million burglar alarm concern that local, state and Federal consumer agencies have investigated for allegedly deceptive selling practices went into bankruptcy last week, just as the license of the company, Vigilant Protective Systems, was being revoked by the city's Department of Consumer Af fairs.

title: Race Bias Laid to Guard In Brooklyn Armory Plan
description: The leader of a black veterans' group has accused New York State of attempt ing to limit the number of blacks and Puerto Ricans in the National Guard by closing the Sumner Avenue Armory in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn this fall.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Down in New Jersey and Pennsylvania they're running stockcar events that might be called satellite races. The ?? is to run a big race with a sizable purse at a well known track, the competitors being drivers who have quali fied by winning races at smaller tracks. One of the on Aug. 22. It will be run for a purse of $25,000 plus manu facturers' accessory awards over Trenton's 1mile kid neyshaped course. more interesting of these is the annual Trenton 200 for modified and latemodel sportsman cars on Aug. 22. It will be run for a purse of $25,000 plus manu facturers' accessory awards over Trenton's 1mile kid neyshaped course.

title: Even pure science isn't pure
description: In the summer of 1931 a group of Soviet scholars journeyed from Moscow to London in order to par ticipate in an international congress on the history of science and technology. Headed by the attractive and brilliant Nikolai Bukharin, and composed of scientists, philosophers, engineers, government administrators, and economists, the group pre sented a series of papers which exercised a re markable, although frequently unacknowledged, influence among Western scientists and historians of science, especially in Great Britain.

title: August
description: So it's August, practically the midmark of summer by the calendar, almost halfway from the solstice to the equinox. Early goldenrod is in blossom and the first asters are showing white. The sun doesn't rise till after 5:30 now and the day's dimensions have noticeably changed. You see it in the shift in the noonday shadows.

title: South Bay Sailing Off
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., July 31  The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's first day of race week was postponed to day because of high seas whipped by a brisk spanky southwester.

title: Ramirez, Martin Win
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 31 (UPI)Raul Ramirez of Ense nada, Mexico, and Billy Martin of River Forest, Ill., won singles titles and shared doubles crowns today in the Western junior and boys tennis championships.

title: Twins' Parking Lot Is a Haven for 10,000 Campers
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 31For more than 10,000 people from about 20 states and three Canadian provinces, home this week end is the concrete parking lot at Metropolitan Stadium.

title: UNE DE MAI TAKES FRENCH TROT EASILY
description: ENGHIEN  LES  BAINS, France, July 31Une de Mai kept in shape for the Roosevelt International Trot, a race her trainer still thinks the French mare will contest, by spotting 14 horses handicaps today and winning easily.

title: Browns, Rams in Deal
description: CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) Joe Taffoni, an offensive tackle who was miffed at being de moted to the Cleveland Browns second unit, was traded to the Los Angeles Rams today.

title: Two for the price of onea theory of history, a defense of policy
description: W. W. Rostow has led a double life. He is widely known as an eco nomic historianin particular as the author of The Stages of Economic Growth, a view of economic evolu tion that provoked considerable con troversy among his professional col leagues when it appeared 12 years ago. He has also been a counselor of state, generally credited with a major role in shaping the foreign policy of the Johnson Administration. In this book, both Rostows speak. The economic historian expands his view of history as a stagelike devel opmental process; the counselor of state provides us with a general rationale for the policies he has so persuasively advanced.

title: Letters
description: We rush to the defense of Simone de Beauvoir's good taste and refined sensuality in her appreciation of younger men (Europe's First Feminist Has Changed the Second Sex, by Curtis Cate, July 11). What, precisely, do young men have? Fine strong bodies, uninlrebited sexuality, exuberance, willingness to ex periment, a sense of adven ture, boyish charm, emotional freshness free of the stifling layers of defensiveness that come with age and the quest for power, andmiracle of miraclesinfinite potency.

title: Joe Cesare Colombo, a Designer Of Furniture and Interiors, Dies
description: ROME, July 31  Joe Co lombo, a leading figure in Ital ian design, died last night of a heart attack in his home in Milan at the age of 41.

title: Stamps
description: PRINCE BERNHARD of the Netherlands, hus band of Queen Juli ana, was 60 years old on June 29. The Netherlands issued four stamps and an air letter sheet to commem orate the event, and Surinam and the Netherlands Antilles each issued a single stamp, adapted from a portrait ad hesive in the Netherlands se ries. This design pictures the Prince and a facsimile signa ture, against a background of the globe, the new Indus tries Fair Building at Utrecht, a blast furnace at Ijmuiden, and two airplanesa Fokker Friendship F27 and a Boeing 747B. The Netherlands and the Surinam stamps were of 25c denominations, the An tilles stamp, 45c.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ROCHESTER, Minn., July 31 (AP)Bart Starr, the Green Bay Packers quarterback, will re main in St. Marys Hospital for several more days, a spokes man for the Mayo Clinic said today.

title: School Gets Guilt Money
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31 (UPI) The Board of Education has received three checks totaling $100 from an unknown donor who mailed them to the Eshel man Avenue School, saying that the money shoidd he used for repairs. School officials he hove that he was probably in volved in vandalism at the school at one time and is send ing the money to salve his con science. They assume that he is a G.I. in West Germany, be cause the money is mailed from there in the form of armed ser ices money orders.

title: Scott in Benefit Match
description: Gene Scott, the former Davis Cup player, will meet George (Butch) Seewagen, the Colum bia coach and former national amateur champion, in a tennis match on Sunday, Aug. 22, for the benefit of the Columbia team. Tickets for the match at Baker Field are $10, $25 and $50. The receipts will be used to purchase a station wagon for the team to travel.

title: For More Commuters Here, Easy Riding's a Motorbike
description: A small but growing num ber of New York City coin muters have traded their subway tokens and railroad tickets for a pair of goggles and a helmet. They are Man hattan's version of the easy rider, the button  down, briefcasetoting devotees of the motorcycle.

title: Miss Cumming Will Be Bride
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 31The engagement of Miss Lynne Alison Cumming to Keith Thomas Darcy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Darcy, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton K. Cumming. Both families reside in Bronxville.

title: A Bond Boom in Memphis
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn.  Down in Olive Branch, Miss., a farming town 16 miles south east of here, bond salesmen work in a converted auc tion barn, peddling tax exempt bonds over the tele phone under the direction of a 23yearold, while back ground music plays Feelin' Groovy. Twentydollar bills Scotchtaped to a blackboard act as cash incentives.

title: Amateur Baseball Slated
description: Detroit will defend its cham pionship when the 27th annual AllAmerican Amateur Baseball Association's limited division tournament opens Aug. 28 in Johnstown, Pa.

title: SUIT ATTACKS TEST TO GROUP PUPILS
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., July 31 A suit filed this week against Aiken County schools attacks the use of ability grouping for classroom assignments in de segregated schools.

title: Indians Bow to A's, 91, and Suspend McDowell for Not Reporting for Game
description: CLEVELAND, July 31 (UPI) Rick Monday drove in three runs with two homers and Gene Tenace connected with a man on to help Chuck Dobson notch his 10th victory today as the Oakland Athletics snapped a fourgame losing streak by defeating the Cleveland Indians, 91.

title: Suspect Wounded by Police In Holdup at Change Booth
description: A 20yearold man was shot and wounded by Transit Au thority policemen when he at tempted to rob a change booth at the Tremont Avenue station of the IND line in the Bronx, the Transit Authority reported.

title: Movies
description: COMERCIAL American movies are at last beginning to talk about sex with pertinent and re freshing candor. But although they are outspoken, most of the new movies are less revolutionary than they look. Traditional puritanical attitudes are often concealed beneath the kinky contemporary trappings, still dictating rewards and punishments for the char acters. Only the language of the ser mons has changed; now they are phrased in the uptodate psychoanalyt ic lingo that the permissive society understands.

title: The Captive City
description: Senator Edward Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts, has formed a National Citizens Committee to arouse support around the country in behalf of democratic selfgovernment for the city of Washington. For nearly a century, the nation's capital has been deprived of home rule. A small breakthrough a few years ago pro duced an elected school board, but all other municipal affairs are controlled by a Mayor and City Council appointed by the President and tightly supervised by committees of Congress.

title: $24MILLION. ESTATE GOES FOR EDUCATION
description: NORWALK, Conn., July 31 A preliminary inventory of the estate of Richard Prentice Et tinger indicates a gross of more than $24million, according to records filed with the Probate Court here.

title: Van Nostrand Heads Draw In Tamiment Tennis Aug12
description: King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, L. I., heads the seeded list for the fifth annual Tami ment invitation tennis tourna ment starting Aug. 12 at the Pocono resort. The event, a fix Vire on the Middle States Lawn Tennis Association schedule, at tracts many Eastern players.

title: WILT TO PLAY AGAIN IN STOKES BENEFIT
description: Wilt Chamberlain of the Los Angeles Lakers, basketball's leading career scorer, has ac cepted an invitation to partici pate in the Maurice Stokes Me morial benefit game Aug. 17 at Kutsher's Country Club in Mon ticello, N.Y.

title: TWINS TOPPLE YANKEES, 54;
description: In a glorious burst of illog ical irrelevancy, the New York Mets celebrated the 20th anniversary of Bobby Thomson's famous home run as part of their annual Old Timers' Day at Shea Stadium yesterday  and Thomson traded places with his fa mous victim, Ralph Branca, who promptly hit a long fly ball to center field, where Cal Abrams caught it. And everybody had a marvelous time.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Benjamin Pogrund joined The Rand Daily Mail of Johannes burg in the early 1960's as a re porter on African affairs, a dif ficult assignment for a white writer in South Africa, and wrote two series of articles with wide impact. The first described malnutrition in African rural communities, the second church attitudes on race relations. In 1968 a series charging that three South African prisons were rid dled with brutality got him into trouble. After an eightanda halfmonth trial, Mr. Pogrund and his editor, Laurence Gan der, were convicted of publish ing the articles without check ing the facts with the authori ties; both were given nominal fines. Mr. Gander said after the trial. I have never had any doubt that [the] articles were accurate.

title: Johnson Wins Shields Class In Cow Bay Area Yachting
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 31Harold Johnson cap tured Shields Class honors this afternoon in the Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition.

title: Harry Rodgers: The Little Man Who Stands Tall in U.S. Soccer
description: Robert Henry (Harry) Rod gers, as tiny as Willie Shoe maker, but with hair as white as snow and 68 years on his shoulders, has controlled, soccer games as a player and referee for 43 years. But when he received the highest soccer award here recently, he couldn't control his tears.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, India, July 31 (AP)India held a narrow lead over Rumania in the doubles of the interzone Davis Cup tennis semifinals today when play was stopped because of darkness.

title: 1976 Bicentennial Group Is Planning a Varied, YearLong Celebration for Entire Nation
description: The planners of the nation's 1976 bicentennial celebration are putting together an ambi tious agenda designed to en courage local communities and foreign countries to participate in the event.

title: Kennedy and Mashie Share Lead In a Gallup Survey of Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Senators Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Edmund S. Muskie of Maine share the lead in a field of 13 potential Democratic Presidential candi dates, according to the latest Gallup poll.

title: Margot Finn Wed To Robert Wycoff
description: WOLF CREEK, Ore., July 31Miss Margot Harriet Finn and Robert Darrell Wycoff were married here this morn ing at Forgotton Works, a commune, by the Rev. John Gregg of the Universal Life Church.

title: The World
description: DACCA, Pakistan  The Government's army is largely confined to the towns and roads. The guerrilla rebels in the countryside get help from across the border. A clandes tine radio transmitter reports liberation army successes and predicts eventual victory.

title: Announcements
description: Births

title: Miss Jayne M. Kurzman Is Married
description: Miss Jayne Martha Kurz man and Frank A. Rykowski Jr., who were graduated from the Harvard Law School in June, were maried here last evening by the Rev. Henry A. Zinzer at St. Thomas Episco pal Church.

title: LETTERS
description: As an expert in economics and manpower development, Mr. Cohn (June 20) ought to know that the current short age of goodpaying jobs is probably the most important reason that the JOBS pro gram has failed to reach its goals.

title: HIGH RESEARCH COST LINKED TO U.S. FUNDS
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 31 (AP)Massive Federal invest ments in defense and space exploration research of a decade ago have led to inflated research costs for private in dustry, two Massachusetts In stitute of Technology officials contend in the current issue of Technology Keview.

title: QueensMidtown Express Bus Set
description: Encouraged by the suc cess of two earlier express bus services, the Transit Authority will begin a new express line tomorrow be tween Hillside Avenue and 267th Street in eastern Queens and midtown Man hattan at 7 A.M.

title: George Jackson Radicalizes the Brothers in Soledad an San Quentin
description: After Tad Szulc's prison conversation with George Jackson in April, he submitted four additional questions to Jackson through one of the lawyers in the case. The questions were these: (1) Aren't any black people guilty of crimes in American society? (2) Aren't any of them criminalsfor example, a black man who rapes or murders a black woman? (3) What about a black man who guns down a Black Panther? (4) Are you really saying that all criminals are victims of society?

title: Doberman Captures First Major Award At Barrington Show
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., July 31 A 3yearold black and tan homebred Doberman pinscher, Ch. Aventine's Tamiko, owned by Frank and Eleanor D'Arnica of Glen Cove, L. I., took her first bestinshow award today at the 61st annual all breed dog show and obedience trials of the Providence County Ken nel Club. The event drew 959 dogs.

title: Timothy T. Scores In Realization Trot; Gunner Is Second
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 Victory in the $101,469 Reali zation Trot at Roosevelt Race way tonight went to Timothy T., a horse that never had cov ered the 1 1/16mile distance, and to John Simpson Jr., a 28yearold who had never driven in that long a race.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: U.S. MONETARY RESERVES fell $307million In June to $13,504,000,000. Gold stocks in June fell by $61million to $10,507,000,000. Taking into account the priority claims against U.S. gold by the International Monetary Fund, the net gold holdings were $9,979,000,000, the lowest level since 1938. . . . The Government reported that the Federal budget for the fiscal year ended June 30 showed a near record deficit of $23.2billion. The figure, although not a surprise, was more than $4billion higher than estimated as recently as January.

title: Long Line of Linemen
description: The Penn football captain, John Curley of State College, Pa., is the 11th straight lineman to lead the Red and Blue. Cur ley is an offensive tackle.

title: Jacques Gains His 6th Title In FreeStyle Roller Skating
description: LINCOLN, Neb., July 31 (AP) For the sixth consecutive time, Michael Jacques of Nor wood, Mass., captured the United States men's freestyle roller skating title last night.

title: Flushing Plans a Lunch For Gertrude Ederle
description: The Flushing, Queens, Chamber of Commerce will honor Gertrude Ederle at luncheon Wednesday to com memorate the 45th anniver sary of her historic swim across the English Channel, the first woman to have done so.

title: Sweater game
description: The fashion action this fall revolves around the comeback of the classics. In sweaters, its a fast breakaway from the effete shrunken knits. Swinging back for another slam success are the boxy cardigan, the twin sweater set, and patterned vests worn over a monotone sweater.

title: Aaron's 622d Decides
description: SAN DIEGO, July 31 (UPI) Henry Aaron smashed his 30th homer of the year and 622d of his career tonight in the eighth with none on and two out to snap a 22 tie and give the At lanta Braves a 32 triumph over the San Diego Padres.

title: Pamela. Snyder, R. B. Galloway Plan Nuptials
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 31Mr. and Mrs. Edward Philip Snyder Jr. of South port and Stratton Mountain, Vt., have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Lyndon Snyder, to. Richard. Bruce Galloway of Denver. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Richard Galloway of White Bear Lake, Minn.

title: RUN THE GANTLET FIRST AT AQUEDUCT
description: Run the Gantlet of the Rokeby Stable ran over older opposition to win the $61,500 Tidal Handi cap, the closingday feature at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Jetties Give Fire Island Village Erosion Shield
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Is land, July 31This village, the largest community on this thin sandy strip off Long Island's South Shore, today celebrated the 50th anniver sary of its incorporation, a mark many residents feared might never be reached be cause of the constant ravages of man and nature.

title: Patriots Acquire Thomas, Cowboy Holdout
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 31The New England Patriots com pleted a trade with Dallas here early today that brought them Duane Thomas, an angry hold out but an excellent running back. In exchange, the Cow boys received the Patriots' first draft choice in 1972.

title: Bay State Rejects Use Of Road Tax for Transit
description: BOSTON, July 31 (AP) The legislature has rejected a proposed amendment to the state Constitution that would permit highway fund revenue to be used for mass trans portation.

title: Miss Sandford Is Wed in Jersey To Harry Emanuel Morgan Jr.
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., July 31 Miss Catherine Sandford and Harry Emanuel Morgan Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Crescent Ave nue Presbyterian Church by, the Rev. Charles L. Mead.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Vice Presi dent Agnew, theorized conserva tive columnist James J. Kilpat rick the other day, is a sort of Mount Everest to liberals. They like to criticize him because he is there. But as Mr. Agnew returned home last week from a 32day goodwill tour around the world, the wonder in Wash ington was how much longer he would in fact be therea heart beat away from the Presidency.

title: DR, ELI S. JONES
description: HAMMOND, Ind., July 31  Dr. Eli Sherman Jones, former chief of surgery at St. Marga ret's Hospital and a former president of the Industrial Med ical Association, died yester day. His age was 82.

title: Put It Back! Recycle!
description: ANYONE who cares about the en vironment is already recycling bottles, aluminum cans and the Sunday newspaper. Now it's time for the conscientious gardener to take stock of the myriad ways he can apply the principle of recycling while tend ing to his chores.

title: Fewer Americans Are Traveling Abroad This Year, but European Tourists Are Taking Up the Slack
description: PARIS, July 31  Although you can't tell it by the preva lence of American accenis around Trafalgar Square, Place de l'Opra or the Spanish Steps, there are fewer American tour ists in Europe this year than last.

title: Technicians Reported Out
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 31  ProWestern informants here reported today that a group of Soviet technicians had been forced to abandon a milk processing plant they had been running at Babanusa, in Kordo fan Province southwest of here.

title: U.N. TO SEND TEAM TO EAST PAKISTAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 31The United States, working behind the scenes, has won the agree ment of both Pakistan and the United Nations to station an international group of 153 civil ian relief and rehabilitation experts in East Pakistan under United Nations sponsorship, officials said today.

title: DR. ELMER NAGY, OPERA DIRECTOR
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., July 31Dr. Elemer Nagy, an internationally known opera and stage directordesigner, died of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: DWIERS DOG BEST OF 1,000 ENTRIES
description: SCRANTON, Pa., July 31 Ch. Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, a German shepherd awned by Daniel P. Dwier of Kresson, N. J., and handled by Kim Knoblouch, was the choice of Mrs. Dorothy L. Cass for best in show at the 42nd annual show of the Lackawanna Ken nel Club today at Daleville, Pa.

title: Harris, Defensive End, Voted Best of AllStars
description: CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) Richard Harris, a 265pound defensive end from Grambling, carried the highest honors to day as he and his AllStar buddies returned to pro foot ball training camps.

title: DODGERS BEAT REDS ON 4RUN EIGHTH, 41
description: LOS ANGELES, July 31 (UPI) Steve Garvey, just off the disabled list, collected three hits, including a key double in Los Angeles's fourrun eighth inning, tonight as the Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds, 41.

title: Bold Reason Wins American Derby, With Mr. Pow Wow 2d by a HalfLength
description: CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) William A. Levin's Bold Reason, packing top weight of 124 pounds including his jockey, Laffit Pincay, registered his fifth straight victory today by winning the $138,200 American Derby by onehalf length from Mr. Pow Wow at Arlington Park.

title: Weather Proves No Friend
description: FRIENDSHIP, Me., July 31 (AP)About 50 sloops left fog shrouded Friednship Harbor to day, leaving behind the un awarded 1971 Friendship Sloop Race Trophy. For the first time in its 11year history, the annual evet was canceled be cause of bad weather on all three days.

title: East Germany Publishes Offer For Better Ties With West Berlin
description: BERLIN, July 31East Ger many has proposed a separate settlement to West Berlin, with guarantees of access, long or frequent visits to East Ger many, and even minor adjust ments of the boundary that has enclosed West Berliners more than a hundred miles inside East German territory since 1961.

title: Music Mailbag
description: Perhaps Harold Schon berg's suggestions in Rec ipes to Spice Up That Diet at the Met may lead Goeran Gentele to a rediscovery of Samuel Barber's opera, Van essa. Gentele might be in terested in the fact that all of the members of the Met's 1958 production of Van essa are still on the Met's roster, with the exception of Eleanor Steber. That opera, though 20th century in its composition, is very much Romantic in its musical na ture. Even if Miss Steber could not perform the role of Vanessa today, as she did on the only recording of the op era (and it's out of print), surely the Met could supply an equally convincing Van essa (Leontyne Price, may be?)

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: 16th Proprietor of Gardiners Island Conducts Visitors on a Bouncy Tour
description: GARDINERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 31  The 16th Lord of the Manor, tightly encased in a white jump suit, waved a plastic glass filled with Rhine wine toward a pegged plank in an ancient windmill and exclaimed:

title: Survey Shows Church Aid to Housing
description: More than 150 of the city's churches and synagogues are spending nearly $300,000 a year in support of lowincome and moderateincome housing in the five boroughs, according to a survey prepared by the depart ment of church planning and research of the Council of Churches of the City of New York.

title: Shivar Gains Tennis Final
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. July 31 (AP)Walker Shivar gained the final of the 26th annual Long's Peninsula Inviitational tennis tournament tonight by eliminating Steve Beland of Winter Haven, Fla., 67, 62, 62.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Analysts and investors scan everything from tea leaves to pointandfigure charts in their appraisal of stockmar ket indicators.

title: Wilson's Powerboat Scores
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 31 (AP) Willard Wilson drove his Lil' Lectron hydroplane to victory today in the 145 class of the powerboat championships. Perry Walter of New Canaan, Conn., won the 7litae class with Miss Jersey.

title: ReformMinded Doctor to Join MinePension Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 31Dr. Paul B. Comely, a former pres ident of the American Public Health Association, who is a widely known advocate of med ical reform, has accepted a high position with the United Mine Workers Welfare and Retire ment Fund, Inc., the fund said today.

title: City to Pay to Fix Houses Damaged In Queens Digging
description: The city has decided to pay for damage to homes in Forest Hills, Queens, that resulted from caveins during a sewer digging project.

title: Coins
description: A NEW public area, de signed for the pleas ure and convenience of visitors touring the Denver Mint, was opened re cently. Mrs. Mary T. Brooks, Director of the Bureau of the Mint, and Gov. John Love of Colorado officiated at the ceremony, which was attend ed by numismatists from many states. The remodeling of a huge room, once used only for storage purposes, included a new doorway leading to the street. The coinproducing plant, at West Colfax and Delaware Streetsso rich in early American historyis a major tourist attraction in Denver. According to Mrs. Brooks, between 3,000 and 4,000 per sons go through, the Mint daily during the spring and summer months, and a more convenient exit to the street was needed, she said. De lays in getting in and out of the plant have long been a complaint of visiting vaca tionists. The renovations were planned to expedite the tours. The small window counter in the lobby, where the miniature Presidential medals and Denver's own miniature medal, first struck in January of this year, had been sold, was found most inadequate. The irate phone calls from visitors complaining about wasting precious va cation time waiting in a long line to buy a medal con vinced me I had to expand the medal sales area, too, Mrs. Brooks stated. With space at a premium at the Denver Mint, it posed a prob lem finding a square foot not in use. Finally, however, we selected a room that could not accommodate production equipment and was used for storage. Visitors formerly got only a gallery view of the coin age manufacturing operations and perhaps a glimpse of the famous $1million display of gold bars. Now the new area makes it possible for us to exhibit some historic pieces of Mint equipment for our visitors to see at close range, the ener getic Mint Director pointed out. We also can offer for sale the national medals available in official locations (such as the Philadelphia Mint) in other parts of the country. The new displays include a coin press from 1873. This fascinating old press has been replaced by more modern equipment, but it was used as recently as 1968, after having been retrieved from the San Francisco Museum during the coin shortage of 1965the year mint identi fication marks were aban doned. The mint marks were restored in 1968. The old warlirse has the capacity to strike .240 cents a min ute, whereas its modern coun terpart produces 500 per minute.

title: Two Tourists View the Moon
description: DAVID SCOTT (9:30 A.M., E.D.T.)As I stand out here in the wonders of the un known at Hadley, I try to realize there's a fundamental truth to our nature. Man must explore. And this is explora tion at its greatest.

title: Moscow Warns of Break In Relations With Sudan
description: MOSCOW, July 31The So viet Union, already angered by the antiCommunist campaign in the Sudan, today charged the Sudanese authorities with provocative acts against Soviet personnel and warned of a pos sible break in relations be tween the two countries.

title: Wrage Takes Narrow Lead In Mariner Class Sailing
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., July 31 George Wrage of Baldwin, L. I., who had a second and third took the lead by three quarters of a point today in the Mariner Class national sail ing championships. Stedman Smith of Salisbury, Md., was second.

title: Advance Guard, Favorite, Wins San Diego Handicap
description: DEL MAR, Calif., July 31 (AP) Bill Shoemaker rode Advance Guard, the heavy favorite, to victory in the $22,400 San Diego Handicap after Raul Ramirez, jured in a twohorse spill today jured In a twohorse spill today at Del Mar Race Track.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: William McChesney Mar tin's forthcoming report for the New York Stock Ex change is due soon. As chair man of a leading third mar ket firm, which has often dif fered with the exchange on market structure, I believe that the prime objective of Mr. Martin's study should be to clear the way for a broad, national securities market. While specific details may vary, I believe the entire in dustry supports this objec tive.

title: MANDARIN GIVEN AT STATE THEATER
description: In an impossible ballet one strives for survival not even hoping for success. American Ballet Theater's Miraculous Mandarin is a ballet that would drive the hope out of all but the most resolute. Diana Weber was The Girl and Royes Fernandez The Man darin in the principal roles Friday evening at State Thea ter and made the most out of the intractable dance material with which they were pre sented.

title: Mixed Housing, Commercial and Industrial Community Approved for Islip
description: HAMPTON BAY, L. I., July 31The way has been cleared for construction of Suffolk County's most ambitiously planned community, a develop ment of 1,732 housing units with commercial, industrial and park facilities in Holbrook in the Town of Islip.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: David Rockefeller points with pride that the Chase Manhattan's Community Eco nomic Development program has placed $9million in loans to small, largely minority owned businesses with mar ginal credit qualifications (July 18).

title: Sarah Pauline Finch Is Betrothed
description: MYSTIC, Conn., July 31 Mrs. Edward Cary Williams of Mystic and Edward Cor nell Kip Finch of New Ca naan have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah. Pauline Finch, to Phillip Joseph Minella, son of Mrs. Peter Pish of Old Forge, Pa., and the late Joseph Min ella. The wedding is planned for September in New Ca naan.

title: An AfroAmerican Show That Isn't
description: MANY observers in the art world almost automatically expec ted some controver sy over the exhibiiton of black artists at the Whitney Museum in New York last spring. As it turned out, they were right. Several artists who were dissatisfied with the museum's policy in se lecting the show withdrew their entries and set up an exhibition of their own, a kind of black Salon des In dpendents.

title: BILL SEEKS TO BAR QUEENS HOUSING
description: A Queens City Councilman has proposed legislation that would require boroughwide ap proval in a referendum before a lowincome housing project could be built in the city.

title: McManus, Osborne Win
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 31 (UPI)Jim McManus and Jim Osborne defeated Clark Graeb ner and Erik Van Dillen in three sets today in the semi finals of the $20,000 Buckeye Tennis Championships, 67, 64, 62.

title: Letters:
Mrs. Damon Has Child
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., July 31A daughter was horn here on July 19 to Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Damon. Mrs. Damon is the former Miss Deborah Taylor, daugh ten of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Hall Taylor of Southport, Conn.

title: U.S. Convict on Leave Wins Flyweight Bout
description: CALI, Colombia, July 31 (AP)Bobby Lee Hunter, a convict from Charleston, S. C., sent the United States off to a winning start tonight in the boxing tournament of the PanAmerican Games when he outpointed Juan Vil Iota of Chile in a flyweight bout.

title: RULING MAY BE AID TO FAR ROCKAWAY
description: The tactic of blockbusting the conversion of a stable neighborhood into a slumre ceived a legal setback last week, and the residents of Far Rockaway, Queens, may have something to cheer about be cause of it.

title: Tennessee Ernie in Lawsuit
description: NASHVILLE, July 31 (AP) Chancery Court Judge Ned Lentz has issued a temporary, injunction prohibiting Tennes see Ernie Ford Foods Inc., from further use of the entertainer's name or likeness. Mr. Ford has filed suit charging that the Nashvillebased food franchise company failed to live up to a contract and owes him $125,000 in royalties.

title: Agnew Reportedly Relayed a Sadat Message
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 Vice President Agnew report edly told President Nixon on Wednesday that he had been invited to relay the willingness of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt to discuss an interim Middle East settlement if the negotiators for Israel were native Palestinian Jews,

title: Economic Charade
description: The acting out of collective bargaining in the steel industry, which continues today under a 24hour contract extension, bears a certain resemblance to that ancient form of Italian dramatic art known as commedia dellarte a comedy in which masked entertainers improvise their lines and actions from a standard plot outline.

title: BRAZIL LEADS, 20, IN ZONE TENNIS
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, July 31 (UPI)Brazil took a 20 lead over Czechoslovakia by winning opening singles matches today in their Davis Cup tennis interzone semifinal.

title: Soviet historiography at work again
description: From Lenin's dayand especially with the rise of Stalinhistory in the Soviet Union can be defined as the carrying on of politics by other means. We all know the uses to which history, its distortion and its suppression, may be put by any gov ernment, but nowhere except in Russia has the mendacious process been so consistent; each change rend ering obsolete whole series of vol umes until the bibliographic ware houses of the archival police are crammed to the rafters. (Books are never burned in Russia nor shoved down an Orwellian memory hole a turn of the wheel may make them again current.)

title: A FIVEMILE TRIP
description: HOUSTON, July 31  For hours of exploration at its greatest; two American astro nauts drove across the desolate surface of the moon today in man's first motorized excursion among the ancient lunar rocks, craters and rolling hills.

title: Director of the Fresh Air Appeal Retiring After 25 Years in Post
description: He is modest, of course, but there is still no question that he takes full responsibility for what happens.

title: News of Dogs
description: Traced back 7,000 years by archeologists, the Saluki is said to be one of the most ancient breeds in the world. Treasured member of the mighty households, from the Caspian Sea to the Sahara, the Saluki never was sold but given Vas proof of highest esteem. Possessed of tremendous speed and remarkable sight, he was trained to hunt the gazzelle in the most dif ficult terrain from deep sand to rbcky mountains. According to the standard, the whole appear ance of this breed should give an impression of grace and symmetry. A slender dog, he averages from 23 to 28 inches in height.

title: Miss Weissner Plans Nuptials
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., July 31The engagement of Miss Wendy Louise Weissner to Roger Lee Beahm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Beahm of Burlington, Colo., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Weissner Jr. The wedding is planned for next summer.

title: DAWSON PREPARES FOR SUPER SEASON
description: LIBERTY, Mo., July 31 (AP) The arm of the Kansas City Chiefs is poised and ready to throw again. This is Len Daw son, who is starting his 15th season of professional football and is regarded by the Chiefs' coach, Hank Strain, as the most accurate passer in the game today.

title: French Keep Pace With Horse  Druggers
description: CHANTILLY, France, July 31  France has the best, most scientifically drugged thoroughbreds in the world. But it's all perfectly legal.

title: Chiefs Get Bears' Weis
description: LIBERTY, Mo., July 31 (AP) Karl Weis, a tight end, has been obtained from the Chicago Bears for an undisclosed draft choice, the Kansas City Chiefs announced yesterday.

title: Movies
description: ANNMARGRET acts! And the movie going public has not been so astonished, since Garbo talked. After 10 untriumphant years of simpering and cooing and purring through a bushel of Pat Boone songfests, Elvis Presley twistathons and Joe Na math motorcycle myths, the torrid teeny bopper with the hyphen in her name and the slither in her walk has finally made it as a superstar. The movie that has skyrocketed AnnMargret into that longelusive galaxy is Carnal Knowledge, Mike Nichols bleak block buster about the American way of sex. She plays Bobbie, a busty blonde whom men persist in loving only for her body, and her performance is so cap tivating that there is already chatter about on Oscar.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: These are trying times for some of America's most prominent growth stocks. They are proving once again that glamour looks spectacu lar on the way up and dismal on the way down.

title: Madalon a Tredennick Married
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., July 31 Miss Madalon Gist Treden nick, daughter of Mrs. Wil liam B. M. Hutchinson and the late Joseph Beacham Treden nick, was married here this afternoon to Paul Richard Hinchey Jr., son of Mrs. Hin chey of Salem, Mass., and the late Dr. Hinchey, a surgeon.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  I have pledged to the American people that I would submit a balanced budget for 1971, said President Nixon at the outset of his budget message to Congress 18 months ago. This is particularly neces sary because the cost of living has been rising rapidly for the last five years.

title: ATOM BLAST DELAY BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Senate voted today to postpone the planned under ground explosion of a fivemeg aton nuclear warhead in Alaska unless President Nixon gives his direct approval.

title: U. at Stony Brook Hires Controversial Police Chief
description: A former Beverly Hills, Calif., Police Chief, Joseph P. Kimble, whose liberal law enforcement views became an issue in this community, has been appointed director of security at the Stony Brook campus of the State University of New York. Mr. Kimble, who is 45 years old, also will lecture in the school of social welfare at Stony Brook.

title: PalmerNicklaus Post 126 And Lead by 4 Strokes
description: LIGONIER, Pa., July 31What combination of golf pro fessionals can beat an Arnold PalmerJack Nicklaus team? The question was prevalent today in the minds of their rivals on 63 challenging teams. But Palmer and Nicklaus made it seem academic in the national team championship by estab lishing a 36hole record for the betterball event with a total of 126. Their card clipped the old mark by one, at the Laurel Valley Golf Club course.

title: Stamps
description: SCOTT Publishing Com pany is revising the format of its 1972 catalogue, long the bi ble of American stamp col lectors. It is also revamping its specialist albumsfrom hinge  on to the self  con tained hingeless (pochette) variety.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Academi cians with ideas for reform ing the nation's tax system are hard to find. It is a bit unusual, however, to find one who is considered a liberal who favors increasing the revenue raised at state and local levels through sales taxes.

title: Ann King Engaged To T. H. Shriver 3d
description: BALTIMORE, July 31Mr. and Mrs. James Sydney King, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Ann Eberhart King, to Thom as Herbert Shriver 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shriver 2d. Both families live here.

title: Himalayan Confrontation?
description: Pakistan's role as the jumping off point for Dr. Henry Kissinger's recent secret flight to Peking may help explain though not to excuse  the Administration's shocking support for the Yahya Khan Government during the first few months of the vicious military crackdown in East Pakistan. But now that the door to China has been opened, it is impossible to excuse or explain Wash ington's continuing supply of arms to Islamabad and Its persisting ambiguity in the face of a deepening tragedy that threatens to erupt before the year is out into major international conflict.

title: Recordings
description: ONE of the most cele brated concerts in re cent times was Josef Hofmann's Golden Ju bilee progrant at the Metro politan Opera House, No vember 28, 1937. The for midable, world acclaimed pianist, then 60 years old, was commemorating his 50th year before the American. public. His career was never less than a sensation  like his playing. A spectacular debut at 10 in the huge Metropolitan Opera audito rium was followed by some years of flagrant exploitation, of the boy genius's gifts by his father and manager. Then rescue by a mysterious benefactor, who provided money for study so long as the boy stopped playing in public. At resumption of the career, Hofmann was again acclaimed a prodigious mas ter of music and the key board.

title: Elizabeth Bisso To Be the Bride Of Navy Officer
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 31 Mrs. Joseph August Bisso 2d has announced the engage ment of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Bisso, to Lieut. (jg.) Frederic Halsey Morris of the Naval Reserve, son of Mr. and Mrs. Grinnell Morris of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: About Baseball
description: Joe Pepitone, of all people, has a shot at a remarkable homerun record, one beyond the reach of Babe Ruth, Wil lie Mays, Hank Aaron and all the other sluggers more fa mous than Pepi.

title: Queens School to Set Up Annex of Intimate Classes
description: A satellite high school for students who are turned off by traditional programs and con ventional classroom environ ments is scheduled to be opened this fall in Queens.

title: Lunar Safari
description: A major new stage in the history of man's exploration of the moon has begun. The mobility given the astronauts by the lunar rover multiplied their capabilities enormous ly. The results were evident yesterday in the large area astronauts Scott and Irwin covered, and the wide variety of scientific tasks they performed. Now, for example, men know what the Hadley Rifle looks like close up, something they never knew before. As a result, even before the crew of Apollo 15 returns to Earth, geologists have abundant new material from which to revise their old ideas about the origin of this chasm, one of the most mysterious features on the entire moon.

title: Music Mailbag
description: THE way Pierre Boulez is attacked by both the left and the right of musical opinion proves that his new approach to programing can, at best, be described as a half mea sure which would scare away the subscribers and still leave new music's audiences un satisfied.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: The most important in gredient in the promotion mix for the country's $4,9billion prescription  pharmaceutical industry, and perhaps the most important communica tions link between the indus try and the physician, is the detail man.

title: RALLY CUT SHORT BY TWINS IN NINTH
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 31Like all companies today, the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem has been trying to cut ex penses, saving dollars wherever possible and sometimes where some employes think it isn't possible.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Ecological and environ mental considerations are be ing brought to bear in vari ous sections of the country insofar as industrial develop ment is concerned. It is be ing felt, for example, in such matters as factory build ings. Do they clash with ex isting landscape? Do they visually mar the natural ter rain?

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WHILE optimism on the state of the economy continues to be the watchword in Washington, the mood elsewhere has been quite different. As the year rolls along, a diminishing level of confidence is obviously developing in business, economic and investment circles.

title: CHINA'S ASIA TRADE INCREASED IN 1970
description: PARIS, July 27Fourfifths of China's international trade was with capitalist countries in 1970 compared with only one fifth in 1960.

title: PRESSURE BUILDS ON BRAZILIAN AIDE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 The public prosecutor who first broke open Brazil's deathsquad murders, attributing them firm ly to policemen in six cases now in the courts, is under renewed pressure to withdraw from the investigations and in dictments he began one year ago.

title: Buffalo Man Heads School
description: MANILA, July 31 (Reuters) The Asian Institute of Manage ment has announced the ap pointment of Dr. James W. Culliton of Buffalo as its second president. The institute is a pro fessional graduate school of management located in Makati, a few miles outside Manila. Dr. Culliton was a member of the United States Tariff Com mission appointed by President John F. Kennedy.

title: Calls From Fire Department to the IRT
description: Following is the text of the transcript of a tape recording made by the Fire Department of telephone calls from the Manhattan fire dispatcher's office to the Transit Author ity's trainmaster's office be tween 9:15 and 9:30 on the morning of July 16:

title: Money Flows Into Canadian Oil
description: TORONTO  Investors, no tably American and Euorpean institutions, have been pour ing money into the stocks of Canadian oil companies in recent weeks.

title: Mrs. Linda Kondrad Married on Yacht
description: Mrs. Linda Resnick Kond rad and William Maynard Sutton of New York, formerly of White Plains, were married here yesterday evening aboard the Palace 2d, a pri vate yacht, in the Hudson River. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian min ister, performed the cere mony.

title: Ethnic Travel: When You Find Your Roots You Eat Them
description: SAN VITO CHIETINO, ItalyI recently visited the birthplace of Gabriele d'Annunzio and Ugo Mancini. D'Annunzio, the Italian poet, is fairly well known, of course, but who's Ugo Mancini? Well, not to prolong the suspense, he is my father, and these are the notes of his native American son.

title: Battrick, Case In Final
description: HILVERSUM, the Nether lands, July 31 (AP)  Gerald Battrick of Britain and Ross Case of Australia advanced to day to the men's singles final in the Dutch open tennis cham pionships.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  At 6 P.M. last Monday, after his 50 invited guests had sipped their beer, cola and orange juice, Gen. Duong Van Minh stepped on to the steps of his villa in downtown Saigon to an nounce that he had definite ly and officially decided to run for President of South Vietnam. Big Minh, the man with the best chance of up setting President Nguyen Van Thieu at the polls, finally de cided to take that chance.

title: Bridge
description: IF you make an asinine play your opponent will sometimes start wor rying about gift horses. In fact, an expert can on occasion make a de fenshre move that seems to have nothing to gain and everything to loseand profit by the resulting con fusion.

title: Fire Inquiry Scores Transit Authority
description: A special panel inquiring into the IRT subway fire two weeks ago reported to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that the subway trainmaster's office had hung up the telephone three times when the fire dispatcher tried to call in requests to have the power cut off so firemen could fight the fire.

title: Celia Carroll Simon Is Affianced
description: RYE, N. Y., July 31Miss Celia Cairoll Simon, a promo tionresearch assistant with the publication division of McGrawHill, Inc., in New York, and William Francis Holbrook, of Keene, N. H., who expects to receive an M.B.A. degree this fall from the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, will be married Sept. 18 in Rye.

title: Chess
description: THE fifth annual Atlantic Open, played here in New York City over the July 4th weekend, attracted a total of 398 players to compete in four separate tourna ments. The open tournament itself, an eightround event conducted on the Swiss system with 180 players, was won by Dr: Orest Popovych, a professor of chemistry at Brooklyn College and runnerup this year in both the Marshall and Manhattan club championships, with a score of 71. Half a point behind were grandmasters Pal Benko and Rob ert Byrne senior master and Manhattan club champion Arthur Feuerstein, and veteran New York master Walter Ship man.

title: P.O.W. LIST PLEDGED IF U.S. SETS DEADLINE
description: PARIS, July 31 (AP)The Vietcong have promised for the first time to identify all the United States war prisoners as soon as the United States sets a deadline for the total with drawal of its troops from Vietnam.

title: Books:
description: With every monthly re ported increase in the cost of living, the tide of opin ion for a more definite wage restraint policy by the Gov ernment gains momentum. Just last week Gardner Ack ley, a former member of the President's Council of Eco nomic Advisers, spoke strongly in favor of a strong incomes policy.

title: AUTORACE DRIVER KILLED IN CRASH
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 31 (AP)A 30yearold Atlanta sportscar driver was killed and a Tampa driver was injured today after a spinout on a turn in the second lap of a Paul Whiteman Trophy race.

title: Jim Brown, Tittle, Robustelli and Lombardi Inducted Into Pro Hall of Fame
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 31Jim Brown saluted the people of his hometown, Manhasset, L. I., who sent him on his way; Andy Robustelli gave credit to the loaves of bread shaped like a football that he bought for his mother, and Y. A. Tittle broke a promise to his wife that he would not choke up and drop a tear.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: DeepSea. Anglers Catch 900 Blues and 40 Winks on Safari at Night
description: BRIELLE, N.J.  Deepsea anglers who find sleeping dif ficult might consider trying the Bogan's Basin insomnia cure. It entails going on night safari in search of blue fish.

title: Stadium Meets Age Test
description: Franklin Field, the home of Penn football and regarded as one of the nation's top viewing stadiums, was built in 1895. It has both an allweather field and track.

title: Colts Trade Jefferson For Redskin Receiver
description: BALTIMORE, July 31 (AP) The Baltimore Colts today traded Roy Jefferson, their wide receiver who had been in a contract dispute with them, to the Washington Redskins.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONFor months now, the thunderheads have been gathering, the threat of crippling, nationwide strikes in two major industries growing ever more ominous. As the dead lines neared, with no sign of settlement in sight, all eyes turned to that ultimate labor management peacemaker, the President. His response was the velvet glove, but there was no sign that it covered an iron hand.

title: Operation Transition
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C.  Robert L. Ollie, who was re leased from the Army at nearby Fort Bragg earlier this year, went to work the day after his separation as a flooring craftsman for a local tile company.

title: Herrmann Injured In Giants' Practice
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 31 Don Herrmann, the wide re ceiver for the Giants, broke his left shoulder today when he dived for his own fumble of Dick Shiner pass during a con trolled scrimmage.

title: BLACK GROUPS CHECK ON INCIDENT IN PARK
description: The National Conference of Black Lawyers and the Com mittee for a Black Vanguard are questioning witnesses to a dis turbance that erupted at the Roberta Flack concert in Cen tral Park last Wednesday.

title: Saratoga Opens Tomorrow With Earlier Post Time and Advice: Bring Money
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 31Here with the annual attempt of your cor respondent to brief the oncoming popu lace on the state of Saratoga, with par ticular reference to the noted racecourse out Union Avenue, easily accessible via the Northway and a halfdozen other arteries, but no longer accessible by rail. In keeping with the current policy of progress, unquote, and service, again unquote, to the traveling public, all rail way passenger service north of Albany was discontinued last spring.

title: Donohue Keeps Pole Position for Quebec TransAm Race
description: MONT TREMBLANT, Que bec, July 31Javelin took three of the first five starting posi tions and Mustang the others as qualifying was completed today for tomorrow's running of the Players Quebec Trans Am.

title: FLYERS WILL TRAIN AT PENN'S PAVILION
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 31 (UPI)The Philadelphia Flyers will take their National Hockey League training camp to the University of Pennsylvania starting Sept. 28 until the season opens Oct. 9.

title: Substitute Teller Robbed
description: A young woman teller filling in for the first day from an other branch of the Manhattan Savings Bank was robbed yes terday of $1,600 in the bank's Yorkville branch, at 186 East 86th Street, the police reported. The holdup man passed a threatening note to her, de. manding the money. Atter ne fled with the cash, the teller, who was not familiar with the buttonalarm system, screamed, attracting the attention of the other 15 persons In the bank.

title: PLIMPTON SHIFTS TO COLT UNIFORM
description: WESTMINSTER, Md., July 31 (UPI)George Plimpton is a man who is used to having his own way, who likes to be on top of whatever situation he is in and enjoys the company of important people  people who have mastered their trade.

title: The Good Word: A Great Place for Bad Writers
description: Last year Eire did for writers and artists what the United States does for oilmen: made their gushings vir tually taxfree. So far, there has been no great invasion to take ad vantage of this, only a quick dribble of hacks. Good writers presumably move more slowly. Although literary men talk about money as much as anyone alive, there is a touch of the Sam Spade about it. Don't be too sure that I'm as crooked as I'm supposed to be. What they really believe in is magic and spells; they want to know how their amulets and charms will travel and whether their sacred powers carry across water.

title: Education
description: The new mood in Wash ington has greatly improved the prospects for Federal sup port of education at all lev els. Until early July, the school and college leaders were in deep gloom, even panic, about their budgets. Now, there is a growing con sensus behind the scenes that Congress has instituted a new phase of major education support and that the White House, which less than a year ago had opposed such spend ing as inflationary, will give its blessing and enjoy some of the credit.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The village of Voss snuggles in a valley amid all the spectacular Norwegian mountain scenery. To the average tourist it was a stop of no great significance, that led through Oslo, Stockholm, Helsinki, being a minor pause along the long road Leningrad, Moscow and Copenhagen. But to one breed of traveler the visit had aspects of a pilgrimage to Mecca. For a football nut like me, Voss automatically rated exalted status because it had been the birthplace of Knute Rockne.

title: Mrs. Career Posts A 71 for 142 Total And 2Stroke Lead
description: LOUISVILLE Ky., July 31 (AP)Mrs. JoAnne Carver used a blazing putter to gain a one underpar 71 and a twostroke lead today in the second round of the $25,000 Bluegrass invita tion golf tourney.

title: Agostini Wins 10th Title In World Motorcycling
description: IMATRA, Finland, August 1 (Reuters)Giacomo Agostini of Italy became the first man to win 10 motor cycling world championships today after clinching the 350 C.C. title at the Finnish Grand Prix.

title: ProfitFigure Revisions Raise Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 The recent drastic revisions in cor porate profit figures in the Gov ernment's statistics raised basic questions about financial analy sis, public policy and even the recent performance of the stock market, a leading economist said today.

title: Miss Susan Parnes Wed to Roger Tucker
description: GREAT NECK, Aug. 1  The marriage of Miss Susan Gale Parnes to Roger Tucker took place here this afternoon in the garden of her home. The bride is a daughter of William Parnes, president of Chuck Howard Boutique, a division of the Paul Parnes Corporation in New York, and Mrs. Parnes. Her grandfather is Paul Parnes. Mr. Tucker is a son of Mrs. Jerry Bresse of Hempstead and Thomas Tucker of Edison, N. J.

title: Meet the Henry Crewses, the Average Americans
description: CRESTWOOD, Mo.It is very hot in middle America these days, and Henry Crews worries a lot about his grass.

title: Personal Finance
description: People who sue for dam agesand winin accidental death cases may now be able to recover substantially more money than was pos sible heretofore.

title: FOREIGN MINISTER IN AUSTRALIA OUSTED
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 1 Prime Minister William Mc Mahon dropped Leslie H. E. Bury, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, from the Cabinet today and replaced him with Nigel H. Bowen, who had been Attorney General.

title: Tourist Business in Slump Here
description: Tourist business in the city fell off sharply in July and indications are that August will be no better.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 1 (Reuters)Shortly before his departure from the Cabinet was announced, Mr. Bury said pub licly that he had profound mis givings about the process in volved in the planned meeting between President Nixon and Premier Chou Enlai of China.

title: Twins Down Yanks, 107, on 6 in First
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 1  Harmon Killebrew again failed to hit his 500th career home run today, but the Twins and the Yankees hit just about everything else as Minnesota won another bizarre game, 10 7.

title: I.T.T. Cutback May End Era of Giant Mergers
description: The day of the giant mergers may have ended Saturday when the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation agreed to divest itself of some of its recent acquisitions.

title: Petty Passes Million Mark With Victory in Dixie 500
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 1 (UPI) Richard Petty zipped ahead of Bobby Allison with 30 laps to go today and won the Dixie 500 stock car race at the Atlanta. International Raceway. The first prize of $20,560 which he won made him the first driver to win $1million in National Associa tion for Stock Car Auto Racing competition.

title: Gold mark, Retiring at C.B.S., Rejects Limbo for Executives
description: Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, de signer of the color camera unit responsible for the television pictures from Apollo 15, has rejected a longterm offer of $750,000 rather than be put in the Columbia Broadcasting System's limbo for retired executives.

title: Subsidizing Lockheed
description: The Senate is due to act today on a proposed $250 million loan guarantee bill designed to save the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy. The measure was endorsed by the House in a close vote on Friday.

title: Many at Welfare Parley Ignore Moon Exploration
description: PROVIDENCE, R. L, Aug. Mrs. Anita Fording of Co hoes, N. Y., and Mrs. Shirley Johnson of Cape Girardeau, Mo., looked surprised when newsman asked them about the Apollo astronauts on the moon. They said they were not interested.

title: MRS. SAMUEL NULMAN
description: Mrs. Nellie Feder Nulman, widow of Samuel Nulman, a merchant, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 78. She lived at 156 Hillside Road, Elizabeth, N. J.

title: Sudan, Beset by Problems After Abortive Coup, Warns Soviet on Criticism
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 1Only two weeks after the abortive leftwing coup, the Su danese regime is beset by staggering array of problems old and new.

title: Invisible PoorWhites in Suburbia
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J.Mrs. Linda North sat in her kitchena room empty ex cept for a stove, refrigerator and a secondhand table with two old chairsand explained why poverty in the metro politan suburbs is so often quiet, hidden or voice less.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rains Flood City Streets, Tying Up Subway Trains
description: Torrential rains pounded the metropolitan area for the third straight day yesterday, flood ing streets and hundreds of basements, disrupting subway service and electrical systems and soaking those who ven tured out.

title: Books of The Times
description: GOING NOWHERE., By Alvin Greenberg, 143 pages, Simon & Shuster, $4.95.

title: New Jewelry at Starting Gate
description: Everybody's crazy over horses. Well, almost everybody. Last year 45 million racing fans cheered on the thorough breds in 28 states across the country and wagered a total of $4.billion.

title: Some Foreign Service Wives Balk at Their Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)The spirit of the Wom en's liberation movement has come to the distaff side of United States diplomacythe wives of some American dip lomats believe there are times when Uncle Sam behaves like a male chauvinist.

title: PEKING ARMY SAYS U.S. MUST QUIT ASIA
description: PEKING, Aug. 1  Despite President Nixon's recent efforts to establish normal relations with China, powerful officials of the People's Liberation Army are mounting a campaign for total withdrawal of United States troops not only from Tai wan and Vietnam but also from Korea, Japan the Philippines and Thailand.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: The Tortured Americans. People just like you. See today's book page.

title: Amherst City Fears Youth Vote
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 1 This quiet city of 13,000 citizens has always been dominated by its institutions of higher learning.

title: Jazz Band of the U. of Illinois Presents Original Compositions
description: The University of Illinois Jazz Band, one of the country's most versatile and polished jazz groups, shared the stage of Town Hall Saturday night with Gary Burton, the vibraharpist, in the weekly Connoisseur Con cert series.

title: Donohue Drives Javelan to Fifth TransAmerican Victory at Mont Tremblant
description: MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, Aug. 1  On the 60th lap, with 10 laps to go, Mark Donohue got the EZ sign from his car owner, Roger Penske, at the time donohue's factory Javelin was beyond challenge from the, Bud Moore Mustang driven by George Follmer.

title: Choice on Amchitka
description: The decision on whether to go ahead with the under ground nuclear test on Amchitka Island in the Aleutians rests with President Nixon. It is very much a personal decision. His advisers are divided. Congress is uneasy but reluctant to take the responsibility.

title: Van Nostrand Beats Sack
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 1 King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, L. L, defeated Lester Sack, Jr. of Clarksdale, Mass., 64, 26, 62, in the finals of the United States Men's 35 years and over clay court ten nis championship today.

title: JOSEPH KRIMSKY, 88, A RETIRED, SURGEON
description: ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Aug. 1Dr. Joseph Krimsky, a re tired surgeon who wrote books on philosophical subjects, died yesterday in Halifax District Hospital, Daytona, He was 88 years old.

title: TV: Pomp and Politics in Wives of Henry VIII
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation has been good to American television viewers. Now, with The Six Wives of Henry VIII, shown by the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, it gives no indication of changing its rewarding ways.

title: MISS GOOLAGONG WINS DUTCH TITLE
description: HILVERSUM, the Nether lands, Aug. 1 (AP)  Evonne Goolagong of Australia added another European title to her growing list of triumphs today by defeating Christine Sand berg of Sweden, 86, 63, in the Dutch open tennis final.

title: Kouwe Wins Ouimet Golf
description: AUBURNDALE, Mass., Aug. 1 (AP)Bob Kouwe of Newark, N. Y., birdied two of the last three holes today for victory in the fourth annual Francis Oui met memorial tournament. Kouwe finished with 72, 73 145 at the Woodland Golf Club.

title: Federal Support for Colleges Down 7% in 1970
description: Federal support for colleges and universities declined by $227million, or 7 per cent, be tween the fiscal years 1969 and 1970, according to the annual survey of the National Science Foundation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The bill to guarantee Lockheed's debts has finally established the su premacy of my wife as the social thinker in our house.

title: M'DOWELL IS FACING INDIANS' GRIEVANCE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP) Gabe Paul, president and gen eral manager of the Cleveland said today the club was starting a grievance pro cedure against Sam McDowell. The ace lefthanded pitcher was suspended yesterday for not re porting for games and is de manding to be declared a free agent.

title: 5 Patrolmen Hart in Brooklyn Trying to Arrest Drag Racers
description: Five policemen, were injured early yesterday when they tried to arrrest several drag rac ers in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: COMBAT DUTY ENDS FOR 2,990 MORE G.I.'S
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (AP)The United States command pulled seven more Army units out of combat to day, cutting American troop strength in Vietnam by 2,990 men. The withdrawal was the biggest in a month.

title: Double Parking Scored in lire Death
description: The Fire Department charged yesterday that illegally parked cars, doubleparked, and block ing hydrants, had stymied firefighting efforts at a three alarm blaze in the Bronx where a battalion chief died of a heart attack and nine firemen were injured.

title: A Summer Street Fight: How It Grew and Ended
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 1  Saturday night in the sum mer  that's when riots get started. Policemen and offi cials in many cities recog nize the phenomenon and stay on special alert every Saturday night during the summer.

title: Advertising:
description: George J. Poris, who left S.S.C.&B. as a senior vice president in 1968, is return ing there in grade. But now instead of being an associate creative director, he's crea tive director and has for his memory book the experience of having been vice president for advertising of Revlon, Inc.

title: Brazil Gains Final Round
description: PORTO ALEGRE, Brazil, Aug, 1 (Reuters)Brazil clinched its interzone semifinal Davis Cup series with Czechoslovakia by winning the, doubles today for a 30 score in matches.

title: Shibata Outpoints KyuAn
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Aug. 1 (AP) The World Boxing Council featherweight champion, Ku Maki Shibata of Japan, pound ed out a unanimous decision over Kim KyuAn of South Korea in a nontitle 10rounder today. Shibata weighed 128 pounds and KyuAn 127.

title: Crucial Test for Dr. Allende
description: Pressure from his own Socialist ranks may shortly provide the most severe test of President Allende's repeated pledges to maintain Chile's democratic system while building socialism. The secretarygeneral of the Socialist party has reacted to the defeat of the candidate of Dr. Allende's Popular Unity coalition in a special parliamentary election in Valparaiso by calling for re placement of the present Congress by a new People's Assembly.

title: WEST OPTIMISTIC ON BERLIN ACCORD WITH SOVIET SOON
description: Western officials believe So viet acknowledgment of re sponsibility for unimpeded civilian access to West. Berlin, a major Western objective dur ing a quartercentury of East West conflict there, has sharply improved prospects for new Big Four accords on the city.

title: Stadium Soccer Postponed
description: The soccer doubleheader in which Pel's Santos Club of Brazil was to play Deportive Cali of Colombia in the feature game after a North American Soccer League match between Rochester and the Cosmos, was postponed yesterday because of wet grounds at Yankee Stadium. The games will be played to night, beginning at 6 o'clock.

title: Compromised Draft Bill
description: A HouseSenate conference committee has substantially weakened the Mansfield amendment to the Selective Service Act by eliminating its forthright call for the withdrawal of all United States military forces from Indochina within nine months, subject to the release American prisoners of war. This and other changes in the Mansfield version, which was adopted by the Senate by a 5742 vote, leave the President broad leeway in the conduct of the war.

title: Cubs' Pizarro Eeats Mets' Seaver, 32;
description: The New York Mets, who were happy to flee from July, stumbled into August yester day and found no relief.

title: Japanese Replace Defense Minister As Result of Crash
