description: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. (Reuters)  Naomi Nishimura, 65 years old, was appointed minister in charge of defense today, replacing Keikichi Masu hara, who resigned over last Friday's Japanese air disaster in which 162 people died.

title: LIBYAN REPORTS PLAN ON JORDAN
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 1Col. Muammar elQaddafi declared today that secret resolutions were adopted Friday at a five nater conference on Jordan and would be applied in due course.

title: Cuba Upsets U.S. Five;
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 1The United States invented the game of basketball, but Cuba borrowed the ingredients for success today and scored stunning 7369 upset of the men's team in the sixth Pan American Games.

title: Russian Sees Threat in Leisure
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 1Dr. Pyotr L. Kapitsa, the Soviet physi cist, says civilization is threat ened by the increase in wealth and leisure time in advanced industrial countries. He advo cates a more liberal education that would turn out indepen dentminded, creative thinkers able to cope with the new life style of the future.

title: TESTIMONY BEGINS IN PANTHER TRIAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 1  A black judge and a jury of 10 black men and two white men began the trial today of 12 Black Panthers charged with attempted murder of five New Orleans policemen in a gun fight last Sept. 15.

title: Venezuela Preparing Measure To Nationalize Gas Resources
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 31 The Venezuelan Congress which is unusual in Latin Amer ica in that it dictates its wishes to the executive branch of Gov ernment, is preparing legislation to nationalize all natural gas resources in the country.

title: Opera: Thomson and Stein in Revival
description: When Virgil Thomson and Gertrude Stein wrote their second opera, The Mother of Us All, 24 years ago, they were well ahead of their time. Important artists usually are.

title: CasperEsnault Team Wins
description: CRANS SUR SIERRE Switzer land, Aug. 1 (UPI)Billy Cas per, playing with M. Esnault, French amateur, won the $5,000 American Express proam to clay with a bestball score of 58, 13 under par for the 6,885 yard par71 Alpine course at the Crans Golf Club.

title: RAY COLCORD JR., BUILDING EXPERT
description: Ray Colcord Jr., a specialist in the design, supervision, con struction and leasing of com mercial buildings, died Satur day of a heart ailment at his home, 419 East 84th Street. He was 54 years old.

title: Astronauts to Cancel New Stamp on Moon
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI)The Post Office said today that Apollo 15 astro nauts planned to cancel a new United States stamp on the moon tomorrow and that it would then go on sale im mediately at Cape Kennedy, Fla., Huntsville, Ala., and Houston.

title: Screen: The Beatrice Lillie of 1930
description: Although it was made in 1930, "Are You There?," starring Beatrice Lillie and directed by Hamilton MacFadden, had its New York premiere yesterday as part of Miles Kreuger's retrospective of very early American musical movies at the Museum of Modern Art. Since the entire Beatrice Lillie filmography doesn't extend much over a half dozen movies, "Are You There?" automatically constitutes a raritythough one with a good many familiar elements.Shirley Travis, girl detective (Beatrice Lillie), is engaged by young Geoffrey (John Garrick) to unmask the guileful Countess Helenka (Olga Baclanova), who is plotting to marry his father, Duke of St. Pancras (George Grossmith).Disguised as Lady Diana Drummond, England's most valiant huntswoman, Miss Lillie charms the Duke, cuddles a fox, subdues the mighty Helenka, and during a gala spectacular staged in the courtyard of the ancestral castle (Miss Lillie and the chorus sing and dance a number called "Bagdad Daddies") captures an international gang of crooksthus saving the Duke's money so his son may inherit it.Although it would be a bad movie in any year, "Are You There?," can only have improved with time. The tacky production pieces, the labored comedy routines, the generally helpless acting, even the California hills rising behind the portals of Castle Troongain from mellowness what they never have had in style.There is very little reason for seeing "Are You There?" except for Miss Lillie, but in seeing it, the changes of 40 years furnish a patina that in the popular arts inevitably encourages a kind of silly, forgiving nostalgia.Miss Lillie, of course, does have style, and a wit so specialized that her range and the range of the movie she is in scarcely ever meet with enough relevance to justify her being there. When she simply raises an eyebrow, she is often very funny, but "Are You There?" furnishes almost no situations to which a raised eyebrow would be appropriate. A good part of her time is wasted with a dreadful comedian named Lloyd Hamilton, feeding him material for slapstick clowning.But in her disguise as Lady Diana, Miss Lillie has at least one song suggestive of her talent ("Queen of the Hunt Am I"), and I suspect there could have been more. Before not releasing the movie, Fox cut out four musical numbers of which Mr. Krueger has obtained the titles. Among these, it might have been good to hear Beatrice Lillie sing something called "The Iron in the Spinach."

title: RALPH A. POWERS, A MANUFACTURER
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. IRalph Averill Powers Sr., container manufacturer and former squash racquets cham pion, died today in Lawrence and Memorial Hospitals. He was 77 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Wesley Grant never played a regularseason game for the football Giantsand he never will. Yet few players recent years have caused more speculation in New York, and fans, for whom a defensive left end is a key to happi ness, arc mystified by what happened and why.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ENCOUNTER LULL
description: The credit markets, troubled by the volume of Government financing over the next five months and concerned about a rift between the Nixon Admin istration and the Federal Re serve Board, are pessimistic about the chances for lower interest rates.

title: ALFRED CHESTER, 42, NOVELIST, REVIEWER
description: Alfred Chester, an avant garde novelist and short story writer, was found dead Wednesday in his apartment in Jerusalem, where he had moved more than a year ago and where he had been working on a novel. His, age was 42.

title: EYE DAMAGE LAID TO A SAFE DRUG
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 1  A drug that is widely prescribed for minor intestinal upsets has ap parently caused thousands of its users to suffer severe dam age to eye muscles and nerves, a medical journal has warned physicians.

title: Help Halt Polluters And Get Paid for It, Seymour Advises
description: United States Attorney Whit ney North Seymour Jr., yester day urged people boating or fishing during the summer to help his office track down sources of pollution in the Hud son River and its tributaries.

title: 2 Shot on Hudson Cruise; Assailant Flees in Crowd
description: A security guard and a pas senger aboard an excursion boat returning from a moon light cruise on the Hudson, were shot and slightly wounded at 2 A.M. yesterday by an alleged marijuana smoker whom the guard had tried to arrest.

title: British Keeps Sailing Title
description: LA ROCHELLE, France, Aug. 1 (AP)Rodney Pattison and Julian BrookeHoughton of Brit ain retained their world yacht ing championship today in the Flying Dutchman class, al though they finished fifth in the seventh and final heat.

title: Gorman Wins in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 1 (AP)Tom Gorman, regaining his form after a 26day layoff with back problems, rallied and defeated young Jim Connors today, 67, 76, 46, 76, 63, in the Buckeye tennis final.

title: Liguori Captures 1,500
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 1  Marty Liguori made it look easy tonight en route to a gold medal in the 1,500meter run at the PanAmerican Games.

title: Trade Strength Offsets Gloom Over Nation's Deficit
description: The United States may see its traditional trade surplus vanish this year, but an examination of strengths and weaknesses in the overall trade outlook indicates that gloom at this prospect may be premature.

description: Arts Abroad

title: U.S. Faces Growing Isolation on Berlin
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The United States is reported to be increasingly isolated among its Western partners in its oppo sition to the installation of a Soviet consulate general in West Berlin.

title: Etruscan Tomb Panels Now Called Forgeries
description: LONDON, Aug. 1  The dating technique by which Oxford archeologists have established Anatolian neo lithic pottery as forgeries had also shown supposed Etruscan tomb paintings to be fakes.

title: Stewart Wins German Prix Race, Nears World Title
description: ADENAU, Germany, Aug. 1 (AP)  Jackie Stewart of Scot land all but clinched the world driving championship today by winning the German Grand Prix in record time.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Lack of Industrial Space Here Cited as Main Cause of Exodus
description: The City Planning Commis sion has found that the main reason industries consider leav ing New York City is not crime, taxes, unions or transportation difficulties, but their need for new space in which to expand.

title: Texas Instruments Profit Declined in Second Quarter
description: Net income of Texas Instru ments, Inc., dipped to $8,518,000 or 77 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1971 from $9,283,000, or 84 cents a share, in the yearearlier quarter, the company announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: Tournament Director Gives An Example of His Play
description: One of New York's lead ing tournament directors demonstrated during the Swiss team Championship at the New York Hilton this weekend that he, too, could play when he got the chance.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 1Lyndon Johnson and, Harold Wilson could hardly be more different in background and personalitya flamboyant Texan larger than life, a cautious pipe smoking Yorkshireman. But their years of political power were alike in one profoundly depressing sense. Both created deep disillusionment among the naturally optimistic reformist ele ments in their societies.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stringent Precautions Prevent Hijackings in Pakistan
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 1 Pakistan's airliners do not get hijacked or sabotaged. A typical halfhour flight with in strifetorn East Pakistan shows why.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Radical Lawyers Adopt New LifeStyle
description: BOULDER, Colo., Aug. 1 With hair down to his shoulder blades, a wispy beard, denim bellbottoms and beads around his neck, Barry Balis of Golden, Colo., hardly fits the typical image of a lawyer. But when he has an important case, he goes into court with his flow ing hair tucked under a short wig.

title: 40,000 Cheer 2 Beatles in Dual Benefit for Pakistanis
description: Two of the four Beatles, the rock group that came out of Liverpool to make musical history in the nine teensixties, were reunited on stage for the first time in more than four years yester day. Over 40,000 people acclaimed them at two sold out concerts at Madison Square Garden for the bene fit of East Pakistani refugees.

title: ONTARIO PASSES A MAGAZINE BILL
description: TORONTO, Aug. 1  The Ontario Legislature gave final passage last week to a bill to prevent foreigners from buying more than a 25 per cent in terest in wholesale distributors, of magazines and paperback books in Canada's most popu lous province.

description: THE 12YEAR REICH. A Social History of Nazi Germany 19331945. By Richard Grun berger. Illustrated. 535 pages. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $10.

title: Raga and Rock Link 2 Cultures
description: This affair might have been called Mad Dogs and Harri son. A band of roughly 20 persons, including something like eight guitars, apparently being directed by Leon Rus sell, had to come out sound ing like the famous Joe Cocker Orchestra. It did, which is to say the music at this benefit was very, good.

title: School Unrest Laid to Gap in Programs
description: An investigation into school unrest here has found that the failure of high schools to provide viable programs for a large segment of the student population appears to be a major cause of disruption.

title: Frontier for Mankind
description: The enormous progress made by the United States manned space program in just two years has been amply demonstrated by Falcon's stay on the lunar surface. Astronauts Scott and Irwin have already accomplished many times as much useful work as did their pioneering predecessors during all of Apollo 11's stay in July, 1969.

title: PALMER, NICKLAUS KEEP TEAM CROWN BY 6SHOT MARGIN
description: LIGONIER, Pa., Aug. 1Not rain nor fog nor a late cloud burst that briefly halted play could deter Arnold Palmer and Jack Nicklaus on their rounds today.

title: SPEARS TRIUMPHS IN FINAL, 3 AND 2
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 1 Richard (Rick) Spears of the Orange County Golf Club at Middletown, in his nexttolast tournament before turning pro fessional, won the Metropolitan Amateur championship today. He defeated Jerry Courville of Shorehaven Golf Club at East Norwalk, Conn., 3 and 2, in the 18hole final over the 6,913 yard, par35, 3570 West Course at Winged Foot.

description: NEWCOMB, N. Y., Aug. 1 (AP)The 22clay search for 8yearold Douglas Legg ended without success shortly after sundown tonight.

description: WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 1 The John F. Kennedy Presi dential Library has opened virtually the entire official White House files except for secret papersspanning the years of the Kennedy Adminis tration, from Jan. 20, 1961, to Nov. 22, 1963.

description: QUEBEC, Aug. 1 (Canadlen Press)Tom Okker of The Netherlands collected his sec ond pay check in eight days by defeating Rod Laver of Australia, 6.3, 76, 67, 61 today in the final of the $50,000 Quebec tennis open.

description: Wilbur Wood, whose left handed knuckleball is more tiresome to the opposition than to himself, boasted re peatedly this season that he could pitch both games of a doubleheader.

title: Frisbee: A Toy for All Seasons
description: The recent death of Donald Franklin Duncan, who made a fortune on the Yoyo, reminds us of the passing of both a man and a toy. We live in new age of both men and toys. The present Age of Aquarius has a toy which is as appropriate to it as the Yoyo was to the 1930's. It is a little plastic disc called a Frisbee.

title: THEY LEAVE TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1Apollo 15's moon explorers took their second Rover ride today and discovered on the slope of the massive Apennine mountains a crystalline rock that scientists believe may be a sample of the original lunar crust.

title: M'GOVERN SEEKS WISCONSIN VOTES
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1Sen ator George McGovern cam paigned through the papermill towns and family farms of Wis consin this weekend, pressing his few but important advan tages in the race for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination.

description: Five skippers completed threerace series sweeps yes terday in the Bayside Yacht Club's 33d annual weekend regatta on Little Neck Bay.

title: Dance: Robbins and the Royal Ballet
description: LONDON, Aug. 1  For years Jerome Robbins has been negotiating with Brit ain's Royal Ballet. Indeed, years ago, his famous version of Les Noces was planned for the Royal Ballet, but got lost in transit. The Royal Ballet's loss was the Ameri can Ballet Theater's gain.

title: DR. ROYALL CANNADAY
description: Dr. Royall G. Cannaday, neurologist who retired in 1968 after being associated since 1914 with the Neurological In stitute of the ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center, died yesterday in the center's Hark ness Pavilion. He was 84 years old and lived at 1158 Fifth Avenue.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Advertising:
description: It's quite possible that this week the fiveman panel of the monthold United States Postal Service will announce the agency or agencies it's selected to help it sell itself.

title: CALLEY SAID TO FACE A 2030YEAR TERM
description: Newsweek Magazine, in its current issue, reports that the life sentence imposed on First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for his role in the Mylai massacre will be reduced to 20 to 30 years by Lieut. Gen. Albert Connor, the Third Army com mander, who is the reviewing officer.

title: Premiere of Hoving's Zip Code Given at American Dance Fete
description: Almost unnoticed except by two decades of students, Lucas Roving rounded out 20 active years at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival over the weekend. From his first ap pearances as a dancer and then choreographer and teacher, Roving has expended his benign and dedicated strength for the festival. On Saturday evening after the performance featuring the premiere of his newest work Zip Code he was presented with a 20candle cake marking the occasion.

title: 3Year Steel Agreement Averts Strike; Wage Increase Is 30%
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1The United Steelworkers of America overwhelmingly approved to night a new threeyear contract described as the best ever by union officials.

title: PROSPECTS BLEAK FOR MORE HIRINGS
description: That longawaited upsurge in employment looks like it's go ing to be waited for quite bit longer.

title: Stabilizing Europe
description: There is a heady atmosphere in the chancelleries of Europe this summer. Success in Britain's negotiations to enter the Common Market and a breakthrough toward agreement in the Big Four ambassadorial talks on Berlin are stirring the blood even of cynics and sophisticates. The feeling every where is: Europe is entering a new era.

title: Command Module Pilot, Alone in Orbit, Conducts Survey of the Moon's Chemistry
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1  In what was described as a his toric innovation in the explora tion of space, the Apollo moth er ship, orbiting the moon with its lonely pilot, conduct ed today a chemical survey of the hidden as well as the visible faces of the moon.

title: Spacemen's Heart and Metabolic Rates Normal as They Adapt to Moon's Gravity
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 1The ex plorers of Apollo 15 have ap parently adapted so well to working in the moon's tricky gravity, onesixth as strong as earth's, that their heart and metabolic rates returned to normal today.

title: JAMES A. MEESE
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Aug. 1  James Alfred Meese, a portrait painter and former commercial artist, died Friday of cancer in Good Samaritan Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 13 Victor Road.

title: The Johnsons Hold an Autograph Party
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 1Lyn don and Lady Bird Johnson came down from the ranch to day and spent the afternoon signing autographs for a clamorous crowd at the Lyndon Baines Johnson Presidential Li brary and Museum. They were raising money to expand the library's information and guide service.

title: Chess: Comin Through the Ruy, Or Is the Schleimann Alive?
description: The Rev. William Lom bardy of St. Mary's Church in the Bronx is, in his spare timewhat he has of it one of America's strongest grandmasters. Though he has played no tournament chess lately, he has given a few exhibitions of simultaneous play.

title: Michel SaintDenis Dies at 73; Director Led Acting Schools
description: LONDON, Aug. 1  Michel Jacques Saint Denis, consultant director of the Royal Shake speare Theater, died here yes terday at the age of 73.

title: Dr. Harriet M'Intosh, 84; Formerly With St. Luke's
description: Dr. Harriet Carswell Mc Intosh, retired chief of roent genology at the New York Infirmary and the Women's Hospital Division of St. Luke's Hospital, died Friday of a cere bral hemorrhage while visiting friends in Williamstown, Mass. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MexicanCuban Air Pact
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 1 (UPI) Mexico reached agreement on a new air pact with Cuba last n ight, continuing the direct HavanaMexico City flights that for a decade have been Cuba's only connection with the rest of the Western Hemisphere.

description: Jerome A. Johnson, who was killed moments after he al legedly shot Joseph A. Colombo Sr., apparently spent an un eventful night before the shoot ing with little hint of the violence to follow the next day.

title: The Artifacts of Camelot: 1,000 Days in 1,902 Boxes
description: WALTHAM, Mass., Aug. 1 There are no clocks visible in the huge windowless green room where 14tiered book cases stretch almost to the high steel rafters, and storage bins hold 159 busts of John F. Ken nedy.

title: For Women in the Military, New Attractions
description: Yes, the young woman is still joining the armed forces. But even before she steps foot in a recruiter's office these days, she generally has two hurdles to overcome: Strong antimilitary pressure from friends who are disillusioned with the war in Vietnam, and objections from parents who remember that some military women had unattractive reputa tions during World War II.

title: Savings Units Report Lags In Mortgage Delinquencies
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI)  Mortgage loan delinquencies at savings and loan associations remained low during the second quarter, despite continued in flation and substantial unem ployment, the United States Savings and Loan League an nounced today.

description: COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 1 (UPI)  The French yacht Gitana V, designed and skip pered by Dick Carter of the United States, withdrew from the 1971 Admiral's Cup con test today giving Britain's Prospect of Whitby the official lead.

title: Rewards Up to $11,000 Set for Captured Vietcong
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1The United States and South Vietnam have decided to start paying the highest cash rewards of the warup to the equivalent of $11,000for in formation leading to the cap ture of certain key leaders of the Vietcong's political under ground.

title: PROSECUTORS AID NARCOTICS COURTS
description: The five city District Attor neys have completed plans for staffing the 12 proposed special parts of State Supreme Court here that would deal exclusive ly with narcotics felonies.

description: LONDON, Aug. 1Prime Minister Heath will drop out of the second race in the Ad miral's Cup, the international sailing event, to tend to poli tics tomorrow.

title: Astronauts Will Make Last Excursion Today
description: The two Apollo astronauts were scheduled to make their last trip across the lunar sur face today. They were orig inally scheduled to begin their final excursion at 3:24 A.M., but the time was de layed as the astronauts ran behind in most of their ac tivities.

description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. CARER'S 210 WINS BY 3 SHOTS
description: LOUISVILLE, Aug. 1 (UPI) Mrs. JoAnne Carner fought off a challenge by Sandra Haynie with a 25foot eagle putt on the last hole today to win the $25, 000 Bluegrass invitation tourna ment by three strokes with a sixunderpar 210.

title: Cubans Told About Apollo 15
description: MIAMI, Aug. 1 (UPI)Cuban internal radio newscasts gave the Cuban public today a de tailed account of the Apollo 15 lunar mission. Radio RELOJ, an allnews station in Havana, read reports of the activities of the astronauts on the moon, without editorial comment. The out editorial comment. The broadcast was monitored in Miami.

title: Pope Praises Astronauts' Trip; Exchange of Messages Revealed
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 1 (UPI)Pope Paul VI praised the genius, skill and daring of America's Apollo 15 moon exploration today and disclosed that the three astro nauts had sent him a message of thanks for his good wishes to them.

title: STEEL USERS LOOK FOR RISE IN PRICES
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 1Steel users can look for higher prices and steel producers can look for lower operating rates.

title: Indians Recall Austin
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 1 (AP)  The Cleveland Indians recalled today a lefthanded pitcher, Rick Austin, to replace an in fielder, Fred Stanley, who will be serving two weeks of mili tary duty.

title: News Analysis
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 1 Whatever the outside world may think of the international activities of Col. Muammar el Qaddafi last month no serious criticism is audible here or in Egypt and the Sudan, which are his friends and beneficiaries.

title: A Venture in Symbolic Diplomacy
description: It has been evident for some time that our Government was seeking to detach itself from a China policy con gealed in aspic for the last twenty years. What no one expected was the spectacular means chosen to bring it about. Presumably the President might have explored, and with luck devel oped, an improved understanding with Peking by traditional diplomatic means. But, in announcing arrange ments for a personal visit, he quite deliberately adopted what might be called symbolic diplomacya form of international maneuver in which the chosen method of diplomatic inter change is itself a political act produc ing major consequences regardless of any substantive agreement that may emerge.

title: Advertising:
description: When a company decides to establish a house agency or otherwise bring its adver tising creativity inhouse, usually two reasons are of fered for the move: It will save money and it will lead to better ads.

title: Phillies to Retain Lucchesi As Manager for '72 Season
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (UPI)  The Philadelphia Phil lies announced today that Manager Frank Lucchesi, whose club has been in fifth place in the National League East for most of the season, would be retained for another year.

title: WILLARD ATKINS, AN ECONOMIST, 82
description: Prof. Willard E. Atkins, first chairman of the economics de partment at New York Univer sity's Washington Square Col lege, died Saturday in St. Vin cent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 82 years old and had lived in Califon, N. J., for the last 30 years.

title: Senate Debates Campaign Fund Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Senate opened debate on campaign spending legislation today with the Nixon Adminis tration and the Democratic leaders at loggerheads over how much candidates should be allowed to devote to radio and television.

title: GANNETT TO ACQUIRE HAWAII NEWSPAPERS
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 2  The Gannett Company, Inc., of Rochester will acquire The Ho nolulu StarBulletin and five other newspapers of the Ha waiibased corporation in an exchange of stock conserva tivey estimated at more than $27million.

title: PONY HUNTER BIDS FOR 14TH VICTORY
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 2Richard E. McDevitt's Sul tan's Quest, who has won 13 championships in a row, fin ished second in three classes today at the Orange County horse show.

title: Robert J. Milano
description: Born in New York City, June 14, 1912 ... Attended City College ... Started Mill master Chemical Company, 1936 ... After World War II, expanded his holdings by purchase of the Berkley Chemical Company, Berkley Freights, N. J.... Now chair man of Millmaster Onyx, which has an annual volume of business of $70million, overseas branches ... In World War II, rose from pri vate to captain ... A three time trustee of the Chemist Club, past president of the Salesman's Association of the American Chemical Industry ... Married, lives on Man hattan's East Side.

title: Congress Told of Shortage Of Raw Materials for U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  The United States, the world's largest consumer of minerals, faces an acute short age of raw materials in the coming decades, Interior De partment officials told Congress today.

title: STEEL PRICE RISE OF 8% ANNOUNCED BY 5 BIG CONCERNS
description: Most of the nation's major steel producers announced yes terday that they would raise prices by an average of about 8 per cent on nearly all types of steel products.

title: 19,739 See Cali Tie Santos, 22, And Cosmos Score 32 Victory
description: Pel, soccer's premier star, was supposed to be the main attraction in the 22 Santos Deportivo Cali match at Yan kee Stadium last night, but the show was stolen by a support ing actor on the Santos squad named Edu.

title: 11 Street Theater Groups to Join In a Festival at Lincoln Center
description: Eleven street theater groups from this city, Washington and Watts in California will par ticipate in a festival of their productions Aug. 19 to 29 in the parks and plaza areas of Lincoln Center for the Perform ing Arts. The festival will be open to the public free.

title: B.&M. Blacktopping Is Asked by Trustee
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Boston & Maine Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to dis miss an application calling for abandonment of the 1,500mile railroad.

title: Rocky Road for Giants' Rookie
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 2 Ralph Gary Thompson Symonds, born in Bermuda, today demonstrated he was a master at American slang. It don't matter if you're No. 1 or No. 51you got to cut the mustard. You got to do your own thing.

title: Father and Son Seized on Yacht Off Cuba in Draft Evasion Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) A California dentist and his son were arrested on their yacht by the Coast Guard near Cuba yesterday, and their in dictment in connection with aiding draft evaders was an nounced here today.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2The top leaders of all the Sovietbloc countries except Rumania held a oneday meeting today and issued a communique de nouncing deviations from Mos cow's line and expressing grave alarm over the anti Communist campaign in the Sudan.

title: CLASH IS REPORTED IN CAMBODIA SWEEP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2 (AP)New fighting was reported today in eastern Cam bodia, where 3,500 South Viet namese infantrymen launched a sweep operation six days ago.

title: Flowers Kept Fresh on a Grave in Prague
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 2A simple grave covered with fresh flowers in Prague's Olsany Cemetery, the burial place of Jan Palach, appears to repre sent the last token of resist ance to the Sovietled invasion of Czechoslovakia nearly three years ago.

title: Sudan Ousts 2 Communist Diplomats, Charging Link to Plotters

The first course stresses blocking effectively against blitzing linebackers in order to preserve the quar terback's health, notably Joe Namath's.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Dr. Powrie V. Doctor, an au thority on the education of the deaf, died Saturday in Paris, where he was attending the Congress of the World Federa tion of the Deaf. He was 67 years old.

title: Leigh R. Sanford, 83, President Of Shipbuilders Council, Dead
description: Leigh R. Sanford, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America from 1950 to 1961, died Sunday on his 83d birth day in Winter Park, Fla.

title: Effects of Rains Disrupt Phones and Transit Here
description: Thunderstorms that dumped nearly six inches of rain on the city since Friday gave way to patches of sunshine yester day, but the effects of the storms lingered on in disrupted telephone service, flooded base ments and scattered delays in transit services.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: LOOKING FOR A NEW CAREER? See Our Knight on Page 38 First Investors Corp.Advt.

title: POSTAL SERVICE ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Rev. Jesse Jackson, director of the Operation Breadbasket arm of the Southern Christian Lead ership Conference, accused the new United States Postal Serv ice today of job discrimination against blacks.

title: RIVA RIDGE WINS BY TA LENGTHS AS SPA REOPENS
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2The Saratoga racing meeting, a financial shot in the arm to the economy of this region, started its 103d season today with the running of the $34,950 Flash Stakes.

title: U.S. Grand Jury Chosen In Garrison Bribery Case
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 2 (AP) A special 24member Federal grand jury was chosen today to investigate bribery charges against District Attorney Jim Garrison.

title: U.P.I. WILL PRODUCE NEWS FOR CABLE TV
description: United Press International and. Sterling Communications, Inc., announced yesterday that U.P.I. would produce, beginning in September, a new, 100word aminute newswire to be used exclusively for cable television.

title: Suit on Housing Seeks to Block Regional I.R.S. Center for L.I.
description: A suit seeking to block the, Internal Revenue Service and the General Services Adminis tration from establishing a $25million regional I.R.S. cen ter in the Town of Brookhaven, on Long Island because of the lack of lowincome, integrated housing in the area was filed today in Federal District Court In Brooklyn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MitchellLama Tenants Ordered To Bare Tax Return or Pay More
description: State Supreme Court Justice Harry B. Frank ruled in a deci sion published yesterday that residents in publicly aided mid dleincome housing had no right to secrecy of their state income tax returns because they received what he called public assistance.

title: S.E.C. Investigates Merger
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 2 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company despite the recent agreement between the Justice Department and I.T.T. on the case, it was learned today.

title: VESCO SAID TO LIFT HOLDINGS IN I.O.S.
description: GENEVA, Aug. 2Robert L. Vesco, head of the International Controls Corporation, was re ported today to have acquired about 40 per cent of the pre ferred shares of Investors Over seas Services, Ltd., in his fight for control of this mutualfund complex.

title: No Pay for Legislators
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 2 (UPI)Pennsylvania's 252 legis lators and many other state employes were denied their usual pay checks today because the legislature failed to enact a budget. A stopgap appropria tion of $160million ran out during the weekend. State em ployes are paid twice a month.

title: Equipment Is Ordered For Control of Pollution
description: The Northern States Power Company stated in Minneapolis that it expected to spend $36, million for environmentalcon trol equipment on its new $360million Sherburne County generating plant slated to begin operations in 1976.

title: Merger News
description: Directors and management of the Collins Radio Company and the North American Rockwell Corporation approved yesterday a definitive agreement under which North American Rock well will invest $35million in a new Class A $5 cumulative convertible preferred stock of Collins. Last May the companies announced that they had begun preliminary discus sions whereby North American would endeavor to purchase a significant interest in Collins. Under the agreement announced yesterday, which is subject to approval by Collins shareholders, Collins is to adopt new restated articles of in corporation and North Ameri can will have the power to designate and elect a majority of the Collins board.

title: FRED LEDERER
description: Fred Lederer, a lawyer with the law firm of Hirzfeld & Ru hin, 40 Wall Street, died yes terday of a heart attack at his home. He was 61 years old and lived at 9918 66th Avenue, Rego Park, Queens.

title: Lockheed Employes Are Elated, But Recalls Are Still Uncertain
description: BURBANK, Calif., Aug. 2 Elation and some screaming and hollering was the general reaction of employes of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation here today to the news that the Senate had approved and sent to the White House legislation that would guarantee loans that would prevent the company's imminent bankruptcy.

title: Confusion Reigns as Astronauts Check Possible Leak Before Jettisoning Falcon
description: Following are conversations between Capcom, the capsule communicator in Houston, and the Apollo crew, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: CLERIC ON TRIAL IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 2 (Reuters)The Anglican Dean of Johannesburg pleaded not guilty today at the opening of his trial on charges of plot ting the violent overthrow of the Government. This was fol lowed by the testimony of a member of the Dean's congre gation who had been working for the security police.

title: Israelis Hunt Guerrillas In Gaza Refugee Camps
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 2  As bulldozers cut security lanes through Gaza's crowded re fugee camps, the military government today circulated tens of thousands of leaflets advising Arab guerrillas to surrender and save their lives.

title: MICHEL DUMONT, PRESS COUNSELOR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2Michel Dumont, press counselor of the French delegation to the United Na tions for 16 years, died yester day in Lenox Hill Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 61 years old.

title: Bill Aids U.S. Workers Here
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Federal employes in cities of 500,000 or more would be given costofliving pay increases un der a bill introduced today by 17 House members from New York. Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a Democrat, said a family of four on welfare in New York City received more than the starting salary for a Federal employe in the lowest three pay grades under Civil Service.

title: WESTBURY DROPS BAN ON GILMOUR
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 2 William (Buddy) Gilmour, the nation's leading harness driver, was given clearance to drive here again in a surprise move today by Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Once upon a time the Cleveland Indians were setting American League attendance records with more than 2 million customers. They also were winning pennants while Bill Veeck, the presiding genius of their operations, cackled with glee and pounded the promotional tomtoms.

title: Gambling Suspect Seized In Raid on Apartment Here
description: Detectives from the Public Morals Administrative Divi sion and the Manhattan Dis trict Attorney's office raided the residence of an alleged gambler early this morning, arrested him and seized $9,000 in cash and records that they said showed several million dollors in gambling transac tions.

title: Shirley A. Chisholm
description: Born in Brooklyn, Nov. 30, 1924 ... Graduate of Brook lyn College and Columbia University ... Nursery school teacher and director, 1946 53 ... Director Hamilton Madison Child Care Center, 195359 ... Educational con sultant, Division of Day Care, New York, 195964 ... Served with Democratic Women's Workshop, Brook lyn Branch National Associ ation for the Advancement of Colored People, National Association of College Wom en ... BedfordStuyvesant Political League ... Jane's Methodist Church ... Served New York State Assembly, 196568 ... Elected to Cong ress, Nov., 1968, reelected Nov., 1970 ... Married to Conrad Chisholm ...

title: 4 Office Theaters Are Taking Shape
description: Some concrete evidence is beginning to emerge from the program developed four years ago by the City Plan ning Commission to revita lize the theater district by persuading builders to con struct playhouses in new office buildings on and around Broadway.

title: Stiffer Loyalty Rules Considered for Government Employes in Key Positions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Justice. Department and the Civil Service Commission are considering a proposal that would make it easier for the Government to dismiss em ployes who belong to terrorist /revolutionary organizations.

title: A Scarecrow Image
description: A scarecrow image. This is what South Africa's detractors manufac tured for that country in the past number of years. The nightmarish image often scares and infuriates peoples and nations to the ends of the earth.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 2 (AP) Rumania, ahead by 21, moved closer to victory in the Davis Cup interzone semifinals to day with Ion Tiriac leading Jaideep Mukheriea of India in a singles match that was halt ed because of darkness.

title: J. GUS LIEBENOW
description: J. Gus Liebenow, founder of the Box Printing Machinery Company of Chicago, died there Sunday at the age of 79.

title: Pompidou Acts to Save Pavilions of Les Halles
description: PARIS, Aug. 2President Pompidou and the Govern ment have intervened to save at least one of the 19th century shedpavilions that formed the heart of Les Halles, the old central market of Paris.

title: ALIOTO PROPOSES WIDE DRUG DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Mayor Joseph L. Alioto of San Francisco told a Senate sub committee hearing today that a Federal commitment of at least $1billion for nationwide drug treatment programs was necessary to reverse what he called the growing menace of narcotics abuse in the United States.

title: A FOURTH CANDIDATE ENTERS SAIGON RACE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2  A fourth candidate for South Vietnam's presiden tial elections has appeared with out fanfare here, and some po litical sources speculate that he is a token rival promoted and helped by President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Subdue Orioles, 74
description: The Boston Red Sox are determined to keep baseball interest in at least one divi sion race.

title: . . . Good Sense on the Rails
description: The Administration has won handsomely its gamble that it could persuade both sides in the long battle over modernizing railroad work rules to settle their dispute without a fresh recourse to Congress for nostrike legis lation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Action Taken To Force Lindsay Out of the G. O. P.
description: State Senator John D. Cal andra, the Bronx Republican leader who has been seeking to oust Mayor Lindsay from the party, went to court yes terday and obtained an order requiring the Mayor to show why his enrollment as a Re publican should not be nullified.

title: NoFault Trims Costs 53% in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  Gov. Francis W.. Sargent an nounced today that the aver age cost of paid insurance claims and the number of claims filed in the first six months of the state's nofault auto insurance law were down 53 per cent compared with the same period last year.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Three Massachusetts plants operated by Honeywell Infor mation Systems, Inc., will share part of a $35.6million govern mental dataprocessing con tract, according to an an nouncement from Senator Ed ward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts. The Brighton plant will receive $9million with $9.6million to the Wal tham facility and $4.6million to the Framingham unit. The bal ance will go to Honeywell plants around the country.

title: May's Homer in 9th Stops Matlack Bench Stars
description: The Cincinnati Reds, who were in first piace by 11 games a year ago, arrived in New York last night in fifth place, 18 games out with a fivegame gosing streak. But they got prompt, temporary relief when they scored two runs in the ninth inning and defeated the wandering Mets, 42.

title: Shooting of 500 Eagles Described by a Pilot
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  A helicopter pilot testified today that more than 500 eagles were killed from the air in Wyoming and Colorado from last Novem ber to February.

title: Cars Impeding FireFighting Face Ban
description: City officials called yester day for measures to prevent parking violations that impede fire  fighting and jeopardize lives.

title: Richey Wins
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) Cliff Richey of Sarasota, Fla., posted an easy victory today but Ray Moore of South Africa was upset in opening matches of the $30,000 Western tennis tournament.

title: U.N. Studying U.S. Move Backing a Seat for Peking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 2Diplomats here voiced agreement today that the United States' support for seating Communist China in the United Nations, while a major policy development, hardly af fected any of the obstacles to Peking's arrival.

title: Kent State U. President Elected
description: KENT, Ohio, Aug. 2 (UPI) Dr. Glenn A. Olds, former United States representative to the United Nations Eco nomic and Social Council, was elected today president of Kent State University by the school's board of trustees.

title: Senate RollCall on Lockheed Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP)Following is the roll call by which the Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill authorizing $250million in loan guarantees to aid the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation:

title: GOVERNORS IN SOUTH CITE RACIAL AMITY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  Seven Southern Governors pub lished today brief, dispassion ate and generally sanguine statements on race relations.

title: HONEYWELL RAISING PRICES BY ABOUT 7%
description: Honeywell, Inc., information systems announced yesterday at Waltham, Mass., that it has raised prices on computer equipment products and serv ices up to 7 per cent, effec tive Aug. 1.

title: Brinkley and Chancellor Get New Assignments on N.B.C.
description: The National Broadcasting Company confirmed yesterday reports that it had new assign ments for David Brinkley and John Chancellor on its N.B.C. Nightly News.

title: Bergen Record Ends Use Of William Buckley Column
description: William F. Buckley's syndi cated column, On the Right, has been dropped by The Rec ord, a New Jersey newspaper published in Hackensack. The Record explained in an editorial that it had taken the decision because Mr. Buckley had de stroyed the credibility of his own publicationNational Re view, the conservative mag azineby the publication of false secret documents.

title: Divers Kill Sea Urchins
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) Scuba divers say they have killed about 800,000 purple sea urchins in a project. designed to make the sea safe for sea weed. The urchins have eaten most of the kelp that is the habitat of many other marine creatures. The Palos Verdes Underwater Restoration Project began operations yesterday with nearly 1,000 volunteer divers.

title: Inflation in Steel ...
description: No matter how little validity the domino theory may have in international relations, the bingbang increase of steel wages and prices leaves no basis for doubt that is working with chilling inexorability in labor relations.

title: Moon Test Backs Up Galileo In Pisa Experiment on Gravity
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2 (AP)  Col. David R. Scott dropped a hammer and a feather on the moon from waist high today to Illustrate that both objects are accelerated equally by lu nar gravity and that both would hit the surface at the same time despite their differences in mass or weight.

title: Apollo Lingering in Orbit to Map the Moon
description: Instead of rushing home after their visit to the moon, the Apollo 15 astronauts are spend ing two more days in lunar orbit, scooping up radioactive particles for analysis and col lecting data for physical and chemical maps.

title: U.S. SEES INCREASE IN WHEAT SURPLUS
description: Surplus stocks of American wheat may increase by more than 100 million bushels during the 197172 marketing season, economists of the Agriculture Department estimated in a summary of the agency's wheatsituation report, which was released yesterday. The full wheatsituation report will be issued tomorrow.

title: Peterson Wins With 4 Hitter  Clarke Sparkles Afield
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 2  A fourhit shutout by Fritz Peter son, a busy night for Horace Clarke at second base, and a wellcoordinated attack that produced four runs with two out in the fourth inning gave the New York Yankees a 70 victory over the Cleveland In dians tonight.

title: City Loan Program Contractor Indicted
description: The first indictment growing out of an investigation of the Municipal Loan Program was returned yesterday against a contractor accused of paying 58,200 in bribes to five public officials.

title: SENTENCE UPHELD IN SECRETS CASE
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP)  A finding of contempt of court against Anthony J. Russo, who has refused to testify be fore a Federal grand jury that is investigating the leak of the Pentagon papers, was affirmed today by a panel of three Feder al judges.

title: Vice Chairman Leaving First National City Corp.
description: Thomas R. Wilcox, 54year old vice chairman of the First National City Corporation, quit his $144,000ayear job yester day to pursue other business interests. The resignation will be effective Sept. 1.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 2 It was 5 A.M. Streaks of lightning were still flashing across the sky to the southwest. Visibility was limited, but the pelting rain was subsiding.

title: 2 PAPER COMPANIES CUT BACK ON MILLS
description: Two major paper companies are getting rid of paper mills, they said yesterday.

title: Edward L. Ryerson, ExHead Of Inland Steel, Is Dead at 84
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (UPI) Edward L. Ryerson, chairman of Inland Steel Company from 1940 to 1953, died early today after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Bridge: Final Deal Proves Decisive In Swiss Team Tourney Here
description: A strong finish in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton Sunday night gave victory to Dan Salkoff, Keith Garber, Jay Wendt, Fred Dossenbach and Merle Tom, all of New York, and Frank Mela of Great Neck, L. I.

title: Kennedy Data: Years at Harvard
description: John F. Kennedy's senior thesis at Harvard in 1940, which won him academic honors despite his undistin guished grades, generated substantial disagreement in the university's government department at the time.

title: Stuart Nash Scott
description: Born, Madison, Wis., Dec. 6, 1906... Graduate Phil lips (Andover) Academy, Yale University and Harvard Law School... Assistant professor at Harvard Law School, 193031... Admit ted to bar in New York, 1932... Has practiced since in New York City... Served as counsel to French Pur chasing Commission, 1939 40 and Bureau of Aeronau tics of Navy Department, 194144... General counsel, Surplus War Property Ad ministration, Office of War Mobilization, 1944... Na tional chairman, Harvard Law School Fund, 195961 ... Married to former Kath erine Miller... Has one daughter... Lives in New York City at 784 Park Ave nue.

title: C.I.A. Says It Maintains Army in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Nixon Administration acknowl edged today, through a Senate subcommittee staff report, that the Central Intelligence Agency was maintaining a 30,000man irregular force now fighting throughout most of Laos.

title: Lucius D. Clay
description: Born, Marietta, Ga., April 23, 1897 ... Graduated from United States Military Acad emy, 1918 . . . Advanced through grades to general in 1947 ... Retired from mili tary in 1949 after service on staffs of Gen. Douglas Mac Arthur and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower ... Representa tive of President John F. Kennedy to Berlin in 1961 ... Former chairman of Continental Can Company Director of Lehman Corporation, Allied Chemical, U.S. Lines, American Express Company, Chase International Investment Corporation ... Married to former Marjorie McKeown ... Has two chil dren ... Lives at 200 East 66th Street.

title: JOSEPH LAWE DIES; INDUSTRIAL DESIGNER
description: Joseph S. Lawe, an industrial designer who received many awards for his work, died Fri day of a heart attack at his home, 10435 205th Place, Hol lis, Queens. His age was 40.

title: Fortunes of Chinese Films Rise Here
description: Though New York's Chi nese community is predomi nantly Cantonesespeaking. filins in the Mandarin dialect, the official tongue in both Nationalist and mainland China, have all but complete ly replaced Cantonese movies here over the last five years.

title: Whitney Young Foundation Set Up to Train Blacks
description: Mrs. Whitney M. Young Jr., speaking softly and with tears often brimming in her eyes, an nounced yesterday the creation in her husband's memory of a foundation devoted exclusively to training young black leaders in the field of social relations.

title: EXSOLDIERS REPORT VIETNAM SLAYINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2Two former military  intelligence agents asserted today that Vietnamese were indiscrimi nately rounded up, tortured and murdered by Americans in an effort to eliminate Viet cong cadres.

title: RONINEY DEFENDS HOUSING POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Nixon Administration's housing and community development programs, policies and propo sals were strongly defended to day by George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Ur ban Development.

title: U.S. Inventories Stayed On a Level Trend in June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The essentially flat trend of manu facturers' inventories continued in June, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: REDISTRICTING PLAN IN TEXAS IS VOIDED
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 2A Texas legislative plan for re apportionment of the State House of Representatives was declared unconstitutional today by a State district judge.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
RETAIL BUSINESS SEEN AS STEADY
description: Retail business in New York is holding at a steady level, a survey of leading department stores indicated yesterday.

title: Out to Get their Share of the Cosmetics Business
description: The text for the day's class was written on the black board: Transform boiled eggs into sparkling chandeliers.

title: 4 SHOW HONORS GO TO MR. ED STABLES
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 2Edward Waskiewoicz's Mr. Ed Stables of Canterbury, Conn., produced two cham pions and two reserve winners last night as the western sec tion of the Orange County horse show ended.

title: Credit Markets Advance; Detroit Bank Lifts Prime
description: The credit markets tossed aside the implications of costly steel and rail labor settlements and scored a modest advance yesterday.

title: HAL JAMES, 58, DEAD; A THEATER FIGURE
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 2 Hal James, best known as co producer of the durable musi cal Man of La Mancha, died today at his home here after suffering a stroke on Friday. He was 58 years old.

title: JAPAN GETS APOLOGY BY SATO FOR CRASH
description: TOKYO, Aug. 2Premier Eisaku Sato named a new civilian head of the defense forces today and apologized to the nation for an air col lision Friday that took 162 lives in the worst air disaster on record.

title: Bamboo Curtain Has Parted, but the Chopstick Wall Remains
description: PEKING, Aug. 2China may have the answer to America's problem of over eating and overweight. Having unsuc cessfully tried every slimming formula from Lenten repentance to Joe Alsop's drinking man's diet, I have switched to chopsticks and reached the scientific conclusion that it is impossible not to lose weight if you rely on these slippery implements.

title: Blast Set in Supermarket
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 2 (AP)An incendiary device ex ploded tonight at a shopping center supermarket, injuring three persons slightly, shatter ing glass and triggering a fire in the store's bakery, the po lice said. Harold Olson, deputy police chief, said the store had received three or four recent calls in threatening it would be bombed unless money was placed in a bag outside.

title: Price Leads After 4 Races In Midget Class Sail Series
description: MORICHES, L. I., Aug. 2  Mike Price of the host Moriches Y.C. won two of four races to day and took the lead in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Midget Class sail ing championship. Price had 20 points.

title: OBSERVER
description: Ever since publication of the Penta gon papers, Government people have been complaining about the press in vading the Government's privacy. Un thinkable, said an F.B.I. man. Un thinkable to have a situation where people cannot even write memos in the privacy of Government offices without some newspaper getting hold of the material.

title: Herman Kahn
description: Born in Bayonne, N. J., Feb. 15, 1922 . . . Bachelor's degree, University of Cali fornia at Los Angeles, 1945 . . . Master of science degree, California. Institute of Tech nology, 1948. . . With the Rand Corporation, 19481961 . . . A founder of the Hud son Institute, 1961 . . . Known as the man who spe cialized in thinking about the unthinkable . . . Served as consultant and specialist for government agencies and privatesector organizations . . . His books include On Thermonuclear War and Thinking the Unthinkable . . . Prolific contributor to popular and scientific maga zines . . . Married, with two children . . . Lives in Chap N. Y.

title: Women Are Gaining as Pastors, but Slowly
description: When the Rev. Margaret Howland began looking for a job as pastor after serving eight years as a minister in other capacities, one of the questions that Presbyterian church officials asked her was whether she would not be embarrassed if the plumb ing were to spring a leak and a trustee had to visit her at midnight to repair it.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ellis T. Cox has been elected president of Allis Chalmers Powers Systems, Inc., an affiliate com pany of AllisChalmers Corporation and Kraftwerk Union of West Germany. He will also continue to serve in his present post as group executive and vice president of the AllisChalmers Corporation. Mr. Cox came to AllisChalmers Corporation early this year from the Babcock & Wilcox Com pany, where he was vice president and general manager of its power generation division.

title: PRISONER SEEKS TO. TELL OF BRIBE
description: A prisoner in the Men's House of Detention here has asked a Senate subcommittee to let him testify that he bribed the secretary of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer with $15,000 in an attempt to avoid a conviction for arson, burglary and grand larceny.

title: Welfare Clients Here Get Jobs For City Under New State Law
description: Melvin Hatcher, for two years a homerelief recipient while receiving treatment for tubercu losis, cheerfully showed up at the city's Transportation Admin istration yesterday morning as the first relief recipient re ferred there for a payless city job under a new state law.

title: North Wins Western Golf
description: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., Aug. 2 (UPI)  Andy North sank a onefoot putt for a par 4 on the 18th hole today to score a 1up victory over Barney Thompson and win the Western Amateur golf tourna ment.

title: U.S. HEARING SLATED ON PORT COMPACT
description: TRENTON, Aug. 2  Gov. William T. Cahill announced to day that a House Judiciary subcommittee in Washington had agreed to hold a public hearing on a proposed compact approved by New Jersey and New York that would extend the police powers of the Water front Commission of New York Harbor to the region's major jetports.

title: Sisco and Israelis Confer Again in Tight Security
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 2  The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian affairs, Joseph J. Sisco, held a second working meeting today with Premier Golda Meir and other top Israeli policymakers, with all the signs suggesting that a new diplomatic initia tive to reopen the Suez Canal is being worked out.

title: DEPOSITS RISE A BIT FOR SAVINGS UNITS
description: The nation's savings and loan associations had a net in crease in deposits of $1.3bil lion in June, the smallest monthly increase so far this year, the National League of Insured Savings Associations reported yesterday. Other thrift institutions have similarly re ported a slowdown in savings.

title: Mrs. Court Takes Tennis Maternity Leave
description: Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, the world's toprank ing woman tennis player, will not be in the United States Open at Forest Hills, Queens, Sept. 1 through 12.

title: Buick Recalling 3,500 Cars Over Possible Short Circuit
description: FLINT, Mich., Aug. 2 (UPI) The Buick Motor Division of General Motors Corporation re called today 3,500 new Buick Le Sabre, Centurion and Elec tra models because of the pos sibility of a short circuit and resulting fire in the instrument panels.

title: U. S. Backs U. N. Seat for Peking, Opposes Ousting Taiwan
description: Transcript of Rogers news briefing is on Page 2.

title: Friendly Moon
description: Now that astronauts Scott and Irwin have success fully rejoined the mothership orbiting the moon, the historic Apollo 15 mission has entered its final research phase. All the evidence suggests that this is the most productive scientific expedition ever carried out in space. Even before the astronauts' own return, the information they have sent back has already forced reconsideration of some key ideas about the natural history of the moon.

title: Thant Warns Council of IndianPakistani Clash
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 2  Secretary General Thant warned today that a major conflict could break out between India and Pakistan, which could all too easily expand.

title: Investing Fever Grips Brazilians
description: SAO PAULO, BrazilStock market averages soaring 250 per cent in six months. Thou sands of investors crowding brokerage offices each day with fistfuls of money. And share earnings jumping 50 per cent or more a year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL FELL 5% IN WEEK
description: Steel production fell last week by 15 per cent, compared with output the week before, because many producers were beginning to shut down facil ities against the possibility of a steel strike.

title: RAIL STRIKE ENDS WITH 42% PAY RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  A damaging rail strike ended to day with the signing of a con tract that could usher in a new era of labormanagement rela tions for the nation's long troubled railroad industry.

title: YANKEE GIRL WINS SECOND CUP RACE
description: COWES, Isle of Wight, Aug. 2 (UPI)Britain widened her unofficial lead over the United. States, the defending champion, in today's second race of the. fourevent Admiral's Cup series by placing her three yachts, among the top 11 finishers.

title: Tape Recording Sends Crew Into Blue Yonder
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2  The lunar sky may be black, be cause of the absence of air, but when Apollo 15's moon explorers rocketed off the surface today they radioed the recorded strains of Off We Go Into the Wild Blue Yon der.

title: Taub Gets Narcotics Post
description: Assistant District Attorney Arnold T. Taub, the chief of the Rackets Bureau in the Queens District Attorney's of fice for two years, has been named to head the newly created special narcotics court bureau in the Queens office, District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell announced yesterday.

title: I.T.T. STOCK OFF 7 AND MOST ACTIVE
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was yesterday's most actively trad ed issue on the New York Stock Exchange. A total of 197,000 shares changed hands and the issue fell 7 to close at 55.

title: Clashes in East Reported
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 2 Clashes and incidents between Pakistani Government troops and Bengali guerrillas were re ported by various sources to have occurred over the week

title: West Germans Place Ban On Horses From Americas
description: BONN, Germany, Aug. 2 (AP) West Germany announced to day a ban on all horses from North, South and Central America because of the acute spread of a contagious horse disease on the American conti nents.

title: Alleghany Corporation Lists A Sharp Rise in Net Assets
description: The Alleghany Corporation, which controls Investors Diver sified Services, Inc., the mu tualfund organization, had net assets of $18.19 a common share, as of June 30. This com pared with $12.32 a share on the same day last year.

title: Olympic Storm Stirring
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 2 Should United States athletes on official international teams be allowed to live in separate but approved housing outside Olympic quarters?

title: SAMUEL GELMAN, HOSPITAL OFFICIAL
description: Dr. Samuel J. Gelman, exec utive vice president of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn, died Sun day of a heart attack at his home, 80 Donnybrook Road, Scarsdale, N.Y. His age was 58.

title: ALBANY NOTES DROP IN TAX COLLECTIONS
description: ALBANY, Aug. 2 (UPI)  Tax collections for the first third of the state's fiscal year were about $118  million be hind last year's level, the Tax Department said today.

title: Cunard Board Favors Offer
description: LONDON, Aug. 2The board of the Cunard Steamship Company recommended today acceptance of an offer of $65.5million to take over the company. The offer was made by Trafalgar House, a huge property group. The new offer, an increase of $3.1million over its previous bid, is worth $5.04 a share.

title: 1,500 Calmly Flee A Burning Building Without Injuries
description: Fifteen hundred people were evacuated in less than 15 min utes from the 42story West vaco Building at 299 Park Ave nue yesterday afternoon after a smoky fire broke out in a 16thfloor storage room.

title: ASTRONAUTS LEAVE MOON AND DOCK SAFELY; ASCENT OF THE MODULE TELEVISED TO EARTH
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2The two moonexploring astronauts of Apollo 15 blasted off the lunar surface today, in the first tele vised launching from another world, then rejoined their orbit ing command ship two hours later.

title: ASHE DOWNS PILIC IN U.S. PRO TENNIS
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 2 (UPI)Arthur Ashe of Miami, avenging an upset loss to Nikki Pilic two weeks ago, defeated the tall Yugoslav, 64, 63, today in the first round of the $50,000 United States pro tennis, championships.

title: Sergeant on Force for 20 Years Accused of Bribery in Brooklyn
description: A police sergeant with 20 years on the force was ac cused of bribery yesterday after he allegedly tried to shake down the operator of a social club in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: OTB's Spa Action $137,944 Despite Long Waits at Windows
description: A balky tape that failed to transmit $8,926 worth of daily double action to Saratoga gave the Offtrack Betting Corpora tion a $4,491 windfall yester day in what was otherwise wastefully inefficient upstate debut.

title: Prefontaine Takes PanAm 5,000 Title
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 2 Steve Prefontaine continued United States dominance of longdistance track and field events at the PanAmerican Games tonight with a convinc ing victory in the 5,000meter run.

title: State Panel Named To Study Finances And Service of City
description: All 10 city superagencies and the city's overall fiscal policies will be examined at public hearings by a new state com mission whose full membership was announced yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DAY OP THE JACKAL. By Frederick Forsyth. 379 pages. Viking. $7.95.

title: Draft Bill Snagged; Delay in House Vote Until Fall Expected
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 2 (AP) The twoyear draftextension bill, already in trouble in the Senate, hit a parliamentary standoff in the House tonight, apparently ending chances for Congressional approval before September.

title: Like It or Not, DDT Is Good for You
description: Why is it so necessary to defend DDT and to resist attempts to ban it? First, let it be clear that saving DDT will not protect the profits of the chemical industry. Quite the contrary. The replacement insecticides cost far more than DDT, which sells for around 17 cents a pound. DDT is the poor man's chemicalfor 25 years the life saver of the emerging peoples. So we shall dismiss the rubbish about the robber barons who are allegedly try ing to con the public into continuing to buy DDT.

title: House, 351 to 36, Asks H.E.I. for Data on School Busing, Hinting Opposition
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The House ordered today that the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare furnish Congress with information on the extent of school busing to achieve ra cial balance.

title: New Drive by Laotian Army Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 2 Western military sources re ported today a determined push by the Laotian Army toward the town of Pak Song, a key control point on the Boloven Plateau in the southern pan handle. Pak Song and the plateau were overrun by North Vietnamese anti Pathet Lao forces in May.

title: Rail Line Dispute Based on Definition
description: Is a seven  hour  and  46 minute round trip on a train a commute? And is some one who makes the trip twice a week a commuter? Many people in New York's peaceful rural Upper Harlem Valley say the answer to both those questions is yes. Attor ney General Louis J. Lefko witz agrees with them. The Penn Central says no, and ap parently Governor Rockefel ler agrees with the line.

title: BUS FIREBOMBED BY ANGRY YOUTHS
description: A crowd of about 100 youths went on the rampage in the East Village last night, setting scattered fires in trash cans firebombing a passing bus and breaking into two stores, fol lowing the arrest of a man carrying 22caliber pistol by two plainclothes men.

title: JOHN M'DERMOTT JR., WON GOLF OPEN IN '11
description: YEADON, Pa., Aug. 2 (UPI) John J. McDermott Jr., the youngest man to win the United States Open golf championship, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Rwanda Suffers in Neighbors' Dispute
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 2 Tanzania and Uganda are at each other's throats diploma tically, but it is the little coun try of Rwanda that is stran gling.

title: Canadian Leads Series
description: PORT WASHINGTON, LI., Aug. 2Gordie Brown, a 20 yearold sailing instructor from Montreal, led after three races today in the North American Yacht Racing Union's Mallory Cup semifinal series.

title: Senate Votes Radio Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) The Senate passed and sent to the House today a stopgap bill that authorizes $35million this year for Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty, both of which broadcast to Eastern Europe.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Fall at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Gov erment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: Convicted Jersey Officials Formally Ousted by Council
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 2The City Council voted unanimous ly today that Mayor Thomas J. Whelan and Council Presi dent Thomas M. Flaherty were guilty of crimes of moral turpi tude when they were convicted on extortion charges by a Fed eral jury July 5.

title: KEY LABOR PACTS HEARTEN MARKET
description: Peaceful developments on two key labor frontsthe steel in dustry and the railroadslifted stock prices briskly yesterday in a reversal of last week's nearrout in the market.

title: A WAR POWERS BILL APPROVED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The House passed and sent to the Senate today a war powers bill that would require the Presi dent to report promptly to Con gress when he commits the armed forces to conflict with out specific Congressional authorization.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ernest R. Schmidt, ExAide With the Budd Company, 76
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 Ernest R. Schmidt, a former ex ecutive vice president and director of the Budd Company, died yesterday in Temple Hos pital. He was 76 years old and lived in Huntingdon Valley.

title: S.E.C. Seeks BrokerageDisclosure Rule
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2  The Securities and Exchange Commission is working on a new rule that would require brokerage firms to make pub lic disclosure of their finan cial condition and other sig nificant facts, chairman Wil liam J. Casey said today.

title: JERSEY NUN FREED IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 2Sis ter Margaret Murtha, the Do minican nun who went to jail five days ago for refusing to cooperate in a grand jury mur der investigation, was freed today when the case was re manded to Juvenile Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place:
description: Those who keep score cards on mutual fund portfo lio activity have frequently totted up the amount of money invested in various industries and the natural in ference is often drawn that if these stocks are favorites of the pros they ought to be pretty good for the average investor, too.

title: Advertising:
description: An anonymous caller said before hanging up that Pan American World Airways and its agency, J. Walter Thomp son, were coming to a part ing of the ways. So calls were placed to both parties.

title: GAINS ARE REPORTED BY DUQUESNE LIGHT
description: The Duquesne Light Com pany reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: Norwalk Paper Is Renamed
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 2  The Norwalk Hour, a daily newspaper that observed its 100th anniversary last spring, omitted the word Norwalk from its nameplate today, and is henceforth to be known simply as The Hour. Officials said the change was made to reflect the paper's policy of expansion to cover the heart of Fairfield County, rather than just the one city.

title: Dodgers Activate Sudakis
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (UPI) The Los Angeles Dodgers re activated Bill Sudakis today. The disabled catcher had been out since June 14 with an in jured right knee.

title: 6 GROUPS SEEKING A HOSPITAL ON S.I.
description: If the United States Public Health Service should give up its 636bed hospital on Staten Island, six private organizations say they are ready to take it over to serve the island's rapidly growing population.

title: Mitchell Is Given Summary Of a Report on Kent State
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 David L. Norman, acting head of the Justice Department's Civil Rights Division, said in a letter today that he had given Attorney General John N. Mitchell a summary of a pri vate report released last month on the Kent State shootings.

title: STORE OWNER HERE SENTENCED IN FRAUD
description: Shepard Boneparth, owner of a furniture and appliance store in Harlem, was sentenced yes terday to two weeks in jail and fined $1,000 for using a decep tive form to obtain financial information about customers with overdue bills.

title: Compusamp Names Director
description: Andrew Fisher, formerly an executive vice president of The New York Times, has been elected to the board of direc tors of Compusamp, Inc., a computerized sampling organ ization, it was announced yes terday. Mr. Fisher is also a member of the board of trustees of Russell Sage Col lege and the Albany Medical College and Is a director of the Harvard Business School Club of New York.

title: HARTFORD VETOES WITHSTAND TEST
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 2The Connecticut General Assembly reconvened today to review the 173 vetoes, a record, by Gover nor Thomas J. Meskill, but rigid adherence to party politics forced a virtual stalemate.

title: Man in the News
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2While the men of lunar module Falcon roamed the moun tains and valleys of the moon, Joseph Percival Allen 4th served as the single hu man link between them and the hundreds of technicians, engineers and scientists on earth. His role during all three surface ex plorations of the moon was that of what the space agency calls the capsule commu nicator, a term left over from the days of the Mercury program when the spacecraft was little more than a cap sule. If that term, now short ened to Capcom, was not yet an anachronism, it is now.

title: Shop Talk
description: In the days when almost everyone lived in a house and had an attic, or when everyone's grandmother lived in a house with an attic, it was easy to keep odds and ends of cloth that could be used for patchwork.

title: A Little Red Book
description: HAVANAWhen I came to Cuba recentlymy third visit since 1968 1 brought with me a little red book. Not the prescriptions and prophecies of Chairman Mao, but a 22page pamphlet of the Department of State: U.S. Policy Toward Cuba.

title: ANTHONY PETRONELLA
description: PROVIDENCE, Aug. 2 (AP) Anthony Petronelia, a longtime boxing supervisor for Rhode Island and former president or the National Boxing Associa tion, died yesterday after a re cent operation. His age was 64.

title: French Reds, Seeking New Image, Move Into a Modern Home
description: PARIS, Aug. 2The French Communist party began moving into new headquarters today as part of its modernization process. But a poll indicated that for a large part of the French public, it is still the same old party.

title: COCACOLA RAISES EARNINGS TO PEAK
description: The CocaCola Company achieved record secondquarter earnings of $48,660,439, or 82 cents a share, up 14 per cent from the yearearlier $42,453, 263, or 72 cents a share, the company reported yesterday from Atlanta.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The first televised liftoff of a manned space craft from the moon had none of the beauty and power of those moments when a huge Saturn rocket rises ma jestically into space from Cape Ken nedy. The quick pop that sent off the Falcon in a shower of sparks looked more like something held over from the Fourth of July, and the part of the landing craft left on the moon was all too suggestive of an auto graveyard.

title: Sun Oil Planning Units
description: The Sun Oil Company an nounced yesterday a plan to reorganize marketing, refining, exploration and production operations into two separate subsidiaries of a new Pennsyl vania corporation. The re organization will not change the rights of shareholders or bondholders.

title: LEO MARGOLIN, 60, COLLEGE OFFICIAL
description: Leo J. Margolin, head of the business administration division of Manhattan Community Col lege, and a former reporter and public relations man, died yes terday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Notes on People
description: Maurice H. Stans, the Sec retary of Commerce, yester day appointed John L. Jen kins, a black official of the department, to head minority business programs, thus end ing a behindthescenes strug gle over the position.

title: Vietnam Election
description: Failure to replace promptly the resigning chief nego tiator in Paris with his designated successor, Ambassador Porter, suggests that Washington may be deliberately delaying a serious reply to the new peace proposals submitted by the Communists one month ago. One apparent reason would be an Administration hope that the forthcoming presidential election in South Vietnam, scheduled for Oct. 3, will somehow strengthen the allied position for a negotiated settlement, or even for a satisfactory resolution of the conflict without negotia tions. The way the election campaign is shaping up today, there is little evidence to sustain that hope.

title: Senate Backs Lockheed, 4948
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The Senate, by a onevote margin, gave final Congressional ap proval today to legislation aimed at saving the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

title: HARRELSON CARDS A 76 IN PRO DEBUT
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 2 (AP) Ken Harrelson battled a balky putter and struggled to a 76 today in his first brush with professional golf, but the for mer baseball star promised to break par tomorrow.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW INCREASE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted their first ad vance in nine sessions yester day as most stocks rose in moderate trading.

title: Rage of Paris: What Chinese Wear at Work
description: PARIS, Aug. 2The newest rage in Paris is the Chinese worker's suit. It has over shadowed perfume, gloves and scarves as the object of tourists' quests along the Faubourg SaintHonor. Artists, working people and students are already wearing the heavy navy blue cotton suit as a utili tarian garment, and it's likely to be the next big fashioninthestreet.

title: Miss Casals Is Defeated In Final of Tennis in Venice
