description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 2 (UPI) Mrs. Helga Masthoff of West Germany won the $4,400 Venice women's open tournament to day with a 36, 64, 63 victory over Rosemary Casals of San Francisco.

title: $180,000 in Grants Offered By Creative Artists Program
description: Commissions totaling $140, 000 are being offered to profes sional artists in various crea tive fields by the 197172 Creative Artists Public Service Program.

title: NIXON AIDES FEAR STEEL OUTPUT CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2The the 8 per cent price increase White House criticized today announced by the United States Steel Corporation and later fol lowed by a number of other major steel producers.

title: THE JEWS OF ISRAEL AND U.S. COMPARED
description: REHOVOT, Israel, Aug. 2  Thirty American Jewish and Israeli intellectuals and com munity leaders today debated the differences between Jews as a minority in America and majority in Israel.

title: JUDGE IN NASSAU IN POLITICAL FIGHT
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 2 A Nassau County District Court judge has violated the Republi can and Democratic parties' ban on crossendorsements from minor parties and will face a primary fight next month from the major parties.

title: POLICE CAPTAINS DENOUNCE INQUIRY
description: A group representing most of New York's police commanders has denounced the commission investigating allegations of po lice corruption and has told its members not to fill out a com mission financial report.

title: Geological Findings on Moon Indicate Triumphant Expedition
description: HOUSTON Aug. 2  With their liftoff from the moon to day the Apollo 15 astronauts have completed what may ul timately be regarded as one of the most triumph and expedi tions in the history of geology.

title: Britons Express Relief on Passage Of Lockheed Aid
description: LONDON, Aug. 2  British legislators and labor union leaders expressed relief tonight at the Senate's decision, which insures the continued produc tion of the RollsRoyce RB211 engine for the Lockheed L1011 Tristar airbus.

title: C.B.S. Laboratories Picks A Successor to Goldmark
description: Renville H. McMann Jr. has been appointed executive vice president of the Columbia Broadcasting System Laborato ries in Stamford, Conn., with the understanding that he will succeed Dr. Peter C. Goldmark as president on Dec. 31. Dr. Goldmark is retiring at the age of 65 to pursue other interests.

title: Jobless Space Engineers Seek New Careers in Trial Program
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 2 An experimental employment program began here today in an effort to find new careers for 200 engineers discarded by the shrinking aerospace indus try.

title: Critics Mark 25th, Year of the Computer
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 3The 25th anniversary of the invention of the electronic computer was celebrated today with an eve ning blacktie banquet and a long afternoon of shirtsleeve selfcriticism.

title: State Rehires OneThird Of Its LaidOff Employes
description: ALBANY, Aug. 3 (AP)The Rockefeller administration re ported today that it had rein stated  in comparable jobs nearly a third of the 3,378 per manent state employes who had been laid off earlier this year in an economy move.

title: Cuba Closes Embassy in Spain; Trade Talks Reported Broken
description: MADRID, Aug. 3The Cuban Embassy in Madrid was closed today, but the Spanish Govern ment said that relations be tween the two countries had not been severed.

title: City and Welfare Union Set A Tentative 27% Increase
description: The Social Service Employes Union and the city have reached a tentative agreement on a new contract that would provide in creased wages and benefits to taling 27 per cent over three years.

title: Albatross Draws the Outside for Stake
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 3 No handicapper could have improved on the job done blind ly today by Charles Plumb of the New York State Harness Racing Commission and Lee Benson, a trainer from Great Neck, L. I., as they officiated at the postposition draw for Friday night's $32,200 Commo dore Pace at Roosevelt Race way. The ninth annual one mile test for 3yearolds will have eight starters and Alba tross, everyone's choice to suc ceed, wound up in the No. 8 slot.

title: Okker Rallies to Defeat Fairlie At Longwood by 36, 76, 61
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 3 (AP)Slender Tom. Okker of the Netherlands rallied from the brink of elimination today to overtake Brian Fairlie of New Zealand for a 3.6, 7.6, 61 openinground victory in the $50,000 United States pro tennis championships at Long wood.

title: U.S., Abandoning Traditional Policy, Tells U.N. Group It Favors 12Mile Limit for Territorial Waters
description: GENEVA, Aug. 3  The united States, formally aban doning its traditional position favoring a threemile limit to territorial waters, proposed to day that the breadth of these waters off a coastal state be extended to 12 miles.

title: AID TO SEGREGATION IS LAID TO AIR FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Civil Rights Commission accused the Air Force and De fense Department today of us ing their influence to perpetuate segregated schools in Del Rio, Tex.

title: Cuba Downs U.S. Nine. In PayAm Games, 43
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 Fidel Castro has lost his fast ball, or so the story goes, but Cuba regained some of its tar nished amateur baseball pride today with a 43 victory over a young but determined United States Pan American Games team.

title: Pilot Says Wyoming Game Was Killed From Air
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The helicopter pilot who first told Federal agents that bald and golden eagles had been illegal ly shot from the air said today that antelope, elk, deer and Canada geese had also been shot illegally in the same man ner over Wyoming.

title: Dock Strike Talks Gain
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. (AP)Federal mediators called off today a scheduled meeting with three Governors in the monthlong dock strike because of what was described as prog ress in local bargaining, a me diation official said. Cancella tion of tomorrow's meeting of the Governors of California, Washington and Oregon with union and management in San Francisco was announced by J. Curtis Counts, director of the Federal Mediation and Concilia tion Service in Washington.

title: Missourian Asks U.S. Hand In Cleanup of Battery Park
description: A Missouri Congressman who has been complaining that Battery Park is a gar bage dump because of litter announced yesterday that he was drafting a bill that would authorize sending two Na tional Park Service employes to help the city clean up the park at the foot of Manhat tan.

title: Strike a Worker's Farewell
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 3 (AP)  Harry Blackwelder, a Southern Railway engineer, went back to work yesterday after the 18day railroad strike ended, but that was his last day of work. He retired today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 3 (AP)Rumania won the inter zone Davis Cup semifinals to day with a 41 victory over India.

title: Roundup: Blue's Attempt For No. 20 Fails Again
description: Vida Blue didn't win again, but he didn't lose either.

title: Stock Prices Drop Across Wide Front
description: Renewed selling pressure smacked a jittery stock market yesterday and sent prices top pling across a broad front. Stocks registered their second largest setback of 1971.

title: Dead Eagles Reported Found on Ranch
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 3 The United States Attorney for Wyothing, Richard V. Thomas, said today that an undeter mined number of dead eagles had been discovered on ranch owned by a Wyoming stockman. The eagles were under the bones of other ani inals.

title: ExJersey Aide Before Jury
description: NEWARK, Aug. 3 (AP) Robert J. Burkhardt, former Democratic state chairman, ap peared before a Federal grand jury here today. Mr. Burkhardt, who served as Secretary of State during Democratic admin istrations, appeared for a few minutes and then was excused.

title: House Votes to Cut Aid to Greek Junta And to Pakistanis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The House approved today, by a close vote, a foreign aid bill that would authorize $6.9 billion in economic and military assist ance over the next two years, but would suspend aid to Paki stan and Greece.

title: The Oregon Environment ...
description: The Oregon Legislature recently passed a set of bold new laws designed to help protect and enhance that state's unique environmental quality.

title: 4 Israelis Won't Serve; Term Army Occupying
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 (AP) Three Israeli men and a wo man said today they had sent their draft notices back to Defense Minister Moshe Day an with a letter saying they were not ready to serve in an occupying army.

title: DR. PAUL D. FOOTE, 83, LED GULF RESEARCH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Dr. Paul Darwin Foote, former director of research and execu tive vice president of the Gulf Research and Development Company, died at his home here yesterday. He was 83 years old.

title: HARRY BERGMAN, 86, EXPERT ON BEDROCK
description: Harry M. Bergman, an au thority on the soil and bedrock of Manhattan Island, died yes terday in the Florence Nightin gale Nursing Home, 175 East 96th Street. He was 86 years old yesterday and lived at 1 Fifth Avenue.

title: MRS. ROBERT FULLER
description: NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 3  Mrs. Dolf Weed Fuller, Weston civic leader, who was the wife of Robert E. Fuller, died yester day at Norwalk Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 86 Godfrey Road, Weston.

title: New Disney on Parade
description: What can you say about a Walt Disney production that rivets an army of youngsters, yet draws their cheers? They ate up the second edition of Disney on Parade last night at Madison Square Garden. That is all that matters or just about all.

title: China Reported Preparing Flexible Strategy for Nixon
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 3Be hind a screen of tough polem ics and propaganda, China's leaders are reported formulat ing a flexible strategy for their encounter with President Nixon.

title: 10 Railroads Roll After Costly Strike
description: The wheels rolled again yes terday on 10 railroads, ending an 18day selective strike by the United Transportation Union. The end came late, how ever, for many companies that had already suffered millions of dollars in losses.

title: Arms Aides Meet in Helsinki
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 3 (Reuters)The United States and Soviet delegations to the talks on the limitation of stra tegic arms held their seventh session today, in the Soviet Embassy here.

title: 2 Witnesses Found in Schweitzer Case
description: Two witnesses who are said to have information about an alleged bribe of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer said yesterday that they would honor subpoenas and appear next week before a Manhattan grand jury.

title: A World Without Birds?
description: PRINCETON, N. J.When people who know I am hooked on conserva tion ask me the familiar question, What's more importantbirds or people? I am tempted to reply, birds. As I know such a response never converts anyone, I try to Con vince them it is not an either/or situation, that there is plenty of room for both if we only cared enough to save them. It is sad that as a nation we have not cared enough.

title: Popes to Sell. Stock of Colonial Sand
description: Merger News

title: Sports Car Club Blamed for Failure To Publicize Racers
description: About Motor Sports

title: Senate Backs Curb On Party Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Senate reached agreement in a series of votes today on a cam paign spending formula that would limit each party's na tional ticket to radio and tele vision time worth $8.34million in 1972.

title: Tin Cup for Industry
description: By the narrowest of margins, Congress has launched the nation on a course that could make the Federal Gov ernment the underwriter for every mismanaged business, provided it is big enough and sick enough. That is the unhappy implication of the Congressional decision to go along with President Nixon's recommendation that it guarantee $250 million in hank loans to save the ailing Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

title: CONGRESS PRESSED ON NIXON PROGRAM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The White House expressed concern today over what it called Congress's leisurely pace on President Nixon's priority domestic legislation combined with the possibility of adjourn ment in midOctober.

title: Importers Say Antidumping Zeal Bars Competition
description: The American Importers As sociation charged yesterday that a recent get tough pol icy of the Treasury Department in enforcing antidumping reg ulations was raising a barrier to the legitimate competition of imports.

title: Bonwit Teller Ends LieDetector Tests Of Store Employes
description: William Fine, president of Bonwit Teller, said yesterday that the Fifth Avenue specialty store would discontinue its ex periment with polygraph in terviews, or liedetector tests.

title: PRIDE 'N JOY TAKES PONY HUNTER TITLE
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug 3 Nancy Baroody's Pride 'N Joy rallied to capture two classes today and win the large pony hunter championship at the Orange County Horse Show.

title: Car Standard Voted on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP)The Assembly voted, 64 to 0, today to require that toll new cars sold in California, beginning with 1974 models, be constructed to withstand a 5mileanhour front or rear collision without damage. The bill was approved May 18 by the Senate but must return there for approval of Assembly amendments before it can go to Gov. Ronald Reagan's desk.

title: Pearl S. Buck: The Two Chinas
description: PERKASIE, Pa.Time changes everything. This is a trite saying but it is annoying to realize how true trite sayings are. Verily there is nothing new under the sun! The United States now agrees to the admission of Com munist China into the United Nations. Communist China will be admitted.

title: Drug Use Up Among Vietnamese
description: NHATRANG, South Vietnam, July 31Some friends of Tran Tan, aged 15, who worked with him in a bar frequented by American soldiers asked him to sniff some white powder they were peddling. It made him feel strong and happy. Within a month he was injecting heroin into his arm twice a day.

title: Italian Takes Opening Event In Jumpoff at Dublin Show
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 3 (UPI)Capt. Rairhondo d'Inzeo of Italy won the opening event of the Dublin international horse show today with a clear round on Bellevue in a 19horse jumpoff.

title: A.S.P.C.A. and Its Critics Open a Joint Effort to Help the City's Animals
description: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and a coalition of humane organizations that have criticized the A.S.P.C.A. for inhumane practices have agreed to set up joint com mittees to insure a coopera tive effort to improve the lot of all New York City ani mals.

title: HALL WINNING SAILOR IN MALLORY CUP TEST
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 3  Graham Hall of Sea Cliff Y.C., representing the Long Island Sound Yacht Rac ing Association, won the Mal lory Cup semifinal series today.

title: N.A.S.D. Says Flooding May Affect Quotations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)The National Associa tion of Securities Dealers said today that because of tele phone cable problems, the association's automatic quo tation system for the over thecounter stock market may be out of line with actual market prices for some stocks.

title: Japan Irked on Nixon Trip
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3Intellectu ally I know that another war between Japan and the United States is unthinkable, the Japanese official said. But emotionally, I sense a kind of prePearl Harbor atmosphere in the relations between our two countries.

title: U.N. Votes to Send Inquiry As Guinea Forecasts Attack
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3The Security Council voted unanimously tonight to send a special commission of three of its members to the West African Republic of Guinea to investigate charges by President Sekou Toure that his country is about to be in vaded by forces based in the neighboring territory of Portu guese Guinea.

title: House Panel Approves Bill On Land Claims in Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)The House Interior Sub committee on Indian Affairs ap proved a bill today that would award 40 million acres of land and $925million in cash to set tle Alaskan native land claims and help clear the way for construction of the Alaskan oil pipeline.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 14.89Point Decline In Prices of Stocks Is 2d Biggest of '71
description: Fears of continued inflation and a possible increase in the prime lending rate sent stock prices tumbling yesterday in the second biggest setback of 1971. The DowJones industrial aver age plummeted 14.89 points to 850.03.

title: Shiedler Beats Out Price To Win Title Midget Sailing
description: MORICHES, L. I., Aug. 3 Howard Shiedler of the Baby lon Yacht Club captured the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing championship today. He won the fifth event of the series and was third in the finale to out point Michael Price of Moriches and Kai Madsen of Bay Shore in the sixrace roundrobin series.

title: U.S. Group Appeals To Kosygin to Allow Visit to Jewish Area
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3  Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, who ar rived here II days ago at the head of an 11man delegation from his National Economic Growth and Reconstruction Or ganization, or NEGRO, has ap pealed to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin In allow the group to visit the capital of the Jewish Autonomous Region.

title: STEEL PRICE RISE JOINED BY INLAND
description: More steel producers an nounced yesterday that they would match the 8 per cent price increases on nearly all steel products, initiated Mon day by the United States Steel Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sculptures Come Out Into Environment
description: The chatter of power tools fills the air, and there's mar ble everywherein big blocks and small chips and minute particles that powder clothes and hair. Sidewalk superin tendents stop to kibitz, and youngsters come in flocks to watch and talk.

title: British Reserves Grow; French Relax the Franc
description: LONDON, Aug. 3Britain's gold and dollar reserves climbed for the 10th successive month to hit a new high of $3.87bil lion in July, Treasury figures showed today.

title: Mets Top Reds, 94, After a 52 Defeat
description: Things got worse before they got better for the New York Mets last night as they divided a doubleheader with the Cin cinnati Reds before 47,271 per sons in. Shea Stadium.

title: Peking, Taipei and the U.N.
description: The carefully drafted announcement by Secretary State Rogers that the United States would support the admission of Peking to the United Nations while opposing the expulsion of Taipei responds to the realities of the world situation.

title: TRIAL FOR DESERTION BEGINS FOR EXP.O.W.
description: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 3 (AP)The trial of Marine Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney of West Baby lon, L. I., began today one day ahead of schedule, after a sur prise move by the defense to waive trial by a courtmartial board and have the evidence heard by a military judge alone.

title: U.S. and Industry Seeking To Convert Coal Into Gas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The Government and industry joined forces today in a re search project to turn coal into cleanburning gas. The proj ect will cost $296million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Music: Mostly Mozart
description: Fashions in Mozart playing have oscillated several times during the last 50 years, and there is no reason to believe they will ever stop entirely until musicians are extinct. There was a time when all the better Mozart pianists tinkled away in courtly style, in hopeful pursuit of the graceful galant manner that flourished in his time. More recently, a weightier ap proach has been applied, par ticularly in the piano con certos, which can stand up to any composer's best, Beethoven's not excepted.

title: John Sloane, 88, ExChairman Of Furniture Company, Is Dead
description: OLD BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 4John Sloane, who retired in 1955 as chairman of the Man hattan furniture concern of W. & J. Sloane, Inc., died yesterday in Putnam Memorial Hospital, Bennington, after a short illness., He was 88 years old and lived also at 1107 Fifth Avenue in New York.

title: U.S. Envoy Reports Rise In Opposition in Greece
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Henry J. Tasca, United States Ambassador to Greece, report ed today that there was grow ing intensity of opposition to the military junta there, Con gressional sources said.

title: Buy a Candelabrum and Get a Free Wine Bottle to Put It On
description: Shop Talk

title: Moderate Leads in Mississippi Race for Governor
description: JACKSON, Miss., Wednesday, Aug. 4Lieut. Gov. Charles L. Sullivan, a racial moderate, led the field handily in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Mississippi in yes terday's primary.

title: COAST OPERA NAMES LONDON AS DIRECTOR
description: George London, the former Metropolitan Opera bass bari tone, has been named general director of the Music Center Opera Association in Los Ange les, a new company formed to produce opera for Los Angeles and southern California. Mr. London, whose appointment was announced yesterday by John A. McCone, chairman of the association, will begin immediately to prepare his first esason, 197374.

title: Eight Turn Down Jobs
description: Eight welfare recipients who refused to accept payless jobs in the agency will have their welfare payments terminated, a spokesman for the Department of Social Services said yester day.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Voids RadioTV Ban on Controversial Paid Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  The United States Court of Ap peals here ruled today that radio and television networks and stations must stop refusing to sell advertising time to political parties, antiwar advo cates and other groups that wish to buy time to broadcast controversial messages.

title: Ken Harrelson Survives Cut
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 3 (AP) Ken Harrelson survived the cut in his first pro golf tourna ment today, shooting a one overpar 73 for a 36hole total of 149 in the $20,000 Little American Golf Classic. Ross Randall of Alameda, Calif., carded a 68 on the 7,110yard Firestone North Course for a onestroke lead with 141.

title: CASE PUSHED TO BAR GETTYSBURG TOWER
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP)State Attorney General J. Shane Creamer charged to day that a proposed 307foot tourist tower overlooking the Gettysburg Battlefield would do irreparable harm to the en vironment and historic sig nificance of the area.

title: BEAUKINS VICTOR IN SARATOGA RACE
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3It rained here most of today, cutting the attendance to 12,026 at the Saratoga race track.

title: RAIL CHIEF SEES RATE RISE NEEDED
description: The chief executive officer of the Union Pacific Railroad, John C. Kenefick, said yester day that the railroads almost certainly would have to have a general freightrate increase to help offset the cost of the settlement of the selective strike of the United Transpor tation Union.

title: LONGEVITY LINKED TO REDUCED DIET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3Ex periments disclosed today at a scientific conference show that some mice live longer and are less likely to get cancer if their lifetime food intake is reduced sharply.

title: Atlantic City's Better Half Is All Most Tourists See
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 3 On the Boardwalk of this sweltering seaside resort, thousands of tourists stroll during the summer days and nights, seeking the pleasure promised by ocean breezes, neon signs and cotton candy.

title: Ludwig A. Anselmini, Official Of International Nickel, 54, Dies
description: Ludwig A. Anselmini, who was consumer product indus tries manager for the Inter national Nickel Company, Inc., died on Monday at the Scho harie County Community Hos pital in Cobleskill, N. Y., after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: Chanteys and Drama at Pier 15
description: The bygone days of Ameri can sailing vessels came pungently to life yesterday in So Long, My Tottie!, an 85 minute combination of sea chanteys and drama authen tically rigged to the past and performed on an old down town pier.

title: Black Banking
description: Economic Analysis

title: Key Witness Against Alleged Mafioso Is Feared Slain After Suffolk Escape
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 3  Tile state's key witness in the trial of a reputed lieutenant in the alleged Mafia family of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. has es caped from custody, it was dis closed today. The Suffolk County District Attorney's of fice fears he may have been kid napped and slain after his es cape.

title: RICHARD SKINNER, STAGE PRODUCER
description: Richard Skinner, a Broadway producer who played an impor tant part in the growth of sum mer repertory theater away from the city, died Tuesday in the Lynwood Nursing Home, 306 West 102d Street, after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: U.S. Shifts Nerve Gas to Atoll
description: JOHNSTON ISLAND, Aug. 3 (UPI)A shipment of approxi mately 5,300 tons of nerve and mustard gas shipped from Oki nawa arrived today at this tiny atoll 700 miles southwest of Hawaii.

title: Taxi Agency Bars '72 Dodges; Calls for Three Modifications
description: The 1972 Dodge was rejected for use as a New York City taxicab yesterday by the city's new Taxi Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Instant Playground Shown Here Has Plenty of Give
description: At noon it was stacked in pieces on a small truck. Fif teen minutes later it was spread out over 2,500 square feet of West 102d Street, and 200 children were jumping on it, pounding, pummeling and yanking at yards and yards of soft, flexible plastic shapes.

title: TV: An Astronaut and DowntoEarth Commentary
description: Walter Cronkite, anchor man, and Walter M. Schirra, analystthat particular Co umbia Broadcasting System collaboration, going back to the Apollo 11 of July, 1969 and man's first steps on the moon, has been one of the more successful in televi sion's coverage of events in space.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Garozzo's Schedule Heavy In Competition at Chicago
description: In the Summer Nationals in Chicago last month it was possible to play three ses sions of bridge each day, be ginning about 9 A.M. and ending around midnight with brief breaks for meals. One of the few who undertook this strenuous program was the ubiquitous Benito Garoz zo of Rome, a holder of many world titles who played for several days in Chicago en route to a business appoint ment in New York.

title: Brazil Removes the Prosecutor In Case of Police Death Squads
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 The Brazilian public prosecutor who brought policemen to trial in the summary executions of petty criminals was removed from his assignment under Gov ernment pressure last night. He had found the military Govern ment's bestknown political po liceman at the center of one of the vigilante groups known as death squads in Brazil's larg est city.

title: Washington Post Appoints Simons Managing Editor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Washington Post announced to day the appointment of Howard Simons as managing editor. Mr. Simons, who has been deputy managing editor since October, succeeds Eugene C. Patterson, who resigned yes terday to become a professor at Duke University.

title: U.S. May Sell 110 Planes To Israelis Over 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Nixon Administration is con sidering a plan to modernize the Israeli Air Force by selling it about 110 jets over the next three or four years.

title: Washington: For the Record
NIXON DISAVOWS H.E.W, PROPOSAL ON SCHOOL BUSING
description: Text of President's statement is printed onPage 15.

title: Rocks and Soil From Hadley Base May Disclose Major Chapters in Lunar History
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3The ex ploration of another outpost on the earth's frontier is now complete.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) Tom Gorman, the Buckeye in vitation champion, hopped off a single engine charter plane, waited out a three hour rain today and defeated John Pecks kamp of Cincinnati, 63, 75, in a firstround match of the $50,000 Western tournament championship at the Cincinnati Tennis Club.

title: NARCOTISM KILLS NEGRO SCULPTOR
description: James Lightbourne, who spent 29 months in jail awaiting trial on a murder charge and then was acquitted, was found dead in bed early Monday morning of what the Medical Examiner described as acte and chronic intravenous narcotism.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN CORN FUTURES
description: Wheat and corn were mixed, oats fractionally higher and soybeans higher at the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: GEORGE W. SJOBLOM, A CHORUS MANAGER
description: George W. Sjoblom, who had been manager for a number of Finnish choruses on tours of this country, died last Thurs day in Lutheran Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old and lived at 661 41st Street, Brooklyn.

title: French Ease Franc Curbs
description: PARIS, Aug. 3The Govern ment virtually eliminated ex change controls today for French tourists traveling abroad. Other restrictions on franc transfers for business reasons were also considerably loosened.

title: $35Million Lost by California Farmers
description: FIREBAUGH, Calif., Aug. 3 The trains started rolling again today, hauling fruit and vegetables to waiting Eastern markets, but the legacy of the 18day railroad strike will ling er a long time here in Cali fornia's rich farm country.

title: MEDICAID IN CITY SCORED IN AUDIT
description: Health Department monitor ing indicates that 5 to 10 per cent of reported service under the Medicaid program for the poor is unacceptable and that low fees are in part responsi ble, First Deputy Commissioner Lowell E. Bellin said yesterday.

title: AMEX DROP WORST SINCE MAY, 1970
description: The American Stock Ex change took its worst beating in more than 14 months yesterday as prices tumbled in moderate trading.

title: Stay Given on Discontinuing Penn Central Runs Upstate
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3A Federal judge today ordered the Penn Central to continue passenger train service between New York City and Chatham, N. Y., on its Upper Harlem Valley line until Sept. 7.

title: QUARRIE WINS 200 IN PANAM GAMES
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 United States track and field athletes saw their string of suc cesses in the PanAmerican Games interrupted again to night by Donald Quarrie of Jamaica.

title: 4 Watson Jurors Excused
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) Four more potential jurors were excused today as jury selection continued in the trial of Charles (Tex) Watson for the seven Sharon Tate murders. Twentytwo potential jurors have been excused since the trial opened yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ... and Remember Maine
description: State of Mainers have won another important battle in their fight to protect the unique beauty of their 3,000 mile coastline with its rich fisheries resources.

title: Ellington Changes Format on Return To Rainbow Grill
description: Duke Ellington's annual Au gust visit to the Rainbow Grill, where he appears with a small group drawn from his full or chestra, can usually be counted on by Ellington followers as an opportunity to hear the Duke from the set routine he has been following in his concert appearances during the previ ous year.

title: Original Endeavour Had A Water Problem, Too
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The Apollo 15 astronauts were told today how disaster was averted 201 years ago by James Cook, the English explorer and captain of En deavour, seagoing predeces sor of their spaceship.

title: JUNE CRIMES DOWN BUT VIOLENCE RISES
description: The number of crimes re ported to the police in June showed an overall decrease of 5.1 per cent from the figures for June, 1970, according to statistics released yesterday.

title: ExOfficer of Diners' Club Sentenced in Conspiracy
description: A former vice president of the Diners' Club in charge of computer operations received a oneyear prison sentence in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiring in false dealings and charging the club for work that was not done.

title: Text of Nixon Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI)Following is the text of President Nixon's state ment today on the busing of schoolchildren:

title: 1,000 Wait in Rain, But Philharmonic Gives Up Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic, caught out in Central Park last night in a heavy rain and, an electrical storm, failed to open its summer season of parks concerts. But not for lack of an audience. Perhaps a thou sand watersoaked enthusiasts, most of them huddled under umbrellas, squatted determined ly in the Sheep Meadow, which had been turned into a bog by intermittent rain hours before the concert's scheduled 8:30 starting time.

title: PressureBomb Threat Diverts a Jet to Denver
description: A bomb hoax diverted a Londonbound 747 jumbo jet from Montreal to Denver yes terday before the plane flew on to England with 361 pas sengers and a crew of 22 aboard.

title: Books of The Times
description: BASEBALL: The Golden Age. By Harold Sey mour. 492 pages. Oxford. $12.50.

title: Tenneco Raises 3Month Net 18%
description: Tenneco, Inc., the Houston based producer of oil and gas, chemicals, machinery, ships and other goods, achieved an 18per cent increase in second quarter earnings on a gain of 14 per cent in revenues, N. W. Freeman, chairman and presi dent reported yesterday.

title: Robert Morse Is Nominated As a U.S. Attorney Here
description: Robert A. Morse, the chief assistant United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York, was nominated yesterday by President Nixon to be United States Attorney for the District, which encompasses Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

title: Giants' Players Make Their Points in Show
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 3 In a summer season of complicated playermanage ment relationships, the Giants took a break last night to attend a boutique sized musical called simply the Rookie Show at C. W. Post's Little Theater.

title: Arlan's President Resigns; No Successor Is Named
description: Warren Eisenberg, president of Arlan's Department Stores, Inc., has resigned, it was an nounced yesterday by Sidney E. Kamino, chairman of the board. No successor has been named.

title: Senate Votes Funds for Red Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3The Senate approved late today by a margin of two votes a con ference report that upholds an expansion in the power of the Subversive Activities Control Board sought by the Adminis tration.

title: 3 Vietnam Veterans Ask Raids on P O.W. Camps
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Three soldiers told a House committee today of spending agonizing months chained in side jungle cages as prisoners of the Vietcong and voiced the hope that the United States would carry out more forays like last year's raid on a North Vietnames prisoner of war camp.

title: A First for Long Island
description: The proposed transportation center at Farmingdale on Long Island promises a substantial, gain for the people of eastern Nassau and western Suffolk counties. It may not quite add up to what Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, calls the most modern transportation facilities in the nation. But, as the first attempt to give coherence to travel by rail, air, bus and automobile, it deserves full encouragement.

title: 2 NEWSPRINT MAKERS JOINING PRICE RISES
description: The Boise Cascade Corpora tion and the International Paper Sales Company, Inc., yesterday joined the ranks of newsprint producers who plan to raise prices by $8 a ton, effective Nov. 1. International Paper Sales is a subsidiary of the Canadian International Paper Company, which is a unit of the International Paper Com pany.

title: East Pakistan's Tea Plantations Hear Thunder of Border Guns
description: SYLHET, East Pakistan, July 30The tea planters Of Sylhet, whose way of life for the past century has symbol ized the majesty of the Brit ish empire in a colonial land, have been dealt a series of blows by guerrilla in the past few months. An institution may be ending.

title: Macbeth Soliloquy On Suicide Chalked Near Youth's Body
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 3 The body of a 17yearold Garden City youth who had scrawled a soliloquy from Shakespeare's Macbeth on blackboard before apparently committing suicide by gas was found today in a chemistry laboratory at Garden City High School.

title: Typical Day at Cali: Riot, Defection, Disaffection
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 3 A boxing riot, the defection of a Cuban athlete, the con demnation of a Colombian hero and a contingency crisis for two American marathan ers have added more tumult to the first week of the Pan American Games.

title: PROTEST UPHELD IN COWES SAILING
description: COWES, England, Aug. 3 (Reuters)  Britain's hand some 47point lead in the Ad miral's Cup yacht races was slashed tonight to 9 points aft er an Australian protest was upheld:

title: Shipyard's Workers Seek Control of Clyde Builders
description: CLYDEBANK, Scotland, Aug. 3  Angry Scottish shipyard workers are trying to assert control over a bankrupt ship building group here to protest the bleak economic prospects for the Glasgow region of Scot land.

title: OUTLOOK ON PRIME DEPRESSES BONDS
description: The Government bond mar ket yesterday was troubled by the possibility of another round of prime rate increases, and prices declined.

title: Ghana Awards Mine Rights
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 3 (Reu ters)  The Americanowned Volta Aluminum Company has won prospecting rights for the development of bauxite de posits at Kibi in eastern Ghana, it was announced today.

title: Philip Levin, Head of Madison Square Garden, Dies
description: Philip J. Levin, president and chief operating officer of the Madison Square Garden Corporation since February, died of a heart attack early yesterday in his suite at the Pierre Hotel. Mr. Levin, who was 62 years old, lived on 106acre estate in Warren, N.J.

title: Notes on People
description: F. Edward Hbert, chair man of the House Armed Services Committee, has ap pointed an active antiwar Congressman, Lucien N. Nedzi, a Michigan Democrat, chairman of the House sub committee that keeps an eye on the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Lower Courts Here Cut Jams, but Serious Cases Rise
description: The city's complex crim inal justice system, bulging with a quarter of a million new cases a year, is operat ing more rapidly and smooth ly in the lower courts than in many years.

title: Executive Changes
description: H. P. Hood & Sons announced yesterday the election of John M. Fox as president and chief executive officer. Mr. Fox, who recently re signed as president of the United Brands Com pany and its United Fruit Company division, suc ceeds Ezra Merrill as president. Mr. Merrill will become vice chair man of the board and Gilbert H. Hood will con tinue as chairman. Mr. Fox was a founder and president of the Minute Maid Corporation prior to joining the United Fruit Company in 1961. He is a director of Inter national Business Machines, Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, USM Corporation, and continues as director of United Brands. The Hood company, a leading New England dairy and food products company, said Mr. Fox will bring to the Hood company the experience needed to continue the diversification and expansion programs currently underway.

title: Mooring Finds CatchUp Pace For Jets' Tackle Spot Is Tiring
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 3 I'm tired, admitted big John Mooring, the Jets' No. 2 draft pick, just before going out on the Hofstra University field today for only his sec ond workout as a pro.

title: Nixon and Inflation: Policy Change Unlikely
description: News Analysis

title: U.S. Voluntary Unit Leaving Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3After 15 years in South Vietnam, one of the best known American volunteer organizations here, whose members have often attacked United States policy and the Indochina war, is being shut down.

title: City to End Blue Shield Contract Over Increase
description: The city announced yester day that it would end its con tract with United Medical Serv ice, Inc.Blue Shieldon Aug. 31, and leaders of municipal unions immediately said they would fight the move.

title: Jersey Cars Face Test Of Exhaust Emissions
description: TRENTON, Aug. 3New Jer sey environmental officials said today that they were going to start testing automobiles under the most comprehensive air pol lution inspection system in the country.

title: West Berlin Says It Erred In Identifying 2 Shot at Wall
description: BERLIN, Aug. 3The West Berlin government declared to day that it had erred in the identification of two men shot by East German border guards at the wall on July 24.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A privileged minority contrives to go through life strewing gratuities with such grandiose flourishes that the recipients knuckle their brows and even mutter words thanks. The suspicion is strong that these lordly creatures have overtipped as a cowardly way of protecting their egos.

title: OTB Insists It Won't Welsh on Bets it Books
description: New York's only legal book maker promised yesterday never to welsh on a bet.

title: Israeli Spy for Egypt Freed
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 (Reuters) Mordecai Luk, a 37yearold Is raeli jailed as a spy for Egypt has been released here seven years after he was found gagged, bound and drugged in an Egyp tian diplomatic trunk at the Rome airport.

title: Tose Case Is Dismissed
description: NORRISTOWN, Pa., Aug. 3 (AP)  A Montgomery County judge dismissed today with prejudice action by the wife of Leonard Tose, owner of the National Football League's Philadelphia Eagles, to have him declared incompetent to handle his financial affairs. Judge Alfred L. Taxis Jr. made the ruling when lawyer for Mrs. Andrea Tose failed to appear in court for resumption of the hearing.

title: Installment Credit Up Faster in June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Consumer installment credit rose by $525million in June, making the second quarter the strongest for this indicator since the last quarter of 1969, the Federal Reserve Board re ported today.

title: Fire in East Bronx Leaves 38 Homeless; Crowd Pelts Police
description: Thirteen firemen and two policemen were hospitalized last night for smoke poisoning and exhaustion after a fire swept through an apartment house in the East Bronx leaving 38 persons homeless.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 3 Prime Minister William Mc Mahon today welcomed the statement by Mr. Rogers, saying it clearly reflects the close ac cord of the United States and Australia on the China repre sentation issue.

title: Big Board Reports On Firms' Profits
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday that 47 per cent of the brokerage firms covered in a monthly survey by the exchange had losses on their commission business in the month of June.

title: STEAMFITTERS WIN PRAISE ON TRAINING
description: State Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine has commended Local Union 638 of the Steam fitters for adding 100 new journeymen from minority groups to the union rolls.

title: Advertising:
description: The newest agency in town opened its doors last week and heading it is a man well known to the advertising and marketing world, George J. Abrams.

title: HANS C. SONNE, 80, OF PLANNING UNIT
description: Hans Christian Sonne, who served for many years as board chairman of the National Plan ning Association, died yesterday at his home in Tuxedo Park, N. Y. He was 80 years old.

title: Trevino Is Hailed by 30,000 During His Day in El Paso
description: EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) Today was Lee Trevino Day and townsfolk by the thou sands turned out to welcome their favorite son, home for the first time since his sweep of the American, Canadian and British Open golf titles.

title: Idea of Conference Rejected
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 3 (Reu ters)China rejected today the idea of a new Geneva con ference on Indochina.

title: GAINS ARE LISTED BY COLUMBIA GAS
description: The Columbia Gas System, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the six months ended June 30.

title: Europa First to Finish
description: DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 3 (Ca nadian Press)A yacht from Chicago, Europa, was the first to complete the 1971 Trans Superior yacht race today, ar riving at 3:01 A.M. Europa was far ahead of the other 20 en tries, which were 20 to 60 miles away.

title: 4 More Victims of Rains In Baltimore Area Found
description: BALTIMORE, Aug 3 (AP) The bodies of four more vic tims of recent heavy rains in Baltimore County were recov red today as officals began alerting the public to possible health hazards. Firemen said the bodies of Warren Shaffer, 24 years old, a volunteer fire man; Robert M. Wood, of Jop pa, and a woman believed to be Mr. Wood's wife, Cecelia, were pulled from the Gunpow der River.

title: APOLLO 15 CHARTS MOON FROM ORBIT; HEADS BACK TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3  The Apollo 15 astronauts continued circling the moon today, con ducting the most extensive sci entific survey of the lunar sur face ever undertaken by a manned space mission.

title: Advertising:
description: The New York City Off Track Betting Corporation, whose logo and initials of OTB have become familiar to improvers of the breed all over the area, has appointed another agency for a special market.

title: PEKING
description: PEKING, Aug. 3The routine of life for an American visitor in China these days is full of paradox. For example, you live in an atmosphere of vicious and persistent antiAmerican propa ganda, but are treated with unfailing personal courtesy and are free to cable your impressions without cen sorship from the lobby of your hotel.

title: Greening of the Board Room
description: Shareholders meetings in 1971 were no humdrum business. Although James M. Roche, chairman of General Motors Corporation, may rail at the profes sional critics and the instant ecolo gists, socialpolitical proposals have been in the limelight now as they are in our society.

title: Torture Charge Made
description: ATHENS, Aug. 3The aged mother of a Greek student on trial here with 16 others for sedition fainted in court today when her son told the judges a police lieutenant testifying for the prosecution had tor tured him.

title: U.S. Increasingly Critical
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3In the wake of President Nixon's announcement that he would visit China, Administration of ficials have become increasingly free in their expression of ir ritation with Japan, the United States' major ally in East Asia.

title: Mrs. Phyllis Williamson Watts Married to Alexander Aldrich
description: Mrs. Phyllis Williamson Watts and Alexander Aldrich, who is president of the Brooklyn Center of Long Is land University, were married here last Friday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan's Exports Rise
description: TOKYO, Aug. 3 (UPI)Ja pan's licensed exports in July rose to alltime high of $2.36 billion, the Ministry of Inter national Trade and Industry, said today.

title: Market Place: Taking a Look At Sharon Steel
description: There is a great sense of trust in Sharon, Pa., the home of the Sharon Steel Corpora tion and a quiet community of some 25,000 people nestled in the Shenango River Valley just east of the Ohio State line.

title: Remember Bullet Belts? Now Uniform Is a Fad in Europe
description: PARIS  The big American fashion import on the streets of Europe this summer is the United States Army look. Tshirts in olive green, decorated with shoulder patches and insignia, have re placed last year's tiedyed Tshirt as the everyday uniform among the young. But multizippered pilots' jackets, fatigue green shorts and pants and camouflage colored suits are also ubiquitous.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES $1BILLION JOBS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP)  The House Appropriations Committee approved today $1billion emergency bill de signed to provide jobs in public service for an estimated 123, 400 to 172,000 persons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONIn preparing its assess ment as a preliminary to warming up SinoAmerican relations, the White House appears to have concluded that any kind of Chinese military descent into Southeast Asia is most improbable for at least the next five years, at very minimum, and indeed is unlikely for years to come.

title: ISRAEL REPORTED WEIGHING A PLAN
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 3Pre mier Golda Meir met with her closest Cabinet advisers in private session late tonight as the Israeli public heard sug gestion that the Government was considering reported Amer ican proposals for an Israeli pull back of about 25 miles from the Suez Canal.

title: HIGHLEAD PAINTS LISTED BY CITY
description: The city's Health Services Administration yesterday re leased the brand, names of in terior paints with excessive amounts of lead that could cause lead poisoning in children.

title: International Nickel Cuts Dividend
description: The International Nickel Com pany of Canada, Ltd., suffered one of its worst profit declines in this year's second quarter and first half, according to yes terday's midyear report. As a consequence, the board re duced the quarterly dividend to 25 cents from 40 cents, the sharpest reduction since 1944.

title: 18% FAIL TO TAKE WELFARE CHECKS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3  Governor Rockefeller said today that since New York State be gan requiring last month that employable welfare recipients pick up their relief checks at state employment offices and perhaps be compelled to accept a job, 18 per cent of the wel fare checks have gone un claimed.

title: U.S. Team Keeps Lead
description: CASCAIS, Portugal, Aug. 3 (AP)James Schoonmaker and Tom Dudinsky of the Biscayne Bay Yachting Club in Miami Beach retained their overall lead in the 32d European and North African Star Class open sailing championships today.

title: PRIMERATE RISE UPSETS CONNALLY
description: The Nixon Administration yesterday termed any increase in the prime lending rate un justified and said that such ac tion could put a general busi ness recovery in jeopardy.

title: Allied Planes Level 2 of Enemy's Cambodian Havens
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (AP)Allied aircraft leveled two Cambodian vil lages today and drove out North Vietnamese and Viet cong soldiers blocking a South Vietnamese advance in eastern Cambodia.

title: EARLY STUDY FOUND ROLLSROYCE SHAKY
description: LONDON, Aug. 3A confi dential report indicating that RollsRoyce, Ltd., was finan cially unsound had been made more than a year before the company went into liquidation last February.

title: Civic Groups Assail City Municipal Loan Program
description: A number of predominantly lowincome housing groups pre sented examples yesterday of what they termed grandscale fraud in the city's Municipal Loan Program, including inflat ed mortgages, kickbacks and other abuses.

title: Ford to Reopen Plants
description: DETROIT, Aug. 3 (UPI)The Ford Motor Company said to day it would reopen its Kansas City, St. Louis and Chicago assembly plants next Monday, recalling about 8,600 workers. They have been closed because of the railroad strikes.

description: Man in the News

description: DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP)The Burroughs Corporation will construct an 80,000squarefoot manufacturing and distribution center in Bardstown, Ky., the company announced yesterday.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 President Nixon asked Con gress today to appropriate $636,000 to begin an immediate and massive declassification of 160 million pages of World War II documents.

title: HOPING IS A CHOICE TO DIRECT '76 FETE

title: Seismic Net Set to Find Source of Tremors as Moon Nears Earth
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 3Some where inside the moon an ex traordinary upheaval occurs every time the moon comes closest to the earth and, within the next week, the location of this phenomenon may become apparent.

title: BUSH AND DELEGATES MEET ON CHINA ISSUE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3  George Bush, the United States delegate was host to other delegates today in what was understood to be the first of a series of meetings on tactics in dealing with the Chinese membership this fall.

title: Oil Industry Honors Scott

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Senator James L. Buckley of New York said today that the seating of mainland China in the United Nations would raise significant questions about the future of the world organi zation.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) A Chicago banker told Sen ate investigators today that his bank, relying on the word of favored customer, had been lured into granting $300,000 in loans secured by collateral that proved to be forged.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP] Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate completed Congressional action today on a $4.1billion StateJustice Commerce Department money bill, including funds for the Subversive Activities Control Board:

Phillips, also a member of the Milwau kee Common Council, to Mil waukee County Court. He will serve in the branch that han dles childrens cases.

title: Hassan Ousts Moroccan Cabinet
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 4 King Hassan II dismissed his Cabinet today and promised to rid the country of corruption. The moves came 25 days after a mutiny failed to depose him.

title: Norbert Ardelli Dies at 69; Opera Singer and Teacher
description: Norbert Ardelli, a singing teacher and former operatic tenor, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in the Ansonia Hotel.

title: Pennsylvania Lacks Funds

Pennsylvania has been unable to spend any money legally since midnight last Sat urday, when a bill providing emergency appropriations ex pired.

title: OBSERVER
description: There was an item in the paper the other day about the passing of the convertible. An open car, it appears, makes no sense any more even for the rich. On hot days they prefer turn ing on an airconditioner to peeling back a roof. This has something to do with the usually loathsome consist ency of the outside air in much of the country, but the more compelling consideration may be the turnpike speeds at which cars commonly travel nowadays. At 70 miles an hour, a ride in an open convertible is some thing like flying in an opencockpit airplane. In any event, the convertible, which once played a big part in every boy's dream of the sweet, soft, decadent, sinridden life, is about through. Chrysler has quit making them, and Ford and General Motors soon follow suit.

title: The Big Boys Against Prink Hill
description: PRINK HILLWhen he was work ing on our porch two springs ago, Ralph Teter, builder and neighbor, spoke the unbelievable words. He said the New York State Power Au thority had completed plans to build a massive power transmission ine through our community. Originating over the mountain at a pumped stor age plant in Blenheim and Gilboa, it will cross a ridge of Pisgah Moun tain, which is the western wall of our town, and go down through the Durham and Catskill valleys to Leeds near the Hudson River.

title: WagePrice Runaround

This hardly qualifies as leadership from a President who campaigned nearly three years ago on a pledge to couple price sta bility with low unemployment and has thus far failed to deliver either.

title: Pacifist Strategy of 'Johnny Got His Gun'
description: "Johnny Got His Gun," which opened yesterday at the R.K.O. 59th Street Twin Cinemas, was written and directed by Dalton Trumbo, after Mr. Trumbo's own antiwar novel, originally published in September, 1939, almost on the eve of World War II. The story strongly reflects the emotional strategy of pacifist sentiment between the wars, and in the film makes some effort to re-create not only the intentions, but also the tone of that strategy.The hero of "Johnny Got His Gun," whose name is Joe, is an American soldier who on the last day of World War I, has his arms, his legs and his face blown off by an artillery shell.Nevertheless, he survives, and, as a medical curiosity, he is kept alive beneath sheets and a gauze mask by doctors who believe that his brain is so damaged as to render him a living vegetable. They are wrong, however. Joe both feels and remembers, and his feelings and his memories are, in colored flashback and monochrome present action, the substance of the film.It should be obvious that, like its hero, "Johnny Got His Gun" is shrouded in virtue. But insistent virtue, without ideas, becomes demagoguery. "Johnny Got His Gun" has perhaps two ideas: one, that war is a crime, and two, that it is a crime committed by the old against the young. The first of these ideas seems unquestionable, but uninteresting. The second, though questionable, is also uninteresting. And yet they are virtually all the thought that gets into the film, the rest being a mess of clichd, imprecise sentimentalizing and fantasizing. On any terms that I might recognize and possibly credit, "Johnny Got His Gun" is a stultifyingly bad movie.Although Mr. Trumbo is primarily a screenwriter ("Hawaii," "The Sandpiper," "The Horseman," etc.), screenwriting is only the worst of the film's several failures. Each of the many reveries (Joe goes fishing with his father, Joe sleeps with his girl for the first time on the night before he leaves for war, etc.,) is directed for a kind of awkward open honesty that achieves only awkwardness instead. Although they are all wholly conventional in content and manner, they are all, in the ways they are photographed and staged, wholly grotesquelike the work of a Norman Rockwell who couldn't draw.The various nightmare fantasies, though as conventional (mostly neo-Fellini) are somewhat less grotesque, as if the director's imagination in aiming for the outlandish had fallen instead among the more comfortable old properties on a studio backlot. The hospital scenes, in setting very drab and rather formal, in the style of 1930's serious-movie interiors, are the most acceptableuntil they are ruined by Diane Varsi, a kindly nurse who finally gets through to Joe, in what may be one of the worst performances in the history of movies.Jason Robards plays Joe's father with the kind of awe at being just folks that he has long made familiar. Donald Sultherland plays Christ, a somewhat gratuitous role, with less awe but equal familiarity. The part of Joe is taken by Timothy Bottoms, a newcomer, and against all odds, he is very good. For reasons that I think have little to do with the writing or direction of his role, he brings a bit of real warmth and uncomplicated but cohesive humanity to "Johnny Got His Gun."

title: Diaper Rinse Warning
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 4 (UPI)  The American Academy of Pediatrics has warned that some baby clothes are still be ing laundered with substances that may be harmful to infants. The academy issued the warn ing in its current newsletter, saying some infants had be come ill after their diapers were rinsed in substances containing trichlorocarbanilide, or TCC.

description: Legal textual material is not to be construed as a protective screen for obscene pictures in publications.

title: The Ravaged People of East Pakistan
description: A planetary catastrophe Is taking place in Asia, a human disaster so massive that it could bathe the future in blood, not just for Asians, but for those of us in the West as well. Yet the response of the global community has been minimal at best In the United States, the official response has been worse than minimal and morally numb.

title: 2% of Businesses in U.S. Owned By Blacks in 1969, Survey Says

Based on a survey conducted by the Census Bureau, the report also indicates that receipts from blackowned businesses amount ed to less than half of 1 per cent of the nation's total busi ness revenues.

title: Yog -- Monster From Space'
description: Commandeering an unmanned Jupiter-bound rocket, a little cloud of shimmery blue spangles turns it around and rides it back to earth. The little blue cloud is in fact a militant astro-quasar bent on world domination. And though he is never introduced properly, I should guess that he is called Yog, Monster from Space, after the movie of the same name, which opened yesterday together with "Dr. Phibes" at neighborhood theaters.Yog lands near a Pacific island, a paradise but for its hyperactive volcano. He then occupies, in turn, the bodies of a huge, sub-zero, land-walking, man-eating octopus; an enormous hairy crab; a super-turtle; and a happy-go-lucky but somewhat unscrupulous resort hotel promoter.About the trouble he causes and the troubles he is caused, let there be silence. The crab, the turtle and the hotel promoter are nothing much. But the octopus, sensuously swaying on its eight legs, its red-and-white eyes flashing over the treetops, a swarm of bats circling its head, though not exactly lovable, it is at leastwell a little sexy.

title: Suit Is Filed Against State Aides on Migrant Housing

title: A Shoot-'Em-Up 'Lawman' Bows
description: Some cutting dialogue and boiling psychological tension are the most winning things about "Lawman," a potent but curiously exasperating Western with those three hardies, Burt Lancaster, Robert Ryan and Lee J. Cobb.This is the setup, familiar but perfectly viable. An iron-jawed realistic marshal, played by Lancaster, arrives in town to arrest an iron-jawed land baron and his henchmen for accidentally killing an old man. The crime, we repeat, was accidental and everybody knows it.Why, then, wouldn't this shrewd visitor ride straight to the ranch of his main quarry and confront this equally intelligent chap? This is Cobb. Instead, the intruder aggressively stalks around town, arousing the hatred of the good (and weak) citizens and the halfhearted support of a bright, weak sheriff, Ryan. Cobb's boys murderously go at the intruder one by one.There is, indeed, a baffling, oblique arrogance about the central character, played well by Lancaster, that belies his seeming quest for justice ("The law is the law"), the point of the film. But he is also a cold, egocentric fish. Wait till you see the final, main-street shoot-'em-up.While unresolved in substance, the picture is long on sting, as sharply directed by England's Michael Winner and cynically turned by the writer, Gerald Wilson. The acting is solid, straight down the line. Especially good are Robert Duvall, Albert Salmi and Sheree North, a lady who has never had her just acclaim.But it doesn't hold water, or convincing fire, for all the shooting.

title: JERSEY CITY PICKS AN INTERIM MAYOR
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 4The eightman City Council voted today behind closed doors to name Cliarles Krieger interim mayor until a special election Nov. 2 when a successor to Thomas J. Whelan is to be picked. Mr. Whelan was one of eight defendants found guilty July 5 by a Federal jury of extorting money from con tractors doing business with the city and with Hudson County.

title: Bridge: Overtricks Yield Big Profit In Duplicate MatchPoints
description: Those who played auction bridge before graduating to contract will recall that mak ing 12 tricks was a source of considerable profit even if the contract was fixed at a lower level.

title: House Approves Rise of $1Billion In Health Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The House passed and sent to the Senate today a bill ap propriating $20.8billion for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Protest Held in Hiroshima
description: HIROSHIMA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 6 (Reuters)Several young demonstrators tried to attack Premier Eisaku Sato here to day, but were dragged away by bodyguards. The Premier was attending Hiroshima's an nual memorial service for those killed in the atomicbomb attack on the city 26 years ago.

title: Prosecutor to Be Investigated In Illinois Black Panther Case
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5A judge here today appointed a state official to investigate the con duct of a special prosecutor whom the judge had named to investigate the slaying of two Black Panthers.

title: Bridge: Roth, in New Mayfair Home, Still Welcomes Everybody
description: One of the world's most famous bridge clubs acquired a new home and a new char acter earlier this week. The Mayfair House of Bridge, long established on 57th Street under the direction of Alvin Roth, and before him, Harry Fishbein, moved into luxurious new quarters at 14 East 60th Street and became a membership club.

title: HERBERTR. NOXON, ART DIRECTOR, 67
description: Herbert Richards Noxon, se nior art director of McCann Erickson, Inc., the advertising agency, from 1933 to 1964, who specialized in poster de signs, died Wednesday in Doc tors Hospital: He was 67 years old and lived at 1100 Madison Avenue.

title: Yanks Top Orioles, 50;
description: It was as if the Good Fairy of the East eradicated a curse that the Wicked Witch of the Midwest had placed upon Mel Stottlemyre in Minnesota four days ago.

title: Killing of Arsonists Is Sanctioned in Syracuse
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 5After the third night of firebombing incidents, Police Chief Thomas Sardine said last night that citizens who feel their life and property are threatened by arsonists may use deadly force.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds made his flippant observation a month ago, baseball men snickered slightly and nodded in knowing fashion. As the aphorism says, many a truth is said in jest and the crack by the irrepressible Pete seemed to have all the proper elements. Said he:

title: Morton Maps WesternTour Of Interior Agency Domain
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton moved his head quarters west today for month to find out what goes on at the ground level of the vast natural and human re sources empire he administers.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Fishing Report

title: The Talk of Stiltsville
description: MIAMI, Aug. 2Home owners in Miami's most ex elusive neighborhood gather on their porches in the long summer evenings to watch the sun melt into the horizon and listen to porpoises slide past their front doors.

title: PANTHER WITNESS DESCRIBES SHOTS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 5A witness for a group of Black Panthers charged with attempt ed murder testified today that she saw two persons shot from a helicopter in a police raid on the New Orleans Black Panther headquarters last September.

title: Mets Lose, 21, in 17th
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 5The New York Mets didn't need 17inning game to open a two week trip after they had lost 24 of 34 games. But they got one tonight, and lost it, when the Atlanta Braves punched over a run in the bottom of the 17th for a 21 victory.

title: Army Sgt. Rennolds Wins In National Pistol Shooting
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 5 (UPI)Sgt. Harland Rennolds, of Columbus Ga., representing the United States Army, won the national trophy individual championship in the final round of the National Pistol cham pionships today.

title: Draft Order by Birthdays
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)Following, in calendar order, are the 1972 draft lottery numbers drawn today the Selective Service lottery for men born in 1952:

title: Congress Rebuffs Nixon On Transfer of a Beach
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)Congress blocked the transfer of 6.5 miles of beach near President Nixon's San Clemente home to the state of California today.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE WATER LORDS. Ralph Nader's Study Group Report on Induetry and Environ mental Crisis in Savannah. By James M. Follows, 294 pages, Grossman, $7.95.

title: Reston Meets With Chou
description: TOKYO, Aug. 5 (AP)  Premier Chou Enlai met in Peking today with James Res ton, vice president of The New York Times, and Mrs. Reston, the official press agency, Hsinhua, reported.

title: WILLYWIN VICTOR IN JERSEY MILE
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5 Keystone Stable's Willywin re pelled Famous Gun's stretch rally and drew away to a 3 length victory today at Mon mouth Park.

title: Advertising:
description: A salvage job has just about been completed that was designed to restore Media Records, Inc., to fi nancial viability and therein hangs a tale.

title: Cosmos No. 432
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today put into orbit No. 432 in its Cos mos series of research satel lites, the official press agency, Tass, said.

title: Man In the News
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 5A 57 yearold Viennaborn stock broker who fled Nazi persecu tion to come to the United States 30 years ago, was elected the interim Mayor of Jersey City today by a 7to1 vote of the City Council. The new Mayor, Charles Kiva Krieger a stocky, baldish man who is cultivating a mustache, will serve until Nov. 2, when a special election is sched uled to provide a successor to Thomas J. Whelan, who was convicted last month of extortion.

title: REBUILT HOUSING AN EAST SIDE HULK
description: According to copies of offi cial records, a sixstory house on the Lower East Side was completely rehabilitated two months ago with almost $400, 000 from a city loan fund. It stands today a doorless, win dowless bulk.

title: Carloading Report Omitted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Association of American Rail roads omitted its weekly car loading report today, as it did last week. Because of strikes by the United Transportation Union, available data on ton mileage and cars loaded were incomplete.

title: It May Be a Losing Battle, but W.C.T.U. Is Out There Fighting
description: CHICAGOLiquor consumption was down 99 per cent at the PickCongress Hotel earlier this week. Orange juice, however, was being gulped as fast as could be squeezed. The reason was simple: More than 1,000 members of the World Woman's Christian Temperance Union were quartered there for their 25th triennial convention.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Survey of Big Concerns Finds 1971 Prospects Top 1970 Results
description: Thirdquarter corporate prof its are not likely to match the inspiring results of the vigorous second quarter. However, the final three months may push the year's performace to a lofty total exceeded only by the rec ord year of 1966, according to a preliminary survey by The New York Times.

title: HAROLD MACK
description: Harold Mack, retired president of Peck & Mack, New York im porters and exporters of hard ware, died Wednesday in Dan bury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 220 Madison Avenue.

title: GOVERNOR PRAISES LONDON GOVERNING
description: LONDON, Aug. 5Declaring himself impressed with the way London governs its 8 million people, Governor Rockefeller suggested today that New York City study the British capital's methods of decentalization.

title: SEYMOUR LUSTMAN, PROFESSOR AT YALE
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5Sey mour L. Lustman, professor of psychiatry at Yale University, drowned today while sailing a small boat in Lincolnville, Me. He was 51 years old.

title: '72 Draft Lottery Assigns No. 1 to Those Born Dec. 4
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Selective Service System, in a lottery drawing that lasted just over two hours, deter mined today the order in which about two million young men born in 1952 will be sub ject to the draft next year.

title: A.E.C. Member Opposes Nixon Plan for a Shift of Functions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  A member of the Atomic Energy Commission opposed today a sweeping reorganization sought by President Nixon that would transfer some commission func tions to a new department of natural resources.

title: GUN DRIVE OPENED BY JEWISH LEAGUE
description: The Jewish Defense League announced a drive yesterday to arrange for Jews to buy rifles and shotguns. Rabbi Meir Kahane, the league's director, who has been ordered by a court to have nothing to do witi weapons, was present but did not participate in the news conference announcing the drive.

title: The Story Behind The Bombing
description: SAN DIEGO  There has been so much discussion about the Pentagon papers recently that I thought I had better get my comments in while the subject is still hot. It is important to begin by defining exactly what we ere talking about when we say The Penta gon papers.

title: DRYSDALE DEFEATS TAYLOR IN 2 SETS
description: BROOKLINE, Mass. Aug. 5 (AP)  Thirdseeded Cliff Drys dale of South Africa, able to concentrate fully on his game in the absence of demonstra tions, moved into the quarter final round today in the $50, 000 United States pro, tennis tournament at Longwood.

title: Lottery Number Is 553506
description: WILDWOOD, N. J., Aug. 5 (AP)This week's winning New Jersey lottery number is 553506. Those who hold tickets with all six digits win $50,000; those with the last five digits win $4,000; those with the last four, $400; those with the last three $40, and those with the last two a free ticket in a millionaire lottery drawing.

title: HUMPHREY GUESS: NIXONCONNALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said today that he thought there was a good possibility that President Nixon would re place Vice President Agnew with Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally when Mr. Nixon runs for reelection next year.

title: SENATE VOTES AID TO JOBLESS AREAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Despite Republican grum blings, the Senate rushed through legislation today to provide the same Federal disaster aid for economically distressed areas as that given victims of hurricanes, earth quakes, forest fires and other calamities.

title: Judge Dismisses Indictment Of 3 in a Securities Case
description: Judge Charles H. Tenney dis missed a 1968 indictment in Federal Court here yesterday on the ground that the Govern ment had denied a speedy trial to the defendants in the securi ties case.

title: BANK DENIES HARM TO ITS THRIFT UNIT
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5The Community Bank of Huntington Park, Calif., denied today charges that it had unduly in terfered with the management of the First Surety Corpora tion, a Burbank savings and loan holding company in which the bank owns a controlling interest.

title: Senate Votes Campaign Spending Curb
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Senate approved overwhelm ingly today a comprehen sive campaign bill designed to reduce mounting political spending and to let the public know who finances bids for of fice and how the money is spent.

title: L.I. Prisoners Sue On Assassination Of Morris, a Mouse
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 5 A group of 22 prisoners at the Suffolk County Jail filed suit in State Supreme Court here today over what they called the assassination of their pet mouse, Morris.

title: Excerpts From Report on Securities Markets Submitted by Martin to Big Board
description: Following are excerpts from the report on securities markets submitted yesterday to the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange by William McChesney Martin Jr.:

title: First LaborRelations Act In Britain Becomes a Law
description: LONDON, Aug. 5The In dustrial Relations Bill, a legis lative landmark in postwar Brit ain and a symbol of Prime Minister Heath's Conservative party Government, received royal assent today and became law.

title: Pentagon Believes Chinese Have a Few Missiles Ready
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Defense Department authori ties said today that China probably has deployed a few mediumrange ballistic missiles with a range of 600 to 1,500 miles.

title: City Delays Sending. Blue Shield Clients Termination Notes
description: The Office of Collective Bar gaining announced last night that the city had agreed to postpone for one week its mail ing of health plan termination notices to city employes re ceiving Blue Shield medical and surgical coverage while inten sive negotiations go on next week with unions resisting the move.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5The preelection maneuver ing here, with all its confusion and uncertainty, has at least served to illustrate again what officials concede is the decline in Washington's leverage on the Government of President Nguy en Van Thieu.

title: Pornography Sentences Stir Protests in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 5  Three editors of an underground newspaper were ordered to prison today for up to 15 months in sentences that set off bitter social and political protest.

title: A Bit of Coney Island for Russia
description: Russians will be introduced to the fun of an American amusement park next week when a parachute ride and modern versions of the Whip and other whirling carnival at tractions go on display at a trade fair in Moscow's Gorki Park.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 108.5 from 108.3 last week.

title: CANDIDACY OF KY BARRED BY COURT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 5Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today lost a major round in his fight to get on the ballot for the presidential elec tion Oct. 3. The South Viet namese Supreme Court re jected his application for can didacy on the ground that it did not comply with the rules established in a stiff electoral law sponsored by Mr. Ky's chief rival, President Nguyen Van Thieu.

title: Stage: Well ServedUp Servant of Two Masters
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug: 5Many summer com munities have a theatrical choiceif they have a choice at allbetween reruns of recent Broadway hits or re vivals of old Broadway hits. But in East Hampton, almost any night of the week, one can see a program of ex perimental oneacts (at the Old Post Office Theater) or a new fanciful creation of the John Drew Repertory Company (at the John Drew Theater).

title: Wayne Duke of Big Eight Named Head of Big Ten
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) Wayne Duke, who enhanced the Big Eight's image of a national football power while serving as conference com missioner the last eight years, was named today as com missioner of the Big Ten.

title: HEALTH COST RISE OF 50% PREDICTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  A major Federal study of the na tion's health care costs, made public today, forecasts that medical expenses will rise 50 per cent in the first half of this decade to more than $100 billion.

title: AN ADDICT THIEF WRITES TO VICTIM
description: While Mrs. Cheryl Schmidt of Independence, Ohio, was watching a performance of Applause at the Palace The ater on Broadway near 46th Street, a thief broke into her car parked nearby and stole her purse.

title: Street Theater Trotipes Find the Play's Ther Thing
description: Olatunji, Tony and Maria, Sinbad the Sailor, Brother Jonathan, Little Red Riding Hood, the Ballet Hispanico and casts of several hun dreds are in the streets and parks of the five boroughs of New York this summer.

title: OFFER IS SUCCESS IN UTILITY BONDS
description: The third highgrade utility bond issue this week came to market yesterday and, like the first two, was a smashing success.

title: WALLACE ASSERTS HE'LL RUN IN '72
