description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 5 George C. Wallace says he has decided to run again for the Presidency in 1972.

title: PEKING
description: TIENTSIN, China, Aug. 5You hear a lot about the Chinese theory of peo ple's war and protracted war these days but what does it all mean?

title: Strike at Evening News Backed By Labor Leaders in Newark
description: NEWARK, Aug. 5New Jer sey labor leaders held a rally in front of the strikebound Eve ning News today in an effort to demonstrate solidarity behind the strike by the American Newspaper Guild, which is now in its 11th week.

title: Marriage Is Held For Miss Wilerisky
description: Miss Sallie Wilensky, for mer administrative director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, was married here yesterday to Martin Blumen thal, a widower, who is pres ident of A. J. Hollander & Co., Inc., an importexport concern specializing in leather and hides. The ceremony was performed at the Municipal Building by City Clerk Her man Katz.

title: House, in Reversal, Opens Way To Expanded EastWest Trade
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5Re versing an earlier stand, the House agreed today to open the way for further expansion of trade with Communist countries through ExportImport Bank fi nancing of exports.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Shop Talk
description: With all the talk about organic this and organic that, it's not surprising that some one has come up with an organic mud pack. But Rene Furterer's mud pack is no ordi nary smear for the face. It's for the hair. (Actually it's for the scalp, but just try putting it on the scalp without getting it on the hair.) Mr. Furterer has been plastering heads with it for quite a while in Paris. Now the person who wants mud in the hair can have it right here in New York because a couple of young Frenchmen have stocked all the Rene Furterer products in their own clinic they pronounce it cleeneeque) at 14 East 53d Street.

title: MIKE HILL, HEARD PACE AKRON GOLF
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 5 (AP) Mike Hill curled in a 30foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to shoot a three under par 67 and tie Jerry Heard for the firstround lead in the $150,000 American Golf Clas sic.

title: U.S. and Soviet Act to Ban Germ War
description: GENEVA, Aug. 5  The United States and the Soviet Union presented today a joint ly drafted text of an interna tional convention they said was designed to make impos sible for the sake of all man kind the waging of war with biological weapons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Redskins' Chief Relies on Old Warriors
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 5 Twentytwo is not George Allen's favorite age.

title: Author of Report Born Into Banking
description: The boy wonder of Wall Street. The nation's chief money manager. The Happy Puritan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: At Sunapee, All Their World's a Stage
description: LAKE SUNAPEE, N.H. Next week, East Lynne?

title: NRBQ Group Shows Versatility In a Rock Session at Folk City
description: For nearly three years now an odd aggregation called NRBQ has been my favorite rock band. This has not been an easy conviction to maintain. In terms of popularity, the go ing has been rough for the group.

title: A.L. FREEDLANDER, 82, DIRECTOR OF DAYCO
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 5 A. L. Freedlander, director and chairman of the Dayco Corpo ration's executive committee, died yesterday at Good Samari tan Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The question of U Thant's successor is crucial to the future of the United Nations, A personality is needed of the highest calibre and universal accept ability.

title: 5 AMERICANS KILLED BY MINE IN VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South. Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 6Five American soldiers were killed and two were wounded when a United States armored personnel car rier from the 196 Brigade, Americal Division, struck a mine yesterday 26 miles south of Danang, the United States command reported today.

title: Stability in Pakistan
description: The resignation of fourteen diplomats of Bengali origin from the Pakistani embassy in Washington and the United Nations mission here offers further evidence of the depth and bitterness of the division between the two Pakistans, East and West. The responsible positions the defectors have held in the Pakistani Governmentthey include the economic counselor of the embassy and the number two man in the U.N. missionrefute the charge of Pakistani President Yahya Khan that the Bengali uprising is merely the work of mischief mongers, saboteurs and, infiltra tors. It also casts doubt on his claim that the resistance has been crushed.

title: F.C.C. ISSUES PLAN FOR CATY MARKET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Federal Communications Com mission issued today its de tailed plans for the develop ment of cable television in bigcity markets, but said it would not implement the new policy until Congress had re viewed it.

title: TRAINMEN ON L.I.R. DEMAND FIRE CURBS
description: The president of the train men's local on the Long Island Railroad, Harold J. Pryor, said yesterday that his men would not operate trains through the Penn Central's East River and Brooklyn tunnels after Aug. 15 unless fire safety measures were taken.

title: Diplomats Called Home
description: TAIPEI, Aug. 5 (Reuters) Nationalist China has called home its diplomatic mission chiefs in Asia and the Pacific region for an emergency meet ing tomorrow to discuss the United States policy on the United Nations.

title: A ChildAid Group Is Planning Suits To Close Spofford
description: The Institute for Juvenile Justice announced yesterday that it would file suit in Fed eral and state courts early next week asking for the im mediate and permanent closing of the Spofford Juvenile Center in the Bronx, the city's largest childdetention facility.

title: Mrs. Rudolph de Villiers, 77; Founded Leukemia Society
description: Mrs. Rudolph Roesler de Villiers, founder and first presi dent of the Leukemia Society, Inc., died Wednesday, after a long illness. She was 77 years old and lived at 49 East 86th Street.

title: Astronaut Works in Space as His Daughters Watch
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 5  An Apollo 15 astronaut, Maj. Al fred M. Worden of the Air Force, stepped into the black vacuum 196,000 miles from the earth today to become the first man ever to take a float ing excursion outside his craft in interplanetary space.

title: Dialogue During the Space Walk
description: Following are conversations between Capcom, the capsule communicator in Houston, and the Apollo crew, as tran scribed by The New York, Times:

title: Ellsberg Is Ordered to Stand Trial on the Coast
description: BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP)A United States District Court judge today ordered Dr. Daniel Ellsberg removed to Los An geles Aug. 16 to face charges of illegal possession of secret Government documents in the Pentagon papers case.

title: City Sees Sun Again After RainSoggy July
description: Sunny skies and pleasant temperatures returned to the city yesterday after a week of rain that sometimes fell in torrents.

title: Text of U.S.Soviet Draft Convention on Elimination of Bacteriological Arms
description: GENEVA, Aug. 5 (Reuters) Following is the text of a draft convention on bio logical arms submitted today by the United States and the Soviet Union to the 25nation disarmament conference here:

title: Key Retail Chains Found Sizable Gains in Sales Volume During July
description: Leading chainstore organiza tions in the country chalked up sizable gains in sales volume during July compared with the year before, indicating that con sumer spending continues as a strong factor in the economy.

title: Botswana Deal Put Off
description: Botswana RST, Ltd., and Bamangwato Concessions, Ltd., said yesterday that they had been advised by MetalGesell schaft, A.G., that it was not prepared now to go forward with proposed financial guaran tees and sales contract cover ing the sale in West Germany of the nickel and copper to be produced from the SlebiPikwe mining project in Botswana.

title: BID TO FLY P.O.W.'S REMAINS MYSTERY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  The mystery deepened today over the identity of the person who asked the Swedish airlines office in Bonn, Germany, three weeks ago to arrange a charter flight to Laos to fly. 187 un identified persons to Rome.

title: Hearings on DDT Slated
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP)  The Environmental Protec tion Agency announced today that a public hearing would be gin Aug. 17 on a proposed Fed eral ban on all remainng uses of the pesticide DDT. The agen cy began the proceedings, un der a Federal court order, last January. Some 45 manufac turers of DDT products ap pealed the notice and sought the public hearings.

title: George W. Smyth Dead at 85; Former Children's Court Judge
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 5  George W. Smyth, Judge of the Westchester County Children's Court from 1930 through 1955, died here today at the age of 85. He lived in Orleans, Mass., and at 99 Greenridge Avenue in Scarsdale; N. Y.

title: L.I. MAN CONVICTED IN BANK ROBBERY
description: A 27yearold Suffolk County man was convicted in Federal Court in Brooklyn last night of taking part in the $25,000 rob bery of a Bay Share, L.I., bank last Dec. 21.

title: Dr. Wilson G. a Leader In Public Health, Is Dead at 84
description: NEWFANE, Vt., Aug. 5Dr. Wilson G. Smillie; a leader in public health and especially in epidemiology, died today, at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: NEW ROLES DANCED BY PRINZ AND NAGY
description: Like a wellmannered tiger, John Prinz danced the male lead in Theme and Variations for the first time Wednesday evening at the State Theater. The production, one of Ameri can Ballet Theater's perennials, offers a series of virtuoso and partnering challenges that Mr. Prinz met with caged exuber ance.

title: Broome of Britain Captures Prize in Dublin Horse Show
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 5  Two American riders, Neal Shapiro on Kings Row and Conrad Homfeld on Silver Scott, won third and sixth places, respec tively, at the Dublin Horse Show today in the top score international competition.

title: Notes on People
description: Henry M. Ramirez, a one time migrant worker in Cal ifornia, was named by Presi dent Nixon yesterday as chairman of the Cabinet Committee on Opportunities for SpanishSpeaking Peoples. He is the first Hispanic American to serve on the President's staff.

title: Verona to Tour City's Parks and Playgrounds
description: Two Gentlemen of Ve rona, the new musical ver sion of the Shakespeare play by John Guare, Mel Shapiro and Galt MacDermot, now playing under the aus pices of the New York Shakespeare Festival at the Delacorte Theatre in Central Park, will tour the city's parks and playgrounds from Aug. 11 to 29.

title: SCHWEITZER GETS NO SENATE CALL
description: State supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer will not be subpoenaed by the United State Senate subcommittee that has already heard testi mony that the judge received $50,000 in bribes, the chief counsel for the subcommittee said yesterday.

title: U.S. Stand Irritates Peking But Nixon Is Still Welcome
description: PEKING, Friday, Aug. 6 China Is taking a hard line against the Nixon Administra tion for trying to have both the Peking Government and the Chinese Nationalists in the United Nations, but this has not changed its decision to welcome President Nixon here some time before next May.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The Commerce Department today es timated last week's department store sales at $715million, up 11 per cent from the yearearli er $646million. Last week's to tal retail store sales were about $7,532,000,000, up 8 per cent from $6,985,000,000.

title: Japan Will Raise Prices On TV Exports to U.S.
description: The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Indus try yesterday told the Electron ic Products Industry Associa tion in Tokyo to have its mem ber companies raise prices of both color and blackandwhite television sets for export to this country by about 5 per cent, effective Sept. 1. The move is expected to raise retail prices of Japanese sets in this country by more than 5 per cent.

title: For Tom Egan, Dedication Means Breaking Rock
description: At a high spot on the ser pentine terraces that he singlehandedly carved but of a granite hillside over the last five years, Tom Egan set down his wheelbarrow yes terday morning.

title: Shorter Wins Marathon for Tough Double
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 5A worldrecord performance in the triple jump, another gold medal run by Frank Shorter and a raucous series of fights highlighted a hectic windup to track and field competition at the sixth PanAmerican Games tonight.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 When William D. Ruckelshaus became administrator of the new Environmental Protection Agency eight months ago, he made plain his intention to en force antipollution laws' fairly but aggressively. In a recent news conference, he was asked whether he was beginning to feel a little iso lated. He replied, I don't feel com pletely isolated, and then, grinning, added, I don't feel surrounded, either. This was perhaps the best face Mr. Ruck elshaus could put on the situa tion in view of what is recog nized here as an offensive by industry against the agen cy's implementation of the clean air and water laws. It is industry's complainta com plaint that has had a sympa thetic hearing in the Depart ment of Commerce, the Federal Power Commission, the Office of Management and Budget and some sections of Congress that the standards and regula tions issued by the environ mental agency are unneces sarily harsh and take insuffi cient account of economic feasibilityin short, costs.

title: Good Weather Foreseen
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 5 (UPI)  The weather 300 miles north of Hawaii is expected to be satisfactory for Saturday's splashdown of Apollo 15. A special branch of the National Weather Service said today that there should be scattered cloud cover but good visibility with eastnortheast winds at 27 to 23 miles an hour and temperatures in the upper 70's. Seas are expected to run up to six feet.

title: Beban, Cut by broncos, Decides to Quit Football
description: DENVER, Aug. 5 (UPI) Gary Beban, a former Heis man, Trophy winner who tried for four years to make it as a pro quarterback, was cut by the Denver Broncos today and said he would quit football entirely.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished higher yes terday in very slow trading.

title: Touches of Sidewalk Splendor Planned for Midtown
description: Several of the nation's larg est corporations will build promenades, plazas, pools, fountains and underground pe destrian walks to beautify Rockefeller Center and show their faith in the future of the city.

title: City Deducts Strike Fines From Police Paychecks
description: The city yesterday started to deduct part of the $8,025,206 the city's 19,274 patrolmen were fined for taking part in last January's strike.

title: Miss Kaplan Bride Of John Streicker
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 5 Miss Barbara S. Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Goodman Kaplan, was Mar ried here this afternoon to John Harrison Streicker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter M. Streicker of Pound Ridge, N. Y.

title: Pagan Out for Season
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 5 (UPI) Jose Pagan, the Pittsburgh Pirates' third baseman, will be out for the balance of the sea son because of a broken left arm he suffered in tonight's game, when he was hit by a pitch from John Strohmayer in the fifth inning.

title: WHOLESALE INDEX OF PRICES IN JULY CLIMBED SHARPLY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The rise in industrial wholesale prices quickened in July though there was a welcome decline in food prices, the Labor De partment reported today.

title: Pakistan Accuses Bengalis Of Massacring 100,000.
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 5 The Pakistani Government, which has been stung by ac cusations that the army killed thousands of people when it moved to crush the Bengali sep aratist movement in East Paki stan, said today that the sepa ratists themselves were respon sible for thousands of deaths.

title: Faust Counter Faust Offers Operatic Fun
description: The notion of mixing sev eral versions of the Faust legend into a multimedia col lage, as is done by W. Wes ley Balk and John Gessner in Faust Counter Faust, makes eminent theatrical sense. And musical sense, too. The opera's treatment of themes in pointcounterpoint style, in itself aptly medieval, evokes sharply the complex ities of moral and musical thinking in Faust's time.

title: A Kind of Eggplant Sandwich
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Black Holes in the Sky Sought By Apollo Crew
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 5  Today and tomorrow the Apollo 15 astronauts, in prearranged col laboration with Soviet and Dutch astronomers, are trying to observe what some scientists suspect are black holes in the sky.

title: In Russia It's the In Thing to Debate Fads
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5The mother's complaint was not uncommon. Her 15yearold daughter, Lena, wanted only to buy this or that fash ionable thing. Their neigh bor's daughter, Vera, was completely spoiled: Twice a month she was taken shop ping to get pretty, fashion able clothes.

title: Health Agency to Combat Graft
House Hare...
description: Few things are more predictable in a preelection year than a Presidential rebuke to Congressusually on the ground of inactivityif it happens to be controlled by the opposing party. President Nixon, speaking through Clark MacGregor, his counsel on Congressional relations, made good on that expectation on the eve of the law makers' recess to Sept. 8. And House Speaker Carl Albert has been equally prompt with the ritualistic response that Congress is doing all it can to surmount Admin istration lethargy.

title: MILES IS INVITED TO E.E.C. SESSION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  Representative Wilbur D. Mills announced today that he and the House Ways and Means Committee, which he heads, will visit Brussels in early No vember to confer with the ex ecutive commission of the Eu ropean Economic Community.

title: Peasant in Turkey Seized as Forger Of Ancient Pottery
description: BURDUR, Turkey, Aug. 5 Turkish police have arrested a peasant here who is believed to have manufactured some of the forgeries of Anatolian neo lithic pottery purchased by sev eral museums as genuine arti facts.

title: Abolish the Turnstiles?
description: Even in these days of astronomic increases in the price of practically everything, a jump in New York City's transit fare to 50 cents would be a metropolitan disaster. The air of utter helplessness with which most city and state officials have been contemplating this prospect has at last been shattered by the proposal of Bronx Borough President Abrams for a quantum leap in the opposite directionelimination of all fares on the subways and buses.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Van Arsdale Joins the Pickets Protesting Imports of Clothing
description: Members of the Amaggmated Clothing Workers of America picketed Alexander's here and department stores in three oth er metropolitan areas yesterday as part of the union's continu ing protest against the sale of imported men's clothing from lowwage countries.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The LTV Aerospace Corpora tion, which Is controlled by LingTemcoVought, Inc., has received a $41.9million addi tion to a Navy contract for production of A7D and A7E aircraft for the Navy and Air Force.

title: Washington: For the Record
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reserve Finds No Letup In Money Supply Growth
description: The nation's credit managers have yet to make any significant progress in cutting back the rate of expansion in the money supply, Federal Reserve banking data indicated yesterday. During July, for example, the money stock currency in circulation plus private checking accounts grew by more than 12 per cent on a seasonally adjusted annual rate basis, even more than the rate of growth dur ing the first half of the year.

title: Ali Fighter of Month
description: Muhammad Ali, who knock ed out Jimmy Ellis in 12 rounds July 26, was named fighter of the month by Ring magazine yesterday.

title: AntiPeking Posters Dot Taipei As Officials Weigh U.N. Plans
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 5A red and white banner draped over the entrance to the Taipei Municipal Council Building on one of the city's busiest cor ners proclaims in Chinese and English: No U.N.

title: Penn Station Site Chosen For New OTB Computer
description: Tickertron's undefeated off track computer system will get its first big test next Monday when it goes to the post at one of the two betting sites in Penn Station.

title: Yachtsman Held in $3.5Million Hashish Smuggling
description: A 38yearold Englishman was held here in lieu of $250, 000 bail yesterday on charges that he sailed a yacht with 1,800 pounds of hashish from Morocco to New York.

title: Strikes: A Way of Life in Copper Industry
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 5 At the Arthur Frank Hab erdashery on Main Street, business was frankly lousy this past month, if you'll par don a pun, according to the shop owner, Si Frank. Out at Bud's hardware store, on suburban 62d South Street, clerks report very good sales of paint, plumbing sup plies, wood paneling and the like.

title: Johnson, Frederickson Out of Giant Exhibition
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 5 Ron Johnson, Tucker Frederick son, Junior Coffey and Les Shy, all suffering from various degrees of leg trouble, won't accompany the New York Giants to Houston on Sunday for their first exhibition game of the season, against the Oil ers on Monday night.

title: ... and Senate Tortoise
description: Handicapped by its own leisurely debating rules including such oddities as the filibusterthe Senate is expected to plod along almost to the end of the year. But beyond what it may do about the legislation men tioned above, it can already point to at least two impor tant achievements. It has focused sharply on the issue of where the power to make war resides in the American democracy and it has passed almost unanimously a bill that the National Committee for an Effective Congress hails as the first realistic campaign finance law in the country's history.

title: A SINGLE MARKET FOR STOCK TRADES URGED BY MARTIN
description: A sweeping reorganization of the nation's securities industry was recommended yesterday by William McChesney Martin Jr., the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Copper Range Omits Payouts
description: The directors of the Copper Range Company, voted yester day to omit the quarterly divi dend. The last payment was 12 cents in June. A company spokesman cited the strike of 2,400 workers at the company's mine and refinery in White Pine, Mich., as the major factor.

title: Walk Deep in Space
description: The ease, precision and dispatch with which Maj. Alfred Worden walked in spaceroughly 200,000 miles away from earthprovides the last proof, if any were needed, that men properly garbed, trained and equipped can work outside spaceships anywhere in the immense void between the earth and the moon. And there is every reason to suppose that in time men will walk and work in the space enveloping other portions of the solar system as wellin the neighborhood of Mars, for example.

title: INCO WILL CLOSE 2 CANADIAN MINES
description: TORONTO, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press)  The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., said today it was closing two mines with a combined work force of about 1,000 men because of reduced demand for nickel. The workers will be transferred to other Inco operations.

title: Cocaine Worth $175,000 Seized With Suspect Here
description: Federal agents seized a paper hag filled with 18 pounds of cocaine from a man about to board an Eastern Airlines plane yesterday at La Guardia Airport bound for Charlotte, N. C. They estimated the drug's streetsale value at $175,000.

title: Sadat Said to Warn Soviet He'll Resist Reds in Middle East
description: CAIRO, Aug. 5  President Anwar eiSadat has told the Soviet Union unequivocally that Egypt will continue to re sist Communism in the Arab world, it was reliably reported today. The Kremlin appears to have bowed to his position and to have decided that its Stra tegic interest in the Middle East outweighs the fate of Arab Communists.

title: DOW UP BY 4.53; VOLUME IS SMALL
description: Stock prices advanced yes terday on small volume in what Wall Street analysts de scribed as a technical recovery in the wake of recent sharp losses.

title: G.M. to Raise Price Of 1972 Cars $176
description: DETROIT, Aug. 5  The General Motors Corporation said today that it would raise 1972 car prices by an average of $176, or 3.9 per cent.

title: HAROLD F. NUNN, 56, LED MACHINE FIRM
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5Har old F. Nunn, chairman of The Lamson & Sessions Company in Cleveland, manufacturer of ma chine tools. and distributor of machinery, died Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 56 years old and lived in Hunting Valley, a Cleveland suburb.

title: Kick Fatal to Soccer Player
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug, 5 UPI) An 18yearold amateur soc cer player died last Sunday, several hours after a collision on the field during a soccer game, authorities reported to clay. Juan Manuel Napoles Acosta collidd with another player during a game on a city sports field. Eyewitnesses said the other player kicked him in the stomach after the colli sion.

title: Main Spring Wins On Clean Jumpoff In Upstate Show
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 5Main Spring, owned by Lee Barney of Burlington, Wis., and handled by Rod Jenkins, won the intermediate jumper class at the Orange County Horse Show today and moved into a commanding lead for the cham pionship.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Dictaphone Corporation announced yes terday the election of E. Lawrence Tabat, 58 years old, as president and chief executive officer effec tive Sept. 13. Mr. Tabat, currently vice president and division manager of the Power Tool division of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company, succeds Walter W. Finke, chairman and president, who will relinquish both those positions on that date. Mr. Flake will continue as a director and a consultant to the office machine company.

title: Market Place: Ecological Near Another Ordeal
description: The battered shareholders of Ecological Sciences have another ordeal ahead of them when the shares begin trad ing overthecounter on Mon day.

title: U.S. Volleyball Visit To Cuba Is Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) The State Department has granted the United States men's volleyball team permis sion to visit Cuba for a tour nament next week, depart ment officials disclosed to day. The tournament, sched uled to take place in Havana between Aug. 12 and 16, will decide the North American entry in the 1972 Olympics.

title: Sugarman Reports Fewer Relief Clients Fail to Get Checks
description: Jule M. Sugarman, the city's Human Resources Administra tor, said yesterday that 17 per cent of employable welfare re cipients failed to pick up their biweekly relief checks last Fri day. This figure compared with 22 per cent who failed to pick up their checks in the first two weeks of July.

title: Ellen J. Stern Wed To Martin Teeman
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 5Miss Ellen Jane Stern was married here this evening to Martin Allen Teeman at the Sunningdale Country Club by Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman, who in 1938 married the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Stern of Scarsdale.

title: U.N. Drops Guinea Inquiry
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5  A United Nations spokesman said today that the dispatch of a threeman mission to Guinea to investigate charges by President Skou Tour, that the country was about to be invaded from neighboring Portuguese Guinea had been indefinitely suspended. A second message was received last night from President Tour asking without explanation that the investigation be postponed in definitely.

title: Lunar Data Trove to Be Tapped
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 5  The package of instruments that was operated continuously by Al Worden in lunar orbit and by a team of scientists and engineers on the earth has produced an unbelievable reser voir of information on geo chemical and physical nature of the moon.

title: Area Residents Protest Plan for Brooklyn Piers
description: Residents of the shabby but richly Latin neighborhood that stretches along Columbia Street in South Brooklyn yesterday expressed opposition to a plan to develop the adjacent Butter milk Channel piers into a mod ern containerized port.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDONThe nightmare vision of Soviet policy runs something like this: Moscow is preparing a longrange plan to assert unchallenged leadership of the Communist world by smashing China to the east and reestablishing control over heretical Marxist lands to the west. While no such grand strategy, can ever be confirmed, diplomats con sider there is circumstantial evidence available.

title: Advertising:
description: The New York Times will introduce a separate Sunday section beginning Sept. 12 in a move to expand its news coverage of Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island.

title: Nixon Gets Gideon Bible
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Gideons International, which promotes use of the Bible by placing copies in hotel and motel rooms, presented its 100 millionth Bible to President Nixon today in a brief White House ceremony.

title: U.S. FIVE CRUSHES SURINAM, 128 TO 48
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 5 (UPI) The United States lost the women's springboard diving gold medal in the PanAmeri can Games for the first time today, but the United States men's basketball team crushed Surinam, 12848, to retain a chance at that title.

title: A Vote Against The Common Market
description: LONDONWhy shall I vote next October against acceptance of the Government's white paper recommend ing entry into the Common Market?

title: TOOTHPASTE STUDY RELEASED BY PELL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Senator Claiborne Pell, Dem ocrat of Rhode Island, dis closed today an Army study that indicated that some brands of toothpaste may cause painful gum inflammation.

title: Advertising:
description: There's a rumor out of New York (not Detroit by any means) that the agency finalists in the race for that $17million Pinto, Maverick and Mustang account will be told today by the Ford Motor Company who gets the brass ring.

title: U.S. Charges Racial Bias By North Carolina Concern
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today against a Charlotte, N. C., construction concern, charging it with discrimination against blacks in hiring and in sale and rental of residential property.

title: U. S. Asks for Laws to Protect Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5  The Administration asked Con gress today for Federal author ity to prosecute cases involving attacks on American and for eign officials and their families.

title: An Imaginative Menu and an Impressive View
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmo sphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: LISBON HOLDS AIDE OF JOURNALIST UNION
description: LISBON, Aug. 5The politi cal police arrested the secre tary of Portugal's journalist union today while parliament was approving a Government bill abolishing formal press censorship.

title: Culebra Plan Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) The Senate refused today to set May 31, 1975, as the date for ending Navy shelling prac tice at the Caribbean island of Culebra but approved a Penta gon plan to develop an alterna tive by the end of 1972.

title: JET PROVIDES BASE FOR A LOOK AT MARS
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 5 (UPI) A group of 26 scientists in spected Mars from a special jet flying 45,000 feet over the Pacific early today for man's closest look at the mysterious planet. They termed the ven ture a success.

title: The Screen: Love Machine' Opens at Two Theaters
description: About "The Love Machine," which opened yesterday at the Loew's State 2 and Orpheum Theaters: "I'm not sure how to put it, but the book is better. Anyone who has stumbled through the Valley of the Dolls and even beyond, hoping for yet another camp masterpiece in the tradition of, say, "Young-blood Hawke" will know what I mean. And he may go right on stumbling.For although "The Love Machine" has enough dumb lines to qualify as a veritable anthology of unintentional humor, it hasn't the energy or the wit or, finally, the commitment to its own absurdities to provide the exhilarating sense of life that is the real appeal of the good-bad movie.I suspect that Samuel Taylor, in adapting the book, and Jack Haley Jr., in directing the film, knew pretty, well what they were about. But that knowledge seems all in the head, and not in the heart, where schlock belongs. And because everything is merely seen and not felt, certain key scenes, like the suicide of the beautiful model Amanda (in blurred close-up; the body across the bed, the empty vial, a few yellow pills beside the pink telephone, etc.), are never as funny as in more sensitive hands they might have been.Amanda kills herself because of a rotter named Robin Stone (John Phillip Law), a TV newscaster who makes it big with his boss (Robert Ryan), his boss's wife (Dyan Cannon), several unnamed ladies of the night and his best friend (David Hemmings).He rises high in the network news, and even bids to take over the company, but loose habits and general rottenness eventually bring him lowwhich is where we leave him, walking off into the night, still spurning the help of Maggie, the girl who loves him and who figures heavily in the book but only gets into the movie enough to prepare for, perhaps, a Return of the Love Machine that may follow.A lot of good people are wasted in "The Love Machine," and somewhere during Ryan's front-office pep talk to Law and Jackie Cooper, a nervous executive, about the importance of egghead prestige ("Look at those pictures on the wall. Picasso, Matisse  do you think those fellows played it safe?") I began resenting the waste. Actors like Robert Ryan seem more and more like a precious national resource, and to say that Ryan escapes this movie with his soul intact (as he does) is to say too little.John Phillip Law generally adopts a posture of reserved displeasure, which may suggest his true feelings more than his character. The excellent David Hemmings plays a gay fashion photographer with some dignity but no enthusiasm, and only Jackie Cooper acts as if the movie actually mattereda position with which I don't agree, but for which I rather like him.A very lovely girl named Jodi Wexler plays Amanda, and though she is no actress, the rather intense nobility of her face is the one real memory the film offers.

title: Soviet and China Sign New Trade Pact at Ceremony in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 5The So viet Union and China signed a new trade and payments agree ment today reflecting their stated desire to conduct nor mal relations despite the po lemics that continue between them.

title: The Dance
description: LONDON, Aug. 5  One idly suspects that Queen Elizabeth II had a mild shock last night at the Royal Opera House, Covent Gar den. Together with the Queen Mother and Princess Mar garet, she attended the first Covent Garden performance of Glen Tetley's ballet Field Figures.

title: CARL O. BONDORFF
description: Carl O. Bondorff, a partner in the New York law firm of Frueauff; Farrell, Sullivan & Bryan, died on Tuesuay. He was 54 years old and lived at 1330 E Street, Elmont, L. L.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 5 (AP) Topseeded Stan Smith of Pasa dena, Calif., received a scare today but win his third match in the $30,000 Western Tennis tournament in a day of upsets.

title: APPALACHIA AID BILL SIGNED BY PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) President Nixon signed into law today a $3.9billion bill to help development programs in Appalachia and five other re gions.

title: Giant Incinerator Plan Dropped; City Cites Costs and, Pollution
description: Plans were officially aban doned by the Lindsay adminis tration yesterday for a giant incinerator that, in 1967, was called the answer to the city's growing garbage crisis.

title: PROXMIRE REVEALS BANKDEPOSIT DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Ignoring Treasury Depart ment objections, Senator Wil liam Proxmire made public today the deposits of more than $1.3billion by three in ternational financial institu tions in commercial banks in the United States.

title: SUGAR FUTURES EXTEND ADVANCE
description: Sugar refiners and other sugar users have been incrovs ing purchases of sugar here in anticipation of a longshore men's strike in September.

title: Miss Connell, 1962 Debutante, Becomes Bride
description: Miss Katherine Ann Con nell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Connell of New York and Madison, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Richard Morley Sincerbeaux at the Colony, Club by Justice Owen Mc Givern of the State Supreme Court, Appellate Division.

title: Herbert P. Fates Dies at 66; Banker and Government Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Herbert Peck Fales, manager of the. International Banking de partment of the American Se curity and Trust Company here, died Tuesday after a heart attack at the age of 66.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: House Investigation Sought In Today Ouster of Jessel
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Representative Harley O. Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, who is chairman of the House Interstate and For eign Commerce Committee, was asked today to investigate last Friday's incident on NBCTV's Today Show in which George Jessel, the comedian, was re moved from the show after making remarks about The New York Times and The Washing ton Post.

title: R. J. Lewis, Investment Banker, Marries Mrs. Helen H. Stookey
description: Mrs. Helen Hoyt Stookey and Robert James Lewis, an investment banker, were mar ried yesterday afternoon in the presence of their 5 chil dren and 19 grandchildren.

title: Roundup: Pizarro of Cubs Halts Padres on I Hit, 30
description: Maybe Juan Pizarro can now unpack Ms suitcase and stay awhile. Since he left Puerto Rico in 1956 to try baseball as a career, the 34 yearold lefthander has worn seven different major league uniforms in both leagues and five minor league baeball suits from Jacksonville, Fla., to Hawaii.

title: Turkey Opens Peking Relations And Breaks Ties With Taiwan
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 5 Turkey announced today that she had recognized Communist China and severed diplomatic relations with Nationalist China. A joint communiqu is sued simultaneously in Ankara and Peking said Turkey recog nized that the People's Re public of China is the sole le gal government of China.

title: Insko Primed for Another Shot At Albatross in Pace Tonight
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 5 Del Insko, a little man who has had some busy days and nights recently, spent today and tonight in comparative idle ness.

title: McCloskey to Open Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Representative Paul N. Mc Closkey, Republican of Califor nia, said today that he would open his New Hampshire cam paign for the Republican Presi dential nomination Monday at Concord. That state has the nation's first primary, March 7.

title: Lucky Traveler, $72
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5  Nelson B. Hunt's Lucky Traveler took the right route in the $35,500 Test Stakes today. Under a resourceful ride by Chuck Baltazar, Lucky Traveler sped along on the out side of her 11 rivals in a field of 3yearold fillies and regis tered a surprising twolength triumph. The Ess and Zee Stable's Tibb was next, half a length ahead of Forward Gal.

title: VIRGINIA M. STEELE, FASHION EDITOR, 42
description: Miss Virginia M. Steele of New York City and Warren, Vt., died yesterday of cancer in the Burlington (Vt.) Hospital. She was 42 years old and lived at 25 East Ninth Street.

title: 2 UNIONS LOSE BID ON POLLUTION SUIT
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 5  A State Supreme Court Justice es tablished here today what he called a new rule holding pol luters liable for punitive dam ages for deliberate or contemp tuous disregard of the environ mental rights of others.

title: TV: For the Early Viewer on the Run
description: It's the quiet month in tele vision as the industry tools up for the SeptemberOcto tober detonation of its fall schedules. That also makes it the convenient mouth for the critic to dip into the golden ghetto of daytime pro graming, an area too often neglected in the constant hassle to keep up with prime time evening products.

title: FulbrightKissinger Relations Becoming Diplomatic
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Senator J. W. Fulbright, chair man of the Senate Foreign Re lations Committee, and Henry A. Kissinger, the President's na tional security adviser, have taken a first step, over drinks at the Senator's home, toward restoring diplomatic relations between them.

title: 7 Sites Are Named As SAC Satellites, Raising Total to 20
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 5The locations of seven additional satellite, or supplemental, bases for the Strategic Air Command were disclosed late today by the Pentagon. This will bring the total number of such bases to 20.

title: Ford Official Expects '71 Mark For IndustryWide Auto Sales
description: On the basis of sales so far this year, the automobile indus try should chalk up a new in dustry mark of between 9.7 million and 10 million units, William D. Innis, executive vice president of the Ford Motor Company for North American automotive operations, said here yesterday.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks
description: Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan area this weekend may encounter delays because of construc tion work at the following points listed by the Automobile Club of New York:

title: Sisco and Israelis End Talks; Some Hope on Canal Is Voiced
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 5The discussions between the United States and Israel over reopen ing the Suez Canal ended today with both sides agreeing that the prospects for an interim accord with Egypt were still alive.

title: 3DCLASS BULK MAIL SLATED FOR INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) The Postal Service has told mailers it will raise thirdclass bulk rates from 4.2 cents to 5 cents apiece Sept. 15 to help eliminate a projected $430mil lion deficit.

title: Spokesman for Higher Education
description: The appointment of Dr. Roger W. Heyns as president of the American Council on Education comes when higher education is in urgent need of a persuasive voice in Washington. Under the leadership of Dr. Logan Wilson the council, a nongovernmental organization dedicated to advancing the Interests of individual colleges and universities and of most major education associations, has grown to a total of 1,588 institutional members. But, except for some research publications, the council up to now has been more effective in addressing itself to the educational establishment than in presenting the case and blueprinting the futureof higher education to the larger public and to the Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG SCORES PLAN FOR INCOME LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6Sen ator Russell B. Long charged tonight that the familyassist ance plan backed by the Nixon Administration and approved by the House does not consti tute welfare reform at all.

title: SUSAN SAXE POSTS 2D SAIL TRIUMPH
description: BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 6Sev en skippers made it two straight today as the Great South. Bay Yacht Racing Aisociation's an nual race week championships resumed. The regatta continues tomorrow off West Babylon and concludes Sunday off Amity ville.

title: Over 150 War Protesters Are Arrested Near Boston
description: BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 6 (UPI)  More than 150 per sons protesting the Vietnam war were arrested without in cident today at the four gates leading to Hanscom Field.

title: Trustee Files Court Plan For Four Seasons Nursing
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Aug. 6 (AP)  The courtappointed trustee of Four Seasons Nurs ing Centers of America has filed a plan with the Federal District Court here to relieve the company of $5.5million in debts.

title: SNELL TESTS HEEL IN TAMPA TONIGHT
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 6Matt Snell's progress in recovering from heel surgery will provide the most significant element for the New York Jets tomor row night in their opening ex hibition game against the De troit Lions.

title: Eagles Scrimmage Hard to Overcome Many Weaknesses
description: READING, Pa., Aug. 6 The assets of the Philadelphia Eagles for the coming season are a remarkable 55,000 sea son tickets sold for the new Veterans Stadium, which has a football capacity of 65,000 and a nucleus of young ca pable players. The debits, however, are many.

title: SENATE APPROVES $16BILLION BILL TO AID EDUCATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The most sweeping aidtoedu cation bill in history cleared the Senate tonight as Congress began a monthlong vacation.

title: Solidity of Regime Of Duvalier in Haiti Reported Cracking
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The solidarity of the ruling group behind JeanClaude Duvalier, the new President of Haiti, be gan breaking as a power strug gle broke out between two of its key members, diplomatic sources said today.

title: CLARENCE JACOBSON, STAGE MANAGER, 84
description: Clarence Jacobson, a veteran theatrical company manager, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Trenton. He was 84 years old and had lived for the last two years in the Princeton, N. J., Nursing Home.

title: 5 ANTIWAR INMATES PROTEST AT DANBURY
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 6 Five antiwar inmates of the Federal Correctional Institution here began a hunger strike and work stoppage today after is suing a set of demands and urg ing their fellow prisoners to loin in their strike.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Recent events in the case involving Justice Schweitzer illustrate clearly the need for an improved procedure in New York State to investigate, dis cipline and remove judges. The Court on the Judiciary Is a cumbersome pro cedure, seldom used, convened only after widespread public charges, and slow to act. While the special court is in session (six months in the present instance), lines of authority within the judiciary to suspend judges under in vestigation are unclear. Neither the interests of the public nor those of the judiciary are served by this process.

title: ExPatrolman Is Sentenced For Taking Bribe in Bronx
description: Frank Zanotti, a 36yearold former patrolman, was sen tenced to three months in jail yesterday for taking a $15 bribe from a motorist in return for not giving him a traffic sum mons.

title: Albatross, $2.20, Sweeps To 12th Straight Victory
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 6If the $32,200 Commodore Pace staged tonight for 3yearolds at Roosevelt Raceway had en a prize fight instead of a har ness race, the referee would have intervened, stopped the mile classic and declared it no contest. That's how superior Albatross, the streaking Mead ow SkipperVoodoo Hanover colt was over his seven rivals.

title: Mrs. Chadsey Retains Title With 1 4and12 Golf Victory
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 6 Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill retained her Wo men's WestchesterandFair field Golf Association cham pionship today by defeating Mrs. Harry M. Day of Wood way, 14 and 12, in the sched uled 36hole final of the 49th annual event. Mrs. Chadsey took an 11up lead in the morning round by carding 37, 4077 over the 5,475yard, par 36, 3773 course. She lost only one hole, the 17th to a par 5.

title: Murder Suspect is Held
description: CARIBOU, Me., Aug, 6 (AP)  A20yearold Queens man was arrested on fugitive charges today in connection with the strangulation last month of Donald Schultz, a 25yearold student in Queens. The man, John Conran, was stationed at Loring Air Force Base near here, according to the police.

title: China Said to Want Accord On Key Issues Before Ties
description: China is understood to have decided to refrain from establishing diplomatic relations or engaging in significant trade with the United States until major political and secu rity problems involving the two nations are settled.

title: F.C.C. DENIES UNION AIR TIME FOR ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6De spite a recent court ruling that radio and television stations must accept some controver sial paid advertisements, the Federal Communications Com mission rejected today a de mand by the Communications Workers of America for air time to discuss a proposed con tract settlement.

title: HASSAN APPOINTS NEW GOVERNMENT
description: RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 6 King Hassan II of Morocco to night named a new Government of 15 independents to carry out the reforms he promised the country after a military mutiny failed to overthrow him last month.

title: Miss Whelan Wed To Stephen Dixon
description: RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 6 Miss Frances Ellen Whelan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent M. Whelan, was married here this afternoon to Stephen Power Dixon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gordon Dixon. Both families are of Rumson. The Rev. Joseph Sheehan performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church.

title: Fireman Rescues 2 in Separate Fires
description: A 24yearold fireman called Super Sam by members of his ladder company because of his athletic interests and his zeal for the job has lived up to the name.

title: Dr. Harold Lewis, 53, Artist And Teacher at New School
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 6Dr. Harold Lewis, a painter and art teacher, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 53.

title: Penn Central Using Buses During Work on. Spur Link
description: Buses will be substituted for trains on the New Canaan spur line of the Penn Central's New Haven Division this weekend to permit routine maintenance work on overhead power lines, the railroad announced yes terday.

title: Protesters Mark Bombing Of Hiroshima 26 Years Ago
description: On the 26th anniversary yes terday of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, demonstrations were held throughout the city protesting the Government's use then of nuclear weapons.

title: MEAT VIOLATION BRINGS 4TH FINE
description: A meat wholesaler, whom an assistant United States attor ney once called the worst vio lator of Department of Agricul tare regulations in the East, has been fined $13,000 in Fed eral Court here for shipping uninspected veal with forged Federal inspection stamps on it.

title: FRANK SIMMONDS, 95, BANKERS' GROUP AIDE
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., Aug. 6 Frank W. Simmonds, who re tired as senior deputy manager of the American Bankers Asso ciation in 1944, died today in the Doylestown (Pa.) Manor Nursing Home. He was 95 years old and lived at Thatch er's Hill.

title: Thieu Reported Confident of 55% of Vote
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6  President Nguyen Van Thieu is reportedly going into the presidential election in October confident that he will win with 55 per cent of the vote, now that Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky apparently has been eliminated from the con tention and Mr. Thieu's only opponent is Gen. Duong Van Minh.

title: Coast Guard Acts As Primary Defense On Yacht Smuggling
description: Coast Guard patrols repre sent a primary defense against smuggling by small pleasure craft such as the yacht that allegedly carried a cargo of hashish from Morocco to New York City.

title: Draft Beer, Not Men
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 6 (AP)A sign erected near here today said, Draft beer, not men.

title: OTB Makes a Profit Again Booking Wagers
description: The Offtrack Betting Cor poration ended a week yes terday in which it twice made a handsome return on wagers it had been unable to transmit to race tracks.

title: State Accuses New York Hilton Of Padding Bills With Fake Tax
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday accused the New York Hilton, the city's largest hotel, of overcharging more than 100,000 guests by hidden overcharge of 2 per cent disguised as a tax.

title: MONMOUTH RACE LISTS FIELD OF 12
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 6 F. J. Caldwell's Jim French gets a chance to settle a score with October House Farm's Pass Catcher tomorrow in the $100,000 Monmouth Handicap at Monmouth Park. Ten other 3yearolds are scheduled to start.

title: Village Residents Score City on Parking Meters
description: The Greenwich Village Com munity Planning Board called yesterday for the ouster of Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff because of a re cent decision to install parking meters at 28 locations in the area.

title: The Screen:
description: Next!, a flat, flabby pancake of a suspense melo drama from Europe, arrived yesterday at the Forum The ater. Anyone willing to shell out good money to watch a razor slashing and hacking human flesh, with some cas ual nudity and Viennese backgrounds added, is wel come to this picture. Those are the three principal come ons in this ItalianSpanish production, whose interiors were shot in Rome.

title: The Sheep Baa, and the Children Squeal as a Farmyard Zoo Is Dedicated in Prospect Park
description: The squawks and baas of animals and the oohs and ahs of children yesterday drowned out the speakers at a dedication, but the speak ers did not appear to mind being ignored.

title: OHIO EDISON'S NET FELL IN QUARTER
description: The Ohio Edison Company reported yesterday a decline in secondquarter net income de site higher operating revenus.

title: Eagle Killings Echo Past Strife
description: CASPER, Wyo., Aug. 6Two large concrete eagles perma nanently roost atop the broad chimney of Herman Werner's home on East 15th Street.

title: Mets Top Braves on Seaver's 4Hitter, 91
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 6The New York Mets, who would have given their kingdom for a run during 17 innings last night, re bounded with all sorts of runs tonight as Torn Seaver cruised to a 91 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Anderson Going to England
description: Pete Anderson, rider of a dozen stakeswinners last year, leaves tonight for Newmarke for a month's raceriding on English courses.

title: Bridge: Automatic Perseverance Can Cause Complications
description: Bridge: Automatic Perseverance Cause Complications A player who holds a vir tually solid suit and is on lead against notrump tends to persevere automatically with leads in that suit. This is sometimes wrong, as the diagramed deal shows. It was reported by Joseph Pastor from a rubber bridge game at the Hungarian Bridge Studio in New York City.

title: Mountain Lion Toll Listed
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 6 (UPI)Hunters killed 83 mountain lions in California last year despite conservation ists' complaints that the ani mals are a dying species. The State Department of Fish and Game filed a report yesterday with the legislature saying hunters bought 4,459 mountain lion tags during the last fiscal year and returned 83 of them.

title: FOUR MINISTERS QUIT ALLENDE'S CABINET
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. (AP)  Four Cabinet ministers presented their resignations to President Salvador Allende Gossens today, in the first such resignations since the Marxist President took office Nov. 4.

title: Pursuit of Pleasure at the Pool
description: She was the third child whose life I'd saved. Like the others, she was less than four years old, had been wandering around the pool by her self, and had simply turned and walked into the deep water.

title: SENATE APPROVES GATEWAY PROJECT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The Senate today approved the establishment of the Gateway National Recreation Area, which would open up more than 26,000 acres at the en trance to New York harbor to an estimated total of 10 mil lion visitors a year, more peo ple than visited the nation's six national seashores last year.

title: 2 Policemen Are Suspended For Links to Horse Racing
description: Two city patrolmen, Joseph Ferrigiana and John A. Suffel, have been suspended by the Po lice Department on the ground that while calling in sick they sometimes were racing their horses at local harness tracks.

title: Crime Cut by Study of Patterns
description: A policeman who, as one of the new planning ser geants, has been studying crime patterns, has found it possible to predict when and where certain street crimes will occurand to prevent some of them.

title: The Martin Report
description: In his eagerly awaited report to the New York Stock Exchange, William McChesney Martin Jr. has presented a plan for reshaping the nation's securities markets into a single, closely integrated, auction market.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Russo Wins Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) Anthony J. Russo, the re search analyst who refused to testify before a grand jury in the Pentagon papers case, was granted a temporary reprieve from prison today by Justice Hugo L. Black.

title: City Audubon Group Watches Pollution, Not Birds
description: A group of downtown busi nessmen and women, the ma jority nested in the Western Electric and American Tele phone and Telegraph building at 195 Broadway, have organ ized themselves under the ban ner of the National Audubon Society.

title: ROBERT B. JACOB, 55, DAYCO CHAIRMAN
description: Robert B. Jacob, chairman of the Dayco Corporation, di versified industrial manufac turer, died here yesterday while on a business trip. He was 55 years old and lived in Dayton, Ohio, headquarters of Dayco, the former Dayton Rubber Company.

title: Zamboni: Cards' Protest Upheld
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 6 (UPI) Charles Feeney, president of the National League, up held the St. Louis Cardinals' protest against the Philadel phia Zamboni today and ruled that the Cards will re gain three runs they had lost.

title: Books of The Times
description: PIERS THE PLOWMAN. By William Langland. Translated and with an introduction by Margaret Williams. 366 pages. Random. $10.

title: U.S. Contacting TV Source Of Report on Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reu ters)The State Department plans to contact a West German businessman who played a role in reports yesterday that Hanoi might release 187 United States prisoners of war.

title: Miller's 137 Leads in Golf
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 6 (AP)  Allen Miller, playing in his last amateur competition, shot a twounderpar 68 today for a tworound total of 137 in the Porter Cup golf tournament and a stroke lead over the defending champion, Howard Twitty.

title: Fausto Cleva, Conductor at Met Since 1920, Is Dead in Athens
description: ATHENS, Aug. 6  Fausto Cleve, a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera in New York for more than 50 years, died here tonight of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: AMEX VOLUME OFF TO 11MONTH LOW
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange posted their sec ond consecutive advance yes terday in the slowest trading in almost a year.

title: LOCKHEED'S CHIEF PRESSES JET PLANS
description: LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP)Dan iel J. Haughton, chairman of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, said today he hoped it would only be a matter of weeks before his company's Tristar airbus and the RollsRoyce RB 211 engine program was going again.

title: Fulbright and Laird at Odds on Military Aid Data
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird told the Senate Foreign Rela tions Committee today that the Defense Department did not have a current fiveyear plan for military assistance and therefore could not provide one as requested by the committee.

title: MISS FRACCI TAKES LEAD IN PAQUITA
description: American Ballet Theater's current production of Paquita saw Carla Fracci taking the fe male lead Thursday night for the first time during the current State Theater season. The di vertissement, constructed as it is for flashing showcase virtu osity, does not show Miss Fracci in her best light.

title: PAUL CUSHMAN; HELPED THE POOR
description: Paul Cushman, who devoted himself to social services after retiring as a stockbroker in 1942, died Thursday in Roose velt Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 115 East 67th Street.

title: Did the Ape Descend from Man?
description: CAMBRIDGEIs man descended from the apes? Recently, it was still thought that our ancestors branched off from something pretty close to the gorillas and chimps, as late as the Ice Age. Now, for the first time, fossil evidence is accumulating on man's early origins; and as the pieces fall into place, a very different solution is taking shape. We might even wonder whether it was the apes that descend ed from man's early ancestors, rather than the other way around.

title: HOMETOWN LAUDS BIX BEIDERBECKE
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, Aug. 6 (AP)Jazz buffs and musicians wearing Bix lives buttons toasted the jazz immortal, Bix Beiderbecke, with early morn ing champagne and the Daven port Bluesthe song he wrote for his hometownover his grave hero today.

title: Times to Buy Up to 50,000 Of Its Shares in the Market
description: The New York Times Com pany announced plans yester day to purchase in the open market up to 50,000 shares of its Class A common stock.

title: Amid Distrust in Past Pakistan, a Need for Coexistence
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 4 A Bengali pedicab driver had parked his flamboyantly decorated tricycle taxi out side the entrance to the In tercontinental Hotel and was watching people go in and out.

title: News Analysis
description: Welfare clients, normally among the quietest of Amer ican social groups, have organ ized across racial lines and around a common cause of need and are pushing to become a force that the nation will have to respect.

title: Miss Joan Marie Accettella Married to Mark. W. Kenedy
description: BAY SHORE, L.T., Aug. 6 Miss Joan Marie Accettella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ramon F. Accettella, was married here this afternoon to Mark William Kenedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Reid Kenedy. Both families are of Bay Shore.

title: 2 Detectives Bring $1Million Suits Against City
description: Two New York detectives, have demanded damages of $1 million each from the city on charges of false arrest, false imprisonment, assault and def amation by members of the Police Department's anticorrup tion unit.

title: A British Sailor Circles World Against Winds and Currents
description: HAMBLE, England, Aug. 6 Wrong Way Chay returned home today, successfully com pleting the first solo nonstop sea voyage around the world in a westerly direction, against prevailing winds and currents.

title: Rabbi Jay Kaufman, 52, Dies; Vice President of B'nai B'rith
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Rabbi Jay Kaufman, executive vice president of B'nai B'rith, Jewish service organization, since May, 1965, died last night of pneumonia at Washington Hospital Center. He was 52 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Two Prominent Leftists In Egypt Reported Held
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6 (UPI)The Beirut newspaper Al Nahar said today that the Egyptian authorities had arrest ed two prominent Communist sympathizers. It identified them as Khaled Mohieddin, an Egyp tian politician known as the Red officer for his leftist leanings, and Ibrahim Saadud din, president of the Socialist Institute of Egypt.

title: BRITAIN TO INCREASE GARRISON IN ULSTER
description: LONDON, Aug. 6Britain announced today that she would increase her garrison in North ern Ireland by 1,800 men in the face of the prospect of in creased strife there.

title: Martin's Goal Is Integrity for Market
description: William McChesney Mar tin Jr. said yesterday that his proposals for a broad reor ganization of the nation's securities markets were de signed to enhance their in tegrity so that investors would be sure of having access to the best possible markets.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug 6 (UPI) President Juan Velasco Alva rado announced today that Peru had approved recogni tion of China.

title: CURRENCY FUROR SUBSIDES ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 6The tur moil in European foreignex change markets subsided today, as the unexpected mid week outburst of speculation involving the French franc pe tered out. Dealers said the whole thing might have been avoided by more adroit han dling in Paris.

title: Busch to Be Honored
description: The 80th birthday of the late Adolf Busch, one of the found ers of the Marlboro Music Fes tival, will be commemorated at the festival on Sunday with a performance of his Quintet for Flute and Strings.

title: Banning Biological Weapons
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have virtually assured another forward step in arms control by submit ting to the Geneva disarmament conference a joint draft treaty to ban the development, production and stockpil ing of biological weapons.

title: U.S Five Is Eliminated At Cali on Point Spread
description: CALL Colombia, Aug. 6In a game filled with foreign in trigue and ethical overtones fa miliar to sports gambling in stincts, Brazil beat Cuba, 7368, today to eliminate the United States from basketball competi tion in the PanAmerican Games for the first, time.

title: Pan AmT.W.A. Talks On Merger Continuing
description: The possibility of a merger between Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines remained open yes terday after Pan Am's di rectors reviewed the progress of discussions between the two.

title: A U.N. Team in Geneva To Direct Pakistani Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 6 (Reuters)Secretary General Thant reported today that a United Nations work ing group had been estab lished in Geneva to coordi nate the total United Nations relief effort for East Pakistan.

title: Market Place: After the Storm, Some Sunshine
description: If you're looking for that sustained bull marketwhich, like prosperity, may be just around the corneryou had better use a highpowered periscope.

title: Wounded Bank Robber Flees in Crowded Bus
description: After holding up a Bronx bank, a robber was shot in the leg by a detective yester day but managed to escape In a crowded city bus. He did not have the required exact fare, but he did have two guns.

title: LOUIS KOHL
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 6  Louis Kohl, a partner in the brokerage firm of Gruntal & Co. stockbrokers, and a mem ber of the American Stock Exchange, died Wednesday at his home in Horizon Towers North. His age was 70.

title: Tokyo Gives Business A U.S. View of Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 6 (AP)The Foreign Ministry has distrib uted to business circles in Japan an English translation of a document called A List ing of Recent U. S. Criticisms Against Japan.

title: 8 UNDINE CREWS GAIN IN ROWING
description: The Undine Barge Club of Philadelphia qualified eight crews in the 95th national row ing championships yesterday on the Orchard Beach Lagoon course. The New York Athletic Club followed close behind with seven qualifiers in the 24 races that were rowed from quartermile dashes to 2,000 meter events.

title: Cali Is the City of Hopes: Some White, Some Black
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 6 Bobby Lee Hunter stands feet 2 inches and weighs 112 pounds, a quiet, 21yearold black convict from a South Carolina correctional institu tion.

title: Sale of Tracks Planned
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Compa ny have signed a memorandum to sell the New Haven Rail road's mainline passenger tracks between Boston and Providence, RI., to the State of Massachusetts and the Mas sachusetts Bay Transportation Authority.

title: ResearchCottrell Project
description: ResearchCottrell, Inc., has received a contract for the first commercialscale installation of a new combination fly ash and sulphur oxide removal system. The contract, for more than $4 million, was awarded by the Arizona Public Service Com pany for its Cholla generating plant at Joseph City, Ariz.

title: TWO POLICE GROUPS RECEIVE PARITY PAY
description: Nearly $5.5million in retro active parity payments went to 3,208 transit patrolmen and to 829 housing authority police men yesterday, the City Con troller's office announced.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Community Development. The President appointed Samuel C. Jackson, an As sistant H.U.D. Secretary, to be general manager of the newly created Community Development Corporation. The corporation will make grants, loans and loan guar antees for assisting new com munities under the direction of the H.U.D. Secretary.

title: Psycholinguistics: A New Science Rises From Babble
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 6When Psamettlchus, King of Egypt In the sixth century B.C., wanted to find the primordial language of man, he entrust ed two infants to a shepherd, who was never to let them hear a word.

title: South African Halts Filipino
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Aug. 6 (UPI)Anthony Sithole of South Africa stopped Willie Cordova of the Philippines after the fifth round of a sched uled 10rounder today when Cordova was unable to continue because of a cut left eye. Sit hole weighed 122 pounds, Cordova 122.

title: Yanks Rout Orioles, 123, for 5th in Row
description: The Yankees crushed the Baltimore Orioles, 123, last night, creating an atmosphere that prompted Toby Wright, the Yankee Stadium organist, to play Seems Like Old Times late in the game.

title: BirthCurb Backer Seized; Child, 3, Attended His Talk
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 6 (AP)William R. Baird, the birth control advocate, was ar rested tonight while speaking on birth control to a women's liberation group and charged with endangering the welfare of a 3yearold child who was with her mother in the audi ence.

title: Swiss Release Dr. Leary
description: GENEVA, Aug. 6Dr. Tim othy Leary, jailed here since June 30, at Washington's re quest, was released today from Bois Mermet Prison in Laus anne, under $18,000 bail. Offi cials acceded to a request for his release for health reasons, since no demand for Dr. Leary's extradition had been received from the United States. He will have to report regularly to the Swiss police.

title: Appeals Judge Delays Ruling on Ellsberg
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 6 Judge Frank M. Coffin of the United States Court of Appeals said today that he would con sult with at least one of the two other appeals judges be fore ruling on a petition by Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Frederick Stephan, Professor Of Statistics at Princeton, Dies
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 6 Frederick F. Stephan, a statis tical expert and professor emeritus of social statistics at Princeton University, died Monday at Princeton Hospital. He was 68 years old.

title: LOSSES TRIMMED BY CROP FUTURES
description: Influenced by a private, au thoritative estimate of record harvests of corn and soybeans this year, commodity futures were heavily traded on the Chi cago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Antiques: Steeple Clocks
description: American steeple clocks of the 19th century are turning up in the strangest places these days.

title: The Talk of Taipei
description: TAIPEI, TaiwanTaipei, a resident said, is a city with no past and no future.

title: Shop Talk
description: The dictionary definition of a bassinet is an infant's bed made of wickerwork, plastic or any other mate rial, but the dictionary hasn't heard of Mrs. Marcia Taaffe. By the time Mrs. Taaffe has finished with a simple wicker basket, a pe riod that entails anywhere from three to 12 days, it is swathed, lined, decorated and guaranteed to give any baby an unassailable sense of secur rity. Mrs. Taaffe, who is tucked away in her own workroom at Saks Fifth Ave nue, views an unadorned bas sinet with somewhat the same emotion as most peo ple accord a naked baby. She can't wait to cover the basic structure with layers of fabric and then further adorn the covering with em broidery and bows. Every thing is done by hand.

title: AIRLINES' TALKS ABOUT $20 APART
description: MONTREAL, Aug 6A dis agreement on $20 in the price of a proposed new kind of roundtrip excursion ticket be tween North America and Eu rope was the major obstacle today blocking approval of a new trans  Atlantic air  fare agreement.

title: AETNA LIFE ACCEPTS ROYAL COACH STOCK
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 6 (UPI) Accepting stock in place of dollars it was owed, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company has gained operating control of Royal Coach Inc., operators of five luxury hotels, it was announced today.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 6Philip Toynbee, the English critic, was writing in The Observer of London some years ago about The Naked Lunch and an other book by William Burroughs. He was troubled at finding himself on the side of the Philistines.

title: Dr. Charles Lyon, Botanist and Researcher, Dies
description: HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 6 Dr. Charles J. Lyon, professor emeritus and adjunct research professor of botany at Dart mouth College, died today in the college infirmary. He was 74 years old.

title: PANTHERS FREED IN NEW ORLEANS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6 Twelve Black Panthers were found not guilty today of at tempted murder of five New Orleans policemen in a shoot out last Sept. 15.

title: U.S Plans Complex I.M.F. Deal That Cuts Reserves $1Billion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) In a complex deal reflecting the dollar's international weak ness, the United States said today that it would exchange $862million in Belgian francs and Dutch guilders for dollars those two nations don't want.

title: Play Opens Here Today In Stevens Cup Tennis
description: Peru will play Mexico to day at the Town Tennis Club in the opening matches for the Stevens Cup, often re ferred to as the Senior Davis Cup. The first group of inter zone matches, pairing the South American winner and the Central American cham pion, will start at 2 P.M. The series will continue through Monday.

title: Greek Press Traditions
description: Among the writers who could not meet the proposed governmental requirement that words written in Greece heed the HellenicChristian traditions are Aesop, Aes chylus, Aristophanes, Demosthenes, Euripides, Herodotus, Pindar, Plato and Socrates. Since they wrote more than two thousand years ago, they might satisfy the Hellenic qualification but not the Christian.

title: Ann Huff Is Bride
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 6  Miss Ann Plant Huff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Craig Huff Jr. of Swampscott and Hopedale, was married here at noon today to Andrew Loring Rowe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowe of Chicago and Edgartown. The Rev. Dr. Rollin J. Fairbanks performed the ceremony in Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: Draft Advice Planned
description: BOSTON, Aug. 6 (UPI)The Archdiocese of Boston said to day that it had established a draft counseling service to give young parishioners expert ad vise about military service. Archbishop Humberto S. Me deiros said that the program had been set up because many parish priests did not have enough information to counsel young draftees.

title: Davis Museum of Arts May Close in the Fall
description: The Shelby Cullom Davis Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center will close by early fall if opera tional funds are not made available, a library official has warned.

title: Woolworth Profit Down
description: The F. W. Woolworth Com pany, the nation's largest chain of variety stores, had lower earnings in this year's first half, reflecting rising costs and the decreased profit of its Brit ish subsidiary, the company re ported yesterday.

title: Bills Subdue Saints on Harris's Scoring Pass, 1410
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 6 (AP)An electrifying 92yard punt re turn by Alvin Wyatt and the fourthquarter passing of Jim Harris paced the Buffalo Bills to a 1410 victory over New Orleans in a preseason game tonight.

title: WILLIAM H. GOODMAN
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 6 (AP)William H. Goodman, president and publisher of The CourierNews, Plainfield, died yesterday of cancer. He was 50 years old.

title: Dance: A Modernist Trend in London
description: LONDON, Aug 6The quest for the English version of the American modem dance continues apace. At least I think it is apace that it is continuing. Not only has the Royal Ballet mounted a new work by Glen Tetley in which even Rudolf Nu reyev is scheduled to appear next season  but also two moderndance companies are making considerable head way with British critics and, to perhaps a lesser extent, with British audiences.

title: U.S.SOVIET PARLEY ON SPACE IS ENDED
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 6 (UPI) Three joint SovietAmerican space groups have completed five days of meetings in Mos cow and adopted a number of unspecified recommendations for space cooperation, the United States Embassy an nounced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As part of its drive to break even financially, the new.U.S. Postal Serv ice might consider asking Congress to levy appropriate, surcharges on the Federal taxes of those who live in rural or suburban areas where mail delivery costs are significantly higher than those in cities.

title: NIXON SETS LIMIT ON JOB PROMOTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The White House ordered Cabinet departments today to limit pro motions among the Govern ment's 1.2 million whitecollar workers in order to cut costs and seta standard for private industry.

title: Syracuse Fire Bomb Area Reported Relatively Quiet
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 6A pre dominantly black district of Syracuse, hit by three nights of firebombings, was relatitive ly quiet last night, a police of ficial said.

title: Laotian Military Reshuffle Reported
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 4 A drastic reshuffle of the mili tary command designed to re store the eroded hold of the central Government in this factionalized kingdom has re ceived royal approval and will soon be announced, according to high Government sources.

title: Roundup: Cash's Homer Thwarts Red Sox Gain
description: Norm Cash reported to spring training determined to prove a point. He had to con vince Billy Martin, the new Detroit Tiger manager, he wasn't washed up and fit only for parttime duty at the age of 36.

title: An Emergency Funding Bill For Pennsylvania Enacted
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 6 (AP)  Gov. Milton J. Shapp signed an emergency funding bill today to meet government expenses in the absence of a budget through the month of August.

title: PRICES MARK TIME ON STOCK MARKET
description: It's really quiet here today, a broker in midtown Manhat tan remarked yesterday, after noon. To tell you the truth, things are extremely dull.

title: END AID FOR REGION, E.E.C. ORDERS ITALY
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 6  The European Common Market Commission has told Italy that she must end the aid that she gives to attract industry to the region of FriuliVenezia Giulia.

title: Notes on People
description: Three years ago this month, in 4 hotel in Miami Beach, other members of the New Jersey delegation to the Re publican National Conven tion pleaded in vain with Nelson G. Gross to remain committed to the favorite son candidacy of Senator Clifford P. Case, who was trying to hold the delegation together for Governor Rocke feller.
