When the floor vote came, Mr. Gross switched to Richard M. Nixon, breaking the delegation and dashing any possibility that Mr. Rockefeller might block Mr. Nixon's nomination on the first ballot.

title: British Gas Council Sets Deal With M. W. Kellogg
description: The British Gas Council and the M. W. Kellogg Company have agreed to cooperate in the development of substitute na tural gas process technology.

title: Ruskin Will List the Landlords City Suspects of Loan Frauds
description: Robert K. Ruskin, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that he would disclose next week the names of landlords who he says have defrauded the city of substan tial funds under the Munici pal Loan Program.

title: Taipei Won't Comment On Its Ankara Policy
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 6 Government officials would not comment today on the significance of Taiwan's suspension rather than sev erance of diplomatic rela tions with Turkey, which yes terday announced her recog nition of Communist China.

title: ROBBERIES FOILED AT 2 BANK BRANCHES
description: Attempts to rob two branches of the First National City Bank yesterday failed. Two suspects were captured and no money was taken.

title: Merger News
description: The Coleman Company and the Crosman Arms Company, Inc., announced yesterday they had approved a previously an nounced agreement to merge Crosman into Coleman.

title: 3 Queens Men Arrested In Sale of Bogus Money
description: Three Queens men were ar rested by Secret Service agents yesterday in two separate ar rests involving the sale of $175,000 worth of counterfeit money.

title: Farm Closures Decried
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Senator Hubert H. Humphrey protested today that the na tion's farmers were the for gotten Americans, as far as consumers and Government economists are concerned.

title: Suharto's Party Clear Victor; His Reappointment in '73 Seen
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 6 Gen. Suharto's Government, as expected, has won a large enough victory in Indonesia's national election virtually to guarantee his reappointment in 1973 as President for another five years.

title: Splashdown Forecast Ideal
description: ABOARD U.S.S. OKINAWA, Aug. 6 (AP)  Ideal weather conditions were forecast today for tomorrow's splashdown of the Apollo 15 astronauts north of Hawaii.

title: LAYOFFS SPREAD AT STEEL MILLS
description: Six days after the steel in dustry and union agreed on a new contract without a walk out, tens of thousands of steel workers have been laid off and many hearths are cold, as steel users draw from inventories stockpiled against a strike.

title: A CONCERT SAMPLER OF MOZART OPERAS
description: Selections from eight of Mo zart's operas made up the pro gram of the Mostly Mozart Festival concert at Philhar monic Hall on Thursday night. Eve Queler conducted, and nine singers were on hand to per form arias and ensemble num bers of various types with the New York Chamber Orchestra.

title: Grace Amid the Concrete
description: It is not always easy to persuade businessmen of the need to build headquarters that are more than the metal, stone and glass required to enclose corporate personnel and computers. It is to the credit of the companies Whose buildings will make an expanded Rockefeller Center that they were so persuaded.

title: First U.S. Unit in War Ends Its Combat Role
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6The last troops of the first United States Army unit to enter the Vietnam war, over five years ago, pulled out of the field today in preparation for the trip home.

title: HEARD'S 133 LEADS AMERICAN CLASSIC BY THREE STROKES
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 6 (AP) Jerry Heard, without a victory in his three seasons on the pro tour, shot a fourunderpar 66 today for a 36hole total of 133 in the $150,000 American Golf Classic.

title: POLLUTION PANEL FORESEES GAINS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6  The White House Council on Environmental Quality said to day in its second annual report that the costs of controlling pol lution will be high over all but well within the capacity of the American economy to absorb.

title: THREE TIED AT 70 IN ATLANTA GOLF
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 6 (AP)Mrs. Marlene Hagge and Margee Masters sank putts for birdies on the 19th green today to tie Mrs. Judy Rankin for the open inground lead at 70 in the $20,000 Lady Pepsi open. The trio leads by two strokes.

title: HorseDies, 4 Riders Hurt In State Fair Race PileUp
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 6 (AP) Four jockeys were injured and one horse was killed in a pileup yesterday during the State Fair races.

title: Mrs. Alice Hardenbergh Clark, Women's Groups Leader, Dies
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 6Mrs. Alice Harden bergh Clark, who had been ac tive in efforts to improve pub lic education, died yesterday of cancer in Greenwich Hospi tal. Her age was 60.

title: Agriculture Department Forms New Rights Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) A new Office of Equal Op portunity in the Agriculture Department has been set up with a 33yearold black law professor in charge, the Sec retary of Agriculture, Clifford M. Hardin, announced today.

title: Never Bow, TopWeighted at 126 Pounds, Favored Today in $60,500 Whitney
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6The Whitney Stakes, one of the more attractive races on the local calendar, will serve as the feature on tomorrow's card. With a field of 14 listed to compete in the 44th running, the Whitney will have a gross value of $60,500, with $36,300 earmarked for the winner. The conditions of the race call for weight distribution to be made primarily on the basis of earn ings.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Two days after The Times published the shocking story about the French youth paralyzed possibly for life in wanton, murderous attack by robbers, William vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, charges barbaric treatment in connection with the suicide of a youth who was awaiting sentence after pleading guilty in the stabbing to death of an elderly man In Queens.

title: Saigon Units Report Killing 68 in Battles In Eastern Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, Aug. 7 (AP)A South Vietnamese armored column, reinforced by infantrymen, bat tled North Vietnamese and Viet cong troops yesterday in a fresh outbreak of fighting in eastern Cambodia.

title: Ryan Committee Aims to Head Off The 50Cent Fare
description: Representative William F. Ryan announced yesterday the formation of a committee of 60 legislators, public officials and civic and trade union leaders to stop the 50cent fare.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Medical Schools in City Gaining Minority Students
description: Enrollment in the city's seven medical schoolsvir tually all white as recently as three years agois be ginning to include significant numbers of blacks and Puerto Ricans.

title: OUTPUT OF CARS DOWN FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, Aug. 6 (AP) United States auto production fell this week, but the trade paper Automotive News re ported that the modelchange over slowdown had bottomed out and that production would show a steady rise until full production of 1972 models was reached.

title: U. S. Without Information
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) U. S. officials said today that they had no information to con firm the report.

title: Chatfield in Swim Upset
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 6 (AP) The United States won nine gold medals in swimming, shooting and weightlifting to day at the sixth PanAmerican Games.

title: Lockheed Wins Contracts For a Total of $53Million
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reu ters)The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has been awarded three contracts totaling $51 million, the Defense Depart ment announced today. All three were modifications of ex isting contracts.

title: Gisbert Routs Gorman
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (UPI) Seeded players continued to drop from the 84th Western championships today as Juan Gisbert of Spain defeated fourthseeded Tom Gorman of Seattle, 61, 63.

title: World Land Speed Record Established By Silver Eagle
description: WENDOVER, Utah, Aug. 6 (UPI)The bulletshaped Silver Eagle set a world land speed record today of 146.437 miles an hour for electric cars, using the same type of batteries that powered the Apollo 15 lunar rover.

title: HighFlying Check on Mars
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 6 (UPI) Twentynine scientists, con vinced that their rare look at Mars from a jet will make an important contribution to man's knowledge of the planet, made their second flight today over the Pacific in a highaltitude astronomical laboratory. The scientists hope infrared emis sions from Mars will tell them about the planet's atmosphere, temperature and surface water content.

title: 8th Atlanta Drug Death
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 6 (UPI) Anthony Crutch, a 15yearold boy with 61 needle marks on his arms, died today of appar ent drug abuse, becoming the eighth young victim here in the last nine days. It is the most I can ever recall due to drugs, said a detective, Captain Morris Redding.

title: Mexico Says She Has No Guerrillas, Just Bandits
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 6  Despite steppedup terrorist activities in several cities and publication of a recent inter view with a rural guerrilla leader, the Mexican Govern ment is maintaining Its posi tion that no guerrillas are active in this country.

title: She Doesn't Bother to Wear Her Own Jewelry
description: ROME  She wears her international workingartist uniform of black sweater and blue jeans whether she's at her workbench or greeting prospective customers in her starkly modern shop at 16 Via Gregoriana.

title: Crum & Forster Increases Dividend and Plans a Split
description: Crum & Forster, the insur ance concern, has announced an increase in the dividend and plans for a 2for1 stock split.

title: The GoodGuy Americans
description: Every Saturday night, when the sober news reports from Saigon to Santiago are over, it is comforting to view a broadcast where Americans are united at home and devastatingly efficient abroad; a broadcast where intense young students wait eagerly for the Americans to arrive and wave goodby sadly when it comes time for them to go; a broadcast which injects the old American daring, strength and pioneer ingenuity into foreign affairs. Mission Impossible.

title: GROMYKO TO VISIT INDIA TOMORROW
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 6Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union will visit India Sunday in what foreign dip lomats here view as a ges ture of solidarity in India's current dispute with Pakistan.

title: SUBWAY POWER CUT AFTER F TRAIN FIRE
description: An empty IND F train caught fire shortly after it dis charged its passengers yester day morning and was taken to a layup spur at Second Avenue and Houston Street.

title: Lon Nol Presides Again
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 6 (Reuters)Premier Lon Nol presided today over his first full Cabinet meeting since he suffered a paralyzing stroke in February.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Evel Knievel's doctor looks at the motorcycle stunt man and says, Every man has to make his mark. Yours'll be on the north wall. Evel, who does not have much of a sense of humor, is not amused. Evel describes himself as the last gladiator in the new Rome, a man whose role is lift humanity from the humdrum by jumping 20 cars with out getting splattered. His credo, once shouted to his bridetobe as they cycled down the steep steps of her college residence, is: It doesn't matter if, you get killed if you're doing something you believe in.

title: Formosa's Future
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio  The re cent dramatic developments in Wash ingtonPeking relations have created an atmosphere conducive to a more rational and less emotional discussion concerning the future of Formosa. In evitably, it is one problem the United States will have to face, because ad justing relations with Peking auto matically involves adjusting relations with Taipei.

title: Executive Changes
description: U. S. Industries, Inc., announced yesterday the election of C. Russell Luigs as corporate executive vice president and director of the consumer serv ices and industrial products company. Mr. Luigs, who joined the company in 1957 as a sales engi neer, was formerly a corporate vice president.

title: APOLLO ON TARGET FOR SPLASHDOWN IN PACIFIC TODAY
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 6  The Apollo 15 astronauts sped clos er to earth today with such precise aim that, for the first time, no course correction was considered necessary before splashdown.

title: Ericsson Receives Orders For Brazilian Telephones
description: The L. M. Ericcson Telephone Company reported yesterday receipt of two contracts total ing $37million for telecommu nications equipment to be de livered to Brazilian telephone administrations.

title: 747 JET IN MISHAP CALLED TOO HEAVY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said yesterday that he had in formation indicating that Pan American World Airways jumbo jet, badly damaged tak ing off from San Francisco on July 30, may have been be tween 10 and 25 tons over weight.

title: Coop at 4 East 72d St. W ins Discrimination Case
description: The City Commission on Hu man Rights ruled yesterday that a prospective buyer had failed to prove that he was denied an East Side cooperative apartment because he was a Jew.

title: Democrats to Meet '72 Hopefuls Here
description: Democratic district leaders, officeholders and other politi cians throughout the city have been invited to meet potential Democratic Presidential candi dates late this month at a gathering at the Long Island estate, of Jerry Finkelstein, chairman of the city's Demo cratic Committee.

title: RISE IN STEEL PRICES TO CAUSE INDEX GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (Reu ters)The recent 8 per cent rise in steel prices will cause the Industrialprice component of the wholesaleprice index to rise 0.3 per cent in the next two months, according to the Bu reau of Labor Statistics.

title: Pacific Coast Exchange Reports 6Month Profit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (AP)The Pacific Coast Stock Exchange has announced a profit on increased trading volume for the first six months of 1971.

title: ClipClop in Park Gets Younger Beat
description: Under the tall silk hat there is likely to be a mane rivaling the horse's. And the traditional garb of black cut away coat and tails has given way to a melange of denim, leather and suede. The under30 generation in New York City has discov ered a new occupation: driv ing horsedrawn cabs.

title: Mrs. Reyea Is Wed Here
description: Mrs. Pamela Shearer Relyea and Walter M. Eberhart Jr., both of New York, were mar ried here yesterday afternoon in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler.

title: What's an Old Shack Doing in the Shadow of East Hampton?
description: SAGAPONACK, L. I.Even old shacks can fit into a sophisticated building scheme in this resort village about five miles west of East Hampton.

title: Horror Film:'Brotherhood of Satan' Showing at Criterion
description: Lovers of horror movies are doubly deceived. Already so lost in Plato's cave that our eyes can only recognize the shadows, we still seek an ideal that is no more than what our dreams project into the deeper darkness. Almost everybody I know has a perfect horror movie in mind, and, of course, nobody has ever seen it. Everybody has seen bits and pieces of it, however. And in "The Brotherhood of Satan," which opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater, there are more bits and piecessometimes simply how long a shot is held, or the way the camera moves or doesn't moveto hoard against the rational daylight and the miseries of common sense."The Brotherhood of Satan" concerns a coven of ancient witches who take up residence in an isolated Southwestern town, where they proceed in a dreadful manner to gather the town's children of a certain age, whose bodies they plan to enter so as to ensure their immortality. They lack one to make the necessary 13, and it is for this reason that a young vacationing couple (Charles Bateman and Ahna Capri), whose daughter (Geri Reischl) has just had a birthday, find that they can drive into the town but that they cannot possibly leave.The witches procure their children by means of dolls and toys, not as enticements but as a way of murdering parentslike the toy tank that in the pre-credit sequence systematically demolishes a car and its occupants, leaving only a little boy, free now to join his already enchanted companions. In this sequence, and in a few others, the film displays bold, direct, relatively uncomplicated acceptance of its supernature that seems the essence of fantasy moviemaking and that extends to some wonderfully spooky scenesin a car, in a family living roomin which nothing quite happens and which are the most terrifying moments in "The Brotherhood of Satan."Compared with this, the actual brotherhood (and sisterhood) is a pretty dismal affaira kind of black-magic golden-age club to whom hooded figures serve cocktails before they settle down to their blood and witchcraft. Much of the latter involves parody religious ritual, along with a ritual cinematic bathos of hand-held camera, eerie closeups, etc., that only disrupts the mood at hand.A large part of "The Brotherhood of Satan" is set in the local sheriff's office, where the sheriff (L. Q. Jones), his deputy (Alvy Moore) and eventually the young couple lock themselves away from the terror stalking the town. These scenes are poorly acted and woodenly written, but they suggest a few ideas. I don't know what Bernard McEveety's ambitions as a director are. I don't think that he is about to bring the white magic of "El Dorado" or "Rio Bravo" into this genre. But around the little group of besieged good guys and the lighted office in the night, I begin to weave a fantasy and to dream of an ultimate Howard Hawks horror movie.

title: Music: In the Parks
description: The New York Philhar monic, flooded out in its attempt to open its summer season Tuesday night in Cen tral Park and drizzled upon throughout Wednesday night's only slightly more successful concert in Staten Island, finally broke out of the clouds on Thursday night. The Nethermead of Brook lyn's Prospect Park was flooded, but this time it was with music listeners, who were served up an excellent concert under the direction of Istvn Kertsz.

title: General Signal Unit Wins Washington Transit Job
description: The General Signal Corpora tion's General Railway Signal Company unit has announced that it was low bidder at $59, 567,737 for a new automated train control and communica tions system for the mass tran sit network now being con structed to serve Washington, D. C.

title: GREEKS FREE 18 OF 25 IN SEDITION TRIALS
description: ATHENS, Aug. 6An Athens court tonight acquitted 18 of 25 Greeks charged with sedi tion. Seven defendants were given relatively light prison sentences, ranging from three months to three years.

title: Laver and Ashe Ousted In Tennis Quarterfinals
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 6 (UPI)Seventhseeded Marty Riessen rallied from one set down and fought off two match points today to upset Rod Laver and join Cliff Drys dale, Ken Rosewall and John Newcombe in the semifinals of the $50,000 United States pro tennis championships.

title: SIX NEW ISSUES TRADED IN WEEK
description: Six privately owned compa niesengaged in petroleum ex ploration, doubleknit fabrics, automobile supplies, sports wear, electronics and the in stallation of telephone lines offered their shares to a gen erally unenthusiastic public this week, specialists in new issues reported.

title: Travelers Net Up in Half;
description: The Travelers Corporation, one of the nation's leading in surance concerns, reported yes terday that net adjusted earn ings for the first half of 1971 advanced to $45.38million, or 97 cents a share, tip substan tially from the $40.23million, or 85 cents, reported a year earlier.

title: U.N. Concert and Dinner Slated Oct. 23 in Capital
description: Bernard J. Lasker, former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday an nounced the annual United Na tions concert and dinner to be held in Washington, D. C., Oct. 23 under the patronage of Pres ident and Mrs. Nixon.

title: Wide Range of Products Tagged With Price Rises
description: Foreign cars, newsprint, box board, steel and aluminum were among the products whose prices moved upward yesterday.

title: DRAFT OFFICIALS EXPLAIN POLICIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Men born in 1952 who hold draft deferments next year will not be inducted for military service as long as they retain their deferments. If they lose their deferments in a subse quent year they will be drafted only if their lottery number is reached in that year's call.

title: 78 Dead in Storm's Wake In Japan and South Korea
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 7 (AP)Typhoon Olive swept out of southwestern Japan and eastern Korea yesterday after killing 78 persons and injuring campsite of the 13th World Boy Scout Jamboree.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 A New York consulting physicist, who contracted rheumatoid arthritis and lost almost completely the use of his hands, regained full control of them with an exerciser he invented. Sem yon E. Krewer is patenting his Hand Gym, which has been used in hospitals and clinics and will be placed on the market this fall by the Tip Top Tool Company, Inc., Philadelphia.

title: FREDERICK T. SMALL; OWNED RARE STAMP
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 6Frederick T. Small, the Australian stamp collector who once owned the world's rarest stamp, the British Guiana 1cent magenta, died today at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Unemployment Rate Is Up But Below the Peak of May
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 6The nation's unemployment rate moved slightly higher in July from the artificially low rate of June but remained well below the peaks of last winter and spring, the Labor Department reported today.

title: RETRAINING PLANS FOUND TO AID FEW
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 6The re training of outofwork scien tists, engineers and technicians to provide them with new ca reers in such fields as environ mental control and urban plan ning appears to have met with scant success.

title: Nixon Seeks Better Nursing Homes
description: NASHUA,. N. H., Aug. 6  President Nixon, announced here today a series of steps using Federal funds to super vise and improve conditions in nursing homes around the country.

title: Carolyn Beale Married
description: ROCHESTER, Aug. 7 Miss Carolyn Clark Beale and David Van Varick were married here this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Gerald Moser. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Robert Beale of Rochester. Her father is with the Boller Clark Division of Marsh & McLean, insurance brokers and consultants, of which he is a vice president. Her hus band is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Van Varick of Oradell, N.J. His father is secretary of the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation in York.

title: HOMER, GUITARIST WITH JETHRO, DIES
description: HAMMOND, Ind., Aug. 7 (UPI)Henry T. Haynes, the guitarist known to country and Western music fans for many years as Homer of Homer and Jethro, died of a heart attack toady at St. Margaret's Hos pital. He was 51 years old, and lived in Lansing.

title: Miss Blalock Cards 70 and Takes 2Shot Lead in Lady Pepsi Golf on 142 Total
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 7 (UPI) Jane Blalock from Concord, N. H., resumed where she left off last year and grabbed the secondround lead in the Lady Pepsi golf tournament today.

title: Protanto First at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 7  Protanto, the Crag wood Stable's stretchrunner, came along in the final phase of the $60,500 Whitney today, to finish first. His runnerup among the 14 contestants in the 1mile event was the Hobeau Farm's Peace Corps, who preceded Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee.

title: D'Oriola Wins Irish Cup; Shapiro 4th on His Mount
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 7 (AP)Pierre Jonqueres d'Oriola gave France its first victory in the Dublin horse show championship by riding Moet et Chandon to vic tory in the Irish Distillers' event.

title: W. H. Smith Jr., Margaret Smith Have Wedding
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 7  Miss Margaret Dunn Smith and Winthrop Hiram Smith Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. Margaret's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. B. J. Fin negan. The Rev. Thomas Dwyer assisted. The couple's families are not related.

title: OneMan Veto
description: A year ago the conviction of George Meany that the International Labor Organization, was being turned into a sounding board for Soviet propaganda induced Con gress to cut off United States funds. This year the A.F.L,C.I.O. chief has parked his guns, but Representa tive John J. Rooney of Brooklyn has moved into the vacuum as a oneman torpedo squad against giving the I.L.O. the money this country owes under international law and the rules of the United Nations.

title: With Brooklyn Singers, All Is Harmony
description: The sounds of fourpart harmony, multiplied by 10 or 11 or even 12, billow out across 15th Avenue and 72d Street in Brooklyn these summer Tuesday evenings.

title: Smith Tops Proisy to Gain Final in Western Tennis
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 7 (AP) Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., seeded No. 1, defeated Patrick Proisy of France, 64, 61, in the semifinals today of the 184th annual Western tennis championships.

title: Tigers Register a 128 Victory Over Red Sox as McAuliffe Bats in Six Runs
description: BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP)Dick McAuliffe drove in six runs to day with his 13th homer and a pair of basesloaded hits as the Detroit Tigers outslugged the Boston Red Sox, 128.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Private pensions are an important fringe benefit for employers, and a critical aid to workers in retirement, but they also provide about $140 billion in investment capital and at least one economist thinks they are set to render a severe blow to the stock market.

title: Marcia Rogers Is Bride
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7Miss Marcia Ellen Rogers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Ferris Rogers Jr. of Es sex Fells, East Hampton, L. I., and Long Bay, Antigua, W. I., and William Martin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin of Fairfield, were married here today. The Rev. Vernon Shankle of the First Presby terian Church of Caldwell performed the ceremony in the church.

title: Seoul Aides Foresee Chance Of Meeting With the North
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. Premier Kim Jong Pil said to day that direct talks between South and North Korea would be inevitable some day in the future to achieve peaceful uni fication of the divided country.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON President Nixon's bitter antibusing statement was circu lated to millions last week by news papers, radio and television. But it went almost unnoticed that the very next day the school Superintendent of Harrisburg, Pa., refuted the Nixon posi tion point by point, in an account of the actual experience of that city.

title: U.S. GIRL, 14, SETS PANAM SWIM MARK;
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 7 Kim Peyton was nervous, more nervous than any time in her competitive swimming career. I wanted to do well, she said, because I thought it would get our team off to a good start.

title: EDITORIAL WRITERS LEAN TO DEMOCRATS
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Aug. 7 (UPI)Nearly twice as many edtorial writers for daily news papers say they are Democrats as the number who say they are Republicans, according to survey by the Indiana Univer sity Journalism department.

title: Martin Remedy: Shakeup Big Board
description: The heralded Martin Re port has officially emerged from the crisis that beset Wall Street last year, and it already is proving controver sial.

title: For optimist and pessimist
description: On the eve of the 200th anniver sary of the American nation Robert Dahl has written two books to prove that the experience was worth The trip. Not that he is merely a patriotic cheerleader: Polyarchy is addressed to those who are too optimistic about democracy, After the Revolution? to the overly pes simistic and the contemptuous.

title: Rough Regulator for Insurance
description: When Milton J. Shapp, the millionaire industrialist, be came Governor of Pennsyl vania about six months ago, one of the first persons he consulted was Ralph Nader.

title: Founder of Morris Plan Celebrates 90th Birthday
description: OSSINING, N. Y.Every day I meet people who say my father and my grandfather got started with the Morris Plan, said the founder of the plan, Arthur J. Morris, who celebrated his 90th birthday last Thursday.

title: SOLING CROWN GOES TO 1308 MOSBACHER
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP)Bob Mosbacher of Houston edged Lowell North of San Diego by about five sec onds today to claim the North American Soling Championship on Santa Monica Bay.

title: JURY MAY WIDEN ELLSBERG INQUIRY
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7A secret Federal grand jury re sumed its investigation here this week into how the Penta gon papers were made public.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Can you think of a single good reason that an adver tising agency would want to be among the first to try a fourday week?

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Et Al.
description: A jaundiced view of Cali fornia, which may or may not justify the subtitle (Report From Our First Parafascist State) but certainly does the title. Lamott by writing im pressionistically and produc ing a series of vignettes, has attempted to illuminate the Californians character, one of whose qualities seems to be a determination to be happy so strenuous that it causes un happiness. California knock ers like Lamott are outnum bered by the boosters but are more interesting to read.

title: Bengali Rebel Tells of Aid From India
description: KOTWALIPARA, Pakistan, Aug, 4 (AP)At a hideout in a 200squaremile paddy swamp members of the East Pakistani. Mukhti Bahini  Liberation Armysay they are getting shipments of mines and am munition and freshly trained Bengali reinforcements from India to support their warfare against the Pakistani Army.

title: Dance
STRIP MINING ADS WEIGHED BY F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The Federal Trade Commission has begun a preliminary investiga tion of possible unfair or de ceptive practices in national advertising by the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

title: Bunker to Fly to U.S. To Confer with Nixon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 (AP)  Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker will leave Saigon tomorrow for Wash ington to confer with Presi dent Nixon and other top officials, a United States Embassy spokesman said to day. Mr. Bunker is expected to remain in Washington about a week.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Orthodox Jews in Jerusalem Stone Buses and Fight Police
description: JERUSALEM. Aug. 7 (AP) Policemen battled Orthodox Jews for three hours tonight in the worst outbreak of recent violence triggered by alleged Sabbath violations.

title: Miss Joan McGrath Engaged To Massimo A. Triulzi of Italy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick of New York and Oyster Bay Cove, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss LucyJohn McGrath, to Massimo Alivse Triulzi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paolo Antonio Triulzi of Rome and Ronchi, Italy.

title: City to Modernize 2 Miles of 4th Ave., Brooklyn Artery
description: City Highway Commis sioner Vincent J. Gibney an nounced plans last week to modernize more than two miles of Fourth Avenue, a major northsouth artery in Brooklyn.

title: Jungle Lovers By Paul Theroux. 307 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $5.95.
description: Obviously, some novels are a pleasure to excoriate, others an hon or to celebrate. But those that fall between, especially the undoubtedly talented, ambitious nearmisses, are a real agony to review. I am un familiar with Paul Theroux's highly praised earlier novels, and only wish I could like Jungle Lovers more. There is so much that is admirable in the novel, and deeplyfelt; it dis tresses me to have to say that I, for one, found it ultimately unsat isfying. Forced in the ideological hot house. Even so, Jungle Lovers abounds with virtues. It is genuinely perceptive. Mr. Theroux's ear for the absurd, for the nuances of British and African dialogue, is convincing, subtle. He also writes exceedingly well about the taste and feel of tropical Africa.

title: Marriage and the Job
description: Marital discord doesn't necessarily destroy the career of the man who marries the boss's daughter.

title: STUDY FINDS LAG IN PRIVATE JOBS
description: New York State's job growth over the last decade generated only 1.7 new private jobs for every new Federal, state and local government employe added, according to an analysis released last week by Assem blyman Andrew Stein.

title: Boxer Getting Her Unkindest Cuts in Brooklyn
description: The former Brooklyn Navy Yard, where proud warships were once launched, is wit nessing the death of one of the Navy's proudest ships.

title: Koster Assumes New Post
description: ABERDEEN, Md., Aug. 7 (AP) Brig. Gen. Samuel W. Koster, who commanded the Americal Division at the time of the My lai slayings in Vietnam, has re ported to his new job as deputy commanding general and chief of staff at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground. He was re duced in rank from major gen eral by former Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor on May 19 for failure to adequately in vestigate the killings.

title: DR. JACOB S. FREEDMAN
description: PASSAIC, N. J., Aug. 7 Dr. Jacob S. Freedman, di rector of surgery at Beth Israel Hospital, died there to day of a heart ailment. He was 65 years old and lived at 178 Hamilton Avenue.

title: News of Dogs
description: A frequent complaint of dog owners flying to shows or on vacations is that they cannot take their pets in the plane's cabin.

title: Obscenity Curb Upheld
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 (AP) A panel of three Federal jud es here has upheld the consti tutionality of a yearold law al lowing persons to bar the mail ing of obscene material to them. People can notify the Postal Service they do not want to receive sex advertisements and companies that produce such material must comply.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Blomberg, a Gourmet, Seeks a More Diversified Diet of Pitchers
description: Ron Blomberg's gastronom ical feats very likely will become legends in their time:

title: House Painters Union Here Endorses New 3Year Pact
description: The union representing 10,000 New York City house painters voted 2 to 1 yesterday in favor of a new threeyear contract and averted a strike set for midnight tonight.

title: U.S. Beats Canada, 104, In Water Polo Test at Cali
description: CALI, Columbia, Aug. 7 (AP) The United States easily de feated Canada, 104, today in the first finalround water polo action of the PanAmerican Games.

title: Brookhaven Rezones to Allow for Mobile Homes
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I., Aug. 7A change. in zoning laws to enable the construction of mobilehome communities in the Town of Brookhaven was unanimously adopted by the Town Board this week, despite the opposition of many of the town's residents.

title: Miss Melville, Mrs. King Gain Houston Tennis Final
description: Houston, Aug. 7 (UPI)  Seventhseeded Kerry Melville and topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King battled their ways into the final of the $40,000 Vir ginia Slims international Hof heinz Pavillion.

title: Jockey Wins Six Races
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP)Roger Cox scored six victories and two secondplace finishes in eight races today, setting a Finger Lakes track record.

title: Room at the top
description: What do you do if you want to expand and you live in a fourroom house that is attached to the house next door on one side, has about four feet to the property line on the other two sides and abuts directly on the sidewalk in front? Clearly, you go up. That's what Anne Tyng did with her little red brick house in the heart of Philadelphia. Miss Tyng, an architectural theorist and writer who works with architect Louis Kahn, needed two years to work out her twolevel, highrise plan before she was ready to call in the builder. It took time, because she wanted a work room, a sitting room with fireplace, a bedroom, a bathroom and storage galoreall in a 13 by 26foot space. And a feeling of airiness and serenity. The photographs on this page how she achieved her goals.

title: MISS BARE RECORDS SWIMMING DOUBLE
description: LANCASTER, Pa., Aug. 7 (AP)Betty Lou Bare of the Lancaster Aquatic Club regis tered the only double victory in the Eastern swimming cham pionships at Golden Meadows Swimming Center today.

title: Theater by London
description: LONDON.

title: BALDWIN IS FIRST IN 420 CLASS SAIL
Et Al.
description: A straightforward account of Ivan Allen's climb to power in Atlanta and his two terms as mayor. Clear and unpretentious, the book also describes the city's progress in civil rights. Allen does not suggest that this progress is the child of senti ment; he has no doubt that Atlanta's growth as a Southern business center compelled the more liberal approach to race and politics. A solid political autobiography.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: Erich Segal's Identity Cri sis was reduced to absurdity many years ago in Saki's The Secret Sin of Septimus Brope. All his present agony could have been avoided i?? Mr. Segal had written Love Story under a pseudonym and then kept his mouth shut. Had he done this, he would now be laughing rather than crying all the way to the bank.

title: Et Al.
description: Still another book on Israeli identity. J. L. Talmon, profes sor of modern history at the Hebrew University of Jeru salem, has fresh things to say, and says them clearly. His book is divided into three es says, on Jews as revolution aries, on the durability of Theodor Herzl's Jewish State, and the merging of the twin forces of nationalism and revo lution that resulted in the pres ent state of Israel. Talmon wears his scholarship lightly but securely and is a pleasure to read.

title: Texas School Official Confused by Conflicting U. S. Stands on Busing
description: AUSTIN Tex., Aug. 7Man in White House speaks with fork in tongue, said Jack Da viddson in a weary tone.

title: My Son, the President
description: The board of directors of the Stop & Shop Com panies, the New England based supermarket chain, met last Monday and to no one's surprise promoted Avram J. Goldberg, 41 years old, from executive vice president to president.

title: Gulf Coast of Florida Alerted For New Outbreak of Red Tide
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla, Aug. 7Patches of the fishkilling microorganism called the Red Tide remained bottled up in Tampa Bay this week as clean up crews claimed they were winning the massive job of carting away tons of dead fish.

title: PANEL GIVES WAYS TO SAVE 30C FARE
description: A panel appointed by Mayor Lindsay yesterday recommended action by a special session of the Legislature to save the 30 cent subway and bus fare here.

title: ORAL HISTORY BOOK TO AID U.S. SCHOLARS
description: A new research resource in modern history was made avail able last week by the Oral His tory Association.

title: Et Al.
description: The effects of sensory per ceptions through the skin on human behavior. Montagu does not fall into the trap of attrib uting total character formation to his subject, but he does ar gue from animal and human behavior that especially in in fancy touching or the lack of it plays an important part. For instance, some women starved for touch as babies grow up to be nymphomaniacs or prosti tutes, although why others don't isn't clear. This is less a popularization than most of Mr. Montagu's books.

title: GROUP WOULD AID BENGALI SCHOLARS
description: A Harvard University econ omist has combined an urgent appeal for relief to East Pakis tani intellectuals who have fled, to India with a warning against attempts to resettle them in Europe or the United States.

title: Plumbers Union Elects
description: DENVER, Aug. 7 (UPI)Mar tin J. Ward, 52 years old, of Chicago, has been elected gen eral president of the United Association of Plumbers and Pipe Fitters.

title: REDS' TRADE BLOC SEEKS TO EXPAND ITS GLOBAL ROLE
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 7The So viet Union and its bloc partners today published a 60,000word program for coordinating their economic policies and intensify ing their cooperation to com pete more successfully in the world arena during the next two decades.

title: Alice I. Angelo, John Huff Wed
description: Miss Alice Irene Angelo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joa chim Robert Angelo of Brook lyn, and John Leonard Huff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Eugene Huff of Winnetka, Ill., were married yesterday morning in St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: G.O.P. EDITOR DENIES CRITICISM OF NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) A liberal Republican organi zation has accused an editor of the National Committee weekly of moonlighting for a publica tion critical of President Nixon. The editor, John W. Lofton Jr., denied it.

title: Wood, Field and Stream:
description: SAGRES, Portugal  The earliest sailors thought this to be Land's End and even today, when dark clouds shroud the horizon and omi nous winds blow, a visitor wonders if there can be any thing but ocean beyond this wild headland on the west ernmost tip of Europe.

title: Reader's Report
description: Addie Pray By Joe David Brown. 313 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $6.95

title: Giant Elephant Killed
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 7 (Agence FrancePresse) A giant elephant, believed to be the second to the world record for size, has been killed in Tanzania's Ruaha National Park. The killers were appar ently poachers. The animal's tusks weigh just over 213 pounds each, compared with the world record of 220 pounds held by an elephant killed sev eral years ago on the slopes of Kilimanjaro, Africa's high est mountain.

title: PRESIDENT NAMES LAWYER TO S.E.C.
description: BREWER, Me., Aug. 7Presi dent Nixon has nominated Philip A. Loomis Jr., general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to be a member of the commission.

title: HOSPITAL'S PLANS CREATE A DISPUTE
description: OCEANSIDE, L.I., Aug. 7 Plans for a $12million expan sion program for South Nassau Communities Hospital here have drawn protests from resi dents who live in the area.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OREGON BACKS AID FOR BICYCLE PATHS
description: SALEM, Ore., Aug. 7 (UP) Oregon's State Highway Divi sion, an accomplished builder of eightlane freeways, is being challenged to produce equally impressive bicycle paths.

title: Music
description: THE misfortunes of an individual are only interesting so long as others can learn from inem, and in the case of my recent treat ment by Columbia University, the notion is doubly true. For the issue that is joined is not whether an individual has again been done dirt by an institution, but rather whether or not large bureau cratized educational organs are capable of supporting artistic (dare one say creative?) activity.

title: 2 REFORM BILLS PASSED IN ITALY
description: ROME, Aug. 7The Italian Senate today approved two ma jor reform hills aimed at alle viating the shortage of lowrent housing and revising the coun try's antiquated tax structure.

title: Letters:
description: The article on national parks by Robert A. Jones (Travel section, July 25) shows clearly that in the Range War at Generation Gap there is little difference between the youthful despoil ers and the older despoilers of our parks. While ecological awareness has increased among many of the young, other members of my genera tionthe socalled counter culture do little more than mouth empty slogans. The young who come into a na tional park with motorcycles, pot and stereo tape decks playing Jefferson Airplane numbers are as reprehensible as the old who camp out in housesize trailers, complete with color television.

title: Oil Slick Reported Off Coney Island; City Alerts Crews
description: City cleanup crews were placed on alert last night after an oil slick of undetermined origin was reported off the coast of Coney Island and other parts of Brooklyn.

title: Cricket Game Is Drawn
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club drew yesterday with the Fairmount Cricket Club of Philadelphia in a match at Walker Park on Staten Island. Fairmount had 194 runs for four wickets declared, Staten Island had 142 for nine.

title: Miss Marianne Perry Is Married
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 7Miss Marianne De Wolfe Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Perry Jr. of Salvador, Brazil, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Alexander De Witt Bowman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Parker Bowman of New York and Brookfield, Conn. The Rev. Donald T. Ma lone performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Bernard F. Ryan at the Roman Cath olic Church of St. Theresa.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The New York Jets made their first plunge into the troubled waters of presea son play against the Detroit Lions in Tampa last night, a splashy adventure that their fascinated fans could follow on television. It's a cinch that Giant followers also peeked in on the proceedings and did so without any of the perfidious feelings that might have troubled them in earlier years.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Lockheed Vote Was the Center of Battle of Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7On the morning of the Senate vote last Monday on whether to per mit the Government to guaran tee aid to the stricken Lock heed Aircraft Corporation, President Nixon telephoned four wavering Republican Sen. ators to urge their support.

title: Harrelson in $165,000 Golf
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP) Ken Harrelson, who played baseball with the Cleveland Indians until June 21, said to day he had accepted an in vitation to play in the $165,000 Massachusetts classic at Sutton, Mass., a regular pro golf tour stop, starting Thursday.

title: U.S. Seeks to Strengthen Its Sudanese Ties
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7The United States is moving quietly to strengthen its strained rela tions with the Sudan at a time when SudaneseSoviet relations appear to have reached their low point.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CALI, Aug. 7 (UPI) Manuel Gonzalez Guerra, head of the Cuban Olympic Committee, said tonight that three members of his learn were missing. He said he believed that one had de fected and that two had been kidnapped.

title: Onus on on Autoists
description: The most densely populated state in the nation, with highway traffic second to none, New Jer sey produces a bumper crop of autoexhaust pollution. Last week the state announced a tough new program to combat the problem.

title: Headliners
description: Once MoreWith Feeling

title: Front Page 1  No Title
DEVALUED DOLLAR IS ASKED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7A Congressional subcommittee said today that the United States dollar is overvalued in relation to other currencies and urged that, one way or another, it be devalued.

title: The World
description: RIO DE JANEIROOne year ago, a diminutive public prose cutor in Brazil's largest city, volunteered to investigate and bring to trial the anonymous executioners of the local death squad, one of four vigilante groups in Brazil blamed for more than 1,000 murders of petty criminals. Last week, after he had been responsible for in dicting 34 policemen for 14 hith erto unsolved death squad mur ders, the prosecutor was re moved from his assignment.

title: Oh, the sequins, the furs, the plumes of Rome!
description: Rome has a secret weapon in the classics revival that has enchanted designers on both sides of the Atlantic. The recent fall and winter haute couture showings in Rome proved that there are still fine tailors in Italy who can turn out clothes with the clean, crisp lines that classics require. But these are classics with a differencewhile the styling is basically mannish, the embellishments are brazenly feminine. Rome loves big plumed hats, gobs of fox and sequins by the yardand the way they all look with pants.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: An Opium Shipping Center in Laos Untouched by War
description: BAN HOUEI SAI, Laos. The sweetness of opium and peace hangs over this Me kong River town. Ban Houei Sai is reputed to serve as a major transshipping point for illicit opium from the nearby hills in Laos, Thailand and Burma, and the war has not touched it with death, destruction or an invasion of foreigners.

title: Horsemen Reach Accord In Dispute at Finger Lakes
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Aug. 7 (AP)An agreement ending a dispute between Finger Lakes Race Track and its horsemen was announced today. Details were not disclosed.

title: Cards Win in 10th, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (UPI) Matty Alou singled in the 10th inning and kept right on run ning to score the winning run as the St. Louis Cardinals stole a 32 victory from the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: Mailbox:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Electric Circus Turns Off Lights for the Last Time
description: The Electric Circus, the last of the major East Village music centers to feature hard rock and dancing, closed last night, less than two months after its principal rival, Fillmore East, shut down.

title: What goes on in the heads of Indians about what goes on in the universe
description: The Amazonian jungle has chal lenged the world's imagination ever since Francisco de Oreliana came back in 1541 with his improbable stories of the mightiest river on earth. The jungles have not changed much since then, but the travelogues have if anything become more lurid as the whole vast region continues to refuse man's dominion. Amazonas has become a sort of crucible which di vested man of his technology, virtual ly stripped him of his culture and showed him up in all his rapacious cruelty. From the conquistadors to the rubber barons to the modernday land grabbers the somber history of the region has been one of plunder, exploitation and massacre.

title: Rumor Control Officer Rejected in Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 7 (AP)  An ordinance that would have given Lexington its first rumor control offi cer has been defeated on a 5to0 vote by the City Com mission.

title: Namath Hurt
description: Joe Namath, the New York Jets' star quarterback, in jured his left knee in the team's first exhibition game last night. He will undergo surgery today. Dr. James Nicholas, the Jets' surgeon, said Namath may be able to play in late November.

title: the traveler's world
description: HERE remain a few items of un finished business before we sweep the accumulated notes and treas ured reminders off the top of the desk in preparation for a fourweek holiday from this column. Time, as only it so graciously can, has distilled the urgency out of most of them, leaving the following few to be attended to:

title: Coalition Backed by Suharto Wins by Apparent Landslide
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 7 (AP)The Governmentbacked coalition, Sekber Golkar, won a landslide victory in last month's parliamentary election, gaining control of 65 per cent of the contested seats and 73 per cent of the total seats in the national parliament, the Government an nounced today. The showing had been expected.

title: The World
description: Rolf Steiner has lost a lot of wars. As a boy of 15 in 1945, he fought with the Volksturrn, the home guard, against the Allied invasion of his native Germany. In 1954 he was one of the French Foreign Legion defenders of the doomed Indo china war bastion of Dienbien phu. In 1956 he was with the French forces parachuted into Suez. In 1961 he was one of the Legionnaires in French Algeria who joined the abortive generals' revolt against the Gov ernment of General de Gaulle.

title: Report Finds Most U.S. Priests Oppose Paul's 1967 Birth Edict
description: Twothirds of the Roman Catholic priests in this country think Pope Paul VI misused his authority in issuing his 1967 encyclical against artificial birth control, according to an official report circulated last week among the American bishops.

title: Mary Fitzsimmons Wed in Jersey
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., Aug. 7Miss Mary Louise Anne Fitzsimmons, a director of corporate fundraising for the United Fund of Greater New York, was married here this afternoon to David Wil liam Morgan, who is with the sales advertising depart ment of Seventeen magazine in New York.

title: Voice of the Coast Guard
description: NEW LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) Bill Stowe, crew coach at the United States Coast Guard Academy, has been named the academy's sports information director. Stowe, a Cornell Uni versity graduate, succeeds Jack Cruise, who is retiring after 12 years in the post.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Gilligan's Island Named Penn Ridge Club's Bestir Show
description: HILLTOWN, Pa., Aug. 7 The standard of the German shepherd calls for a strong, agile, wellmuscled animal, alert and full of life. It could have been written for Ch. Lakeside's Gilligan's Island, a black and tan owned by Daniel P. Dwier of Kresson, N. J.

title: Decontrolled Apartments Show Sharp Rise in Rents
description: The first month of the con troversial vacancy decontrol law has resulted in sharp in creases in rents for previously controlled apartments in the city, with some new tenants, particularly in Manhattan, be ing asked to pay twice the rents that were permitted under rent control.

title: Nassau Plans to Monitor Pollution Level in County
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 7 Starting Tuesday, employes of the Nassau County Health De partment will monitor air pol lution froth a trailer set up in Eisenhower Park in East Mead ow.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Manta 3d to Street Dancer In Turf Handicap on Coast
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP)  Street Dancer, a 4yearold daughter of Native Dancer, spoiled Manta's bid for an eighth consecutive turf victory today in capturing the $27,750 Ramona Handicap for fillies and mares.

title: L.I. SEWAGE STUDY IS PLANNED BY U.S.
description: A total evaluation of sewage treatment facilities on Long Is land, covering plants built as long ago as 1956, will be under taken by the United States En vironmental Protection Agency.

title: SAN JUAN IS WARNED OF TERRORISM WAVE
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 7 (AP)  Puerto Rico's fire chief has warned that a wave of terror ism will increase next month during the annual conference of governors.

title: Hoffman Stock Car Victor
description: WALL, N. J., Aug. 7 (AP) Jim Hoffman of Union Beach, N. J., won the 35lap modified stockcar feature at Wall Sta dium tonight in the record time of 8 minutes 52.2 seconds for the one  third of a mile track. Gary Shelly of New Egypt, N. J., took the 30lap limited sports man feature.

title: Fresh Air Fund Studying Vacation Program Effects
description: The Carnegie Corporation and the Fresh Air Fund are work ing on a preliminary study of the 94yearola summer vaca tion program as the first step toward a longrange compre hensive investigation next year.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: AFTER reading Ada Louise Huxtable's recent ar ticle about London, A Design That Soured, I was all set for a followup on the same theme lambast ing 1.M. Pei for coming to Washington and destroying vistas of the Capitol dome with a 10story '39 World's Fair Swisscheese design of a building pointing at the Capi tol in Dali fashion shrieking Mamma, Washington is wounded. Instead I was shocked to learn that she was pleased with the design of Pei's building, which she labeled one of the greatest 20century buildings.

title: Pair Sets Archery Record
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP) Scoring 552 of a possible 560, Steve Lieberman of Reading, Pa., the world champion, and Chris Labucki of Westfield, Mass., set a United States rec ord for the Hunters Round to day at the fourth annual field archery tournament at Miami University.

title: Article 2  No Title
SoftDrink War Between CocaCola and Gold Spot Bubbles in an AntiAmerican Atmosphere in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 7  While the threat of war with Pakistan fills the air these days, another conflict is bub bling in India: the softdrink war between the Pause That Refreshes and Livva Little Hot, Sippa Gold Spot.

title: CUBS TOP GIANTS; 18TH FOR JENKINS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (UPI) Glenn Beckert drove in two runs with a twoout single in the fourth inning today and Ferguson Jenkins became the first National League pitcher to win 18 games this season as the I Chicago Cubs defeated San Francisco 65, for the Giants' sixth loss in a row.

title: Author in Governor's Race
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 7 (UPI)David Chandler, the au thor of a 1970 Life magazine article on the influence of or ganized crime on the Govern ment of Louisiana, said today that he was running for Gov ernor. He said he would not accept any campaign contribu tions because he wants to dis prove the theory a candidate needs to spend $1million to be elected Governor of Louisiana.

title: Queens Science Hall to Get Atomic Reactor
description: A working nuclear reactor the first to be incorporated into any museum for public displaywill be the central feature of an addition to the Hall of Science in Flushing MeadowCorona Park, Queens, that will expand the exhibit space by 400 per cent.

title: The World
description: A decade ago, Nikita Khru schev had a dream. He envi sioned the eight nations of the Soviet bloc transformed into one country economically, one coun try of 300 million operated un der one plan from one economic headquarters: Moscow. The stimulus to his dream was the increasing economic integration of Western Europe's Common Market, a form of capitalist co operation whose existence pointed the finger of reproach at the lack of similar integra tion among Communist  ruled nations.

title: The Nation
description: Among the controversies that have swirled about the nation's welfare program, none has been more acerbic than that over a single question: Is there a signif icant number of people receiv ing welfare assistance who are not entitled to it?

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIn weary frus tration, the 92d Congress last week began a monthlong vaca tion. The past six months have left the Congress frustrated on many scoresby domestic and in ternational problems that seemed beyond solution . . . by a Presi dent who seemed insistent upon maintaining a distant, almost hostile attitude . . . even by its own inability to get much work done.

title: Woman Dean Approved
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 7 (AP)Mrs. Hanna Gray, 40 years old, a University of Chi cago faculty member since 1961, was named yesterday as the first woman dean of North western University's College of Arts and Sciences.

title: For Young Readers: Three Novels
description: Cool Cat is a brisk, welltold story about a group of teenage boys in a ghetto suburb of Los Angeles. Buddy, whose father is a probation officer and whose mother is a social worker, carries on a valiant struggle for survival in his jagged environ ment. Dope pushers and their vic tims, racist gangs and their parti sans, policemen and their informers, are involved in intricate warfare within the community. To avoid these dangers and pitfalls, Buddy needs exactly the right combination of suspicion and compassion, ambi tion and discretion.

title: Quantitative Thinking
description: Each year certain stretches of road hi Huntington, L. I., develop craterlike potholes, become flooded and wash away. The problem inevita bly recurs, even after exten sive repairs are made. Ear lier this year, a group of students set out to learn why.

title: The Nation
description: The handswung lanterns and the terminals in the middle of nowhere that cut up the nation's railroads as if they were run ning through a thousand Balkan empires are about to join the Iron Horse in oblivion. No longer will the rails crisscrossing America be fenced off in 100mile boxes, with new crews required every time a train crosses these unionen forced boundaries.

title: Harry M. Shulman Is Dead; Refrigeration Engineer, 82
description: DETROIT, Aug. 7Harry M. Shulman, a retired refrigeration engineer who was known for his innovations in the quick freezing of meat, died today. His age was 82.

title: Fairfield Poloists to Play Greenwich Team Today
description: The Fairfield County Hunt Club polo team will meet the Greenwich Pitchforks today for the Michelob Cup. The game is scheduled for 3 P.M. at Fair field in Westport, Conn.

title: U.S. Boxing Team Gains Victory Over Poland, 108
description: WARSAW, Aug. 7 (AP) The United States national box ing team tonight beat Poland, 108, in a match in Sosnowiec, Southern Poland.

title: NAMATH HURTS KNEE, LOST AT LEAST TILL NOVEMBER;
description: TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 7  Joe Namath severely damaged his left knee tonight while attempt ing to tackle Mike Lucci, a De troit Lions' linebacker. Surgery will be performed tomorrow in New York on the Jets' 28year old quarterback. It will be his fourth knee operation and the second on the left knee.

title: OBSERVER
description: Lately Frank Merriwell has been dropping by late at night. The first time, he was sitting there in a big armchair on the other side of the room. On each knee he supported a young woman. Their skirts were mi nute. Frank's hair was surprisingly long. It hung down so far that it curled up. Another odd thing was his knickers. That is, his lack of knickers. Frank Merriwell always wore knickers, didn't he? Well, Frank was now wear ing striped bellbottoms.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Leading Aide of Mao Under Attack in Peking
description: Chen Pota, the fourthrank ing official in the Chinese Com munist hierarchy and the party's leading theoretician, has become an object of bitter de nunciation in the Peking press.

title: In Affluent Suburbia, a Problem Parents Only Whisper About
description: WESTPORT, Conn.  It's a com Muters' town, population about 27, 000, in southern Fairfield County. But it could be any one of the upper mid dleclass suburban communities across the nation.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  President Ngu yen Van Thieu won the first round of his reelection bid last week when he knocked his rival and longtime en emy, Vice President Nguyen Cab Ky, out of the race be fore the campaign had even begun. And he did it a little more smoothly and a little more ruthlessly than his op ponents or the American Em bassy had expected.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Killing Eagles for Sport
description: Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton's promise to prosecute vigorously the human predators who have been slaughtering eagles from the air over Western ranches for sport and profit represents a welcome, longoverdue, shift in Federal policy. In the past the Interior Department has been reluctant to tangle with the ranchers in spite of their illegal and incredibly in humane depredations against a vanishing species that includes the bald eagle, symbol of the nation.

title: In Lieu of Soap
description: It may unsettle some of us to see an antiwar message or a political party message in the accustomed place of a soap or beer commercial, said Judge Skelly Wright of the United States Court of Appeals in Wash ington last week. But, he added, a society so saturated with commercialism may be the bet ter for it: all we may lose is some of our apathy.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: FINANCIAL markets continued to be buffeted by severe crosscurrents last week that pushed them in opposite directions, as Wall Street's bearish mood seemed to shift to a state of confusion over the business and economic outlook.

title: RABBI ITZHAK LEWIN, EXISRAELI MINISTER
description: TEL AVIV, Aug 7Rabbi Itz hak Meir Lewin, a Minister in Israel's first Government and a member of the Knesset since its inception, died this morning in Jerusalem. He was 77 years old.

title: NoFault Auto Insurance a Key Issue, But Few States Have Implemented Plans
description: The question of who should pay the hospital bills for the victims of automobile accidents was raisedand often argued in 28 state legislatures this year but in most of them the issue, nofault insurance, was con signed to the limbo of commit tees and study groups.

title: $6.1Million More Slated For Services to Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Nixon Administration has announced that it will spend $6,1million additional to pro vide an operational base for coordinating local services to the elderly and developing a national program of compre hensive services.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS RATIFY NEW PACT
description: Members or Social Service Employes Union Local 371, representing 17,500 city wel fare and antipoverty workers, have ratified a new contract that their union said provides minimum salary increases of 27 per cent over three years, from last Jan. 1 to Dec. 31, 1973.

title: Stamps
description: BANGLA DESH is a hope, an aspiration, the dream of millions of East Pakistanis. Ban gla DeshBengal Nation, or homeland, is what Sheik Mujibur Rahman sought through his Awami League, but its victory at the ballot box has resulted in the im prisonment of Banga Bandhu (Bengals friend)  Rahman, and the killing of thousands of East Pakistanis, and driven millions of them into refugee privations in neighboring India.

title: Arf, Arf! It's Jack Nicholson
description: BEWARE of the dog trainer may be the message of The Second In terval. Why beware? Be cause the dog trainer will be played by Jack Nicholson, that cad who was so mean to Karen Black and Susan Anspach in Five Easy Pieces and to Candice Ber gen and AnnMargret in Car nal Knowledge. In his new film; he'll have the chance to be mean to Jeanne Moreau, who can he something of a femme fatale herself.

title: Broberg Hurls First Shutout
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) Pete Broberg, signed off the campus of Dartmouth Univer sity for $150,000 less than two months ago, tossed his first majorleague shutout and drove in two runs with his first big league hit tonight in leading the Senators to a 70 victory over the Cleveland Indians.

title: Mailbox:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Some week, some month, some year there may come the time when it can be asserted confidently that in flation in the United States is really abating, but last week was not it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIPresident Nixon boasted at a news conference last week that American aid so far for the more than 7 million East Pakistani refugees who have fled to India  $70.5million is more than [that of] all the rest of the nations of the world put together. Perhaps inadver tently, he left out economically strained India, which has ab sorbed the refugees and will bear the bulk of the crushing cost  perhaps as much as $500million or $600million a year.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: U.S. WARNS STATE ON WELFARE LAW
description: The Federal Government has warned New York State that its new law requiring employ able relief recipients to go to a state employment office to pick up welfare checks might be illegal harassment, official documents disclosed yesterday.

title: TakeOver, Fuqua Style
description: ATLANTA  It was almost like old times in March, when J. B. Fuqua, Georgia's finan cial whiz, announced he was buying 40 per cent of the stock of a rather ob scure castiron soilpipe man ufacturer, the Central Foun dry Company.

title: For Young Readers: Three Novels
description: From the very first moment Reggie appears in the storyan unusually appealing black boy who plays the guitar and the harmonica, and is in tellectually gifted we know he is doomed. Reggie is the son of Nilma, housekeeper and colored nurse for the white, middleclass Bonner fam ily. The Bonner parents are amica bly divorced, and Mrs. Bonner, her 17yearold son, Tony, and 14year old daughter, Kim, live in an Upper East Side apartment. Reggie is two years older than Kim, the narrator.

title: CAB METER THEFTS PLAGUE INDUSTRY
description: More than 1,000 fare meters have been stolen from licensed taxicabs in the last 10 years by gypsy drivers who install them In their own cars, accord. hip to the fleet taxi industry.

title: Tia Pan Scores by Nearly Two Lengths in New Hampshire Sweepstakes Race
description: SALEM, N. H., Aug. 7 (AP) Tia Pan won in nearrecord time while the 25 favorite, Great Mystery, finished next to last today in the $10,000 Manchester Handicap at Rock ingham Park. The race also de cided the summer New Hamp shire Sweepstakes.

title: The Flame Is Green By. R. A. Lafferty. 245 pp. New York: Walker & Co. $5.95.
description: Politics, poetry, magic and a thick mist of Celtic obfuscation go into the manufacture of this strange and delightful novel. Its hero is a young fisherman named Dana Coscuin, who is mysteriously summoned from Bantry Bay to the European revolutions of 1848. Dana is a heroic brawler, swordsman, lover and observer of political turmoil. Looking over his hero's shoulder, R. A. Lafferty draws shrewd analogies between the dynamics of the Second Em pire and the unease of today, and makes 19thcentury history shimmer with lyrical blarney. Tucked in among the symbolic manifestations of good and evil are bright splashes of humor.

title: Bridge
description: LEADING somebody astray is usually thought a deplorable proceding. At the bridge table the victim is almost always one's part ner, who becomes understandably abusive when the hand is over. In some rare cases an opponent may become the victim by being diverted from a line of play that would succeed, and induced to undertake one that fails.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: BRANNAN VICTOR IN JUNIOR GOLF
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., Aug. 7 (AP)Mike Brannan of Sali nas, Calif., became the youngest champion in the history of the United States junior amateur golf championship today, scor ing a 4and3 victory over Bob Steele of Buffalo.

title: United Nations
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers stood on a platform be fore a roomful of Washington correspondents, reading a state ment on the need for foreign policies that look to the future, take account of the past and flees a stable peace. The report ers snowing what was coming, waited for the platitudes to un coil. Looking tenser than his wont, Mr. Rogers came to the core.

title: Stamps
description: On Wednesday, Canada will issue a multicolored stamp miniaturizing one of Paul Kane's highly regarded paintings, Indian Encamp ment on Lake Huron, Four color lithography was em ployed by the British Ameri can Bank Note Company, Ottawa, for the reproduction of the larger than usual 7 cent Canadian commemora tive stamp (approximately 2 inches by 1 inches).

title: TAX CHIEF TERMS FUND ISSUE TOUGH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Charitable foundations face a rocky road ahead because of growing legal challenges to their taxexempt status, the newly appointed commissioner of Internal Revenue says.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: First American Crew Wins European Title
description: CASCAIS, Portugal, Aug. 7 (AP)  James Schoonmaker and Tom Dudinsky of Florida's Biscayne Bay Yachting Club today became the first Ameri can crew to win the Europe and North Africa Star Class open sailing championship.

title: Et Al.
description: The famous storiesGimpel the Fool, The Spinoza of Market Street, Short Friday, A Friend of Kafka, etc., the complete text of The Magician of Lublin, and four episodes from In My Father's Court which was omitted from that novel when it was published here. The selections were made by Singer and his editor Robert Giroux.

title: Wilhelmina told it the way it wasand it was wild
description: Royalty by its very nature is or chidaceous: in the fetid jungle of a Court strange blooms flourish, their roots deep in the corruption that overwhelming power and authority always create. Few monarchs are dull; even minor royalty acquires such quirks of temperament that it almost requires genius for a princess to be dull and boring. And so it would be wrong to think that the Prussian Court described in these memoirs was very exceptional, al though it combined two houses which had always been rich in odd per sonalities, the Hohenzollern of Bran denburg and the Guelph of Hanover, who in 1714 had succeeded to the throne of England. Frederick William I, the father of Wilhelmina was mar ried to the daughter of George I of England, who had electrified the Court by having his wife's lover killed and the Queen shut up in fortress. A passionate, yet highly ef fective monarch, he quarreled spec tacularly with his own son, the Prince of Wales, took away his chil dren and considered putting him under arrest.

title: Pediatrics Group Warns Of Diaper Cleaner Peril
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Aug. 7 (UPI) The American Academy of Pediatrics warns that the laun dering of baby clothes in sub stances containing the chemical trichlorocarbanilide may cause illness and possibly death in infants.

title: Spahn in OldTimers' Game
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 7 (AP)The Atlanta Braves announced to day that Warren Spahn, a for mer ace lefthander, had ac cepted an invitation to play in the OldTimers' game next Sat urday at Atlanta Stadium.

title: Rail Negotiator Was Barred From Talks
description: Although his signature was on the final contracts that ended the nationwide railroad strike last week, the chief nego tiator for the railroad industry acknowledged yesterday that he had been excluded from the bargaining table three days be fore the settlement at the in sistence of his union counter part.

title: Art
description: EDGAR DEGAS, having seen some works by Mary Cassatt, ex pressed himself as dumbfounded that a woman could draw so well. Not as well, one imagines it was understood, as he, Degas, could draw, but quite well, with skill and intelligence he would scarcely have suspect ed were within the ken of the weaker sex. One can easily believe that Miss Cas satt's feelings upon hearing Degas' caustic compliment were mixed. On the one hand, coming from a master, it was flattering; on the other, pa tronizing her sex, it was an other sharp reminder that as a woman presuming to man's role she was to antici pate acceptance only as a treak.

title: Swedish Driver Gains Pole For Formula II Race Today
description: MANTORP, Sweden, Aug. 7 (AP)Ronnie Peterson of Swe den captured the pole position today for tomorrow's Formula II European championship race by clocking the fastest time on a slippery track.

title: PACIFIC ISLANDERS HOPE TO JOIN U.S.
description: LAVONGAL New Hanover Native leaders here, who once tried to recruit Lyn don B. Johnson to be their ruler, still want this small coconut growing island and its neigh bors in the Bismarck Sea, north of New Guinea, to be come part of the United States.

title: Bengals Top Dolphins, 2710, on Anderson's 2 Scoring Passes in 4th Quarter
description: MIAMI, Aug. 7 (AP)Ken Anderson, a rookie quarterback, threw two touchdowns in the fourth quarter tonight and led the Cincinnati Bengals to a 2710 victory over the Miami Dolphins in an American Foot ball Conference exhibition game.

title: POLLUTION CURB STIRS A DISPUTE
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 7Conservationists and pollu lion control officials, each in voking the name of the environ ment, are locked in an unusual dispute here over the future use of the scenic New River.

title: Chiefs Beat Colts, 107
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 7 (AP) The Kansas City Chiefs throt tled Baltimore's offense and made two firsthalf scores stand up for a 107 victory over the Super Bowl champion Colts tonight in a National Football League exhibition.

title: Coins
description: THE 80th anniversary convention of the American Numismat ic Association will open for five days in the na tion's capital Tuesday morn ing. The Washington Hilton, Connecticut Avenue at Co lumbia Road, N.W., will be headquarters.

title: Lee Krasowich Is Bride
description: The marriage of Miss Lee Krasowich, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Krasowich and the late Mr. Krasowich, who was a partner of Gregory & Sons, a securities firm, to Mark MarquezFlores, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Joseph P. Frary performed the ceremony. The bride groom, an account executive with the investment banking concern of E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., is a son of Mrs. Verceclad Flores de Marquez of Sari Juan, P. R.,

title: City Is Said to Lead in Pupil Absences
description: Absenteeism in New York City's public schools is the worst in the nation, City Con troller Abraham D. Beams said yesterday.

title: Cuba Clinches Title Tie
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 7 (AP)  Cuba defeated Venezuela, 60, today to gain at least a tie for the baseball crown in the PanAmerican Games. Cuba has six victories without a defeat.

title: EAST FRISIA JOKES A FAD IN GERMANY
description: LEER, West GermanyWhy do East Frisians wear wooden shoes? So that they don't bite their toes while grazing.

title: Kurkjian and Figueroa Dances Introduced by the Boston Ballet
description: LEE, Mass., Aug. 7There are two complementary ways of expanding a ballet com pany's repertory: judicious bor rowing from established choreographers and direct com missioning of new work. The latter is by far the riskier but also the one with the greatest import for the future. This week at. Jacob's Pillow. Dance Festival, the Boston Ballet has been demonstrating the use fulness of both approaches.

title: If Broadway Ever Turned To Double Features...
description: ALL of us are accustomed to double features at movie theaters. The way things are going on Broadway, the legitimate stage may soon have to resort twin bills, too. Should that dire day come, pro ducers would probably try to woo customers by showing plays whose titles are appropriately paired. Here are few neatly matched double bills that might look good on theater marquees. Playgoers are invited to while away the summer doldrums by adding to the list:

title: About Pro Football
description: READING, Pa., Aug. 7 Why training camps? Is it really necessary to run a pro football team through eight weeks of Spartan life in a training camp to get ready for the season? For at least the first two weeks, in the heat of midsummer, the ath letes are practicing twice a day. Gary Petti grew, a standout defensive tackle for the Philadel phia Eagles, asks serious questions about the value of training camps as they are presently consti tuted. Pettigrew's credentials are such that his inquiry car ries weight.

title: Negro Former Exile Is Shocked By Bad U.S. Racial Relations
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.Almost two years after he declared that America represented the best chance ever for social changes and racial justice, Robert F. Williams is begin ning now to have some doubts.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Warning: Prolonged Exposure to the Sun Can Be Harmful to Your Health
description: IN the West, where the sun shines brightly for most of the year, there Is a child who is not allowed to see the light of day.
