description: Prices drifted lower on the New York Stock Exchange yes terday despite a halfhearted attempt at a rally about noon.

title: ANGELA DAVIS LOSES PLEA FOR JURY DATA
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI)  Judge Richard E. Ar neson rejected today a request by attorney's for Angela Davis that the grand jury members who indicted her on murder and kidnapping charges be brought into court for ques tioning.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Plans Price Rises on Stainless
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of specialty steels, announced yesterday in Pitts burgh that it would take action to raise the actual selling prices of stainless items by about 8 per cent.

title: SONNY SAYS QUICK SCORES IN JERSEY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 (AP)Peter Fuller's Sonny Says Quick and W. S. Farish 3d's Pas de Nom won the divisions of the Seashore Stakes for 3yearold fillies before 12,327 at Atlantic City as the shore track opened its 60day meet ing today.

title: Executives Work On Study of H.R.A., Lindsay Reports
description: A group of 10 business and financial executives has been working on a business and management study of the city's Human Resources Administra tion for the last month, Mayor Lindsay announced last night.

title: Employer Is Given Support in Court By Blind Workers
description: As Judge Nathaniel T. Hei man was listening to cases in State Supreme Court yesterday, 17 blind and nearblind persons filed into the courtroom to of fer silent testimony as to their actual existence.

title: G.E. Wins Approval Of Fairfield Board To Move Its Offices
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Wednes day, July 11The General Elec tric Company won final ap proval early today to move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to a 100acre rural site in this affluent community.

title: Dock Strike on West Coast Jams Port of Vancouver
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Aug. 10Six weeks ago the waterfront here was trans formed from Canada's major Pacific port to North America's major Pacific port.

title: College in Vermont Seeks A License to Sell Liquor
description: WINOOSKI, Vt., Aug. 10 (AP) St. Michael's College, a Ro man Catholic school, may be come the first institution of higher learning in Vermont to sell alcoholic beverages on cam pus.

title: Brooklyn Prisoner Found Dead After a Scuffle With 2 Guards
description: A 37yearold inmate of the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men died yesterday about two hours after he was subdued by two guards who found him with a homemade knife, Correc tion Commissioner George F. McGrath said.

title: Westinghouse and Tenneco in Nuclear Plan
description: Two of the nation's top industrial giants joined forces here yesterday in a joint effort aimed at solving regu latory delays in the nuclear power field.

title: McGraw's Strong Relief Saves Met Victory, 64
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 10Gary Gentry developed a pain in his lower back, but Tug McGraw showed the Padres his sound left arm as the Mots defeated San Diego, 64, tonight.

title: Leave It to Agnes Is Cry At State Labor Meeting
description: Oh, Agnes is going to be furious. Agnes is not going to lice this. They weren't supposed to open the doors Without Agnes approving it.

title: MESTER CONDUCTS MOZART CONCERT
description: Jorge Mester, who con ducted Monday night's Most ly Mozart Festival program at Philharmonic Hall, found himself blessed with two ad mirable soloists and a con cert full of masterpieces. And yet this accomplished musi cian also found ways to keep the night from being the com plete pleasure it might have been, beginning immediately with a thintoned, flabby reading of Schubert's Sym phony No. 2 in B flat.

title: Whither Couture?
description: PARIS, Aug. 10 (AP)  Pierre Cardin and Andr Courrges hinted today that they might soon follow Yves Saint Laurent's lead in drop ping haute couture.

title: WHELAN AND 2 GET 15 YEARS IN PRISON
description: NEWARK, Aug. 10Former Mayor Thomas J. Whelan of Jersey City and two others convicted July 5 in the Jersey CityHudson County extortion conspiracy trial were sentenced in Federal District Court here today to 15 years in prison.Four other defendants re ceived lesser terms.

title: David G. Moore, Controller Of Shipping Association
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Aug. 10 David G. Moore, controller of the New York Shipping As sociation, which negotiates waterfront labor contracts in the Port of New York, died yes terday at Hackensack Hospital after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 280 Prospect Avenue.

title: U.S. ASSERTS SOVIET TESTED SPACE BOMB
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Soviet Union testfired a space bomb on Sunday for the first time in about a year, the Pentagon announced today.

title: FILIPINO SOLDIERS CIRCLE INSURGENTS
description: MANILA, Aug. 10Some 700 Government soldiers with armored trucks and artillery have moved into positions around Buldon Town in north ern Catabato Province where a rebel army composed of Mos lems is reported dug in. More than 1,000 reinforcements were nearby, the constabulary head quarters said today.

title: Eleven Senators Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Eleven Senators urged today that the United States Govern inent convey to Pakistan their profound hope that compas sion would be shown to Sheik Mujib.

title: Rate Rise Announced
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)  Over the protests of advertisers and other bulk mail ers, the Postal Service an nounced today plans to raise thirdclass rates by a full cent a piece next month, instead of spreading the rise over five years, as originally intended.

title: Art Show Makes a Visit And a Hit With Patients
description: The brightly striped red, yellow and orange vinyl bubble atop the mobile truck on Ward's Island formed an exotic accent to the busy East River and the New York skyline.

title: VAATAINEN IS VICTOR IN 10,000METER RUN
description: HELSINKI, Aug. 10 (Reu ters)Juba Vaatainen of Fin land outsprinted Jurgen Haase of East Germany in the final lap to capture the 10,000meter run in the European track and field championships tonight.

title: Nixon's Weekend Trip Is Ruled Nonpolitical
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP)The White House re iterated strongly today that it considered President Nixon's visit to New Hampshire and Maine last weekend. non politicaland therefore sub ject to being paid for by the taxpayer.

title: CUBA, U.S. NINES FINISH 12 AT CALI
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 10 (AP) The United States won the silver medal for baseball today with a 72 finalgame victory over Venezuela in the Pan American games.

title: U. S. Apologizes for Cali Flag Caper
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 10 (UPI)The head of the United States delegation to the Pan American Games apologized to night for the action of an American gymnast in taking down the flag of Cali last night.

title: Safety Standards Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Chamber of Commerce of the United States called on the Federal Government today to develop and enforce safety standards for products having an unreasonable risk of death or personal injury. It presented a statement to the Senate Com merce Committee, which is con sidering hills that would estab lish Federal safety standards.

title: Fatal Phrase
description: Overlooked in the Senate's lastminute scramble to pass a campaign finance bill was a loophole big enough to sink the most desperately needed of its proposed reforms. Just six words long, it can undo six months of hard legislative work.

title: Bridge to China
description: TOPEKA, Kan.  President Nixon's momentous new China policy must be considered in the light of the change in our relations with all the world's nations.

title: Testing Service Gets Grant
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The United States Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare awarded a $650,000 grant today to the Educational Testing Service of Princeton, N. J., Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, an nounced.

title: ADVANCE ON AMEX BEST IN 5 MONTHS
description: The American Stock Exchange scored its biggest advance yesterday in more than five months as trading continued light.

title: Heart Transplant on Coast
description: STANFORD, Calif., Aug. 11 (AP)A surgical team headed by Dr. Norman Shumway performed last night Stanford Medical Center's 33d heart transplant, and the recipient was in fair condition today, the hospital said. He was identified only as a 47yearold man from Rochester, N.Y.

title: Japanese Agency Wins A U.S. Client on Coast
description: Advertising:

title: A RECORD CORN CROP IN 1971 SEEN BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1971 corn crop at a record of 5,345,057,000 bushels, 30 per cent more than last year's.

title: CHINA DISCUSSED BY TOKYO'S ENVOY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  The Japanese Ambassador to the United States cautioned the Nixon Administration tonight to consult fully with Tokyo on further initiatives in China policy and denounced the Chinese Communists accusations of Japanese military ambitions as nonsense.

title: Stock Swap Proposed
description: In, a move to extend its operations outside the New York metropolitan area, Alexander's, Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement for the acquisition of Jefferson Stores, Inc., a Florida chain of discount stores.

title: CHRYSLER CHAIRMAN SHOWING OPTIMISM
description: LAKE OF THE OZARKS, Mo., Aug. 11Lynn Townsend, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, said today that he was optimistic about the coining year for the auto industry because, despite inflation and high unemployment this year, people will still end up buying about 10 million cars.

title: Soviet and India Cite Crisis
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11India and the Soviet Union issued a joint statement tonight that Indian official sources said should be read as a declaration that the two countries hold identical views on the crisis in East Pakistan.

title: Market Place: Money Manager Is RiskOriented
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 When David H. Meid was 14 back in 1950 he worked 50acre farm near Fort Wayne, Ind., that was his father's hobby.

title: FROEHLING IS UPSET; GRAEBNER ADVANCES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 11 (UPI)  Patricio Cornejo of Chile upset sixthseeded Frank Froehling of Miami in men's singles today at the national clay courts tennis championships. The scores were 64, 76.

title: Film: 'The Hired Hand':Peter Fonda Directs and Is Cast as Hero
description: After seven years of wandering, of tired days and of nights with the earth for a bed, Collings feels that there is nothing for him but to return home, to his farm, to the wife he left when he was still almost a boy and to the little daughter who thinks he is dead. Reluctantly the wife takes him back, at first as a hired hand who works the land and sleeps in the barn. But in time their desires meet and he becomes a husband again. And it is then that he learns that Harris, his companion of the seven years, is held captive by a man he had wounded and is being slowly tortured to death. So Collings leaves his wife and farm and child and goes off to save his friend and to meet his fate.I don't know just what I expected of the Peter Fonda Western, but certainly not a film so sensitively appreciative of what might be possible in a Western as is "The Hired Hand," which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater. A certain amount of what might not be possible also gets in, for "The Hired Hand" is a rather ambitious simple movie, with a fairly elaborate technique and levels of meaning rising to the mystical, which seems so much a part of the very contemporary old West.But the technique, the lyrical lap dissolves and super-impositions, the straining to preserve images, the attempt to transform light into substance and symbolall belong to a mysticism that is not so much other-worldly as this-worldly, and which works to ameliorate the excesses and to forgive the pretensions of this lovely but by no means perfect movie. For "The Hired Hand" deals with spiritual imminence, and I think that its greatest ambition is to understand and, to a degree, to figure daily life in a state or grace.When Callings (Peter Fonda) gives up his wandering to return home, he rejects a role in an earthly Hell in order to earn a share in an earthly Paradise. Given its methods and its preoccupations, "The Hired Hand" is better with Paradise than with Hell, better with the solemnities of Verna Bloom's farm wife than with the ironic Christian symbolism of Severn Darden's evil outlaw McVey.For the outlands are full of signs and symbols and portends, but the farm is a place that is fully consonant with what it means  and there are no clues because all the mystery, though no less mysterious, has been rendered prefectly accessible. I find this notion exciting. And the images that are used to illustrate it  ordinary images of landscape, sky, house and people  I find absolutely ravishing."The Hired Hand" knows that its Paradise is both tenable and actual, but it also knows that nobody can stay there for very long, and that is why it accords so well with the gentle fatalism of the Western.Although it has some violence, "The Hired Hand" is best in its gentler moments and with its gentler performancesFonda himself, and especially Warren Oates as the friend he ransoms and who will carry on his life.But its greatest glory is in the passing of the natural day, the coming of the evening lightin all those commonplace gifts of awareness that could be merely decorative effect but that here seem visionary insight."The Hired Hand" was photographed by Vilmos Zsigmond with a perfect feeling for dramatic nature. Its music, which is simple, directly appealing, and very beautiful, was composed by Bruce Langhorne.

title: City to Retain Blue Shield for Employes
description: The city reversed itself yesterday and announced that it would continue Blue Shield medical insurance for the 112,000 municipal employes now covered by contracts.

title: CANDIDATES FEAR PHUOCLONG ROADS
Apache Unit Elects Officer
description: The Apache Corporation has named Kenneth G. Reed as vice president of its oil and gas division and as a director. Mr. Reed was formerly executive vice president of the Amerada division of the Amerada Hess Corporation.

title: Rapid Detoxification Program Aiding Addicted Veterans Here
description: The first rapid detoxification program for drugaddicted veterans has been introduced by the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan.

title: FRANK CONWELL, 59, OF JERSEY ASSEMBLY
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 11 (AP)  Assemblyman Frank R. Conwell died of a heart attack yesterday in Neptune while on vacation. He was 59 years old.

title: Lindsay the Democrat
description: After months of indecision Mayor Lindsay has switched his political affiliation from Republican to Democrat. The Mayor is still not saying whether he will seek the Democratic Presidential nomination next year, but his decision to press for new national leadership is likely to have important consequences for the Mayor himself, both political parties, and not least for the city.

title: REV. CLARENCE W. JONES
description: BELLEAIR BLUFF, Fla., Aug. 11  The Rev. Clarence W. Jones, who was rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L. I., from 1944 to 1960, died in Clearwater hospital yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: 2 Airlines Divide Pacific Island Routes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 President Nixon and the Clvili Aeronautics Board today divided the interisland tourist routes of the Central and South Pacific between Continental Airlines and Pan American World Airways, ending a hardfought battle.

title: Strikes Adding to Allende Woes
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 11 Strikes in two big copper mines and a wave of rural work stoppages are taxing the political skills of President Salvador Allende Gossens. A Cabinet crisis, which involved the resignation of five ministers, was resolved, tonight.

title: How Mother of 10 Supports Her Family
description: Every morning, Monday through Friday, Barbara Spurgeon, a 47yearold mother of 10, gets up at 7:30 A.M., catches an 8:15 subway near her hotel in Brooklyn Heights, and rides into Manhattan to begin her day as a Dictaphone secretary at a Wall Street law firm.

title: FUND SHAREHOLDERS SUING K. C. SOUTHERN
description: A mutual fund shareholders suit filed here yesterday seeks to require Kansas City Southern Industries, Inc., and certain of its officers to return some $13.4million of profits obtained from the sale of a controlling interest in Supervised Investors Services to Kemperco, Inc., in May, 1970.

title: McGeorge Bundy Sets Record Straight for Press
description: A handwritten message by McGeorge Bundy, President John F. Kennedy's adviser on national security, praising the vague wording of a 1963 press announcement on Vietnam policy, did not assert that such communiqus should say nothing in such a way as to fool the press without deceiving them, as reported last week in The New York Times.

title: NEW ORLEANS SELLS BONDS FOR STADIUM
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11  Bonds totaling $113million were sold today to finance construction of a domed stadium seating 82,000 people.

title: IRVING I. SCHNUR
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 11 Irving I. Schnur, a founder and former chairman of Fields Plastics and Chemicals, Inc., died here yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS NET RESTATED FOR GAIN
description: The San Diego Gas and Electric Company said yesterday that, in line with a ruling of the California Public Utilities Commission regarding treatment of the method of recording property taxes, its firstquarter net income rose about 7 cents a share,

title: Dublin Aide in London
description: LONDON, Aug. 11Ireland's External Affairs Minister, Patrick Hillery, spent an hour and a half today with British Government ministers here discussing the situation in Northern Ireland.

title: Youthful Troupe's Summer Stock Rises
ExExecutive of I.B.M. Is Sentenced in a Drug Case
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 11 Lawrence A. Tate, a 45yearold former I.B.M. executive who for nearly a year and half has contended that he is the victim of local police harassment, was sentenced in Village Court here this afternoon to a $1,000 fine and a year's probation on two misdemeanor convictions arising from a police drug raid on his home a year ago.

title: Indians Assure U.S. on Treaty With Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 India privately assured Washington today that her new friendship treaty with the Soviet Union was not directed against the United States or any of its allies.

title: Philip Berrigan Is Moved To U.S. Facility in Missouri
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 11 (UPI)The Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and 10 other inmates at the Federal prison here who were involved in a hunger strike were moved today to a medical center for Federal prisoners at Springfield, Mo.

title: Trial Reported Open
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug, 11 (AP)Informed sources said Sheik Mujib went on trial today. He faces death.

title: Coast's Bay Area Is Lure for Filmmakers
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe Bay Area has become a home away from home for Hollywood filmmakers looking for a nice place to visit and work, if not necessarily live.

title: Plans for I.T.T. Proceed
description: The Justice Department and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation were reported yesterday to be preparing to seek Federal court approval this week or early next week for proposed consent decrees in settlement of three antitrust suits.

title: Heckl's Six Gold Medals Pace U.S. at Cali Games
Paradox in Wyoming
description: Letters to the Editor

title: California Legislature Approves Welfare Reform Bill After Compromise With Reagan
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 11Legislation cutting welfare expenditures, tightening antifraud controls and requiring greater support of the aged by their adult children was approved today by the California Legislature.

title: HANOI UNITS ATTACK TWO BASES NEAR DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12 (AP)North Vietnamese troops shelled and assaulted a South Vietnamese military district headquarters near the demilitarized zone early today, killing 10 defenders and wounding 10 others, the Saigon command reported,

title: Pomfret of Times Named Assistant to Sulzberger
description: The appointment of John D. Pomfret as assistant to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, was announced yesterday by the publisher. The appointment is effective Sept. 1.

title: A.F.L.C.I.O. Parley Takes Strong Stand on Import
G.M. Lets Dealers Sell Its'
description: DETROIT, Aug. 11 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation has authorized Its dealers to start selling 1972 model cars now instead of waiting until the official introduction date of Sept. 23.

title: Chess:
description: A doubleround team match on 18 boards between Switzerland and Bavaria, played at Kaufbeuren, Germany, last month, was won by the Swiss, 19116. The Bavarians, with Grandmasters Wolfgang Unzicker and Lothar Schmid on the top boards, had tied, 1616, in a similar match played last year at Lucerne, but this year, in their absence, the Swiss team pulled ahead.

title: Appeal by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has appealed to 23 heads of government around the world to use their influence to save Sheik Mujib.

title: Golfer Sued Over Loan
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 11 (UPI)The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation filed suit today against Doug Sanders, the golfer, alleging that he borrowed $70,000 from the Sharpstown State Bank and never repaid the loan. The bank is now defunct. The F.D.I.C. took over the bank after a run by depositors caused it to fold earlier this year.

title: 28 Tied for First Place In National Chess Open
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 11After three rounds of the United States Chess Open Championship held at the Ventura Fairgrounds, Seaside Park, 28 players were tied for the lead with perfect scores of 3 points.

title: TV: Accentuating the Positive on Detroit's Blacks
WineBottle Sizes Uncork a Dispute
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 11 The size of wine bottles could become the next addition to the growing list of trade disputes between the European Common Market and the United States.

title: IRVING LEUCHTER, LAWYER WAS 69
description: VERONA, N. J., Aug. 11 Irving Leuchter, the general counsel to the American Newspaper Guild, died at his home yesterday of a heart attack and emphysema. He was 59 years old and lived at 68 Morningside Road.

title: F.B.I. Says Policy Operator Paid Police
ERNEST F. DISTLER JR.
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 11  Ernest F. Distler Jr., who retired in 1949 as an accounting executive of Lamont Corliss & Co., now merged into the Nestl Company, died yesterday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola. He was 87 years old and lived at 133 Chestnut Street.

title: The Irish Choice
description: The bloodiest rioting in the fifty years of Ulster's existence as a separate Irish province, united with Britain, is threatening to destroy selfrule in Northern Ireland. It is also erasing the best hope in years for peaceful reconciliation of the province's two warring religious communities.

title: Farm Worker Union Opens Heublein Products Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  The United Farm Workers Organizing Committee today formally opened a 40state boycott of Italian Swiss Colony Wines, Smirnoff Vodka and other products of the Heublein Allied Vintners Corporation in a dispute over union organizing eforts.

title: Klondike Gold Still Way of Life
description: DAWSON CITY, Yukon Territory, Aug. 5As far as I know, this is the richest pay streak in the world, Gus Heitman said as he surveyed his claim in the heart of the Klondike gold fields.

title: Shipping Unit Elects Two New Officers
description: The New York Shipping Association, a trade group made up of 129 steamship companies, stevedores and other waterfront employers, has elected two new top officers and a new board of directors.

title: Weary Layer Loses, Quits Tour
Groslimond Tennis Victor
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 11Gery Groslimond of Daytona Beach, Fla., a player at Stanford University, defeated Gene Scott of New York, 16, 75, 63, to gain the quarterfinals of the United States men's amateur grass court tennis championships today at the Meadow Club.

title: REACTIONS MIXED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  Leading Democrats opened their arms, but not necessarily their hearts, to Mayor Lindsay of New York today.

title: William P. Bundy Backed as Quarterly's Editor
description: David Rockefeller reaffirmed yesterday the appointment of William P. Bundy as editor of the quarterly journal Foreign Affairs.

title: Committee Says Congress Adds $4.2Billion to Nixon's Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  Congressional actions to date have already added about $4.2billion to the budget spending level proposed by President Nixon for the current fiscal year, a joint committee of Congress reported today.

title: RIOTING IN ULSTER FLARES FOR 3D DAY; TOLL RISES T0 23
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11 Gun battles, sniping and fires broke out today in Belfast. It was the third day of violence since the Government invoked emergency powers of preventive detention.

title: PADRES TOP METS ON GROTE'S ERROR IN 12TH INNING, 10
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 11Larry Stahl, who earlier saved the Padres with a diving, backhanded catch in center field, scored an unearned run in the 12th inning that gave San Diego and Dave Roberts a 10 victory over the Mets tonight.

title: A Democratic Legislature Is One of Lindsay's Goals
description: Mayor Lindsay, who made himself the state's most powerful Democrat and a frontrunning candidate for Governor yesterday, has told his staff that he wants to stay somewhat detached from the internal politics of his new party, but does intend to campaign hard around the state for a Democratic Legislature in 1972.

title: Executive Changes
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday the election of Charles E. Reed a senior vice president. Named to succeed Dr. Reed as vice president and group executive is Reuben Gutoff, formerly vice president and general manager of the company's chemical and medical division. Dr. Reed becomes a member of the corporate executive staff with responsibility for technical resources. Mr. Gutoff will head the components and materials group which comprises five divisions.

title: CHARLES R. OGSBURY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (AP) Charles Reid Ogsbury, a retired executive of the Friden Corporation and a former vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Monday. He was 79 years old.

title: Rare Condors Believed to Be in Mexico
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 The nearly extinct California condor may be alive and well in Mexico.

title: Black Power Group in Vietnam Fights Heroin Addiction, the Enemy Within
description: LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 4  The Black Power movement in Nam was kicking off good in 1968, it had unity up to 1970, but that year I saw skag was going to be a problem and separate the Woods, the black soldier said.

title: Wyoming Rancher Denies Role in Shooting of Eagles
description: CASPER, Wyo., Aug. 11 (UPI)Herman Werner, rancher and banker, denied yesterday that he had anything to do with the shooting of bald eagles over his ranch.

title: Distinction Better Part of Valor As He Sets Records for Breed
description: Nathan Putchat holds degrees in civil, mechanical, structural and sanitary engineering. He's also a lawyer. At the University of North Dakota he was a Little allAmerica football player.

title: Uncle Sweatshop
description: By almost every measure the draft is an odious business.

title: Downhold in Washington
description: At least once in every Administration someone in the White House takes a look at the Federal payroll and discovers that many millions of dollars have been added through a process of bureaucratic upereep. Officials find ways to circumvent established pay ceilings for their subordinates by inflating job descriptions and thus getting them into higher pay brackets.

title: Three 32Story Luxury Towers To Rise on Queens Golf Course
description: The City Planning Commission approved unanimously yesterday a controversial luxury housing development on the Glen Oaks Golf Course in Queens, and by a split decision approved lowincome housing for a Manhattan site currently occupied by squatters.

title: Fireproof Fabrics Called New Pattern
description: The new Commerce Department standard for flameresistant fabrics will change the nature of the textile industry in the next few years, Robert Bendheim, president of M. Lowenstein & Sons, Inc., said yesterday.

title: Hadfield, New Captain, Signs Ranger Contract
description: Vic Hadfield, the newly named captain of the New York Rangers, became the first Ranger to sign his 197172 contract yesterday.

title: ALFRED SOUPIOS, 55; HEADED JOB AGENCY
description: WILLINGBORO, N. J., Aug. 11Alfred V. Soupios, who operated a temporaryemployment concern in Trenton, died Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital, Trenton. He, was 55 years old and lived at 53 Hillcrest Lane.

title: Postal Pact: What Victory?
description: To the Editor: In a July 22 editorial you referred to the agreement between the United States Postal Service and its employes as a victory for collective bargaining. You also reported a 20 per cent wage settlement.

title: Packard Offers a Plan, Based on Soviet Practice, to Produce Mare Experimental Weapons Systems
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard, criticizing the management of defense contracts by the Pentagon and industry, announced today a new program aimed at attacking some of these problems and producing more experimental weapons systems.

title: Moscow's Second Thoughts
description: It is reasonable to suppose that at least part of Georgi A. Arbatov's Pravda article on WashingtonPeking relations was originally prepared as a classified memorandum for Mr. Brezhnev and his Politburo comrades. Much of its assessment of conflicting trends in American public opinion reflects a sophistication at sharp variance with the stereotypes normal in Pravda, reinforcing the belief that its basic purpose was to guide serious policymakers.

title: Muskie Urges Tax Cut and Aid to States and Cities
description: DALLAS, Aug. 11Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for an immediate $3billion tax cut and a new $4billion program of Federal aid to states and cities to reverse what he called the Nixon Administration's no win economic policy.

title: Over the Rainbow
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 John Lindsay suggested at his news conference that his decision to turn Democrat did not come to him as if he were Saul being knocked off his horse on the road to Damascus. Mr. Lindsay had to think it over a long time, as would anyone in view of the mess the Democrats have made of themselves in New York; and in the end the Mayor announced his decision rather as a man might who had decided to move in with his motherinlaw.

title: U.S. ASKS WIDENING OF MONETARY BAND
Oil, Condors and the Bureaucrats
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11  President Nixon has sent to Congress a proposal to establish a Cabinetlevel Department of Natural Resources. The department would take over responsibilities now scattered among six existing departments and agencies  Interior, Agriculture, Defense, Commerce, Transportation and the Atomic Energy Commission. In Southern California are two conspicuous examples of why the President's Advisory Committee on Executive Reorganization last February recommended this consolidation, and why President Nixon hastened to pass the proposal on to Congress.

title: BRITAIN VICTOR IN YACHT SERIES
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 11 (AP)  The United States picked up 21 points on Britain in the final event of the Admiral's Cup series, but the American yachtsmen wound up second to the Britons and Prime Minister Edward Heath, who won the trophy today.

title: Music: A Park Overture
description: The crowd gathered for the New York Philharmonic concert at Sheep Meadow in Central Park on Tuesday night seemed especially relaxed and comfortable, and its good feelings were certainly engendered in part, at least, by the music.

title: REST ASSURED WINS IN SUSSEX JUMPOFF
Casey Names Two Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and. Exchange Commission, has named two New York lawyers as his special counsel. They are Lee A. Pickard, 32 years old, formerly with Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander, President Nixon's old law firm in New York, and John M. Liftin, 28, formerly with the New York firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: Fran and Joe: Calculated and Romantic
description: For years, a favorite timewaster in New York was comparing the life styles, the quarterbacking skills and the hair lengths of Fran Tarkenton and Joe Namath. What arguments, what speculations. Can you imagine Joe behind that Giant line of the Sixties? He'd spend all day looking in clouds. What about Fran with the Jets? A winner, if they could move fast enough to keep him protected. The Super Bowl of 1969 and the GiantJet games tended to discourage the dilettantes, but the hard core compared on: Off the field, they noted, Tarkenton seemed most concerned with making money, Namath with making love. Tarkenton, a tidy, packaged man, seemed organized; he had a larger vision for himself and a scheme to fulfill Namath, big, wolfish, seemed to be loping stiffly in everwidening circles. Preachers found examples and anecdotes in Tarkenton's life and politicians courted him, both for his support and for his potential as a candidate. Broadway Joe's every success was a heartache to high school coaches and clergymen who ominously predicted a generation of harddrinking, everloving standup quarterbacks. For all those who stayed with the game, the unfortunate events that sent Namath to the hospital and Tarkenton home this week were unexpected but not surprising twists.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Sport Fishing USA, a profusely illustrated 464  page volume produced by the Bureau of Sport Fisheries and Wildlife, presents a sweeping portrayal of a pursuit that as early as 1955 involved the expenditure of billions of dollars annually.

title: INDICTNIENT CITES 2 JERSEY FIGURES
description: NEWARK, Aug. 11Robert J. Burkhardt, a former New Jersey Democratic state chairman, and State Senator Willard B. Knowlton, a Bergen County Republican, were indicted separately here by a Federal grand jury on charges of bribery and extorting a total of $211,000 from a New York construction company.

title: HARTFORD IS SPLIT ON NEW TAX PLAN
description: HARTFORD, Thursday, Aug. 12The Connecticut House of Represenatives late last night rejected a bill passed earlier by the Senate that would have repealed the recently enacted state income tax and substituted a sales tax of 6.5 per centup from 5 per cent.

title: Photos Show the DNA Molecule's Twisted Structure
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 11The first photographs clearly showing the twisted, doublestranded structure of DNA, the molecule that carries the code of life, have been produced by a team of scientists at two universities.

title: Hair Grooming Goes Unisex
description: Before unisex, the hairdressing shop was clearly either his or hers. Women went their own way to beauty salons, while barber shops were as masculine as football locker rooms. These days, when you can't tell which twin has the shoulderlength locks or the pony tail, nothing is so square to the under30 generaation (and some of its older followers) than going to the beauty parlor or the barber's. The bluejeans set is flocking to the increasing number of unisex emporiums that started in the East Village and are now spreading all over town.

title: LINDSAY SWITCHES TO DEMOCRATS, URGES NEW NATIONAL LEADERSHIP; AS FOR PRESIDENCY: I DON'T KNOW
description: Stressing national issues, Mayor Lindsay switched his party enrollment from Republican to Democrat yesterday to help build a coalition that can change the direction of the, country and bring about new leadership in Washington.

title: Justice Department Drops Inquiry on Wallace Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP)The Justice, Department is dropping its investigation of alleged kickbacks and irregularities with campaign money involving associates of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

title: Business Inventories Up At a Slow Pace in June
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Total business inventories continued to rise at a slow pace in June and in the second quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S Tells National Banks Of TaxFree Bond Deceits
description: The Controller of the Currency has issued a warning to the presidents of all national banks that unsafe and unsound practices involving municipal bond transactions are increasing in number.

title: To Save the Health Council
description: To the Editor: Congratulations on your editorial appealing to city and state officials to save the Health Research Council [July 12]. The city has many unique health problems that will continue to cost much more than some $4 million annually to keep the council going. Associated costs of lost wages, increased crime to keep the addict supplied with heroin, etc., should be added to the costs of caring for those who are unnecessarily sick or disabled. Investing in the search for solutions to problems is sound fiscal policy.

title: Policemen Use a Tug To Save Man in River
description: A 270pound man was rescued from the East River yesterday by two patrolmen who commandeered a tugboat to reach him.

title: State Fights Snug Harbor Bid to Move
description: Sailors Snug Harbor, founded in 1806 as a home for aged, decrepit and wornout seamen is seeking court permission to move from the site it has occupied on Staten Island for almost a century and a half to North Carolina.

title: NIXON SIGNS 3 BILLS ON FUNDS AND BOATS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) President Nixon signed three bills today involving appropriations and Federal safety standards for boats.

title: CAMBODIA PLANNING A WINTER OFFENSIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Acting Premier Sisowath Sirik Matak said today that the Cambodian Army would mount a winter offensive with American air support and South Vietnamese ground forces against the Vietnamese Communists.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
25 ARRESTED BY F.B.I. IN DRIVE ON GAMING
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested 25 persons in nine states today in what its director, J. Edgar Hoover, called a major crackdown against organized interstate gambling.

title: Dr. Arthur Billings Hunt; Led National Hymn Group
description: Dr. Arthur Billings Hunt, former executive director of the National Hymn Sing Association, died Tuesday in Pilgrim State Hospital, Brentwood, L. I. He was 81 years old and lived in Wantagh, L. I.

title: Uncurbed Population Growth
description: To the Editor: In his July 27 letter, Prof. Joseph Zaremba states, Mankind has shown a remarkable ability to find new resources to replace those used up, and has shown an equal ability to adapt to new environments, such as reduced living space, as the need arose.

title: Thought Control v. Birth Control
description: The arrest on Long Island of a crusader for birth control and a mother who attended his lecture with her fourteenmonthold baby would be ridiculous, as Suffolk County Executive H. Lee Dennison originally termed it, if it were not something more serious.

title: France Has Trade Surplus
description: PARIS, Aug. 11 (UPI)Foreign trade figures for July showed a 10.4 per cent balance of trade favorable to France, the Ministry of Economics and Finance said today. French exports totaled $1,850,000,000, while imports were $1,675,000,000.

title: TENANTS'
description: About 100 tenants who consider their East Side apartment building a notorious site of prostitution, drug peddling and other illicit activities have been given an Aug. 23 hearing date in Civil Court here on which to argue their demand for a courtappointed administrator, one of those tenants said last night.

title: 52 Head Bring $1,183,200 As Spa Yearling Sales Begin
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 11 (AP)  A bull market in the thoroughbred racing, stock was confirmed last night as the 51st annual Saratoga Yearling Sales began.

title: New Archeology in the Holy Land
description: TEL GEZER, IsraelBiblical archeology, the romantic and evocative quest of gentle scholars who often seem bent on proving the Bible, is rapidly giving way to a nonpartisan science of Syro  Palestine studies.

title: Yanks, Angels Postponed, Play Two Here Tonight
description: A doubleheader starting at 5 P.M. today at Yankee Stadium was created by yesterday's rainstorm that washed out the game between the New York Yankees and California Angels after one inning with the score 00.

title: LA GUARDIA LEFT THE G.O.P. IN 1936
description: Mayor Lindsay is not the first Mayor of New York to abandon his Republican party enrollment and register in another party. Fiorello H. La Guardia took the same step in 1936, and in his case, too, national rather than local politics were a principal cause.

title: FUTURES TRADING HAS CAUTIOUS DAY
description: Trading was cautious yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade before the release of crop harvest estimates by the Agriculture Department.

title: Lindsay Dines With the Men Who Get Out the Vote
description: Mayor Lindsay and his wife, Mary, made their first public appearance after his announcement that they had become Democrats before an exuberant throng of 1,200 supporters last night in an atmosphere akin to that of a campaign kickoff.

title: BrandNew Democrat John Vliet Lindsay
description: A casting director's dream of a televisionera politician, Mayor Lindsay, wearing levis and an openatthethroat blue shirt, sat in a Colorado ski lodge chatting casually over cheeseburgers and beer.

title: BIG BOARD APPROVES INCREASED AID FUND
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday, that its membership had approved a $20million increase in authorized assistance funds for customers of member organizations that went into liquidation before the formation of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

title: U. N. Seeks Funds to Ship Aid to Pakistan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11  Secretary General Thant appealed today for more money to help send relief to East Pakistan.

title: Red Reality, $9.40, Wins Baruch Handicap at Spa
Lufthansa's Veto Threatens an Airline Price War
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 11Lufthansa, the West German airline, rejected tonight a new transAtlantic fare package worked out by other airlines at the end of a bitter conference that lasted more than six weeks. The veto threatened to touch off a price war over TransAtlantic fares next Feb. 1.

title: McGovern Calls Nixon Policies On Economy a Total Disaster
description: Senator George McGoverx charged yesterday that President Nixon's economic policies were a total disaster and said they would be the major isue in the campaign for President next year.

title: ACTIVITY STRONG IN TAXEXEMPTS
description: The taxexempt bond market again yesterday seemed able to handle another large load of new issues without much difficulty.

title: Irish Captain Breaks Leg
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 11 (UPI)Doug Gemmell, senior forward and captain of Notre Dame's 197172 basketball team, broke his left leg in a motorcycle accident in his home town, Irvington, N.J., the university's sports publicitty office said today.

title: Deposits at Savings Banks Slowed a Bit in July
description: The nation's mutual sayings banks continued last month to record massive gains in deposits, although the pace of growth showed another small decline, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: Mrs. Grosvenor Is Wed to General
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 Mrs. Pamela Mott Grosvenor and Maj. Gen. Ellsworth Ingalls Davis, U.S.A., retired, were married here this morning in the chapel of the Episcopal Christ Church Cathedral. Canon C. William Ziegenfuss performed the ceremony.

title: Ralph Coats Roe, 80, Engineer And SelfTaught Inventor, Dies
description: TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 11 Ralph Coats Roe, a selfeducated inventor and engineer, end chairman of Burns & Roe, Inc., of Oradell, an engineering concern he founded in 1932, died yesterday in a Paramus nursing home. He was 80 years old and lived at 220 Hudson Street.

title: Taipei Can Coexist With Peking
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.China is not a new land settled by nineteenthcentury pioneers devoted to selfdetermination. The Chinese have a distinctly nonAmerican background. The concept of Taipei's autonomy under Peking's sovereignty comes from two thousand years' experience in the world's largest political unit, which invented bureaucracy and civil service examinations when Europe was still in the Dark Ages.

title: Indonesia Gets Appeal On Behalf of Prisoners
description: LONDON, Aug. 11  Between 75,000 and 90,000 Indonesians are still in prison without trial five or six years after being arrested as Communists, according to a memorandum by Amnesty International made public here today.

title: 200 Phony Checks On a City Agency Found on Beach
description: A batch of what appeared to be City of New York Finance Department checks was found in the sand at Long Beach, L.I., early yesterday, and Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin put into operation a program designed to keep banks from honoring forged checks.

title: Personal Finance
description: The father of the bride has more than bills to pay, once the happy and frantic few hours of the wedding and reception are over. True, his daughter becomes some other man's responsibility, but there are some worries that a chat with his new soninlaw might put to rest.

title: An Arrangement in Queens
description: To the Editor: Your Aug. 2 editorial condemning the arrangement between Matt Troy and Nelson Rockefeller to select Louis Laurino as Queens County Surrogate was most welcome. While you were correct in pointing out that Judge John T. Clancy's resignation was timed so as to avoid a primary and thus disenfranchise the Queens voters, you were in error about the length of Mr. Laurino's term.

title: U.S. Team Is Cleared for Havana Trip
description: CALI, Colombia, Aug. 11 At 9:37 A.M. today, in the offices of the American Consulate, final approval was received from Washington granting visas to the United States men's volleyball team for its trip to Cuba tomorrow.

title: Lindsay Says Decision Was Made on Mountain
description: In announcing his switch to the Democratic party yesterday, Mayor Lindsay said his decision had been reached during his recent vacation with his wife, Mary, in the Colorado mountains.

title: OPERATING NET UP AT CITY INVESTING
description: The City Investing Company, whose diversified interests include housing and land development, manufacturing and financial services, increased its earnings from operations in the second quarter and first half, the company reported yesterday. Because of reduced gains on sales of real estate and securities, the net income in both periods declined from the year before.

title: Yugoslavs Stress Arms Preparedness as Brezhnev Visit Nears
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 11In the month before a visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party chief Yugoslav leaders are talking louder than ever of their preparedness to mobilize the nation against any aggressor.

title: Lindsay Chose Home To Announce Switch
description: In announcing his switch of party enrollment yesterday at Gracie Mansion rather than at City Hall, Mayor Lindsay was trying to separate what is almost inseparable for an elected official  the personal and political from the public and governmental.

title: STOCKS SHOOT UP AS VOLUME GAINS
description: Prices surged on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday on a small wave of increased trading activity.

title: Six ExJustice Ministers Say Athens Violates Laws
description: ATHENS, Aug. 11Six former Justice Ministers denounced the Government today for violating its own laws, calling for restoration of elementary conditions of freedom and justice in Greece.

title: Never Out of the Spotlight
NEGROES ACCUSE POSTAL SERVICE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The National Alliance of Postal and Federal Employes charged flay that blacks in the United States Postal Service were being subjected to sophisticated elimination from the new system.

title: PERU AND BRITAIN SPLIT IN TENNIS
description: Peru and Britain split their first two singles matches and Australia took a 10 lead over Canada in the semifinals of the international senior team tennis eliminations for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Transcript of Mayor's Statement on Party Switch
description: Following is a transcript of the statement by Mayor Lindsay announcing his switch in political parties, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Suit Says Dam Would Flood Sacred Sites
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11  The Environmental Defense Fund sued in Federal District Court here today to halt the Tennessee Valley Authority's construction of the $69million Tellico Dam, which it said would destroy what it called historic and sacred Cherokee Indian village sites.

title: Why, Liberation Must Be Everybody's
description: LONDONThe most noticeable result of women's lib in England is that most women nave already benefited from it. To some extent, they are beginning to feel freer from doubletalk, doublethink, isolation and guilt. Worry about sexual role and sexual performance; physical exhaustion, at the social and psychological load they have been carrying; distaste for the projected images of womenall are being aired. I don't know of any woman who isn't grateful for this.

title: Marine Who Was Held by Hanoi Found Not Guilty of All Charges
description: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 11 A young Long Island marine who spent 18 months as a prisoner of war was acquitted today of charges that he had run from his unit and, when captured, had made propaganda statements broadcast over the Hanoi radio.

title: MRS. W. G. HILDEBRAND
description: Mrs. Catherine Johnston Hildebrand, wife of William G. Hildebrand, executive director of the New York State Food Merchants Association, died of cancer on Tuesday in St. Agnes Hospital, White Plains. She was 47 years old and lived on Perch Bay Road in Waccabuc, N. Y.

title: BRIGHAMYOUNG BANS NEW KRAMER MOVIE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 11(UPI)  A Brigham Young University official said yesterday he banned a new Stanley Kramer film from the campus because it showed materialistic parents, bloodthirsty hunters, sexobsessed summer campers and doltish counselors.

title: EXCADET GETTING ARMY DISCHARGE
description: A 21yearold man who resigned from West Point last September after being denied a discharge as a conscientious objector is receiving such a discharge from the Army.

title: $21Million First Ave. Complex To House Archdiocesan Offices
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that it would move its administrative offices from the Villard Houses, a Renaissance revival landmark on Madison Avenue, into a $21.5million building to be constructed at First Avenue and 55th Street.

title: Herring Ad Irks Miss Hepburn
description: The makers of Vita herring products have imitated her voice to sell fish, Katharine Hepburn charged, and she sued the company and its advertising agency, SolowWeston inc., for $4million.

title: 97 Reported Dead In Jetliner Crash At Siberian Airport
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (UPI)A Soviet airliner crashed and exploded on takeoff from the Irkutsk Airport in Siberia, killing all 97 persons aboard, travel officials said today.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL DEFERS INCREASE IN SOME PRICES
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the country's second largest steel company, surprised the industry late yesterday with an announcement that it would defer for two months a previously scheduled price increase on an important class of products.

title: Bridg: Mrs. Rappaport Shatters Precedent by Taking Trophy
description: The outstanding performer in the Summer National Championships each year receives the Sally Fishbein Trophy. In two decades the winners have been exclusively male, and they have owed their successes largely to good performances in the Spingold master team championship.

title: U.S. Sues Gatorade Maker for Its Profits, Saying Grant Financed Developer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The Government sued StokelyVan Camp, Inc., today for all the profits the company has made from Gatorade, a soft drink that is advertised as unusually effective in quenching thirst.

title: Kennedy Sees Refugee Camp
description: CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 11 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy today visited hospitals jammed with East Pakistani refugees to see what could be done to treat children suffering from severe malnutrition. The Massachusetts Democrat had planned to end his refugeecamp tour today and go to Pakistan for two days, but Pakistan yesterday abruptly canceled permission for him to visit Dacca and Rawalpindi.

title: DDT Makes Matters Worse
description: STONY BROOK, N. Y.The pesticide industry tells us that DDT controls insects, yet frequently DDT creates more insect problems than it solves. DDT is a broadspectrum poison that kills all insects, including parasitic and predatory insects that help keep pests under control. By destroying these natural enemies, DDT often causes increased pest outDreaks, aggravating the problem. Pest resistance to DDT makes matters worse. Salesmen convince farmers that still more treatments are needed and they soon find themselves in an endless treadmill of insect problems, insecticide bills, and falling yields and profits. DDT is one of those ideal products (for manufacturers) that generate an apparent need for more of themselves. It's like drug addiction.

title: Mrs. Colette Roberts
description: Mrs. Colette Roberts, an influential art gallery director and author of studies in modern art, died Monday of congestive heart failure in the American Hospital on a visit to her native Paris. She was 60 years old and lived at 510 East 85th Street.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock owncrship by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies.

title: Medalist and Former Victor Lose in New Jersey Golf
description: WEST CALDWELL, N. J., Aug. 11  The tournament medalist, Mrs. David Johnston of Montclair and a former champion, Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells, were eliminated in the quarterfinals of the 46th New Jersey women's amateur championship today at the Mountain. Ridge Country Club.

title: Party Switch Pleases Democrats in Council
description: Mayor Lindsay's party switch is expected to improve his generally good relationships with the Democraticcontrolled City Council and Board of Estimate.

title: Roundup: Hit by Hebner Beats Cubs in 9th, 32
description: Richie Hebner enjoys people and they enjoy him. He is on a firstname basis with many of the ushers at Three Rivers Stadium in Pittsburgh and the Pirate fans agree that he is the club's most cooperative autographsigner and its friendliest player.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Aug. 6 editorial you call for the immediate suspension of United States aid to Pakistan, pointing to increasing evidence that the Bengali resistance is deeprooted and spreading. In his report from New Delhi appearing Aug. 8 Sydney Schanberg confirms that West Pakistan's military repression in East Pakistan is not succeeding and warns that the specter of an international war is hovering over the continent.

title: Junior Yachting Postponed
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 11A thunder squall lashed the fleet in the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Race Week today on Manhasset Bay, postponing the windup of the series until tomorrow morning.

title: Itkin Testifies 2 Light Concerns Got Millions by Fixing City Bids
description: Accusations that the Broadway Maintenance Corporation and the Welsbach Corporation rigged bids to obtain millions of dollars in streetlighting contracts with the city were made yesterday in testimony at a perjury trial in Federal Court here.

title: PUMP IMPLANTED IN HEART PATIENT
description: Air  Driven Booster Device Is the First of Its Kind

title: DR. JOHN LUND DIES; EDUCATOR WAS 80
description: NORWALK, Conn., August. 11  Dr. John Lund, an educator, died on Monday. He was 80 years old and lived at 12 Sunset Hill Avenue.

title: Soviet Weekly Reprints Attack On Rumania's Stance on Peking
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 11The Soviet Union today lent its support to a sharp attack on Rumania for failing to join with the rest of the Soviet bloc in criticizing China's policies.

title: DR. F. F. BREWSTER
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Aug. 11  Dr. Frederick F. Brewster, a dental surgeon who practiced in Brooklyn for many years, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital following a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 48 Vanderveer Court.

title: Nixon Tells Federal Aides: Limit Busing or Lose Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The White House warned today that Government officials could lose their jobs or be, transferred if they sought to impose widespread busing as a means of desegregating schools in the urban South.

title: FOURPOWER SESSION ON BERLIN EXTENDED
description: BERLIN, Aug. 11The ambassadors conducting the fourpower talks on Berlin conIferred for eight hours more today, bringing their current session to 17 hours.

title: Plan for Arab Talks Reported
description: CAIRO, Thursday, Aug. 12 (AP)The leaders of Egypt, Libya and Syria will hold a conference in Damascus next Wednesday to discuss their proposed Confederation of Arab Republics, the authoritative newspaper, Al Abram, said to day.

title: AIRPORT PROPOSAL INCENSES SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 11  Suffolk County legislative officials, faced with community reaction against plans to expand the Suffolk County airport at Westhampton Beach, said today that public hearings would be held and extensive consideration would be given to community feelings before any expansion plan was put into effect.

title: MeatEating, 230Pound Doctor Is Now 175Pound Vegetarian
description: STERLING, Va.Andrew T. Weil, M.D., is a doctor with only one patient himself. He lives alone here in a house surrounded by woods and filled with exotic Amazonian plants, not far from Washington's Dulles International Airport. He is conducting a private experiment.

title: Paper Warns Strikers
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Press told its employes today that it might soon have to withdraw all offers of retroactive pay increases to the striking printers and other craft unions idled by the printers' walkout. The press and The Morning PostGazette, which The Press prints under contract, have been closed since May 14 by the strike.

title: Powerful Vikings Get 2 Guards In a Move to Increase Depth
description: MANKATO, Minn., Aug. 11 The Minnesota Vikings, one of the strongest teams in pro football, made two small trades today typical of a challenger beefing up for a run at the championship.

title: Apollo Data Indicate Two Forces Combined to Shape the Moon
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 11 Scientists said here today that preliminary scrutiny of the photographs and rocks brought back from the moon by the Apollo 15 astronauts tended to confirm some previously held ideas about the moon's formation but that new subjects for inquiry had been raised.

title: KY REJECTS DECISION TO BAR CANDIDACY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 12Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said this morning that the Supreme Court decision that he had not qualified as a candidate for the presidential election on Oct. 3 was illegal and that he still considered himself a candidate.

title: Mexico Curbs Sulphur Output In Attempt to Stabilize Prices
description: The Mexican Government took steps yesterday to stabilize the price of Fraschprocess sulphur by restricting production to assigned amounts. The Government itself is the majority stockholder in the two sulphur producers.

title: 3 SCHOLARS CAUTION U.S. ON CHINA POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Calling for the United States to end or ease its insistence on a two China policy, three longtime China scholars said today that Taiwan has been used for 20 years to mount covert offensive operations against mainland China.

title: Jets Designate Hollomon Emergency Quarterback
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 11  As a precaution against both Al Woodall and Bob Davis being injured in the same game, Weeb Ewbank selected today Gus Hollomon, the strong side safetyman, as the New York Jets new emergency quarterback.

title: TEMPERATURE DIPS HERE AFTER STORM
description: Thunderstorms from the northwest moved through the metropolitan area yesterday, deluging communities on Long Island Sound, knocking out electrical power in parts of Westchester County and uprooting trees in other suburban areas.

title: Giants Back in Camp and Woes Mount
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 11With an air of resignation evident in the way they moved and the way they played, the Giants went back to their workouts today for the first time since their doubleknockout of recent days. The first blow was, of course, Fran Tarkenton's abrupt departure last Sunday night at Houston. Without him, the Giants were wrecked the following night at the Astrodome by the Oilers, 356.

title: Cold Duck Drinkers Sought
CASPER PUZZLED BY SLUMP IN GOLF
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 11 Billy Casper, twotime United States Open champion, rejoined the pro tour here, hoping to end a slump.

title: Weyerhaeuser Terms Set On Offering of Preferred
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company, the forest products concern with $1.9billion in assets, announced yesterday the terms of its $100million offering of convertible preferred stock. A total of 2 million shares will be offered to investors this morning at $50 per share by a group of investment firms headed by Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc.

title: Rumania Affirms Stand
description: VIENNA, Aug. 11 (AP) Rumania declared today that she intended to strengthen links with all Communist countries, evidently including China.

title: U. S. Export Bank Refuses Chile Loan To Buy 3 Airliners
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11: The ExportImport Bank today rejected a Chilean request for approximately $21million in loans and loan guarantees for the purchase of three airliners two Boeing 707's and a Boeing 727.

title: State Says District Attorneys Should Check on Relief Frauds
description: The state administration ordered local welfare officials yesterday to refer to District Attorneys cases in which welfare reciptents classified as employables were failing to report to job centers or work or training.

title: The Soo, a Mecca for Tourists, Fights to Stem Decay
description: SAULT SAINTE MARIE, Mich.  The no vacancy signs are lighted nightly now at the 20 motels in this 300yearold border town. The attraction is the Soo Locks, among the busiest in the world.

title: Alka Seltzer TV Spots Set
description: After almost nine months of waiting with bated breath, it's here, it's here.

title: Tarkenton Takes Original Offer And Rejoins Giant Camp Today
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 12 After a 2hour meeting with his boss that ended near midnight, Fran Tarkenton tonight accepted the same contract he had found unacceptable last Sunday night, when he walked off the New York Giants club.

title: I.O.S. DISPUTANTS SET OUTOFCOURT TALKS
Merger News
description: The Federal Paper Board CoMpany and the Riegel Paper Board Corporation announced yesterday they have agreed in principle on the merger of Riegel's paper and real estate activities into Federal.

title: Deposed but Defiant
description: I like a few drinks when I finish work, John G. Gorton once told an interviewer. I like a party where I can sing and dance and yarn; yes, I even like talking to women.

title: Faulkner Issues Reply
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 12 (AP)Prime Minister Brian Faulkner said he found neither the tone nor the substance of Mr. Lynch's criticism at all helpful in a situation where the prime need is to protect democratic methods against the rule of the gun.

title: Henry KorabJaniewicz, 74, A PolishAmerican Leader
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Aug. 12 Henry M. KorabJaniewicz, former president of Pasco Meat Products, Inc., who was a leader in PolishAmerican activities, died yesterday at his home, 27 Park Row. His age was 74.

title: Market Place: Then and Now: Enterprise Fund
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 12The elegant headquarters building of the Enterprise Fund is in Century City, Beverly Hills huge office building complex and its monument to overexpansion. The building at 1888 Century Park East is called, simply, Shareholders, which has prompted more than one critic of Enterprise's sponsor, the Shareholders Management Company, to ask whether the halffilled building belongs to the management company.

title: LINDSAY'S CHANCE IN NATIONAL RACE IS REPORTED SLIM Democratic Chiefs Put Him Far Behind Others Who Bid for Presidency PARTY RESPONSE MIXED Some Democrats Welcome Mayor, but Others Are Cool and Even Critical
description: Democratic state chairmen across the country declared in telephone interviews yesterday that if Mayor Lindsay entered the race for President, he would find himself far behind other Democratic hopefuls, whose campaign organizations and tours through key primary states have already tapped most liberal support.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUP TIED TO SHOOTINGS
description: The police are investigating reports that persons associated with a Jamaican religious group, the Rastafarians, are responsible for at least five and possibly 10 recent shootings in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: JAMES BERRYMAN, CARTOONIST, DIES
Jerseyan Is Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that First Lieut. Glen J. Taliaferro of the Air Force, who was from Eatontown, N. J., has been killed in Southeast Asia.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $754million, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $680million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,422,000,000, up 8 per cent from $6,875,000,000.

title: TEACHER BARRED OVER SEX CHANGE
description: BASKING RIDGE, N. J., Aug. 12The Bernards Township school board tonight suspended a 52yearold music teacher who underwent a sexchange opeartion and wanted to return to class in September as woman after teaching 14 years here as a man.

title: WILLIAM H. COWLES, SPOKANE PUBLISHER
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Aug. 12 (AP)  William Hutchinson Cowles, chairman of the Cowles Publishing Company, and the. Spokane Chronicle Company, died Thursday of heart failure in a hospital here after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Treating Symptoms
description: To the Editor: As each succeeding survey shows a rising incidence of crime and violence in our society, well meaning persons call for more police and greater penalties. The Kerner Commission Report revealed that urban unrest and to a great extent violent crime are merely symptoms of a greater illness in the general society. The Gross National Product is at an alltime high, while citizens are hungry. Corporate profits are growing, while the inner cities are deteriorating. Affluence abounds as ghetto schools graduate functional illiterates. Homicides increase as frustrated people strike out at those nearest to themselves, their family and close friends. Unemployed and underemployed youth watch examples of the good life on television screens. It is hoped that our leadership will start treating the disease and not the symptoms before it is too late.

title: Ulster Rioting Ebbs as Toll Reaches 24
description: BELFAST, Aug. 12  British troops pressed the hunt today for terrorists in the smoldering Roman Catholic slums here and in Londonderry.

title: Article 1  No Title
U.S. COMBAT DEATHS ROSE BY 4 IN WEEK
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 (AP)  American battlefield deaths in Vietnam increased slightly last week but maintained the sixyear low that has prevailed for the past month, the United States Command reported today.

title: On the Town to Return
description: The revival of On the Town, presented by Jerry Schlossberg, and directed by Ron Field, is scheduled to open at the Imperial Theater Oct. 31, with previews starting Oct. 27. Three male leads, Kurt Peterson, Bill Gerber and Jess Richards, have been added to the cast of the musical.

title: Wallace Defies Court on Busing Plan
Australian Premier Ousts Gorton as Head of Defense
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 12  Prime Minister William McMahon today dismissed Defense Minister John G. Gorton, his controversial predecessor as head of government, in a, lively political confrontation that has been a national sensation this week.

title: G.O.P. Liberals Dispute Lindsay on Party's Direction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Liberal and moderate Republicans generally disagree with the assessment of Mayor Lindsay of New York that their party has abandoned the fight for more responsive government.

title: PACKETS AVAILABLE ON PENNSY'S REALTY
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday mailed special information packets to 800 potential buyers of the 24 realty parcels in midManhattan that it is offering for sale.

title: DEFEAT ON FUNDS UPSETS RAMAPO Young Voters Surprised by SchoolOutlay Rejections
description: SPRING VALLEY, N. Y., Aug. 12Some residents of the Ramapo Central School District 2, the eighth largest in the state, appeared stunned today by the voters defeat of nine school propositions yesterday.

title: Bridge:Capsule Recommendations Usually of Dubious Value
description: Most of the capsule recommendations to novice players handed down from the days of whist are of dubious value. The best of them is perhaps secondhand low and the worst is perhaps lead through strength.

title: Labor United on Issues
description: The plaints of labor leaders at this week's convention of the New York State A.F.L.C.I.O. harked back to some of the earlier, less affluent days for labor.

title: From a Cellblock in Connecticut
description: The following statement was written by a group of prisoners calling themselves the Danbury Resisters inside the Federal Penitentiary in Connecticut, where the Berrigan brothers have been serving sentences for destroying draft records. After issuing the statement on Aug. 6'the anniversary of Hiroshimathey4 began a hunger strike. On Wednesday, Philip  Berrigan and ten strikers were removed to a Federal, prison hospital in Missouri. The statement gave these reasons for the prisoners protest:

title: Cosmos 434 Is Orbited
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (AP)The Soviet Union has launched another unmanned satellite in its secret Cosmos program, the official press agency, Tass, reported today. It said that Cosmos 434 would continue space exploration. It did not disclose the date of the launching but said that the craft's orbit ranged from 177 to 122 miles above the earth and had an angle of inclination to the Equator of 51.6 degrees.

title: Vikings Grant Has His Opinion Of Exhibitions: To Make Money
description: MANKATO, Minn., Aug. 12 Mick Tingelhoff, who calls himself a country boy from Nebraska, is the allleague center for the Minnesota Vikings. His subject today was his team's coach, the sphinx  like Harry (Bud) Grant. Jr.

title: U.S. to Study Moves
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Mr. Ziegler said today that the Justice Department and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare would look into the actions of Governor Wallace.

title: Bush Insists U.S. Will Press Two China Policy in the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 12George Bush, obviously concerned about rumors that the United States was not serious in its stated intention to keep Nationalist China in the United Nations, insisted today that the Administration would use everything we have to bring Communist China into the world organization without excluding the Taiwan Government.

title: Coddling the Segregationists
description: President Nixon, whose Administration has often charged that the courts are coddling criminals, now has labeled as villains those who want to enforce and administer the school desegregation law. He has read the riot act, not to those school districts which stand accused of continuing segregation but rather to public servants in his own official family who want to assure compliance with the law.

title: Korean Musicians to Play In Central Park Tomorrow
description: A concert performed by Korean musicians and presented by the Korean Cultural Center in cooperation with the AmericanKorean Foundation will be given at the Central Park Mall tomorrow night at 8 P.M.

title: President Criticized On 1776 Celebration
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Democratic National Committee accused President Nixon today of stealing the American Revolution by loading the Bicentennial Commission with Republicans and squeezing out Democrats,

title: Jackson at the Post
description: Senator Henry M. Jackson is now enough of a Presidential candidate, however undeclared, to have established the pitch and tenor of his campaign. At this stage, a candidate's objective is to detach himself from the field, so it is not surprising that there is the Senator's opening salvos less of substance than conscious effort to establish a base for himself. He is staking out a claim, as it were, to represent a basic segment of the Democratic, party's .political spectrum.

title: U. S. Cyclist Wins at Cali
Reserve Regaining Grip On Expansion of Credit
description: The Federal Reserve appears to have made progress toward regaining a firm grip on credit expansion, according to data for the most recent two weeks published yesterday.

title: PARIS PEACE TALKS NOW IN DOLDRUMS
description: PARIS, Aug. 12Xuan Thuy, suffering from what a spokesman termed a slight indisposition, did not represent North Vietnam today at the peace talks.

title: County Democratic Chiefs In, State Split Over Lindsay
description: A strong split developed yesterday among state Democratic county leaders outside New York City in the wake of Mayor Lindsay's switch from the Republican to the Democratic party.

title: Soviet Move to Avert War Is Seen in Pact With India
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  Authoritative United States officials said today that they understood the Soviet Union succeeded in dissuading India from formally recognizing East Pakistan as an independent nation three days ago by quickly signing a friendship treaty with India.

title: MORTON DESIGNATES 11 LANDMARK SITES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) The Interior Department announced today the designation of 11 outdoor classroom sites as national environmental education landmarks in nine states and the District of Columbia.

title: 2 IN BRONX INDICTED IN DEATH OF INFANT
description: A Bronx couple accused by a grand jury of evincing a depraved indifference to human life were indicted yesterday on charges of murder, criminally negligent homicide and manslaughter in connection with the death last June of their 13monthold daughter.

title: Court Bars San Francisco Delay On a Desegregation Busing Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12 (UPI)A Federal court refused today to delay citywide elementary school desegregation and busing in San Francisco and ordered the city to put a desegregation plan into effect Sept. 8.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Scientist Denies Picture Shows Double Helix Structure of DNA
description: Dr. Albert V. Crewe of the University of Chicago said yesterday that a photograph in yesterday's edition of The New York Times, purportedly showing the double helix sturcture of a DNA molecule, was actually a picture of a virus or a cell fragment.

title: Just for the Record
description: It has been said that the customers always write. Sometimes they write with more indignation than is necessary. That's why it seems advisable to set the record straight and shuffle a few facts into proper historical perspective. In a letter to the editor a few days ago David Scott of New York took strong issue with a column I had written a week earlier about Knute Rockne and his signal contributions to football.

title: China's Nightmare
description: PEKING, Aug. 12One of the few remaining symbols of the old preCommunist diplomatic life in Peking is the International Club with its cool highceilinged rooms and its tennis courts and swimming pool in the middle of the capital. Here visitors are now taken by officials to see Japanese movies which are said to prove the revival of Japanese militarism.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: Hawker Siddeley Aviation, Ltd., yesterday received a $81.2million contract from the United States Marine Corps through the British Ministry of Aviation for continued production of the AV8A vertical takeoff and landing jet fighter.

title: Sayville Lawyer Is Indicted On Two Counts of Perjury
description: RIVERHEAD, L, I., Aug. 12  A Sayville, L. I., lawyer was indicted today on two counts of perjury and one of criminal contempt for allegedly lying under oath to a grand jury about interest payments on a loan he had received from a Suffolk County loansharking ring.

title: Procter &
description: Sales of the Procter & Gamble Company in the fiscal year ended June 30 topped the $3billion mark for the first time and earnings rose 12 per cent, the company reported yesterday. The results set records for the 15th consecutive year, according to the annual statement to 89,000 stockholders,

title: 2YEAR CONTRACT FOR RON JOHNSON
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 12 The Giants got a thorny problem out of the way today when they signed Ron Johnson, who had the distinction of being the team's first major holdout.

title: MAN KILLED BY POLICE IN BRONX INCIDENT
description: Plainclothes men in the Bronx last night killed a man allegedly wielding a meat cleaver and critically wounded another man, they said was armed with a baseball bat in an incident in which the policemen came to the aid of two other men being chased by a crowd of about 30 persons.

title: TRADING IS ACTIVE IN CORN FUTURES
description: The Chicago Board of Trade had a very busy day yesterday  about 66 million bushels of corn and 89 bushels of soybeans were traded.

title: Allocation of the Funds To Provide Public Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12Following are the apportionments, in thousands, of the $600million going to some 700 cities, counties and states and the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico under the Emergency Employment Act:

title: SCHLEE, WITH 66, LEADS BY STROKE
