description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 12 John Schlee, who has stood up through many discouraging years to remain on the pro golf tour, led the $165,000 Massachusetts Classic field today with a sixunderpar 66.

title: SOVIET WOMAN SETS WORLD DISCUS MARK
description: HELSINKI, Aug. 12 (UPI) Faina Melnik of the Soviet Union set a world record in the women's discus throw today as athletes from the East continued their domination of the European track and field championships.

title: Death Toll of 34 Million Over 50 Years Laid to Chinese Reds by Senate Study
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) A study published today by the Senate Internal Security subcommittee estimated that Chinese Communism has cost at least 34 million lives, and possibly as many as 63 million, in the last 50 years.

title: Worthless Tickets Bring Refunds in OTB Snafu
Arresting Patrolman Testifies Director Refused to Cooperate
description: A patrolman testified in court yesterday that Alan Schneider, the theatrical director, had refused to cooperate with policemen controlling crowd at the scene of a construction accident last May 25.

title: Ties With Jordan Severed by Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12 Syria broke diplomatic relations with Jordan today and barred Jordanian planes from Syrian airspace following reported border clashes between the two countries.

title: WAR'S TIDE AND JOBS LINKED BY ROMNEY
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (UPI) George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said tonight that more Americans were out of jobs because fewer were being killed in Vietnam.

title: Priorities in Space
description: Not unexpectedly, Apollo 15 commander David R. Scott has called for reinstatement of the cancelled Apollo and 19 missions and for a multibilliondollar lunar exploration program modeled on the precedents set Antarctica. Great as is our admiration for the accomplishments of the Apollo 15 crew, it would be a gross distortion of national priorities to assign still more money to space.

title: TWO BY BUCKPASSER SOLD FOR TOP PRICES
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 12 (AP)Two yearlings by Buckpasser brought the highest prices among 60 head sold last night for a total of $1,622,900 at the annual FasigTipton horse auction. The average sales price was $27,048.

title: If You Hanker to Dine a la Chou Enlai
description: The ambiance and the political conversation are impossible to duplicate, but when it comes to the food, that's another matter. Almost everything served at a dinner party given by Premier Chou Enlai in Peking last week is available here.

title: LARRY BLACKER
description: Larry Blacker, a retired clothing manufacturer and former president of Blacker Brothers, Inc., died yesterday. He was 77 years old and lived at 201 East 66th Street.

title: Accord Is Reached On Minority Hiring At Harlem Project
description: The Board of Education announced last night that it had reached an agreement with a Harlem organization that would result in the hiring of more blacks and Puerto Ricans in the construction of the Marin Luther King Jr. High School, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street.

title: State Panel Plans UnitPrice Hearing Sept. 23
description: The Joint Legislative Committee on Consumer Protection will start public hearings here Sept. 23 in a renewed effort to enact a statewide unit pricing measure that died in the Legislature this spring.

title: Prices of Bonds Advance; Government Notes Rise
description: Bond prices advanced fairly sharply yesterday, responding to a combination of relatively light inventories of securities, Federal Reserve buying Wednesday and some news developments favorable to the credit markets.

title: Australia and Peru Take Stevens Cup Tennis Leads
description: Australia and Peru took 21 leads in their respective semifinals of the international senior team tennis eliminations for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Fishing Report AREA AAfter a few days of poor pickings because of storms, angling conditions again are good. Blues are responding in sizable numbers at Manasquan and Barnegat Ridges by chummers using butterfish and smelt for bait. A few small tuna and bonita also being found here. Blues, up to 25 pounds, in substantial evidence at The Klondike. Along shore, fluke from 3to6 pounds being taken with cut bait. Surfcasters also are doing well with blues from Asbury Park to Seaside. Barnegat Light boats have been doing well with blues and fluke.

title: The Grapes of Wrath
description: Protectionism is putting its vinegary bite in the wine bottle. The California Wine Institute has launched pressure drive to convince United States trade representatives negotiating with the Common Market Brussels that the size of the bottle is of vital national interest and that the standard 70centiliter European bottle should be outlawed in this country.

title: Lindsay, the Democrat, Makes a Tour of East Harlem
description: Mayor Lindsay, Democrat of New York, spent much of the day yesterday touring East Harlem, chatting with drug addicts, shaking hands with storekeepers and drawing oohs and ahs from crowds.

title: MARCUS TESTIFIES AT LIMNS TRIAL
description: James L. Marcus testified yesterday that he had agreed to accept a 5 per cent kickback on a city contract with the Broadway Maintenance Corporation when he was Water Commissioner.

title: Both Connecticut Houses Approve 6.5% Sales Tax
Betrayal of Rebels Charged
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 (Reuters)An Indian political leader today accused his country and the Soviet Union of stabbing Bangla Desh.

title: STEEL RIFT CAUSED PRICERISE DELAY
description: Major steel producersother than the Bethlehem Steel Corporation  have proposed to ship metal to automobile manufacturers after Dec. 1 without charging them the publicly announced higher prices for coldrolled sheets scheduled to take effect on that date, it was learned yesterday.

title: Catholic Group Honors Godspell, Rock Show
description: Godspell, a musical that will celebrate its 100th performance tonight at the Promenade Theater, received the National Theater Arts Conference's Dineen Award yesterday. The show, a rock musical based on Bach's St. Matthew Passion, was cited for its relevancy of theme, original and artistic treatment of subject, for its positive statement to a world weary of negativism and for its excellence of production.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 108.1 from 108.5 last week.

title: Army Investigates Alleged Atrocity by General
RevolvingCredit Agreement Completed by Ozite Corp.
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (Reuters) The Ozite Corporation said today it had completed a new revolving credit and termloan agreement with an initial amount of $21million.

title: Rail TonMileage Off 14% From Comparable 70 Period
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Aug. 7, affected by the United Transportation Union strikes against 10 railroads was considerably below the volume in the corresponding 1970 week. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Padres Shut Out Mets Again
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 12 Steve Arlin, a practicing dentist when he isn't pitching, dreamed the other night that his patients told him he should stick to baseball. The Mets wished tonight he would have stuck to dentistry.

title: Pakistani to Visit Soviet
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 12 Foreign Secretary Sultam Mohammed Khan has been invited to visit the Soviet Union. The invitation was received last week, it is understood, and has been accepted for later this month.

title: U.S. RIGHTS PANEL CRITICIZES NIXON ON SCHOOL BUSING
Fuel Concern Urges Court To Allow Maine Refinery
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 12Maine Clean Fuels, Inc., has appealed to the state Supreme Court the recent denial of its application to build a $150million oil refinery on Sears Island.

title: PROPHET JONES, 63, DETROIT PREACHER
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12 (UPI)Prophet Jones, a flamboyant preacher who once owned $12,000 fur coat and a 54room mansion bought for him by his followers, died today at the age of 63.

title: Many Deaths Laid to Products in Home
Trade War With Japan?
description: The crisis in JapaneseAmerican relations set off by President Nixon's secret negotiations with Peking is explosive because it comes on top of a series of economic disputes that are politically sensitive in both countries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: No matter how much new blood, new money, new reorganizing and redrawing of organizational charts are imposed upon commission regulation, one fault is so pervasive that if it is not corrected commission regulation in a private enterprise economy must ultimately fail. I refer to both the immorality and the nonsense of permitting commissioners and their staff the right to be employed by the private firms they have regulated subsequent to their termination of employment with the regulatory body.

title: Heart Patient Comfortable
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12 (AP) Doctors at Sinai Hospital reported today that Haskell Shanks, a 63yearold factory plant guard, was conscious, ble some 30 hours after receiving a partly mechanical heart. A team of surgeons implanted the sixinch rubber and Dacron device yesterday.

title: Finding the Golden Easter Egg
Is There a Case for Irish Unification?
description: To the Editor: William V. Shannon begins his July 29 column, Light on Ulster, with one very obvious inaccuracy, which, while not important in itself, serves as preview of the confusion and onesided views that follow.

title: NEGROES PURSUE POSTAL JOB ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  An official of the National Alliance of Postal and Federal Employes, a predominantly Negro union, charged today that the only route to job security for or blacks in the United States Postal Service was to try to get along with supervisors.

title: Angus Dun, Episcopal Bishop Of Washington, 194462, Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12The Right Rev. Angus Dun, who as Episcopal Bishop of Washington from 1944 to 1962, officiated at many national ceremonies, including the funeral service for President Franklin D. Roosevelt, died today of a stroke. He was 79 years old and had been sick since March.

title: Stock Market Gain Best Since Nov. 30
description: The stock market rallied yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing 12.63 to 859.01, its best gain since Nov. 30, 1970.

title: Sugar Quota Increased On Possible Port Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)The Agriculture Department today announced an increase of 100,000 tons in the 1971 United States sugar quota in an effort to build up supplies because of a possible strike at Gulf and East Coast ports at the end of September.

title: UPSETS TRIM FIELD IN U.S. CHESS OPEN
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 12  Five upsets helped narrow the field of leaders to 10 players last night in the fourth round of the United States Open Chess Championship.

title: Quick Doctor, the Needle
description: LUTHERVILLE, Md.The rash of reports from the Chinese People's Republic on marvelous cures by acupuncture will surely create a demand here for these heretofore unheralded miracles.

title: Roundup: Lolich Wins 19th as Tigers Take Over 2d
description: Mickey Lolich decided during spring training to concentrate less on strikeouts and more on winning games. The pudgy, 30yearold Detroit Tiger lefthander is doing well in both departments. He is second in the major leagues to Vida Blue of the Oakland Athletics in victories and strikeouts.

title: $600Million Allocated for Public Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 Apportionment of $600million to 700 city, county and state governments under the $1billion emergency public service employment program was announced today by Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson.

title: Genesis Rock Unboxed
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Colonels Scott and Irwin watched scientists unbox their. genesis rock, socalled because it may be part of the moon's original crust, late today and confirm it indeed might hold the secrets of the moon's creation 4.6 billion years ago.

title: Books of The Times
description: The plotthat overmaligned instrument of entertainmentis alive and serpentine in Joe David Brown's Addie Prayvery much alive and twisting its way through the South of the 1930's to bring us nothing of great significance but a very good time. The time I'm talking about, mind you, Miss Acidic Pray begins, was a few years before and after Franklin D. Roosevelt was elected President for the first time. I know you've heard about the Depression we had back then. Well, I don't think times were nearly so bad as some people put on. . . . I don't think there was a place Long Boy and I went that we couldn't find somebody to do business with.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Colorado Interstate Corporation announced yesterday in Colorado Springs the appointment of W. E. Mueller, already President, as chairman, president and chief executive officer. In other changes, Thomas L. Pelican, president of the Colorado Interstate Gas Company subsidiary since 1965, was named senior vice president in charge of the parent corporation's energy group. Joseph P. Roetzel, president of the Colorado Oil and Gas Corporation since 1965, was made vice chairman of this subsidiary and a senior vice president of the parent corporation in charge of land development. Robert C. McHugh, a senior vice president of the Colorado Interstate Corporaton, replaces Mrs. Pelican as president of the Colorado Interstate Gas Company. Robert H. Mahon was named president of the chemical subsidiary.

title: AGAUNAR OF ITALY ARRIVES FOR TROT
Shevelove Will Direct Full Circle, a Musical
description: Burt Shevelove, who directed the hit musical No, No, Nanette, has been signed to direct an original musical about three generations of a wealthy, liberal American family set against a background of the last halfcentury.

title: 2 PIRATE RADIOS SEIZED IN YORKERS
description: Federal marshals, yesterday dismantled two pirate radio stations in Yonkers and arrested the owners, two young men who say they plan to make a test case of our Constitutional right to broadcast.

title: Burns Meets With Mayor To Discuss Commitments
BERLIN NEGOTIATIONS RECESS FOR 4 DAYS
description: BERLIN, Aug. 12  After 21 hours of intensive talks since Tuesday, the ambassadors of the Big Four powers decided to pause today in their attempt to negotiate an agreement on Berlin.

title: PAYOFF CHARGES LEFT TO F.B.I. HERE
description: A Police Department spokesman said yesterday that the department was not investigating charges made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation by a Queens policy operator that he had paid out $1,500 a month for police protection.

title: Work Clothes Gain as Career Apparel
description: DETROIT, Aug. 12John F. Foley drove his big Dodge motorhome the other day into the parking lot of the Michigan State University employes credit union in East Lansing. Between 8:30 and 9:30 A.M. the credit union's 20 women workers filed in and out of his airconditioned sitting room on wheels as they tried on their new dresses and jackets in bittersweet with brown trim.

title: The Vatican Word on News
description: These observations on the right to be informed and on the news are part of the pastoral instruction by the Pontifical Commission for the Means of Social Communication, as reported in the Vatican newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Concern about the dollar appears to result from attempts to interpret our present situation in the light of traditional rules that are not applicable.

title: Miami Police Chief Sued
description: MIAMI, Aug. 12 (AP)John J. Harrington of Philadelphia, national president of the Fraternal Order of Police, filed a $1million libel suit yesterday against Bernard Garmire, the Miami police chief, contending that Chief Garmire had called him a poor excuse for a police officer.

title: Commitment to Sadat by Nixon Is Reported in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Aug. 12  President Nixon was authoritatively reported tonight to have promished President Anwar eISadat that the United States would press for a specific solution of the dispute between Egypt and Israel.

title: J.V.KENNY NAMED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: NEWARK, Aug. 12 A Federal grand jury today indicted John V. Kenny, the bedridden Hudson County Democratic leader, and three other men on charges of extorting a $20million subcontract at the $40million automated post office project in nearby Kearny.

title: A ScientistAstronaut Will Fly on Apollo 17
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) The space agency tonight picked Dr. Harrison H. Schmitt, a geologist, to be the first scientist to set foot on the moon. He will be a crewman next year aboard Apollo 17.

title: July Surplus Is Put At $103Million
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters)  Britain's overseas trading in July resulted in a surplus of $103.2million, the Government announced today.

title: A.T. &
Speculative Attacks Grow On U.S. Currency Abroad
Pasadena Museum: Cutbacks and Hopes
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 12 There is always something happening at the Pasadena Art Museum . . . says the brochure to the $8.5million building, which opened a year and a half ago In the Los Angeles suburb that Jack Benny used to make jokes about.

title: Firemen in Denver Ask Public's Help To Curb Bombings
description: DENVER, Aug. 12  The Denver Fire Department asked today for public help in curbing an epidemic of bombings in which 36 fire bombs and two dynamite bombs have gone off in the city in the last five days.

title: A Liberal Episcopalian
description: Bishop Dun, tall, ruddy and broadshouldered, was an author, teacher and orator who stirred his church and international religious conventions with his pleas for unity among Christian denominations.

title: U. S. Helping Artists Record Natural Beauties
description: MILLBROOK, N. J., Aug. 8 Natural beauties that have stirred campers, hikers and motorists are being transferred to canvas by a cluster of professional artists and gifted students in a federally sanctioned commune  like school in the Delaware Water Gap, Recreation Area.

title: AMEX SHARES UP AS VOLUME RISES
description: The American Stock Exchange scored its biggest advance in nine months yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: Mississippi Training Program Decries Cutoff of Federal Aid
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 12  Leaders of a program of manpower training and basic education that has prepared thousands of poor Mississippi black and whites for jobs over the last six years protested today what they said was a cutoff of funds by the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: ST. CATHARINES SETS EARLY ROWING PACE
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 12  High winds and rough water hampered the oarsmen today in the opening of the 89th Royal Canadian Henley regatta.

title: Syrians Back From Sudan
description: CAIRO, Aug. 12 (Reuters) Two top Syrian officials flew back to Damascus today after a brief unannounced visit to Khartoum that observers saw as an attempt to mediate between the Soviet Union and the Sudan.

title: TIGHTER S.E.C. RULE ON FIRMS PROPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today an amendment to its rules on the capital requirements of brokerage firms, applicable mainly to smaller firms.

title: Scott Urges Restoring Canceled Apollo Flights
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 12The commander of Apollo 15 said here today that there was still so much to learn from manned exploration of the moon that lie favored restoring immediately the canceled Apollo 18 and Apollo 19 flights.

title: U.S. PLANS TO AID PETROCHEMICALS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)  The Nixon Administration decided today to give the fastgrowing petrochemical industry a greater share of cheap crude oil imports in an effort to spur investment, jobs and exports.

title: Little Rock Group Barred In Attempt to Block Hair
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 12 (AP)Judge G. Thomas Eisele, issued an order in Federal Court here yesterday enjoining the Little Rock Auditorium Commission from interfering with the booking and presentation of Hair, the rock musical.

title: Weary, Fearful Refugees From Ulster Crowd Into Ireland
description: GORMANSTON, Ireland, Aug. 12 In the mess hall of the Irish Army camp here there are travel posters on the walls, an Ironic backdrop to the rows of women and children and a few men sitting at the long tablesrefugees from the troubles in Northern Ireland.

title: I.T.T. DENIES AIDES TRADED ON DATA
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation issued a statement yesterday in which it labeled as baseless and without foundation press reports that several of its executives had indulged in insider trading in the company's stock in advance of a major news announcement issued by the company on July 31.

title: RAGAMUFFIN WINS BRITISH SAIL PRIZE
description: PLYMOUTH, England, Aug. 12 (UPI)Ragamuffin, the Australian yacht that won the 605mile Fastnet race, was confirmed today as the champion of the 1971 Admiral's Cup sailing series.

title: REPAYMENTS SET AT ROLLSROYCE
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (UPI) The preferred creditors of RollsRoyce, Ltd., will get half their money back plus interest next month and may get more before the end of the year, the company's liquidator said today.

title: Acquitted Marine Gets Honorable Discharge
description: QUANTICO, Va., Aug. 12 (AP) The Marine Corps gave Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney, 21 years old, an honorable discharge today.

title: Socialist Workers Nominate Candidates
description: Mrs. Linda Jenness and Andrew Pulley were officially designated the Socialist Workers party candidates for President and Vice President in 1972. The party is convened in Cleveland.

title: Puerto Rico Government Takes Firm Line on Evicting Squatters
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 11 The Puerto Rican government has adopted a hard line in dealing with poor landless families that have seized private and public land on which to build squatter settlements.

title: U.S. to Declassify More Secret Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  President Nixon has ordered early declassification of secret Government documents on the Korean war, the 1958 intervention by American troops in Lebanon, the abortive invasion of Cuba in 1961 and the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, the White House announced today.

title: TWO VETERANS BILLS ARE SIGNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)  President Nixon signed two bills today affecting veterans with serviceconnected disabilities.

title: City Accuses 14 of Mortgage Loan Frauds
description: City Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin charged yesterday that 14 developers and contractors had defrauded the city of $792,002 through inflated mortgage loans for slum rehabilitation from the Municipal Loan Program.

title: Newcombe Eliminates Riessen in Canadian Tennis
Memory of Schnabel To Kindle a Concert
Dr. Blake Appeals on Mujib
description: GENEVA, Aug. 12The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, said today that the secret military trial of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the East Pakistani leader, may invite wider conflict. In an appeal to President Agua Mohammad Yahya Khan of Pakistan, Dr. Blake also said that such a trial was likely to increase animosity, suspicion and human suffering.

title: A BretonStyle Inn In the Countryside
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: 941526 Wins in Jersey
description: EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 12 (AP)  This week's winning New Jersey lottery number is 941526. Holders of tickets with all six digits win $50,000; with the last five digits, $4,000; with the last four, $400; the last three, $40, and those with the last two get a free ticket in a millionaire lottery drawing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Stanley Rosenthal's letter (Aug. 5) adds little to what he describes as the continuing polemics surrounding vacancy decontrol. His assertion that rentcontrolled housing is underutilized when compared with uncontrolled housing is simply not supported by the facts.

title: Case of Missing Engineer Stirs Political Controversy in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12 Last January, a Brazilian civil engineer was arrested in his home by Government security agents and disappeared. He has not been heard from since. But his case exploded in noisy publicity today, one day after the military government had blocked a last attempt to clear it up through legal channels.

title: P.S.C. Examiner Backs Con Ed's Hudson Plan
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12A bearing examiner for the state's Public Service Commission recommended today that the Consolidated Edison Company be allowed to build a controversial 52mile electric transmission line above ground through Sullivan, Orange and Rockland Counties, rather than underground as demanded by residents and conservationists.

title: Large Cars Find Favor At Chrysler
description: LAKE OF THE OZARKS, Mo., Aug. 12  For the Chrysler Corporation, the American consumer who wants a big automobile that gives him a feeling of status and catches his eye with striking design and color is not becoming extinct.

title: Thousands of Vietnamese Told To Display Portrait of Thieu
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 2Hundreds of thousands of large photographs of President Nguyen Van Thieu, who is running for reelection this October, are being handed out in the provinces by local officials who are ordering the, Vietnamese to display them.

title: Nixons at Opening of Wolf Trap Repertory Center
description: VIENNA, Va., Aug. 12The resident company of the new Wolf Farm Park for the Performing Arts opened its inaugural season here tonight with President and Mrs. Nixon in attendance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It seems unlikely thatwith or without an incomes policythe trend toward increases of wage rates far beyond increases of productivity can be stopped. Should we not try to increase productivity if we wish to reduce inflationary pressure?

title: Bank of France Says Its Reserves Climbed
description: PARIS, Aug. 12 (AP)The Bank of France reported today that its reserves rose nearly $190million to about $5.25billion in the week ended Aug. 5, bringing the increase in four weeks to about $810million.

title: Past Gallup Polls Show Lindsay Faces Big Fight for Nomination
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 11  Four surveys taken by the Gallup Poll organization between last November and June indicate that Mayor Lindsay faces a difficult uphill battle if he seeks the Democratic Presidential nomination, but that some factors favor his success.

title: Ramirez Upstes Stockton
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 12  Raul Ramirez of Mexico, the United States junior champion, upset Dick Stockton of Port Washington, L.I., the topseeded player, 63, 64, in the quarterfinals of the United States amateur men's grass court tennis championships at the Meadow Club today.

title: Once Sheets Were for Beds and Halloween
description: More than a few of the David de Wildes's friends have chosen to sleep in the den rather than in the guest room.

title: Theismann Stars in Debut
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 12 (UPI)Joe Theismann, a rookie, threw a 94yard touchdoyn pass and scored on an 84yard quarterback draw play tonight as the Toronto Argonauts defeated the Montreal Alouettes, 2614, in Canadian Football League game.

title: Levitt Urges Upgrading Of School District Bonds
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt urged yesterday that all bonds sold by school districts in New York State be rated at least A by Moody's and Standard & Poor's, two major credit rating services.

title: Fire Warning Issued On Two Feather Boas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Two types of feather boas distributed by a Chicago company and used to trim dresses, negligees and other feminine garments are highly flammable, the Federal Trade Commission warned today.

title: Dublin Urges a Change in Rule for Ulster
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 12The Irish Government, after lengthy reflection on the violent crisis in the North, called today for abolition of the Government of Northern Ireland in its present form.

title: P.O.W. Ads Facing Controversy
description: That Advertising Council campaign to focus attention on the plight of prisoners of war in Vietnam, awaited since it was announced in May, has become enmeshed in controversy. And the campaignwhich is being prepared on behalf of the National League of Families of American Prisoners and MisingInAction in Southeast Asia and the American Red Crossisn't even ready to go yet.

title: U.S. Presses Japan on Liberalization
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI)  The United States has informed Japan that unless her trade  liberalization policy is speeded up, it will have no alternative but to take its trade problems to the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs in Geneva, American officials said today.

title: Neff Scores Again
Con Edison Is Granted Increase in Gas Rates
description: ALBANY, Aug. 12The Consolidated Edison Company of New York was granted permission today by the Public Service Commission to raise gas rates an additional $14.5million a year.

title: ATLANTIC FARE CUT BELIEVED ASSURED
description: In the wake of one of the most bitterly fought international airfare negotiating sessions in history, most aviation leaders agreed yesterday that one way or another, most of the traveling public would find it much cheaper to fly across the Atlantic next year.

title: BULL RALLY STIRS STOCKPRICE JUMP
description: The stock market had an honesttogoodness rally yesterday with prices advancing across a broad front in the heaviest trading in more than a month.

title: Political Reporter in Brazil Seized by Military Police
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 12D'Alembert Jaccoud, a political reporter and columnist for the Rio de Janeiro newspaper Jornal do Brasil, was arrested this afternoon by military police in his office in Brasilia, the capital.

title: Convicts Return to Cells
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 12 (UPI) Two hundred convicts returned to their cells today after more than 24 hours of rioting and protest against conditions in the Idaho State Prison. Gov. Cecil D. Andrus began selecting a special team to investigate the prison

title: 90Story Fall Kills Woman
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI)A woman plunged 1,000 feet to her death today from the 90th floor of the John Hancock Center, Chicago's tallest skyscraper. The police said they were investigating the death of Mrs. Lorraine Kowalski, a 29yearold widow, as an apparent suicide. The building has 100 stories.

title: ImageMaking on Welfare
description: To the Editor: Governor Rockefeller's latest comments on the new employment requirements for welfare recipients (news story Aug. 4) only serve to underline the political and punitive motivations at the heart of those requirements.

title: Cod and the West
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandFuture strategy of the NATO allies depends on what agreement they can reach about catching the glistening, nutritious codfish abounding in this island's waters. Cod and haddock harvested from the neighboring sea comprise Iceland's greatest natural resource and finance its high standard of living and remarkable culture.

title: 5% of Ford Group Policy Goes to a Black Company
description: DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 12 The Ford Motor Company said today it has directed the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, which handles the $1.8billion Ford employes group life insurance, to give 5 per cent of the coverage, or $90million, to the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company, a blackowned concern in Los Angeles.

title: Currency Step Asked
description: TOKYO, Aug. 12 (Reuters)A group of leading Japanese concerns, including Mitsui & Co., the Mitsubishi Corporation, C. Roll and MarubeniLida, have asked the Japanese Government to Intervene in the forward exchange market to re,store normal trading if it has no intention of revaluing the

title: Most Riders on L.I. R. Think the Service Has Improved
description: Two years ago this month, Governor Rockefeller promised that in 60 days the Long Island Railroad's commuter service would be the finest in the country.

title: Office of Saline Water Is Assailed by Proxmire
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI)Senator William Proxmire said today that he would challenge continuation of Government agency that he said had to hire someone else to justify its existence.

title: Reid Praises Mayor But Will Stay in G.O.P.
description: Representative Ogden R. Reid, a liberal Republican who. has been a consistent backer of Mayor Lindsay, said yesterday that he hoped to work closely with Mr. Lindsay but had no plans to follow the Mayor into the Democratic party.

title: Tombs Fire Burns Inmate
description: A prisoner identified only as John Donaldson was burned over half his body at 11:15 P.M. yesterday in a mattress fire that ignited fresh paint in his 10th floor cell in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men (the Tombs), at 125 White Street, according to the Department of Correction. The victim was taken to Belles Hospital, where he was listed in critical condition.

title: BILL WOULD ERASE ADMISSION QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12  A House subcommittee is considering legislation that would forbid universities to limit their enrollments to students of one sex or to here quotas on the number of men or women students they accept.

title: Bahrain, Barring Federation, to Go It Alone
description: BAHRAIN, Aug. 12Bahrain, a Persian Gulf island group with a population of 200,000, has decided against federation with eight neighboring states and to go it alone, the head of the governing council, Sheik Khalifa bin Sulman alKhalifa, said today.

title: Richey and Mrs. King Gain; Kodes Is Upset by Tanner
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 12 (UPI)Topseeded Cliff Richey and Mrs. Billie Jean King breezed through matches but Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia was upset by Roscoe Tanner, a Stanford junior, today in the national claycourt tennis championships.

title: Dr. Leroy A. Martin, 70, ExHead of Chattanooga U.
description: CHATTANOOGA, Aug. 12Dr. Leroy A. Martin, former president of Tennessee Wesleyan College at Athens, and also former president of the University of Chattanooga, died today. He was 70 years old.

title: LINDSAY'S SWITCH DRAWS REGRETS
description: Governor Rockefeller, Senator Jacob K. Javits and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz  three Republicans who said they had helped John Lindsay throughout his political career  asserted yesterday that the Mayor's switch to the Democratic party would not deter their fight to maintain a broadbased representation in the G.O.P.

title: Esther McCracken Dies; British Playwright, 69
description: LONDON, Aug. 12 (AP)Esther McCracken, the playwright whose Quiet Weekend ran for more than 1,000 performances in the West End here during World War II, died yesterday. She was 69 years old.

title: Owners Accused of Tolerating Prostitution to Harass Tenants
description: Three legislators here warned yesterday that landlords were beginning to allow prostitution to flourish in their buildings as a way of harassing tenants into vacating their apartments so rents could be raised.

title: ROIADAN VICTOR IN JERSEY SHOW
Patrolman Is Suspended
description: Patrolman Richard S. Brown, 32 years old, was suspended without pay yesterday on suspicion of using narcotics. A spokesman for the Police Department said that a urineanalysis showed the patrolman had used cocaine. The patrolman had been on the force 10 years and recently was transferred as a plainclothes man from the Seventh Division in the Bronx to the 11th Division in Brooklyn.

title: Rents Through the Roof
description: Rents on vacant apartments removed from rent controls have soared since the state decontrol law took effect last month. Benjamin Altman, New York City's Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner, calculates the increases at close to 100 per cent across the city's four largest boroughs. Charles Urstadt, State Commissioner of Housing and CommunitY Renewal, puts the increases at about 50 per cent, still a staggering figure.

title: Swaziland's Newest Export: Hot Pants and Maxis
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Now it's hot pants from Swaziland, a pocketsized kingdom in southern Africa.

title: ExGov. Rhodes Drops Libel Suit
description: James A. Rhodes, former Governor of Ohio, dropped his $10million libel suit against Life magazine.

title: Black Legislator to Continue His Tour of South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, Aug. 13, South Africa  Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, a Negro, flew to Capetown from Pretoria today, determined to continue a tour of South Africa that he almost called off yesterday.

title: HEART PACE UPSET DURING MOON WALK
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13  Col. David R. Scott and Lieut. Col. James B. Irwin suffered brief spells of irregular heart rhythm while they were on the moon, probably as a result of extreme fatigue, the chief doctor of the Apollo 15 astronauts said today.

title: In Italy, the Noisy Clackers Have Gone From Nuisance to Recognized Sport
description: ROME, Aug. 13  Clickclack, the noisy game that has been having a boom in Italy, has graduated from the ranks of a national nuisance to that of a recognized sport.

title: LAWYERS ASK NIXON TO RELEASE 3 AIRMEN
description: BOSTON, Aug. 13Lawyers for three Air Force enlisted men imprisoned in Vietnam for refusing to carry arms petitioned President Nixon today to release them pending appeal of their cases.

title: Market Place: Ecological Gives A BearHugging
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 This man is no ordinary shareholder. He has been riding with the Ecological Science Corporation since early 1969. That was rather late to get aboard this now financially troubled pollutioncontrol conglomerate but especially at prices in the area of 28, which proved to, be the high.

title: News Analysis
description: United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr.'s appeal to the public to help track down polluters is widening the rift between New York State and Federal pollution control officials.

title: Mrs. Streit Leads by Stroke
description: WEST VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Aug. 13 (Reuters)Mrs. Marlene Streit of Fonthill, Ontario, led the Canadian women's amateur golf championship today by a stroke after the second round with 76 and 73 for a total of 149.

title: $39,621,257 IN SALES SETS SOTHEBY MARK
description: Sotheby Holdings, Ltd., announced yesterday that, despite the slow pace of the economy, total sales of Sotheby, ParkeBernet in the United States for the period from Sept. 1970 to July, 1971 set a record at $39,621,257.

title: Greek Official's Rebuttal
description: To the Editor: I am deeply distressed and severely offended by Maurice J. Goldbloom's July 22 letter.

title: RESTAURANTS LOAN TO SPUR BLACK CHAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Government approved a nearly $2.4million loan today to help establish a chain of restaurants owned and operated by blacks in Chicago, Cleveland and Washington.

title: MOST GRAINS RISE ON CHICAGO BOARD
UNION DROPS SUIT AGAINST DENTISTS
description: The city's major public employe union and the state dental society halted a court fight yesterday, thus clearing the way for the operation of one of the nation's largest laborsponsored dental healthcare plans.

title: This Little Engine Should
description: MILLERTON, N. Y.As rail passenger service in this country deteriorates, more and more people jump into their automobiles and, with constantly expanding highways, feel little concern for the decline of the railroads.

title: Latin Lands Said to Ease Stand on Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 Diplomatic sources said today that increasing numbers of Latin  American governments were willing to lift the sanetions on Cuba that the Organization of American States imposed in 1964, largely at the instigation of the United States.

title: ExPanther Aide Sentenced
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 13 (UPI)A 33yearold former Black Panther party organizer, Lawrence E. Townsend, was sentenced to three to six years in prison today on two aggravatedassault charges resulting from a shootout with city policemen last Jan. 5. The sentence was imposed by Superior Court Judge William L. Tierney Jr. Townsend was tried on charges of assault with intent to murder two policemen, but was convicted of the lesser aggravatedassault charges.

title: Belfast Says Dublin Seeks Overthrow of Government
BRAZEN BROTHER WINS AT SARATOGA
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 Brazen Brother took the $34,700 Jim Dandy today and created a mild upset in the sevenfurlong sprint for 3yearolds. The field of seven included two exceedingly formidable colts, Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's previously undefeated Marshua's Dancer and the Kosgrove Stable's Bold Reasoning, the owner of seven victories in eight attempts.

title: MRS. JEETER MITCHELL
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 13 Mrs. Anna Driscoll Mitchell, wife of the late Jeeter J. Mitchell and mother of the late James P. Mitchell, former Secretary of Labor, died yesterday at her home. She lived at 217 Shelly Avenue and was 93 years old.

title: Roundup: Cards Hasten Pirate Plunge
description: The St. Louis Cardinals appear determined to make a pennant race in the National League Eastern Division, and the Pittsburgh Pirates, who lead the league in batting and home runs, have been most cooperative. They have stopped hitting and scoring. The Cards, who trailed firstplace Pittsburgh by 11 games three weeks ago, beat the Pirates, 20, last night in Pittsburgh. The victory, coupled with a Cincinnati triumph over Chicago, hurdled St. Louis into second place, six games behind.

title: Rustin and Black English
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Jan Bart, 52, Cantorial Singer Heard on WEVD 30 Years, Dies
description: Jan Bart, tenor, composer and author, who raised funds for Israel Bonds since 1950, died of a kidney ailment Thursday in Prospect Heights Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 52 years Old and lived at 559 Beach 130th Street, Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: An Astronaut Backpack To Be Tested in Space
description: DENVER, Aug. 13 (UPI) A gas rocket backpack, which may hold astronauts as steady as if they were sitting on a rock, will be tested in the first United States orbiting space laboratory in 1973.

title: Cepeda Recovering Here
description: Orlando Cepeda, Atlanta Braves first baseman, was in satisfactory condition after undergoing surgery yesterday to repair his left knee. Cepeda is recovering in St. Vincent's Hospital, where Dr. Anthony Pisani, chief of orthopedic surgery, removed damaged cartilage and repaired stretched liganients.

title: 4 Skippers in Contention For Sunfish Sailing Title
description: SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 13 Four skippers have good chances to capture the Sunfish Class North American seniors championship regatta that started today.

title: Positions Just South of DMZ Shelled by Enemy
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP)  North Vietnamese gunners fired more than 400 rockets and mortar shells into eight South Vietnamese positions along the demilitarized zone yesterday in an upsurge of fighting that has taken the lives of seven United States soldiers in a helicopter, military spokesmen said today.

title: To Improve Medical Care
description: To the Editor: This is a reply to Max W. Fine's July 30 letter To Reform the MedicalCare System.

title: WALTER 0. BENTLEY, RACINGCARDESIGNER
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (Reuters) Walter Owen Bentley, designer of the Bentley sports cars, died tonight in a nursing home in Woking, south of London. He was 83 years old.

title: SALES UP AT FORD, DOWN FOR OTHERS
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13The four American auto makers reported today that their dealers delivered 154,871 United Statestype cars in the Aug. 110 period, up 4 per cent from 148,591 sales a year ago.

title: PRESIDENT'S CURB ON SCHOOL BUSING STIRS CONFUSION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 President Nixon's new policy of restricting the use of busing to achieve school integration has set off a shock wave of reaction among Federal and local officials from Washington to Dallas.

title: U.S. Calls Franchising FastGrowing Industry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP)The franchising industry is one of the nation's fastest growing areas of business, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

title: Students Visit Mrs. Agnew
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) Ten French students called on Mrs. Spiro T. Agnew today and presented her with six red roses. She gave them etchings of the capital.

title: WALLACE BLAKEY
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 13  Wallace Blakey, treasurer and director of the American Systoscope Makers, surgical equipment manufacturers, of Pelham, N. Y., died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 30 Boxwood Drive.

title: SUSPECTED PIMP SLAIN BY POLICE
Preliminary Prospectus Gets Bit of Color
State Takes Title to Land for Jetport
description: Acting swiftly in the wake of a favorable court decision, the state gained legal possession of 8,657 acres of land west of Stewart Airport in Orange County yesterday as the site for a major new jetport.

title: CHAOTIC TRADING WEAKENS DOLLAR
Utica School Board Told to Show Why It Can't Bus Pupils
description: State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist directed the Utica Board of Education yesterday to show cause why it should not implement this fall a plan to bus more than 1,000 pupils to achieve racial balance in the city's 22 elementary schools.

title: POLITICAL ARRESTS REPORTED IN BRAZIL
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 13 Diplomatic informants reported today that a Government roundup of suspected political enemies was apparently quietly under way in Brasilia, the Brazilian capital.

title: In Orbit: Eerie Unreality About It
description: There is a stillness a silence and floating smoothness  about orbiting the moon, particularly when you are there alone, as I was those three days that Dave Scott and Jim Irwin were down at Hadley Base. There is an eerie unreality about it. You are in this big metal vessel, the command module of Apollo 15Endeavour. It was built by men down on earth. Its atmosphere is artificial, an essential oasis in space. There's no noise aboard, no sound. There's no atmosphere outside, and consequently no bumpiness, none of the little jerks you get in airplanes.

title: U.S. Volleyballers Arrive In Cuba for Olympic Trials
description: HAVANA, Aug. 13Twenty United States citizens arrived in Cuba tonight, and not aboard a hijacked commerical airliner. Twelve players on the United States men's volleyball team, three coaches, one doctor, a trainer and three American journalists boarded a Cubana Airlines charter late this afternoon in Kingston, Jamaica, for the 90minute flight.

title: COURT TECHNICALITY IMPEDES I.T.T. PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) A court technicality may temporarily hold up resolution of three Government antitrust actions against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

title: Shubert Alley to Close Tonight for 24 Hours
description: Shubert Alley, the privately owned street that has become the hallmark of the Broadwaytheater area, will be closed to the public from midnight tonight to midnight tomorrow.

title: C. B. Allen, ExAviation Editor Of Herald Tribune, Dies at 75
description: WINCHESTER, Va., Aug. 13 C. B. Allen, former aviation ediitor of The New York Herald Tribune, a pioneer flier and an aerospace executive, died last evening in the Winchester Memorial Hospital. Mr. Allen, who was 75 years old, had suffered a heart attack on Aug. 5. His home was in Moorefield, W. Va.

title: New Curbs Set by Swiss To Stem Influx of Dollars
description: GENEVA, Aug. 13 The Swiss National Bank erected new barriers today against the invasion of Switzerland by dollars seeking to escape a possible loss in value by taking refuge in the Swiss franc.

title: A Student Describes The Slave System
description: The student is probably the most intellectually conditioned animal in existence, and he suspects it least. In the same way that a small child is rewarded with an ice cream cone for being good, an adept student quickly learns to find out what the teacher wants or expects from him in terms of work and intellectual participation (i.e., thinking).

title: Arrests Barred in Suffolk At BirthControl Lectures
description: Federal Judge Edward R. Neaher signed a temporary restraining order yesterday enjoinging the police in Suffolk County from making further arrests of people who bring their minor children to lectures on birth control and contraception.

title: The British Troubles
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 13James Callaghan, the British Labor party's shadow Home Secretary, was commenting the other day on the political context of the violence in the streets of Belfast. If they wish Northern Ireland to live in relative peace, he said, both sides will have to give up something,

title: Nancy Lynch, Reporter, Wed
description: GREENVILLE, Del., Aug. 13  Miss Nancy Elizabeth Lynch and Lawrence Bell Steele 3d, graduates of the University of Delaware, were married this afternoon in the Chapel of the Christ Child at Christ Episcopal Church, Christiana Hundred, by the Rev. Calhoun W. Wick.

title: Mrs. Hagge Ties Mark With 29, Cards 65 for ThreeShot Lead
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)Mrs. Marlene Hagge, with a course recordtying 29 on the front side, shot a sevenunderpar 65 today to take the firstround lead in the $25,000 Buckeye open.

title: A Role in Bank Fraud in Texas Is Laid to Lieutenant Governor
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13 Lieut. Gov. Ben Barnes, whom former President Lyndon B. Johnson has boomed as a future President, has reportedly been linked by Frank W. Sharp, the Houston developer, to a $100million stock fraud case that has the Texas Democratic party in a turmoil.

title: Environmental Chief Silent on 2 U.S. Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  William D. Ruckelshatts, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has failed to comment, as required by law, on the environmental impact of two controversial Federal actions. One is proposed by the Forest Service and the other by the Interior Department.

title: Rockland Split on Centralizing Police
description: CLARKSTOWN, N. Y.There are 17 different police jurisdictions in the 173 square miles of Rockland County and for 39 years a goodly number of its residents have been disputing whether there ought to be a single, countywide force.

title: New Voters Are Told Of Deadline Today For Role in Primary
description: The Board of Elections reminded potential new voters yesterday that they must register and enroll in a party by today to be eligible to vote in the Sept. 14 primaries.

title: The Talk of Berlin
description: BERLIN, Aug. 13Spy novelists and script writers savor it. Tourists swarm to it in buses. Children and frustrated adults scribble messages on it Daredevils still try to climb over or tunnel under it. Here and there West Berliners use it as a garbage dump. But today, 10years after its painful birth, few people mention the Berlin wall in the great city it divides. A deadsubject and a deadening object it is, this tall and broad barrier wriggling northsouth across Berlin like a huge worm that has devoured everything in its path.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Marine Corps has given a contract worth $81.2million to Hawker Siddeley Aviation, Ltd., for continued production of the AV8A verticaltakeoffandlanding jet fighter. The contract to the British concern was let through the Ministry of Aviation Supply.

title: HUGE LEAD TAKEN BY ST. CATHARINES
Officials Differ on Best Way to Halt Lead Poisoning
description: Congress passed a $7.5million appropriation for lead poisoning prevention last week, but the basic question  what constitutes prevention?  remains unsolved among public health practioners.

title: Goodyear Recalling Tires
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 13 (AP) The Goodyear Tire and Rubher Company announced today that it was recalling 9,056 automobile tires from the replacement market because improper fabric was used on a quantity of tires produced in May at its Los Angeles plant. Goodyear said that all of the tires were in the Power Belt line in sizes G7814, 07815 and H7815.

title: Screen: All Alone in L.A.:Charlton Heston Stars in 'The Omega Man'
description: As "The Omega Man" Charlton Heston has a real problem. In 1976 he is apparently the sole normal survivor in the entire Los Angeles area following germ warfare "between Russia and China." Fortified in a penthouse perch and guarding a precious life-saving serum, he roams the city by day. At night, he battles a horde of bloodthirsty, half-human scavengers, got up in Spanish Inquisition robes, growling and waving torches. Wait till you see them.For about a half-hour, the picture coasts along uncertainly. The idea, derived from a Richard Matheson novel, is certainly sound. And Boris Sagal, the director, and his color photographer, Russell Metty  apparently working as a dawn patrol in Los Angeles  have impressively set the stage with some vivid, sweeping panoramas of a lifeless metropolis. Heston is an intelligent actor, but his flinty soliloquies pall, especially with those hooded zombies flapping around him. The film is best in its middle third, when Heston discovers and protects a group of young people in hiding, including a cheerfully cynical girl, played by Rosalind Cash, who perks up the whole thing. Peppered with some sharp, even amusing dialogue, the story temporarily shelves the heavy allegory and slips into good, slam-bang suspense.But it doesn't last. And the climax is as florid and phony as it can be, like a tired Western, with Dracula and company thundering after Hopalong Heston. They nail him down, quite literally, in an embarrassing fade-out carefully suggesting a crucifixion.If only the picture had sustained the brisk vigor introduced by Miss Cash, a doll with no nonsense about her. Even she gets trapped at the end.

title: Farmers Home Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Secretary of Agriculture, Clifford M. Hardin, announced today the appointment of C. William Haines Jr., of Masonville, N. J., as director of the Farmers Home Administration for New Jersey, Maryland and Delaware.

title: WILLIAM COLFORD, C.C.N.Y. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. William E. Colford, professor of Romance languages at City College and former assistant dean of its College of Liberal Arts and Science died Thursday of a heart ailment at his home, 539 Chilton Street, Elizabeth, N. J. His ,age was 63.

title: SelfExamination Must Begin With the Faculty
description: PRINCETONThe recent contribution from Mr. Ottinger was a sad example of faculty backlash. In teaching his composition course, he responded to what he felt to be student current desires by giving them complete freedom. Dispensing with a list of standand topics, he told them to write on anything that interested them. At the end of the term, he was utterly disillusioned. The students hadn't thought, and they hadn't been turned on.

title: It's Hotter Down Below
description: New Yorkers, sweltering in steamy subway cars these torrid days, are so used to hearing that things will be better next yearor the year after or maybe two or three years after thatthat they take with understandable reserve renewed official hope for vast improvements in airconditioned service underground.

title: Americans Ordered to Avoid Saigon Ministry Till Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 13 (UPI)  The United States Embassy has ordered all American officials to stay away from the Vietnamese Government Information Service until Oct. 4. Sources said the reason for the action was that President Nguyen Van Thieu is using the service in his campaign for reelection Oct. 3.

title: PAKISTAN EXPECTS BENGALI ATTACKS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 13 Pakistan's armed forces and police prepared tonight for a threatened wave of attacks by Bengali guerrillas on the 24th anniversary of the independence of Pakistan and India from Britain, which is on Sunday.

title: Opera: Yerma, by VillaLobos, Bows
Lindsay Looks to Coalition For New National Policies
description: Mayor Lindsay said in an interview yesterday that he would offer no immediate solution to the massive problems that beset the nation, and no immediate alternatives to the Nixon Administration policies that he assailed in announcing his conversion on Wednesday from a Republican to a Democrat.

title: Thieu Declares Ky Slanders South Vietnam's Institutions
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 14 (AP)President Nguyen Van Thieu accused Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today of having indulged in groundless accusations and slanderings against national institutions.

title: NANCY TOPF DANCES WITH GIBSON MUSIC
description: Nancy Topf, dancer, and Jon Gibson, musician, offered an improvisational concert of motion and music Thursday evening that had frequent moments of high interest but also a sense of inconclusiveness. The pieces Dance/Flute and Dance/Logdrum/Flute were presented at the American Theater Laboratory under the auspices of Dance Theater Workshop.

title: JAPANESE MOVES ON STEEL VEX U.S.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 13 (Reuters) The United States Government has expressed dissatisfaction with the terms of a Japanese plan for extending voluntary control over Japanese steel exports for three more years starting in 1972, Japanese industry sources said today.

title: Schweitzer's Accuser Is liven 10 Years
description: A 28yearold convicted felon, who has charged that he bribed the secretary of State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer with $15,000 in an attempt to avoid conviction, was sentenced in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday to up to 10 years in prison.

title: New Stock Issues Register a Decline In Slow Turnover
description: The new  issue market where shares of privately held companies recently gone public are traded  declined in slow trading this week, specialists said yesterday.

title: Canada's Surplus of Payments At Midyear Trailed 1970 Pace
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 13 (Canadian Press)  Canada's international balance  of  payments surplus stood at $220million at midyear after a marked contraction in April, May and June, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: I.C.C. TO SEEK LAW ON RAIL SECURITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13The Interstate Commerce Commission, stung by criticism from House investigators that the I.C.C. is a marvelous device to evade Federal securities laws, said today it would seek legislation to tighten regulation of rail and motor company securities.

title: V.F.W. CHIEF EXPECTS P.O.W. RELEASES IN '71
description: DALLAS, Aug. 13 (UPI) Herbert R. Rainwater, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said today he had inside information that some American prisoners of war would be released before Christmas.

title: Bridge: Consideration for Partner    Key in Terms of Technique
Buckpasser Colt Brings $235,000, Spa Sales Mark
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 13 (AP)  A bay colt offered by Nydrie Stud brought $235,000 last night at the FasigTipton yearling sales. The sum was a new high in the 51year history of the Saratoga sales.

title: Russians Send Photos
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 13 (Reuters) Russia's robot moon buggy, Lunokhod 1, robot moon buggy, tures of the lunar terrain back to earth today as it continued exploring the Sea of Rains, Tass, the Soviet press agency, said.

title: DR. HANS H. HECHT, HEART SPECIALIST
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13  Dr. Hans H. Hecht, an authority on the electrophysiological study of heart action, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, on the campus of the University of Chicago. His age was 58.

title: Taipei Authorities Release Teacher Arrested in April
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 13 (AP) A Taiwan teacher, whose arrest last April stirred protests by United States students here, has been released by security authorities, Government spokesmen said today.

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF AS VOLUME DROPS
description: Prices on the American Stock EXchange finished slightly lower yesterday in slackened trading.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Satchel Paige was formally inducted into baseball's Hall of Fame this week, an honor that was simultaneously unearned and beneath him. The Hall of Fame, which is administered by a private foundation outside baseball's immediate jurisdiction, has specific qualifying rules. Paige did not play long enough in the major leagues to qualify, and his accomplishments as a major league pitcher were not, of themselves, overwhelming. On the other hand, his lifetime performance as a pitcher, mostly preserved only in the minds of those who played with him, would rank him far above many of the other men whose bronzed likenesses hang in the lifeless museum at Cooperstown.

title: 100 Flee Floods in Texas
description: HONDO, Tex., Aug. 13 (UPI) Flood waters fed by more than a foot of rain washed out of normally peaceful Texas hill country rivers and creeks today, forcing more than 100 persons from their homes in three townsHondo, D'Hanis and Quihi.

title: Teachers Must Create Conditions for Growth
Chrysler Plans Growth Abroad
description: LAKE OF THE OZARKS, Mo., Aug. 13The Chrysler Corporation expects to build about half its cars and trucks overseas in six to seven years compared with the onethird that are now built in foreign countries.

title: Calculator Prices Set
description: The Japan Machinery Export Association said yesterday hi Tokyo that exporters of desk, top calculators had formed cartel to set minimum prices for exports to the United States and 13 other countries. The Ministry of International Trade and Industry ordered the exporters to fix minimum prices because the United States and other countries had complained of low prices on imported calculators.

title: Poland's Party Dismisses Secretary of Lublin Area
description: WARSAW, Aug. 13 (AP)A regional Communist party leader was dismissed yesterday, bringing the total number of changes in provincial posts to 11 since Edward Gierek came to power in December.

title: RAINEY S. TAYLOR
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., Aug. 13 (AP)Rainey S. Taylor, former State Assemblyman and a lawyer in Middletown and Orange Counties, died today at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: Mexico Frees Relative Of Guatemalan Writer
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 13 The daughterinlaw of Guatemala's Nobel Prizewinning writer, Miguel Angel Asturias, was released here after having been held incommunicado four days by the Mexican security police.

title: U.S. to Resume Training Flights Near a Nuclear Plant
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The Strategic Air Command said today that it would resume lowlevel training flights in the area of a nuclear power plant in Michigan.

title: LEADERS BID CITY SAVE HEALTH UNIT
description: A proposal to save the city's Health Research Council from being abolished because, of budget restrictions was made yesterday by two leaders of the City Council.

title: Oil Nations Seek Share In Assets of Companies
description: VIENNA, Aug. 13 (UPI) The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced today that its member nations will meet next month to demand a share In the assets, profits and management of oil companies drilling in their territories.

title: HOLDUP MAN SLAYS BROOKLYN WOMAN
description: A 21yearold college senior who worked as an interpreter for the Port Authority at Kennedy International Airport was shot and killed early yesterday by one of three robbers in a Brooklyn park while with her boyfriend.

title: FIlION CAPTURES 5 HARNESS RACES
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13 Friday the 13th was in no way unlucky for Herve Filion. The leading North American harness racing driver for the last three years and heading the pack this season, the 31yearold FrenchCanadian, injured in a spill here last Monday night, resumed driving this afternoon at Freehold Raceway in New Jersey, where he won one of two starts.

title: Wallace Tells Local Board to Defy Court and Reopen School
description: TROY, Ala., Aug. 13 (AP) Gov. George C. Wallace ordered an Alabama school board today to disregard the busing plan of a Federal court and reopen a predominantly black school that the court had closed. He then challenged President Nixon to issue a similar order to halt busing nationwide.

title: Mrs. Noble Wins Golf Title
description: WEST CALDWELL, N. J., Aug. 13  Mrs. James Noble of Morris County, beaten last year in the championship round, won the 46th New Jersey women's amateur golf title today with a 6and4 victory over Mrs. Joseph Pistoria of Glen Hurst at the Mountain Ridge Country Club. Mrs. Noble led by six holes at the end of the first 18 over the 5,861yard course.

title: Aluminum Output Cut Set
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third largest aluminum producer, announced yesterday that it would close temporarily a production line at Ravenswood, W. Va., with a capacity of 40,000 tons a year.

title: U. S. Move Protested
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 13 (AP)The Chilean Government delared today that the United States had made an illicit and unacceptable attempt at pressure and interference by holding back credit to Chile unless she pays American copper firms fairly for their expropriated properties here.

title: SIR SHANE LESLIE, 89, BRITISH AUTHOR, DIES
description: LONDON, Aug. 13  Sir Shane Leslie, author and member of the Irish Academy and a cousin of Sit Winston Churchill, died today at Hove, Sussex. His age was 89.

title: Syria and Jordan Accuse Each Other of Renewing Shelling Along Their Tense Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 13 Renewed shelling was reported today along the SyrianJordanian frontier, underscoring Jordan's increased isolation in the Arab world after King Hussein's vigorous suppression of the Palestinian commando movement.

title: UrbanSuburban Competition
description: To the Editor: The July. 27 editorial Urban Plus Suburban Equals? missed the real point of my proposal, for a strong suburban coalition.

title: Output Rises in Week
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13. (AP) Domestic automobile production was up 28,000 units this week and was expected to continue on the increase as the General Motors Corporation joins the other major manufacturers and begin 1972model assembly.

title: Man Is Slain in Restaurant By His Wife as 20 Watch
description: A woman stabbed her husband to death in a restaurant on the Upper West Side last night after a domestic dispute, the police reported. Nearly 20 patrons were present during the incident.

title: Victory Is 5th in RowDobson Wins 12th
description: The Oakland Athletics, with the best record in baseball; opened for the weekend in Yankee Stadium last night, spotted the Yankees two runs, rallied in the late innings and scored a 52 victoryand Vida Blue never moved a muscle.

title: Tranquillity and Terror in a Brooklyn Park
description: Willis Brooks, a 64yearold baker, sat on a bench beneath a maple tree in BedfordStuyvesant's Brower Park yesterday afternoon and watched his 14monthold granddaughter, Adele LeGrande, playing on the asphalt walkway.

title: In Mountains: A Friendly Place
description: To appreciate the beauties of the moon, the grandeur of its peaks and the serenity of its valleys, it helps to be a man who loves mountains.

title: New Process Puts Color In BlackandWhite Film
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 A method of encoding blackandwhite film or videotape makes possible the projection of images in color. The system, which was invented at C.B.S. Laboratories, Stamford, Conn,, is expected to produce full color on television and motion picture screens at the cost of blackandwhite cutting the expense in half. William E. Glenn Jr., general manager of applied physics at the laboratories, was granted Patent 3,598,9.01 this week, assigning it to the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.

title: Veterans Rebuff Army's Plea to Back Pentagon
description: DETROIT, Aug. 13An effort by Army officers has failed to win the support of a major veterans organization for a variety of policies favored by the military.

title: Cultural Blackout
description: The curtailed weekday hours and complete weekend shutdown of the central branch of the New York Public Library create serious hardships for students and other researchers. For many who must hold regular daytime jobs, the austerity schedule decreed for the city's most important research facility will inflict a disastrous handicap.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Pacific Would Sell Stock In Illinois Central to Get Merger
description: The Union Pacific Railroad confirmed yesterday that it had informed the Interstate Commerce Commission that under certain conditions it would dispose of its holding of 2,149,320 shares, or 15 per cent of the common stock, of Illinois Central Industries, Inc.

title: Mrs. Rosenberg Is Married Here
description: Mrs. Rosalind Navin Rosenberg, a Stanford University graduate student, and Gerald Alan Rosenberg, an assistant United States attorney in the Southern District of New York, were married here yesterday at the Ethical Culture Society. Khoren Arisian, a leader of the society, performed the ceremony.

title: Justice Agency Called Indecisive on Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 An internal Justice Department report has charged that the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has no stand ards for dealing with police departments that engage in racial discrimination.

title: MESKILL CRITICAL OF TAX PACKAGE
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 13Gov. Thomas J. Meskill refused today to say whether he intended to accept or reject the increased sales tax program that the Connecticut General Assembly passed yesterday as it voted to repeal the recently enacted income tax.

title: Shall We Gather at the River
description: William Maxwell's Ancestors is a family historymore precisely a fleshing out of a genealogy chart that his cousin gave him long ago and that he immediately put away in a drawer and forgot about for 15 years.

title: Dr. Maria D. Lodyjensky, Retired Internist, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Maria Donskoy Lodyjensky, a retired internist, died Thursday at her home at 502 West 113th Street. Her age was 85.

title: Rookies in Stokes Game
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 13The top college draft choices of three National Basketball Association teams will perform on Tuesday night at Kutsher's Country Club in the Maurice Stokes Memorial basketball game. Dana Lewis of the Philadelphia 76ers will play as will Stan Love of the Baltimore Bullets and Clarence Glover of the Boston Celtics.

title: Appeals Court Sets Hearing On Nashville Busing Plan
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 13 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit has scheduled a hearing for Wednesday on a request to stop the enforcement of a Federal court order to bus 51,000 children in Nashville, to achieve racially balanced schools.

title: Jellyfish Invade Rockaway
description: About 40 persons at Rockaway beaches were treated at firstaid stations yesterday for jellyfish stings. A Parks Department spokesman said bathers in the area between Beach 116th and Beach 96th Streets had been treated.

title: Giffen and 2 Mutual Funds Plan Exchange of Securities
description: Giffen Industries, Inc., said in Miami yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Fund of Funds and the ITT Fund for the mutual funds to exchange debentures of Giffen International, N.V., for a package of cash and Giffen shares. Fund of Funds is managed by Investors Overseas Services, Ltd.

title: Anthony Newley Divorced
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 13 (UPI)Anthony Newley, British actor and singer, was divorced today from Joan Collins, the actress and his wife of eight years. She testified that they had irreconcilable differences. An agreement submitted to the court showed Mr. Newley would pay $1,250 a month for support of their two children, Tara, 7 years old, and Alexander, 5.

title: James V. Stafford, Editor of American Metal Market
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Aug. 13 James V. Stafford, executive editor of American Metal Market, a daily newspaper of the metal industries, died of heart attack at his home, yesterday. He was 57 years old and lived at 10 Georgetown Place.

title: Tarkenton, Back at Giants Practice, Is Prepared to Pay Fine for Absence
Lindsay Smiles His Way Through City
description: Mayor Lindsay continued his campaignstyle tours in the city yesterday, dedicating a prefabricated firehouse in the Bronx, dedicating a new swimming pool in Brooklynand walking four blocks from City Hall to a meeting at the Department of Sanitation, at 125 Worth Street  smiling and shaking hands with passersby all the while.

title: OKKER AND GIMENO ADVANCE IN TENNIS
description: TORONTO, Aug. 13 (AP) Tom Okker of the Netherlands and Andres Gimeno of Spain posted quarterfinalround victories today in the $70.000 Canadian open tennis championships.

title: Entremont In Recital Of Mozart
description: Philippe Entremont plays the piano with an appealing mixture of insouciance and confident charm. When his technical equipment is under reasonable control, as it was in his recital at Philharmonic Hall on Thursday night, one is certain to hear a good deal of pleasant musicmaking.

title: U.S. Retaliating for Foreign Seizures
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 The Nixon Administration has begun to apply a tough new policy of refusing credits to any foreign country that nationalizes American private property without an immediate commitment on acceptable terms of compensation.

title: 7 OIL CONCERNS TOLD TO SHUN PRICE FIXING
description: NEWARK, Aug. 13 (AP) Seven of the nation's leading producers of gasoline have been ordered by a Federal judge not to engage in pricefixing practices.

title: 5 SYRACUSE YOUTHS SEIZED IN BOMBING
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 13  The police arrested five youths here last night, two during a tense confrontation with a crowd during which they drew their guns. The youths were charged in connection with the firebombing of a car on Aug. 2.

title: Al Kooper Shows LowKey Manner In Gaslight Stand
description: Al Kooper, one of the founders of the Blues Project and Blood, Sweat and Tears, is making a rare appearance through Monday at the Gaslight, 152 Bleecker Street.

title: Witness Says He Received Check That ltkin Described as Payoff
description: A prosecution witness testified yesterday that Milton Lip!tins of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation gave him $1,000 check that an earlier witness described as part of payoff.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS VOLUME FAILS
description: The stock market staged an orderly retreat in subdued trading yesterday.

title: The Instructor's Role Is to Guide Students
Mayor's Aides Assay His Chances
description: Mayor Lindsay's top aides are busily surveying his chances as a Democratic Presidential candidate by tuning in on an unofficial national organization of contacts that they have carefully built up in recent years.

title: Mattucci and Miritelle Reinstated at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 13  Eugene Mattucci and John Miritello, horseman whose privileges at Roosevelt Raceway had been withheld since the start of the meeting, were restored to good standing today.

title: Food Is Seized by F.D.A. as Recall Lags
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  The Food and Drug Administration said today that the Bon Vivant Company and the National Canners Association had failed to bring all outstanding stocks of its soups and other products into controlled central assembly points.

title: Police Investigating Charges of Payoffs Made to 16th Division
description: First Deputy Police Commissioner William H. T. Smith said yesterday that, contrary to an earlier official statement, the Police Department was investigating charges made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation about a $1,500amonth payoff to the police.

title: McGovern Urges Spending Rise Of $10Billion to Reduce Jobless
description: DALLAS, Aug. 13  Senator George McGovern of South Dakota proposed today a $10billion increase in Federal spending over the next year in an effort to bring the rate of unemployment down to 4.5 per cent by the end of 1972.

title: Soviet Endorses Treaty With India
Man in the News
description: The highestranking churchman to be singled out by the South African Government as an example to ecclesiastical peers who might be tempted to protest the system of apartheid too much is a dour and donnish bachelor who got a good deal of his early education into the ways of the world as a hobo. In fact, it was during this period in his life that the Very Rev. Gonville Aubie ffrenchBeytagh, the Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, who is on trial in Pretoria this week on charges of plotting the violent overthrow of the Government, decided to become a priest.

title: U.S. Calls on Egypt and Israel To Avoid Jeopardizing Truce
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  The State Department called on Egypt and Israel today to avoid taking any actionincluding the setting of deadlinesthat would jeopardize the ceasefire that has prevailed along the Suez Canal for the last year.

title: Rumanian Stand Assailed
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 13A leading Soviet foreign affairs journal today attacked Rumania's refusal to join the rest of the Soviet bloc in condemning China's policies.

title: Atlantic Fare Is Reduced By Irish National Airline
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 13 (Reuters)  Irish International Airlines today announced sharp fare cuts on flights between North American and Ireland provided that tickets were purchased three months in advance.

title: THANT AGAIN ASKS AID TO PAKISTANIS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 13 Secretary General Thant reiterated today that there was still an urgent need for more cash donationsas distinguished from donations of suppliesto aid the victims of the recent fighting in East Pakistan and the cyclone there last November.

title: Stuttering in Steel
description: By outright postponement or hidden discounts, the major steel companies are holding off some of the price increases they announced immediately after signing the most costly wage agreement in their history last week. On the face of it, any slowdown in higher prices for this most basic of industrial commodities would seem to be good news for an inflationgroggy economyespecially when the steel involved is the kind that goes into automobiles, refrigerators and other heavy household appliances.

title: Alexander's Agrees to Curtail Sale of Imported Men's Suits
description: Alexander's, Inc., agreed yesterday to expand the sale of men's suits made by unionized American manufacturers and to curtail sales of imported suits.

title: The School Busing Controversy
Letters to the Editor
