description: To the Editor: A member of the bar for 23 years reads with dismayand disgustthe letter of Lois Smallwood in your Aug. 7 issue, How Good the U.S. Lawyer?

title: Reformist Montagnard Candidate for Assembly Says Vietnamese Must Pay
description: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 10When Dinh Nai was a boy, typhoid was known among the Hre villagers in their dialect as Illness Lasting Long Time. There was no confusion about cholera because its victims died with their fingers curled or bent. Men hunted elephants with poison arrows. Children, to be healthy, wore no clothes.

title: German Rightists Stage Protest March to Wall
description: BERLIN, Aug. 13 (Reuters)  About 500 members of rightwing organizations, including the National Democratic party, marched to the Berlin wall tonight to protest its construction 10 years ago.

title: Elting C. Niver, 70, Dies; Former Insurance Official
description: Elting C. Niver, an insurance man who handled many major claims, among them those growing out of the crash of an Army bomber into the Empire State Building in 1945, died of a heart attack in a doctor's office on Thursday. He was 70 years old and lived at 180 Riverside Drive.

title: TRANSFER REJECTED BY U.S. INDIAN AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 William H. Veeder, an outspoken critic of the Govern ment's treatment of Indians, rejected today his transfer by the Bureau of Indian Affairs from Washington to Arizona.

title: Injunction Is Sought
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 13 (AP) A civil rights lawyer charged in a Federal court suit filed today that Governor Wallace's order to the Jefferson County school board would sabotage a desegregation plan.

title: 49ER RALLY TIES DOLPHINS, 1717
description: MIAMI, Aug. 13 (AP)Steve Spurrier hit Jerry Simmons with a 12yard touchdown pass with 2 minutes 13 seconds to go tonight and the San Francisco 49ers salvaged a 1717 tie with the Miami Dolphins in a National Football League exhibition game.

title: MITCHELL DROPS KENT STATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13  Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today that no Federal grand jury would be empaneled to investigate the fatal shooting of four Kent State University students by Ohio National Guardsmen in May, 1970.

title: U.S. Judge Bars Rail Union From North Western Strike
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 13 (UPI) United States District Judge Joseph Sam Perry enjoined the United Transportation Union today from striking against the Chicago & North Western Railway in a longstanding dispute over the size of operating rews.

title: Channel 13 Gets Grant
description: Channel 13 has received a grant of $125,000 from the Helena Rubinstein Foundation for a second season of its weekly series Flow Do Your Children Grow? with Eda LeShan, a family counselor, as host. The grant will be used for the production or 14 halfhour programs in color, which will be televised on New York's noncommercial station beginning Oct. 24.

title: Protest on Brooklyn Heights Welfare Hotels Rising
NATO Headquarters Is Leaving Malta
Antiques: On Wedgwood
description: Take Wedgwood test by visiting the amazingly comprehensive exhibition of England's best known pottery organized by JoAnne Blum at the Antiques Center of America, 415 East 53d Street.

title: Pact Said to Bury India's Nonalignment
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 13  Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko was hack in Moscow today after having resurrected Indian morale and burying, in the view of most observers, India's cherished policy of nonalignment.

title: HUNGARY REPORTS CHOU PLAN TO TOUR BALKANS IN FALL
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 13Hungary reported today that Premier Chou Enlai of China would visit Albania, Yugoslavia and Rumania this fall to try to establish an anti Soviet. group in the Balkans.

title: Republican Follows Lindsay
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 13Igor Sikorsky Jr., son of the developer of the helicopter, announced today that he was following the example of Mayor Lindsay of New York and was resigning from the Republican party to become a Democrat. Mr. Sikorsky, a lawyer and a Republican for 21 years, said that the posture of both the state and national Republican party organizations is out of step in the area of minority rights, civil rights and dissent.

title: Princess Anne On Palace Life
description: LONDON, Aug. 13 (UPI) Life in Buckingham Palace is not all that fairy tales make it out to be. At Limes it can be quite lonely.

title: U.S. Freight Co. Increases Earnings
description: The United States Freight Company recovered from depressed earnings last year, when forwarding operations were impaired by Teamster strikes, the company reported yesterday for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

title: John Struckell, Managed Atlantic City Radio Station
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 13 (AP)  John G. Struckell, vice president and general manager of radio station WFPG, died yesterday while working at the station's transmission site at Absecon. He was 50 years old.

title: Director Acquitted on Charge Of Ignoring Patrolman's Order
description: Alan Schneider, the Broadway director who has accused a patrolman of beating him, won an acquittal yesterday on a charge of obstructing government administration.

title: Urich Joins Bills Staff
description: DEKALB, Ill., Aug. 13 (UPI) Dod Urich resigned today as football coach at Northern Illinois to join the Buffalo Bills of the National Football League as an assistant coach. Bob Brigham, Northern Illinois athletic director, said Jerry Ippoliti would replace Urich.

title: 132 Out at Space Center
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)The Manned Spacecraft Center announced today that it would lay off 132 civil service employes because of manpower reductions ordered throughout the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Sixtynine more workers were told they would be reassigned or placed in jobs of lower grade. The reduction cut the center's Government work force to about 4,000.

title: JEROME A. SANDERS
description: Jerome A. Sanders, longtime New York newspaper advertising man, died on Sunday in Denver, where he had lived for the last several years. He was 77 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street here and in Denver.

title: Richey, Graebner Advance
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 13 (UPI) Cliff Richey, Zeljko Franulovic and Clark Graebner, the three topseeded players, advanced to the semifinals of men's singles today in the national clay court tennis championships. Jaime Fillol of Chile, Ithe seventhseeded player, occupied the other bracket. Richey, the defending champion and topseeded player, defeated Eddie Dibbs of Miami, 64, 63. Secondseeded Franulovic of Yugoslavia ousted Patrico Cornejo of Chile, 67, 62, 63.

title: A Fair Statement
description: KENT, Ohio, Aug. 13 (UPI)Dr. Robert I. White, the president of Kent State University, and Col. Joseph McCann, an Ohio National Guard spokesman, today characterized Mr. Mitchell's decision as acceptable and as a fair statement.

title: What About Yourself, Mr. Ottinger?
description: COLUMBIA, MO.When a lover is spurned by his love, all the brightness is taken away and disillusionment sets in. I sense that that is what has happened to you. I can't help but feel that you really do love those halfformed, recalcitrant, and ignorant young minds.

title: TENNESSEAN MEETS ON BERRIGANS CASE
description: DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 13 Representative William R. Anderson, Democrat of Tennessee, visited the Federal Correctional Institution here today to urge quick action on the hunger strike that began last Friday in a protest involving the Berrigan brothers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: JAEGER DEFENDS PLAN TO MERGE
description: The management of the Jaeger Machine Company, in a letter to shareholders yesterday, urged them to vote for the proposed merger of Jaeger into the Danmont Corporation.

title: FOUR GRANDMASTERS GAIN CHESS SWEEP
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 13 After five of the 12 rounds of the United States Open Chess Championship, four grandmasters continued to sweep all opposition, holding the lead with perfect scores of five points each.

title: HOUSE STUDY BRINGS REMOVAL OF MARINE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13A Marine captain has been reilieved of his duties and an electronics company has been blacklisted as a result of a report issued earlier this week by the investigating subcommittee of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: George Johnson and Schlee Lead at 136
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 13 George Johnson, one of the seven black professionals who play regularly on the golf tour, caught up with John Schlee today and shared the lead after 36 holes in the $165,000 Massachusetts Classic at 136. Their margin was one stroke.

title: Upstate G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (AP) The Defense Department announced today that Specialist 4 Robert D. Severson, a soldier from Silver Springs in western New York, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Democracy in American Samoa
description: Gov. John Haydon Jr. of American Samoa ordered the deportation early this year of the editor of a local newspaper that had been critical of his administration. After Associate Justice Joseph W. Goss of the High Court of American Samoa had stayed the deportation order, the judge, who has also been at odds with the Governor, was abruptly transferred by the Interior Department to a Washington assignment.

title: Setback Drops New Yorkers to 500 Mark
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13When the Mets arrived in San Francisco today, they heard that the Giants had been valiantly trying to flee from first place. But when they got to Candlestick Park tonight they were determined not to aid the escape and didn't. They lost, 73.

title: SmithvilleA Place to Shop, Dine and Glimpse an Earlier Era
description: SMITHVILLE, N. J.The air was clear and sparkling, a hint of a breeze cutting the heat of the bright summer sun. Not a Smithville day, according to Ethel Noyes who, with her husband, Fred, founded the village as it now exists back in the early nineteenfifties.

title: Parents Deplore Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI)  The parents of the four slain students said today that they had suffered a loss of faith in our Government because of Mr. Mitchell's decision.

title: Bruised Kidney Will Prevent Jets Maynard From Facing Raiders Tonight
description: Because of a bruised kidney, Don Maynard probably won't play for the New York Jets against the Raiders in the exhibition game at Oakland, Calif., tonight. The 34yearold wide receiver hopes to be ready for the Giants next Sunday at the Yale Bowl.

title: GAF Sets Price Rises
description: GAF, Inc., said yesterday it would raise prices, effective Sept. 13, by 6 per cent on asphalt roofing materials and by 9 per cent on roofing felt. GAF cited rising costs of materials and services, as well as capital outlays for pollutioncontrol equipment.

title: Stamps
description: DRUG Prevention Week is sched uled for October 39 throughout America. Excepting those who profit from the illicit manufac ture and sales of drugs to the detriment of thousands, Americans will hail the observation.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: The key to McCabe & Mrs. Miller is not its studied avoidance of con vention, as Peter Schjeldahl claims in McCabe & Mrs. Miller: A SneakyGreat Movie. In fact, director Robert Altman confronts, in corporates, and reforms scores of Hollywood Western conventions in his most re cent, agonizingly beautiful movie.

title: Recordings
description: BORODIN'S Prince Igor is, by all accounts, sec ond only to Mussorg sky's Boris Godunov in popularity with the Rus sian people. Yet outside of Russia, it is hardly known at all except for the much played Polovtsian dances. This may seem surprising for an opera that is as famous as Prince Igor. But remem bering the New York City Opera's recent production admittedly inadequateand listening to the recent full length recording of the work by the Bolshoi Theater on Angel/Melodiya (four disks), it is possible to under stand why it has found no place in the repertory of West European and Ameri can opera houses.

title: Carole Lane Engaged To Jonathan Besdine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Lane of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Carole Susan Lane, to Jonathan Besdine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Bes dine of Forest Hills Gardens and Hollywood Fla. The wedding will take place in November.

title: The Family
description: IN a Street in New York City, 10 wo men rub their hands rhythmically over their large, pregnant bellies while their husbands stare at stop watches, encouragingly giving hand signals. The couples are in training for natural childbirth with Mrs. Elizabeth Bing, who has spread the gospel in this country that male and female should share in the dramatic event of the birth of their child. Fifty to sixty new couples sign up for this course a month. What are they all doing? What are they doing several months later, walking around in their nursing bras, buying mobiles that swing from crib tops and potties with musical boxes and on and on in to a future radically different from that of their childless past? Don't they know, this army of young peo ple pushing strollers through the park, that they are behaving in a reactionary way? The nuclear family is not now a thing of fashion.

title: Dr. James Grace Jr., 48, Dead; A Leading Cancer Researcher
description: NEWINGTON, Conn., Aug. 14Dr. James Thomas Grace Jr., a surgeon who became one of the nation's leading cancer researchers after he saw his own son die of leukemia, died yesterday in the Veterans Ad ministration Hospital here. His age was 48.

title: Lava Spurts 200 Feet From Hawaii Volcano
description: HILA, Hawaii, Aug. 14 (UPI)Ten fountains of fire spurted lava 200 feet in the air today in a spectacular eruption of Kilauea Volcano, the first from its summit in 17 years.

title: Cooperation Among the Contenders Is Sought by Party Chairman
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14For the first time, the Democratic party has laid down a compre hensive political plan covering the year before its Presidential candidate is chosen. The plan is aimed at improving the can didate's election prospects.

title: 2ARENA SCHEDULE PREPARED BY NETS
description: The New York Nets will open their 197172 American Basketball Association season on Friday, Oct. 15, against the Pittsburgh Condors at Island Garden in West Hempstead, L.I.

title: Science
description: There is as good fish in the sea as ever came out of it, wrote Sir Walter Scott, provid ing solace to generations of dis appointed lovers. But once in a while the fish that come out of the sea are not so good  in fact, th0 may be laden with poison.

title: Discontent on Trade
description: With a trade deficit likely to reach $1billion to $1.5 billion by the end of the year, the United. States will be facing a winter of dis content, over trade policy darkened by shadows of dol lar devaluation and import restrictions.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent settlements reached through poweroriented collective bar gaining in the telephone, steel and railroad industries clearly demonstrate that if the consumer is to be protected we must find a better way to handle our labor problems. Many people rec ognize this fact, and a number of economists as well as a group of Re publican Senators have suggested that wage price controls by the Govern ment would be superior to the present type of bargaining in certain indus tries. However, the Administration seems to be oppcised to using such controls.

title: 2 SOLING CROWNS AT STAKE NEARBY
description: The finkeeled Soling, a sloop that will be a new entry when the sailing phases of the 1972 Olympics are staged at Kiel, Germany, will be spot lighted on Long Island Sound next month in two champion ship regattas.

title: LI FOLK CONCERT IS A BIG SUCCESS
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 14 No one, least of all the or ganizer of Huntington's first Folk Festival last summer, expected more than 3,000 people to turn up for this year's event in Heckscher State Park.

title: New Complex Highlights The 2 Worlds of Newark
description: NEWARK, Aug. 14  When the new $50million Gateway Center, a massive downtown office and hotel complex, is completed here next Christmas, a covered glass bridge will link it to Penn Station so commut ers can get to their offices without having to set foot in the streets.

title: Hannah P. Mellicker Is Engaged
description: DENVER, Aug. 14The en gagement of Miss Hannah Patricia Mellicker to Des mond Thomas Barry Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rice Mellicker, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry of Bronxville, N. Y., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Father Fox's Pennyrhymes
description: Right now I feel that Father Fox and his pennyrhymes ought to be admitted into the select company of other great foxes. I think of Aesop, of Burgess's Reddy Fox and Brer Fox, Reynard and Foxywoxy from HennyPenny and The Fox Went Out on a Chilly Night by Peter Spier, for example. Maybe I'm a little impulsive; things haven't been too grand in children's books lately.

title: 12 Federal Cars Operate On Liquefied Natural Gas
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14  The tiation's largest fleet of motor vehicles operating on liquefied natural gas is expected to be on the road within two months as part of a Government ex periment with lowpolluting fuels.

title: BASES IN U.S. FACE G.I. DRUG PROBLEM
description: Military officials across the nation, asked about the drug problem on domestic installa tions, have assessed it in terms that recall the old riddle about the bottle: Is it halffull or halfempty?

title: A person, not a persona
description: Hildegard Knef has published her autobiography under her real name, even in America where her real name is almost unknown. I think she was right to do so. Under her American name, she was never really big star; in spite of Silk Stockings and Decision Before Dawn, few Americans are going to be consumed with curiosity about Hildegarde Neff. Anyway, in spite of occasional references to Marlene and Tyrone and Cole and a few others, this is not a book of Holly woodBroadway gossip. It does not recount the adventures of a persona, a public image made up and project ed to meet the demands of celebrity hood; it really seems to have been written by and about the autobiog rapher's real self. This is Knef's book; Neff is only a minor charac ter in it.

title: BROWNE TIES EVANS FOR U.S. CHESS LEAD
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 14 Walter Browne of Australia and Larry Evans of Reno took the lead in the sixth round of the United States open chess cham pionship yesterday with perfect scores of 60.

title: HOLLIS STACY WINS JUNIOR GOLF AGAIN
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 14 (UPI)Hollis Stacy of Savan nah, Ga., became the first three time winner in the history of the United States Golf Associa tion junior girls championship today when she sank a 10foot birdie putt on the 19th hole to beat Amy Alcott of Los Angeles.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Blue to Give Yankee Turnstiles A Run for Their Money Today
description: An autographed baseball was delivered to Michael Burke at Yankee Stadium before yesterday's game, and the president of the New York Yankees read the in scription with surprise and delight: To Mike from Vida Blue.

title: Keeping The African Experiene A ricani
description: AMONG the millions of visitors to America's national parks four years ago were 15 citizens of Tanzania, trustees of that East African country's national park system. They had flown halfway around the world to see how United States parks worked. They visited two worldfamous areas, Yellowstone and Yosemite, during the peak tourist season, in midsummer, and they came home inspiredto pro tect their own parks from similar on slaughts. The African visitors were ap palled by the crush of people and cars and the spread of litter they had encountered. Besides, they wondered, where were the animals?

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I have long hair, and I have just come back from touring the national parks out West. So I got a lot out of Range War at Generation Gap and thought it was unbiased. My question is: Does anyone know what we get for the percentage of our salaries that goes to the Federal Gov ernment? I thought it helped to build interstate highways, but half of them are toll roads. Then I thought some of it might go to the national parks, but you have to pay to get in and pay again to stay overnight. Then I thought some of it might go to people like the Indians, but they are all starving.

title: Grace Butler Attended by 7 At Her Nuptials
description: RYE, N.Y., Aug. 14Miss Grace Tucker Butler, daugh ter of Jonathan Fairchild Butler and the late Mrs. Polly Puntnam Butler, was married here this afternoon, to Jotham Johnson 5th, son of Mrs. Johnson 4th of New York and Sodus Point, N.Y., and the late Professor John son.

title: B.S. Hall Is Fiance Of Nan Lowlicht
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Martin Low licht have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Nan Leslie Lowlicht, to Benjamin Staples Hall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Leicester Hall of Huntington.

title: Miss Evert Triumphs
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 (AP) Chris Evert of Fort Lauder dale, Fla., the No. 1seeded player, won the United States Girls 18andunder Grass Court tennis championship today de feating Jane Newberry of La Jolla, Calif., 61, 63 at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

title: Monoxide Test Here Shows An Excess in 42% of Cars
description: Tests of 878 cars in the Bronx and Staten Island showed that 376or 42.8 per cent  were emitting excessive amounts of carbon monoxide in their exhausts, the Tubercu losis and Respiratory Disease Association of New York re ported last week.

title: CITY U. PROGRAM A MODEL FOR U.S.
description: An experi Mental City Univer Sity program designed to de velop a desire for learning among high school dropouts in poverty areas has become a Model for study by other cities.

title: Baylor to Play Final Season
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Aug. 14 (UPI)  Elgin Baylor said today he would call it quits after his 13th National Basketball Asso ciation season. Baylor, who will celebrate his 37th birthday be fore the Los Angeles Lakers start practice Sept. 17, played in, only two games last season. He underwent surgery Dec. 2 for a torn Achilles tendon.

title: French Hydrogen Bomb Exploded Over Pacific
description: PARIS, Aug. 14 (AP)An experimental hydrogen bomb with the power of one mil lion tons of TNT was deton ated today over the lagoon of Mururoa Atoll in the French Pacific islands, the French Defense Ministry an nounced.

title: Residents in Williamsburg Fighting for Traffic Light
description: For years there has been smoldering resentment in the Williamsburg section of Brook lyn because many of the resi dents there feel that they are being shortchanged by the city.

title: Filion Scores at Freehold With a Consecutive Double
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 14 Herve Filion, who had won five consecutive races at Roose velt Raceway last night, posted a consecutive double today at Freehold Raceway.

title: 3 ARE SUSPENDED IN MIGRANT CASE
description: LYONS, N. Y., Aug. 14 Three officials of a rural health program have been suspended after filing a suit charging that 54 migrant labor camps had been given operating permits by the state although the camps allegedly failed to meet state health standards.

title: Rita Willsey Bride Of William Neher
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14  Miss Rita Claire Will sey was married here this afternoon to William Kenneth Neher.

title: The Last Word: An Overlooked Novel
description: Edmund Wilson on, one of life's pleasures: There are few things I enjoy so much as talking to people about books which I have read and they haven't, and making them wish they had preferably a book that is hard to get or in a, language that they do not know. Earlier this summer there appeared an agreeable book called Rediscoveries (Crown. Cloth, $7.50. Paper, $2.95), edited by David Madden, who enlisted 27 novelists to write about their favorite neglected works of fiction. Besides full length essays such as Robert Penn Warren's on Andrew Lytle's The Long Night, Joyce Carol Oates on Harriette Arnow's The Dollmaker, and Evart S. Connell Jr. on Janet Lewis's The Wife of Martin Guerre, the book has a valuable checklist of 210 other ignored or outoffashion novels and shortstory collections worth investigating.

title: Fire Kills 2 Boys in Harlem Despite Efforts of Mother
description: Two young brothers were killed in a fire in their Harlem apartment despite their moth er's efforts to save them.

title: Historical Sites in Brooklyn Hidden by Neglect of Time
description: Under the east tower of the Brooklyn Bridge, on an abandoned and rotting fire boat pier that is veiled by a chainlink fence, there is a kneehigh rock with a bronze plaque on it.

title: RETURN IS $27.40
description: SARATOGA SPRING, Aug. 14 Lauries Dancer, a Canadian campaigner with only one pre vious appearance on the local track, registered a surprise vic tory in the $58,800 Alabama Stakes today, before a near record crowd of 28,345.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: OAKFIELD, Nova Scotia, Aug. 14 (AP)Dick Siderowf of Easton, Conn., won the Ca nadian amateur golf champion ship today by sinking a 20foot birdie putt on the first hole of a suddendeath playoff.

title: Chess
description: THE 1971 champion of the Nether lands is 27 years old international master Hans Ree, who won out on tiebreaking points over grand master Jan Hein Donner atfer each had scored 7 points in the twelve man event. This is Ree's third championship victory (he won the title in 1967 and 1969) and firmly establishes him as one of Holland's two leading playersDon ner is of course the othereven though he has achieved little success thus far in international competition. (In 1966 he won a small but strong tournament at Ter Apel, the Netherlands ahead of Bent Larsen, but that has been his sole international success to date.)

title: JoEllen Dicker Wed to Lawyer
description: Miss JoEllen Dicker, who will teach science this fall at the Chapin School here, was married yesterday eve ning to Dennis Steven Malen, a lawyer with Dreyer & Traub.

title: AllAmerican Family Named
description: LEHIGH ACRES, Fla., Aug. 14 (AP)The AllAmerican family award was won today by an Oklahoma family whose motto is togetherness and communication  Edmond Synar, 46 years old; his wife, Virginia Ann, 43, and their three children were chosen by a panel of judges as America's most representative family. Mr. Synar is a rancher and real estate broker in Muskogree. The family won a $30,000 condomi nium here, a 1972 car, savings bonds and a 110volume library.

title: PROSOVIET PLOT IN SANA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 14 Seven Yemeni Army officers trained in the Soviet Union were arrested in Sana, the capi tal of Yemen, earlier this month in connection with what is be lieved to have been a proSoviet plot to overthrow the Yemeni government, American intelli gence sources said today.

title: Gregory C. Bangs, an Analyst Fiancee of Jean R. Middendorf
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Aug 14 The engagement of Miss Jean Reynolds Middendorf to Gregory Charles Banus, of Topsfield, Mass., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Ken nedy Boone Middendorf of Laurel Hollow. Mr. Banus is a son of Dr. Mario Banus, a senior staff member of Lin coln Laboratories, Massachu setts Institute of Technology and the late Mrs. Banus.

title: Busing for Desegregation to Affect 350,000 Pupils in the South
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 14Despite politics and protest, thousands of Southern children will be riding buses to integrated schools when classes resume later this month.

title: Ecology
description: A pleasant, useful manual of the workings and problems of environ ment. Interesting descriptions of land, air, water, etc., and recommen dations on ways young people can help restore some of the things we have taken for granted and almost destroyed. A long list of suggested reading and an equally long list of environmentminded organizations make an appropriate wrapup.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN his review of the exhibit, Eight AfroAmerican Artists, at the Rath Museum in Geneva, Switzerland, David Shirey presents clear evidence that he is sorely remiss in his knowl edge of American art history (i.e., his reference to Jasper Francis Cropsey as a black artist!) and black people.

title: Pete's Ruler, Great Career Win Del Mar CoFeatures
description: DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 14 (UPI)Pete's Ruler and Great Career captured the $15,000 added divisions of the La Jolla mile, traditional tuneup for the rich Del Mar Derby today.

title: Mary Bowne Wed To Michael Brandt
description: BAYVILLE, LI., Aug. 14 Miss Mary Elisabeth Bowne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney B. Bowne Jr. of Bay vile and Harbour Island, Eleuthera, the Bahamas, and Michael Brandt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Brandt of Roslyn Heights, were mar ried here today at the Bowne family home. Justice Robert C. Meade of the State Su preme Court, performed the ceremony.

title: Paul Brandow to Wed Miss Goldstein
description: SCARSDALE, Y., Aug. 14Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Goldstein have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Gene Goldstein, to Paul Wendell Brandow. He is the son of Mrs. and Mrs. Wendell Bran dow of Pelham Manor.

title: Lifeboat Station Seized
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug, 14 (AP) Members of the American In dian Movement Beized an abandoned Coast Guard lifeboat station in Milwaukee early to day to protest the plight of the urban Indian.

title: Hawaii Hard Hit as Dock Strike On Coast Halts Normal Trade
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 14Ha waii's sugar and pineapple plan tations, which produce crops worth $400million a year, are scrambling for chartered ships to move cargo backlogged here by the West Coast shipping strike.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There are two happy byproducts of the decision of The Times to publish the Pentagon papers: the action of the Kennedy Presidential Library In greatly expanding access to scholars and President Nixon's request for the declassification of the bulk of World War II documents.

title: Yellowstone Policy Called Peril to Grizzly
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The grizzly bears of Yellowstone National Park are in danger of being eliminated by the very policy that is designed to pro tect them, according to two prominent wildlife biologists.

title: O'LEARYS CAPTURE MG CLUB'S RALLY
description: For the second consecutive year the husbandandwife team of John and Renee O'Leary of Newark, Del., has won the International 1000 Rally of the MG Car Club. The couple, driving a Triumph Stag, totaled only 153 penalty points in four days of driving through upstate New York and sections of Canada and New England.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Harry J. Noznesky is not one to back out of a fight. Thus, when the Federal Trade Commission recently opposed the $68.1million merger of his company, the General Battery Corporation, into TRW, Inc., it came as no surprise that he was only beginning to battle.

title: Dart Hanover Wins U.S. Trotting Title
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 14 Dart Hanover, a 5yearold Americanbred and foreign owned bay son of Hoot Mon and Delicia Hanover, captured the $50,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. He thus gained a berth in next Satur day's $125,000 International Trot and set off a string of complications.

title: Chrysler Adds Litter Bags
description: LAKE OF THE OZARKS, Mo. Aug. 14 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that litter bags would be Lanclard on all its 1972 cars. The bags made of heavygauge plastic and capable of holding up to two quarts, hang from the in strument panel.

title: Hammer Throw Mark Set
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) Tom Miller of Syracuse set a meet record today in the Na tional junior track and field championships by tossing the hammer 179 feet 4 inches. The previous mark was 1722.

title: Staten Islander Elected
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 14 (AP) Jerry Cohen of Staten Island, N.Y., was elected national com mander of the Jewish War Vet erans of the U.S.A. tonight. Mr. Cohen, who was decorated for his service with the Navy during World War II, led the fight for a resolution adopted yesterday urging withdrawal from Vietnam by Dec. 31. The group's national convention ended tonight.

title: Horse Show News
description: This has been a frustrat ing summer for the United States Equestrian Teamall because of the epidemic of Venezuelan Equine Enceph alomyelitis (VEE).

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON Jim is 26 tall, bright, lanky, trim of hail neatly dressed and a deserte from the United States Army.

title: Sally Fleeson Kansas Bride
description: KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 14Miss Sally Lynn Flee son, daughter of Col. George Seward Fleeson, U.S.A., and Mrs. Fleeson, of Arlington, Va., and Donald Hayden Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dean H. Fisher of Kansas City, were married here this afternoon.

title: Players Shun Basketball Exhibitions
description: In view of what happened to Joe Namath in a preseason game against the Detroit Lions last Saturday night in Tampa, National Basketball Associa tion players are becoming in creasingly skeptical of playing exhibition games and may take a harder line in the negotia tions currently under way with the owners.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally Jr., in a recent interview in Busi ness Week magazine, observed that the United States should get tough with Latin Ameri can countries that expropriate American holdings because, as he put it, We don't have any friends there anyway.

title: Lightship Going to War
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Coast Guard light ship San Francisco, a mariner's beacon off the Golden Gate Bridge for 42 years until last April, has been pulled out of a short retirement for war duty in Vietnam. The 133foot, bath tublike vessel was towed out of the Hunters Point naval shipyard yesterday bound for Pearl Harbor. She will be towed to the Philippines to be out fitted for war duty.

title: Nixon Discusses Budget
description: THURMONT, Md., Aug. 14 (UPI)President Nixon, met with: four top aides at his mountain retreat at Camp David today to discuss the eco nomy and the next Federal bud get. Joining Mr. Nixon for the sessions were Treasury Secre tary John Connally; Dr. Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; Dr. Paul W. McCracken, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and George P. Shulz, director of the Office of Man agment and Budget.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Some erroneous impressions were given in the article on hay fever (Travel section, July 18). The terminology king of allergies was appa rently coined by the author, Dan Carlinsky: it is not used in allergy circles. If there is any king of allergic dis eases, it is obviously asthma. Asthma affects 8,000,000 peo ple in the United States, about half of whom are children, It is generally accepted that up wards of 70 per cent of asth ma is allergic in nature. Asth ma is a lifethreatening dis ease and causes approximately 5,000 deaths a year. Most al lergists will agree, however, that untreated hay fever may lead to asthma problems later in life. We also regret the im pression that the only thing one can do about hay fever is to leave the home area, For many years allergists have been successfully desensitiz ing many patients to the point where they can live comfort ably and normally during the season. And, it should be pointed out, the ragweed sea son of Aug. 15 to the first frost applies principally to the Northeast, or east of the MisUnless definitive diagnostic tests are made by a compe tent physician, preferably an allergist, to determine the particular plant pollen or mold spores causing the reaction, one can go into areas free of ragweed pollen only to dis cover that it is something else, or something in addition to ragweed, that is causing the problem. Mr. Carlinsky did not indicate the wide vari ety of trees, plants and grass es that cause allergic prob lems. Also omitted from the article was the basic fact that allergy is a disturbance of the body's defense mechanism known as the immune system. This means that the allergic individual can become sensi tized to many other environ mental substances affecting various organs. Treatment gives protection.

title: Herbicides: Should We Use Them Or Not?
description: WHAT weedkillers can I safely use around my home? In the present atmosphere of eco logical concern, this is a ques tion properly asked by gar deners who are concerned about chemicals that might affect us or our environment.

title: U.S. to Bring Home Public Safety Aides For Narcotics Talks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14  United States public safety ad visers in 26 foreign countries have been summoned to a major conference, starting here Oct. 11, which will seek broader international effort to stamp out the illicit traffic in narcotics.

title: Diane Hollander Is Bride
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Aug. 14  Miss Diane Hol lander was married here this evening to Haynes Merlin at Temple illel, Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Hollander of North Woodmere. Dr. Hollander is physician. The bridegrodm is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Leonard Merlin of Bethany, Okla., where Mr. Merlin is a lawyer. The couple grad uated from the University of Oklahoma. Mr. Merlin is con tinuing his studies at the Baylor University School of Dentistry in Dallas.

title: THOMAS. CONDUCTS AT MOZART FETE
description: Since Michael Tilson Thomas is so gifted and accomplished a conductor, it is difficult to remember that he is still only In his mid20's and cannot pos sibly have had time to acquire experience in every branch of the concert repertory.

title: Miss Frankum Is Bride on L.I.
description: MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 14In the Congregational Church of Manhasset this afternoon, Miss Barbara Ellen Frankum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Frankum, was married to David Patrick Boyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Charles Boyle Jr. of Hendersonville, Tenn. The Rev. Dr. George Gerald Parker of Old Lyme, Conn., performed the cere mony.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Walker, Manager of Astros, Hurt in OldTimers Game
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 14 (UPI) The Houston Astros manager, Harry Walker, pulled a ham string muscle in his right leg tonight while playing in an old timers game.

title: P.S.C. Cites 60% Increase in Use of Power in 10 Years
description: New York State consumers have increased their average use of electricity 60 per cent in the last 10 years, the State Public Service Commission re ported yesterday in a call for steppedup planning to meet new needs.

title: Ecology
description: A concise yet comprehensive ex planation of how our environment operates. Moving from the general to the specific, the author lucidly de scribes the ecosphere (i.e. earth and the forces that affect it), shows how its various components inter act and sums up with facts about pollution and how it is being com batted. A must for young people and parents as well.

title: TERMS OF HUSSEIN ON PACT REPORTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 14 King Hussein of Jordan was reported today to have de manded an end of the Arab campaign of political and eco nomic pressures against his government as a condition of a new agreement with Pales tinian commando organizations.

title: Philadelphia Plans $400Million Expansion of Airport
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14A $400million expansion project creating a transportation city at Philadelphia International Airport over the next 20 years is being planned here.

title: Marriage Held For Miss Hayes
description: Miss Cassandra D. Hayes, daughter of Mrs. Lawrence A. Hayes of Rochester and the late Mr. Hayes, was mar ried on Aug. 6 to Paul T. Miller of Newark, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Miller of Pittsford, N.Y. The bride groom's father is president of The Associated Press and chairman and chief executive of the Gannet Co., Inc., newspaper publishers.

title: Horse Show News
description: This has been a frustrat ing summer for the United States Equestrian Teamall because of the epidemic of Venezuelan Equine Enceph alomyelitis (VEE).

title: Ecology
description: Although the title suggests other wise, this book is largely about man. It shows how man ignorantly though usually with the best inten tions,removes animals from their proper habitat, causing violent dis ruptions of ecological balance, e.g. the introduction of a few rabbits in to Australia in the 1860's brought on a plague of them that almost killed off all the vegetation. Most of the chapters reiterate the same theme: man should not move things around that lie knows nothing about.

title: Weary of City Life, They Headed for the Hills and the Sea
description: The mass postwar exodus out of New York and into the suburbs has a new parallel now: the move out of megalopolis into the promised land of the country side.

title: Peking's American Dilemma
description: After two decades of angry complaint about the American presence in Asia, Communist China now ap peirs to be equally troubled by the prospects of Ameri can withdrawal.

title: CARDS SCORE, 110
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14Bob Gibson, aided by Jos Cruz's onehanded running catch of Milt May's long drive in the seventh inning, pitched the first nohit game of his career to night as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Pittsburgh Pi rates, 110.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your July 29 editorial Resolved: To Save the Whale is wellintentioned but misguided. To preserve the behe moths of the deep, while allowing a fair harvest for those nations utiliz ing the whale for food, lubricants and other useful purposes, should be an objective of international organization and management, not a tenyear mora torium.

title: Arsenal Beats Chelsea, 30, in British Soccer Opener
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (Reuters) Arsenal opened its defense of the English League First Di vision soccer title in convinc ing style today by scoring a 30 victory over Chelsea, the holder of the European Cup Winners Cup.

title: Laird to Seek $80Billion, Up $3Billion
description: NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 14De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that he would seek a defense budget of about $80 billion for the fiscal year be ginning July 1, 1972.

title: Architecture
description: THE butterflylike tent that appears to be floating over the upper part of the Museum of Modern Art garden this sum mer is not the setting for a garden party. It is banner and shelter for the Frei Otto show, an exhibition of tensile and pneumatic structures by a man who has turned a cre ative obsession with the tech niques of lightweight, mini mal construction into high art. It will be there through September 27.

title: PATRIOTS TO OPEN STADIUM TONIGHT
description: The New York Giants, who have a new stadium of their own in mind, will help the New England Patriots open the na tion's newest sports facility to night in a preseason football game at Foxboro, Mass. Schae fer Stadium is the name and it significantly reverses a trend in stadium building.

title: Party pretty
description: Even the bluejeans generation likes to dress up occasionally. And this year's party clothesfor girls and boyshave an otherera charm that will make children want out of those jeans!

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Consumer interests, which are now pressing for reforms on a wide front, have been taking a close look in some states at revolving credit plans offered by department stores or various creditcard operations.

title: Movie mailbag
description: I thoroughly agree with Vincent Canby's putdown of Death in Venice. I also agree with Burton Pike's putdown of Vincent Canby's putdown. I read Canby's re view as a member of a film audience. He was right. Vis conti's film is dull, confus ing, adapted from a book which is, at best, a doubtful choice for a film. On the other hand, as a literature specialist I had to agree with Pike's analysis of the film. Visconti is knowledge able; he has made an accu rate rendering of Mann's setting, characters and im agery; I was able to appre ciate the Doctor Faustus flashbacks.

title: Reader's Report
description: Lifelines is a fine, dour novel about different styles of dying. Dan Fenwick, an Eng lish newspaperman in Hong Kong is coming unglued with the help of large brandies and wrenching inner conflicts. Andy Burns, an American jour nalist, is in the early stages of leukemia. These endgames con verge when Burns falls in love with the wife that Fenwick is discarding.

title: Switch Ends Minneapolis G.O.P. Rule
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 14  Alderman John Cairns, a Re publican and an admirer of Mayor Lindsay of New York, wrested control of the Minne apolis City Council from his own party yesterday by join ing the minority Democratic FarmerLabor caucus on sev eral organizational votes.

title: Stamps
description: NEW ZEALAND'S health stamps, issued since 1929, have pro vided much help for the children of the island na tion, offering health care in many fashions, possibly the most notable success being through the establishment of health camps.

title: Team of 35 Is Cruising on Old Navy Tug in a Study of Long Island's Waters
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Aug. 14 A 35man oceanographic research team is now at work on a converted Navy tug to determine, among other things, where the waters around Long Island come from and where they are going.

title: Hendren of Broncos Retires
description: DENVER, Aug. 14 (AP) Jerry Hendren, a wide receiver for the National Football League Denver Broncos, retired today. He will take a coaching job at the University of Idaho.

title: WITNESSES BACK CAR EXHAUST TEST
description: CHERRY HILL, N.J., Aug. 14 Two days of public hearings this week on a state plan to test cars beginning next year for carbon monoxide and hydro carbon emissions drew en thusiastic support from environ mental and health groups and grudging endorsements from automobile manufacturers.

title: Pop
description: EMERSON, LAKE & PALMER: Tarkus (Co tillion). No circus, mime show, athletic contest, or grand opera is more entertaining than see ing Emerson, Lake and Palm er in concert, but as long as they're not in town, well have to make do with rec ords and let the imagination conjure up Keith Emerson juggling an electric organ and a Moog synthesizer and grin ning like a madman. Happily, he even manages to grin like a madman on record, helping to create this 12inch vinyl delight known as Tarkus and featuring a malevolent battletank armadillo on the cover. Why not a battletank armadillo? Why, indeed, not anything at all? There is the basis of ELP's music: some thing between Why not? and Let's see what it sounds like if

title: Headliners
description: Her voice, Katharine Hepburn said last week, was dis tinctive with a unique, characteristic quality of sound, style, delivery, pitch, inflection and accent, and that any misappropriation of her voice damages her reputation. For that reason, the strongwilled actress said, she didn't want anyone imitating her voice for radio commercials. She charged that the makers of Vita herring products had done just that; so she sued the company and its advertising agency for $4million. A spokesman for the agency denied that Harriet Hubert Herring, who praises fish in the com mercial, was a Philadelphia Main Line type like Miss Hepburn.

title: 32 Jets Worry About Making It
description: It's as if a guillotine were poised above their necks throughout the training camp practices and exhibi tion games.

title: Sabotage by Pakistan Is Charged by Indians
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 14 (AP)  The Indian Government radio reported today that freight train and an ambu lance were blown up today in Eastern Assam state by mines planed by Pakistania agents.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The physical sensation one feels upon squeezing into a race car for the first time is that the cockpit is so cramped. The body is semirecumbent; knuckles and elbows keep bumping the inside Of the body.shell, and the left foot tangles with the steering shaft; the constricting safety harness is ornery to cope with, and the threepound helmet takes a hold on the head. The psychological reaction is What am I doing here?

title: Nassau Board Postpones Plans To Build 1,500 Beach Houses
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug, 14The Nassau County Board of Super visors this week tabled a con troversial proposal by County Executive Ralph G. Caso to build 1,600 cabanas at Nassau Beach on the South Shore.

title: Parents Efforts Save a Parochial School in Newark
description: NEWARKTopavoid send ing their children to public schools here, hundreds of parentsmost of them non Catholic and nearly all of them blackhave pledged to raise $125,000 to keep the fi nancially faltering St. Charles Borromeo parochial school open for another year.

title: Criminals At Large
description: So there's this foreign power who infects carriers, with the bubonic plague and sends them into Canada and the United States. Once the plague is trig gered, goodbye to both coun tries. Read all about it in COPPERHEAD by James Hen derson (Knopf, $5.95). This is the kind of book with a very complicated plot, where you can't tell the good guys from the bad, where a tired, over worked agent toughguys and wisecracks his way through the story.

title: Stamps
description: TERENCE CARDINAL COOKE, Archibshop of New York, is the new president of the Cardi nal Spellman Philatelic Mu seum, on the campus of Regis College, Weston, Mass. Sis ter Fidelma Conway contin ues as executive director, with Edward J. O'Connor, Malden, Mass., replacing her as treasurer, and Francis J. Vaas, Boston, as secretary.

title: RIGHTS GATHERING STRESSES POLITICS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14 The Southern Christian Leader ship Conference ended its an nual convention here yesterday with an optimistic commitment to the election of a Southern black congressman.

title: Naturalists Doubt Report of Condors In Baja California
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP) A report that a colony of the rare California condor may be nesting in a remote area of Baja California has been termed pre mature, by some naturalists.

title: Resolute Skippers Triumph
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 14  The Resolute Class beat the Shields Class in both the A and B division team races today during the Cow Bay area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta on Manhasset Bay.

title: Risking everythingwell not everythingon a throw of the dice
description: It is an old and honorable literary conceit that the mad understand life far better than those assumed to be sane; and, if the work of R. D. Laing is a true portent of things to come, this once sportive inversion of ra tional behavior may become the next piece of melodrama in the history of psychoanalytic theory.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: There is a recession go ing on but I forget it, Peter Kaszonyi said, sounding apologetic. Until I talk to someone out of our indus try, he added.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON  Back in 1948, I served as a voter registrar in Moore County, N. C. As I recall it, the law required me to have the books open for new registrants at a designated place on three specified Saturdays. Those who wanted to register had to do it on those particular days, at that particu lar place; otherwise, they had to find me and hope that I had the registra tion books on hand. There was no es tablished way for people to find out who the registrar was or where he lived and worked, and the only adver tising of the three Saturday registra tion days was in fine print on the classified ad page of the local weekly.

title: September Nuptials For Miss Pinkerton
description: WAYNE, N. J., Aug. 14 Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Pinkerton have announced engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Jeanne Pinkerton, to Edwin N. Homer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Homer of Metamora, Mich.

title: WAGEPRICE BOARD FAVORED BY SCOTT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Senate minority floor leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsyl vania, said today that a wage prive review board to help curb inflation is becoming more and more necessary.

title: Dianne Wingerter Bride in Jersey
description: RUMSON, N. J., Aug. 14 Miss Dianne Wingerter, daug ter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Bayard Wingerter, and Vin cent James Robinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robinson of Fair Haven, were married here this afternoon in St. George'sbytheRiver Epis copal Church by the Rev. George Willis.

title: Britain, Adopting Metric System, May Drop Measures Such as Gallon, but Beer Will Still Come in Pints
description: LONDON, Aug. 14 (AP)  The British are likely to lose their scruples, along with their drams, grains, ounces, pounds, hundredweights, pecks, quarts and bushels.

title: Builder Is Supported in Plan to Erect HighRise Apartments in Glen Oaks
description: Residents of the Glen Oaks area have lost a major battle in their attempt to prevent the construction of three 32story luxury apartment towers on the site of the Glen Oaks Golf Course.

title: Hoine Improvement
description: HOMEOWNERS and apartment dwellers who are annoyed by unwanted or excessive noise traveling from one room to another in the houseor from outside to inside the houseoften decide that the installation of some acousti cal ceiling or wall.panels, or other form of acoustical in sulation, will provide a per manent means of solving their problem.

title: Art
description: ANYWHERE from 50 to 75 years after their deaths, artists whose work has gone out of fashion can be hauled out, dusted off, and examined again to see whether the victim was buried alive or was not worth digging up for a second look. The German academician Max Klinger who was born in 1857, enjoyed suc cess, and died cum laude in 1920is currently the subject of an exhumation a long way from home at the Wichita, Kansas, Art Museum. On display are 73 etchings on loan from the Staatliche Graphische Sammlung, Munich, under the patronage of His Excellency, Dr. Rolf Pauls, the Ambassador of West Germany to the United States, in an exhibition entitled A Glove, and Other Images of Reverie and Apprehension: The Graphic Suites of Max Klinger.

title: Ovid's Metamorphosis
description: Englished, Mythologized, and Represented in Figures by George Sandys. Edited by Karl K. Hulley and Stanley T. Vandersall. Foreword by Douglas Bush. Illustrated. 725 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. $50.

title: Coney Island Lobby Works for Beaches
description: A group of Brooklyn politi cal and civic leaders has opened a campaign to get Congress to approve con struction of a milelong dike to end pollution and erosion problems which, they say, are threatening Coney Island's beaches.

title: Sheila Marvin, Syracuse Alumna, Wed to James Frederick Mack
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 14Miss Sheila Craw ford Marvin and James Fred erick Mack were married here this afternoon in the Presby terian Church by the Rev, John M. Whallon.

title: Isdale, Meinertz and Oldak Score on L.I. Sound
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 14 George M. (Dooie) Isdale Jr., at the helm of the Etchells22 sloop, Galaadriel; David T. Mei nertz with Sonderho in the Shields Class, and Elliott B. Oldak at the tiller of Elusive among the Solings were win ners on a 10.8mile Gold Cup course on Long Island Sound today.

title: Swimming Party on Aug. 30 To Aid Damaged Hospital
description: The Emergency Flood Relief Committee, founded to help a flood damaged hospital in Queens, has decided to raise money by sponsoring a swim ming party.

title: Shiner, Giants Backup For Tarkenton, Leaves
description: Dick Shiner, Fran Tarkenton's understudy as quarterback of the New York Giants, stepped into the wrong role yesterday and walked out instead of on.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Some of the pleasures avail able to those of us lucky enough to live in this part of New Jersey were covered fully in David M. Alpern's excellent article on skydiving in Lakewood (Travel section, July 25). However, I wish to point out that the Cricket Restaurant, the Imperial Jade Shop and St. Alexander Nevsky Church are located not in Lakewood, as the arti cle implied, but in Howell Township. It is Mr. Alpern's loss that he did not look past U.S. 9. In addition to the na tion's newest golf course, he would have seen two Buddhist temples among Howell's 15 churches.

title: Japanese Team to Visit China
description: TOKYO, Aug. 14 (AP)A Japanese table tennis team left today for a 19day visit to Communist China. The 14 play ers are scheduled to play matches in Pckin,2, Shanghni and other Chipese ???

title: Crable Injured in Crash
description: BRAINERD, Minn., Aug, 14 (UPI)Ron Grable of Mountain View, Calif., broke his right leg and right heel today when he crashed into an embankment during qualifying trials for the L. & M. Continental at Doriny brooke race track tomorrow. He was taken to a St. Paul hos pital for surgery.

title: Packers Drop Rookie Back
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 14 (UPI)The Green Bay packers announced the release of John Lanier, a rookie running back from Parsons College, tonight.

title: COSMOS ARE BEATEN BY OLYMPICS, 5 TO 4
description: MONTREAL, Aug. 14Ken Wallace scored three goals and assisted on another tonight in leading the Montreal Olympics to an upset victory over the New York Cosmos, 54, in a North American Soccer League game. Randy Horton, of the losers, also scored three times.

title: Long Beach Plans to Sue County on Welfare Dumping
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 14This city will take the Nassau County Department of Social Services to court in the next few weeks on the issue of just who is respon sible for the impact of a large welfare population on the community.

title: COUNTERFEIT MONEY LEADS TO 5 ARRESTS
description: NEW MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 14 (UPI)Five persons, four of them from Florida, were held today on counterfeiting and drug charges after two outof state men allegedly tried to ex change bogus bills for good ones at a bank.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We have just bought an old, rundown farm like so many other city people anx ious to escape the noise and bustle. I read Bromfield's Pleasant Valley, in which he tells how he, too, bought an old farm in Ohio and how he restored the top soil to its original richness. Intrigued, I asked the local U.S. Farm Agent to consult with me about my plans for clearing the fields and rotating crops, all the while spouting my newlearned knowledge from Bromfield's book. He listened patiently for two hours then placed his hand gently on my shoulder and said:

title: Java's 12Piece Garnelan Orchestra Yielding to OnePiece Tape
description: KUPUH, Indonesia  Indo nesia's gamelan orchestras the xylophone, drum and gong ensembles that have helped give this nation its enchanted flavorare slowly finding themselves out of a job.

title: Mrs. Hagge Cards 69 for a 134 to Lead by Four Strokes in $25,000 Tourney
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 14 (AP)Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge fired a threeunderpar 69 today for a 36hole total of 134, pushing her lead to four strokes in the $25,000 Immke Ladies Professional Golf Asso ciation open.

title: Bishops Grant $1,072,012 To Ease Poverty in U.S.
description: The Campaign for Human Development, which is the Roman Catholic bishops na tional effort to combat domes tic poverty, announced 53 grants yesterday totaling $1, 072,012 for domestic selfhelp projects.

title: Foe Attacks Village Near DMZ After Strikes on Allied Positions
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 15 (AP)North Vietnamese forces attacked village south of the demili tarized zone early today in the fourth day of intensified fight ing in northena South Vietnam, the Saigon command said.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: It seems a pity that such an articulate and important person in the Gay Liberation movement as Stuart Byron should have to scratch so hard for the merest scraps of comfort in viewing Death in Venice and Fortune and Men's Eyes. For the ugly truth is that neither of the filmS really has anything much to say about the co n temporary ethos of a homo sexual living in today's world  liberated or not.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: For blacks, there is still no fair play in business. Nar rowrnindedness still prevails. No matter how sharp the black's thinking, or how as tute his business sense, how can he go into business for himself when the govern ment and the banks will not lend him capital?

title: MISTER DIZ TAKES JERSEY TURF RACE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14 (AP)Nathan L. Cohen's Mis ter Diz raced to a 3length victory today in the $28,700 Philadelphia Handicap at Atlan tic City Race Track.

title: Saigon Detains Taiwanese
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14 (Reuters)The South Vietnamese Navy detained 14 fishermen from Taiwan for about two hours this week after they landed on one of the Paracel Islands, which are claimed by South Vietnam and Taiwan.

title: R. W. Rennie to Wed Kate Barrett
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 14The engagement of Miss Kate Waller Barrett to Robert Winfield Rennie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gil lis Rennie of New Milford, Conn., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Waller Barrett, for merly of New York. The wed ding is planned for late October.

title: 800 Persons Honor Vaught
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 14 (AP)John H. Vaught, retired University of Mississippi foot ball coach, was honored here tonight. Football dignitaries were among 800 persons who paid tribute to Vaught.

title: More bounce, more color
description: Farout fashion is finally back where it belongson children. And it never looked newer or better. Pow colors, pop patterns, cartoon figures and knits, Knits, KNITS (see cover) are all here. They often looked a bit kittenish on adults, but they're precisely right for children. For dressup time the picture is pretty. Darkened prints turn up on dresses that might have stepped right out of the Edwardian era. And as for boys well! They can either do it up stylish in knicker suits with Prince of Wales plaid socks or rough it in tough, takeanything coats lined with warm, fuzzy fake fur. An added attraction: Most clothes this autumn require very little careleaving a mother time for activities of her own.

title: Mr. Jet Moore 21 Choice In Rich Quarter Horse Race
description: RUIDOSO DOWNS, N. M., Aug. 14 (UPI)Mr. Jet Moore was named the early favorite today for tomorrow's running of the Rainbow Futurity, the second step of quarter horse racing's triple crown.

title: Muriel C. Morisey Married in Capital
description: Miss Muriel Corinne Mori sey, daughter of A. Alexander Morisey of New York and Mrs. Juanita P. Morisey of Phila delphia, was married in a civil ceremony in Washington on July 30 to Clifford John Pugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melville W. Pugh Jr of Towson, Md.

title: REAGAN STOCK LOW AS 72 CONTENDER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 Few of the political insiders around the West any longer consider that Ronald Reagan is in contention for the Repub lican Presidential nomination next year.

title: U.S. Cautiously Seeking Better Haitian Relations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The United States is preparing to seek an improvement in re laitons wih Haiti and to ease cautiously the nineyearold policy of ostracism that was im posed by President John F. Kennedy.

title: The Making of 'The Godfather' Sort of a Home Movie
description: AS was his custom before the drive home from work with his son, the old man walked across the narrow, tenementlined street in Manhattan's Little Italy to buy some fresh fruit. The grocer, who had known him for many years, helped the old man sort out some prize oranges and, as a gift, handed him a perfectly ripened, homegrown fig. The old man smiled, accepted the backyard offering with a slight nod and started toward his car. It was then that he spotted two gun men.

title: Monument Valley: here Sandst ne Sways i the Wind
description: MONUMENT VALLEY is a partto my thinking the most dramatic partof what some Ari zonans call The Standing Up Country. This name derives from the fact that the region Is stacked with literally thousands or red sandstone formations that stand bolt upright on the valley floor. Some are needleshaped, some stick up like organ pipes, some rise like thrones or castles, and many exhibit beautiful arches and natural bridges.

title: Sex Balance by Edict
description: Congress is preparing legislation which would forbid colleges to limit their enrollments to students of one sex or to establish quotas for the number of men women to be admitted. These proposals, supported by Senator Birch Bayh and Representative Edith Green, are motivated by the best of intentions to curb sex discrimi nation. Given the present emotional atmosphere as well as the many serious injustices toward women in academia, the proposals have strong superficial appeal.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHI  Last Tuesday, the day after India and the So viet Union signed their surprise 20year friendship treaty in New Delhi, a member of the In dian Parliament noted that the date of the signing, Aug. 9, was the anniversary of the launch ing of Mahatma Gandhi's Quit India movement in 1942. The member asked, jocularly, whether this meant that three decades after we ask the Brit ish imperialists to get out, we are going to ask the Russians to come in.

title: Chiefs Triumph, 1210
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 14 (UPI) Jan Stenerud kicked four field goals, the last from 50 yards, to earn the Kansas City Chiefs a 1210 victory over the Atlanta Falcons.

title: BURTIS TAKES LEAD IN STAR TITLE SERIES
description: NIANTIC, Conn., Aug. 14 Alan R. Bortis of Sea Cliff Yacht Club, the 1969 winner, sailed Gauchero to a 7point lead for the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship today after the first two races of the 47th annual Blue Star event of the International Star Class First District off Niantic Bay Y.C, The final race is scheduled to morrow.

title: Whom the Dewey Thruway Would Destroy It First Drives MadWNSEEEEEEEE!
description: ISPENT a large, a very large, part of last summer on the Governor Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and its Impressive adjuncts in what was possibly one of the more ambitious com muting operations in recent history at least one round trip a week, about 600 miles, between the tiny Adirond'ack village of Upper Jay and New York City. All in all, I have few complaints about the Thruway and its younger cousin the Northway; they are straight, welloaredfor roads and they allow top speed of 65 miles an hour, for which I am still abundantly grateful. But they are boring, as only straight, wellcaredfor roads can be boring (e.g., a sign reads ALBANY 100 MILES, and 9.23 identical minutes later another sign reads ALBANY 90 MILES).

title: Florida Acts to Put Diploma Mills Out of Business
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 14  Florida's diploma mill Industry, which has been grinding out worthless degrees for years in everything from religious ordination to Ph.D.'s in nuclear physics, may soon be as dead as Mexico's quickie divorce mills.

title: FISCHER FAVORED TO BEAT CHAMPION
description: The president of the Interna tional Chess Federation said last week that he would put the odds at 6040 that Bobby Fischer would beat the world champion should the two play next year.

title: The Devils Finds An Advocate
description: Acable piece of artThe Los Angeles Times. Morbid miasma  wanton violence shameful carnality. Its X rating is thoroughly deservedThe Saturday Review. Might have been writteh and filmed by Nero and the Marquis de SadeNewsweek.

title: BLACK PANTHERS SUE BALTIMORE OFFICIALS
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14  The Black Panther party and a white lawyer awaiting retrial on ac cessorytomurder charges have filed suit against four Baltimore officials asking $1million in damages and an injunction against continued surveillance of the party.

title: Grover, Picken and Reilly Win in Bay Shore Sailing
description: BAY SHORE, L. L, Aug. 14 Jim Grover, the national cham pion, was first home today in the Narrasketuck Class as the Bay Shore Yacht Club's annu al invitation regatta got under way. A light southeasterly wind prevailed and made for a long day.

title: The Nation
description: Illusions that the Berrigan brothers, while in prison, would be less of an establishment hair shirt were dispelled last week, when the peacepriests became the focus of hunger and work strikes at the Federal Correc tional Institute in Danbury, Conn.

title: Knapp Urges New Police Anticorruption Unit Divorced From Regular Force
description: The creation of a radically new Police Department anti corruption force, manned by investigators who would never return to regular police duties, has been proposed by the chair man of a commission investi gating charges of police cor ruption here.

title: Announcements
description: HEIMBERGMr. and Mrs. Robert Holmberg Oleo Marion Trislor) of Manhasset, ionfully announce the birth of a daughter Louise Jennifer, sister of a Jessica, on July 30 al Lenox Hill Hospital. Proud grandmother is Mrs, Tobie Trister, of Brookfield, Conn.

title: THORNTON DELEHANTY
description: Thornton A. W. Delehanty, a newspaperman who had done scriptwriting in Hollywood for many years, died Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif., at the age of 77.

title: At Youth Camps in Yugoslavia, Drabness Is a Thing of the Past
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 14  Summer work camps for young Yugoslays are not what they used to be.

title: ALBATROSS WINS TWO ADIOS HEATS
description: MEADOW LANDS, Pa., Aug. 14Albatross won his 14th and 15th races of the year and his 13th and 14th in a row tonight at The Meadows, taking the $88,800 Adios Stake for 3yearold pacers in straight heats.

title: Parties, Not Ideologies
description: Mayor Lindsay's departure from the Republican ranks can have a harmful and unnecessary consequence if it encourages a polarization of the two major parties along ideological lines. Persuasive as were the factors that seemed to the Mayor to deny him a future as a liberal Republican, they did not add up to the proposition, implied in his farewell statement, that liberalism itself has no future in the G.O.P.

title: A Special Kind Of Zoo in The Catskills
description: CATSKILL, N. Y.Near the en trance is a large glass  covered blackboard. Under the heading BORN RECENTLY is chalked the following list: 41 llama, 34 fallow deer, 4 barasingha, 1 muntjac, 9 sika deer, I springbok, 4 gemsbok, 8 eland, 3 zebra, 1 onager, 4 Przewalski horses, 2 tarpans, 4 kangaroos, 1 capybara, 2 yak. The tabulation ends with the words and man/ others.

title: Rotterdam Nine Wins Title
description: WATERVLIET, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP)  The Rotterdam team beat a Lakeshore, L. I., nine today, 9G, to win the New York State Little League cham pionship and gained a berth in next week's Eastern regional tournament.

title: Evening in Paris
description: Paris couturiers have come up with the most spectacular display of dazzling evening gowns in years. The reason? The international set is anticipating gala social season this fall. For starters, there are the Raffles Red and White Gala at the Hotel du Cap on the French Riviera, and the week of festivities commemorating the 2,500th anniversary of the Persian Empire in Iran. All this has propelled the Paris designers, who will presumably supply a lot of the celebrants with their clothes, out of their recent preoccupation with dull and dreary dresses. They've brought back full skirts, tiny waists and a festive look.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: Just a month ago Pan Amer ican World Airways and Trans World Airlines con firmed reports that they had held merger discussions as a means of possibly solving their financial problems. A major problem in any merger of two large transportation companies is meshing the per sonnel  as the unhappy ex perience of Penn Central has shown. How this might af fect a Pan AmT.W.A. con solidation was one of the topics discussed in an inter view last week with Charles. C. Tillinghast, chairman and chief executive officer of T.W.A. Excerpts from the in terview follow.

title: City Hospitals Get Crash Renovation Pat at $50Million
description: The city's hospitals are un dergoing the most ambitious and extensive crash renovation program ever undertaken by the municipal hospital system, Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the Health and Hospitals Cor poration, said yesterday.

title: Yanks Waiting for Giants to Drop Other Shoe on Move to Jersey
description: Michael Burke, president of the New York Yankees, wishes that Wellington Mara, president of the New York Giants, would hurry up and announce his final decision about movhig the football team from Yankee Stadium to a projected sports com plex in New Jersey.

title: Store Gas Stations Vex Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 14 At the new, fourstory air conditioned Town Hall here, the public relations corps smiles and brags about many things.

title: Concerts HangersOn Upset Queens Residents
description: Ilvo weeks ago, a security guard was stabbed to death a block and a half from the Forest Hills Tennis Stadium as he tried to subdue a young gatecrasher at a rock con cert.

title: Movie milbag
description: Burton Pike's letter attack ing Vincent Canby's review of Death in Venice is an interesting example of the kind of pretentiousness that Canby deplores in Visconti's film, a pretentiousness that permeates the movie almost as much as the peasoup pho tography.

title: National Notes
description: The atmosphere in the court room in San Francisco was tense last Monday. About to begin was the trial of the Soledad Broth ersGeorge Jackson, 29, John W. Cluchette, 28, and Fleets. Drumgo, 26three black prison ers at Soledad Prison charged with killing a white guard in January, 1970. But hardly had the court convened when the lawyers for the three men were on their feet.

title: African Queen at Work in Wilds of Oregon
description: SUNRIVER, Ore, Aug. 14  It has been 20 years since the African Queen made her perilous voyage down the Ulandi River in search of the German gunboat Konigen Louise, with Humphrey Bo gart at the tiller and Kath arine Hepburn as the only passenger.

title: Queens Councilman To Succeed Leviss
description: The next Borough Presi dent of Queens will be Coun cilman Donald R. Manes, a Democrat of Flushing, a like lihood that is freely admitted by every politician around except Mr. Manes.

title: News of Dogs
description: Mrs. George B. St. George of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., heads 28 judges for the 54th annual allbred show of the West chester Kennel Club at Cro ton Point Park, Crotonon Hudson, N. Y., Sept. 12.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In the headlong rush to assert the centrality of the marketplace several things are happening. Members of the New York Stock Ex change appear, receptive to William McChesney Martin's idea that institutions must not be allowed access. Mr. Martin has recommended that member firms should not be allowed to manage mutual funds. Out of 581 member firms, only 48 manage open end mutual funds and out of these firms, only a fraction would be seriously hurt by any enforced divestiture. Hence the consensus to move ahead is likely to develop quickly.

title: Bombs, Grenades, Flak Found at Olympic Site
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 14 (AP)Bombs, gre nades and flak have been unearthed at the site of the 1972 Olympic Games, the Bavarian Interior Minister said today.

title: Cosmos to Play Bangu In Soccer Here Friday
description: The New York Cosmos who are seeking their first victory against the other two expan sion teams in the North Amer ican Soccer League, will meet Bangu of Brazil Friday night at Yankee Stadium at 8 o'clock.

title: POWER IS ASSURED THE ILL BY CON ED
description: Consolidated Edison has just completed an inventory of 102 customers here who have a critical need for power to oper ate lifesupporting medical ma chines and will get emergency service in the event of power failures.

title: U.S. Attorney for Eastern Disrict Calls Drugs No. 1 Problem
description: Ambition, attention to de tail and experience have ad vanced Robert A. Morse to the post of United States At torney for the Eastern Dis trist of New York.

title: Californian Captures 34th Soap Box Derby
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 14 (UPI)Larry Blair, 13 years old, of Oroville, Calif., won the 34th running of the All American Soap Box Derby to day. His winning time in the final heat was 27.20 seconds.

title: Watchdogs Called Key to Transplants
description: British researchers believe they have shown conclusively that four recently discovered chemical watchdogs of the body play a key role in de termining whether or not a kidney transplant is successful.

title: Stamps
description: BOGUS untagged er rors of United States stamps are re ported by Alfred Boer ger, a pioneer in the field of tagged stamps. Since 1963 the United States stamps have been given an invisible totheeye luminescent coat ing to speed their cancella tion in automatic devices at numerous post offices. Legiti mate errors do occurthe coating, or tagging, as it has been referrd to in stamp collecting, can miss a sheet or pane of stamps, or a por tion of a sheet or pane, as it leaves the presses.

title: Nation
description: LOS ANGELES Welfare reform is this year's ecol ogy, and no politician can afford to be against it. Events in the nation's two largest states last week il lustrated the growing public opposition to mushrooming welfare costs.

title: Ecology
description: Mr. Pringle delivers a deft, clear eyed appraisal of the population ex plosion. Imagine a 24 hour a day rush hourthat's.Japan, India, China, Pakistan and many other places. Most other places, in fact. The book discusses growth rates, food produc tion capabilities, new varieties of grain, birth control and prejudices or customs that militate against controls.

title: ACTON PACES TRIALS FOR MICHIGAN RACE
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Aug. 14 (UPI)Mary Ac ton of Porterville, Calif., led the field today at 153.502 miles an hour in the final qualifying round for tomorrow's Yankee 400 stock car race at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Auto Pollution Studied
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Federal, state and local agen cies have begun a threemonth study in 27 urban regions to measure air pollution caused by automobiles. The Environ mental Agency said today that the study was intended to pro vide data for the design of state plans to achieve national air quality standards for carbon monoxide and similar pollut ants.

title: A Sugary Approach to Helping Women
description: ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 14 (AP)Birth control and health information is being dispensed in Emory University's Family Planning Program through a sugarcoat ed pill  a pulp confessions magazine titled, True to Life.

title: Senate Panel to Study Effects, Of Mortgage Policies on Blacks
