description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14The Senate Antitrust and Monopoly Subcommittee will begin ex tensive hearings next month into charges that the practices of mortgage bankers have con tributed to the perpetuation of minority districts of the central cities.

title: Roughandready gear
description: Blue denim jacket is cut like a bomber pilot's, warmlined with Orlon fleece. Chips n Twigs. Sizes 8 to 12, $25; 14 to 20, $28. The second floor, Saks Fifth Avenue. Jacquard sweater is by Robert Bruce. Sizes 8 to 12, $10; 14 to 20, $12. Second floor, Bloomingdale's.

title: GARMENT DISTRICT TO BE CLEANED UP
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday an intensive cam paign to clean up Manhattan's Garment District.

title: Royals Pin Sixth Loss in, Row on Red Sox, 61
description: BOSTON, Aug. 14 (AP)Key hits by Lou Piniella, Cookie Rojas and Bob Oliver sparked a fiverun first inning today as the Kansas City Royals stretched their mastery over the Boston Red Sox to nine straight victories eight this year with a 61 decision.

title: New Attack on Certificates
description: Before Labor Day, the 55 000 stockholders of a large West Coast company will be asked to take part in what seems likely to be a major step toward the elimination of the stock certificate.

title: PITTSBURGH JUDGE BARS BUS STRIKE
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 14A Judge ordered a halt today to a wildcat strike that was set off when a black bus driver ap peared at work wearing a Free Angela Davis button. The strike cut off bus service to about 35,000 daily commutess here this week.

title: U.C.L.A. Awaits Eligibility Ruling
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14The most im portant move of the 1971 football season for young James McAlister and the Uni versity of California, Los Angeles, may be made next Saturdaythree weeks before their season's opener.

title: ROBERT A. DEUTSCH
description: JERSEY CITY, Aug. 14 Robert A. Deutsch, who retired in 1965 as an electrical engi neer and section chief in the New York City Department of Marine and Aviation, died here Wednesday. He was 65 years old and lived at 2742 Kennedy Boulevard.

title: Ecology
description: From clouds, to rain, to streams  at last to the ocean. A primer about the metamorphosis of clouds done with simple eloquence and elegant photographs of lightning cracking the sky, streams spilling over cataracts, waves surging, crested in foam.

title: Miss Fogelberg Wed
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 14  The marriage of Miss Christine M. Fogelberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl 0. Fogelberg, to Robert D. Fountaine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. Fountaine of North Wantagh, took place here this afternoon in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Ca thedral. The Rev. William J. Tierney performed the cere mony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: CUITE WOULD EXTEND ENROLLING FOR SOME
description: An extension of the deadline for party enrollment by new votersnow Oct. 2 for those wishing to participate in the 19720 nominating primaries was proposed yesterday by Thomas J. Cuite, majority lead er of the City Council.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I must offer a criticism of Robert A. Jones's otherwise excellent article, National Parks: A Report on the Range War at Generation Gap (Tra vel section, July 25). His stress upon the bipolarity of the generation gap ignores third group of campers who are caught financially and chronologically between the hippie campers and the trailers of the fat wallet group. This third group, of which I am a member, sleeps in tents on the groundutil izing this mode of vacation because we enjoy it, and, with children, can reasonably afford it.

title: Carrington and Schoenlank Gain Tamiment Tennis Final
description: TAMIMENT, Pa., Aug. 14 Art Carrington of Elizabeth, N. J., upset King Van Nostrand of Brightwaters, L. I., in the semifinals of the fifth annual Tamiment Invitation tennis tournament today, 63, 1.6, 63.

title: A Dispute Over 17 Staff Dismissals Embroils Columbia's Puerto Rican Program
description: The Urban Center at Colum bia University is involved in ontroversy with the Puerto Rican community over its dis Missal last month of two ad ministrators and 15 students employed by its Puerto Rican program.

title: Leitner Leads in 420 Class With Victories in 2 Races
description: BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 14 Firstplace finishes in each of the first two events sailed today gave Eric Leitner the lead in the 420 Class junior national sailing championship regatta. The Raritan, N. J., skipper is in competition with 40 other helmsmen in the series that concludes tomorrow.

title: Living Theater: Jailed in Brazil
description: JUDITH MALINA and Julian Beck and 13 members of the Living Theater have been in jail in Brizil on a marijuana charge since.July 1, and the inter national art community, including, Jean Paul Sartre, Jean'Genet, JeanLouis Barrault, James Baldwln,: Allen Ginsberg, Larry Rivers, Susan Sontag and Mike. Nich ols, have rallied to their support: The: charge can get, them as much as five years in prison and they are being held until their trial, set for Oct. 1. The U.S: State Department has thus far given no indication that it will intervene. Demonstrations are being organ ized around the world at Brazilian consulates on Fri clays at noon and benefits are being organized to raise money for legal fees.

title: Rosemary stew
description: There is a pleasant old wives tale about the origin of rosemary: The Virgin Mary, it is said, spread a linen robe over a white flowered bush and turned the flowers blue. This is pretty nonsense. The name rosemary is an English corruption of the Latin ros marinus, meaning marine dew. In any case, sprigs of the plant add a heady, pungent odor to all manner of food. In this stew from Italy, it is combined with several other herbs traditional Mediterranean countries. The combination considerably dresses up a simple, basic cooking idea without requiring outlandish expense or particularly arduous maneuvering in the kitchen. Why Italian restaurants do not feature this recipe with the same pride and frequency that the French reserve for a navarin or one their special stews is a mystery as dark and mazy as the puzzle of what makes national identities. There is no puzzle about what makes tasty stews, and here is one as good in summer as in winter. 1 pounds lean beef such as top or bottom round or chuck 3 cups fresh or canned peeled tomatoes with basil  cup chopped celery  cup chopped parsley, loosely packed  teaspoon oregano  teaspoon thyme 2 tablespoons olive oil Salt and freshly ground pepper 4 tablespoons butter 1 teaspoon finely chopped garlic  cup dry white wine 1 sprig fresh rosemary or 1 teaspoon dried rosemary leaves 8 thin slices French or Italian bread Butter

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: While our association certainly appreciated Joan Cook's article on the tem porary help industry (August 1), there are certain points in the article that deserve clari fication.

title: Ian Matthews Sings And. Plays Guitar At the Bitter End
description: Ian Matthews, a Londoner who served with two rock groups of some note, Fairport Convention and Matthews Southern Comfort, is appearing on his own through tomorrow at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: 12 Killed in Nigerian Crash
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 14 (AP)  A passengercarrying truck crashed into a road con struction vehicle in northeast ern Nigeria today, killing 12 persons and injuring 15, the po lice announced. Eight of the dead were secondary school pupils, a spokesman said.

title: Education
description: New York City's vast school system, now begin ning its second year on a de centralized basis, is finding that community control is no panacea for all its problems. The squabble that broke out last week in Brooklyn's Dis trict 23, which includes Ocean HillBrownsville and the sur rounding area, provided chap ter and verse.

title: GRAHAM CARDS 207 TO LEAD BY MOT
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 14 Lou Graham adhered to a prin ciple today and was charged with a penalty stroke at the last hole. Despite this he took the 54hole lead in the $165,000 Massachusetts Classic after a 68 brought his total to 207.

title: BAHRAIN BECOMES SOVEREIGN COUNTRY
description: BAHRAIN, Aug. 14Sheik Isa bin Sulman alKhalifa, the Ruler of Bahrain, today de clared his Persian Gulf island group an independent sovereign country.

title: Miss Vandeburgt Wed
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 14  Miss Rensje Vande burgt and Victor Laube 3d, on of Mr. and Mrs. Lauhe Jr. of Oradell, were married here this morning in Holy Trinity Church by the Rev. Eugene Hazewski. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hendrik J. Vandehurgt of Westwood. Her father is designer of stained glass windows.

title: G. J. GONZALEZ DIES; EXCELLIST AT MET
description: Guillermo Jose Gonzalez, a cellist, composer and arranger who had been a member of the Metropolitan Opera Company's orchestra, died on Friday in Cordoba, Mexico. He was. 79 years old.

title: Pistons to Face Rockets
description: The Detroit Pistons of the National Basketball Association meets the American Basketball Association's Denver Rockets in an exhibition game Sept. 28 at the Denver AuditoriumArena.

title: Big Board Gadfly
description: If the president of the New York Stock Exchange, Rob ert W. Haack, has picked up a few more gray hairs these days, it could be for any one of a dozen different reasons.

title: The Nation; Labor:
description: Samuel Gompers, who summed up all of organized labor's goals at the turn of the century in the single word more, woulc have, been nonplussed at the gloomy mood that hung over meetings of top unionists from coast to coast last week.

title: Braves Sudue Astros, 70
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 14 (UPI) Pat Jarvis pitched a threehitter tonight and Earl Williams and Tommie Aaron drove in two runs apiece as the Atlanta Braves beat the Houston Astros, 70.

title: MAYOR, 21, CHOSEN IN WILLIAMSBURG
description: The young people of, Wil liamsburg elected 21yearold Robert Rodriguez as their may or last week to head what is billed as the first youth government in New York's his tory. Of 6,500 eligible voters in the 14to25yearold bracket, nearly 2,000 cast their ballots in the Brooklyn area.

title: Cowboys Trounce Saints
description: DALLAS, Aug. 14 (UPI) Roger Staubach threw 69 and 81 yard touchdown passes to Bob Hayes and Margene Adkins and Toni Fitsch kicked 46 and 50 yard field goals as the Dal las Cowboys recorded a 3621 victory over New Orleans to night.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Having visited my father's home town, San CarloSessa Aurunca (in the mountains between Rome and Naples), I enjoyed reading Anthony Mancini's Ethnic Travel (Travel section, Aug. 1), which told of his visits to rel atives in Abruzzo. The article stirred many happy memories. The warmth and the love or our Italian relatives is unfor gettable, especially since both these qualities are so lacking in American life.

title: CARDINALS SCORE OVER OILERS, 1614
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14 (AP) The Baltimore Colts choked off several Chicago threats while nursing a 1point secondhalf lead, then padded their advan tage on a 37yard scoring pass by Earl Morrall and beat the Bears, 2113, tonight.

title: Gorton to Quit Party Post
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 14 (AP)Former Prime Minister John Gorton said in a copy righted article in The Sunday Australian that he would re sign as deputy leader of the governing Liberal party. Mr. Gorton was dismissed from his Cabinet post of Defense inter this week.

title: Report by Quakers On Israel Assailed By Jewish Groups
description: The American Jewish Con gress and the AntiDefamation League of B'nal B'rith have de nounced as antiIsrael a 1970 Quaker report calling on Israel to take a step toward peace in the Middle East by pledging to withdraw from territories oc cupied in the 1967 war.

title: Miss Freeman Wed To Gary L. Brooks
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 14  Miss Nancy Leonard Schuy ler Freeman, a descendant of Gen. John Philip Schuyler, a member of the First Con tinental Congress, was mar ried here this afternoon to Gary Lee Brooks. The Rev. Perry Burton performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: Appreciating Rare Books
description: Rarebook collectors, like collectors of paintings, an tique cars or fine wines, en joy a certain psychic income prestige and ego satisfac tionand, if they play their cards right, a healthy appre ciation on their investment, even in hard times, But it isn't easy to play the cards in this game.

title: Photography
description: OVER the past two weeks I've been relishing the work of two photogra phers whose work was entirely unknown to me un til the mails brought me their respective monographs.

title: St. Catharine's Club Wins 4 Races in Canadian Row
description: ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Aug. 14  The St. Catharines Rowing Club continued to dom inate the 89th Royal Canadian Henley regatta today with four victories that raised its total to 10. St. Catharines won the junior pairoared event, 154 pound and heavyweight eight oared shells, and the senior 135pound singles.

title: BLACK POLICE GROUP SUES CHARLOTTE, N.C.
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 14 A state organization of black law enforcement officers has filed a suit here charging that the Charlotte Police Depart ment uses tests and other fac tors not related to job per formance to keep from hiring and promoting black officers.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Unfortunately, Joseph Papp did not know the facts con cerning the changes planned in the Vivian Beaumont's Forum Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Judith Smith Wed to Potter Stewart Jr.
description: FREEDOM, N.H., Aug. 14 Miss Judith Ann Smith and Potter Stewart Jr., both of whom are with The Environ mental Protection Agency in Washington, were married here this afternoon in the First Christian Church. The bridegroom is the son of As sociate Juitice Potter Stewart of the United States Supreme Court and Mrs. Stewart of Washington.

title: Guests Find Havana City of Faded Charm
description: HAVANA, Aug. 14The car, a beige Lincoln Continental, cruised briskly along Malecon Drive, once the showplace of this city, the Collins Avenue of the Caribbean.

title: Susan Burpo a Bride
description: Miss Susan Mary Burpo and Richard John Nocella were married yesterday morn ing in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn by the Rev. Patrick J. Flem ing, who also celebrated the nuptial mass. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Burpo and Dr. and Mrs. Rocco Nocella, all of Brooklyn.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSThe merican dilemma in Greece is in a sense whether to be liked by the Government and disliked by the people in order to shore up sagging Mediterranean strategic posi tion, or whether to jeopardize U.S. ability to stand by NATO and Middle East commitments in order to affirm preference for democratic rule.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IREAD with considerable interest the article by Gordon Watkins Hoo ray But Also Shut Up in The New York Time of July 25, To place Mr. Wat kins's comments in perspec tive, a few comments are in order.

title: Wood Field and Stream: The Top Rod
description: CHILMARK, Mass.  You write about them and I'll catch them has been, for several years, my younger brother Dan's irritating atti tude toward our respective angling achievements.

title: Ecology
description: Yes, they actually did parachute cats on Borneo. Why? Borneoans had sprayed DDT to do away with mosquitoes. But the insecticide was also ingested by cockroaches which were eaten by geckoes which, in turn killed the cats that swat lowed them. And so the rats took over. Thus, the airlift. It's a compli cated chain superbly presented in an amusing verseplay format and ex cellent illustrations.

title: Convoy Reaches Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 14 (AP)  A convoy of 114 trucks reached Pnompenh to day after traveling on embat tled Route 4 from Kompong Som, the nation's only deep water seaport. They carried gas oline and goods for civilian markets, which have suffered severe shortages.

title: New Techniques Lifting Volleyball to Game of Power
description: HAVANA, Aug. 14The problem with volleyball in the United States, Edward DeGroot Jr. said today, is that coaches have the idea that it's a recreation sport, a girl's game. Most of them have never seen a power volleyball game.

title: Australia and U.S. Seek to Protect Airlines in Dispute Over Commercial Flights
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug 14 Australia and the United States are in a heated argument over commercial air traffic between, the two countries, with Wash ington demanding more flights, here by American carriers and the Australian Government, balking to protect its own inter national airline, Qantas.

title: The Making Of Homeric Verse
description: It is almost inconceivable that anything could radically alter our concept of classical literature, espe cially if it did not involve a new manuscript or an archeological find. Yet in 1928, a young man woke literati out of centuries of com placency with discoveries whose relevance is only now fully ap preciated. Milman Parry, hailed as the Darwin of Homeric scholar ship, was among the first men to conceive of literature not merely in terms of genre; but of media.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: SOME letters have ap peered in this column; which have been mis leading and uninformed about City Center's plans for the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. Without trying to answer factless pieces of vituperation, may I just describe what the plan actually is, so that readers may judge for themselves?

title: It's How You Go About It
description: IWELL remember father's evening ritual of water ing the lawn. He would sit on the front steps after dinner, puffing on his favorite pipe, and play the garden hose back and forth across the front yard with perfect cadence for 15 min utes or so.

title: 6 Presidential Hopefuls Stress Economic Issue at Texas Convention
description: DALLAS, Aug. 14  Mark my words, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a rapt dinner audience of 1,500 Texans, you have seen the next President of the United States.

title: The last in a series of novels as alike as a row of bayonets
description: Ivy Compton  Burnett, D.B.E., who died at 85 on Aug. 27, 1969, was the Greek Jane Austen. Her sole subject was the English family by its fireside, talking. Her 19 nov els are all set in late Victorian coun try houses; her characters are ar ticulate, well bred and intensely idle. They are also selfish, mean and murderous. Miss ComptonBurnett's assessment of humanity was not merely grim; its iron pessimism is no theory that she is advancing and no philosophical ground that she is defending, but rather her cool as sumption that mankind is viciously selfish. That compassion and gen erosity might have some power over men is an idea that she would seem to have rejected utterly.

title: NEGROES TO OFFER OWN HEALTH PLAN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12 The nation's organization of black physicians went on record during its annual convention and scientific assembly here this week as opposing every major national health insurance plan under consideration by Congress.

title: Irwins: Strict Disciplinarians
description: Mrs. Irwin, a strong and spirited woman whose glance at times flashes with the fire of conviction, is the daughter of a diligently observant Sev enth Day Adventist family. She once was a model, and says she veered away from her upbringing in her teens but has come back to it since.

title: 58 to Start Play Tuesday In Barbara Kirkland Golf
description: The third annual 36hole Pinehurst championship for the Barbara Kirkland Memorial Trophy will be played Tuesday and Wednesday at the Meadow Brook Club, Jericho, L. I.

title: NEWCOMBE, OKKER GAIN TORONTO FINAL
description: TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Reuters) John Newcombe of Australia and Tom Okker of the Nether lands gained the men's singles final in the Canadian open ten nis championships today.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: CONTROL DATA is negotiating a $225million revolv ing credit agreement with 14 banks headed by Chase Man hattan. Westinghouse Electric and Tenneco said they planned to build a $200million assembly line at an un disclosed site to turn out four 1.2millionkilowatt, floating nuclear power plants a year. Controller of the Currency William B. Camp has issued a warning to all national bank presidents against unsafe and unsound practices involv ing municipal bonds. President Nixon released $2billion of special housing funds that will, in effect, subsidize the F.H.A. and V.A. mortgage interest rate to hold it at 7 per cent.

title: Russia Fights Pollution
description: MOSCOWThe other day I came across some lines written by Edgar Allan Poe in 1841. Drawing pictures of the future of our planet, he en visioned innumerable cities, huge and smokeinfested. The green foliage was wilting under the hot breath of the hearths. The beautiful face of nature was disfigured as if after some evil disease.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The United States should stop trying to reverse the trend that sees industry flee ing the inner cities for the suburbs.

title: Foreign Notes
description: South Vietnam's Presidential election is still almost three months away but President Nguyen Van Thieu's supporters were already working last week for his reelection. One of their moves was to distribute thou sands of copies of a large, glossy portrait of the 48yearold leader, retouched to make him look younger and thinner than he is. Government officials in towns and villages were ordering in habitants to display the photo graph and to have it framed at their own expense.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Once again, with an increase in the price of steel, the Administration has warned the offending concerns that is not in their best interest. It is in deed fortunate that American indus try has someone to warn them when they are making a mistakeor, after a series of mistakes, to bail them out.

title: Olympic Fund Post Goes To Farmingdale Educator
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Aug. 14. Dr. Charles W. Laffin Jr., president of the State Univer sity center here, has been named chairman of colleges in the 1971 fund drive sponsored by the Long Island division of the United States Olympic Com mittee.

description: As stage manager of Last of the Red Hot Lovers, wish to answer Mrs. Robert Sherry's letter in which she.

title: Riding Tune Wins Dash
description: SALEM, N. H., Aug. 14 (AP) Riding Tune won the $10,000 feature at Rockingham Park to day, covering the six furlongs in 1:09 2/5. Demetri the Greek finished second two lengths back.

title: GIRL
description: A 25yearold Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with seconddegree kidnapping in the case of an 8yearold girl whose body was fdund in the Bronx River.

title: Hit by Bando in 9th Helps A's Hunter Top Kline, 10
description: Curt Blefary's bat came back to haunt the New York Yankees yesterday, but it was swung by Sal Bandowhose ninthinning single broke up a scoreless pitching duel be tween Steve Kline and Jim Hunter to provide a 10 victory for the Oakland Athletics. The borrowed bat punched the ball over second base just beyond Gene Michael's reach and gave the Athletics their 11th straight on the road. It also gave them their second in a row over the Yankees in a series that will peak this after noon with Vida Blue pitching against Stan Bahnsen.

title: The World
description: BELFAST  There was a nightmare unreality about the scene in Belfast this past week. It was as if place or time were out of jointas if this corner of the United kingdom had be come part of some Balkan nov el, or had gone back in time to the wars of religion that dev astated Europe 300 years ago.

title: Hold Your Peace and Governor Max Win Divisions of Arlington Futurity
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) Hold Your Peace and Governor Max won divisions of the ArlingtonWashington Futurity at Arlington Park today.

title: Scotts: Practical Travelers
description: Mrs. Scott, in cream tone slacks, sat with her legs curled up on an easy chair and sipped ice tea and talked for over an hour. The Scotts home was built to their own specifications. Of course, we built it with our furniture in mind, Mrs. Scott remarked.

title: AROUND THE  Gar en
description: Look to the lawn. Seed or sod new ones and repair established grass where turf is thin Order bulbs for fall planting. Sow house plant seed indoors for winter window sill plants. Plant colchicums near the house for early fall display. Keep up with the rapid vegetable harvests. Paint fences.

title: Forman Leaves Peking
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 14 (UPI) James Forman, leader of a delegation of the Black Work ers Congress from the United States, and a delegation mem ber, Mrs. Helen Jones, left Peking for home today after a visit to China, the official Chinese press agency reported.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Article 2  No Title

title: Pitchman for Free (And Freewheeling) Theater
description: JOSEPH PAPP, the Shakespearein thePark man, the love person (as some of his actors and writers call him), the producerdirec tor who eats critics for breakfast and politicians for lunch, has now, after 18 years perilously near defeat, reached what he calls his culminat ing moment. He has at last got the City of New York squarely behind his cultural cornucopia, the Shake speare Festival Public Theater on Lafayette Street, by selling its build ing to the city for $2.6million and staying on as tenant at $1 a year. Thus lives what is doubtless the most ambitious theatrical enterprise in the country, but more important, in Papp's view, is the city's commit ment to public theater, a concept that sees theater as an essential serv ice. I just want equality with gar bage collection, says Papp, not a higher status.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THERE were morsels of good news from the price front last week and a crumb of hope for the dollar. Meager as they were, they were enough to give the stock market, which had been starved for encour agement, its best day's gain in more than eight months.

title: StatehoodforCity Advocates Offer Data
description: Advocates of statehood for New York City asserted yester day that the city would gain financially and administrative ly from the change, saying that it already performed all the major functions of a state government.

description: Picture knits

title: GIANTS WIN, 65, ON A FLY IN 10TH
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 14 If the Giants are supposed to be ill, the Mets must be dead.

description: About 150 demonstrators, some chanting: British troops must go! picketed the offices of British Overseas Airways Corporation at Fifth Avenue and 45th Street yesterday pro testing British imperialism in Ireland,

title: G.A.O. QUESTIONS MILITARY PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Federal Accountants raised questions about a Pentagon practice of paying the writing and editing costs of civilian newspapers published for mili tary bases.

title: Son to Mrs. McCardle
description: HADDONFIELD, N.J., Aug. 14  A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Mc Cardle on Aug. 4 at Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Cam den. The child has been named Thomas James. The child's grandparents are Mrs. Joseph Pillmeier of Florida, N.Y., and Mrs. Joseph Mc Cardle of Rowayton, Conn.

title: Drama Mailbag.
description: I must take exception to Mrs. Robert Sherry's letter complaining about Danny Kaye's clowning in Two By Two.

title: Senators Beat Angels, 20
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) Jeff Burroughs's two  run home run in the seventh inning backed the sixhit pitching of Mike Thompson and sparked the Washington Senators to 2.0 victory over the California Angels tonight.

title: Ecologists and Governor at Odds on Dredging Permit
description: MARCO ISLAND, Fla., Aug. 14The State of Florida is ex pected to sign an agreement next week permitting a private developer to dredge and fill 10,000 acres of Everglades here in exchange for setting aside 3,850 other acres for conserva tion.

title: RAIDERS TRIUMPH OVER JETS, 4120
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 14 With a pair of unheralded quarterbacks, Al Woodall of the Jets and Ken Stabler of the Raiders, substituting for their more glamorous but injured teammates, Joe Namath and Daryle Lamonica, New York and Oakland met in their only meeting of 1971 tonight.

title: Freetex, $7, Wins by Nose In Stakes at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 Michael J. Stavola's Freetex chose a good spot for winning his first stakes race, capturing the $81,200 Kindergarten at Liberty Bell Race Track today by a nose over Verna Lea Farms Toomuchholme, a first time starter.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I agree with your corres pondent F. Cueras (Travel section, Aug. 1) that the eli mination of a rail link be tween New York and Mont real is a disgrace. But there still is a way to get from New York to Montreal by rail, al though it's considerably long er. There's an 8:30 A.M;train that leaves Grand Central daily and arrives in Toronto at 7:45 P.M.; a connecting train can be taken from there to Montreal. Only coaches are provided; no dining car, only a snack bar. The New York Montreal trains should be re instated with all their ameni ties. Amtrak will have to make a positive effort to woo passengers back by adding amenities to rail travel, not eliminating them.

title: The World
description: CAIROA secret Egyptian promise to the United States not to resume shooting on the Suez front comes to an end to day. But Calm, in an unusually frank expression of despair, has made it clear that it is not about to unleash the dogs of war.

title: Movies
description: NOW I'll tell everybody how to become a movie star. It's the easiest thing out, as my grandma used to say. You just sit around in your apartment for about 20 years, and then this guy comes in with a con tract. Honest, I wouldn't lie about such a serious subject.

title: King Curtis, the Bandleader, Is Stabbed to Death
description: King Curtis, the blues and soul musician, bandleader and composer, died early yesterday morning of stab wounds re ceived during a fight with a man on the stoop of a brown stone he owned at 50 West 86th Street.

title: Williams's Clout Decides
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 14 (UPI)  Billy Williams's tworun homer tonight, his 22d of the season and his fourth in a six game span, carried Milt Pappas and the Chicago Cubs to a 31 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: S.E.C. LIFTS RULES ON STOCK REPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP)The Securities and Ex change Commission issued new rules today that would all but eliminate information blackouts by companiet while their stock registration applications were awaiting Federal approval.

title: Thomas A. Isherwood Marries Allison R.Turek, jersey Student
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 14Miss Allison Randolph Turek was married this aft ernoon to. Thomas A. Isher wood of Rumson. Msgr. John J. Endebrock performed the Roman Catholic cere mony in the Princeton Uni versity Chapel.

title: Robert Hawkes Weds Miss Nancy D. Oles
description: Miss Nancy Diane Oles and Robert M. Hawkes were mar ried here yesterday morning in the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. Emerson Moore, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In a world where most everybody lives on the orig inality of a few, it is re freshing to meet those who persist in doing their own thinking and have achieved success by stubbornly adher ing to a basic concept.

title: Carlson Star Class Victor
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., Aug. 14 Rolf Carlsen's Sweetness won Star Class honors on Hemp stead Harbor today as the Sea Cliff Yacht Club resumed racing after two straight postpone ments for lack of wind.

description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Erminio Spaila, 74, Held European Heavyweight Title
description: ROME, Aug. 14  Enninio Spalla, a former European box ing champion, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 74.

title: Daughter for Diana Ross
description: HOLLYWOOD, Aug. 14 (AP) Diana Ross, the pop singer, gave birth today to a girl at Cedars of Lebanon Hospital. The baby, named Rhonda Su sanne, weighed 4 pounds, 14 ounces.

title: Jean Philippe de Bourbon Marries Virginia Zock
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 14Miss Virginia Maria Zock, a legal assistant with Coudert Brothers, New York law firm, and Jean Philippe de Bourbon, a media planner with J. Walter Thompson in New York, were married here this afternoon by Justice Ed ward M. O'Gorman of the State Supreme Court. The ceremony was performed in the garden of the home of the bride's parents.

title: Vanderbilt U. Plan For Slum Clearance Weighed by Court
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 14  A Federal District Court is study ing a dispute over an urban re newal project where property owners contended that Vander bilt University and the Nash ville Housing Authority had conspired to create a slum that would have to be torn down.

title: Stamps
description: THE New York Hospital is celebrating its 200th anniversary this year. Commemorating the role that this hospitalnow a part of the mammoth up per east side complex known as New York HospitalCornell Medical Center  and other I hospitals have played in the life of their communities, will be a 6 cents postal card, to be issued here on September 16. A miniature post office will be in operation at The New York Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. on September 16. The normal firstday ceremonies will be held the evening of that day, rather than in the morning when the cards go on sale. (As one hospital aide put it, the medical staff, ad ministrators and others are quite. Occupied with taking care of the ill during the morning).

title: LatinOwned Businesses Put at 1% of U.S. Total
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)The Commerce Depart ment says that about 1 per cent of businesses in 1969 were owned by citizens of Mexican, Cuban, Puerto Rican and other LatinAmerican origins.

title: Poloists Clash Today
description: Bob Lubash, John Greenleaf, Dave Rizzo and John Witte more will be on the Locust Valley polo team that will play Sands Point (Ted Shapiro, John Gayer, Russell Corey and Fred Zeller) today at 3:30 P.M. at Bethpage State Park. Admission will be $1.50, with children under 12 admitted free.

title: Sparkman and Moore Take EastofRye Races
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 Palmer D. Sparkman won by 3 minutes 33 seconds and about 25 boat lengths with his Soling, Lulu, and Harry L. Moore by 59 seconds and five lengths With the Shields sloop, Patience, in the Yacht Racing Association championship regatta for fleets based EastofRye on Long Is land Sound.

title: Law Student Weds Miss Hudson
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 14Miss Harriet Pund Hud son acid Peter Henry Bren nan were married here today at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Perry Barruss Hudson. The Rev. Benjamin J. Lake, a Presby terian minister, performed the ceremony. The bride groom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bryant William Bren nan of Fanwood, N. J.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: BLACK SEPARATISTS SUED IN MISSISSIPPI
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 14 A $1million damage suit has been filed against the Republic of New Africa and its leaders by a Hinds County farmer.

title: Son for the Grauers
description: A son was born July 29 to Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Grauer of the Bronx at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine Hospital. The child, whose father is a teacher in the city's schools, has been named Jonathan David. Mrs. Grauer is the former Miss Judith Skalka.

title: Religion
description: Vatican II, the council held from 1962 to 1965, grappled with the fundamental ques tion of whether the Roman Catholic Church is essen tially a structure run by a hierarchy or a community revolving around the entire people of God. It came down on the latter side and produced a sweeping set of reforms, including a call for greater participation by lay men and priests in the oper ation of the church.

title: Politics
description: John V. Lindsay is always called the young Mayor of New York City. But he is almost 50 years old and his time was run ning out. His liberal Republican ism had become a contradiction in terms, he had already lost his party's primary election for Mayor once and there was no way he could hope to get a G.O.P. nomination for anything higher Governor, United States Sena tor or President. Destiny's child had run out of future.

title: MOST EMPLOYES RATIFY BELL PACT
description: Bell System workers across the country voted yesterday to accept a contract offer made July 19, but all but two New York State locals rejected the proposal and will reopen nego tiations tomorrow.

title: DAIREN
description: DAIREN, China, Aug. 14The first thing you learn when you come to Manchuria is not to call It that. This rich industrial area, long the prize of war and struggle by Japan and Russia, is simply Northeast China to the Chinese, who now possess it in reason able security and are developing it as fast as they can.

title: 220 Million Aluminum Cans Are Returned for Recycling
description: Americans returned 220 mil lion aluminum cans for re cycling in the first six months of this year, earning nearly $1 million for their efforts, the Aluminum Association reported last week.

title: 3 Pools in City Are Offering Free Swimming Instruction
description: Three city swimming pools in Brooklyn and Queens are offering free swimming and life saving instruction through Sept. 3 to children from 8 to 14 years old.

title: A MITE INFECTION FOUND INCREASING
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 14Scabies the itchy parasitic skin infec tion, is resurgent throughout the world, although the rea sons are unknown, an Amer ican dermatologist has re ported.

title: Boy Scouts Find Mother Nature on Gardiners Island
description: GARDINERS ISLAND, N. Y., Aug. 14This lovely lonely re treat, which historians and or nithologists call a place where time has stood still, was in vaded early this month by hun dreds of Boy Scouts, assisted by the Army, the Navy, the Marines and the Coast Guard.

title: Chief of Police Reinstated After Clash in South Miami
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP)Sal Vizzini, South Miami's police chief, suspended after a racial disturbance broke out yester day, was reinstated today at the request of lawyers appoint ed to investigate a clash be twen young blacks and the police.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Among the various cate gories in the fastpaced world of magazines, one of the least known to advertis ers is teenage fan maga zines. Yet this group of books is currently enjoying outstanding financial success from single  copy sales as well as virtually unparalleled loyalty and trust from their readers.

title: Invisible Horse Stirs a New OTB Hassle
description: An unlettered 3yearold pacer, whose existence never was acknowledged by the Offtrack Betting Corporation, has come back to haunt the firm's customerservices de partment.

title: Citizen was the word for Brandeis, also pragmatic
description: In 1905 John F. Kennedy's grandfather, Honey Fitz Fitzgerald, renowned in Boston for his bouton niere, his melodious tenor and his casual political ethics, went Sweet AdeWant on a campaign for the mayorship. Louis D. Brandeis swung into action. Fitzgerald, he declared, was one of the worst types of the machine politiciari. Indefatigable, call ing upon a whole battery of carefully chosen weapons, he fought to keep Fitzgerald out of City Hall.

title: NEW ZEALANDERS SPUR RACE AMITY
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 8This country, where interracial marriage is com mon and overt prejudice is un usual, will put a stiff antidis crimination law into effect next year.

title: Siffert Gains the Pole For Austrian Grand Prix
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 14 (UPI)Jo Siffert of Switzerland won the pole position for to morrow's Austrian Grand Prix by clocking the best time turned in at the closing quali fying session today.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: I was appalled by Clive Barnes's paean of praise for Fun. Shakespeare in Fun City the latter being a euphem ism for the bread and cir cuses' which have turned. Central Park into a rowdy amusement park, as anyone living on its periphery will testify.

title: Cost of Queen Mary's Purchase Scored by Legislators on Coast
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 14A California Assembly sub committee report has touched off a new battle between Long Beach and the state over an agreement under which the city purchased the Queen Mary.

title: The Nation
description: HARTFORD  If something less important than the finan cial well being of the state of Connecticut had been at stake, it might have been funny. But as the Great Tax Debate of 1971 fumbled along last week, each development seemed more tragic.

title: Son to the Greenbergs
description: OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 14 A son was born on Aug. 2 in Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown to Mr. and Mrs. David A. Greenberg. The child is named Jeremy Harris.

title: Fairly's Homer Key Hit
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 14 (AP) Ron Fairly's home run broke a scoreless tie and triggered three runs in the eighth inning that carried the Montreal Expos to a 30 triumph over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.

title: ALLENDE ASSAILS U. S. JET SALE BAN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 14 President Salvador Allende Gos sens has termed lamentable the decision by the United States ExportImport Bank to withhold financing for the pur chase by Chile of three Ameri can jet airliners.

title: Linda Brakeley, M. H. Terry Jr. Wed in Suburbs
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14  Miss Linda Smith Brakeley and Michael Howes Terry Jr., son of Mr. Terry of Noroton, and the late Mrs. Terry, were married here this afternoon.

title: The Nation
description: At 7 A.M. on Jan. 1, 1970, champagne corks popped in a Manhattan hotel suite, marking the end of negotiations that led to the most expensive wage set tlement in the Transit Authori ty's history. The next day, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, emerged from a meeting of the agency's direc tors and said they had just voted to raise the transit fare from 20 cents to 30 cents.

title: Starr Oat for Season After Second Operation
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 14 (AP)Bart Starr, knocked out of the Green Bay Packers lineup by surgery to correct an injured arm tendon, un derwent another operation yesterday and will probably miss the entire season.

title: CALDER RACE TAKEN BY KENTUCKY FOLK
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP)Ken tucky Folk, owned and trained by Anthony Paparelli, rallied from last place to win the $10,000added Palmetto Han dicap today at Calder Race Course.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Like an old volcano suddenly come to life, the school desegregation issue was exploding across the Amer ican scene again last week. There was the President of the United States responding, through his press secretary, to the jibes of Gov. George C. Wal lace of Alabama with an asser tion that any civil servant who did not honor Mr. Nixon's anti busing policy would be reas signed or fired. And there was Governor Wallace once again de fying a Federal Court decree.

title: Reader's Report
description: Written in 1924, Mikhail Bul gakov's autobiographical novel transpires during the imperial twilight of the city of Kiev. In 191819, Kiev is an uneasy limbo between the receding German occupation and the advancin.g Bolshevik revolu tion. Bulgakov focuses on the social cataclysm as it im pinges on one uppermiddle class familythe Turbins. A dramatization of the novel, en titled The Days of the Tur bins, became a Moscow Art Theater standby, called by one of its directors the second Sea Gull. Like Chekhov, Bul gakov regards his doomed elite with tolerant fatalism.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IN Charles Higham's recent interview with film di rector Donald Siegel, he quotes Siegel as assert ing the following about a film he directed, 'Two Mules for Sister Sara: I rewrote most of it and had several runins with Rackin (Martin Rackin, the producer of the film) over it. Since the writer of this letter received sole credit for the screen play, Mr. Siegel's statement is keenly intriguing. Martin Rackin and I hereby make the following offer: We will give $5,000 to any charity Mr. Siegel names  not ex cluding the Don Siegel Press Agent Fund  if he will pro duce the script ne wrote for Two Mules for Sister Sara. We will leave it to the Amer ican Arbitration Association to decide who wrote what. Since all scripts written for thefilm are dated and are in the files both of Universal City Studios and the Writers Guild, the decision can be achieved quickly. Will Mr. Siegel reply in your paper to this public offer?

title: Television
description: THE airwaves belong to the people. How many times have you heard that testimonial? In practice, of course, in the history of broad casting, it is difficult to see the people for the forest of special interests.

title: Flemings Gain in Tennis
description: ARLINGTON, N. J., Aug. 14 Alan and Peter Fleming of Chatham, N. J., the defenders and topseeded entry, advanced to the semifinal round of the Eastern clay court fatherand son tennis tournament today at the Arlington Players Club. The Flemings topped Merle and Dave Irwin of Bloomfield, N. J., 06, 64, 75. The tournament will conclude tomorrow.

title: Movie mailbag
description: Five years ago, I doubt that The Times would have printed. Finally, Gay Lib.. Five years ago, I wonder whether the author, Stuart Byron, would have written it. I'm glad both happened. 1 think it's healthy and long overdue.

title: Miss Mortola Bride in Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 14Miss Elaine Hayes Mor tola and Edward Joseph Ra bidoux 3d were married here at noon today in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augus tine. The ceremony was per formed by the Rev. Lawrence J. McGinley, vice president of St. Peter's College in Jersey City and former president of Fordham University, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Ecology
description: One look at the picture of a Ruhr Valley factory spewing thick orange smoke in the air is enough to show you that the United States isn't the only country with smog, polluted rivers and other pressing ecological problems. Lavishly illustrated in color, this book goes around the globe, giving a detailed account of man's use and misuse of his en vironment.

title: Boone the Great Scores
description: TIMONIUM, Md., Aug. 14 (AP)Boone the Great won the featured Majorette Purse by two lengths over Smashing Success as Timonium Race Track opened its 24day season today.

title: Pamela Hynds Bride in Naples Of Peter Dailey
description: Miss Pamela Jane Hynds and Peter Holmes Dailey were married yesterday after noon in Christ Episcopal Church, Naples, Italy, by the Rev. E. David Murset, an Anglican priest.

title: Killebrew Hits 502d
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 14 (AP)The Minnesota Twins, held to one hit for six innings by Joe Coleman, scored five runs in the seventh and four in the eight to beat the Detroit Tigers, 9.4, today.

title: Stamps
description: BRITAIN'S 1971 Anni versary stamps, due Aug. 23, will pay hom age to an ancient city, a sport that was an ante cedent to American football, and a remembrance for its Armed Forces and the nurses who cared for the wounded.

title: Nothing to Do But Sit and Bask Like A Primordial Samuel Beckett Character
description: O CRACOKE, N. C.Vacationers at the Cape Hatteras National Sea shore here make a pleasant mix tureor mix, as the Park Serv ice ranger likes to say. They are old and young, hippie and redneck, North erner and Southerner, Cadillac driver and rucksack hitchhiker, gospel singer and folk guitarist. They are architects of fabulous sand castles, and they are clammers and crabbers, walkers and birdwatchers, beach buggy freaks and treasure diverseven Europeans, among them Germans and Englishmen. Before September ends, some oneandaquarter million people will have come this year to this 75mile strip of barrier islands that lie between the Atlantic and Pam lico Sound. But, since they are spread out over the long, hot summer and miles and miles of beach, you hardly notice them.

title: Thieu Is Accused of VotingCard Fraud
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 14Gen. Duong Van Minh's campaign headquarters charged today that President Nguyen Van Thieu was trying to rig the presidential elections by issuing multiple voting cards to proGovernment voters and in structing them to vote more than once.

title: Fight on Prostitution Pressed in Section of Jamaica
description: The residents of a section of Jamaica, Queens, are alarmed about a problem that many New Yorkers believe is confined to Manhattan: streetcorner prosti tution.

title: Libya Eases Travel Curbs
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Libya has lifted all restrictions on travel by her citizens to other countries in the projected Arab federal union, the government an ti today. The countries are the Sudan, Egypt and Syria.

title: The World
description: MANILA The highestranking Moslem official in the Philippines Government was telling the coun try's Senate last week about an outbreak of violence on the ma jor island of Mindanao, Condi tions are reaching a stage where the Moslems may be totted to fight to defend their homes, and their properties, he said. A holy war, or jihad, is fast ap proaching reality.

title: South Africa Set for Visit By Malawi Leader Monday
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 14, (Reuters)South Af rica put out the flags today for a state visit by President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malwai.

title: PAKISTAN HOLIDAY IS GRIM IN DACCA
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 14 This East Pakistani capital in creasingly torn by violence and terrorism, looked today more like a city under curfew than one celebrating National In dependence Day.

title: Books Essays on Labor
description: ISSUES IN LABOR POL ICY. Edited by Stanley M. Jacks. The MIT Press, Cam bridge, Mass. 182 pages. $10.

title: Evelyn Phoebe Yenson Is a Bride
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 14Miss Evelyn Phoebe Yenson and Dr. ChenChih Sun were married here this afternoon at the College of New Rochelle Chapel by the Rev. Thomas Phelan, who is the resident Newman Chap lain at the Rensselaer Poly technic Institute.

title: Susan Goldman Bride
description: FORT MYER, Va., Aug. 14 Miss Susan Jane Goldman was married here today in the Post Chapel to Harry I. Moatz of New York. Lieut, Col. Richard Dryer, Jewish chaplain at Fort Belvoir, per formed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Capt. Peter J. Goldman, U.S.N., ex ecutive assistant and senior aide to the director of re search, development, test and evaluation at the Pentagon, and Mrs. Goldman. Mr. Moatz is a son of Mrs. Francis Moatz of New York and the late Samuel Teitelbaum. The bridegroom was adopted by the late Mr. Moatz.

title: The world's oldest professional gamine
description: When Ruth Gordon made her Broadway debut in December, 1915, as one of the Lost Boys in Peter Pan, Alexander Woollcott wrote in The Times the next day that Miss Gordon was ever so gay as Nibs, and she has been toujours gai ever since. And now, at the age of 74, the world's oldest professional gamine has written what her pub lishers call a kind of autobiogra phy, But it is not really any kind of autobiography; it is a grabbag of anecdotes and bits and snatches of miscellaneous chatter. Its chap ters tend to break down into strings of frankly discontinuous vignettes, each separated from the next by neat little row of asterisks.

title: Homes of Historic Figures And O'Neill Are Landmarks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The designation of nine Na tional Historic Landmarks in six states, including homes of seven signers of the Declara tion of Independence and Eu gene O'Neill, the playwright, was announced today by the Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton.

title: Son to the Hickoks
description: A son was horn to Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Hickok of Ben nington, Vt., on Aug. 5 at Putnam Memorial Hospital there. The child ix named William Andrew. Mr. Hickok is a filmmaker and writer.

title: Mother Held in Assault
description: Mrs. Hanna Abrams, 23 years old, was arrested on charges of attempted murder yesterday, after she allegedly threw her 6yearold daughter out a third story window of their Bronx apartment and then jumped from the window herself. The child, Cindy Abrams, suffered cuts on her thigh and a possi ble skull fracture. Mrs. Abrams suffered minor injuries and Was released to the police after treatment at Misericordia Hos pital, where the child is being held for observation. The family lives at 3988 Bronxwood Avenue.

title: The Education of Freshman
description: IN some ways, James Buckley's first six months in the Senate have resembled a boy's first year in school. He arrived totally without formal education in the legislative process; since then, he has been polite to his elders, done his home work conscientiously and with en thusiasm, and made some new friends. He has been a model student, of both the traditions and techniques, and if he failed his first important test, on the SST, he has managed to earn high marks all around for self application and deportment.

title: Dance
description: KENNETH MacMILLAN, the new director of Britain's Royal Bal let, has rounded off his controversial first season with his most controversial act so far. That was the re action to the new fulleve ning ballet, Anastasia. Crit ically, this ballet has proved a disaster: a couple of critics admired it, but the rest have attacked with enormous vigor and some justification. It is not as bad as the most im placable of its critics suggest, but it is pretty terrible.

title: VERMONTERS BALK ALLYEAR SCHOOL
description: Tomorrow would have been the start of the fourth week of yearround school at the high school in Hinesburg, Vt. In stead, the school will be closed and the students will be getting ready to return for the begin ning of a normal school year on Sept. 7.

title: Rubens Painting Is Stolen
description: MECHLIN, Belgium, Aug. 14 (Reuters)Thieves broke into the Municipal Museum here during the night and took Rubens painting of the cruci fixion valued at more than $350,000, the police reported today.

title: Despite Lack of Summer Jobs, Youths Haven't Made Trouble
description: SAGINAW, Mich., Aug. 14 One recent summer morning four teenagers lolled on a porch on North Charles Street in this midMichigan city. If you asked them, they were in terested in summer jobs, but not that much. Swimming and fishing and sleeping and watch ing TV and lolling on the porch and messing around were bet, ter.

title: Brooklyn Woman in Race
description: Mrs. Juanita Flynn, chairman of the South Brooklyn chapter of the Young Americans for Freedom, is a candidate for that organization's national board of directors. The election will be held at the group's national convention in Houston, from Sept. 2 to 5.

title: Target: Le Grand Charles
description: Early in an otherwise misspent childhood, I was led to investigate my grandfather's battered copy of Paradise Lost, a coffeetablesized volume, profusely and chillingly il lustrated by Gustave Dore. Those illustrations intrigued me  Dore's pen could invest a sunlit glade in the Garden of Eden with the gruesome ambience of Newark, N. J., on a rainy winter night  so to better understand what they were all about, I patiently inchwormed my way through the entire text.

title: Season's 2d Tropical Storm Forms Off North Carolina
description: MIAMI, Aug. 14 (AP)The second tropical storm of the season, with winds reaching 60 miles an hour, developed off North Carolina today and headed away from the coast.

title: FINN WINS 5,000 FOR RARE DOUBLE
description: HELSINKI, Aug 14 (UPI) Juha Vaatainenq of Finland, urged on by the cheers of his compatriots, won the 5,000 meter run at the 10th European track and field championship, today to complete a distance double achieved oinly twice before.

title: Gardens
description: The county seat of most every coun ty in the United States has an office of Cooperative Extension. It is listed in the telephone book under county government. These offices are exten sions of the state's agricultural colleges and the United States Department of Agriculture and are a means of get ting agricutrural assistance and horti cultural information to the farmer and homeowner.

title: SARATOGA SALES ECLIPSE RECORD
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP)A son of North ern Dancer, from Ivy by Nasrul lah, was sold last night for $170,000 to highlight the auc tion of 54 yearlings for a total of $1,763,000.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Pentagon papers have made it quite obvious that the public and, to an extent, Congress were kept in the dark while two Presidents made and expanded commitments to Vietnam.

title: Miss Storrs Plans Bridal
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 14  Mr. and Mrs. Richard Salter Storrs have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Farewell Storrs, to Yoshi haru Akabane, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keiji Akabane of Tokyo. The wedding is planned for the fall.

title: BLOOD BANKS TO GIVE TESTS FOR HEPATITIS
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (AP) The, American Association of Blood Banks has announced that all approved blood banks will be required to test blood donors for hepatitis indications.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONLast week the possibility arose of Swiss banks trying to keep some foreign money out, in cluding American money, and they may do so.

title: Cardinals Top Oilers, 1614
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14 (UPI) Larry Wilson blocked a punt and recovered the ball for touchdown to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 1614 victory over the Houston Oilers tonight and give their new head coach, Bob Hollway, a victory in the Cardinals preseason opener.

title: Sick of K.G.B. Spying, Solzhenitsyn Says
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 14  Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn, charging that Soviet security police have harassed him for years, has protested to the Government after an incident two days ago in which he said agents as saulted a friend who had caught them illegally searching the writer's country cottage.

title: Elsons Have Daughter
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Elson of Brooklyn on Aug. 6 in Mai monides Hospital in Brook lyn. Mrs. Elson is the former Miss Rae Speer. The child, whose father is an associate systems engineer with the In ternational Business Ma chines Corporation, is named Lynne Ami. She is a grand daughter of Mr and Mrs. Melvin Speer and Mr. and Mrs. Morton I. Elson, all of Brooklyn.

title: DR. HARRY J. GREENE, A GYNECOLOGIST, 68
description: Dr. Harry J. Greene, a gyne cologist and obstetrician, who was a specialist in gynecologi cal cancer, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 855 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. His age was 68.

title: Palmer to Play Exhibition
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C., Aug. 14 (AP)Arnold Palmer, golf's career leading moneywinner, will play an 18hole exhibition in WinstonSalem Sept. 25.

title: A Day in the Life of in ACTivist Mom
description: THE ACT phone in the study rings loudly while I am in the kitchen clearing up the breakfast dishes. I run to answer it, where it sits next to the home phone.

title: A Passion Play For Our Time
description: British playwright Edward Bond, whose Saved won praise here last season, wrote Passion to aid England's Campaign for Nuclear Disarma ment. It was staged at an openair Festival for Life at a racetrack in London last Easter Sunday. The complete Passion is printed below.

title: Steelers Top Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 14 (AP)Terry Bradshaw capped a 98yard drive in the fourth period with a 33yard touch down pass to Dave Smith to night that rallied the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 1613 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Brewers Down Indians, 53
description: MLWAUKEE, Aug. 14 (UPI) Lew Krausse allowed six hits in 8 2/3 innings and drove in run with his first hit of the season to lead the Milwaukee Brewers to a 53 triumph over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sports of The Times
description: Ten years ago Lee Grosscup was taking his turn in that long line of young quarter back candidates of high promise on the Giants, each presumably destined for great ness and none ever making it. He had arrived amid considerable hoopla a season earlier and neither won friends nor influ enced people. His brashness antagonized his teammates.

title: Science
description: We have to run faster all the time just to stay in the same place, an entomologist said last week, and in some cases, I'm afraid, we're falling behind.

title: BRITISH SHIFTING MORE ARMY UNITS TO IRISH BORDER
description: BELFAST, Northern Irelandy Aug. 14British troops seek ing to prevent terrorist infiltra tion moved toward the Irish border today following a bat tle between soldiers and 15 gunmen last night.

title: DRUG USE IS LAID TO MEN IN AUNITS
description: Official armed forces investi gations have found cases of drug use among men in the Navy's Polaris submarine crews, in the Air Force's Stra tegic Air Command and in the Army's NikeHercules missile battalions, Flora Lewis stated in a syndicated column released yesterday.

title: Truck and Bus Inspection Is Increased by U.S. Here
description: A tractortrailer driver parked his rig in a lot next to a Staten Island hotel the other day for a forced eighthour rest. Glued to the sides of his truck were Federal stickers ordering him and his truck out of service.

title: Philadelphia Opens a Campaign to Reduce Autos Air Pollution
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14 William Smith; a truck driver, was surprised when a police man and a Health Department agent halted him in his tractor trailer and informed him that his diesel engine was belching smoke.

title: Avon Products Buys 438 Acres in Orange County to Build a New 1,000 Employe Plant
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday that Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics company, had bought 438 acres in Orange County as the site for manufacturing facilities ex pected eventually to provide 1,000 jobs.

title: PARENTS CONTEST L I. ZONE CHANGE
description: The Board of Education's new zoning lines that affect 16 of the 18 academic high schools in Queens were con tested in Supreme Court last week by a group of Forest Hills parents whose children have been assigned to a new school in Jamaica.

title: Mike Saaf Returns Today For Ox Ridge Polo Team
description: The Ox Ridge Hunt Club's polo team will play the Toronto Polo Club in an outdoor match for the first time today. The game is scheduled for Ox Ridge in Darien, Conn., at 3 P.M.

title: 111 STUDENTS TO GET H.U.D. FELLOWSHIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, has named 111 students as winners of oneyear college fellowships for a year of grad uate study in urban affairs.

title: That brownstone feeling
description: After sampling Paris, London and Los Angeles, Peter and Mary Stone chose New York as home base. Peter, a winner of Emmy, Oscar and Tony awards, wrote the longrunning Broadway hit 1776. The challenge they gave themselves was to create a brownstone feeling in their pent house duplex. And meet the chal lenge they did. The subtle formality of the living and dining rooms, and the country charm of the rooftop porch are ample proof. Under standably the mostused room is the projection room, where the Stones treat friends to movies twice a week.

title: Bridge When the alarm goes offand nobody hears
description: HEAVY sleepers who respond slowly to the ringing of their morning alarm clocks, or perhaps fail to respond at all, sometimes have similar trouble at the card table in the evening. Situations may arise in which an unexpected devel opment causes a player to sound an alarm, but it may ring rather softly and be inaudible to untrained ears.

title: Safety Rules Sought In Transit Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI)  Cities and states wanting Government funds for mass transit projects should be forced to include safety programs in their pro posals, the National Trans portation Safety Board says.

title: N.Y. PIONEER CLUB WINS TWO RELAYS
description: The New York Pioneer Club, paced by Lennox Stewart, and the New York Athletic Club scored two victories each at the national relay champion ships of the Amateur Athletic Union at Randalls Island yes terday.

title: U. S. Grant In the City
description: Like most enthusiastic ob servers of the New York scene, David Freeman is from out of town (Cleveland, Ohio), which accounts in part for his special awareness of the kind of Manhattan phenomenology to which natives cultivate se lective blindness. To wit: the miles of bombed out aban doned tenements on the lower East Side; the peep shows where you can see a stag film on location; Sanitation Depart ment incinerators; abandoned brick kilns in the Bowery. (And when did you last visit the public basketball courts on Sixth Avenue?)

title: Carl Albert, on Taiwan Visit, Assures Nationalists
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 14 A visiting delegation of American congressmen, led by Speaker of the House Carl B. Albert, paid a call on the Chinese Nationalist Legisla tive Yuan (Parliament) today for what was expected to be merely an exchange of pleas antries.

title: The Nation
description: We've got the world's biggest U.N. Security Council, said one airline official the other day. One vote can veto a measure. He was describing the Interna tional Air Transport Association which seeks to set the prices the public will pay for international airline tickets.

title: Follmer to Start on Pole In Watkins Glen CanAm
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Aug. 14 (AP)  George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif., driving a Mus tang, gained the pole position In qualifying trials today for the twohour TransAmerican race tomorrow.

title: The World
description: For some time Peking has been emitting shrill sounds of alarm over revived Japanese militarism. Now James Reston, in his remarkable recorded in terview with Premier Chou Enlai, made piiblic last week, has spelled out this major Chi nese anxiety. Fear of Japan, it now seems, may well be one of the main motives for Pe king's recent moves toward da tente with the United States.

title: A COAST MOUNTAIN CLAIMED BY TRIBE
description: TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 14 Does Mount Adams, the sec ondhighest peak in the State of Washington, belong to the Yakima Indians?

title: Boy, 18, Hangs Himself in Rikers Cell
description: An 18yearold Staten Island youth committed suicide early yesterday morning in his cell in the adolescent remand shelter on Rikers Island, where lie was being held on a burglary charge.

title: Music
description: SHHH! Let's move a bit closer and observe an American in his nat ural habitat. Oh, excellentthis one is a fine specimen, the 1971 variety. Notice the reddened eyes, caused by watching ancient, flickering movies; the quivering nose, raised to test the ecology; the balanced widelegged stance, in readiness to react to sonic boom, war atrocity, municipal strike, urban sprawl, mercury poisoning, dope raid, elm disease, bugging, mugging or mass arrests in the public interest.

title: Britain Considers Credit Reform
description: LONDONIn Britain the field of personal credit has long been a lawyer's night mare. Wellmeaning Vic torian legislators packed the statute books with controls and safeguards designed to protect the impoverished widow and the gullible gam bler from the excesses of the rapacious moneylender.

title: Miss Ann Herrick Wallace Is Wed
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 14Miss Ann Herrick Wal lace and Marcel V. Scoffier were married here this after noon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. John Wingler.

title: NORTHSOUTH TALK IN KOREA TO OPEN
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, Aug. 15The South Korean and North Korean Red Cross soci eties have agreed to hold talks at Panmunjom to arrange con tacts between divided families.

title: Moscow's Balkan Pressure
description: The Hungarian Government newspaper Magyar Hirlap has warned against a possible antiSoviet axis emerg ing in the Balkans. It explained what it had in mind by claiming that Premier Chou Enlai is planning to visit East Europe this fall to encourage a TiranaBelgrade Bucharest axis. It all could lead to an extremely dan gerous situation in the Balkans, the newspaper warned.

title: FRANKLIN SETS PACE IN LIGHTNING SAILING
description: NOROTON, Conn., Aug. 14 Philip Franklin of the host Nor ton Yacht Club held a three quarter point lead over Bruce Nelson of the Manhasset Bay, L. I., fleet, after the first two races in the 19th annual Light ning Class Long Island Sound championship were completed today. One race tomorrow will conclude the series, which is for skippers on both shores of the Sound from City Island to The Race.

title: Jobless Textile Workers Decry Plight in Alabama
description: ROANOKE, Ala., Aug. 14 Jobless textile workers and other witnesses painted a bleak picture of life for the middle aged worker at a Senate com mittee hearing this week in this small town where the rate of unemployment is 17.1 per cent.

title: Education
description: It may come as a surprise to those who picture today's youth as wild products of a permissive age, but there is et startling amount of sexual ignorance among the nation's more than seven million col lege students.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Correcting the skydiving article's mention of hotels in Lakewood  the Claridge is now a resident oldage home, and the Brunswick is closed for the summer. Our hotel has been in operation for over 20 years and offers rooms with private tile bath, air conditioning and TV at mod erate rates.

title: Movie Mythographer
description: Our age's central thinker, Myra Breckinridge calls Parker Tyler, if only because in the decade between 1935 and 1945, no irrelevant film was made in the United States. If Myra's reader realizes that Parker Tyler actually exists, her dubious praise (she liked the inso commer cial just as ferociously) probably makes him more a figure of camp derision than a critic to be read. But now that Tyler's two movie books of the 1940's have been republished by Simon & Schuster, and Grove has brought out his latest (seventh) book about films, Underground Cinema, some clearer estimate of Tyler's qualities as a film critic might be attempted.

title: On the cover:
description: Jacquard knits for boys or girls are one of the strongest notes in children's fashions for fall. Boy's (or girl's) sweater in brown, orange and white comes with brown knitted pants, its own cap (not shown). Piccolino. 2 to 4, $28; 4 to 6x, $32. Sixth floor, Bergdorf's. The girl's sweater is an Aztecpatterned turtleneck with matching long pants. By Justin Charles. S. M. L. Sweater, $5.50. Pants, $6.50. The second floor at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Bengals Win No. 2
description: DETROIT, Aug. 14 (UPI) Ken Anderson, a rookie quar terback, hit on scoring passes of 54 yards to Speedy Thomas and 6 yards to Tom Smith as the Cincinnati Bengals beat the Detroit Lions, 3124, tonight.

title: WORK LOAD SPLITS COLLEGE IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 14  A job action has been threat ened by the faculty negotiating committee at Nassau Commu nity College if the teaching load is increased from 12 to 15 hours a week when the fall term opens on Sept. 16.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: It's been a dismal year so far for the paper industry and the nearterm outlook isn't much brighter, but hap pier days may be ahead in 1972 and 1973.

title: EUGENE MOONEY, 64, OF AMERICAN BRANDS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 14 Eugene F. Mooney, a vice president of the American To bacco Company and a director of American Brands, Inc., the parent company, died today in Greenwich Hospital.

description: To the Financial Editor: The article by Edwin L. Dale Jr., titled, Steady In flation: Would It Be So Bad? (Aug. 8) contained certain statements that require cor rection.

title: 90 BOYS IN A TEST AT FORDHAM PREP
description: Fordham Prep, on the Rose Hill Campus of Fordham Uni iversity in the Bronx, is conduct ing a program that its officials feel should eventually reduce the traditional fouryear high school course to three years.

title: Karen Elizabeth Taylor Married
description: RENO, Aug. 14Miss Karen Elizabeth Taylor was mar ried to Lawrence Clarke An derson here this afternoon by the Rev. Ernest Troutner, a Methodist minister.

title: Australia Allows Few Visitors To a Small Paradise in Pacific
description: KAVIENG, New Ireland, July 26Imagine one southwestern Pacific atoll where there are no tourists, no missionaries and no mosquitoes, the Polynesian girls are companionable and there are no diseases.

title: Darwin Kinsman, 94, Calls Everglades His Home
description: EVERGLADES CITY, Fla., Aug. 14  Ninetyfouryearold Arthur Darwin has 2,100 square miles he calls home  Ever glades National Park.

title: OBSERVER
description: The recent unseasonal flurry of political news in New York reminds us that although all is now sweet summer across America the air will soon be thick with Presidential candi dates attacking, berating, calling for, challenging, charging, condemning, de claring, decrying, demanding and doing all those other dynamic Presidential candidate things from escalating cam paign tempo to zeeing Red threat undiminished, without which American politics would be the poorer in farcical content.

title: Pupil Transferred by Wallace Was in Black School by Error
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 14 The school authorities have disclosed that a high school girl who has been the focus of at tention since Gov. George C. Wallace ordered her transfer from a predominantly black school to a predominantly white school nearer her home should have been in a different pre dominantly white school to start with.

title: BOOK CASTS DOUBT ON JUSTICE IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 14 (UPI) Three reporters who covered the trials of men charged in the assassinations of President Kennedy, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Senator Robert F. Kennedy have con cluded that American justice works accidentally, if at all.

title: Miss Walker, C. R. Stapleton Plan Wedding
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., Aug. 14  Miss Dorothy Bush Walker, a granddaughter of the late George Herbert Walker, investment banker and donor of the Walker Cup in BritishAmerican amateur golf, will be married to Craig Roberts Stapleton in Octo ber.

title: The Poems of Catullus
description: The reasons for the renewed ap peal of Catullus in the last few years are obvious, not to say ostentatious. He spoke for the new poets, or neoterics, against the Ro man literary establishment; he was cheerfully obscene, colloquial, often scurrilously impatient with politi cians, and rejected public values in favor of private onesin the same years that Cicero, was intoning the national virtues of fides and foedus (faith and covenant') Catullus re served the words for the relation ship of individuals, usually that be tween his mistress Lesbia and him self. And, finally, he had the good grace to die at (probably) the un speakable age of 30.

title: Parley Urged on Nixon
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 14 (AP)Gov. Robert W. Scott of North Carolina urged President Nixon today to call a meeting of key school officials to dis cuss the busing of schoolchil dren to desegregation.

title: Mucic
description: AT a recent television show in Paris, a 12 yearold girl rose from the audience and asxed pianist Alexis Weissen berg, How does it feel to be important? I don't know, he answered, somewhat taken aback. Well, aren't you im portant? she insisted. I can only tell you, he replied, while I am working I have to feel important, otherwise I would not be able to go on.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I believe that the steady deterioration of the camp grounds in our national parks is due to two changes that have taken place over the last 10 years. First, the type of people who come camping has changed dramatically. Campers used to be friendly, not frightened, and were al ways willing to extend a help ing hand. They showed con cern. Second, and perhaps more important, the reason people camp has changed. No longer do people walk in the evening moonlight; in stead, they retire into their trailers to watch TV or play cards. Some, as stated in the parks article, lie in the fields having parties, getting artifi cial highs and leaving gar bage. They are certainly not there to rough it. Two years ago at Mount Rainier, there was only one tent besides ours. The other campers came in their trailers, not looking for America's beauty but for a cheap vacation with the kids. To longtime camp ers I offer some advice: The farther away you go and the more strenuous the activity you participate in, the easier it will be to find the return of the nostalgic days of true camping and campers.

title: Kurt Luckner Weds Miss Raubitschek
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 14Miss Agathokleia Raubit schek and Kurt Thomas Luckner were married at noon today in the Stanford Memorial Church. The Roman Catholic ceremony was con celebrated by the Rev. Fran cis G. Deevy of Fairfield (Conn.) University and the Rev. William M. A. Grimaldi of Fordham University.

title: Giants, Eagles Play Aug. 28 In New Jersey Jaycee Game
description: The New York Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles will meet Aug. 28 in the 10th annual New Jersey Jaycee football game in Princeton's Palmer Stadium. The Eagles have won five of the nine games played in the series.

title: Doctors Ask Supreme Court To Ease Curbs on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) A major segment of the med ical profession is trying to per suade the Supreme Court to ease restrictions on therapeutic abortions.

description: Selected community leaders in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn have rejected an offer from the Kings County Addictive Diseases Hospital to establish a comprehensive 600 patient drug abuse treatment center in their community.
