title: Dr. Thomas Briggs, 94, Dies; Professor at Teachers College
description: MEREDITH, N. H., Aug. 14 Dr. Thomas H. Briggs, emeritus professor, of education at Teach ers College, Coltimbia Univer Sit who, from 1912 to 1942 played a le in training thou sands of school leaders, died Thursday at his home here. He was 94 years old.

title: Mary Louise Wazeter Fiancee Of Charles Robinson, a Lawyer
description: HASTINGS ON  HUDSON, N.Y., Aug. 14Miss Mary Louise (Zaza) Wazeter, prod uct development manager with Dansk Designs, Inc., in Mount Kisco, will be married Sept. 18 to Charles R. Robin son in St. Stanislaus Roman Catholic Church in New York. The future bridegroom is senior partner in Weinstein, Tashman & Robinson, a New York law firm.

title: Prisoners Riot in Bay State
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 14 (AP)  About 100 prisoners at the Worcester House of Cor rections rioted for an hour and a half tonight, taking over a wing of the prison for a time and injuring two inmates. The police said the riot broke out while the inmates were watch ing televison. No cause was given.

title: Records Subpoenaed by U. S in Atlantic County Corruption Inquiry
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 14 The Federal grand jury inves stigating corruption in New Jer sey has issued 40 subpoenas for local officials and contractors in the Atlantic County area, in an investigation reportedly fo cussing on multimilliondollar construction projects.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 3 Antiliberal Factions Leaving Presbyterian Church in South
description: Three conservative and in dependent groups in the Pros byterian Church in the United States, dissatisfied with what they term liberal denomination al leanings, last week took the first formal steps toward form ing a new denomination.

title: WHITE SOX SCORE OVER ORIOLES, 20
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 14 (UPI) Bart Johnson struck out Boog Powell withthe bases loaded in the eighth inning and Frank Robinson with two on in the ninth to preserve Tom Bradley's 12th triumph tonight as the Chicago White Sox beat Mike Cuellar and the Baltimore Orioles, 20.

description: BUENA VISTA Colo., Aug. 14 (AP)Eric Evans of Han over, N.H., recaptured the na tional whitewater kayak sla the Arkansas River.

description: A GUIDE BOOK OF UNITED STATES COINS, by Richard S. Yeoman, was re vised for 1972 as a silver an niversary edition and recently was released by the Whitman Hobby Division of the West ern Publishing Company of Racine, Wis.

title: Lung Transplant Repaired
description: CAPETOWN, Aug. 14 (UPI) Adrian Herbert, a heartand rungs transplant patient, under wentwent surgery last night for the third time since his July 25 transplant, a spokesman at Groote Schuur Hospital said today. He said that surgeons had operated on a new leak in the right lung. Mr. Herbert's condition is now satisfactory and his new heart and lungs are functioning well, the spokesman said.

title: LINDSAY BIDS U.S. QUADRUPLE ITS AID FOR JOBLESS HERE
description: Mayor Lindsay requested $62.9million from the Federal Government yesterday to pro vide 8,216 municipal jobs  including 2,000 teaching posi tionsunder a Federal pro gram designed to combat un employment.

title: CANADA PLANNING A PARK IN YUKON
description: WHITEHORSE, Yukon Ter ritory, Aug. 8After years of successful opposition by the wellentrenched mining indus try in the Yukon, the Canadian Government is moving to es tablish a national park in the St. Elias Mountains, the highest range in North America.

title: The 12Year Reich
description: The Nazi era will continue for long time as a treasuretrove for the historian and sociologist. So much has been written about it already, yet only the surface has been scratched. Biographies of Rudolf Hess and Alfred Rosenberg are on the way, and yet another of Hitler, And with all the writing that has already been done, there is still no general view as to why the German people brought, or allowed the Nazis to be brought to power, or why Nazi rule turned into something so utterly evil. A great deal of patient analysis has still to be carried out. This is where Richard Grunberger's book is so valuable. He has pro duced in it a social autopsy of the Nazi era, obviously incomplete but with a wealth of documentation and detail. His is the sort of book that helps to explain who the Nazis really were, in chapters to which he has given headings such as Wom en, Youth, Justice, Religion, The Army, and so on.

title: V.F.W. CHIEF AMENDS REMARKS ON P.O.W.'s
description: DALLAS, Aug. 14 (UPI) Herbert R. Rainwater, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, denied last night that he had inside informa tion American prisoners of war in North Vietnam would be home before Christmas.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: My suitcase, which I had given to the clerk at an air line counter at Kennedy Air port, failed to appear when arrived in Copenhagen last summer, and to this day it is still missing. Since I travel with only one, large suitcase, everything was lost; and when all of one's traveling valuables are in one container, the total value is obviously quite high. The items in my bag included a camera, strobe light, binoc ulars, flycasting equipment and electric razor, as well as much clothing. I calculated the value at over $1,200. After having to waste time shop ping for basic articles of clothing while on vacation, soon learned that no one is legally responsible for the major part of the loss in curred. The airline representa tive merely pointed to the fine print on the plane ticket and offered the maximum settlement of approximately $330. One only becomes aware of this sort of discrepancy when one's suitcase is lost: otherwise the fine print is there to be ignored. If the air lines were obliged to clearly bring the figure of $330 to the eyes of travelers, every one would take proper pre cautions to avoid such treat ment and costly losses.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WASHINGTON  The corn year just ahead  they run from Oct. 1 to Sept. 30  will spread a bountiful 30 per cent more nourishment before the nation's steers, hogs and chickens. What it will do for the next con sumer  of steaks, ham burgers, pork chops and chicken parts  can't be stated so positively.

title: Italy Weighing Stiff Penalties for Art Fraud
description: ROME, Aug. 14Legislation now before the Italian Parlia ment would introduce heavy fines and prison sentences for fakers of ancient and modern art.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Frustrated Middle Man agers by Michael C. Jensen (July 18) omitted several basic situations and pertinent questions.

title: HalfPast Summer
description: MidAugust, and the crickets and the katydids leave no doubt about what time it is. It is halfpast summer. We are halfway down the daylight slope toward the September equinox and autumn. The daylight span now is more than an hour and a quarter shorter than it was in June. Sunrise approaches six o'clock in the morning.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Yosemite and many others of our originally fine national parks had hit the skids 10 years or more ago, long be fore the kids came on the scene. The combination of cars, tent cities, trailer parks, cocktail lounges, laundromats, parking lots and other junk collected by lazy campers and empire  building Park Service personnel had more deeply scarred the landscape than any forest fire. Yosemite Valley was a dump in 1960; it just must be more of a dump today. Who can blame the kids, who are, after all, at tracted by the various refuse heaps of American society? Moreover, who can blame them for wanting to use the junk which American society foists off on them? Mailorder houses encourage them to buy motorcycles that are built ex pressly for use on lawns and in the woods; the law will not permit their use on our streets and highways. Television com mercials tempt them with new, threewheel, extrasturdy bikes by showing youth roaring into the underbrush (perhaps one of our wildlife preserves) The hifi and tape deck industry didn't build in all those decibels so they could be kept quiet under some rock.

title: Art
description: ONE of the most effective things about the very effective Ways of Looking show now on view at the Museum of Modern Art is the show itself. By this, I don't mean dramatic lighting or glamorous staging: the 175 works of painting, sculpture, drawing and assemblage have been crowded into a bare 2,500 square feet of exhibition space in a quite straight forward fashion. The installation, in fact, is reminiscent of a 19thcentury salon exhibition, with the pictures hanging on the walls, tier upon tier, and the sculp tures disposed about the gallery on pedestals.

title: Beard to Play Weekends
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 14 (UPI)  The National Basketball Association Cleveland Cavaliers said today that Butch Beard, a former Louisville allAmeri can now serving two years ac tive duty in the Army, would be able to train with the team during the exhibition schedule, and play weekend games during the regular season.

description: Major Worden, the man who stayed in orbit while the others surveyed the moon and later ventured outside the spacecraft on a walk of his own, had once told his mother that he would give his right arm to fly into space.

title: Pop
description: JIMMY RUSHING: The You and Me That Used to Be (RCA Victor). In recent years, almost nothing has been heard on records by Jimmy Rushing despite the renewed interest in the blues and the fact that Rushing is one of the most distinctive of blues singers. In fact, the only latterday breakthrough on records for Rushing came when William Weilbacher, an advertising man who is a Rushing fan, became so distressed at the lack of current recorded Rushing that he made some records on his own and there by started what is now a successful mailorder label, Master Jazz Recordings (Box 570, Lenox Hill Station, New York, N. Y. 10021).

description: A plainclothes policeman was shot twice in the head last night in a shootout at a busy Harlem intersection.

title: Screen: Karen Sperling's 'Make a Face' Arrives
description: "And living hereis that to conceal the fact that you're a wealthy young lady?" The answer is no. And since "here" happens to be a respectable number of high-ceilinged rooms in one of those Central Park West tenements in the 70's (the Dakota, in point of fact), one might wonder why the question was ever asked. However, he who asks is a Daddy-appointed psychiatrist, and one must expect the least. And she who answers is a solitary young woman, almost a recluse in her splendid apartment, alone with her dog, her art, her radio, her television and her many imagined or perhaps real terrors. She has more important things than her wealth to conceal. And it turns out that she owns the dear old building anyway.Her name is Nina. She is played by Karen Sperling, who also produced, and for the most part wrote and directed, "Make a Face," which opened yesterday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema. Although it is pretty much a one-woman movie (excepting bit parts for the psychiatrist, a young friend, a few hallucinations and telephone voices ranging from grandma to a whispering assassin), "Make a Face" is by no means a one-character movie, since Nina splits into three and possibly four personalities  perhaps including the one that unaccountably changes the window shades, orders the $47 worth of Chinese food she doesn't want and dismantles her apartment when she's out."Make a Face" deals in images at several levels of awareness, sometimes consecutively  as when it cuts between Nina talking and Nina appearing in the mirror-fragment constructions that are her art work and are the film's most straightforward and, curiously, most evocative sign of its intention  and sometimes simultaneously, as when it has Nina on television discussing her work, while behind her a dimmer and larger TV transmission of a nude Nina makes love, and then the camera backs up to reveal that the television screen is itself a television picture, and so on, as if projected into a series of repeating mirrors.Many of Nina's fantasies are sexual, and many of them involve a dark, menacing leather-jacketed young man who keeps appearing in the elevator and outside her door and in her hallwayonly to disappear when she tries to show him to anyone else. He may be hallucination, or he may be the roommate of the transvestite downstairs, who may also be hallucination, and he may be real. In any case, he is a figure of terror, but he is not entirely unwelcome.What Nina lets into her world is a kind of sound-and-light show, pictures and broadcasts, dealing with the current state of the planet's public misery. But what gets into her world, without invitation, is a more subtle blend of expectation and anxiety, provocation and intimidation. It is on this level that "Make a Face" comes closest to making a movie.By no means a dishonorable or uninteresting project, "Make a Face" seems to lack the spirit of its ambitionsthough it clearly has the will, and the intelligence, and almost too much of the technical apparatus. Miss Sperling herself, a very handsome, reserved girl, is not enough of an actress to make her situation as exciting or even as disturbing as it is meant to be. Since she is never absent from the film, by voice or image or both, it is finally the wrong sort of strain to have to wonder not what she is feeling, but whether she is feeling anything at all.There is in "Make a Face" the seed of a mystery story that might be more terrifying and more fun than the mystery of personality that is actually its central subject. For the evil genius in Nina's world is her father, a disembodied telephone voice, who would love to control the property she has inherited and who might not be above producing Nina's nightmares for his own benefit.In this regard Miss Sperling's work at least recalls the cinema of Fritz Lang, especially the magnificent, trashy Mabuse films with their bogus supernature, their psychological traps, their claustrophobia and voyeurism developed in a vocabulary of images very like Miss Sperling's.She is not really making that kind of movie yet, and I don't know whether she wants to. But I think she has the imagination for it, and I hope that she will try again and succeed.

title: Investigating an Investigation
description: If the New York City Council were anything more than the somnolent, disgracefully ineffective body that it is, it would long ago have launched a vigorous investigation of the city's mortgage loan program designed to foster the rehabilitation of slumarea housing. The full dimen sions of the scandal afflicting this vital program are only now beginning to emerge because a single member of the CouncilManhattan CouncilmanatLarge Robert I. Postelhas refused to be intimidated by a backward looking councilmanic leadership or the coldness of other city officials.

title: $2 Suffragette Sill Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) An upstate New York Con gressman is joining with 18 of his colleagues in sponsoring measure to put the likeness of Susan B. Anthony, a 19th century suffragette, on a new twodollar bill. The office of Representative Frank Horton, a Republican from Rochester, to day announced that the law maker was backing a move to put the picture of Miss Anthony, who was also from. Rochester, on the new currency.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Col onlalism10:30 A.M.

title: NEW HAVEN'S EIGHT TAKES SENIOR TITLE
description: ST. CATHARINES, Aug. 15 The New Haven Rowing Club won the eightoared title and the Hanlon Memorial Trophy today at the 89th Royal Can adian Henley regatta. A strong headwind from 15 to 20 miles an hbur roughened the water and made steering difficult.

title: STEEL MILLS FACE PRICE CONFUSION
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug., 15  A major test of steel prices was indicated last weelt.

title: Talk Causes Networks Only Minor Difficulties
description: President Nixon's special economic report to the na tion last night caused only minor difficulties for the four television networks that car ried the speech even though it came at prime time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: My husband has a dependent far ily. Every month he goes to his em ployment office (in this case, called his job) to pick up a check which he uses to support himself and that family. Each time, he can decide whether or not to work for another month and another check.

title: Fairfield County Catholics Get a Greater Voice
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 15 Bishop Walter W. Curtis promulgated sweeping changes affecting 300,000 Roman Cath olics in Fairfield County tonight at an unusual diocesan synod that included laymen.

title: E. GERMAN WOMEN SET TRACK MARKS
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 15 (AP)  East German women set two world records today as the 10th European track and field championships ended.

title: Nova Scotia Threatened By Hurricane in Atlantic
description: MIAMI., Aug. 15 (AP)Hur ricane Beth, with winds of up to 85 miles an hour, headed to ward Nova Scotia today as it swept northeastward at about 20 miles an hour from a posi tion 200, miles southsouthwest of Halifax.

title: Jamaica Seizes 4 Americans
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Aug. 15 (AP)Four Americans and a Jamaican have been arrested and charged with possession of marijuana, the police said to day. They identified the Ameri cans as Daniel Marsh, Andrew Mariman, and Mark Winder, all of Yonkers, N. Y., and Carole Marone, a former New Yorker now living here.

title: Nee Wins 5,000Meter Run
description: Dennis Nee of Babylon, L.I., a student at Emporia Kan., State College won the 5,000 meter run conducted by the New Road Road Runners Club yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, Nee, competing for the New York Athletic Club, was clocked in 15 minutes 25.2 minutes. Joe Boyle, a clubmate, was second, Joe Quaderer of the New York A.C. third.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: What is our specific commitment to South Vietnam as of now? Is it to up hold and protect the democratic proc ess or is there a continuing policy to which the public is not privy?

title: ECOLOGISTS FIGHT DAM IN CAROLINA
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Aug. 15 North Carolina conservation ists have filed suit for an in junction against the Army Corps of Engineers in an effort to stop further construction of the $40million New Hope Dam in Chatham County.

title: Chess: Byrne and Browne Share Laurels in Speed Tourney
description: Running true to form two grandmasters, Robert Byrne of New York and Walter Browne of Australia, scored 101 apiece to tie for first place in the Eastern Speed championship, played at the McAlpin Hotel a few days ago. Eugene Myer of Wood stock, N. Y., was next, with 82, and four players, Rudi Blumenfeld, Danny Ko pec, Dr. Ariel Mangerini and Doug Pader, all of New York City, tied at 83.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: You certainly are presumptuous to write an editorial about the Repub lican party and President Nixon (July 12).

title: Roundup: Alou, ExPirate, Caps Card 4Game Sweep
description: Matty Alou, the middle man in the trio of baseball playing brothers from the Dominican Republic, got in four satisfying swats at his former employer, the Pirates, yesterday and in the process put Pittsburgh's domina tion of the National League Eastern Division in jeopardy.

title: Iran Kills 5 as Drug Agents
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 15 (AP) Firing squads executed five more persons today as drug agentes. The executions in Teheran, Kerman and Rizaiyeth brought the number of people executed for drug offenses in the country in the last two years to 101.

title: Hate Pursues British Troops in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ire land, Aug. 15 They walk slowly down darkened Spring field Road, gripping loaded submachine guns and gaz ing at the narrow streets covered with glass, piles of brick and burnedout furni ture.

title: Personal Finance
description: If you've been trying to fi nance the purchase of a boat but have been getting the runaround even though your credit is good, the chances are very strong that it's all because of a bit of highly important mumbo jumbo known as holder in due course.

title: FundRaising Outlays Found High in Campaigns
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 15The cost of raisin, campaign funds is so high that less than one half of every dollar collected by some committees goes to a candidate.

title: Peru and Australia Tied, 11, In Stevens Cup Net Finals
description: Peru and Australia split the first two singles matches in their elimination finals for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Vishinsky Guilty of Errors, New Soviet Volume Asserts
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15 (Reuters) Stalin's onetime prosecutor, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, one of the leading figures of the Moscow show trials in the nineteen thirties, comes under criticism in a new Russian work for serious errors.

title: News Analysis
description: SMUT, Lebanon, Aug. 15 In the ten and a half months since President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt died, Arab poli tics have become considerably freer and more relaxed, as well as more diffuse and chaotic, according to Arab journalists, politicians and Western diplo mats here. Some Arabs lament the lack of a rally ing point and com plain about the in creasing boldness of Mr. Nassees former rivals in the Arab world. Others bask in the new flexibility.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: How lovely it is to see The Times and the Nixon Administration once more locked in passionate embrace over the China representation question in the U.N. [editorial Aug. 4] after the dispute over the Pentagon papers. Would that The Times take a coura geous position on the China question as well.

title: MEXICO WORRIED BY DRUG PROBLEM
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15 Mexico's rising concern about her own, drug problem is lead ing her to increased cooperation with the United States in the fight against producers and dis tributors of narcotics here.

title: Theater: Black Festival
description: The Black Theater Al liance, a federation of black theaters, is presenting a monthlong Black Theater Festival at the St. Marks Playhouse, the home of the Negro Ensemble Company. The opening play, which saw Saturday evening, was Herbert Campbell's Middle Class Black, a production from Delano Stewart's Bed Stuy Theater.

title: Idaho Inmates Are Kept in Cells Alter Model Prisoner Is Slain
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 15 (AP) Inmates at the Idaho Peni tentiary were kept locked in their cells today as a precau tion against renewed rioting while officials investigate the slaying last night of a model prisoner. The body of a con victed murderer, William Henry Butler, 27 years old, of Bayonne, N. J., was found in the prison gymnasium, wrapped in a wrestling mat. He had been stabbed several times.

title: Symbols and Ritual Turn Trick Dance Into a Religious Solo
description: William Dunas, choreogra pher and dancer, has gone far toward turning the concert solo into a life style. During the last several years no one has cre ated solo dances so exclusive ly, so assiduously, and with such positive results as he. Saturday afternoon on the roof of the Tears Realty Company, 330 Broome Street, he present ed a beautifully shaped new work called The Trick.

title: MISS HAYNIE'S 206 TAKES IMRE OPEN
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 15 (AP)SP.ndra Haynie, trailing by three strokes with four holes to play, sank a 12foot putt on the last hole, her third successive birdie, for a five underpar 67 today and a 54 hole total of 206 to win the $25,000 Immke open title.

title: JAPAN WEIGHS LOAN TO LATINAID AGENCY
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (Reuters) The Japanese Finance Ministry, said this weekend it was con sidering a Joan to the Inter American Development Bank of Washington.

title: Donohue Takes TransAm
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Aug. 15 (UPI)Mark Donohue of Media, Pa., raced his Javelin past George Follmer's spinning Mustang today and won the Glen TransAmerica race for his fifth consecutive victory in the Sports Car Club of America's sedan series.

title: DOWNPOUR FLOODS PINELLAS PARK, FLA.
description: PINELLAS PARK, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP)Torrential rains, up to an inch an hour, fell on this western Florida city today and forced evacuation of at least 50 families from their flooded homes.

title: In Vietnam, a Menu May Be French but
description: SAIGONIf you want to make poulet a la creme, there aren't any good mushrooms. You can't make Swiss fondue because there's no cheese or kirsch. Two years ago they stopped importing wines. But I suppose we shouldn't com plain. There's a war on, said Madame Madeleine Leccia, proprietor of the Guillaume fell restaurant in Saigon.

title: K.G.B. Spying and Brutality
description: The protest of Russia's most brilliant writer and Nobellaureate, Aleksandr r. Solzhenitsyn, about Soviet secret police harassment provides shocking confirmation that less has changed since Stalin's days than the world had hoped.

title: Jersey Man Drowned
description: WILDWOOD CREST, N.J., Aug. 15 (AP)Manford Todd Jr., 45 years old, of Wilwood Crest, was drowned today when he was washed overboard while fishing with two friends in the ocean south of Cape May Point, the police said.

title: Ox Ridge, Paced by Saaf, Ties Toronto Riders, 44
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 15 The Ox Ridge Hunt Club and the Toronto Polo Club played to a 44 tie today.

title: Burglary Suspect Is Shot by Minister At Harlem Church
description: The minister of a Harlem church that has been broken into seven times in the last eight months early yesterday shot a man who, the clergy man said, was trying to loot the building.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP)Ileavy rain last night and today worsened flood con dltions over large sections of Texas. Forecasts called for the downpour to continue.

title: Books of The Times
description: A young Indian novelist, speaking perfect English, recently confronted me with the question: Why were the newest American novelists so difficult to like and under starid? Why, when he appreciated Heming way, Faulkner (about whom he was writing a book), Steinbeck and even Bellow, did he find it hard to respond to such writers as Jack Kcrouac, William Burroughs, John Barth  he reeled off the names with some uncertainty. Because the question didn't have a quick answer and our meet ing had to be short, I passed on the task of answering it to Tony Tanner, whose new book on American fiction was conveniently lying on my desk in the Sunday Book Re view office. I had not read it yet but had confidende in Mr. Tanner as a young Eng lish critic whose interpretations of Ameri can literature combine the astuteness of V. S. Pritchett with the adventuresomeness of Anthony Burgess.

title: PROPOSED RULES STIR BANKERS IRE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Domestic banks are smarting over proposed Treasury De partment regulations setting massive recordkeeping require ments designed to detect illegal activity carried on through United States and foreign bank accounts.

title: Marriage Restrictions Eased For Women in Foreign Service
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) Marriage heed not block a diplomatic career, or vice verse under a new opportiinitiesfor womeri policy adopted by the State Department.

title: Envoy and Wife Handcuffed; Los Angeles Police Apologize
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  The Los Angeles Police Department apologized yesterday for an incident in which the Dominican Repub lic's Consul General and his wife were handcuffed and her elbow broken.

title: Ford Fund Gives $2Million To 5 Community Agencies
description: The Ford Foundation an nounced grants totaling $2,225, 468 to five community devel opment agencies yesterday, United Press International re ported.

title: Princess Anne Turns 21
description: THURSO, Scotland, Aug. 15 (AP)  Princess Anne, only daughter of Queen Elizabeth II and fourth in line of succession to the throne, became 21 years old today.

title: Elizabeth Ann Meyer Is Bride In Hewlett of Henry Koransky
description: HEWLETT, L. I., Aug. 15 Miss Elizabeth Ann Meyer, daughter of Mt. and Mrs. Max B. Meyer, was married here this afternoon to Henry Ar thur Koransky; son of Dr. and Ws. Abraham Koransky of Highland Park, Ill.

title: Dr. Loomis Havemeyer Dead; On Yale Staff Over 50 Years
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 15Dr. Loornis Havemeyer, who retired officially as registrar of the Yale University School of Engineer ing in 1954, but continued un officially as registrar of the Yale undergraduate schedules, died last night in Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: Thieu's Political Brinkmanship
description: The recall of Ambassador Bunker to Washington for consultations reflects the dangerous situation that has arisen in South Vietnam's presidential election campaign. There is a widespread belief that President Thieu is rigging the electionmost blatantly through the maneu vers used to block the candidacy of the country's Vice President, Air Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky. Threats of with drawal are being made by the only remaining challenger, Gen. Duong Van (Big) Minh, and many of his backers.

title: Cambodia Is Planning To Replace Saigon Units
description: PNOM PENH, Cambodia, Monday, Aug. 15 (Reuters) The Cambodian high com mand announced today that plans were being worked out for the withdrawal of South Vietnamese ttoops from their major base of operations along the Mekong River.

title: PATRIOTS DEFEAT GIANTS, 20 T0 14, IN NEW STADIUM
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 15 The New York Giants, did their share to make the opening of football's newest stadium a suc cess tonight. They gave the New England Patriots their first taste of victory over a premerger National Football League team, and they showed up with enough players to make possible a close game for a crowd of 60,423, the largest to see a sport event in New Eng land north of the Yale Bowl.

title: OldTime Hobo Yielding Read to Questing Youth
description: BRITT, Iowa, Aug. 14He sat on an old park bench, talking about the road.

title: Packers Not So Devine: Need Speed and Passer
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 15 The current bumper sticker here says, The Pack Is Devine. The reference is to the Packers and their new coach, Dan Devine. The sticker is less ambitious than its predecessor, The Pack Will Be Back.

title: U.S. Ship Docks at Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Aug. 15 (AP)  The destroyer Furse arrived here today, the first United States warship to an chor in Istanbul since bloody rioting in protest against such visits took four lives on Feb. 16, 1969.

title: 15 Injured by Carnival Ride
description: WEST POINT, Iowa, Aug. 15 (UPI)Fifteen persons were in jured last night when a carnival ride collapsed at the annual Sweet Corn Festival here, trap ping two workmen under the debris. Eleven persons were re leased after treatment at a hos pital in Fort Madison. Four re mained hospitalized today in fair condition.

title: NIXON ORDERS 90DAY WAGEPRICE FREEZE, ASKS TAX CUTS, NEW JOBS IN BROAD PLAN:
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 President Nixon charted a new economic course tonight by or dering a 90day freeze on wages and prices, requesting Federal tax cuts and making a broad range of domestic and international moves designed to strengthen the dollar.

title: MAURICE K. GOTTFRIED
description: WESTPORT, N. Y., Aug. 15  Maurice K. Gottfried, retired president of the Silvercup Bakers, Inc., died Thursday at his home here. He was 64 years old and also lived in Bay Har bor, Fla.

title: Italians on Holiday Abandon the Cities
description: ROME, Aug. 15  About a million cars left this city of three million people this As sumption Day weekend, part of the mass exodus of Italians who have left their homes to go to the seacoasts, mountains and lake regions for their annual holidays.

title: Call to Economic Revival
description: After months of drift, President Nixon has moved with startling decisiveness to stabilize the dollar and spur economic growth. The comprehensiveness of the program he announced last night makes immediate assessment of all its details impossible, but we unhesitatingly applaud the boldness with which the President has moved on all economic frontsand most especially his order for a ninetyday freeze on prices And wages as a preliminary to a flexible policy for checking the runaway spiral that has eroded the purchasing power of all Americans and made American products increasingly uncompetitive in world markets.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: AREQUIPA, Peru, Aug. 15 (AP)Peru will vote in favor of Communist China's admission to the United Nations at next General Assembly, Foreign Min ister Edgardo Mercado Jarrin said yesterday.

title: States Act to Curb Welfare Expansion
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15A decade of liberalization and expansion of the nation's welfare program has come to a halt this year, with state after state focusing on public assistance programs to cut costs.

title: Mayor Asks Help of State And Ronan on 30Cent Fare
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday made two strong appeals to save the 30cent subway and bus fare, asserting that higher rates would cause economic hardship and in some cases economic catastrophe for New Yorkers.

title: Case for School Change
description: The report by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's investi gators of unrest in the New York City high schools is a depressing documentnot because of any specific new revelations but rather because its findings repeat and confirm what critical observers have been saying for years. It is scandalous and discouraging that so many obvious remedies for the deteriorating atmosphere in the schools have been so long ignored.

title: REACTION MIXED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 Politicians and political econo mists who commented on Presi dent Nixon's speech tonight drew careful distinctions be tween the domestic and inter national elements of the pack age.

title: U.S. Urged to Accept Socialism in Hemisphere
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) A study by the Organization of American States declares that the United States must accept the movement toward socialism in some LatinAmer ican countries.

title: L. I. School Vandalized
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Aug. 15The automotive shop of the W. Tresper Clarke Public High School here was destroyed early today by a fire apparently ignited by a stolen automobile driven into the shop's loading doors. No one was in the car when the authorities arrived.

title: J.W.V. Elects Commander
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 15 (UPI) Jerry Cohen of Staten Island, a highly decorated veteran of World War II who campaigns to have the Jewish War Vet erans change its stand on the war in Southeast Asia has been elected national commander o the group. He told the group's convention yesterday that he would give first priority to the problems facing eterans re turning from Vietnam.

title: New Rules Set Rigid Standards In Children's Sleepwear Safety
description: Aside from the extra work load that manufacturers will have in producing flameresist ant sleepwear for children, they will have the formidable task of complying with Federal Trade Commission rulings on labeling, advertising and pro motion of the product.

title: Watts in Nuremberg: A Piano Virtuoso Comes Home
description: NUREMBERG, West Ger many, Aug. 15Andre Watts, the young American pianist, spent a strenuous but trium phant day of homecoming at this ancient German city where he was born soon after the war, the son of a black American G.I. and a Hungarian mother.

title: Explosion Destroys Home
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) An explosion ripped through a home in northeast Washing ton today, destroying the build ing and killing two persons in ide. Fire officials said that they believed a faulty water heater installed just last week might have been the cause.

title: Turbotrain Kills Boy
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 15 (AP) An unidentified boy was struck and killed today by an experimental Turbotrain mak ing a 31state tour to test public reaction to high  speed rail service. The police said that he had been jumping off a trestle into a lake and was just about to dive when he was hit by the highspeed train.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15The following is a list of inans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: WNET Seeks the Right Forrnula
description: A television station in search of an image. That just about sans up the curious history of New York's Channel 13. How ever, recent conversations with station executives and with of ficials in other areas of public television indicate the current searchers may at last be on the rightor at least the most, promisingwave length.

title: Big Push in Exports Narrows Yugoslav Trade Gap
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 15Preliminary trade figures for July made public here re cently show Yugoslavia signifi cantly increasing her exports and marginally reducing her imports for the first time since the dinar was devalued in January.

title: Democratic Chiefs Assess Lindsay's Role in Party
description: Democratic leadersReform and regularhave been meet ing in small groups to assess Mayor Lindsay's role in the party. They plan to confer with him soon to determine how they can work together.

title: Jordan Hangs Two as Spies
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 15 (Reuters)  Jordan said that two Jordanians, one a soldier, were hanged today after being found guilty of spying for Is rael. They were said to have been arrested Dec. 1, 1969 in possession of military secrets.

title: Peruvian Aide, in Peking, To Establish Trade Mission
description: PEKING, Aug. 15 (Agence FrancePresse)Miguel Baran darian, the first Peruvian rep resentative to be accredited to Peking, arrived here today. He had been Consul General in Hong Kong and is to establish a Peruvian trade mission in Peking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times of Aug. 9 quotes the president of the New York Public Library as saying that the library was forced to curtail hours (it now closes at 6 P.M. every day and is not open at all on Saturdays, Sundays or holi days) because of the deficit in the library's finances. This may explain the present schedule of hours, which makes it impossible for thousands of people to use the library at all: it does not justify it.

title: JAMES SWACKHAMER, ARCHITECT IN JERSEY
description: WHITEHOUSE STATION, N.J., Aug. 15James A. Swack hamer, a past president of the New Jersey Society of Archi tects, died today at his home here after a long illness. He was 46 years old.

title: STUDY FINDS ELITE ON HOSPITAL BOARDS
description: CHICAGO, Aug 15 (AP)  A report on a study conducted in Detroit says the boards of non profit hospitals there are domi nated by the financially af fluent and socially elite almost to the exclusion of the general public and those the hospitals serve.

title: C.B.S. Acquires XActo, Inc.
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., announced over the weekend that it has ac quired, for an undisclosed amount of money, XActo, Inc., a maker of precision knives and tools for hobbyists and crafts men. The products of XActo, a privately owned concern, are distributed throughout this Country, Europe and Japan.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS CHINA ON NUCLEAR POLICIES
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 15 (AP) The Soviet Union accused China today of hypocrisy in its policy on nuclear disarmament and again hinted at collusion be tween Peking and Washington aimed at isolating Russia.

title: 18 ADDICTS ESCAPE; 5 ARE RECAPTURED
description: Eighteen patients escaped from two stateoperated nar cotics rehabilitation centers there over the weekend, but five were captured a short time later.

title: Maine Gets Navigation Aid
description: BOSTON, Aug. 15 (AP)The Coast Guard opened New Eng land's second LORANfor Long Range Aid to Navigationsta tion today at Marshall Point in Port Clyde, Me. The other LORAN station is on Nantucket, off the coast of Massachusetts. The normal radio range of the station, 500 to 700 miles, will enable boatmen to obtain pre cise navigational fixes in the Gulf of Maine in any weather.

title: PENTAGON CONTINUES PAY FOR DEPENDENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Defense Department is openly violating the law by paying more than $18million a month to some military de pendents without Congression al authorizationand Pentagon officials do not plan to stop the payments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In your Aug. 9 issue you give con siderable space to reporting the de plorable closure during evenings and weekends of the New York Public Library. A still more serious curtails ment of services is threatened to oc cur as of Jan. 1 next when the Science and Technology Division will be closed at all times to the public.

title: Brooklyn Woman Held in Death of a Foster Child
description: A 33yearold Brooklyn woman who had been receiving biweekly welfare checks of $193 for the care of three foster children was arraigned on a murder charge yesterday after one of the children was found dead of malnutrition and the others close to starvation and bruised from apparent beatings.

title: Gardner Wins U.S. Tennis, Beating Ramirez in 5 Sets
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 15John Gardner of Australia, seeded third, defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico, the United States junior titleholder, 16, 46, 63, 75, 6.4, to win the United States men's amateur grass court tennis champion ship today at the Meadow Club.

title: Truman Imposed Last WagePrice Controls in 1951
description: The President was strongly against wage and pricel Con troli,but with a war being fought Asia, and inflation at home the Congress granted Standby powers.

title: Evidence to Be Presented Today in Trial of Medina
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 15 (UPI)Capt. Ernest L. Me dina, accused of overall respon sibility for the mass killing at Mylai, faces a courtmartial to morrow, three years and five months after his infantry com pany swept through the South Vietnamese hamlet.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: LONDON, Aug. 15 (AP) Home Secretary Reginald Maud lin, Britain's chief security minister, flew to the Spanish island of Mallorca for a vaca tion yesterday in what was in terpreted here as an outward show of confidence that the British Army had suppressed terrorists in Northern Ireland, at least temporarily.

title: NEWCOMBE IS VICTOR IN CANADIAN TENNIS
description: TORONTO, Aug. 15 (UPI) The Wimbledon Champion, John, Newcombe of Australia, turned back Tom Okker of the Nether lands, 76, 36, 62, 76, today to win the singles title and the $10,000 top prize in the $70,000 Canadian Open tennis cham pionships.

title: Panamanian Is Held Here On Two Narcotics Charges
description: A 36yearold Panamanian was held under $5,000 bail'yes terday in Brooklyn by Criminal Court Judge Charles T. Drago on charges of attempting to sell narcotics and possession of narcotics paraphernalia.

title: Rutgers Students to Pay For Dormitory Damage
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. Y., Aug. 15 (AP)Rutgers sity has begun to charge all students for what it call unprecedented amounts of damage to dormitories ap parently caused only by a minority of students. Those who do not pay will not be allowed to return to classes in September.

title: Hearst Castle Is Reopened
description: SAN SIMEON, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI)The castle of William Randolph Hearst, now a state park, reopened today after 14 bus drivers walked off the job yesterday in a pay dispute. New drivers were brought in. The grounds of the late publisher's estate are so vast that the trip from the parking lot to the castle and back is 10 miles, and buses are needed to carry the tourists.

title: The abused child is the responsibility of the community and society at large because, if he survives, he will strike out society and become the criminal; or the battering parent, tomorrow?
description: The screams carry beyond locked doors and closed windows, but to the doctors who deal with battered children, the sound isn't carrying far enough.

title: Tailspin in Dollar Sector Of Eurobonds Is Severe
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 15  The Current tailspin in the dollar sector of the Eurobond market has become the worst since the 1968 gold crisis, resulting in a, cutback in the size of the most prestigious corporate borrow ing ever planned in this market and the cancellation of another offering.

title: NEW TENANT CODE STIRRING DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15  Six months After the Depart ment of Housing and Urban Development ordered the first standard lease and grievance procedure for 3 million public housing tenants, many local authorities have not complied with the order and the Federal effort is locked in a bitter con troversy;

title: Bridge: Dallas Aces Are Favored To Be U.S. Team in Olympiad
description: Playoff matches this fall will determine the United States Open Team kr the 1972 World Team Olympiad to be played in Miami, Beach, and the Dallas Aces, as reign ing world champions, are the favorites to earn the honor.

title: Myles Standish, 78, Dies; Editor in Norwich, Conn.
description: NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 15 Myles E. Standish, editor emeritus and former editor in chief of The Norwich Bulletin, died yesterday at Uncason Thames Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: EXCHANGES IN TOKYO UNLOADING DOLLARS
description: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 16 (Reuters)The Tokyo exchange market was thrown into confu sion today following reports that the United States had sus pended its pledge to convert foreignheld dollars into gold.

title: jets Specialty Teams Are Nod Squads
description: The Jets will bolster theft special teams with experienced and rested players for Sunday's game with the Giants at the Yale Bowl.

title: Arts Abroad
description: BASEL, Switzerland  What Ralph, Hochhuth is supposed to have done to ward breaking Roman Cath olic taboos with his play The Deputy, Dieter Forte now apparently is doing with Protestant taboos in Martin Luther and Thomas Mtinzer. The play by Forte, a former public relations man, is his first and it has been the biggest suc cess of the year here. Martin Lu tiler and Thomas Milnzer Should not be compared to John Osborne's Luther, al though Forte, too, has read Erik Erikson's psychoanalyti cal essay on Luther. But Forte's Luther is not driven by obsessions. He has no theological problems either, except in his creation of ideological superstructures for use by a rising, capitalism.

title: King Curtis Funeral Rites To Be Held on Wednesday
description: Funeral services for King Curtis, the late saxophonist bandleader, will be held at noon Wednesday at St. Peter's Lu theran Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: New BahrainBritish Pact
description: BAHRAIN, Aug. 15 (AP) Bahrain's ruler, Sheik Isa bin Sulman alKhalifa, and Sir Geoffrey Arthur, the British Resident, signed a new treaty of friendship today. They ex changed notes formally termi nating all previous agreements between the two countries. This Persian Gulf island de clared its independence from Britain yesterday.

title: SIFFERT SCORES IN AUSTRIAN RACE
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 15 (UPI)  Jo Siffert of Switzer land won the Austrian Grand Prix today but Jackie Stewart of Scotland emerged as the 1971 world champion even though he had to drop out 18 laps from the finish.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Farm Foreclosures Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)  Foreclosures on farm mortgages, though still affect ing only a small proportion of all farms, rose in the year ended last March I to the highest level since 1965, an Agriculture Department report indicated to day. It said about 3,600 farm mortgages were foreclosed, up from the yearearlier 2,800. In 1965 there were 4,100 fore closures reported.

title: BERNARD L. SOLOMON
description: LONG BEACH, L. I., Aug. 15 Bernard L. Solomon, who retired in 1950 as president of the National Tile and Marble Com pany, died today of a heart at tack in Long Beach Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 117 Lido Boulevard.

title: Guggenheim Will Auction 47 Works by Kandinsky
description: The Guggenheim Museum will sell at auction a block of works from its collection including 14 paintings and 33 watercolors by Kandinsky and a number of others by Chagall, Leger, Gleizes and MoholyNagy, it has been announced by Peter Lawson Johnston, president of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foun dation. ParkeBernet will hold the auction in New York on Oct. 13, bringing to 97 the number of Kandinskys sold by the museum, 50 having been auctioned through Sotheby's in London in 1964.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The decision of the House of Representatives to cut the military aid to Greece is a repetition of a mistake already twice made (April 1967, September 1968). Undoubtedly, it will have political and military im plications in the relationships of all NATO members.

title: PAKISTAN SILENT ON MUJIB'S TRIAL
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 15 Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the political leader of East Pakis tan was scheduled to have gone on trial for his life five days ago, but there has been no information on his fate.

title: Liontamer, a Chow Chow, Named Lakewood's Best
description: LAKEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 15 Six years ago, Frank Foster Davis judged a 9monthold chow chow, Eastward Lion tamer of Elster at Pasadena, Calif., who was making his ring debut. I gave him his first points that day, recalled the 80yearold judge today after he named the red chow chow best of 1,651 dogs at the Sand and Sea fixture in Ocean County Park.

title: Deadline Comes and Cairo Waits
description: CAIRO, Aug. 15  Still an other deadline in the cease fire between Egypt and Israel, now a year old, arrived today without apparent result.

title: Apollo 16 Rover Displayed
description: KENT, Wash., Aug. 15 (UPI) The lunar Rover that will go to the moon aboard Apollo 16 next March was unveiled during the weekend by the Boeing Company at its space center In this Seattle suburb. About 2,000 Boeing employes and their fam ilies viewed the vehicle, a twin of the first Rover left on the lunar surface by Apollo 15 as tronauts earlier this month.

title: Dallas Downs Darts, 20
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) The Dallas Tornado downed the Washington Darts, 20, to day, extending its lateseason drive for the North American Soccer League's Southern Di vision championship.

title: PROF. JOHN A. HAGMAN
description: Prof. John A. Hagman of the Columbia University School of Engineering died last night at his home at 430 West 116th Street after a twoyear illness.

title: Economic Advisers Who Met With Mr. Nixon
description: Following is a transcript of a state ment broadcast on television by Presi elent Nixon last night in Washington as recarded by The New York Times:

title: Advertising:
description: Apparently the decision as to which, ad agency is to get the $17millionayear Pinto, Mustang and Maverick ac count from Ford has been 99.9 per cent reached. And the winner, equally appar ently, is Grey.

title: Daniel D. Hunter Dies at 63; ExState Department Aide
description: Daniel Dulany Hunter, who was formerly with the Depart ment of State and the Central Intelligence Agency, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his, home in Paris. His age was 63.

title: A's Beat Yanks, 64, for Blue's 22d;
description: The New York Yankees had the great Vida Blue on the ropes before 45,343 persons yesterday, but they let him escape, and he was still in there pitching at the end at the Oak land Athletics rallied for a tumultuous 64 victory at Yankee Stadium.

title: China's Charges of Militarism Worry Japan
description: TOKYO, Aug. 15 (AP)  As Japan marked the 26th anni versary of her surrender in World War II, newspapers here expressed growing concern about China's charges that Japan is reviving militarism to fulfill territorial ambitions ter minated by defeat a quarter of a century ago.

title: Public and Parochial Schools Explore Ways of Helping Each Other Improve Their Education
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 When a third grade class met with the Mayor not long ago to learn about governing the, city, the questions and answers were recorded and broadcast over the public school systeth's FM radio station to numerous other classes in the system in terested in the same subject.

title: Mexico Opens Baja California to Foreign Investors
description: ENSENADA, Mexico, Aug. 2. The forbidden zone of Mexico's Baja California, whose scenic splendors have long been inaccessible to all but the most intrepid travelers, are being opened now to private develop ment by foreign investors for the first time.

title: Beats Petty by Car Length After Torrid Duel for Purse of $15,695
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., Aug. 15Bobby Allison won one of the hardest con tested stock car races of his career, the Yankee 400, today, beating Richard Petty by less than a car length. Allison and Petty gave a magnificent exhi bition of classic driving that epitomized the art of stock car racingAllison in a 1969 Mer cury and Petty in a 1971 Plym outh.

title: Employes of 3M to Share In Extra Pension Money
description: ST. PAUL, Aug. 15 (AP) Employes of the Minnesota Min ing and Manufacturing Company here will share in about $30 million in windfall payments re sulting from a change in the company's pension program.

title: Miss Seligman Is Bride Here
description: Miss Nancy Jane Seligman was married here last even ing to Charles Edwin Wein berg. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, senior rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, performed the ceremony in the Terrace ROom of the Plaza: The couple are graduates of the University of Maryland. Their parents are Mr., and Mrs. Edward F. Seligman and Mr. and. Benjamin Cor nelius Weinberg of Randalls town, Md. The bride's father is a member of Seligman & Seligman, New. York lawyers, and her husband's father is President of the Weinberg Marble & Tile Company, altimore.

title: Dismissal of Maryland Prison Official Protested
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 15 Advocates of penal reform and of improved racial relations within the prison system have been expressing growing con cern over the dismissal last week of Joseph G. Cannon, the Maryland Commissioner of Cor rections.

title: Giants Sweep Mets Series, 61
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 Gil Hodges took batting prac tice before today's game be tween the Mets and Giants., After one.of the manager's line drives bounced over the left centerfield fence, Bob As promonte stepped into the bat tine cage and said:

title: Morton, Staubach Spur Dallas
description: Tom Landry is in an en viable coaching position as he plays a waiting game during the preseason football sched ule.

title: FRENCH HORSES 1, 2; THEN HEAD FOR U.S.
description: ENGHIEN  LES  BAINS, France, Aug. 15Three hours before they were scheduled to board a jet for New York, Une de Mai and Tidalium Polo proved again today that they were the two best trotters in Europe.

title: Carrington Takes Net Final In Pocono Tourney, 64, 64
description: TAMIMENT, Pa., Aug. 15 Art Carrington continued his string of tennis tournament successes today by capturing the fifth annual Tamiment in vitation event at the Pocono resort.

title: GARDNER QUESTIONS NIXON BUSING POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) John W. Gardner, chairman of Common Cause, the citizens lobby, said today that President Nixon's stand on the question of school busing was filled with ambiguity and inconsist ency.

title: Highlights of Nixon Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15Following are the high lights of President Nixon's address tonight:

title: STUDY FINDS RISE IN BOMB THREATS
description: A report by the Conference Board, an independent and non ptofit research organization, says that nine out of 10 major United States companies have been threatened with bombing, and that on, the average a bombing takes place every two hours in the nation.

title: Stockton Wins by Shot at Sutton on 66 for 275
description: SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 15  Dave Stockton, who injured his left leg and had to withdraw here in 1968, produced a fourthround 66 today and won the Massachusetts Classic by one stroke.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: LONDON Aug. 15 (UPI)  Prime Minister Heath met with ministers today for talks on an offer made by Britain and her NATO allies for continued use of facilities on Malta.

title: Contributions From Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) 4 Political affiliates of the labor movement fed more than $1million in campaign contributions into governorship races in 27 states last year, Americans for Constitutional Action reported today.

title: U.S. Raids in Zone Reported
description: SAIGON, Aug. 15 (UPI)  American sources said today that B52 bombers have been making unannounced strikes against enemy supply lines in the southern half of the demili tarized zone this month for the first time since the 1968 halt of the bombing campaign against North Vietnam.

title: Con Edison Cornplaints Can Go Right to the Top
description: Charles F. Luce, board chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company, not only took on telephoned questions from the public yesterday, but also disclosed his own direct office telephone num ber to a television audience.

title: 3 Young Pedestrians Killed By Car on Montauk Highway
description: WESTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 15Three young people were killed here early today when they were struck by a car as they.walked across the Montauk Highway.

title: COMPANIES FOUND ADDING SECURITY
description: Many American corporations are increasing security meas ures to protect themselves from bombing attacks, accord ing to the Conference Board, which has found that nine out of 10 major business concerns in the United States have been threatened with bombing.

title: This Is John Doe, Unknown Soldier
description: WARRINGTONThe somber President, dressed in black, strode to the podium In the East Room of the White Rouse and announced to the press corps that hostilities in Vietnam had ended at exactly 4:32 P.M: (our time).

title: Industry Use of Radioisotopes Is Expanding
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Aug 15 Private industry has established more than 100 companies for the production and processing of radioisotopes since the Gov ernment made the first com mercial shipment from Oak Ridge exactly 25 years ago, said Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: U.S. WARNS HANOI OVER DE ACTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15The United States com mand said today that it viewed with deep concern enemy activity along the demilitarized zone and threatened retaliatory action against the North Viet namese.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE REAL ISADORA: By Victor Seroff. 441 pages pial. Po.

title: Time for Hands On
description: Now that President Nixon has ar ranged to meet with Chou Enlai, can he be induced to sit down with, that other prominent Marxist, Harry Bridges?

title: Eisenhower and Diem
description: GREENWICH, Conn.Several years agolong after I had left Washing ton, long after President Johnson had sent thousands upon thousands of American troops into Vietnam, long after hundreds of them had died there in battlethe phone rang on a warm summer Saturday afternoon at my home here.

title: Georg von Opel, 59, Is Dead; Family Began Motor Works
description: FRANKFURT, Germany, Aug. 15 (AP)  Georg von Opel, a grandson of the founder of the West German Opel Automobile Works, died last night after suffering a heart attack while driving. He was 59 years old.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 15Maiden Lane is a narrow street:just a block long, on the south side of Covent Garden in central London. It is the sort of street that gives London its characterin timate, a little shabby, mixing com merce and homes, echoing history. Andrew Marvell lived there in the seventeenth century, Voltaire for sev eral years in the eighteenth.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Remember 1969? Almost every summer and autumn day in that municipal elec tion year Mayor Lindsay surrounded by charts; com munity leaders or, captive Democratswould proclaim sonic new municipal advance.

title: Luce Says Indian Pl. Delay Costs Power U sers Millions
description: It is costing electricity users here $2million to $3million for every month of delay in starting operations of the vir tually completed second Indian Point nuclear power plant, the chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company said yester tlay.

title: Sports of The Times
description: CENTER MORICHES, L. I., Aug. 15Bill Nungesser drove into National Speedway in the late afternoon, his black, 1965 Dodge Dart looking squatty and nude alongside the hot dragsters, the fashionable highperformance cars, the socalled funny cars and the decal freaks. He paid $10 to race and, after waiting in line near the entrance to the pits, he had his car checked out by a tech inspector caded Pump, who examined the brakes, the steering wheel and the seat belts, then looked over the sixcylinder engine and assigned the car to one of more than 100 possible racing classes.

title: Edward Weltman Weds Amy Luskind
description: WOODMERE, L.I., Aug. 15 The marriage of Miss Amy Susan Luskind, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Lus kindof West Hempstead, to Edward Seth Weltman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul N. Welt man of Valley Stream, took place here today at the home of the bride's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Irving Daniels. Rabbi Milton Resnickoff per folioed the ceremony.

title: Advertiding:
description: The State of Nevv York, in Its infinite wisdom lifted re strictions month on the sale of alcoholic beverages in metal containers. As, a result, the battle over the tanned cocktail market has come to the Empire State in big way.

title: Ruskin Plans Further Disclosures Of Fraud in Rehabilitation of Slums
description: City Investigation Commis sioner Robert K. Ruskin said yesterday that his department would disclose within the next 10 days further examples of contractors and developers who bait allegedly defrauded the city, under the Municipal Loan Program.

title: Castro Hails Upsets Over U.S. Athletes
description: HAVANA, Aug. 15  Jos Antonio Huelga, Cuba's Vida Blue, stood in front of the five microphones and tried to ex plain the three home runs that United States baseball players had hit off him during the re cent PanAmerican Games.

title: Pressure by Speculators Forced Action on Dollar
description: President Nixon's announce ment last night that effective immediately the United States would suspend settlement of in ternational transactions in gold came in the wake of a week of intensive speculative selling pressure, against the dollar in the moneymarket centers of Europe.

title: Franulovic, Mrs. King Triumph In National Clay Court Finals
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 15 (AP) Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia and Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., won singles titles today in the $58,000 Na tional clay courts tennis cham pionships.

title: Loan to Korea Assailed
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 15 (Reu ters)  China's official press agency today strongly con demned Japan for promising South Korea $200million in loans for alleged military pur poses.

title: NO U.S. GUIDELINES FOR YOUNG VOTERS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)The Justice Department has decided not to set guide lines to help local voter regis tration of newly enfranchised 18yearolds, according to Sen ator Edward W. Brooke, Republican of Massachusetts.

title: OPTIMISM FOUND IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit markets moved toward lower interest rates last week, and investment bankers are betting the trend will con tinue.

title: Distance Mark Broken
description: AUCKLAND, N.Z., Aug. 15 (AP)Jack Foster, 39yearold New Zealand marathon runner, broke the world 20mile record today with a time of 1 hour 39 minutes 14.4 seconds.

title: Boys Football Is a Serious Game on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 Tom Cruse and Mike Dattilo lingered in the shade by the water fountain. The football squad worked out on the field.

title: Lazar and Owners of Nonmedallion Cabs Meet
description: The chairman of the city Taxi and Limousine Commis sion said yesterday that he had been meeting with owners of nonmedallion taxis to talk over ways of regulating their operation.

title: New Black Caucus in the South Aloof From Presidential Race
description: MOBILE, Ala., Aug. 15 Black politicians from across the South formed an enthusi astic union here this weekend and decided to remain aloof from present and prospective Presidential candidates.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In discussing the disastrous evening and weekend closings of the New York Public Library reference rooms you fail to mention that beginning January, 1972, the music, drama and dance reference sections, housed at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, will cease their services to the public altogether. This means an end to all serious, intensive research for those engaged in these fields. Once upon a time New York City proudly claimed to be the world's cultural cap ital.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India does not want war with any country and is following a policy of peace. She added, in a speech marking the 24th anniversary of Indian independence, India is not afraid of threats from any quarter.

title: StateAided Erie Wins Riders raise or Puncuality
description: HOBOKEN, N. Y.Inside the faded, 1930model Erie Lacka wanna commuter car, typical of the line's electric coaches, it was 90 degrees during the rush hour the other afternoon a dripping, dogday 90 de grees.

title: U.S. Junior Golfers Win
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 15 (AP) The United States, led by the putting of Mike Hemphill, de feated Mexico. 2120, in the International Junior Golf tour nament at La Hacienda Goff Club. Canada was third with 7 points.

title: Miss Laurie Nissel, a Teacher, Is Married to Kenneth Koslowe
description: Miss Laurie Nissel, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Nissel of Far Rockaway, Queens, was married last night to Kenheth Chanin Koslowe, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Irving Koslowe of Ma maroneck, N.Y.

title: Survey Supports Advisers To Amex Governing Board
description: Paul Kolton, president of the American Stock Exchange, re ported yesterday final results of a survery supporting the es tablishment of a committee to advise the exchange's govern ing board on the interests of listed companies.

title: Locust Valley Poloists Win From Sands Point, 13 to 9
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 15 Russell Corey scored six goals, three within 2 minutes in the fourth period, and led the Locust Valley polo team to a 139 victory over Sands Point today at Bethpage State Park.

title: Side Effect of Message: Tennis Tourney Halted
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI)It was going to be the first White House invitational tennis tournament until Pres ident Nixon  deciding to make a televised message to the nationpulled away sev eral of the invited players.

title: SOVIET AIDE ARRIVES IN MALTA FOR VISIT
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 16 (AP)The Soviet Union's Am bassador to London, Mikhail N. Smirnovsky, flew to Malta over the weekend, reportedly in search of facilities for visit ing warships.

title: Miss Joan Manoochehrian Is Wed
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 15 Miss Joan Manoocheh rian was married here this afternoon to Dr. Edward Co hen, an assistant professor of mechanical engineering at Stevens Institute of Technol ogy in Hoboken, N. J.

title: Suburbs Abandoning Dependence on City
description: The largest city in America is now the suburbs of New York.

title: Upper Volta Is Seeking a Rarity in AfricaFreely Elected Rule
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Vol ta, Aug. 6  This remote land just south of the Sahara has de parted from one of modern Af rica's political, habits by install ing a freely elected Govern ment.

title: THOMAS BONHAM
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Aug. 15 (AP)Thomas Bonham, as sistant trainer for the thorough bred racing Cragwood Stable, died today in Long Island Jew ish Hospital. He was 64 years old.

title: Floating Squatter Finds a Horne in Museum
description: For the last year and a half, Jeff Thenstead, a jazz flutist, has been living in his dismasted, 35foot teak sloop. Sometimes he has paid for docking privileges but more often he has simply squatted on the waterways of New York City.

title: Changes in U.S. Agency Stir Anger Among Indians
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 15  The power of the Commissioner of the Bureau of Indian Affairs has been reduced by the Secre tary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, as part of a re alignment of the agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mr. Nixon has told the American people on several recent occasions of his visions of future international rela tions, The United States will withdraw its physical, military presence from many areas in which we are over reached. The five great powers of twenty years hence (Japan, China, Ruisia, Western Europe and the United States) will be engaged in primarily economic competition.

title: Miss Silbert, James Algina Married on L.I.
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 15Miss Elizabeth Anne Sil bert and James Joseph Al gins, graduates of the Uni versity of Rhode Island, were married here this after noon.

title: Autos Called Major Test; Lower Car Prices Likely
description: DETROIT, Aug. 15The auto mobile industry will probably be the major test of President Nixon's attempts to stimulate the economy by calling for a repeal of the automobile excise tax and imposing a surcharge of 10 per cent on imports not subject to quotas.

title: ULSTER GUERRILLAS IN SCATTERED RAIDS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15 (AP)Irish Republican. Army guerrillas struck in scat tered attacks today.

title: Financial Leaders, Back Nixon's Steps
description: The broad steps outlined by the Nixon. Administration to deal with the nation's economic problems met with general but in many cases highly quali fiedapproval from a score of leading bankers, economists and businessmen interviewed last night.

title: Shop Talk
description: Zandra Rhodes is an out rageous young woman. She wears vermilion  streaked hair, purplespangled eyelids and red dots where her eye brows should be. Zandra Rhodes also de signs outrageous clothes. Chiffon dresses slashed to ribbons, coats with seams cut to look like a dinosaur's back. And yet beneath all this seeming insanity lies hard core couture. Couture in the manner of Charles James, for example, whose intri cate seaming and carvedout shapes made clothes mean something.

title: Kilauea Volcan Subsides
description: HILO, Hawaii, Aug. 15 (UPI) Kilauea volcano on Mauna Loa Mountain was quiet today, after turning on for 10 hours in an eruption of fire and lava that gave tourists the best show in years. The eruption sputtered and died last night after spec tatular fireworks that saw fountains of fire and molten lava spurt 200 feet in theair.

title: Northwestern Life Gains
description: The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company's sales of new insurance in the first half this year were a record $1.09billion, up 16.8 per cent from the 1970 initial six months, Francis E. Ferguson, president, reported yesterday. Insurance in force reached $20.2billion on June 30, an increase of 7.6 per cent over a year earlier, and total ad mitted assets gained 5.6 per cent to $6.3billion.

title: An Integrated Day Camp Feels Impact of Reductions in Funds
description: NEW ROCHELLE, Aug. 15 The beaches and playing fields and woodland trails on David's Island in Long Island Sound will be silent and de serted tomorrow. The romp ing, noisy children will not be here because their summer daycamp has been cut short for lack of state and private funds.

title: 300 Stay Out at U.S. Steel
description: GARY, W. Va., Aug. 16 (UPI) About 300 workers at the United. States Steel Corpora tion's coal cleaning plant here did not report for work today because of dissatisfaction with President Nixon's freeze on wages. A spokesman for United Mine Workers Local 7905 said the men probably would return to work on the night shift.

title: Grenade Wounds 17 in Gaza
description: GAZA, Aug. 16 (AP)A grenade exploded in the market of Gaza City today, wounding 17 Arabs, the Israeli Army said.

title: Gonzales to Run Celebrity Tennis Sept. 14
description: I always knew I'd be doing something for a living when I was past 40, Pancho Gonzales said yesterday. But I never thought I'd be making money playing ten nis.

title: STOCKTON UPSETS SMITH BY 76, 76
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 16 Dick Stockton of Garden City, L. I. scored ad upset 76, 76 victory over topseeded Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., today in the Opening round of the 72d Pennsylvania lawn tennis cham pionship at the Merion Cricket Club.

title: Prosecution Says That Medina Chose Not to Intervene at Mylai
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 16Capt. Ernest L. Me dina did not order the mass killings at Mylai but he cal culatingly chose not to inter vene while his troops were killing unarmed civilians, the military prosecutor said today in opening the Government's case against the 34yearold MexicanAmerican officer.

title: Anyone for a $50 Bag for PingPong Paddles?
description: The old symbols of successtravel abroad, designer clothes, second homes have become lifestyles for just about everybody, but all is not lost to the rich and the statusconscious. There are still, if one wishes, ways to distinguish the fashionable from the plebeian.

title: Tourists Confused at Money Exchanges
description: LONDON, Aug. 16Confused and anxious tourists, seeking to exchange dollars for local cur rency, packed banks and Amer ican Express Company offices in Europe today, following President Nixon's speech on the economy last night.

title: Industrial Production Off 0.8% for July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Industrial production declined in July after being flat in June, the Federal Reserve Board re ported today.

title: PRIZE POLICY SHIFTS AT READER'S DIGEST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Reader's Digest has agreed under Government pressure to award every prize dollar it ad vertises in future promotional sweepstakes and to explain to entrants their chance of win ning the Federal Trade Com mission said today.

title: SPYROSP.SKOUWIS DIES AT AGE OF 78
description: Spyros P. Skouras, the mo tionpicture magnate, died last night in his home at 2 Shore Lane, Mamaroneck, N.Y., ap parently of a heart attack. He was. 78 years old.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 10:

title: 12 DIE, 70 MISSING IN HONG KONG STORM
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Aug. 17 (AP)A typhoon hit Hong Kong with 130mile winds early today, capsizing a ferryboat, and it was feared that 70 to 80 crewmen were lost.

title: F.G.C, OVERRULED OVER TV AUTO ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  1 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that tele vision stations must broadcast information outlining the ad verse effects of automobiles on the environment if they carry advertisements promoting big cars and large horsepower rat ings.

title: COURT REJECTS A BID TO BLOCK T.V.A. DAM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) A Federal district court judge refused today to issue a tem porary order barring the Ten nessee Valley Authority from constructing the Tellico Darn.

title: Big Four Resume Berlin Talks; Passports Said to Be an Issue
description: BERLIN, Aug. 16The am bassadors of the Big Four powers resumed the intensive phase of their negotiations on improving the conditions of Berlin today after a threeday pause.

title: 22% of the Prostitutes Arrested in City Are Found to Have Records of Violence
description: Twentytwo per cent of all prostitutes arrested in the mid town area in recent weeks have records of arrests for violent crimes.

title: Customers Waiting for Toyotas Flood Office With Price Queries
description: By midafternoon yesterday, the Toyota Manhattan Company, one of the Japanese auto pro ducer's largest dealers, had re ceived 50 calls from customers, asking whether the President's tax rulings would affect cars they had ordered.

title: Airport Restaurant Closed As Peril in Labor Dispute
description: The main restaurant at Ken nedy International Airport was closed indefinitely yesterday by, the Port of New York Author ity in the interest of the safe ty and health of airline pas sengers as the result of a labor dispute.

title: Questions and Answers on Impact of Nixon's Economic Measures
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16Following are some ques tions about the new economic measures and tentative answers provided by Government officials.

title: YUGOSLAVS CRITICIZE SOVIETBLOC MOVES
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 16Two authoritative Yugo slav papers snapped back to day at what they implied were Sovietinspired efforts to press Balkan nations into more obe dience to Moscow's doctrine.

title: Stage: London Nostalgia
description: LONDON, Aug. 16Nostal gia has gripped the London theater just as it has gripped Broadway. And nostalgia  English styledoes not seem so different from the United States variety.

title: Indonesians Retain Title
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16 (AP)  Rudy Hartono, the world singles chamipon, led Indonesia to a 32 victory over Malaysia tonight for its second straight Asian badmin ton championship.

title: Ballman Stars as Eagles Conquer Bills, 3428
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP)  Gary Ballman, a wide receiver, whose contract nego tiations are snagged by Presi dent Nixon's wage freeze, caught nine passes for 166 yards and scored one touch down tonight in helping the I Philadelphia Eagles to a 3428 victory over the Buffalo Bills. The performance came in a Na tional Football League presea son game.

title: HOMER I. HARRIS
description: Homer I. Harris, a lawyer and author of New York Es tate Practice Guide, died Sun day while vacationing in Vi enna. He was 69 years old and lived at 160 West End Avenue.

title: I.C.C. Moves to Freeze Transportation Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Interstate Com merce Commission, respond ing to the wageprice order, moved today to freeze at their present levels rates charged by railroads, trucking lines and bus companies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In responding to my July 20 OpEd article, Eric Sevareid is right in say ing that Senator Hartke and I did not have exclusive knowledge that the Johnson Administration's Vietnam spending in 1966 was far above the publicized figures, or even those re luctantly admitted to in private. [Let ter July 31]. He did indeed do yeo men service in circulating early evi dence of the widening credibility gap; and many a bemused economist read ing Government handouts both then and now (beginning with the budget itself), might profit by a gaze as ques tioning and a mind as independent.

title: Yukon Asbestos Mine Lifting Output Sharply
description: CLINTON CREEK, Yukon TerritoryHigher taxes, the introduction of landuse regu lations, sagging metal prices and disappointing ore grades have made this less than a sunny summer for most of the Yukon mining industry.
