title: Defendant in LoanShark Trial Fails to Appear
description: One of the five defendants in an alleged loanshark con spiracy, Samuel Santoro of Yonkers, failed to appear as the trial opened here yesterday in Federal Court.

title: Nixon Briefs Executives, Plays Golf With Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) President Nixon briefed some Governmental officials private ly today and then played golf.

title: Maine to Honor Scribner
description: ORONO, Me., Aug 16. Dr. Harvey B. Scribner: Chancellor of New York City's public school system, will receive an honorary degree at the Univer city of Maine at Orono next Friday. Dr. Scribner served as education commissioner of ver mont from 1967 until to be come Chancellor of the New York City system in September, 1970.

title: ALFRED W. GREEN, 50, LAWYER HERE, DEAD
description: Alfred William Green, a, law yer at 20 Exchange Place, died Saturday of an apparent heart attack while vacationing in Athens with his family. He was 50 years old and lived at 941 Fox Hill Lane, Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: LEGAL UNIT ASSAILS POLLUTION PROPOSAL
description: The Natural Resources De fense Council, an environmental legal group, condemned as an environmental retrenchment yesterday the air pollution guidelines issued Saturday by the Environmental Protection Agency, a Federal organization.

title: Movie BoxOffice Star: The $1 Ticket
description: Cheaper movie theater ad missions are on the increase in the metropolitan area. The trend, spurred by a pro liferation of dollarbracket showcases that began in earnest a year and a half ago, has now gained sharper impetus with a new price policy set by Century The aters. In an effort to meet consumer resistance, Cen tury, in a weekend develop nient, scaled tickets from 50 cents to a weekend top of $2 at its 44 showcases in the New York area. Prices previously ranged from $1.50 to $3.

title: OBSERVER
description: Bicycling? Earnshaw shuddered and raised his brandy to his lips, as if to dispel some premonition of shrouds and grave dust. It was a gesture all too familiar to the rest of us seated that midnight around the last embers of the fire there in the club. It meant that Earnshaw had been reminded of a story, which none of us wanted to hear. We rose to leave.

title: Delays Reported By Penn C'entral On 3 Lines Here
description: Commuters on all thre lines of the Penn Central Railroad operating out of Grand Central Terminal were delayed last night as the result of signal trouble affecting two of the railroad's tracks and a minor fire that affected the other two tracks.

title: Strife Laid to Dublin
description: The minister in charge of security for Northern Ireland said in New York yesterday that the turmoil in his coun try would end tomorrow if Dublin wanted it to.

title: $500,000 in Hijacked Goods Found in Brooklyn Garage
description: Two men were arrested and close to $500,000 in hijacked freight shipments was recovered in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn yesterday when mem bers of the police safe and loft squad raided a garage of the Gebbia Trucking Company at 55 Chester Street.

title: Namath Thinks Jets Will Kill Giants on Sunday
description: Joe Namath, the famous Super Bowl prophet, had an opinion yesterday on the Jets Giants exhibition game Sun day at Yale Bowl.

title: Milk Production Rises
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Milk production in July totaled more than 10.3 billion pounds, up 0.8 per cent from a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Nixon's Economic Shift: Why and How He Did It
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  President Nixon chose Sunday night to proclaim his new eco nomic policy in part as a bid to outwit the gnomes of Zurich.

title: Action on Dollar Seen in London As End of Myth on Fixed. Rates of Exchange
description: LONDON, Aug. 16This is the end of the myth, a finan cial expert said today as he dis cussed what the London papers called the dollar bombshell. He might have been talking about the myth of American omnip otence, but what he actually had in mind was an article of financial faith through most of the years since World War II the notion that world eco nomic wellbeing depended on tightly fixed rates of exchange between the major currencies.

title: Governor Puts Nixon In Roosevelt's Class
description: Governor Rockefeller hailed President Nixon's economic proposals yesterday, saying they represented a call for a peaceful revolution to up date the structure of our economic system and make it more responsive to the needs of our people in the light of the realities of to day.

title: Johnson, Coffey Among 7 Injured Giants
description: None of the Giants showed up for practice yesterday, but it was all right; no practice was scheduled. The day was devoted to licking wounds, resting, letting the Dick Shiner situation run its course and trying to begin to get organized to face the next opponent, an outfit called the Jets.

title: Accused of Killing Chlid
description: KHARTOUM, The Sudan, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  Khadmal la Abdalla, a witness for the prosecution, accused Rolf Stein er today of having killed her 7 monthold child and injured her at a rebel camp in the southern Sudan where she was being detained. She also told the court that while she was in the camp she saw Mr. Steiner and Maj. Gen Amia, now President of Uganda, confer ring with Southern Sudanese rebel leaders.

title: I.T.T. STOCKHOLDER SEEKING $850,000
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 16 (AP) A Cincinnati woman asked the United States District Court to day to order six directors of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to pay more than $850,000 to the cor poration.

title: CONGRESS LIKELY TO VOTE NIXON TAX CUTS;
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 House and Senate leaders pre dicted today that Congress would approve President Nixon's proposed tax reductions, per haps granting even more relief than the Administration had sought.

title: China Seems to Soothe Allies on U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 16 Neighboring governments sup ported bysthe Chinese Commu nists appear to have lost some of the apprehension they initial lge showed over Peking's new policy of contact with the United States.

title: French Satellite Launched
description: WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., Aug. 16 (Reuters)A French weath er satellite called Eole was launched from here today to collect information from up to 500 instrumentcarrying bal loons to be sent aloft from Argentina.

title: Roundup. Pirates Victors Behind Stargell, Davalillo
description: Roberto Clemente of the Pirates was tired last night, but his teammate, Vic Da valillo, wasn't. Pittsburgh manager Danny Murtagh rest ed Clemente against the Houston Astros because his regular right fielder looked tired swinging the bat.

title: Roundup of Rebels in Dacca
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 16 Government troops made housetohouse sweeps through Dacca over the weekend, ap parently heading off threatened terrorism by the Bengali sep aratists.

title: The New Economic Policy
description: President Nixon has moved dramatically to change his economic game plan. Just six weeks ago, Secretary the Treasury Connally emerged from a Camp David eco nomic conference tb announce that there would be no wageprice controls, no stabilization board, no tax cuts. Now, after another Camp David conference, Mr. Nixon has done an aboutface. The result is a range of actions the President describes as the most comprehensive new economic policy to be undertaken in this nation in four decades.

title: Debby Deb, $29.20, Captures, Adirondack Sprint at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 16Debby Deb made an early lead stand all the way in taking the $34,700 Adirondack today. The accomplishment was of no small stature, for among those that trailed Nelson B. Hunt's colorbearer was Ogden Phipp's Numbered Account. This hitherto undefeated daugh ter of Buckpasser finished third in the sixfurlong sprint for 2 yearold fillies.

title: Kandinsky Auction Oct. 20
description: The auction of 47 works by Kandinsky and a group of other paintings, watercolors and drawings also in the possession of the Guggenheim Museum has been postponed from Oct. 13 to Oct. 20. the museum has an nounced. The works of art, in cluding some recently acquired from the Hilla Rehay Founda tion, will be auctioned by ParkeBernet here.

title: Consumer Chief Urges Americans to Bay Now
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP)President Nixon's con sumer adviser today asked Americans to follow her ex ample and spend money.

title: $475 JumpPants Gowns Called Flammable by F.T.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Com mission reported today that tests on jumppants gowns that retail for at least $475 indicate they are dangerously flam mable.

title: All Favored Players Gain
description: Led by topranked Steve Miller of New York, all seeded players advanced to the second round yesterday in the fourth annual Columbia tennis cham pionships for juniors and boys at Baker Field.

title: Fund Sets Up a Study Of U.S. Energy Position
description: The Twentieth Century Fund announced yesterday the selection of S. David Freeman, White House energy specialist, to conduct a 16 month study of the nation's energy position and a pos sible national power policy.

title: Metz Foursome Cards 55 For Stroke Victory on L.I.
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 16 Craig Metz, Jim Boshart, George Babcock and Cory Dahl carded 27, 2855 today to win the team prize, by a stroke in the Pinter tournament at the Southward Ho Golf Club. Par for the 6,436yard course is 35, 3671.

title: Judge Hears Richmond Plea for CityCounty School Merger to Spur Integration
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 16The trial opened here today in one of themost farreaching school desegregation cases since the Supreme Court's 1954 decision against separate but equal education for blacks.

title: Executive Oranges
description: The Whirlpool Corporation announced that John H. Platts, president, will in addition become chairman and chief executive officer on Sept. 30, following the, retirement of Elisha Gray 2d, at the mandatory age of 65. Mr. Gray will serve as a di rector and chairman of the finance committee.

title: Concert Is Real Tribute to Schnabel
description: Memorial concerts are not invariably memorable. Rever ence can lay a solemn air on such events, and piety is too often substituted for vitality sometimes even for re hearsal. But the Tribute to Artur Schnabel program at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday night skirted ceremonial haz ards, and quickly developed into a concert.

title: CAMBODIANS TO ASK 72 SAIGON PULLOUT
description: Lieut. Gen. Sisowath Sirik Matak, the Acting Premier of Cambodia, said here esterday that his Government would ask South Vietnam to withdraw its troops from Cambodia by June, 1972.

title: German Tax Treaty Hits Mailbox Units
description: BONN, Aug. 16An estimat ed 10,000 West German mail box companies in Switzerland face the end of their lucrative days as a consequence of a new SwissWest German doubletax treaty that was signed here last week. It will af fect concerns with Swiss head quarters that are mere mailing addresses, designed to take ad vantage of lenient Swiss taxes.

title: Medical Unity Urged
description: DENVER, Aug. 16 (AP)Dr. Ernest Weiner of New York City, newly elected president of the American Podiatry Asso ciation, today called on all health professions to unite in bringing improved health care to all Americans. He addressed the association's 59th annual convention here.

title: All Insurance Rates Face Freeze Order in the State
description: ALBANY, Aug. 16 (AP)All insurance rates in the state will be frozen at current levels for the duration of President Nix on's order to freeze wages and prices for 90 days, the State Insurance Department said to day.

title: Ellsberg Denies Guilt, Will Fight
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16Dr., Daniel Ellsberg pleaded not guilty today to charges that he had illegally possessed and copied the controversial Penta gon papers.

title: U.S. Says Pay Freezes Will Affect Holdouts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) Representatives of profes sional sports teams were un certain today what effect President Nixon's freeze on wages would have on athletes, but a Treasury Department official said the Presidential action applied to sports.

title: Offices Being Set up in 10 Cities to Assure Compliance With WagePrice Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Office of Emergency Pre paredness began setting up of fices in 10 metropolitan centers today to assure compliance with President Nixon's order freezing prices and wages for the next 90 days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I commend The Times for its Aug. 5 editorial Backtrack on Segregation and for the strong column by Tom Wicker entitled Mr. Nixon Defaults in the same issue.

title: Advertising:
description: Ira Weinblatt, a vice presi dent and senior associate media director at Dancer FitzgeraldSample, has, like many agency executives, paid close attention to the ups and downs of media buying services over the last few years. But unlike many others, he has analyzed the rela tionship of buying to the en tire media function and de veloped a theory about the even greater importance of planning.

title: Coast Jury Begins inquiry On KennedyDeath Weapon
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (AP) The cou.ty grand jury opened an investigation today into whether the weapon and fatal bullets allegedly used to kill Robert F. Kennedy had been tampered with.

title: MOST WORLD CURRENCY DEALING IS HALTED
description: PARIS, Tuesday, Aug. 17 Europe and Japan reacted with anxiety and confusion to Pres ident Nixon's radical economic measures, as officials were summoned back from August vacations for consultations on what to do.

title: Rudometkin Recalls His Knick Days
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 16 Rudo, the Reckless Russian, can remember the first field goal he scored in the National Basketball Association. It was one of about 300 he made dur ing a career cut short by cancer.

title: Woman Here Sues Airline for $75,000 In Hijacking Case
description: A Manhattan woman passen ger on the Swissair flight that was hijacked to a desert air strip in Jordan last September is suing the airline for $75,000 the maximum amount possi ble.

title: Psychological Lift Seen
description: Business leaders applauded yesterday, with varying degrees of enthusiasm, the sweeping roposals announced by Presi dent Nixon Sunday night de signed to spur the economy, blunt inflation and strengthen the dollar.

title: G.M. Rescinds Increases In Prices of Its 72 Cars
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16  The General Motors Corporation today rescinded the price in creases announced on Aug. 5 for its 1972 cars, the first move by a major industry to comply with President Nixon's wage price freeze.

title: Attack hi North Reported
description: SAIGON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) A United States Phantom jet attacked an antiaircraftgun po sition in North Vietnam yester day after a reconnaissance plane taking photographs had been fired on near the North Vietnamese coast, about 15 miles north of the DMZ, an American spokesman said to day.

title: Books of The Times
description: MADAME. An Intimate Biography of Helena Rubinstein. By Patrick O'Higgins. 296 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $7.95..

title: Angler Nets $25,000 Fish
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Aug. 16 (Canadian Press) Walter Lucy of Coquitlam, B.C., landed a 34pound spring salmon yesterday, that won $25,000 prize in the British Columbia salmon derby.

title: Johnson and Nixon Given Lower Rating in War Poll
description: Publication of the Pentagon papers on Vietnam has lowered the credibility ratings of both former President Lyndon B. Johnson and. President Nixon, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday.

title: Mets Beat Dodgers Behind Seaver, 60
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 Tom Seaver, extending one of the most glittering pitching streaks of the season, set down Los Angeles on seven hits to night as the Mets whipped the Dodgers, 60, and snapped their fivegame losing streak.

title: Import Tax Is GiftShow Topic
description: Exhibitors at the New York Gift Show, which consists largely of household and per sonal goods imported from all over the world, reacted calmly yesterday to President Nixon's 10 per cent import surtax, mainly because they didn't know how and where it would be levied.

title: Judge Calls Wallace's Busing Stand Meaningless
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 16  Gov. George C. Wallace delayed today his plans to in tervene between school boards and the courts in the busing controversy after a Federal judge described his previous defiance of busing orders as legally meaningless.

title: Nassau Defers Raises
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 16 Ralph G. Caso, Nassau County Executive, announced today that during the period covered by President Nixon's order on wages and prices, the county would defer giving salary in creases to its employes. Mr. Caso put into effect a county job freeze shortly after he took office in January.

title: The Great Eggplant Grows Into a Popular Academic Success
description: The Great Eggplant is what David Halliday and Robert Resnick, coauthors of Physics, call their wildly successful textbook, a purple bound tome of 1,324 pages.

title: STATE FARM PLANS DIVIDEND PAYMENTS
description: The State Farm Mutual Auto mobile Insurance Company an nounced yesterday that it would grant dividends ranging from one to 17 per cent on premiums paid by customers in 31 states and the District of Columbia.

title: A Textile Company Assesses the Impact
description: As in thousands of corpora tions across the country yes terday, the top executives of Burlington Industries, Inc., the nation's largest producer of textiles, gathered to assess the impact of President Nixon's im position of a wageandprice freeze and his call for a 10 per cent surtax on certain imports.

title: Vietcong Sink Vessel
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Aug. 17 (AP)Vietcong frogmen blew up and sank the United States cargo vessel Green Bay early today at Quinhon harbor, 250 miles northeast of Saigon. First reports listed casualties as four injured, one identified as an American. The vessel was re ported to be carrying supplies for post exchanges.

title: Goodrich in Venezuelan Tie
description: The B. F. Goodrich Chemical Company announced yesterday that it had signed an invest ment agreement with Venezue lan interests to establish a $25million polyvinylchloride production facility on Lake Maracaibo in the El Tablazo petrochemicals complex. BFG Chemical, a division of the B. F. Goodrich Company, will own a 25 per cent share in a new company that will carry out the project; the rest will be held by Venezuelan interests.

title: 9 TROTTERS LISTED IN INTERNATIONAL
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 16  Until late Saturday night, virtually all the harness racing talk in the area of Roosevelt Raceway will be about the forthcoming 13th annual Inter national Trot. With today's addition of Ginster of Germany and Stylish Major of New Zealand, the $125,000, 1 mile invitation race became a ninehorse event for the second time in its history. The same number started in the 1967 edition, won by Roquepine of France.

title: Film: Blind Swordsman:Hero of 'Zato Ichi' Can Overcome Any Odds
description: There are several mysteries to "Zato Ichi's Cane Sword," which opened yesterday at the Bijou, not the least of which is the name of its hero, "Zatoichi," according to the theater's publicity; "Zato Ichi," according to the subtitles on the screen; and just plain "Ichi" to those who know and love and honor himas it would seem difficult not to do.An itinerant swordsman, gambler, drinker and masseur, Zato Ichi is an expansive, friendly, sloppy sort of fellow who possesses cast-iron nerves, superfast reflexes and finely tuned sensesexcept in the eyes, where he happens to be blind.But he seems to compensate with sight in the back of his head, and since the typical Ichi adversary tends to attack from behind, the blind swordsman proves always indomitable. Even with his sword in the repair shop and only a walking stick to hand, he overcomes at odds of 4 to 1, and no contest. But using his sword in the grand finale, he had bettered 40 to 1 before I lost count, and his enemies lost heart, and the movie ended with Ichi trudging off alone into the rising sun. He had just finished freeing an amiable countryside from a harsh overlord, winning a lot of money through his uncanny skill at listening to the cast of loaded dice, giving several successful massages, slurping a lot of noodles and winning the heart of the girl of his dreams (Shiho Fujimura)  whom he has the good sense to leave behind to the kind attentions of the innkeeper's handsome son.Almost all the major action is formula, of a not disreputable sort, with individuation prety much reserved for the quirks of the hero's character. It is a rather nice character, as played by Shintaro Katsu, but it is not up to living down the formulathe off-hand slaughter and, above all, the heroic idiocies of the grand climax in which slain samurai fall like candy wrappers into the popcorn snow of the wind-blown studio streets.Where it is quiet enough to allow Ichi his peaceful idiocyncrasies, "Zato Ichi's Cane Sword" is a pleasantly modest film, an amiable contrast to the fateful solemnities of the Toshiro Mifune samurai dramas. Ichi's very invulnerability makes for a certain relaxation, a few songs, a little buffoonery, and much of it to the good."Zato Ichi's Cane Sword" was directed by Kimiyoshi Yasuda and photographed in not-quite color by Senkichiro Takeida.

title: In Upper Volta, No One Fears the Tribal Sun King Anymore
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Upper Volta, Aug. 6  The Mogho Naba, a king whose power used to be likened to that of the sun, has come upon hard times.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The full economic consequences of President Nixon's weekend decisions and his Sunday night speech remain to be seen, although they are bound to be significant. But it is already clear that the speech was a graphic demonstra tion of one of the durable verities of American politicsthat the greatest political power of a President is the power to act.

title: CONFUSION SLOWS FUTURES TRADING
description: Commodity trading was de layed yesterday and one ex change shut down completely while officials tried to figure out what effect the wage and price freeze, the cutting of the golddollar link and the import surtax would have on their operations. All were waiting for clarification from Washing ton.

title: Mayor Buses In to Plug Express Lines
description: Mayor Lindsay traveled by limousine to the Fresh Mead ows section of Queens yester day morning to greet the 10 millionth rider on the city's express bus commuter lines and to pay tribute to what he called an important and exciting transportation innovation.

title: Man, 66, Tries in Vain to Save Stabbing Victim
description: A young white man who was stabbed in the heart by two white teenaged muggers died early yesterday, despite the at tempt of a 66yearold black handyman to carry him to hospital six blocks from the scene of the attack.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As soon as Mayor Lindsay witched parties, the same Democrats who claim they want the 1972 election to be open and determined by the people began to say that Mr. Lindsay must work his way up, pay his dues and dance for the party hacks before he could be a serious candidate for the Presidency.

title: Pirates Send Jeter, Acosta TO Padres in Miller Deal
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 16 (UPI)  John Jeter, an outfielder, and Eduardo Acosta, a right handed pitcher, passed waivers today and were traded by the Pittsburgh Pirates to the San Diego Padres.

title: Mary Budke Cards 75 for 3Way Tie In U.S. Amateur
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 16. (AP) Mary Budke, 17 years old, of Dayton, Ore.; Connie Day of Chattanooga, and Jane Bastan chury of Whittier, Calif., shot threeover par 75's today to lead the opening round in qual ifying for the 71st United States women's amateur golf cham pionship.

title: Bahrain, Oman Apply at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 16The Security Council met today on membership ap plications from the Arab states of Bahrain and Oman, both in the Persian Gulf area. Reliable sources said tonight that Bah rain's application was expected to be approved and Oman's held for further consideration. After receiving the applications the council adjourned and held a closed session as the com mittee on new members. Its report is expected to be pub lished tomorrow.

title: EINAR LUNDEN
description: Einar Lunden, a painter in watercolors and oils of land scapes and still lifes, who exhibited in five watercolor biennials at the Brooklyn Museum, died Sunday of can cer in the Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals. He was 49 years old and lived at 39 Walker Street, Port Richmond, S. I.

title: Kennedy Leaves India
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, Aug. 17 (AP)Senator Kennedy left here early today for Honolulu, concluding a weeklong study tour of the Pakistani refugee problem.

title: Treasury Aide Finds Good Understanding in Talk With European Finance Officials
description: LONDON, Aug. 16  The American Treasury's top mone tary official, Under Secretary Paul A. Volcker, conferred with European finance officials here today on President Nixon's new policy to meet the dollar crisis.

title: CITY U. OFFERS 400 TRANSFER OPTION
description: The City University of New York has agreed to assume a substantial part of the educa tion costs for up to 400 two yearcommunitycollege gradu ates if they enroll next month as business majors at two pri vate colleges.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Brig. Gen. George Arthur Lincoln, who, as director of the Office of Emergency Pre paredness will be in charge of the 90day wageprice freeze announced by Presi dent Nixon last night, has not been a headline figure in the national press. But in the trade press deal ing with the pe troleum and min ing industries and in Congressional committees con cerned with such recondite and moneyladen matters as oil import quotas and Federal stockpiling of strategic and critical materials (115 of them worth $6.3billion as of last March), General Lincoln is well known indeed.

title: Carrier Increases Sales and Profits For Fiscal Quarter
description: The Carrier Corporation, producer of airconditioning, refrigeration and heating equipment, turned in record sales, earnings and orders booked in the third fiscal quarter ended July 31, the com pany reported yesterday from its Syracuse headquarters.

title: Australia Gains 21 Lead In Stevens Cup Tennis
description: Jim Gilchrist and Bob Howe defeated Enrique and Eduardo Buse of Peru, 62, 64, 64, yes terday to give Australia a 21 lead in the senior team elimina tion fianls for the Stevens Cup at the Town Tennis Club.

title: Variety Marks Growth Of Coast Jazz Festival
description: CONCORD, Calif., Aug. 16 A jazz festival that encom passes much more than jazz and exists for purposes be yond those of the usual mu sical festival completed its third summer of steady growth here this weekend.

title: Blight Worries Iowa Corn Growers
description: ELY, Iowa, Aug. 16  Corn growers here are concerned about the appearance of South ern corn blight in their fields again. Last year this particular fungus cut the output of feed corn to 4.1billion bushels at the end of December, or 15 per cent below the figure predicted by the Government in July of that year.

title: Merger News
description: The biggest merger in the steel industry in recent years was completed yesterday with the announcement that the Na tional Steel Corporation had concluded its acquisition of the Granite City Steel Company.

title: WARTIME AIDES HAIL PAY FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Administrators of wartime price and wage control programs welcomed President Nixon's 90 day pricewage freeze today but expressed uncertainty over how effective it might he in curbing inflation.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: South Africa Feels U.S. Steps Will Bring Higher Gold Prices
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 16Although there has been no official Govern ment comment, South Africa's cautious reaction to the Amer loan financial move is to view the next few days as crucial for the future of gold.

title: News Analysis
description: President Nixon's dramatic new national and international economic policies constitute not one new program but three separate onesand the success or failure of one may not de pend very much on the success or failure of another.

title: OFFICIALS PONDER FREEZE ON RENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Real estate and housing offi cials had more questions than answers today on the effects of President Nixon's rent freeze on the nation's 25millionplus rental apartments and houses.

title: Miss Goolagong Loses
description: TORONTO, Aug. 16 (AP)  Francoise Durr of France upset Evonne Goolagong of Australia, 64, 62, today and won the women's singles title in the Ca nadian open tennis champion ships.

title: Market Booms in Nixon Rally
description: The stock market exploded yesterday in a Nixon rally that sent prices soaring to their best singleday gain in history in recordshattering volume.

title: 75% in Poll Back Freeze
description: The American Broadcasting Company said yesterday that a poll it took last month showed more than 75 per cent of 2,500 persons questioned favored im position of wage and price con trols to help curb inflation.

title: Amex and Counter Post Largest Gain In More Than Year
description: The American Stock Ex change and the overthecoun ter market posted their biggest gains in more than a year yes terday in very active trading.

title: Stewardesses Facing Layoffs as Travel Lags
description: Get a sixmonth lease not a year's. Wash your walls don't paint them. Keep calm and don't worry.He hoped his company would keep furloughs below 20 or 30 per cent.

title: Order Imbalance Causes 8 Stocks Not to Trade
description: The record turnover on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday kept brokers, spe cialists and exchange officials busy in an attempt to main tain an orderly market.

title: MAYOR SUSPENDS CITY'S PAY TALKS
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday or dered immediate suspension of collective bargaining with the municipal labor unions and a freeze on city government pay until further clarification from Washington of the President's wage and price controls.

title: Irregularity in Heartbeat
description: DETROIT, Aug. 16 (AP)  Haskell Shanks, who got a mechanical heart booster six days ago, was reported today to have developed some ir regularity in his heartbeat, but doctors at Detroit's Sinai Hospital said that he should be able to bring this under control within 24 hours. They said that his general condition continues to be satisfactory.

title: Texts of Nixon's Orders on Freeze and Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (UPI)Fol lowing are the texts of President Nixon's executive orders issued today providing for stabilization of prices, rents, wages and salaries and imposing a 10 per cent surcharge on all dutiable imported goods.

title: State Suspends Caldwell, Jim French's ExOwner
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 16Frank J. Caldwell, former owner of Jim French, had his owner's license sus pended indefinitely today by the New York Racing Commis sion and the horse became a doubtful starter for Saturday's $100,000 added Travers Stakes.

title: Foe Seizes Post Near DMZ, Inflicting Heavy Losses
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10North Vietnamese troops overran a South Vietnamese Marine company's mountaintop outpost south of the demilitar ized zone yesterday and in flicted heavy losses on the Gov ernment troops, the South Viet namese command announced today.

title: Market Place:
description: DENVER, Aug. 16In this spectacular Mountain set ting, a wellfinanced organ ization, M.C.A., Inc., is dip ping a wellmanicured toe into the waters of persorial money management for the little guy through a new sub sidiary called Finanswer America/Investments, Inc.

title: Pay Freeze Uneven Because of Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Happiness, in the wageprice freeze, is having won your pay raise or increased your prices before last Saturday.

title: A Sudanese Court Hears of a Mercenary's Life
description: CAIRO, Aug. 16It is 110 degrees in the former Assembly chamber at Khartoum. The overhead fans only stir the heat. Sleepily, six darkcom plexioned officers who consti tute the court eye the blond, bulletheaded defendant sitting at his table, guarded by two soldiers with submachine guns.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was a mild form of cheating and was more excusable than reprehensible. It was not quite so serious a breach as first peeking into the last chapter of a whodunit mystery to find out who really had done it. But the effect was the same.

title: American Electric Power Reports Rise in Earnings
description: Net income of the American Electric Power Company rose 19.7 per cent in the three months ended July 31 to $32, 722,000, or 61 cents a share, from the yearearlier $27,329, 000, or 55 cents a share, the company reported yesterday.

title: ARMY TO RELEASE THOUSANDS EARLY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  As many as 43,000 men, most of them draftees, will be re leased from the Army up to four months early, the Army announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mayor Lindsay's enrollment in the Democratic party will not affect na tional politics to the extent that he anticipates. Having received maximum benefits within the Republican party all of his life, he seeks new pastures to advance his personal interests.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Aug. 17, 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ULSTER MILITANTS USE QUIET TACTICS
description: BELFAST, Northern. Ireland, Aug. 16 (AP)Roman Catholics, Socialists and other militants opposed to the Northern Ireland Government on the issue of civil rights subsittuted civil dis obedience today for guns, bombs and stones.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his statement on the trial of Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the U.N. Sec retary General, U Thant, notes that it is within the competence of the judicial system of a member state (news story Aug. 10). While this, seems to be true technically, the trial clearly violates the Geneva Conventions of 1949, to which Pakistan is a party.

title: COURT DEAL LAID TO QUEENS CHIEFS
description: Democratic and Republican leaders in QueensMatthew J. Troy Jr. and Sidney Hein were accused yesterday of con spiring to engineer the resigna tions of three judges and to se lect three candidates to run un opposed for the vacancies.

title: Cleric Files in Rhode Island
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 16 (AP)  Saying he would run under the Vote for Jesus ban ner, the Rev. Clennon B. King of Albany, Ga., became today the first candidate to file offi cially for Rhode Island's Presi dential primary next April.

title: EDWARD HUGHES, 70, NEWSPAPER OFFICER
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 16 (AP) Edward J. Hughes, vice presi dent and editorial director of Westchester  Rockland News papers, Inc., died today in his sleep. He was 70 years old. Death was attributed to a cir culatory ailment.

title: Liberal Policy on Depreciation To Be Maintained by Treasury
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 The Treasury intends to con tinue with the new and more liberal tax rules on depreciation in addition to the proposed new investment tax credit, Secretary of the Treasury John B. Con nally said today.

title: Gifford Accepts Bid to Play In Golf Tourney at Resort
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 16Charlie Sifford, one of the first Negroes to gain prominence on the pro golf tour, has accept ed an invitation to compete in the ConcordLiggett and Myers open starting Aug. 26.

title: Larry Evans Captures First Place in Ches.i Open
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 16 Larry Evans of Reno, Nev., in ternational grandmaster and forfner United States champion, took undisputed possession of first place last night in the seventh round of the United States Open Chess Champion ship here.

title: King Resources Creditors File a Chapter X Petition
description: Three trade creditors of the King Resources Company filed a petition in Federal District Court in Dallas yesterday to begin involuntary Chapter X bankruptcy proceedings against the financially ailing company.

title: Trevino Leaves Hospital
description: TRUTH OR CONSEQUENCES, N. M., Aug. 16 (UPI)Lee Tre vino, who underwent an emer gency appendectomy Aug. 10, was released from the hospital today.

title: Advertising:
description: The announcement that the Ford Motor Company had chosen Grey Advertising for its $17million Pinto, Maverick and Mustang account was not made yesterday. But, Dear born willing, it will be made today at a preview showing of 1972 models held by the company's Ford division.

title: Excerpts From Connally News Conference on Nixon Administration Economic Steps
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally in Wash ington yesterday, as record ed by The New York Times:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The legitimacy of a given political authority is a question which intensely concerned that titan of twentiethcentury social thinkers, Max Weber. It is also, in the present circumstances, a question which should intensely con'cern the voters of New York. For the legitimacy of John Lindsay's authority as Mayor of New York has been thrown open to question by his an nounced change in party affiliation.

title: Cedar Point Takes Lead In Junior Midget Sailing
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug, 16 The Cedar Point Yacht Club crew of Westport, Conn., cap tained by Henry Brauer, took a 4point lead in the elimina tions of the Junior Yacht Rac ing Association's 46th annual Long Island Sound midget sail ing championship off Larch mont Yacht Club today.

title: MALTA CONFIRMS BREAK WITH NATO
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 16 The Government today made official its break with the North Atlantic alliance but simultaneously stated its readi ness to give military facilities here to alliance member coun tries provided they were willing to pay the price.

title: DR. ISIDOR COHN
description: Dr. Isidor Cohn, a diplomate of the American Board of In ternal Medicine, who was on the staffs of the Jewish Hos pital of Brooklyn and the Brooklyn Hebrew Home and Hospital for the Aged, died yes terday in Kings Highway Hos pital. He was 76 years old and lived at 1623 Avenue P, Brook lyn.

title: Land Is Prize in Battle For Control of Suburbs
description: Land is the coin and the treasure of the suburbs around New York City and that landsome of which has risen in value in 20 years from $700 to $90,000 an acreis the prize in a con tinuing battle for control of

title: Soviet Advisers Reported Back at Work in the Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug: 16 (Agence FrancePresse)So viet aid experts are continuing their work in the Sudan, the Sudan press agency reported today.

title: Los Angeles Editor Named
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 (AP) William F. Thomas, 47 years old, was named editor of The Los Angeles Times today.

title: Congress Is Getting Plan to Ease Shortage of Health Personnel
description: A report that recommends changes in licensing of health personnel as a way to case the manpower shortage and im prove the quality of care will go to Congress today.

title: Bond Prices Up Sharply; Some C.D. Yields Decline
description: The bond market yesterday had one of its best days in history.

title: Jewish Philanthropies Names Drive Director
description: The appointment of Leo Hausman, industrialist, to head the 56th annual main tenance compaign of the Federation of Jewish Phi lanthropies of New York, was announced yesterday by Lawrence B. Buttenwieser, president of the Federation.

title: Paul Lukas, 1943 Oscar Winner, Dies
description: TANGIER, Morocco, Aug. 16 (Reuters)  Paul Lukas, who won an Academy Award as best actor in 1943 for his part in Watch on the Rhine, died of heart failurein a hospital here last night. He was 76 years old.

title: Kennedy, in India, Terms Pakistani Drive Genocide
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 16Sen ator Edward M. Kennedy today denounced Pakistan's military action against the East Paki stani separatists as genocide And said that the secret trial of the East Pakistani leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, was an outrage to every concept of international law.

title: $28Million in Wheat Sold By Australia to Soviet
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Aug. 16 (Reuters)The Australian Wheat Board has made its first sale to the Soviet Union in six years.

title: Bridge: American Association Play Under Way in Philadelphia
description: The American Bridge Asso ciation, which is organized primarily by and for black players, began nine days of play in its Summer National Championship in Philadelphia last Friday.

title: Connally Denies Dollar Was Devalued
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 Secretary of the Treasury John 13. Connally said today it would be a premature judgment to say that President Nixon's ac tion Mit night severing the link between the dollar and gold amounted to a devaluation of, the dollar.

title: Notes on People
description: Coming as a distinct sur prise in Washington was the resignation of John S. D. Eisenhower as Ambassador to Belgium.

title: HIGH CUBAN AIDE ARRIVES IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 16 Foreign Minister Ratil Roa of Cuba, accompanied by an Im portant military delegation, ar rived today on an official visit to Chile that could presage a. trip here by Prime Minister Fidel Castro.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: What do you do when you're on vacation, an ac quaintance asked with an ill disguised sneer, work, for a change?

title: Flights Carrying Cubans To Miami Are Resumed
description: MIAMI, Aug 16 (AP)Flights bringing Cubans to Miami re sumed today after a week's suspension. The first of two daily flights brought 98 refu gees.

title: A.F.T. URGED TO BACK A CANDIDATE FOR 72
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug., 16 (AP)David Selden, president of the American Federation of Teachers, said today the 250, 000member group should ac tively support a Presidential candidate in 1972.

title: Little Strategic Loss Seen In a Pullout From Taiwan
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 16  Many United States military planners, looking to the pos sible results of change in Wash ington's policy on China, be lieve that a withdrawal of American forces and installa tions from Taiwan would not substantially weaken this coun try's strategic position in the Far East.

title: Mao's Red. Shadow
description: Mao Tsetung, the Red Chinese dic tator, is some 6,000 miles from the United States. But the shadows of proPeking subversion are daily be coining a more serious problem in this country.

title: Peasant Look Adds a Bit of Elegance
description: IBIZA, Ibiza Island, Spain As much as it rattles the con servative Spaniards, the hip pies who have taken up resi dence on this small Balearic island are doing their best to put Spain on the fashion map.

title: Sidney Lip kins Denies Itkin's Charges
description: Sidney Lipkins, the president and owner of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation, testi fied yesterday that he had never paid anyone to gain favorable treatment from the city.

title: LevinTownsend Revision Of Debentures Approved
description: The LevinTownsend Corn puter Corporation said yester day that it had obtained the re quired number of consents from holders of its 7 per cent sink ing fund debentures of Jan. 15, 1979, to amend the indenture under which the debentures were issued.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fall at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, August 16  Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Doctors Find Irwin Normal After Bouts of Dizziness
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Space agency doctors gave Lieut. Col. James B. Irwin to day his fifth medical examina tion since the Apollo 15 splash down Aug. 7 and pronounced him completely back to normal.

title: Military Will Review Drug Abuse Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has directed the armed forces to review the cases of persons who have received un desirable discharges solely be cause of drug use or possession.

title: TIMES TO PUBLISH JOHNSON MEMOIRS
description: The New York Times, has ac quired the syndication iights to the memoirs of former Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson, and will publish excerpts in The Times starting Oct. 17.

title: DELAY ON DRAFT ACT DEPLORED BY LAIRD
description: DALLAS, Aug. 16 (UPI)De fense Secretary Melvin R. Laird chided Congress today for not extending the draft law and for delaying other most urgent measures in the field of national security.

title: Wellesley President Resigns
description: WELLESLEY, Mass. Aug. 16 (AP)Ruth M. Adams has re signed as president of Welles ley College, the trustees an nounced today. Miss Adams came to Wellesley as the col lege's ninth president in 1966.

title: Harm to Workers Feared
description: George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., charged yes terday that the Administration's 90day wage and price freeze was patently discriminatory against working men and women.

title: PRICES IN GERMANY SURGING THIS YEAR
description: PARIS, Aug. 16 (Reuters) Consumer prices in West Ger many may climb this year a full percentage point more than the 3.8 per cent rise In 1970, the Organization for Economic Co operation and Developmentfore cast today from its office here.

title: Sudden 10% Surcharge Is Assailed by Importers.
description: Importers were stunned and angered yesterday by the sud denness with which they have been confronted with a 10 per cent surcharge on imports of most manufactured articles, pri marily cars, appliances and other consumer goods.

title: New Arlan's President
description: Edward Spector, formerly senior vice president and a di rector of Mammoth Mart, Inc., has been appointed president of Arlan's Department Stores. Ar lan's, a discountstore chain, is currently under the manage ment of the Kenton Corpora tion, a diversified consumer goods company.

title: Riklis Offers $10Million In Financial Aid for I.O.S.
description: A group of dissident stock holders attempting to take con trol of Investors Overseas Serv ices, Ltd., from Robert L. Vesco; its chairman, received an offer of $10million in financial back ing yesterday from Meshulam A. Riklis, the New York fi nancier.

title: A. CARLTON DURLING
description: WHITHOUSE, N.J., Aug. 16 A Carlton on Durling, presi dent of Durling Farms here and the Meshoppen (Pa.) Creamery Company, dairy products dis tributors, died yesterday at the age of 68.

title: South Africa Greets Black Leader on State Visit
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 16A black African lead er, President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malawi, arrived in South Africa today for the first visit o a head o stage to this country in almost a quarter of a cen tury.

title: Garelik Bids Council Back City Loan Program Inquiry
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik yesterday called for a drastic overhaul of the city's scandalshrouded Munici pal Loan Program, by a special committee of the City Council.

title: Heath Rejects Wilson Move
description: LONDON, Aug. 16  Harold Wilson, leader of the Labor Opposition, urged today that Parliament be recalled to de bate the crisis in Northern Ireland, but Prime Minister Heath refused to do so, at least now.

title: Their Home Is Wherever They Park It
description: LOS ANGELES,In the high country of the Mojave Desert an old school bus rests behind a boulder in the Josh ua Tree National Monument.

title: Leading Democrats Call Nixon's New Economic Policy Inadequate and 111Timed
description: WASHINGHTON, Aug. 16 Leading Democrats, apparent ly fearful of losing their big gest potential 1972 political is sue, opened critical fire today on President Nixon's new eco nomic policy.

title: STOCK MARKET UP 32.93 IN RECORD TRADING;
description: The nation's financial mar kets responded enthusiast ically yesterday to President Nixon's new economic pro grams.

title: Mrs. Nixon on LandTransfer Tour
description: BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 16 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon flew into Michigan today on the second stop of her mission to turn over 4,200 acres of Government land to public rec reation use. She found, an un expected welcoming crowd of a few hundred persons at the airport.

title: Courville, Nisselson Lead U.S. Amateur Qualifiers
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Aug. 16  Jerry Courville of Shorehaven and Peter M. Nisselson of Hampshire tied for the medal today in the United States amateur golf championship sec tional qualifying round at The Whippoorwill Club.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With reference to your Aug. editorial Greek Press Traditions,' I heartily commend the Greek Govern ment on promulgating a code of ethics that protects its citizens from irre sponsible journalists who harm the public interest by distorting or slant ing the news. I submit that the pres ervation of a nation is paramount to the absolute freedom of the press. The institution of a comparable code of ethics in our own country would prove salutary.

title: Letting Welfare Mothers Work Is Said to Increase City Costs
description: It would cost taxpayers more to have many of the city's wel fare mothers take jobs than to let them stay idle on relief rolls, the Community Council of Greater New York declared yes terday.

title: Ky Supporter in Saigon Ignites Himself in Protest
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (AP)A Vietnamese war veteran set himself afire at a main intersection today to protest Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky's disquali fication from the presidential election Oct. 3.

title: Federal Air Standards For Plants Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) The Environmental Protec tion Agency proposed today Federal air pollution perfor mance standards for inciner ators, steam generators, ce ment plants and sulfuric and nitric acid factories. The agency's administrator, Wil liam D. Ruckelshaus, said that the standards, requiring the best demonstrated sys tems for reducing smoke stack emission, would apply to new plants and to exist ing plants modified in any way that increased emissions. The regulations, printed in The Federal Register, include procedures by which owners can ask E.P.A. to review plans for the construction or modification of their plants.

title: Supermarket Shoppers sigh in Relief As Price Rises Take 3Month Holiday
description: Butter: 95 cents a pound. Paper towels: two packs for 35 cents. Frozen orange juice, 59 cents.

title: Observers Say Nixon Aim Is 12 to 15% Devaluation
description: The immediate aim of Presi dent Nixon's decision to allow the dollar to float in the in ternational money markets is a devaluation of 12 per cent to 15 per cent in relation to major European currencies and the Japanese yen, informed finan cial sources outside the Govern ment said yesterday.

title: New YorkThe Least Expensive City
description: I am often beset by newly arrived executives crying over the high cost of working and living in New York City. But I em unmoved. They lack awareness of what it means to live in the great City of New York, and they are ignorant of how to take ad vantage of the low cost of living available here.

title: RAPHAEL F. CARLIN
description: Raphael F. Carlin, a lawyer for the Caltex Petroleum Cor poration from 1957 until last May, when he entered private practice, died yesterday of a heart attack t his home, 5 Tudor City Place. He was 48 years old.

title: Steel Output Edges Up
description: Steel production picked up a bit last week from the more than 10year low it set a week earlier, but still was at a near standstill level.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Why all the fuss about Mayor Lindsay's switch? After all, he was Republican in name only, certainly not in spirit or principle. Now, if Republi cans such as Clifford Case and Jacob Javits would only follow suit, the two party system would have more mean ing.

title: Tokyo Governor Visits U.S.
description: TOKYO, Aug. 16, (AP)Gov. Ryokichi Minobe of Tokyo, left for Honolulu today on a 10day visit to the United States, in cluding a conference next Mon day with Mayor Lindsay of New York. Mr. Minobe is scheduled to be in New York Sunday through Tuesday.

title: Chemical Bank Sets Loans At Low Cost for Clean Air
description: The Chemical Bank an nounced yesterday a preferen tial loan program under which manufacturers can upgrade or install air pollution control equipment. It said that it would stand ready to make available any or all of the $100million it estimated is required for such equipment in New York City and in Westchester and Nassau Counties.

title: High Dome Warms U.S. Team in Cuba
description: HAVANA, Aug. 16  Smitty Duke bet Dan Pat terson that he could hit the ceiling of the Coliseum with a volleyball.

title: THOMAS M'GOVERN OF AMEX IS DEAD
description: Thomas Arnold. McGovern, general counsel for the Ameri can Stock Exchange, died yes terday in his sleep. He was 63 years old and lived at 120. East End Avenue.

title: Bridge Weak TwoBid Strategy Discussed in New Book
description: The weak twobid has becalm progressively more popular with tournament players since it was intro duced in the nineteenthirties, so today it is slightly sur prising to find a partnership in serious play that does not use it. It is therefore remark able that nobody had written a book on this major area of bidding theory.

title: The Screen:'Cry Uncle' Combines Sex and Whodunit
description: A new movie called "Cry Uncle" labels itself a satirical skin flick and detective story combined. Check. It also boasts an "X" rating. Just remember, that's as far as the alphabet goes.Cheap, crude, nude and triumphantly filthy as it is, the picture also now and then happens to be extremely funny. Made in New York, under the direction of John G. Avildsen (of "Joe"), it has a group of grubby characters pawing and mauling one another in the wake of a bumbling gumshoe slob, played by Allen Garfield, who looks like Edgar Kennedy, the old-time comic.Sheer brazenness, not to be confused with merit or art, is its trademark, as the film piles on layer upon layer of clichs about sex and more sex, with banal whodunit trimmings.The picture comes on like a fire engine, sparing nothing, and this viewer shook with laughter for a goodor shocked  10 minutes. Some of the dialogue, slamming away at everything from television vigils to police procedure, prostitution and dope addiction, lands on target hilariously. The language is Anglo-Saxon, veering toward latter-day English. And the cast, headed by Mr. Garfield and Madeleine le Roux (fresh from "The Dirtiest Show in Town"), gave it their all and we're not kidding.Actually, there's a good whodunit plot, from a Michael Brett novel, beneath all the commotion. But while the steam seldom runs out, the gas does. The pace lags. It adds up to a dirty joke, often sharp, but dirty. It's too much and not enough. Both.

title: State Officials Deny Approving City U.'s PrivateColleges Plan
description: New York State officials said yesterday that they had not approved plans for the City University of New York to share the costs of sending about 400 community  college graduates to private colleges for further study.

title: COTTON FUTURES DROP $3 A BALE
description: Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined as much as $3 a bale yesterday on general liquidation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Aug. 4 editorial Tin Cup for Industry seems to me unduly optimis tic. When one comes upon a tin cup in the street, one has the option; de pending upon the holder's apparent worthiness or lack of it, to contribute or not. Taxpayers have no such choice. They are forced by the U.S. Govern ment to bail out the bankers who erred in trusting Lockheed.

title: OTB FUTURE ROSY, SAMUELS INSISTS
description: Fresh from a twoday inter lude at Saratoga, Howard J. Samuels predicted yesterday the Offtrack Betting Corpora tion would be handling $1mil lion a day by October.

title: Ulster Internment Move Stirs Doubt and Dissent
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15  A week after the Government imposed intern ment without trial on its mill tant opponents, the impact of the policy remains uncertain and controversial.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 17Dennis Walters of Bat tleground and George. Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills today compiled tworound totals of 148 to tie for the medal in the New Jersey sectional qualifier for the United States Amateur championship at the Essex County Country Club.

title: U. S. Volleyball Team Wins Havana Opener With Ease
description: HAVANA, Aug. 17 Cuba provided a cordial welcome for the United States men's volley ball team, and the Netherlands Antilles was even more gra cious today, winning only 6 points in three games against the Americans.

title: Joe Cribari, 51, Composer For SandlerYoung Team
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 17 (AP)Joe Cribari, the arranger and composer for the singing team of Sandler and Young, died Saturday in Sparks, Nev. He was 51 years old and lived in New Milford, N. J.

title: Dr. Bernard Finch Wins Parole in Slaying of Wife
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 17 (AP)  Dr. R. 13ernard Finch was ordered released on pa role today, from a life term In the slaying of his wife.proached about jobs in Missouri, Nebraska and Maryland. The Missouri offer was from a small rural community that wanted him to operate a small hos pital and clinic.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: As very recent refugees from Ru mania, we would like to comment on Dr. David S. Lefson's statement about Rumania (letter July 27).

title: Chad Cholera Toll at 2.011
description: FORT LAMY, Chad (AP)A total of 2,011 persons have died in a cholera epidemic in this central African state since May. The disease appears to be wan ing, officials said, but a measles epidemic is following it. There were 25 deaths out of 180 cases of measles in the region north of Lake Chad last week, they said.

title: Not Too Early for Yule Plans
description: The temperature was in the 80's yesterday, but officials of Rockefeller Center were look ing ahead to Christmas and the evergreen that towers each year over the skating rink. The Center announced that its 39th Christmas tree would come from East Montpelier, Vt. It is a 65foot balsam, due to arrive in New York on Nov. 29.

title: Peking Is Seeking to Erode Soviet and U.S. Influence
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 United States officials said to day that they believed Peking had opened a worldwide diplo matic offensive concentrating on countries where the Soviet Union has had a dominant in fluence and on those with cloie relationships or alliances with Washington.

title: STRICT RULES URGED ON MINERS HEALTH
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)The director of occupa tional health for the United Mine. Workers of America urged the Federal Government today to pass strict health standards for surface and un derground coal mines.

title: Tidalium Pelo Hurt Again, But Rates 41 in Rich Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 17 A notsofunny thing hap pened to Tidalium Plo on the French trotter's way to Roose velt Raceway this morning. When the van transporting Tidalium Pelo and and. Une de Mai, the other French entrant in Saturday night's $125,000 Roosevelt International, from the quarantine station at Clif ton, N. J., reached Garden City, Tidelium Pelo reared and bounced against the wall of the truck, bruising his right hip.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Prices continued to rise on a broad front in active trading on the American Stock Ex change yesterday although the advance and turnover were less than on Monday. The upswing on Monday stemmed from Pres ident Nixon's plan to curb in flation and to strengthen the economy.

title: Crate Linked to 1733 Ship Defies Attempt to Open It
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 17 Archeologiats were blocked today in attempts to open a packing crate believed spilled into the Atlantic Ocean 288 years ago when a Spanish con voy was sunk by a Florida hurricane.

title: HUGO WEBER, 53, ABSTRACT ARTIST
description: Hugo Weber, a painter long recognized as a member of the avantgarde, died Monday in VincerresHospital following a short illness. He was 53 years old and had lived and worked for many years in the loft rstudio building at 797 Green liwich Street.

title: AIR FARE INCREASES RULED OUT BY C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The nation's airlines were told by the Civil Aeronautics Board today that they would not be able to implement a promised 3 per cent domestic fare in crease or any other rise in Pares during the Administra tion's wageprice freeze.

title: Albrecht Goetze of Yale Is Dead; Leading Babylonian Scholar, 74
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 17Al brecht E. R. Goetze, Sterling Professor Emeritus of Assyri ology and Babylonian Literature at Yale University, and a foun der of the science of laittit ology, died Sunday in Garmisch, Germany. He was 74 years old. Professor Geotze had suffered a stroke while vacationing at Schlosselmau near, Munich.

title: At Last, Devaluation
description: BOSTONPresident Nixon on Aug. 15 announced the de facto devaluation of the dollar. The moment he instruct ed Secretary of the Treasury Connally to suspend gold payments, the fixed exchange system set up in 1944 at Bretton Woods became part of history.

title: Stopping the 50Cent Fare
description: Somewhat like the municipal buses which tend to run late and to travel in packs, New York City's political leaders have all suddenly come alive to the need for action now to save the present thirtycent transit fare. They are not counting on President Nixon's ninetyday wageprice freeze to be extended long enough to provide a bulwark on Jan. 1 when transit labor contracts expire the customary precedent to a big jump in subway and bus fares.

title: Books of The Times
description: MARTIN BUBER. An Intimate Portrait. By Aubrey Hodes. 242 pages, Viking. $7.95.

title: Guidelines on WagePrice Controls Are Drafted Amid Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Amid governmental and public confusion over the specifics of President Nixon's 90day freeze on wages and prices, the Office of Emergency Prepared ness said today that policy guidelines on wageprice con trols would be issued before the end of the week.

title: EVANS PLATS DRAW, LEADS CHESS. AT 7
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 17 International Grandmaster Larry Evans of Reno retained his lead, by half a point, when he drew with International Grandmaster. Pal Benko of New York in the eighth round of the United States open chess championship yesterday.

title: POLICE EXPANDING THE TEAM SYSTEM
description: The Neighborhood Police Team system went into effect yesterday in two more pre cincts, including for the first, time, the entire area covered by one precinct.

title: Paris Simons reaches for ladder from attic eyrie of his bedroom.
description: VANCOUVER, B. C.Like everyone else who comes to their house overlook ing an inlet of the Pacific here, Sidney B. Simons's motherinlaw trudged up the 104 steps that have no railings. The steps are steep, too, for the house is perched about 100 feet above the sea, on a rocky plateau halfway up the hill that is their property.

title: Burroughs to Build Display
description: The TransLux Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Burroughs Corporation for the development of largescale, flat wall information displays. In itially, the new displays will be designed to carry highvisibility alphanumeric information in airports and stockbrokerage operations. Future plans include the subsequent marketing in other industries of multipur pose panel displays.

title: Jets Joke at Namath Bravado For Game He's Going to Miss
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 17 The Jets joked today about Joe Namath's bravado, returned four experienced tacklers to their special teams, placed four rookies on waivers and obtained a 225pound guard, Steve Alexakos, from the Den ver Broncos in exchange for a future draft choice.

title: SISTER TEAM LEADS BY STROKE WITH 77
description: JERICHO, L. I., Aug. 17 Mrs. Justine Cushing of the home club and her sister, Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock, held a onestroke lead after the first round of the 36 hole Barbara Kirkland Mem orial tournament today.

title: U.S. Acknowledges Raids By B52's in Buffer Zone
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Atig. 17The United States command acknowledged today for the first time that Ameri can B52 bombing raids had been flown in the southern half of the demilitarized zone at the border between North Vietnam and South Vietnam.

title: Golf Comes First For Bullets Marin In the OffSeason
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 17Jack Marin stepped up to the 10th tee today and drove the ball about 220 yards. Kevin Loughery, his Baltimore Bullet teammate, was next up and his ball trav eled some 230 yards. Billy Cunningham of the Philadel phia 76ers hesitated for a moment and said both play ers were out of his class and offered to drop out of the match. The stakes were high: The loser had to buy $25 worth of golf balls.

title: WALLACE TO SEEK RULING ON BUSING
description: DALLAS, Aug. 17Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that the Federal Government must take him to court to halt his antibusing orders.

title: Buses in Pittsburgh Put. Back in Service After 8Day Strike
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17Port Authority transit buses re sumed their runs out of the Homewood garage at 4 A.M. today, ending an eightday, walkout that began after a black driver had been sus pended for wearing a Free Angela Davis button.

title: Ammunition Cars Explode In Iowa Freight Derailment
description: ALBIA, Iowa, Aug. 17 (AP) Exploding military smallarms ammunition hindered volunteer firemen who battled flames from a 41car train derailment 10 miles northeast of here to night. The 41 cars were part of an 89car Burlington Northern freight bound from Grand Is land, Neb., to Chicago.

title: BRACCIALE RIDES 5 JERSEYWINNERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 17 (AP)  Dorothy McConville's Go Blow Your Horn scored his second straight victory today in the Hainilton Purse before 12,282 at Atlantic City race track.

title: Mayor Troubled by Effect of the Wage: Freeze on City's Uniformed Services
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that he was deeply trou bled by the impact of Presi dent Nixon's wageprice freeze on the 65,000 men in the city's uniformed services, whose con tract, expired last December.

title: Corporation Leaders Hasten to Study Nixon s Economic Program
description: Hurried executive meetings and detailed studies of Presi dent Nixon's sweeping new eco nomic program took place yes terday in corporate conference rooms across the country.

title: DODGERS OSTEEN DOWNS METS, 40, ON THREEHITTER
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 17 While Nolan Ryan, one of the Mets many enigmas this sea son, continued his rapid slide down the pitching ladder, Claude Osteen pitched a three hitter as Los Angeles defeated New York, 40, tonight.

title: SOVIET OFFER OF AID TO MALTA REPORTED
description: VALLETTA, Malta, Aug. 17 (AP)The Soviet Union, which is said to be seeking air and naval facilities on this Mediter ranean island between Sicily and Libya, has; told the new Maltese Government that it is favorably ready to consider a request for economic assis tance, informed sources said today.

title: Thomas Moseley Dies at 93; Starof In Abraham's Bosom
description: Thomas W. Moseley, who played a leading role in Paul Green's In Abraham's Bosom, which won the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1926, died yester day at his home, 994 St. Nicho las Avenue. His age was 93.

title: SIEGMUND LIST, NAZI GENERAL, 91
description: GARMISCH  PARTENKIR CHEN, Germany, Aug. 17 (AP) Field Marshal Siegmund Wil helm List, whose forces cracked the French Maginot Line in May, 1940, died today. He was 91 years old.

title: Ford Bows to Federal Freeze, Dropping Planned Price Rises
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17  The Ford Motor Company bowed to the Government today and rolled back the price increase on its 1972 models, only hours after Ford officials had said they would ask the Government to allow some increases.

title: Iran Recognizes China
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 17 (UPI)Iran officially recog nized Peking as the sole legal Government of China today and said the two nations would soon exchange ambassadors, according to a joint communi qu made public simultaneous ly in Teheran and Peking.

title: Leone and Merola Call on City To Seek State Transit Subsidy
description: Brooklyn Borough President Sebastian Leone and City Council Finance Chairman Mario Merola called on the Board of Estimate and City Council yes terday to unite in urging a state subsidy to save the 30 cent bus and subway fare.

title: A Show of Italy's Forgotten Art
description: FLORENCE, Italy  Out side Italy, Italian. 19thcen tury art is virtually tin known. Critics at large, historians and the public generally have neglected or simply snubbed it as a vapid, derivative esthetic phenome non with little originality and a little too much aca demicism.

title: Texas Jury Hears Key Figure in Stock Case Scandal
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 17  Frank W. Sharp, key figure in a stock transaction scandal, testified for three hours and 40 minutes before a Travis County grand jury today after, first invoking the Fifth Amend ment protection against self incrimination.

title: 1970 LOSS SHOWN BY DATA INDUSTRY
description: Companies that supply data processing services to industry and government increased their total revenues last year but had an overall loss.

title: Safety or Special Pleading?
description: In the name of safety, the United Transportation Union has been threatening to refuse to run Long Island Rail road trains through the Penn Central's East River tunnels. Harold J. Pryor, president of the trainmen's local, main tains that the chances of tunnel fires will continue endanger passengers and crews until the company com plies with a recent order of the Fire Department, upheld by the Board of Standards and Appeals, for installation of a standpipe system that would allow fires to be fought with hose and water.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)  The Houston Chronicle said to day that Sharp had testified that he arranged for stock in concern he controlled to be pur chased by the wife of a Federal bank examiner who was check ing books at Sharp's bank.

title: Church Plans 4Book Version of Pentagon Study
description: The Beacon Press, a non profit publishing branch of the Unitarian Universalist Associa tion, announced yesterday that it would publish a 3,000page, fourvolume version of the Pentagon's secret study of United States involvement in Indochina.

title: Output of Propylene Oxide In Michigan Ended by Dow
description: MIDLAND, Mich., Aug. 17 (AP)The Dow Chemical Com pany disclosed today that it had abandoned production of propylene oxide in Midland. It said costs of raw material in Michigan are twice as high as on the Gulf Coast.

title: Horace McMahon, Actor, Dies; Noted for Character Portrayals
description: Horace McMahon, the long time character actor who was at home on a Hollywood set or a Broadway stage, died last night in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. McMahon, who was 64 years old, had been suffering from a heart ailment. His home was on Rowayton Avenue in Rowayton, Conn.

title: Government's Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Office of Emergency Pre paredness issued a series of questions and answers today giving policy guidance on the wageprice freeze ordered by President Nixon Sunday eve ning.

title: Chinese Ask Court To Bar Busing Plan For San hancisco
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) A group of Chinese parents appealed to the Supreme Court today to block the massive transfer of Chinese children away from their neighborhood schools in San Francisco.

title: Wallace Move Welcomed
description: HOBSON CITY, Ala., Aug. 17 (AP) Mayor Joe Striplin of Hobson City, a Negro, expressed hope today that Governor Wal lace could get by with his promised intervention in an other school integration dis pute.

title: Announced Dividend Rises Exempt in Freeze Appeal
description: Dividend increases announced but not paid before Aug. 15 are exempt from Treasury sec retary John B. Connally's ap peal to corporations not to pay higher dividends during the 90 day pricewage freeze, it de veloped yesterday.

title: Corvair Recall Urged; Heat System Scored
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 17 (UPI)  Consumers Union urged General Motors today to recall and repair the 900,000 Corvair automobiles still on the road because of what it called dangerous car bon monoxide levels pro duced when the heater is in use.

title: PEKING
description: PEKING, Aug. 17It is hard to see the Chinese people these days for the political billboards, but despite the ceaseless propaganda it is easy to un derstand why so many Americans have had such a crush on them for so long.

title: Worried Europeans Study FreeFloating Currencies
description: LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 18European finance officials, urgently seeking a way out of the dollar crisis, moved last night toward the idea of letting their currencies float against the dollar for a time without fixed exchange rates.

title: 2 AGREE ON SPENDING IN SURROGATE RACE
description: Family Court Judge Millard L. Midonick and Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer agreed yesterday to limit the total amount spent in their campaigns for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Surrogate to $41,500 each.

title: AUSTRALIAN PARTY FILLS GORTON POST
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Wed nesday Aug. 18 (Reuters)  Treasury Minister Billy Sneed den, was elected deputy leader of the Australian Liberal party today to succeed the deposed Defense Minister and former Prime Minister John Gorton.

title: Death Toll in Typhoon That Struck Hong Kong Area Is at Least 90
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 17 (AP) A typhoon killed more than 90 people in Hong Kong and surrounding waters today when it struck the British colony headon with 130 mileanhour winds and 12 inches of rain.

title: Market Place: Cash Dividend: Is It obsolete?
description: DENVER, Aug. 17Is the cash dividend obsolete? Ge nial, rapidtalking Robert M. Abisch seems to think so, He is certainly convinced that this is true as far as mutual funds are concerned, and he thinks it is possible that cor porate cash dividends are ob solete as well.

title: Animators Reactivate Unit
description: Due to increased interest by film animation companies in Mew York, the Animation Pro ducers Association has been re activated, under its 10yearold state charter. Jack Zander, president of Zander's Anima tion Parlour, has been elected president, and Buzz Potemkin, of the Perpetual Motion Com pany, was voted secretary treasurer of the 18companyor ganization at its recent meeting.

title: 426 Acres for Oregon
description: MEDFORD, Ore., Aug. 17 (UPI)Mrs. Nixon gave Ore gon 426 acres of Federal land today and then flew to San Diego, where she will dedi cate 372 acres near the Mex ican border Wednesday. She was spending the night at San Clemente, Calif.

title: Summer Air Scores by Half A Length at Saratoga for his 3d Straight Victory
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 17The Darby Dan. Farm's Summer Air set the pace from the start in the fea ture event today and won the 11/8mile test by half a length. Angel Cordero rode the winner, whose nearest rival was the long shot, Joans Bo, a 3year old ridden by Mike Venezia. In scoring, Summer Air record ed his third straight triumph, his last success being in the Gravesend Handicap at Ague duct.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The bond market continued to surge yesterday in response to President Nixon's new economic program.

title: Excerpts From President's Speech to Knights of Columbus
description: Following are excerpts from the text of President Nixon's speech at the Knights of Coluntbus dinner last night in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Record Set in July For Housing Starts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)Private housing starts set a record in July when resi dential building reached an an nual rate of 2,218,000 dwell ing units, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: Burns, Humm, Siderowf Gain U.S. Amateur Berths
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 17George Burns 3d of Plan dome, a University of Mary land senior, scored 74, 71 145 today at the Deepdale Golf Club to lead the Long Island qualifiers for the United States Golf Associa tion Amateur championship. Par for the 6,915yard course is 35, 3570.

title: SEIXAS DEFEATED IN MERTON TENNIS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 17 Vic Seixas and Alex Olmedo were defeated in the second round of the 72d annual Penn sylvania lawn tennis champion ship at the Merlon Cricket Club oday.

title: Lean Days Beset Catholic Publishers
description: Roman Catholic book pub lishing, which flourished in the wake of the Second Vati can Council of 1962 to 1965, has fallen on hard times.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism3:30 P.M.

title: ALGERIAN PAPER ASKS NEW OILPRICE PACT
description: ALGIERS, Aug. 17 (AP) President Nixon's economic program will require a fun damental revision of the Tehran and Tripoli agreements on crude oil prices. The Alge rian Government newspaper El MoudjahidThe Combatant said today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The New York Mets need all the help they can get these days and one fellow who could have supplied the extra oomph was playing center field yesterday for the Kansas City Royals in the Yankee Stadium. He is Amos Otis and the flounderers from Shea Stadium have no one blame but themselves. They had him but let him get away.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration yesterday received $47.8million addition to an Army contract for continued development of the Cheyenne attack helicopter.

title: COL. ADOLPH KRAMER
description: Col. Adolph Kramer, a retired realestate agent who at one time had owned the Adams and Volney Hotels on the East Side, died yesterday of heart failure in a nursing home in New Rochelle. He was 77 years old and lived at 165 East 72d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Aug. 4 letter of Howard W. Pollock, Acting Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, is so misleading and inaccurate as to require a clarifying response.

title: French Satellite in Orbit
description: PARIS, Aug. 17, Reuters The French weather satellite Dole is orbiting the earth every 100 minutes in a slightly off target orbit, the French space administration said here to day. The satellite, launched yesterday by an American Scout rocket from Wallops Island, Va., was circling the earth at a height varying be tween 535 miles and 125 miles.
