title: Office of Preparedness Open, but Not Too Prepared
description: Can a coffee shop charge 5 cents more today for a cup of coffee than it did on Friday?

title: Justice at Kent State?
description: Attorney General Mitchell has decided against any Federal prosecution of individual National Guardsmen in connection with the Kent State killings, though he shares the belief of the President's Commission on Campus Un rest that the Guard's resort to gun fire was unnecessary, unwarranted and inexcusable. Mr. Mitchell is probably right in contending that the chances of proving per sonal guilt against any guardsman are virtually nil.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSA Greek minister com plains: We only have problems with our friends; our enemies sit back and hope they can benefit. He referred to Greece's expulsion from the Coun cil of Europe, the row about contin uing U. S. military aid and festering behindthescenes arguments in NATO.

title: MORTON POLISHES HIS IMAGE IN WEST
description: PAGE, Ariz., Aug. 17Secre tary of Interior Rogers C. B. Morton is moving with ap parent ease among the bureau crats and politicians on the eighth day of his monthlong tour of 17 Western states.

title: Zambian Tourist Office In Rome Forced to Close
description: ROME, Aug. 17  The Di rector of the Zambian Tourist and Information Bureau for Western Europe, Arsian Hum barachi, said today that the bureau had been closed by the Zambian Ambassador in Rome under pressure from the Italian Government.

title: Businessmen in Europe Feel Anxiety Over Dollar
description: LONDON, Aug. 17The United States surcharge on im ports and the unresolved ques tions about the value of the dollar caused continuing anxie ties today among American and other businessmen in Europe.

title: Lindsay Sends Regrets To Knights of Columbus
description: Mayor Lindsay declined an invitation to attend the an nual Knights of Columbus dinner last night at the WaldorfAstoria that was ad dressed by President Nixon.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Article 1  No Title
description: DETROIT, Aug. 17 (AP) The irregularity in Haskell Shanks's heartbeat was brought under control overnight and Sinai Hospital said today his appetite and strength were im proving daily.

title: Isolationist Burma Seems to Be Opening Door a Crack
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 12 Burma, one of the most iso lationist nations in modern his tory, seems to be reopening the door to the outer world a small crack But if there is any wel come mat at all, it seems to be printed Chinese and not English.

title: TRANSPLANT PATIENT DIES IN CAPETOWN
description: CAPETOWN, Aug. 17 (AP) Adrian Herbert, the world's fourth heartandlung trans plant patient, died today. He lived 23 days after the opera tion, the longest of any of the four.

title: Broadway Maintenance Official Says Checks Paid ltkin's Bills
description: The controller of the Broad way Maintenance Corporation testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had issued checks to Herbert Itkin after receiving bills from him for professional services.

title: Edward Anthony, Writer, Dies; Former Collier's Publisher, 76
description: NEW MILFORD; Conn., Aug. 17Edward Anthony, writer and former publisher of Wo man's Home Companion and Collier's magazines, died of a heart attack yesterday in Gloucester, Mass., where he was spending the summer. He was 76 years old and lived on Aspetuck Ridge Road.

title: Repertory Theater Of Lincoln Center Slates Four Plays
description: The forthcoming season the Repertory Theater of Lin coln Center will offer plays by Arthur Miller, Friedrich Schil ler, Edward Bond and Shake speare at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Each production will run for seven consecutive weeks, preceded by 12 pre views. The cast will be an nounced later.

title: Teledyne, Inc., Down In Sales and Net
description: Teledyne, Inc., makers of electronic and aviation sys tems, specialty metals, un manned aircraft, internal com bustion engines and geophysi cal products, showed lower sales and earnings for the three and nine months ended July 31, it was reported yesterday from Los Angeles headquarters.

title: Flintkote Plans Expansion
description: The Flintkote Company said yesterday that it planned major expansion costing about $13million of its Portland ce ment manufacturing plant at Glens Falls, N.Y. The project increase the plant's kilnburning capacity by 80 per cent to three million barrels a year.

title: Notes on People
description: The in the White House took time out from dealing with problems of the economy to welcome the man of the hour in baseball, Vida Blue, the sensational left handed pitcher of the Oak land. Athletics.

title: Rise in Jobs Poses Problem in Suburbs
description: Ten years ago much of Bridgewater Township, N. J., still looked much as it did when George Washington camped his troops in the safety of the first range of the Watchung Moun tains.

title: Boyer Succeeding Patton As Republic Steel's Chief
description: Thomas F. Patton announced yesterday his retirement as chairman and chief executive officer of the Republic Steel Corporation.

title: City Patrolman, 26, Accused of Raising Marijuana in Park
description: A 26yearold patrolman was arrested yesterday on charges of growing marijuana plants behind a stable in Central. Park used by the mounted pa trol squad.

title: K. of C. Little Changed in Years
description: Founded 90 years ago by a parish priest in New Haven, the Knights of Columbus has grown from a benevolent, fra ternal and somewhat secretive Roman Catholic society with 12 members into a benevolent, fraternal and still somewhat secret society with nearly 1.2 million members.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Aug. 10 article by C. D. Darling ton on the OpEd page concludes with these sentences:

title: Military Pay Rise Delay Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The Defense Department said today the $2.4billion military pay rise scheduled for Oct. might he delayed until mid November under the new wage freeze.

title: About Motor Sports
description: In a move to broaden its competition, the New York Region of the Sports Car Club of America has invited licenseholders from other racing groups to enter its Enduro Race Sunday at the Eridgehampton (L.I.) Race Circuit. Federation Interna tionale de L'Automobile and National Associa tion for Stock Car Auto Racing drivers are Wei come in the race, provided their vehicles meet the safety re quirements of the S.C.C.A. John Laux, the registrar for the event, had entries yester day from competitors.

title: FRANCIS S. MURPHY, HARTFORD PUBLISHER
description: WEST HARTFORD, Aug. 17 Francis S. Murphy, former editor and publisher of The Hartford Times, who had a ter minal building named for him at Bradley International Air port, Windsor Locks, died of a heart attack today at his home. He was 88 years old.

title: Shiner's Demand: Trade Me
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Dick Shiner, backup quarter back who walked out of the New York Giants camp last weekend, said he made only one demand of Coach Alex Webster: Trade me.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS CONGRESS BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  President Nixon spent two and onehalf hours today in an ap parently successful effort to convince leaders of the House and Senate of the merits of his emergency tax reduction pro posals for business and indi viduals.

title: Nine Witnesses Unable to Place Medina at Site of Mylai Slayings
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 17 Men whose testimony helped convict Frist Lieut. Wil liam L. Caney Jr. gave an other recital today of the de tails of the Mylai mass killings. They appeared ha Government witnesses in the courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who commanded the troops involved in the incident.

title: U.S. Artillery Moves Up
description: SAIGON, Wednesday, Aug. 18 (AP)  American artillerymen moved west along the demilitarized zone yesterday to sup port South Vietnamese troops in the sixth day of a North Viet namese drive.

title: CEDAR POINT KEEPS LEAD IN MIDGET SAIL
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Aug. 17The Cedar Point Yacht Club crew, with Henry. Brauer as helmsman, continued to lead in the elimination series of the Junior Yacht Racing Associa tion's 48th annual Long Island Sound Midget championship today. Only one race could be sailed off Larchmont Y.C. dur ing another nine hours on the water because of insufficient wind.

title: New Balance in World Money
description: As the United States heads into negotiations with its chief allies abroad to revise exchange rates and shape a new word financial system, it is essential that the country be clear about the nature of the current monetary crisis.

title: Head of A.E.C. Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) James R. Schlesinger of the White House staff became chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission today when he was sworn in at a ceremony in President Nixon's office. Wil liam Doub, Baltimore lawyer and chairman of the Maryland Public Service Commission, took the oath as a member of the A.E.C.

title: GOVERNMENT ASKS END OF STRIKES DURING FREEZE ON PAY AND PRICES;
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Nixon Administration called today on about 150,000 workers now involved in more than 350 strikes across the country to return to work dur ing the 90day wage and price freeze imposed by the Presided Sunday night.

title: Faulkner Is Backed by Ulster's Unionist M.P.'s
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 17, (Reuters)Northern Ireland's ruling Unionist party tonight gave Prime Minister Brian Faulkner its full support for his policies to end violence.

title: Increased Imports Of U.S. Candies Souring Japanese
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17With all the furor over President Nixon's announcement of a 10 per cent surtax on imports to the United States, Japanese manufacturers have been making sideward glances at what some of them have dubbed a chewing gum and chocolate war.

title: Taipei Suspends Ties
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Nationalist, China has suspended dlplo matic relations with Iran and will pull its rice technical mis sion out of the country in pro test of Teheran's recognition of Peking.

title: Unable to Find New Site, the Chauveron Closes
description: Cafe Chauveron, one of the few remaining grand luxe French restaurants in the city, has closed its doors for good.

title: Fund Adviser Role Urged For Bank Holding Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board issued a proposal today that would permit bank hold ing companies to serve as in vestment advisers to mutual funds under the bank holding company act.

title: Retailing Center Renews Area
description: Fifteen years ago, Joyce C. Hall, founder and chairman of Hallmark Cards, and the late Walt Disney walked out side the sprawling greeting card plant in Kansas City, Mo., and cupped their hands against the sun as they stud ied the nearby area.

title: SIX ISRAELIS GET SOVIET INVITATION
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 17Moscow will be host next week to six prominent Israelis invited by the Soviet Peace Committee for a twoweek tour.

title: CRITICS ANSWERED
description: President Nixon appealed here last night to the nation's moral power and for tempo rary sacrifice to back up his new economic program.

title: Roundup: Surging Reds Making Cardinals Blue
description: Monday night on national television, Johnny. Bench of the Cincinnati Reds, who are far out of pennant conten tion, predicted that his ball club was in good form and that a lot of contending teams will be cussing us out.

title: Bank of Japan Continues Heavy Support of Dollar
description: TOKYO, Aug. 17The Bank of Japan bought $690million on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today in continued heavy support of the American currency, according to reliable sources.

title: Bausch & Lomb Sets Deal
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y. Aug. 17 (UPI)Bausch & Lomb, which has exclusive license from the national patent development Corporation to market new softens contact lens in the United States, has made a simi lar agreement for distribution in Japan Okinawa, South Korea, the Philippines, Taiwan and Hong Kong. Bausch & Lomb, which manufactures the lenses, made the agreement with Na tional Patent and its subsidiary, Hydros Pacific Inc.

title: Dance: Unique Troupe
description: The New York City Ballet Opened its second annual twoweek summer season last night at the State Thee teran occasion to reflect upon the obvious. The ob vious is that there is no other company like it.

title: Executive Changes
description: Clifford Tweter, president of Western Bancor poration, was elected chief executive officer Western and Norman Barker, president of United California Bank, was elected chief executive officer of United California.

title: SAIGON GETS 18 BIDS FOR OIL EXPLORATION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 16 (UPI)  Eighteen oil companies have bid on conces sion rights for offshore petro leum exploration on the con tinental shelf in the South China Sea, the Government news organ, Vietnam Press, an nounced today.

title: Undervalued Yen Called Main Target of Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  President Nixon sees the new 10 per cent surcharge on im ported goods as a form of lev erage that can be retained un til other countriesabove all Japan  make appropriate up ward changes in their curren cies exchange rates, top level officials explained today.

title: Latest Giants Walkout: Recently Arrived Tackle
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug 17  After having recalled waiv ers on Dick Shiner, the New York Giants hoped today to ar range a trade for the disen chanted quarterback.

title: Freeze to Delay Rise In Bulk Mail Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount said today that the Pos tal Service, in line with Presi dent Nixon's order freezing wages and prices, would not implement an increase in third class mail rates that had been scheduled for Sept. 15.

title: Chrysler Units Get Top Credit Rating
description: The Chrysler Corporation an nounced yesterday that the National Credit Office, a unit of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., that rates issuers of commercial pa per, has restored its prime credit rating to the Chrysler Financial Corporation and its subsidiary north of the border, Chrysler Credit Canada, Ltd.

title: TWO SHARE MEDAL IN WOMEN'S GOLF
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (AP) Connie Day and Jane Bastan chury carded their second con secutive 75's today to share medalist honors in the 71st United States Amateur Golf Championship.

title: STATE IS PLANNING WEEKLY LOTTERY
description: New York State plans to switch its monthly lottery to a, weekly lottery around the end of the year, to provide ticket buyers with faster action and to provide the state with, hopefully, more money.

title: The Military and Morality
description: Presidents Johnson and Kennedy sent half a million soldiers to Vietnam. President Nixon is bringing home 14,000 a month (230,000 are left now). Meanwhile, some erstwhile Kennedy Johnson supporters want to impeach Mr. Nixon. Our soldiers are accused not only of waging anlunjust war but also of war crimes and our corn manders of ordering or condoning them. While the enemy has repudiated them, we have recognized the laws and customs of war as binding. They do not avoid the horrors of war, but they do restrict the evil they cannot eliminate. Have we violated them?

title: Muskie Acts to Aid Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, has asked the Labor Department to take steps to protect the jobs and salaries of employes of the Air Force Eastern Test Range in Brevard County, Fla. He noted that the Pan American World Airways contract for main tenance and operation at the site was due for rebidding and said the livelihood of 5,000 workers was threatened.

title: Kathy Walsh, Trainer, Suspended at Track
description: RENTON, Wash., Aug. 17 (AP)Stewards at Longacres Race Track barred the track's leading trainer today and sus pended a second trainer after traces of drugs were found in two horses.

title: DUFALLO CONDUCTS AT MOSTLY MOZART
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival concert given at Philharmonic Hall on Monday night (and scheduled for a repeat there tonight) had Richard Dufallo as conductor of the New York Chamber Orchestra with Chris toph Eschenbach, pianist, and Bernard Goldberg, flutist, as soloists.

title: 14 ARE ARRESTED IN GAMBLING RAID
description: The Brooklyn District Attor ney said yesterday that a $50 millionayear gambling syndi cate controlled by members of organized crime had been smashed with the arrests of 11 men and three women.

title: FIRE DRILLS ASKED FOR APARTMENTS
description: Fire drills should be held in highrise apartment buildings, Dr. Charles F. Schaffner, ex ecutive director of the Mayor's Advisory Committee to Improve Fire Safety in HighRise Build ings, said yesterday.

title: At Havana Games, U.S.Cuban Amity
description: HAVANA, Aug. 17Jos was born in Cuba. He has lived here all his life, is widely read, speaks several languages, attended the Uni versity of Havana at a time when another student, Fidel Castro Ruz, was also in school and works for the Na tional Sports Institute.

title: TRUSTEES OF PENNSY SEEK SALE OF STOCK
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (UPI)The trustees of the Penn Central Railroad asked Federal court today for permission to sell more than a million shares of stock in the Madison Square Garden Corporation, the con cern that owns the New York Rangers hockey club and the Knickerbockers basketball club.

title: Men in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 In Paris today, just before fly ing to Washington, Paul Adolph Volcker, the United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Af fairs, told reporters, The dollar is healthier today than it was at the weekend. There was more behind this remark than met the ears. What was behind it was a change of view as radical as President Nixon's change in economic policy.

title: East Germany's Party Leader Reported Pressing Policy of Fencing Off West Germany
description: BERLIN, Aug. 17The policy of Erich Honecker, the new East German leader, directed at fencing off his Communist state from West Germany is as suming ever stronger forms, according to his party press.

title: On the Old Lower East Side
description: You mean, asked the sociological scholar from Pennsylvania, that this is the Lower East Side you knew as a boy fiftyfive years ago? The pro fessor, who had never visited the area before, was disappointed in too many ways. Where were the crowds of re ligious Jews, the ancient tenements, the Jewish religious schools, the kosher butchers, the colorful cafs all the warming images of the Yid dish ghetto? The high risers had taken over most of the area.

title: Miss Buding Advances
description: LAKE BLUFF, Ill., Aug. 17 (UPI)  Women from England, Italy and West Germany led a field of eight qualifyinground winners today in the first championship flight of the $20, 000 Virginia Slims clay courts tennis tourney.

title: Full Service Range to Be Provided
description: The formation of a partner ship that will conduct a world wide brokerage business in commodity futures was an nounced yesterday by the Louis Dreyfus Corporation and ACLI International, Inc.

title: An Increase of 8.1 % In 1972 U.N. Budget Requested by Thant
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 17  Secretary General Thant has requested a 1972 budget totaling $207,721,500, or 8.1 per cent more than this year's expenses. It would be the first time that the budget has gone above $200million.

title: Merger News
description: Norton Simon, Inc., a diver sified consumerproducts com pany with sales of more than $1billion a year, announced yesterday that it was negotiat ing to acquire the privately owned StitzelWeller Distillery, Inc., a Louisville, Ky., producer of bourbon whisky.

title: Truck With Radioactive Load To Leave L.I. for Disposal Site
description: BELLPORT, L. I., Aug. 17A trailer truck loaded with radio active waste material, which has been sitting on a lot near Sunrise Highway here for more than a year, was set to roll tonight toward its final destina tion, a nuclear waste disposal site near Buffalo.

title: Lottery Bill Gains in Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate gave inl tial approval today to a House passed bill establishing a lot tery in the state. The measure advanced on a 20to15 rollcall following three hours of debate.

title: Mrs. Nixon Turns Over Land to Minnesota for Park
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 17 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon officially turned over 141 acres of prairie on Fort Snelling today for use as a Minnesota state park area.

title: Advertising:
description: Confirming one of the, worstkept marketing se crets of the year, the Ford Motor Company formally an nounced yesterday that Grey Advertising, Inc., has been appointed to handle the ad vertising for Its Pinto, Mav erick and Mustang car lines.

title: Skburas Rites Tomorrow At Holy Trinity Cathedral
description: A funeral service will be held tomorrow for Spyros P. Skou ras, former chairman of 20th CenturyFox Corporation, who died Monday at his home in Rye, N. Y.

title: outlook for part Hazy  As I.L.P. pact Talks Begin
description: Stevedores and the Inter national Longshoremen's As sociation are scheduled to begin negotiating a new con tract here today againgt an economic backdrop that in cludes sweeping technologi cal changes, declining em ployment on the New York waterfront and a slow ero sion of the port's position as the prime factor in the rich North Atlantic general cargo trede.

title: Raw Foods Exempted From the Price Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI)  The Administration today extended the price freeze exemption for whole sale agricultural commodi ties to cover unprocessed raw foods sold at the retail level, such as fresh vegeta bles, eggs, chickens and fish.

title: Judge to Rule on Testimony In Colonel's Trial on Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 17 (AP)A military judge has promised to rule on a defense motion just 30 minutes before Col. Oran K. Henderson of the Army goes on trial on charges of trying to conceal the Mylai mass killings.

title: BANK OF AMERICA PLANS HOUSTON UNIT
description: The Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest bank, is planning to open a new international banking subsidiary in Houston, Tex. The new fa cility, assuming its formation is approved by the Federal Re serve Board, would be the bank's fourth international sub sidiary in the United States out side of California. The others are situated in New York, Chi cago and Miami.

title: DEFENDANT LINKED TO LOANSHARK PLOT
description: The prosecution's chief wit ness in a loanshark conspir acy case named a missing de fendant yesterday as the go between in getting $12,000 in loans for him over a long period of time.

title: Rosewall, 4 Others Say They'll Bypass Open Tennis Here
description: Ken Rosewall of Australia, last year's champion, and four other contract professionals have withdrawn from the Unit ed States Open Tennis Cham pionships, scheduled to start at Forest Hills, Queens, Sept. 1.

title: ARMY WILL PUNISH 9 IN MYLAI AFFAIR
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Secretary of the Army Rob ert F. Froelke has ordered new disciplinary action against nine officers and enlisted men pre viously cleared of criminal charges stemming from the, Mylai mass killings.

title: New Super Drawing Rights Are Considered For International Monetary Reform
description: PARIS, Aug. 17  Super S.D.R. hag reared its head in the worldwide debate now un der way over monetary reform following President Nixon's an nouncement he would suspend the dollar's links with gold.

title: and How to Negotiate It
description: Unquestionably, the dollar has become seriously over valued as compared to the Japanese yen and somewhat less so as compared to the Deutschemark and a few other European currencies. It is not significantly over valued, however, in relation to other currencies Europe and the world, including the British pound. Changes of exchange rates of from 5 per cent to 15 per cent for eight or ten currencies are the maximum now contemplated anywhere. Japan alone is being urged to revalue upward significantly more than 10 per cent.

title: LEADER RESTORED SIN INDIAN BUREAU
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Department of the Interior disclosed today that Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton had re stored full power to the chief of the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: Equine Brain Fever Strikes Mother of Five in Florida
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 17 (AP)A deadly brain fever transmitted by mosquitoes that has infected 10 horses in Flor ida has stricken a 43yearold widow with five children and left her in critical condition.

title: 2 Banks for Freezing Human Sperm Planned in Midtown, With Services Available to Public
description: In a few weeks two human sperm banks are expected to open for business in New York, providing facilities where, for a fee, any man may have his semen frozen and stored indef initely for use in the procrea tion of a child perhaps decades later.

title: Newsprint Price Rise Barred
description: President Nixon's freeze will apply to the scheduled $8aton increase in the price of news print produced in the United States, the Government said yesterday, The rise was to have taken effect Nov. I.

title: Murphy Says Police Innovations Make City Safer
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that in July New York was a safer city than it was in January.

title: I.O.S. and Insurgents Fall At OutofCourt Settlement
description: FREDERICTON, New Bruns wick, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) Management and dissident shareholders of Investors Over seas Services, Ltd., told the ap peals division of the New Brunswick Supreme Court yes terday that they had failed to settle their differences out of court.

title: PRIPADCHEFF DIES; CLARINETIST AT MET
description: Alexander Pripadcheff, for many years principal clarinetist of the Metropolitan Opera, died July 21 while visiting sisters in his native Irkutsk in Siberia. He was 74 years old and lived on Staten Island. His visit was his first contact with his family in decades.

title: Advertising:
description: Media, advertisers, agencies and security analysts were just as confused yesterday as many other businessmen about the effects of President Nixon's price freeze on advertising rates.

title: DeCavalcante Is. Indicted In Jersey on a Gun Charge
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 17 (UPI)  A Union County grand jury today indicted Simone Riz zo DeCavalcante, a reputed Mafia leader, on charges of il legally acquiring a 38caliber pistol.

title: MISUSE OF PROCEEDS IS CHARGED BY S.E.C.
description: The New York office of the Securities and Exchange Com mission yesterday accused 19 individuals and corporations of having misused $1.9million raised in a December, 1969, underwriting, of the shares of Manor Nursing Centers, Inc.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Once there existed a fundamental principle of international law, sworn to by all signatories of the Charter of the United Nations, that no nation is to meddle in the domestic affairs of other nations.

title: WILKINS APPEALS TO TEACHER UNION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17 Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called on the American Federation of Teachers today to police the Government's administration of education laws.

title: YUDIE WEITZMAN
description: Yudie Weitzman, a pianist and teacher who in recent years gave music appreclatioa courses at the New School, died Saturday while vacation ing with his wife in Wales. He was 68 years old and lived at 210 West 89th Stret.

title: Strong Pact Urged To Curb Pollution In the Great Lakes
description: MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Aug. 17  Fifteen resolutions urging the United States and Canada to forge a strong anti pollution agreement for the Great Lakes were passed today in the final session of the special twoday conference of Great Lakes Governors and Premiers.

title: Boston Informer Testifies
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) Federal authorities sealed off today two floors of the Federal Building in Post Office Square as the underworld informer, Vincent Teresa, told a Federal grand jury about organized crime in New England. He testified under heavy security for about two hours before leaving the building shortly after noon. Details of his testi mony were not disclosed.

title: TV: Analyses of Nixon Order Took a While to Gel
description: President. Nixon seems to be making a habit of the bombshell approach to major news announcements. The pattern is becoming predict able relatively short prelim inary notice of a major an nouncement, a broadcast det onation of some radical change in policy, and finally a hectic scramble in the news media to report and, when possible, to interpret that change.

title: Nixon's Order Bothers Tourists Only Slightly
description: President Nixon may have jolted the world's money mar kets when he suspended the dollar's convertibility into gold Sunday night. He may have frightened a few wouldbe tourists, too, and given sup port to husbands who had been trying to convince their wives to see America first.

title: Yankees Beat Royals Here, 20 and 85
description: The New York Yankees put aside their concern over the na tional freeze on wages long enough yesterday to sweep a doubleheader from the Kansas City Royals, snap out of a threegame losing streak and climb back above the 500 mark.

title: Nigeria Oil Drilling Set
description: LOGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 17 (Agence FrancePresse)  Shell BP, the AngloDutch Oil com pany, is to open new oil wells in Nigeria's east central state, an official disclosed here today. Exploratory drilling will start in the Anambra division of the state's northwest later this year and further wells are planned for the same region next year. ShellBP produces more than a million barrels of crude oil a day, making it the country's biggest producer.

title: Foster Stops McIntosh in 3d
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 17 (AP) Bob Foster scored a third round technical knockout to night over John Vern McIntosh. The World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion, who weighed 182 pounds, decked McIntosh, 180, with a short right late in the first round in the overthelimit bout.

title: Rev. Patrick F. O'Neill, 84, Risked Life in Prison Riot
description: CULLMAN, Ala., Aug. 17 (AP)The Rev. Patrick Fred erick O'Neill, a longtime priest and hero of a 1929 prison riot, died yesterday in a nursing home here at the age of 84.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Thomas H. Jukes Aug. 3 OpEd piece, Like It or Not, DDT Is Good for You, is an extraordinary example of pesticide industry propaganda, an industry of which Professor Jukes was a part for twenty years.

title: Auto Issues Lead 2d Day of Rally As Dow Industrials Climb 10.95
description: Led by an upsurge in the automotive issues, the stock market continued to advance strongly yesterday in what Wall Street traders called the Nixon rally.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Nixon has now shelved his New American Rev olution for his New Economic Policy, which he modestly sug gests is the most comprehen sive economic program since, President Roose velt's New Deal. On first sight, the Roosevelt and Nixon reforma tions could not be more different: the New Deal came at a time of drastically falling prices; Mr. Nixon's N.E.P. (not to be confused with Lenin's N.E.P., which repre sented a drastic overhaul of the Soviet economic game plan of the nineteentwenties) comes at a time of sharp inflation.

title: Autos Lead Parade In New Stock Rise
description: The spectacular Nixon ral ly kept rolling through Wall Street yesterday with automo bile stocks leading the parade.

title: CORE Aide Held at Hospital Protest
description: The chairman of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality was arrested yesterday at Harlem Hospital after a brief sitin during which he demanded the ouster of a white doctor.

title: WEED SOLD IN WEST AS DRUG HELD FAKE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17  The Federal Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs said today that a wild weed that had the smell of marijuana and had been sold as a substance that produced a high had been proved by analysis to be a fake.

title: TALKS ON BERLIN ARE INTENSIFIED
description: BERLIN, Aug. 18The Big Four ambassadors, still pressing to negotiate a settlement of the Berlin problem, conferred for six more hours today and emerged indicating that a con clusion of their meetings was much on their minds.

title: Nixon Vows to Help Parochial Schools; Cardinal Calls Government Aid a Right
description: President Nixon told an en thusiastic audience of Romani Catholics here last night that they could count on his help in efforts to reverse the current trend toward the closing of fi nancially troubled parochial itchools.

title: ExJersey Democratic Leader Receives Suspended Sentence
description: NEWARK, Aug. 17I won't touch another penny, a tear ful Walter W. Wolfe said today after be was given a suspended fiveyear sentence for, his part in the conspiracy by Hudson County and Jersey City offi cials to extort money from con tractors.

title: State Sues Builder On City U. Damage At W. 42d St. Site
description: The owners of the Graduate Center of the City University of New York think the con struction of a building on the neighboring site is a blasta $350,000 blast.

title: Brooke Asks Wide. Support Of Nixon's Foreign Policy
description: BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Senator Edward W., Brooke, who has often been at odds with the Nixon Administration, strongly endorsed today the President's foreign policy and said his quest for a generation of peace entitles him to the trust and support of every American.

title: Riggs to Face Howe Today In Stevens Senior Tennis
description: Bobby Riggs of Plandome, L. I., a former national tennis champion, and Bob Howe of Australia will meet in the first singles match today as the de fending United States senior team faces Australia in the challenge round for the Steyens Cup at the Town Tennis Club, 430 East 56th Street.

title: U.S. Urges Banks To Put Off Freeing Of Export Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The Federal Reserve Board asked banks and other lending institutions today to continue for a time to include export credits under the ceiling on lending to foreigners.

title: Freedom Bank Realignment
description: The Freedom National Bank of New York announced yesterday that William R. Hudgins will relinquish his posts of president and chief executive officer to accept a position as vice chairman of the board. No successor has been named to replace Mr. Hudgins, 64 years old, the bank's first president.

title: STORM KING PLANT GIVEN CLEARANCE BY STATE AGENCY
description: Consolidated Edison's controversial Storm King power plant cleared another environmental hurdle yesterday when the state Commissioner of Environmental Conservation certified that the project would not violate water quality standards.

title: Market Plummets As Trading Eases
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As an Englishman, I would like to comment on Richard Crossman's Aug. 6 OpEd article, A Vote Against the Common Market.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's apparent position on every side of the desegregationbusing issue (as posed in the Austin, Tex., suit) may rather reflect his desire to seek a middle stance between the Austin school board that would have no integration and certain H.E.W. officials who would make integration a cause so absolute as to eliminate all other considerations. Yet the busing of children is a manyfaceted issue, challenged from many sides.

title: 62 New York Youngsters Compete in Boston Today
description: Mayor Lindsay gave an official sendoff yesterday to 62 youngsters who will represent New York City, the 1970 winner, in the fifth annual United States Youth Games in Boston beginning today and ending Saturday.

title: 2 Believed Dead in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  A spokesman for the United States Embassy said here today that two Americans who disappeared in southwestern Uganda early last month now were presumed to be dead. Arrangements were under way to have presumptive death certificates issued for Nicholas Stroh, 33 years old, a freelance journalist from Grosse Pointe Fields, Mich., and Robert Siedle, 46, a university lecturer. Their disappearance is under investigation by a Uganda commission.

title: Panic Hits Stock Market
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19 (Reuters)The Tokyo Stock Exchange was thrown into panic today as investors, fearing a yen revaluation, swamped the market with 50 million shares on sellatany price orders.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John Lindsay's shift from Republican to Democrat is understandable, but nonetheless regretted by those who believe in the twoparty system and the healthy struggle within each party for progressive direction. Those Republicans who have supported him consistently at the expense of their own relations with more conservative and dominant party elements had the right to count on his continued leadership, and he owed them some obligation to continue to assert that leadership within their party.

title: I.B.M. Files Antitrust Claim Against Control Data Corp.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had filed a second antitrust counterclaim against the Control Data Corporation, a rival computer manufacturer.

title: JAIME IBRAN
description: Jaime Ibran, vice president of Lee Lacy, Inc., a Los Angeles filmproduction concern, and former interpreter for the State Department, was killed on Monday in Miraflores, Spain.

title: Japanese Ships Visit Boston
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP)For the first time in 4 years, JapaInese Navy ships of war steamed into the harbor here today. They will, remain for three days on a courtesy visit. The ships are the destroyers Katori and Yamagumo.

title: Red Carpet in Pretoria
description: The Government of South Africa, true to its promise, is giving President H. Kamuzu Banda of Malawi a punctiliously correct and warm reception on his state visit. What makes this a matter of note is that Dr. Banda black, while his cordial white hosts in Pretoria are the same men who ruthlessly enforce a policy of apartheid in their own country.

title: Pakistan Says Mujib's Trial Began a Week Ago
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 18A Government spokesman said today that Sheik. Mujibur Rahman, imprisoned leader of the Bengali separatist movement of Pakistan, is already on trial.

title: Judge Asks Study of Charge That Jail Mistreated Russo
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) A Federal judge ordered an investigation today into allegations that Anthony J. Russo, who refused to testify in the leaking of the secret Pentagon papers, has been mistreated in jail.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What would be the healthiest Formosa policy for the U.S. in order to attain a SinoAmerican detente and world peace? To support the establishment of an independent Formosan state under the principle of the selfdetermination of nations would be the right answer. Such an aim would either be fulfilled by peaceful means or violent revolution.

title: U.S. WITNESS SAYS HE LIED TO JURORS
description: The government's chief witness in a loanshark conspiracy) case admitted under crossexamination yesterday that he had lied to a Federal grand jury, the Westchester County; District Attorney and other law enforcement agencies.

title: DR. LOUIS C. LANGE
description: WEEHAWKEN, N. J., Aug. 18Dr. Louis C. Lange, a surgeon and former president of the New York University medical alumni, died yesterday at his home, 50 Clifton Terrace. He was 85 years old.

title: Msgr. Eugene Molloy Dies at 53; Official of the Brooklyn Diocese
description: Msgr. Eugene J. Molloy, secretary for education in the Diocese of Brooklyn, died in his sleep yesterday in his room at St. Joseph's College, Brooklyn. He was 53 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: Market Place: Mathers Tells Fund Approach
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 18Thomas N. Mathers, bullvoiced, whitehaired 57yearold operator of the mutual fund that bears his name, says: I'm older than hell. Everybody I know in this business is younger than I am.

title: ARMS AID CUTOFF LOOMS IN DISPUTE OVER U.S. SECRECY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Controller General of the United States ruled today that funding of foreign military aid will cease Sept. 1 unless the Nixon Administration meets a demand by Congress for a militaryaid document.

title: Stock Prices Fall After 2Day Surge
description: The stock market was buffeted by profit taking yesterday after two days of huge gains that stemmed from President Nixon's economic program.

title: 3 Arab Heads of State Confer on Jordan
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 18 The chiefs of state of Syria, Egypt and Libya met here tonight to approve a constitution for the Federation of Arab Republics, but faced more urgent business on their agendathe crisis with Jordan.

title: 37 G.I.'s Killed as Copter Crashes in West Germany
description: PEGNITZ, West Germany, Aug. 18 (AP)A United States helicopter carrying American troops to a field exercise exploded in the air early this morning, plunged into a hayfield, and all 37 soldiers aboard died in the flaming wreckage.

title: Eggs Contaminated by Chemical May Have Been Sold in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Food and Drug Administration indicated today that some 60,000 eggs contaminated by a chemical called PCB have been sold to consumers in the District of Columbia area.

title: Alfred G. Vanderbilt Jr. Marries Alison Platten
description: DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 18Miss Alison Campbell Platten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Campbell Platten, was married here this afternoon to Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt Jr., son of Mr. Vanderbilt of Mill Neck, L. I., and Mrs. Jeanne Murray Vanderbilt of New York.

title: OBSERVER
description: What a strange world it must be that the President of the United States, the Secretary of the Treasury and those highly publicized leading Government economists inhabit. Can it really be that in their world there are no bills piling up month after month, year upon year?

title: China Remains Silent On U.S. Economy Shift
description: PEKING, Aug. 18In the flurry of world reaction to President Nixon's measures to strengthen the United States dollar, the capital of China has remained remarkably silent.

title: Power in City Cut
description: An apparent frequency disturbance in the power system in upstate New York caused brief blackouts in sections of Long Island and Queens and a temporary 8 per cent voltage reduction throughout New York City and Westchester County late yesterday afternoon.

title: Macy's Broadens BudgetStore Focus
description: Macy's New York, the metropolitan area's largest retailer, which last week announced that it would establish budget centers for lowpriced goods, is going one step further. Besides planning seven such budget centers, mostly to be situated in the existing basements of its stores, the 14store group will also open six Furniture Clearance Centers on Long Island and Westchester County.

title: Heat Fells 50 as E Train Stalls Under East River
description: More than 6,000 rushhour commuters were trapped long as two hours last night on four IND trains stalled an East River tunnel. There was no Queensbound service on the E and F lines between 6:25 P.M. and 8:20 P.M.

title: U.S. Memo Outlines Two China Policy In U.N. Assembly
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18The United States has made its first move to muster support for a two China policy in the General Assembly, which opens next month.

title: Clarification Sought
description: Their status under the order freezing wages and prices and, to a lesser extent, under the import surcharge, continued yesterday to trouble commodity exchanges in New York and Chicago as they awaited clarification from Washington.

title: Dublin Is Concerned
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 18The Irish Government said tonight it was greatly concerned over the announced intention by the United States to suspend the landing rights in New York of Irish International Airlines unless American airlines were allowed to land in Dublin.

title: Numbers to Phone For Freeze Answers
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs, as well as the Federal Government's Office of Emergency Preparedness, is ready to help those with questions or complaints about the President's wage and price freeze.

title: Kennedy Center Food: It Could Be Worse
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18You can't hear a concert yet or see a play at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts. This enormous, white blockhouse of culture won't open officially until September. But you can cat there, in three restaurants, one upper, one middle and one lower class.

title: Washington Comments
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) The State Department press officer, Robert J. McCloskey, said today that the announced withdrawal of Australian and New Zealand troops from Vietnam was in harmony with our own withdrawal program and the Vietnamization effort.

title: I.O.S.MANAGERSSCORE RIKLIS ON REBEL MOVE
description: GENEVA, Aug. 18  The present management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., counterattacked today Meshulam A. Riklis, a New York financier, for offering to back with $10million a dissident group of stockholders if they won control of the financially troubled company.

title: BOYCOTT IS ENDED BY HEUBLEIN PACT
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Heublein, Inc., a major wine producer, announced today an agreement with the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee, ending a nationwide boycott of the company's products.

title: FRED L. RIGGIN
description: PORT HURON, Mich., Aug. 18 (AP)Fred L. Riggin, who rose from an $8aweek secretary post to the presidency of the Mueller Brass Company, died today in a Port Huron hospital. He was 85 years old.

title: BOTH SIDES SUM UP AT LIPKINS TRIAL
description: Milton Lipkins, an assistant vice president of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation, was characterized as a sophisticated corrupter and as a victimized businesssman in summations yesterday by the prosecution and the defense at his perjury trial in Federal Court here.

title: A Rest Stop Where You Feed the Deer
description: CAVE JUNCTION, Ore.Kristen, Sample, 3, gingerly pushed a carrot through the chainlink fence and several deer snapped for it. Why did she like feeding the deer? 'Cause, answered Miss Sample. Why did she like vacation? 'Cause, she said again.

title: Martin's Report Assailed By Head of S.E.C. Study
description: A broad attack on the securities industry report prepared by William McChesney Martin Jr. for the New York Stock Exchange was published yesterday by the director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's institutional investor study.

title: Nixon, in Illinois, Says His Policies Seek to Realign World's Currencies
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 18President Nixon declared today that the international elements of his new economic policy were designed to meet the need to revalue the currencies of the world.

title: Borrowing by U.S. Banks Of Eurodollars Is Lower
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Eurodollar borrowings by United States banks dropped $808million in the week ended Aug. 11 to $1,096million outstanding, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: 11 at Shoe Store Win $100,000 in Lottery
description: A group of Manhattan shoestore employes who have been buying lottery tickets for two and a half years won one of the three $100,000 grand prizes in the July New York State Lottery, which was drawn yesterday.

title: Shrine to Sandburg Awaits U.S. Funds
description: FLAT ROCK, N. C.Carl Sandburg's last home was a strange dwelling place for a prairie poet and biographer of Lincoln.

title: MRS. KESSELRING
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Aug. 18Mrs. Charlotte Elsheimer Kesselring, widow of Joseph Kesselring, the playwright best known for Arsenic and Old Lace, died in Benedictine Hospital here after a short illness. She lived at Willow and at 1 Lexington Avenue in New York City.

title: Froehling Gains Merion Quarterfinals
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 18Frank Froehling, lured back to the game last season after fiveyear absence, put a decided threat from abroad out of contention for the 72d Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship in gaining the quarterfinals by defeating Georges Goven, France's No. 1 player, 76, 16, 76, today at Merlon Cricket Club.

title: JACK CHARIPAR, 46, A DIESEL ENGINEER
description: COLUMBUS, Ind., Aug. 18Jack E. Charipar, vice president of research and engineering at the Cummins Engine Company, manufacturer of diesel engines, died today at his home here. He was 46 years old.

title: Role of Big Speculators. In Crisis Is Discounted
description: LONDON, Aug. 18 dent Nixon's effort to blame international speculators for the troubles of the dollar were dismissed as a red herring today by international bankers and corporate officials here.

title: LincolnMercury Presents Mark IV and Montego
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI)The LincolnMercury division of the Ford Motor Company introduced today its new Continental Mark IV and allnew Montego series as part of a 1972 lineup that included only minor refinements in other models.

title: DIETZ REGISTERS UPSET OF DEMIDDI
description: COPENHAGEN, Aug. 18 (UPI)  Jim Dietz, a 22yearold New YOrker, turned in the first upset on the opening day of the European ,rowing championships today when he won his heat of the single sculls from the world champion, Alberto Demiddi of Argentina.

title: Garelik Disputes Murphy View That City's Streets Are Safer
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik yesterday challenged Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy's assertion that the city streets were safer and warned that such statements could create a false sense of security in the people of the city.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND T.W.A. LIST GAIN
description: American Airlines, Inc. and Trans World Airlines, Inc., showed a sharp recovery in profits in the month of July, their reports disclosed yesterday.

title: Text of Paris Communique
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (AP)Following is the text of the French communique calling for reexamination of the international monetary system:

title: Production of Oil in Texas Trimmed as Demand Lags
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 18Slackening demand for Texas oil, and rising stocks of both products and above ground crude oil, led the Texas Railroad Commission today to trim oil production for September by 13,750 barrels a day from the August rate of production.

title: 3 Whites and 3 Blacks Seeking Democratic Nomination for Mayor of Baltimore
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 18  Six candidates  three white and three black  are seeking the Democratic nomination for Mayor of Baltimore in a campaign that has started to heat up.

title: Roe Tops Paonessa, 3 and 2, To Win Junior Golf Title
description: LAKE MAHOPAC, N.Y., Aug. 18  Chip Roe of Dutchess C.C., defeated Rick Paonessa of Lakeland, 3 and 2, at the Mahopac Golf Club today to win the 47th annual Westchester Junior golf championship.

title: General Reinsurance Is Moving Its Headquarters to Connecticut
description: The General Reinsurance Corporation, the largest reinsurance concern in the country, will move its corporate headquarters from Manhattan to Greenwich, Conn.

title: Welfare Reform Program Is Likely to Be Delayed Until After Election in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18President Nixon's request for a year's delay in implementing welfare reform has sharply reduced the prospect that the welfare program will be enacted before the 1972 election.

title: MARTHA WILKINSON GAINS IN U.S. GOLF
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 18 (AP) The defending champion, Martha Wilkinson of Anaheim, Calif., scored a 7and6 triumph over Margaret Simpson Brass of Orlando, Fla., today in the first round of the United States women's amateur golf championship.

title: S.E.C. WARNS BANKS ON ILLEGAL STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The Securities and Exchange Commission warned banks today to make sure, in exercising securities transaction orders for their customers, that the order in question was not illegal, as for example the sale of an unregistered security.

title: BOX FOUND IN SEA IS FULL OF NEEDLES
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 18 A box found in the Florida Keys where a hurricane sank Spanish fleet in 1733 was sawed open today, and archeologists found that it was full of needles.

title: Advertising:
description: Daily and Sunday newspaper ads for discount stores hit a new peak last year, according to the annual census of the industry compiled by Discount Store News.

title: Stottlemyre's 4Hitter Beats Royals, 31
2 Youths Are Seized in Slaying of Brooklyn Man
description: Two Brooklyn teenagers, one of them 14 years old, were arrested early yesterday and charged with the mugging murder Monday of a telephone company employe.

title: CITY U. TUITION AID AWAITS APPROVAL
description: City University officials were so confident of getting state approval for a plan to subsidize up to 400 students in two private institutions that letters offering such an option were sent out, one official said yesterday.

title: East Pakistan: The Goondas of Saidpur
description: SILIGURI, IndiaI am one of the unfortunates who managed to escape from the massacre perpetrated on the morning of June 13th at Saidpur (Rangpur), a nonBengali Muslim majority town of North Bengal in Bangle Desh. I call myself unfortunate because I left behind 150 members of my community including my parents, brothers, sisterinlaw, nephew and niecesbutchered by the goondas of the Pakistan army in collaboration with the nonBengali police.

title: ...But Bonnie's Still Tending Goal
description: KINGSTON, Ont., Aug. 18 (AP)I just love it, said the 15yearold American hockey player who stepped on the ice yesterday to practice with 125 boys attending Kingston Memorial Centre's annual hockey school.

title: Controversial Greek Measure To Curb Journalists Is Eased
description: ATHENS, Aug. 18The Greek Government bowed to worldwide protests tonight and drastically revised its draft press law, which called for suspension of newsmen who failed to heed HellenicChristian traditions.

title: Miss Hansen Married
description: The marriage of Miss Jeanette Nadine Hansen to Charles Gilbert Slepian, Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department of Public Events, took place here yesterday afternoon. Civil Court Judge Nathaniel Sorkin performed the ceremony in his chambers. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. T. Hansen of Portland, Ore., is a service advisor for the New York Telephone Company. Mr. Slepian, who is also director of the Office of Travel Industry Assistance, is the son of Mrs. Frieda Slepian of New York and the late Jess Herbert Slepian.

title: East Pakistan: We Can Help  But Without Arms
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I have been reluctant in these last months to speak to the political problems of East Bengal. All of us who have served in India are thought to be partisans of that country as doubtless on occasions we have been.

title: G.O.P. ParleyFunds Opposed
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI)  A Republican county committeewoman and a candidate for Mayor here, filed suiti today to block the use of city funds for the 1972 G.O.P. national convention. Mrs. Virginia Taylor said other uses should have higher priorities. If the Republican party wants to come here, they should darn well pay for it, she said.

title: East Side Story: Business Boomor Bust
description: There are two types of signs on the boardedup windows and the padlocked doors of a number of small shops along the Upper East Side these sultry summer days. One type says, On Vacation. The other says, For Sale.

title: POLICEMAN IS SEIZED IN SALE OF BOGUS 10'S
description: A city patrolman was arrested yesterday on a charge of having sold $10,000 in counterfeit $10 bills to an undercover Secret Service agent in a Queens diner last month.

title: Books of The Times
description: How time goes by. Here it is, The Last Whole Earth Catalog already, and some people hadn't even gotten it straight yet what the first one was, or any of the 14 In between. Well, happily for them, among the smallest trinkets in this huge plum pudding of a publication is Stewart Brand's history of the venture he founded. To wit: The WHOLE EARTH CATALOG got started in a plane over Nebraska in March, 1968. I was returning to California from my father's long dying and funeral that morning in Illinois. The sun had set ahead of the plane.... I gazed out the window into dark nothing and slid into a reverie about my friends who were starting their own civilization hither and you in the sticks and how could I help. The L. L. Bean Catalog of outdoor stuff came to mind and I pondered upon Mr. Bean's service to humanity over the years. So many of the problems I could identify came down to a matter of access. Where to buy a windmill. Where to get good information on beekeeping. Where to lay hands on a computer without forfeiting freedom....

title: Nuclear Explosion Set Off
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. IS A nuclear explosive was set off at 7 A.M. today under the desert with no problems the Atomic Energy commission announced. It had a force of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT, in the lowintermediate range, the A.E.C. said. The weaponsrelated shot was the sixth announced this year at the Nevada Test Site.

title: HAROLD L. SMITH, 74, APPELLATE LAWYER
description: SOUTHOLD, L. I., Aug. 18Harold Leonard Smith, a trial and appellate lawyer who spent his professional career with Hughes, Hubbard & Reed, 1 Wall Street, New York, and its predecessor firms, died yesterday at the Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport. He was 74 years old and lived on Oak Avenue.

title: The Theater
description: Cymbeline is one of Shakespeare's most inconstant works, which is why it might be easy to forgive its duplicities and call it modern. In his production for Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, A. J. Antoon, the director, has changed the title to The Tale of Cymbeline. This is intended as the fairytale version, and since the play is playful and even fantastical the new direction seems entirely justified.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: President Nixon's temporary and voluntary wageprice freeze is as cynical as it is immoral. Does he really expect Americans to believe that an order backed by Federal sanctions is in any way voluntary? Should we say that extortion victims pay voluntarily?

title: New Highways Shaping Future of City's Suburbs
description: The sleek new highways begun under the Eisenhower Administration are nearing completion at the edges of the metropolitan region, and they may have already set the basic course of suburban growth for the rest of this century.

title: EUROPE SPLIT IN MONETARY CRISIS
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 18The Western European nations were embroiled in deep conflict tonight on ways to end the monetary crisis created by the United States decision end the convertibility of gold.

title: WILLIAM MITCHELL, MUSIC CHAIRMAN, 64
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Aug. 18Prof. William J. Mitchell, a past president of the American Musicological Society, and chairman of the music department at Columbia University from 1962 to 1968 when he came here to head graduate studies in music at the State University, died yesterday following a short illness. He was 64 years old.

title: SUSPECT IN BOMBING WINS BAIL REDUCTION
description: Carlos Feliciano, a 42yearold Puerto Rican nationalist, accused of trying to bomb the General Electric Building here, won a reduction in bail yesterday from $150,000 to $25,000. He had sought the reduction unsuccessfully for more than year.

title: Advertising:
description: A few news items regarding magazines crossed the desk yesterday, and are worthy of mention. In ascending order of circulation, they involve the Saturday Review, Family Weekly and Reader's Digest.

title: NASA Unit to Layoff 70
description: MOUNTAIN (VIEW, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP)The Ames Research Center said today that it must lay off 70 persons to meet a 5 per cent employe cutback in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's 197172 budget.

title: Day's Events in Freeze
description: Following are developments yesterday affecting consumers and wageearners under the 90day wage and price freeze:

title: U.S. BEATS MEXICO IN VOLLEYBALL, 30; CUBA IS 30 VICTOR
description: MIAMI, Aug. 18 (UPI)The United States scored its second straight victory in the Olympic volleyball elimination in Ha vana tonight, defeating Mexico in a match much tougher than the 30 score indicated.

title: Arab Mayors of 23 West Bank Towns Hold a Meeting
description: BEIT SAHUR, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, Aug. 18For the first time since the sixday war of 1967, moderate Arab leaders of the westbank area of Jordan have managed to meet and adopt a common stand on a question that, though substantially economic, has clear political importance.

title: Yenan, Mao's Old Base, Now a Quiet Town
description: YENAN, ChinaYenan, this sacred place of the Chinese revolution, has the air of frontier town that has known better days.

title: New Life for Young In Old Mining Town
description: WARD, Colo., Aug. 18The showy fleabane is purple along the edges of the road and the dirt lanes, and harebells add patches of blue, but it is time to get ready for the long Rocky Mountain winter now, to chop wood, lay in coal for the cast iron stoves and fill the chinks in walls of the cabins and houses of this oncebustling mining camp. The other day the Doc was up on the roof of his, log cabin, built in the eighteeneighties, stripping off the old rusty tin sheeting and discovering among the rotting eaves the dry bodies of two perfectly preservedpack rats and parts of their hordethree corncobpipes, a safety razor and onehalf of a large plastic set of dice.

title: Shakspere: New Findings
description: A Wesleyan University English professor, combining electronic detective work with deduction based on his literary and legal knowledge of Elizabethan England, believes he has authenticated the only signature of William Shakespeare known to exist outside England and shed new light on the poet's expertise in law.

title: AMEX SHARES OFF AS VOLUME DROPS
F.C.C. Sets Hearing on Stamford Radio Censorship
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 A hearing on the future of radio station WSTC, owned by Kingsley Gillespie, publisher of The Stamford Advocate and The Greenwich Time, has been set for Oct. 19 by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Most Housing Rent Rises Blocked by Nixon Order
description: The 90day wageprice freeze applies to housing rents even if landlords and tenants agreed on an increase before Aug 15. the Office of Emergency Preparedness said yesterday.

title: FIRST A.T.&T. PAYOUT ON PREFERRED $1.21
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company declared yesterday the first quarterly dividend on its new convertible preferred stock and the regular quarterly dividend of 65 cents a share on the common stock.

title: Grabowski, a Part Of $1Million Duo, Waived by Packers
description: Jim Grabowski, who made up half the Green Bay Packers $1million rookie runningback duo in 1966, was placed on waivers yesterday. It was move we had to make, said Dan Devine, the Green Bay coach. I was afraid he was going to get hurt.

title: LINDSAY GREETED MILDLY BY BLACKS
description: Looking like a man on the campaign trail, Mayor Lindsay got a mild reception yesterday during a shirt sleeves walking tour of a predominantly black Brooklyn neighborhood.

title: Roundup: Gullett Victor As Reds Defeat Cards, 50
description: Don Gullett of the Reds, who has never lost a game in Cincinnati in his twoyear major league career, kept his record clean last night. The 20yearold lefthander tossed his third shutout of the season, setting down the St. Louis Cardinals, 50.

title: Personal Finance
description: Betty Furness probably doesn't realize it, but she accomplished considerably more during her brief career as Governor Rockefeller's No. 1 consumer watchdog than she knows.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BAY SHORE, L. I."Man can drop down a mountainside, float back up again, soar through a canyon, merely by inhaling and exhaling, by flipping his feet a little bit, said Bob Shorout, his gin and tonic forgotten, his eyes far away. You drink in all that beauty and it's your own private domain. It's especially yours because you can't communicate down there, you can't turn to your buddy and say, Wow. It's very strange, but when you come up again you've often forgotten what you saw. You only remember it was beautiful and you want to go back down.

title: Rabbi Kahane Acquitted Of Two Criminal Charges
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, director of the Jewish Defense League, was acquitted yesterday in Criminal Court in Manhattan of charges of disorderly conduct and resisting arrest last April 20.

title: Screen:
Chemical Concerns Back Nixon Economic Package
description: The Dow Chemical Company, which derives 40 per cent of its nearly $2billion in annual sales from abroad, has examined President Nixon's economic package and expressed its enthusiasm by wiring him, We are proud of you.

title: Screen:
Palsy Drive Names Chief
description: E. R. Rowley, chairman and chief executive officer of N L Industries, Inc., will serve as chairman of United Cerebral Palsy of New York's 197172 campaign to raise $2million, the agency announced yesterday.

title: A ProLindsay G.O.P. Leader Says 250 in Club Will Switch
description: Members of a proLindsay faction that has been trying for years to gain control of the Bronx Republican organization have voted to follow the Mayor and switch to the Democratic party.

title: Miners and Ecologists Clash On Montana Ore Development
description: BILLINGS, Mont., Aug. 18Mining men and conservationists took opposing stands ton day on the proposed development of copper, nickel and chromium mining in the Beartooth Mountains of south central Montana.

title: MRS. BOWER'S DUO WINS GOLF TITLE
Dollar Gains in Trading Here; Pound and Mark Show Declines
description: The dollar displayed some improvement yesterday in foreignexchange trading in the New York market where the volume of business also picked up from Tuesday's levels.

title: METS TOP DODGERS IN 10TH INNING, 32 ON SINGLETON HIT
An English Show Judge Has Big Following Here
description: Four years ago, when Margaret Osborne of. Sittingbourne, England, judged at the Baltimore show, Shetland sheepdog, collie and corgi fanciers were out in force to have her rule on their entries. Last Sunday, the English authority was in America to judge again, this time at the Sand and Sea fixture in Lakewood, N. J. Once more owners turned out in numbers. Long after she had finished judging, they paraded their dogs before her and asked her opinions.

title: Enforcer of the Freeze Arnold Robert Weber
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Arnold Robert Weber, the economics professor who has been named Executive Director of the newly established Cost of Living Council, was addressing an assembly of high Government officials one day this week on the difficulties in enforcing the wage and price freeze. The textbooks all say how complicated the American economy is, Mr. Weber said. In the last 48 hours I have found out how true that is. The Government must now concern itself with everything from the porkbelly market to titanium.

title: British Troops Kill 2 More in Ulster, Raising Toll to 28
description: LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 18 (AP)British troops in Northern Ireland shot and killed two armed civilians tonight. One of them was a deaf man, who could not hear an army order to surrender the pistol he was waving in the air.

title: Hanoi Reports Victory
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)According to a military commentator here. North Vietnamese forces have succeeded in piercing South Vietnam's northern defenses at several points along Route 9.

title: SCRIBNER SEEKING STUDY ON BUS BIDS
description: School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner has requested that the city's Transportation Administration investigate the procedure by which private bus companies bid for contracts to carry 116,000 city school children.

title: U.A.W. Maps Battle Against Any Extension of Wage Freeze
description: BOSTON, Aug. 18  The United Automobile Workers warned the Nixon Administration today that it would terminate its contracts with the auto companies and fight any extension of the wage freeze that would eliminate upcoming wage increases due the union.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYES'
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18President Nixon's new Cost of Living Council decided today that state and local government employes were subject to the President's 90day wage freeze.

title: MEDINA IS PLACED AT SLAYING SCENE
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 18The alleged slaying of several Vietnamese children, one of them in the presence of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, was described today at the 34yearold officer's courtmartial.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Banner Fall for Ducks
description: The haunting taste and smell of fall was in the air along the East Coast recently, reminding some sportsmen that duck hunting is not far away.

title: PETER A. LEERMAKERS
description: MARIPOSA, Calif., Aug. 18 (AP)Peter A. Leermakers, chemistry professor at Wesleyan University of Middletown, Conn., died Monday when his jeep overturned near his ranch here. He was 34 years old.

title: Black Pro Golfer Agrees to Compete In S. African Event
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., Aug. 18 Although he said he had been admonished not to participate, Lee Elder, a leading black professional golfer on the United States tour, has completed plans to compete in the South African championship and in an exhibition match against Gary Player near Johannesburg.

title: FREEZE INDICATED FOR COMMODITIES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Government officials said today they assumed that commodity futures trading in soybean oil and meal, frozen orange juice and pork bellies came under President Nixon's 90day price freeze.

title: Harbor Development Plan Is Outlined by New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18City officials offered today to turn over a 61acre section of New Haven Harbor at virtually no cost to any developer who promised to build an island there for busineSs and leisure use.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18No country has been more affected than Japan by President Nixon's twin stunnershis proposed visit to Peking and his new economic policy. So Japanese officials here are ruefully quipping that what happens twice may happen three times.

title: Tourists Find Dollar Is Not So Mighty
description: LONDON, Aug. 18Anger, puzzlement and even some humor marked the struggle by American tourists in Europe today to exchange the fewest dollars for the most foreign currency.

title: MITCHELL DISPUTES WALLACE ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Attorney General John Mitchell's office said today that the Attorney General had not told Alabama school boards to go to the Federal courts to seek relief from busing orders. Gov. George Wallace said earlier this week that he had.

title: BROOKLYN BOY WINS IN TENNIS MARATHON
description: Joe Garber, a 15yearold schoolboy from Brooklyn, outlasted Bryan Fineberg of New York in a 3hour50minute match yesterday to gain the quarterfinals in the boys division (16 and under) of the fourth annual Columbia tennis championships at Baker Field.

title: Irish Planes to Be Barred Here Unless U.S. Jets Can Use Dublin
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The United States announced today that Irish International Airlines would be barred from landing in New York unless American carriers  long allowed to land only at Shannon Airport, 120 miles from Dublin are allowed to fly directly to the Irish capital. The ban would take effect in a year.

title: Wallace Bars 2 More. Integration Plans
description: HOBSON CITY, Ala., Aug. 18  While angry, young Negroes tried to shout him down, Gov. George C. Wallace challenged the Federal Government again today by ordering two Alabama school boards to ignore a courtapproved desegregation plan.

title: Holding the Line
description: President Nixon is right in stressing that the willingness of all Americans to accept temporary sacrifices will be a major element in success of the ninetyday freeze he has ordered on prices, wages and rents. That freeze is an indispensable foundation for more flexible, longterm measures to end the inflationary spiral that has gnawed away at pay envelopes, business profits, pensions and every other form of income.

title: BOND RATES SAG FOR NEW ISSUES
U.S. Importers to Meet On Effect of New Duty
description: The American Importers Association will hold a meeting tomorrow at the Commodore Hotel on the effects of the higher customs duties imposed under the Administration's economic emergency measures.

title: RIVALS OUTSHONE BY FRESH YANKEE
Heart Patient Sees Family
description: DETROIT, Aug. 18 (UPI)Haskell Shanks celebrated his first week with his permanent partial mechanical heart today by visiting with his family and sitting in the warm summer sun. The 63yearold plant guard from Warren, who last Wednesday received the me. chanical device during an operation at Sinai Hospital, was reported to be in good condition by heart specialists.

title: GAINS REPORTED AT BERLIN TALKS
description: BERLIN, Thursday, Aug. 19The ambassadors of the Big Four powers appear to have virtually completed a draft agreement on the future of Berlin.

title: An Enigmatic 'Doc'
description: "Doc" misfires. Too bad. this picture is loaded with talent and potential.It is one thing for a Western to frankly set about debunking two legendary stalwarts such as John (Doc) Holliday and Wyatt Earp, with their iron-jawed heroics from other films and television. Teasingly, studiedly and bafflingly, "Doc" serves up a pair of eccentric gunsharps seemingly more interested in each other than in law and order. Well, who knows?But the climax, when these two bland egotists serenely slaughter a clan of seven, who are apparently ready to "talk," is a pious, gory jolt that yanks the rug from under the whole picture. What realistic history book yielded this incident?Around these two focal enigmas, and their workmanlike facade portrayals by Stacy Keach and Harris Yulin, there uncoils an arresting eyeful, populated with mean scroungy Western characters and simmering with promise. The barbed, grisly dialogue comes from Pete Hamill, the columnist, in a screen original. And under the director-producer, Frank Perry, a snakelike, rhythmical tempo builds a cutting tension.In contrast to the fogbound Doc and Wyatt, two other characters are crystal clear and beautifully played by Faye Dunaway, as the mire-spattered Katie Elder, and Denver John Collins, as a young, budding marksman. But the real star of "Doc" is a transplanted Tombstone, Arizona, stunningly evoked in Spain by Gene Callahan, the production designer, and Gerald Hirschfeld, the color photographer."Doc" loses out. The winner is Tombstone, Spain.

title: Proxy Wars in Indochina
description: The State Department has replied with a non sequitur to Congressional criticism of United States support for Thai soldiers fighting in Laos. The department argued the other day that it was entitled to withhold compliance from the Geneva accord neutralizing Laos because of what it termed massive violations of neutrality by 80,000 North Vietnamese now in that country.

title: Proposed Catholic Code Called a Bar to Unity
description: MILAN, Italy, Aug. 18 (AP)The Rev. Yves Congar, a leading French theologian, charged today that the Roman Catholic Church's proposed new fundamental law altered the spirit of the Ecumenical Council Vatican II and placed obstacles in the way of Christian unity.

title: Bristol Is Suspended After Till With Umpire
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Milwaukee Brewers manager, Dave Bristol, was fined $150 and suspended until next Tuesday by the American League today for his actions that led to his ejection during the ninth inning of a 32 loss to the Baltimore Orioles last night. Cal Ermer will manage the club until Tuesday.

title: Dock Walkout to Continue As Bridges Rebuffs Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, said today that the union would continue its strike of West Coast docks despite a request from the Nixon Administration that the stoppage be terminated.

title: Pollution Suits Filed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) A chemical concern and land development company were charged today with polluting waters in North Carolina. Attorney General John N. MitChell announced that civil suits seeking a halt to the alleged pollution were filed against Wilmington Chemical Terminal, Inc., of Wilmington, N.C., and the B & W Development Corp. The suits were filed in United States District Courts in Wilmington and New Bern, N.C.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Hidden under its recent smiling offensive is the true nature of the Peking regime. A few civil words expressed by Chou Enlai have been blown up oat of all proportion to their real intentions. Sweeping conclusions have been drawn that Red China is now abandoning its violent revolutionary principles.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Aug. 19, 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Communists May Escape Surcharge
description: WARSAW, Aug. 18  The 10 per cent surcharge on imports ordered by President Nixon in his economic package may bypass the Communist nations of Eastern Europe through an irony of Cold War legislation.

title: Cohasset Tribe Captures Sanford
PARIS TO CONTINUE ITS NUCLEAR TESTS
description: PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters)French officials said today that France would continue her current series of nuclear tests in the South Pacific despite protests from Japan and New Zealand and a Peruvian threat to break relations.

title: Storekeepers Here Not Certain How to Show Records of Prices
description: Many retailers and restaurateurs yesterday were puzzling over the part of the wageprice freeze order requiring them to make available for public inspection a record of their highest prices during the 30 days before the wageprice freeze, as President Nixon's order requires.

title: Army Clears U.S. Soldiers In Cambodia Hospital Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters)  The Army said today that it had found no evidence of misconduct by United States troops after investigating charges that they shelled a Vietcong hospital complex in Cambodia in February, 1969.

title: Mayor's Office Weighs Plans to End Freeze on City Construction This Month
