description: The Mayor's office expressed optimism yesterday about the possible end this month of a freeze on $200million in municipal construction that was imposed in an effort to pressure four locals into compliance with, plans for admitting more blacks and Puerto Ricans to building trade unions.

title: JAZZ MUSICIANS PLAY AT KING CURTIS RITES
description: More than 1,000 people crowded into St. Peter's Lutheran Church and on the sidewalk outside yesterday afternoon for the funeral of King Curtis, the 37yearold jazz saxophonist and band leader who was stabbed to death last Friday.

title: Naturalists Ask Ban on Coyote Poisons
description: Seven prominent national conservation groups yesterday filed with.William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, a petition calling on him to help stop interstate shipment of, poisons used to kill coyotes.

title: Bid Is Pressed for Floating Price on Industrial Gold
description: Pressure mounted yesterday for the Government to allow floating price on industrial gold, as manufacturers of gold products were squeezed by higher world prices.

title: Combodian Sweep Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 18 (Agence FrancePresse)The Cambodian Army reported today that 4,000 troops sweeping through southeastern Cambodia had inflicted about 100 casualties on enemy forces there on the last three days.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The farreaching measures for the economy just taken by President Nixon are further evidence of his courage and capacity for leadership. In our particular type of democracy there are times of urgency when the executive must act more on his own than by any consensuseven in Congressand when his course at that moment might receive little support. This calls for statesmanship of the highest order, above party and self, and does not have to be of the magnitude or so dramatic as Lincoln during the Civil War, the first 100 days of F.D.R., or the missile crisis.

title: Rousing 'Soul to Soul'
description: "Soul to Soul" will hook you. We defy anybody to watch the final half hour of this color documentary of a soul and gospel music concert, performed in Ghana, without tapping a foot. But it is the sea of rapturous black faces, those of the visiting American artists and their Ghana audiences, that makes this movie a haunting experience.Most fortunately, Denis Sanders, who did so well with his documentary on Elvis Presley at Las Vegas, was recruited to direct this project. The occasion is an American program given last March in a huge open-air theater in Ghana's capital city, Accra, to cap the African nation's 14th Independence Day festivities. Neither Mr. Sanders, the group of visitors nor the movie wastes much time with the travelogue frills and detours.We meet the group of musicians briefly in flight, see them given an airport welcome and watch them take a few excursions. And the warm, frank curiosity of the more sophisticated Americans as they are entertained by the primitive dancers and singers is fascinating to behold and typical of what follows. There is one poignant rendition of the song "Free" as two of the visitors explore an old slave fortress on the African coast.Mainly and compactly, the film sticks to the concert, brilliantly evoking the performances and crowd reactions in a flow of closeups and panoramic shots, to the stabbing, pounding pulse of the music. It would be hard to imagine better good-will ambassadors from this country to anywhere than Santana, Willie Bobo, Roberta Flack, Les McCann, Eddie Harris, the Staple Singers, the Voices of East Harlem, the Damas Choir, Amoa Azangio and the Kumasi drummers.But the highlights of the program and the real thrill of the film are the peerless Wilson Pickett, a performer with strong impact, and Ike and Tina Turner, the latter rendering one blues number, "You Are Gone," the likes of which we have never heard before. And has anybody ever commented on this woman's beautiful smile? In "Soul to Soul," black isn't merely beautiful. It's unsurpassable.

title: Saigon Reports 142 of Foe Killed in Battle Near DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 19 (AP)The South Vietnamese command, today reported that 142 North Vietnamese and 22 South Viet namese had been killed in the biggest battle in months just below the demilitarized zone.

title: Black Separatists Raided in Jackson, Miss.
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 18Two Jackson policemen were in critical condition and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was in fair condition after a gunfight early today between the police and members of a black separatist organization.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18The general manager of the three Kennedy Center restaurants has been dismissed, it was reported today, but no successor has been named.

title: Nixon and Rockefeller Breakfast Here
description: President Nixon and Governor Rockefeller had breakfast together in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday, and they talked about aid to parochial schools, Mr. Nixon's new economic program, welfare reform and revenuesharingbut not, the Governor insisted, about political matters, such as Mayor Lindsay's switching from the Republican to the Democratic party.

title: East Pakistan: A Final Solution in Bengal?
description: PARISAre we to understand that the United States has been exercising quiet but unremitting pressure upon Pakistan for a final solution in East Bengal?

title: Plus and Minus for Jersey Air
description: A model program for reducing harmful automobile emissions is likely to start in New Jersey some time next spring. Empowered by the Legislature and helped by a Federal grant, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has for several years been developing equipment for the instant measurement of exhaust emissions. It is preparing now to require all cars registered in the state to be checked on this score as part of their annual inspection. Those violating the standards will be barred from the roads after two weeks of grace in which to make the required repairs.

title: Executive Changes
description: Exeuctone, Inc., announced yesterday, the election of N. A. Karr as chairman of the board. Mr. Karr who had been president since 1962, will be succeeded by Edward Brody, who had been executive vice president. Philip H. Seaman, the former chairman, was elected chairman of the executive committee.

title: Labor Aid to Democrats Put Far Above G.O.P.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP)Organized labor contributed $4,153,746 to Democratic candidates for Congress and governorships in 1970 compared with $143,550 for Republicans, Americans for Constitutional Action said today.

title: Treated in U.S., Vietnamese Returns Home
description: QUANGNGAI, South Vietnam, Aug. 8Your legs, are they wood or real? the elderly Vietnamese in soiled garments asked.

title: It's Back to the Kitchen for Jan...
description: HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Aug. 18 (UPI)Jan Coehlo can go back to baking brownies for the Hollywood Hills High School football team and leave the quarterbacking duties to the boys.

title: Giants Burned Again: Harper Hurts Ankle
description: BROOKVILLE, LI., Aug. 18 Charlie Harper's balloonedup right ankle was swathed in elastic tape today. The 6foot, 250pound offensive tackle looked at the injury, which will keep him out three weeks, and said: I must be the first football player ever injured climbing out a window in training camp.

title: INCREASE IN VALUE OF YEN EXPECTED
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 19Despite official denials that an upward revaluation of the yen was in prospect, Japanese financial and political leaders began to suggest today that such a currency revaluation was inevitable and preferable to the 10 per cent surcharge President Nixon has imposed on foreign goods imported into the United States.

title: Within Troupe's Stage Is a Bus
description: TROY, N. Y.The actors began striking the multilevel stage that encased an old school bus, while the audience mingled about the area or walked to their cars parked near the grassy field by the pool in this city's Prospect Park.

title: First Surety Acts to Bar Proxy Fight by Bank Head
description: Tom Fusselman, president of the First Surety Corporation, a savings and loan holding company of Burbank, Calif., announced yesterday that his company had taken court action to prevent a proxy contest for control of First Surety by Charles Cook, chairman of the Community. Bank of Huntington Park, Calif.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The President's EightPoint program announced on national T.V. Aug. 15 has certainly been long in coming. Having little desire to comment on the political implications of such a move, permit me simply to express my relief at the Administration's finally taking positive action. I hope such action will serve to improve the general economic climate and aid in the restoration of consumer confidence. Perhaps in the future, White House officials may weigh more seriously the suggestions of men such as the Fed's Arthur Burns.

title: American Home In Pact to Acquire Hartz and Sternco
Thruway Service Stations Warned on Special Tolls
description: ALBANY, Aug. 18 (AP)Oil companies must drop service charges to motorists who run out of gas on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway if they want to compete for a contract to operate service stations on the highway, the Thruway Authority said today.

title: UNIONS REJECT NOSTRIKE APPEAL;
description: Striking unions in many sections of the nation defied yesterday the Nixon Administration's call for a return to work during the 90day wage and price freeze imposed last Sunday.

title: Henry Fitz Gerald Heard Dead; Wrote on Science and Philosophy
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 (AP) Henry Fitz Gerald Heard, novelist, philosopher, teacher and pacifist, has died at the age of 81.

title: Ballet: Jewels Retains Rich Luster
description: There could be worse places to spend a Wednesday matinee than in an airconditioned theater watching a highly sophisticated threeact plotless ballet that also has great popular appeal. Certainly, one of the best places to be yesterday afternoon was at the State Theater, where the New York City Ballet presented George Balanchine's Jewels in the first of six matinees during its twoweek nonsubscription season.

title: Connally Is Reported to Say Other Nations Must Help With Monetary Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally reportedly told the Japanese Ambassador today that the United States had made its monetary decisions and that it was now up to other countries to propose ideas for a better international monetary system.

title: The Cost of Living Council's Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18Following are official answers to frequently asked questions about the 90day wage and price freeze, issued today by the Cost of Living Council:

title: Mayor Names Task Force to Study Loan Program
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed a special task force of deputy administrators and accountants from the city's Finance Administration to conduct a thorough review of the fiscal operations of the city's Muncipal Loan Program.

title: Australia and New Zealand To Quit Vietnam This Year
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 18 Australia and New Zealand announced today that they would withdraw their combat forces from South Vietnam in the next few months.

title: Music: Berkshire Choir
description: When the Berkshire Boy Chair gave a concert last year in the Medieval Sculpture Court of the Metropolitan Museum, this listener found it to be an extraordinarily good choir.

title: Longshoremen's Talks End in impasse
description: The Council of North Atlantic Shipping Associations and the International Longshoremen's Association ended their first negotiating session on a new contract yesterday with no date set for another meeting.

title: Chess: PetrosianKorchnoi Match In Moscow From Dullsville
U.S. SEEKS DELAY OF A BUSING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI)  The Nixon Administration asked the Supreme Court today to delay courtordered integration of the Corpus. Christi, Tex., school district under a massive busing plan originally proposed by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

title: Sony Plans to Raise Prices Of Some Goods Sold Here
description: The Sony Corporation announced in Tokyo yesterday that its wholly owned subsidiary, the Sony Corporation of America, would increase prices on some products to compensate for the newly imposed United States import surcharge of 10 per cent.

title: U.S. Envoy in Lagos Resigns
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 18 (AP)The United States Embassy announced today the resignation of William C. Trueheart, 58 years old, as Ambassador to Nigeria. An embassy spokesman said Mr. Trueheart, who became Ambassador in 1969, resigned to take a post next month as State Department faculty adviser at the United States Air Force University at Maxwell Air Force Base in Alabama.

title: Time
description: You go out in the evening and look at the sky and see the stars, slowly wheeling not only through the night but through the year, the seasons. Star patterns unchanging throughout your lifetime, the same constellations, the same Pole Star and Dipper and Eagle and Swan. And you see the moon progressing through its phases, from the thinnest golden crescent of a new moon to the fat, silver roundness of full moon, to the laterising moon on the wane, shrunken and wan. Moon phases that have been known to man since he first looked at the night sky.

title: Insiders'
description: The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies.

title: HUGE INCINERATOR PLANNED IN JERSEY
description: LYNDHURST, N. J., Aug. 18 Officials of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission disclosed today that they were planning to construct and operate the world's largest garbage incinerator.

title: Bridge: Psychic Bids May Present Some Problems of Ethics
description: Psychic bids are rarely met nowadays in expert play, partly because the losses tend to outweight the gains if the opponents know their business, and partly because some ethical problems arise. A partnership that regularly makes psychic bids in a specific way gains a slight, and perhaps unfair, advantage against opponents who are unaware of their habits.

title: MESKILL PUTS OFF DECISION ON TAXES
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 19After pondering for nearly a week whether to sign or veto a bill that would repeal the recently enacted state income tax, Gov Thomas J. Meskill said today that he would need at least until next Monday to make up his mind.

title: Decision Called Political
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP)President Nixon was accused by minority group leaders today of playing politics over the busing of 15,000 Corpus Christi school children.

title: Nixon's Moves Cheer Consumers
description: In three days, President Nixon in his new economic program has revived the confidence of the American consumer, mainly by moving those with neutral attitudes into being positive, Albert E. Sindlinger, president of Sindlinger & Co., told a financial audience here yesterday.

title: EVANS REGAINS LEAD IN CHESS ON COAST
description: VENTURA Calif., Aug. 19Grandmaster Larry Evans of Reno lost his halfpoint lead briefly, but regained it with the end of the 10th round in the United States Open Chess Championship yesterday.

title: Rooting Out Loan Frauds
description: The appointment by Mayor Lindsay of a special task force to conduct a thorough review of the fiscal operations of the city's municipal loan program is welcome evidence of highlevel concern over charges of widespread corruption in the program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The social catastrophe which has occurred in East Pakistan is well documented. It is now reported that almost eight million refugees fled from bitter repression to find some freedom and security in India. But they were poor to begin with and are now in an economically desperate situation in the refugee camps.

title: Board Rejects Lindsay Bid for Exempt Contracts
description: Mayor Lindsay's attempt to exempt a wide range of city contracts from public hearings was slapped down sharply by the Board of Estimate yesterday.

title: Rapid 10Year Growth Changes Putnam County's Nature
description: BREWSTER, N. Y., Aug. 19 Very little that happens in this Putnam County village escapes the scrutiny of Miss Marjorie L. Addis the 80yearold editor of The Brewster Standard. She can be found most days in her cluttered storefront office near the railroad station where

title: Nixon Urges Veterans to Lead Fight for Peace and Prosperity
description: DALLAS, Aug. 19President Nixon challenged American veterans today to form the front lines in a great battle for a lasting peace and a new prosperity.

title: City Opens 9th and Last Outdoor Pool in the Bronx
description: The city opened the last of its nine outdoor swimming pools this season, at East 180th Street and Mapes Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday.

title: Bones From Babi Yar Smuggled to Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 19Bones of victims of the Nazi massacre at Babi Yar have been smuggled out of the Soviet Union and delivered to Israel in the knapsacks of three University of Maryland students.

title: Subway Purgatory
description: Investigation follows investigation just as regularly breakdown follows breakdown in the city's antiquated and inefficient subway system. Each incident evokes inadequate explanations from the Transit Authority, usually coupled with sharp criticism of the T.A. by the Fire Department.

title: Gloria Swanson Is Returning to Broadway
description: Gloria Swanson, whose extraordinary 58year career spans silent films, talkies and the theater, is returning to Broadway next month, after a hiatus of two decades, to take the part of the quicktongued bourgeoise, Mrs. Baker, in Butterflies Are Free.

title: NewHome Cost Fell in 1970
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (UPI)Despite inflation, the cost of new homes went down a little last year as builders put up smaller houses, the United States Savings and Loan League reported today.

title: METS'OPTIMISM AT PENNANT PITCH Hodges Convinced Team Still Has Chance for East Title
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19Their hopes may be false, their optimism blind, but the Mets firmly believe they still have a chance to win the Eastern Division championship.

title: Street Theater Livens Lincoln Center
description: Behind the blue banner proclaiming EverymanCommunity Theater Festival at Lincoln Center, the plaza teemed with sound, color and humanity yesterday at noon. Several thousand people thronged the vast mall, dotted with colorful balloons and food carts and throbbing with the beat of bongo drums and electronic rhythm bands.

title: Copter Plucks 2 From a Jail in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 19 (UPI) A small blue helicopter landed in the courtyard of Santa Maria Acatitla Federal Prison last night and guards assumed a visiting dignitary would step out. Instead, the police said today, a convicted American murderer and a Venezuelan counterfeiter scrambled aboard and escaped.

title: SHANGHAI
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 19 The dollar crisis was no crisis in China. Even here in this commercial capital of the People's Republic there was no public evidence that anybody was paying the slightest attention to Washington's new economic policy.

title: Army Warns on Pollution
description: BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP)Letters of warning were sent today to about 1,500 New England companies delinquent in requesting permits to discharge waste into navigable waters, the Army Corps of Engineers reported.

title: Gaza a Monument to Wretchedness Caused in Mideast
description: GAZA, Aug. 13  In the swarming, honewhite refugee camp of Jabaliya, five mukhtars, or headmen, sit on a bench outside the camp office, asking futile questions and making futile complaints about the bulldozer that is razing houses nearby.

title: JETS HOPE KICKS WILL FELL GIANTS
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 19 Bob Howfield, the New York Jets soccerstyle booter, does not feel an intense need to kick the stuffings out of the New York Giants in the annual Yale Bowl clash on Sunday. And for that reason he just may return to his old preseason form.

title: A.A.U. DIVING TITLE WON BY BROWN, 22
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19 (AP)Mike Brown of Denver successfully completed a spectacular dive he had never tried before in serious competition to capture his first outdoor National Amateur Athletic Union onemeter diving championship today.

title: Cardinal and President
description: President Nixon has responded to an ardent appeal by Cardinal Cooke for Federal support of parochial schools with an impromptu pledge, You can count on my support.... The President deplored the closing of parochial schools as a result of fiscal pressures, and vowed his help to stop that trend and turn it around.

title: Needed: A New Committee of 100
description: New York City is in a far greater state of disarray than appears from the crises which erupt from day to day or week to week. The rate at which the crises are worsening is accelerating. Most of the manifestations of the crises remain submerged until suddenly one or another appears like a volcano erupting, an iceberg upending or a coal mine subsiding.

title: New Dance Works Increase Interest In Cubiculo Series
description: The Cubiculo Dance Theater's retrospective series, concluded Wednesday evening, has had the added interest of presenting a sprinkling of new works amidst the older dances. Among the most intriguing was Holiday Time at Stanley Brown's.

title: 30 Catholics Resign Posts
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 19Thirty leading Roman Catholics in Londonderry resigned from public office today in protest against the policy of the Government of Northern Ireland of interning suspects without trial and what the Catholics called British Army brutality.

title: Graebner Merion Victor;
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 19Twice standing one point from defeat in the quarterfinals, Clark Graebner rallied to win today in the $15,000 Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at Merlon Cricket Club.

title: 5% DOWN PAYMENT ON HOME ALLOWED
description: Builders and wouldbe buyers of homes were given another incentive yesterday when the Federal Home Loan Bank Board authorized savings and loan associations to make conventional home loans with down payments as low as 5 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Your recent editorial hailing the Supreme Court decision outlawing aid to parochial schools states that by a narrow fivetofour majority it approved the use of Federal fundsa practice that has been followed for some years under a 1963 lawfor construction of such buildings as scientific laboratories and gymnasiums for churchrelated colleges.

title: PAUL FISH
description: SPARTA, N. C., Aug. 19Paul Fish, a manufacturer of smoking pipes, died in AIleghany Memorial Hospital here on Monday of injuries received in an automobile accident. He was 57 years old.

title: MORE LEGISLATORS BARRED IN PAKISTAN
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 19 (AP)The Government has disqualified 195 of the 288 Awami League members elected to the 310scat East Pakistani Provincial Assembly.

title: Winigo Wins Hurdle Race by 8 Lengths
Poet Has Last Word In Suffolk Mouse Case
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 19 The case of Morris the Mouse, was laid to rest today with a quote from Robert Burns.

title: U.S. Casualties Down For 5th Week in Row
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 (AP)American casualties in Vietnam remained at a low level last week while South Vietnamese losses rose sharply, the allied commands reported today.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
Rescuers Pull Boy, 13, From a Gravel Hopper
description: Two Port Authority policemen and a Fire Department lieutenant rescued a 13yearold boy yesterday afternoon who was buried in gravel up to his neck.

title: Tokyo Foreign Exchange Market Recovers Degree of Stability After 4 Hectic Days
description: TOKYO, Friday, Aug. 20The Tokyo foreign exchange market recovered a degree of stability this morning after four hectic days of dollar inflows that brought Japan's foreign exchange reserves to the $11billion level  only about a billion dollars below that of the United States.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Adm. U. S. Grant Sharp's Aug. OpEd article criticizing both The New York Times version of the Pentagon papers and the restrictions placed on the air war against North Vietnam reflects one of the chief fallacies in the thinking of the military mind: The inability to understand the chain of events set into motion by the excessive use of power.

title: U.S. Seeks Convertibility
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The United States hopes to restore soon the convertibility of the dollar and end its potentially floating status against other currencies, but only wheri this Government is satisfied that other countries have taken the painful actions needed to restore the United States financial position in the world.

title: Stanton Kettler Dies at 63; Led Storer Broadcasting
description: MIAMI Aug 19Stanton P Kettler vice chairman of Storer Broadcasting Company and director of Northeast Airlines, died yesterday in the Miami Heart Institute after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Routes to Yale Bowl Uncluttered
description: An easing on Sunday of the usual heavy traffic surrounding the GiantsJets preseason game at the Yale Bowl was predicted yesterday by Capt. David J. Burke of the Traffic Division, New Haven Police.

title: The President as a Scofflaw
description: GREENSBORO, N. C.  President Nixon's statement on the Austin Tex., school case has come as a severe blow to the South. That may seem surprising but only if one is unawareas Mr. Nixon certainly seems to beof the remarkable steps this region has taken in recent weeks to prepare itself for the inevitability of thorough, even traumatic racial change.

title: Minh Quits Vietnam Race, Saying Thieu Rigs Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 20Gen. Duong Van Minh withdrew from the presidential race this morning, leaving President Nguyen Van Thieu unopposed in the elections scheduled for Oct. 3.

title: TEAM GOLF IS WON BY WESTCHESTER
description: HARRISON. N. Y., Aug. 19Westchester Country Club retained the Hoffhine Memorial Trophy today in the club's 28th annual Metropolitan invitation team tournament, but only after finishing in a tie with Winged Foot with a fourman gross of 292.

title: Gun of Policeman Slain Last Fall. Leads to Arrest of Bronx Man
description: The recovery of a service revolver taken from a policeman who was stabbed to death in the Bronx last fall led last night to the arrest of a 24yearold Bronx man on a murder charge.

title: First Puerto Rican Is Designated Head Of City High School
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner yesterday designated Marco A. Hernandez as the first Puerto Rican to become a high school principal in the city's public school system.

title: Nixon May Be Asked to Intervene in Medina Trial
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 19  The possibility that President Nixon may be asked to intervene in the Mylai courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina was raised today by F. Lee Bailey, the defense counsel.

title: HOLT TO PUBLISH PEARSON'S DIARY
description: A diary kept by Drew Pearson, the Washington columnist, from 1949 to shortly before his death in September, 1969, will be published in three volumes by Holt, Rinehart & Winston, starting next year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Aug 21 the third anniversary of the Sovietled invasion and occupation of Czechoslovakia, will pass quietly.

title: Net Redemptions Up Again at Funds
description: The mutual fund industry, for the third consecutive month, paid out in July more to those wanting to cash in their shares than it received from new investors.

title: VESCO BID REFUSED ON S.E.C. SUBPOENA
description: Efforts by Robert L. Vesco to appeal a court order directing him to testify before the Securities and Exchange Commission on Aug. 24 were rejected yesterday.

title: 3 Retail Chains Report Gains;
description: Substantially better performances were shown by the three retail chains that reported results yesterday for the second quarter and halfyear periods.

title: SHORT INTEREST IS DOWN SHARPLY
International Menu Offers Coffee and Alibis
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 19At an Alibi Breakfast such as annually precedes the $125,000 International Trot, each driveror his proxyin the event is expected to voice a prerace excuse. At this year's function today, at the Promenade Cafe at Roosevelt Raceway, three reinsmen offered plausible reasons why their trotters were unlikely to win Saturday night.

title: Lipkins Acquitted of Perjury Charges
description: Milton Lipkins of the Broadway Maintenance Corporation won acquittal last night at the end of his twoweek trial on charges that he had lied to grand jury investigating allegations that the company paid kickbacks on city contracts.

title: Nation's Teachers Assail Wage Freeze and Study Action to Challenge it in Court
description: Teachers and school officials across the country reacted yesterday with confusion and anger to President Nixon's 90 day wage freeze, which will apparently prevent tens of thousands of teachers from reeeiving salary increases next month.

title: Ohio Crane Operator Wins HighPower Rifle Crown
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 19 (AP)Ron Troyer, a 27yearold crane operator from Williamsfield, Ohio, stood off the challenge of Gary Anderson of Axtell, Neb., an international champion, today and retained the national highpower rifle championship.

title: New A.E.C. Chief Pledges Discussions on Hazards
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19Dr. James R. Schlesinger said today that as the new head of the Atomic Energy Commission he would ensure wholly forthright dealings with complaints of nuclear hazards and pollution.

title: On and Off Broadway, Slim Bookings
description: In past years August usually was a busy month for Broadway. The fall schedule was firmly set. The big musicals went into rehearsal and almost all the theaters were booked. Any latestarting show had to scramble for a houseor wait until next year.

title: Thelma Ryan's Rise: From White Frame Home to White House
Nixon Seems Unmoved
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug 10 (UPI)President Nixon was asked his view on Governor Smith's defiance of the wage freeze when the President arrived here tonight for a stay at the Western White House.

title: RAIL TRAFFIC OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Aug. 14 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Mike Hill Gains Stroke Lead With 65 in Philadelphia Golf
Shouting Mothers Lead Protest Against Subway Construction in Central Park
description: Shouting mothers carrying babies led a demonstration in Central Park near Central Park South yesterday that partly halted initial construction for a subway tunnel that would link Manhattan with Queens.

title: COSMOS MEET BANGU AT STADIUM TONIGHT
description: The New York Cosmos, in their first year in the North American Soccer League, can clinch a playoff berth in the eightteam pro loop tonight when they meet Bangu of Brazil at Yankee Stadium at o'clock.

title: Squeeze on Japan
description: President Nixon's decision to cut the dollar loose from gold and to impose a 10 per cent surtax on imports not subject to quotas is having a devastating impact on Japan. The Japanese Government has had to purchase two billions of American dollars in an effort to keep the yen at its present official rate of 360 to the dollar. Since Monday the Tokyo stock market has dropped 20 per cent, causing cumulative losses of over $11 billion. Fears are rampant that Japanese business, heavily dependent on exports to the huge American market, will plummet as a result of Mr. Nixon's tough policy.

title: Executive Changes
description: The OwensCorning Fiberglas Corporation announced yesterday the election of John H. Thomas as vice chairman and deputy chief executive officer, and William W. Boeschenstein as president and chief operating officer. The appointment was made by General Lauris Norstad, chairman of the diversified company. Mr. Thomas, Wile has been president and chief operating officer, has been associated with the manufacture of fibrous glass for more than 40 years and has had an especially active role in the company's research and development activity. He has held more than 20 patents in this area. Mr. Boeschenstein, until now executive vice president, has been with OwensCorning for more than 20 years. The company also elected John G. McLean, president and chief executive officer of the Continental Oil Company, and W. L. Hadley Griffin, president and chief executive officer of Brown Shoe Company, Inc., to the board of directors.

title: A MOZART PROGRAM IS MOSTLY SCHUBERT
description: Playing truant for an evening from their regular summer duties in Tanglewood, seven Boston Symphony Chamber Players (with two associates) visited Philharmonic Hall on Tuesday night as part of the Mostly Mozart Festival. They brought some very infectious music by Haydn, Mozart and Schubert along with them, and their approach to this untroubled lyrical stream was appropriately relaxed, sweettempered and easygoing.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:In D. J. Fink's praise for our space program (OpEd, July 27), we are told that our country's investment in space has bolstered the economy improved the quality of life of our people, increased our national prestige, and contributed to our national security. wish he had told us how. The economy is desperate, our prestige is a sham, our quality of life is decaying and our national security is already at overkill.

title: Laura Baugh Beats Miss McIntire, 1 Up, In U.S. Golf Upset
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 19 (UPI)Sixteenyearold Laura Baugh of Long Beach, Calif., upset the twotime champion, Barbara McIntire,. of Colorado Springs, 1 up, today and moved into the semifinals of the United States women's amateur golf tournament.

title: Confusion Over Curbs Likened to That of 1951
description: One man who is regarding the current confusion over price controls with a certain amount of deja vu is James G. Lyons, a retired dairy farmer who ran, the New YorkNew Jersey bureau of the Office of Price Stabilization the last time curbs were imposed back in January of 1951.

title: Day's Events in Freeze
description: Following are developments yesterday affecting consumers and wageearners under the 90day wage and price freeze:

title: VOTING Al COLLEGE BY YOUTH OPPOSED
VARIETY STRESSED. BY CITY BALLET
description: The New York City Ballet presented one of its somethingfor everybody within limits programs Wednesday night at the State Theater as part of its twoweek engagement.

title: OTB CHIEF WARNS COMPUTER FIRM OVER NEW FAILURE
description: Offtrack betting's soaring romance with its computers reached the shouting stage yesterday after another massive breakdown knocked out service for nearly two hours.

title: Nuptials in Suburb For Anne Starobin
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 19Miss Anne M. Starobin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Starobin, was married here today to Ivan D. Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Greenberg of North Woodmere, L. I. Rabbi Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony at the Starobin home.

title: U.S. JURY INDICTS FOUR UNION AIDES
description: NEWARK, Aug. 19A special investigation by the Fedfi eral Organized Crime Strike Force resulted today in the grand jury indictments of four local officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on charges of embezzling approximately $6,000.

title: Warning System Scans Sea
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 19 (UPI)The Aerospace Defense Command said today that a new detection and warning system to guard against any ballistic missiles attack launched at sea, had gone into operation. The system is scanning coastal waters from seven stations from Maine to Ortgon.

title: Ramsey Clark Scores Nixon's Policy on Busing
description: SAN FRANCISO, Aug. 19 President Nixon's policy against busing to achieve school integration plays into the hands of racists, former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today.

title: Fines Threatened in N.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association held its annual rules interpretation meeting yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore, but the coaches appeared more concerned with the threat of the cancellation of the preseason schedule. The National Basketball Association Players Association, currently in negotiation with the owners, has threatened not to play exhibition games if its demands are not met.

title: Reichhelm Gets Slight Edge In Atlantic Class Title Sail
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 George Reichhelm of the host Cedar Point Y.C. sailed into a onepoint lead for the national championship of the Atlantic Class today after the first two races in the fiverace regatta were completed on Long Island Sound in light easterly air.

title: 800 Crowd Greek Cathedral To Attend Rites for Skouras
description: About 800 people crowded into the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity yesterday morning to pay last respects to Spyros P. Skouras the movie and shipping magnate who died Monday at his home in Rye, N. Y., apparently of a heart attack at the age of 78.

title: NIXON AIDES MAP INFLATION FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19The Secretary of the Treasury, John B. Connally, and the Secretary of Labor, James D. Hodgson, both said today that the Nixon Administration had already begun pianning actions to prevent further inflation after the President's 90day wageprice freeze expires.

title: Books of The Times
description: Here is a little dilly that will lower your body temperature on these August days. That's meant literally Most of the action takes place in the middle of bare Arctic wastes with nothing but ice snow wind and water of polar cold to mark the landscape. Duncan Kyle, a pseudonym knows this white emptiness like his right hand; there is nothing bookish about his telling what it means to live in these subzero temperatures what the merest exposure can do to human flesh what safeguards have to he taken and how vehicles and other machines have to be coaxed to perform their functions. When a handful of men are lowered by plane in the middle of one of these windtormented plateaus in order to bring out a Soviet scientist from captivity 200 miles away the author has the makings of a taut thriller that ought to please everyone who simply can't see slipping Remembrance of Things Past into his vacation rucksack.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Plans Visit to U.S., Paris and West Germany in Fall
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 19 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is planning a visit to the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, West Germany and France this fall, official sources said today.

title: Some of the Many Voices That Are Hard to Forget
description: GAZA, Aug. 13  East Pakistan and Ulster provide more dramatic forms of misery than that of the Gaza Strip, where more than 300,000 Arab refugees wait to return to homes in Israel that many have never known and the rest have not seen for 23 years. But there is particular dead hopelessness about Gaza, possibly because its plight has lasted so long.

title: Foreign Banks'
description: LONDON, Aug. 19 (AP)A British banker proposed today that government banks in Europe and Japan lend their unwanted surplus dollars to the United States Treasury.

title: Bridge: Late Alexander Weiss Won Fame as Theorist and Player
description: A difficult speculative question for students of bridge history and performances is the following: What is the strongest team that can be formed by taking four unrelated people with the same name? Until last month the answer would have been Weiss.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:It was with a great deal of interest that I read William Shannon's column of July $7 concerning the United Mine Workers election fiasco. I congratulate Mr. Shannon for presenting to the public the history of the election and the struggle of Chip Yablonski.

title: Rebellion Erupts Against Leftist Bolivian Government
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 19 (AP)An insurrection against President Juan Jose Torres Gonzales erupted tonight, and the 10 month old leftist military Government declared a state of emergency throughout the country.

title: Heller Says Policy Aids Big Business And Needs Revision
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) President Nixon's plans for the domestic economy are badly out of whack, a leading economic adviser to two Dem. ocratic Presidents said today.

title: Utilities That Import Oil To Appeal Rate Freeze
description: Consolidated Edison and other gas, electric and water utilities declared yesterday that the 90day price freeze would create severe problems for them unless they could look to the President's Cost of Living Council for relief.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSIt is axiomatic in modern Greek history that when there is no open opposition to the Government in power, opposition starts within the Government itself. Something of this sort is now hinted inside the small group of military men or retired officers running Greece.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Judith C. Symonds Aug. 2 letter, A Zoo With Friends, misses the point: the criticism leveled earlier by Peter Schwartz went to the unspeakable conditions in which the animals are kept at the Central Park Zoo. Mrs. Symonds assures us that tilt Friends of Central Park Zoo ark making it a more rewarding place for its several million visitors. It is this blind and blinding anthropocentrism, so deeply embedded in the ChristianJudaic ethic, which is destroying the beauty of this world.

title: C.A.B. Lets 3 Lines Cut Flights On 4 Key Routes by Joint Action
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday authorized American, Trans World and United Air Lines to jointly reduce the number of flights on four routes by an average of 28 per cent Oct. 1. The airlines said the move was necessary to cut losses on the routes.

title: STEEL IMPORTERS COMPLAIN ON TAX
description: Importers of steel mill products reacted bitterly yesterday to the Presidential surcharge of 10 per cent on imports, and they said they were seeking relief from Washington because of its damaging effect on their business.

title: Policeman Dies
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 19 (UPI)  A policeman wounded in a gun battle with members of a black separatist group died today and murder charges werp filed against 11 Negroes.

title: STOCKS RETREAT AS VOLUME DROPS
Advertising:
description: Father Jeremy Harrington was in New York yesterday from his home base in Cincinnati to talk about a magazine's changed editorial and advertising approach.

title: Mrs. King Advances
description: LAKE BLUFF, Ill., Aug. 19 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King. the topseeded player, defeated Kerry Harris of Australia, 61, 62, today and led the field into the quarterfinals of the $20,000 Virginia Slims clay court tennis tournament.

title: Pennsylvania Lottery Gains
description: HARRISBURG, Aug. 19 (AP) A bill creating a statewide lottery in Pennsylvania passed the Senate, 29 to 16, today and was sent to Gov. Milton J. Shapp. The Governor was expected to approve the measure.

title: REINHOLD MAIER, GERMAN LEADER
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Aug. 18 (Reuters)Reinhold Maier, a prominent German liberal politician who played a leading role in establishing the postwar democratic state in West Germany, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

title: LYNCH BIDS HEATH END USE OF FORCE IN ULSTER CRISIS
description: LONDON, Aug. 19  Prime Minister John Lynch of Ireland warned tonight that unless Britain gave up attempting military solutions in neighboring Northern Ireland, I intend to support the policy of passive resistance being pursued by the Opposition there.

title: IRVING HOROWITZ
description: Irving Horowitz, a staff musician with the American Broadcasting Company, who played woodwind instruments for 40 years, died Wednesday in Booth Memorial Hospital. He was 60 years old, and lived at 11120 73d Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, and Rockaway, N. J.

title: Geologist, Picked for Moon Flight, Defends the Choice
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Harrison H. Schmitt, the geologistastronaut, defended today his selection over Lieut. Col. Joe H. Engle of the Air Force for the final Apollo moon flight.

title: Police Follow Trail Of Blood From Bank To Holdup Suspect
description: Police Follow Trail Of Blood From Bank To Holdup Suspect A policeman followed a trail of blood from a bank robbery yesterday at Eighth Avenue and 15th Street to St. Vincent's Hospital  where he arrested a man waiting for treatment in the emergency room.

title: Amex Prices Drop For a Second Day In Slower Trading

description: Ruth Copeland, a screamer but rather a good oneis making her New York rock singing debut through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: Malawi's President Confers With Vorster in Pretoria

Okun, son of Mrs. Murray Newman and the late Alan Okun. Both families are of Brooklyn, New York. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony.

Then, following appropriate expressions of deep concern and official studies indicating that the problem was being ?? in the media, thc, same subject's news value tinned noticeably cool. The problem, unfortunately, is still hot.

He urged the selection committee to consider Gene Brito and thereby reached so far out into left field that he raised enough eyebrows to build an arch across the country.

description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 19The sitar players looked glum and confused.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: AREA AIf the weather holds up for the weekend, weakfish, blues and tuna are expected to remain in abundance at Barnegat Ridge. The blues are running up to 12 pounds offshore, and 2 to 3 pounds off the beach. Trollers are catching blues with a No. 3 squid spoon. Boats are reporting catches of weakfish totaling 500 pounds. The weakfish, going for jigs and bait, are off Long Beach Island. Tuna, from 15 to 25 pounds, are biting at red and white feathers. Flounders, scarce along shore, are being caught from boats in limited quantities. The flounders are going for squid and minnow. The deepsea boats are catching marlin, dolphin and wahoo in Hudson Canyon.

title: Firestone Lists Record Results
Young Duvalier Survives His First Political Crisis
description: PORTAUPRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 19Haiti's young President i JeanClaude Duvalier, has overcome the first serious political crisis since he came to office fOur months ago, but tensions appear to be growing within the small group that shares power with him.

description: The New York Commodity Exchange resumed trading in silver and copper futures contracts yesterday after having been closed since Monday pending clarification of the price freeze order from Washington.

description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 19Following is the second set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

description: A fledgling union at the Mueum of Modern Art, which represents the professional staff, has decided to strike the museumtoday. Opntract talks broke off last night on a range of issues including recent job dismissals and program cutbacks.

description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP)The Coast Guard cutter Vigilant arrived here today with six survivors of a sunken New Bedford fishing trawler, the Malene and Marie. The trawler collided yesterday with a Polish trawler, Nidzica, 50 miles east of Nantucket.

title: Pew Foreigners Here Worry About Currency
description: For most overseas visitors here yesterday, it was the rain. Or the blisters from walking fifty blocks. Or the cab drivers, careening around corners and then braking too quickly. What it was not, in terms of problems or worry, was the International monetary crisis.

title: Talks Last Over 14 Hours
description: BRUSSELS, Friday, Aug. 20The major nations of Western Europe agreed early today to reopen their currency, markets on Monday under conditions that will almost certainly bring about a devaluation of the dollar.

title: China Justifying Nixon Visit for Chinese
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 19The Peking Government is going to considerable pains to explain and justify to the Chinese people its new policy of contact with Americans and in particular the forthcoming visit of President Nixon.

title: CATV  Pitfalls and Horizons
description: Whether cable television (CATV) becomes a national boon or a shockingly wasted opportunity depends largely on decisions now being made or considered. Some of these decisions are now being made at the local leveleven while the White House launches a new study and while Congress considers certain proposed regulations sent it, in an unusual procedure, on August 5, by the F.C.C.

title: DONALD C. LEWIS
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Aug. 19Donald C. Lewis a retired executive of Union Carbide Corporation died today at Phelps Memorial Hospital North Tarrytown He was 67 years old and lived at 88 Holbrook Lane.

title: 766296 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 19 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 766,296. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400 and the last three $40. Those with the last two numbers are eligible for millionaire's drawing.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP)A delegation of Cuban refugees living in New York and New Jersey have protested to the White House an invitation to Cuba to send baseball team here next year.

title: COOPER IN ACCORD ON SMITH, MILLER
description: Cooper Laboratories, Inc., announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Smith, Miller & Patch, Inc., a manufacturer of ethical pharmaceuticals, through an exchange of stock worth more than $30million.

title: Film: Full-Time Voyeur:Benjamin Cast in Lead of 'Young Stockbroker'
description: The latest, and surely the least, of those movies that mean to tell us how we now live, Lawrence Turman's "The Marriage of a Young Stockbroker," opened yesterday at the Sutton Theater. Although its title and the casting of its leading actor and certain elements of its plot may give the impression of something manufactured out of several other films' patched cloth, "Stockbroker" is generally its own different kinds of movie, most of them bad.A young Los Angeles stockbroker (Richard Benjamin), finding himself without accounts and noticing that the broker in the next cubicle has just dropped dead on the job, decides to quit work and give himself up to his hobby: voyeurism. All goes well and routinely enough until one night at the beach his wife (Joanna Shimkus) tires of waiting after he has climbed out the bathroom window to observe the local talent, and the next day she leaves him. For the balance of the movieabout an hourit is touch and go as to whether this marriage can be saved, whether he will reform, whether she will succumb to the melodramatics of her sister (Elizabeth Ashley) or the malpractice of the family marriage counselor (Patricia Barry).I can well imagine a comedy about voyeurism. Most movie critics live one. But "The Marriage of a Young Stockbroker" isn't really about voyeurism, any more than it is about stockbrokering. It does have a bit to do with marriage, but mostly in terms of mechanics  sexual mechanics, the mechanics of marital supremacy, the nuclear family as a machine for getting on in the suburbs. In this connection, its only real subject is its own comic situations, and its real genre is the unsuccessful television pilota type to which a good many recent American movies belong.Richard Benjamin plays the stockbroker in much the same way that last year he played the husband of the mad housewife, a characterization that does not build great sympathy. He is a good comedian, but miscast and, I think, badly miscalculated in his portrayal of the secret life of vicarious passions. It is difficult to say what Joanna Shimkus portrays, except distaste, and only Elizabeth Ashley has command of a role, half timid tease, half domineering housewife, conventional to be sure, that seems to belong to the two-thirds of the movie in which she appears.At one point the stockbroker runs into a girl, a stranger, who invites him to act out his fantasies, which, with considerable unfunny maladroitness, he does. The sequence is a loss, but the girl, a stern and unusual beauty named Tiffany Bolling, isn't.

title: TaxExempt Rates Show Record Decline for Week
Mrs. Palmer Is Married to Prince
description: Mrs. Lucile Forman Palmer and Prince Kyril Scherbatow were married here yesterday. Only members of the immediate families attended the civil ceremony performed by Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court at his chambers.

title: MONETARY MOVES MEET RESISTANCE
ABORTION CHANGE STALLED OVER U.S.
description: Although 35 state legislatures have considered abortion reform legislation this year, no new laws have been passed so far. The proposed bills included attempts by some states to liberalize old laws, as well as attempts by others to repeal or modify liberalized laws.

title: KENNETH WYNNE, 83, CONNECTICUT JUDGE
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 19Kenneth Wynne, who retired as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court in 1958, died today in YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived on Pease Road in nearby Woodbridge.

title: Robert Gimbel Is Leaving Saks to Join White, Weld
description: Robert Gimbel will resign, effective next Friday, as assistant to the vice president and general manager of Saks Fifth Avenue. Mr. Gimbel is the son of Bruce Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, which is the parent company of Saks Fifth Avenue.

Y., had become tall enough so that it approached a highvoltage transmission line between Rochester and Syracuse, thereby causing a short circuit that could have plunged the Northeast into a blackout as severe as the one of November, 1965.

description: A homicidal assault by guards caused the death of an inmate at the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men on Aug. 10, District Attorney Eugene Gold charged yesterday.

title: Exchange Wants Industry To Meet on Martin Study
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday proposed a meeting of different segments of the securities industry to discuss the recommendations of William McChesney Martin Jr. for the development of a single, nationwide, central auction market.

description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and two Criminal Court judges were charged yesterday with violating the law in a number of fashions by their actions in a case involving three youths arrested after a shootout following the earlymorning holdup of a Harlem bar.

description: BOSTON, Aug. 19 (AP)Federal and state investigators began today to track down leads, they hope will aid in breaking, up gangland in New England.

description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 (AP) Unions involved in the more than threeyear strike at The Los Angeles HeraldExaminer said yesterday that members were ready to return to work at the old contract rates.

title: MILTON F. KULP JR.
description: GWYNEDD VALLEY, Pa., Aug. 19Milton F. Kulp Jr., a trainer of hunters and jumpers, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in Newton (N. J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 41 years old and lived on All Around Farms here.

description: Governor Rockefeller declared yesterday that revolutionary changes might be necessary in this country's institutions if they were to be relevant to people's needs.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP)The Nature Conservancy and the United States Forest Service announced today joint project to help save the California condor, a large bird on the endangered species list.

description: Bernice Finch, assistant director of nursing at University Hospital, New York University Medical Center, died on Thursday at her home in Patten, Me. She was 56 years old.

The match will be concluded today.

Buckley Jr. The cancellations continue in the wake of publication, in Mr. Buckley's magazine National Review of fictitious Vietnam war secrets. Reports of the secret papers were carried by wire services and published by newspapers across the country before Mr. Buckley disclosed that it was all a hoax. Reached yesterday for comment on the most recent cancellations Mr. Buckley said he was surprised but he composed, ex nihilo a statement:

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 19  An article based on Soviet archive material asserted today that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev agreed to withdraw the Soviet offensive missiles from Cuba after receiving private assurances from Robert F. Kennedy that the United States would pull its rockets out of Turkey.

Moseson performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Haskell Rosenbloom.

description: ??UANGTRI, South Vietnam, Aug; 19The B52 bombers trace their thin, white jet trails over the Quangtri combat base every day, making a Uturn just to the north and then heading back to their bases in Thailand again, before the tons of bombs thunder into the ground just below the demilitarized zone and send clouds of dus drifting toward the South China Sea.

title: Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Following is the third set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: NORTH SEA PARCELS ARE AUCTIONED OFF
description: LONDON, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Fifteen sections of the North Sea bed were auctioned off to oil and industrial groups today for a total of $89.2million.

title: New Chairman Is Named By Board of First Surety

title: Miss Lemmon Memphis Bride Of Stockbroker
description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 20Miss Elizabeth Minor Lemmon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brandon Lemmon, was married here this afternoon to Hugh Montgomery Brinkley Jr., a stockbroker with Walston & Co., in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Coating Method Improves Textile and Plastic Uses
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The owners of a newly patented process for coating synthetic textiles believe it will be as important to plastics as xerography has been to paper. The consumer is promised improved washability and wetability, added comfort and resistance to static. The Surface Activation Corporation, Westbury, L.I., received Patent 3,600,122 this week for the method of applying an organic monomer such as acrylic acid to a plastic film or textile. The inventor is John H. Coleman, who was president of a predecessor company, the Radiation Research Corporation.

title: Environmental Hedging

Faced with the question of whether or not the project would violate the state's waterquality standards, Commissioner Henry L. Diamond found that it would not, according to the evidencebut that if it should, after all, then operations would be halted immediately and the plant itself closed down.

title: Importers Chafe at Rise in Customs Duties
description: Importers sought relief yesterday from what they charged were gross inequities imposed en their business by the sudden rise in customs duties under the Administration's economic program.

title: DANIEL E. WADE
description: Daniel E. Wade a former member of the New York Stock Exchange who had been a partner in the brokerage firm of Wade Brothers & Co. here, died Thursday in Grosse Pointe Mich. He was 84 years old and lived at 245 East 72d Street.

title: Rockabilly Music By Amazing Grace Swings at New Club
description: Amazing Grace, a New York rockabilly group, is playing weekends at the Third Phase, a relatively new rockandfolk club, at 545 West 111th Street, off Broadway.

title: Calley Juror Says Verdict Offered Few Options
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., Aug. 20A juror in the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. said today that the officer's life sentence, now substantially reduced, might have been lighter in the first place had the six officers who found him guilty of murder had such an alternative.

title: Day's Events in Freeze
description: Following are developments yesterday affecting consumers and wageearners under the 90day wage and price freeze:

title: SALE DELAY URGED FOR POSTAL BONDS
description: Representative Morris K. Udall has urged the Postal Service to postpone the sale of $250million bond issue tentatively scheduled for October.

title: NEW STATUS SOUGHT BY DATA PROCESSING
description: Directors of the Data Processing Financial and General Corporation, a computerleasing company, yesterday proposed becoming a holding company to facilitate acquisitions and diversification.

title: Demonstrators Scrawl Protests Against Excavation in the Park for a Subway Tunnel
description: Demonstrators painted Save the Park and other slogans on a fence bordering a ditch near Central Park South yesterday, but made little other progress in their efforts to halt the construction through the park of a Manhattan to Queens subway tunnel.

title: Film: Seeking Mr. Right: Christa,' All About a Stewardess, Bows
description: The heroine of "Christa" is a pretty, sweet, warm-hearted blonde of 23, an airline stewardess, and a loving mother to her illegitimate baby. Christa also yearns for a Prince Charming. She finds him, whereupon the nasty man from the past pops up menacingly.Will Christa find true happiness? Does a dog have fleas?This is a Danish-made film, by no means a steaming sex pastry, and a determinedly Civilized and confident tribute to that country as an unfettered sexual Utopia. What squashes it into neutrality is that soap-opera plot, with a convenient, melodramatic wind-up.Now it's one thing for an attractive girl to bed down serenely with a succession of new men, hoping for Mr. Right. It could happen here.Denmark, the film keeps insisting, approves emphatically. To emphasize this, the footage drifts off into striking but random travelogue footage of Copenhagen and its vicinity, replete with smiling faces and picturesque architecture. Photographed in color, it all looks perfectly beautiful, including one briskly casual peek inside a pornography book store.In any case, and certainly in hers, Christa, played by a delectable gal named Birte Tove, doesn't waste time. "The human spirit is at its best with all masks off," she tells an Italian lover, whose pop-eyed "Mama mia!" at some nude bathers is plain funny. The nudity, by the way, while pointed, is discreet.Unfortunately, the predictable plot is coated over by Jack O'Connell, who made the movie, with some extremely gauzy, mystical-sounding dialogue. The acting is quite good, especially by Daniel Gelin as a music conductor who sadly leaves Miss Tove ("Music cawms first").Good, too, is Clifton Greyn as the stalwart Australian standing by through Christa's final crisis, when a jarring rock 'n' roll score slips into sweet violins. The dialogue, incidentally, is both subtitled and spoken English.Let's face it. Copenhagen or Oshkosh, a girl who stacks five swains (all we see here) is bound to hit one dud.

title: Nassau Bus Lines Agree to Forestall Service Cutbacks
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 20 Nassau County has reached agreement with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to seek $500,000 from the state' supplemental budget to forestall threatened cutbacks in bus service that were to begin this weekend.

title: Prince Ascanio Colonna Dies; Was Mussolini's Envoy to U.S.
description: ROME Aug. 20Prince Ascanio Colonna di Paliano Mussolini's last ambassador in Washington, died here on Wednesday. He was 88 years old and since his retirement from the Italian Foreign Service in 1947 had lived in the Colohna Palace, a huge complex of stately buildings and parks owned by the wealthy princely family near Rome's Quirinal Palace.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 20And so we are about to try the great international monetary experiment. Willynilly without the usual agreement in these matters of the leading central bankers and finance ministers, the float is on. One way or another, the dollar's value in terms of other major currencies is going to be established over at least the next several weeks in the market place.

title: Susan Agnew Calls Off Engagement to Policeman
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) Susan Agnew, the 23yearold elder daughter of Vice President Agnew, has called off her engagement to First Sgt. Colin N. Macindoe, 36, of the Maryland State Police, an aide to the Vice President said today.

title: HIGH MEXICAN AIDE RESIGNS UNDER FIRE
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20 (Reuters)Attorney General Julio Sanchez Vargas resigned yesterday in a move apparently connected with the violent dispersal June 10 of a student march here.

title: Mexico Says Fugitive Fled to the U.S.
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 20 (UPI) The Mexican police asked the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation today to seek and arrest a New Yorker who escaped by helicopter on Wednesday from a federal penitentiary here.

title: William Crawford Named Joffrey Ballet Manager
description: William Crawford has been named general administrator of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, succeeding Omar K. Lerman, who resigned last month.

title: Peking Rejects 2China Plan, Rebuffs Rogers on U.N. Seats
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Aug. 21Communist China has declared that it would absolutely have nothing to do with the United Nations while the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan was represented there.

title: Black Catholics Weigh a Break With Church at Detroit Meeting
description: DETROIT, Aug. 20A convention of 1,600 black Roman Catholics began today with many delegates debating whether they could remain in a church that they say is not relevant to its black members.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The tennis pro's name was Claude, and he had a beach boy's smile. Hi, Champ, he would say. He bothered remember the names only of people who drove big cars or treated him like a servant or promised to invite him over to their summer places for dinner soon. He had once been ranked in Europe for a season, but now, at 26, he managed three allweather courts off the highway in a resort town and gave lessons with soft, dead balls.

title: I.M.F. IS OPPOSING U.S. GOLD STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The International Monetary Fund, tacitly supported by some leading foreign countries, believes that an outright devaluation of the dollar by means of a small increase in the official price of gold would probably contribute to a solution of the current world monetary turmoil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Without commenting on other positions taken in your editorial of Aug. 7 on the Martin Report, I believe you did not hit the mark on two important antitrust issues. One relates to Mr. Martin's recommendation of immunity for selfregulatory action and the other to his proposal of a single national securities market.

title: MODERN MUSEUM STRUCK BY STAFF
description: Pickets formed outside the Museum of Modern Art yesterday after the Professional and Administrative Staff Msoelation, believed to be the first union of its kind in the country, walked out on a deadlocked job negotiations meeting with John Hightower, the museum's director.

title: School's Hospital Head Resigns
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Aug. 20The director of the planned hospital of the Medical School at the State University of New York at Stony Brook resigned today, two weeks after the school opened its doors to its first students.

title: Independence From Soviet Is Reiterated by Rumanian
description: VIENNA, Aug. 20 (Reuters) President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania in an anniversary speech tonight praising his country's independence heroes told the Soviet Union that there could no longer be one world center of Communism.

title: Eliza Lansing Conze Is Married To Anthony Billington, Ad Man
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 20Miss Eliza Lansing Conze, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter H. Conze, was married here this afternoon to Anthony Henry Billington, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Billington of Newbury, England.

title: U.S PLANS TO ASK COURT TO ENFORCE TEXAS PAY FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Department of Justice announced late today that it expected to seek a court order next week requiring Gov. Preston E. Smith of Texas to obey the Federal freeze on wages and prices.

title: Paz Supports Rebels
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 20Victor Paz Estenssoro, tormer President of Bolivia, declared from exile today his support for the military rebels seeking to overthrow the leftist Government of General Torres.

title: Giants Roar Through Noisy Drill
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 20As if the lid on their emotions had been lifted, the Giants stormed happily through today's workout, their final serious tuneup for the game against the Jets on Sunday.

title: Black Traveler in South Africa Hastings Kamuzu Banda
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 20Dr. H. Kamuzu Banda, the Life President of Malawi, returned home today after a historic fiveday tour that stirred whiteruled South Africa.

title: BANGU TROUNCES COSMOS IN SOCCER
description: The New York Cosmos went to Yankee Stadium last night hoping to clinch a playoff berth in the North American Soccer League but were beaten, 61, by Bangu.

title: Tenants File Complaint to Bar Expansion of Columbus Hospital
description: A state legislator a tenant from an old tenement and a tenant from a new luxury apartment building asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to stop the state from lending Columbus Hospital $39.7million for expansion.

title: Paris Raises Transit Fares
description: PARIS, Aug. 20 (Reuters)Paris bus and subway fares went up today by 20 centimes, or about 4 cents, amid protests by unions and public. Secondclass bus and Metro tickets bought individually rose from about 20 to 24 cents.

title: Henry Sets Pace In 3Meter Trials Of A.A.U. Diving
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)Jim Henry and Mike Brown, Indiana University teammates, resumed their duel in the National Amateur Athletic Union diving championships today, with Henry carving out a huge lead in the threemeter semifinals.

title: Earlier Prices Studied By Allegheny Ludlum
description: Allegheny Ludlum Industries, Inc., said yesterday it was studying selling prices of stainless steel products as of May 25, 1970, to see if any of those prices were higher than present levels.

title: The Calley Review
description: Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor, the first officer to review the Calley case, finds the original conviction to be correct in law and fact. The general nevertheless considers it appropriate for the offense for which he was convicted to reduce Lieutenant Calley's life sentence to twenty years imprisonment, thus making him eligible for parole in six to seven years.

title: Ky Marches in Funeral
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 20  The crippled war veteran who burned himself to death Monday to protest Government election policies was given a large public funeral today while rumors of more political disturbances circulated in Saigon following Gen. Duong Van Minh's withdrawal from the presidential campaign.

title: Ireland Sets Tourist Rate
description: The Irish Tourist Board in New York said yesterday that the Bank of Ireland has established a special rate of exchange for tourists of $2.46 to the Irish pound.

title: With the Pope the Main Attraction, His Resort Is Busy but Not Thriving
description: CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 15"This is the Cinderella of the Castelli Romani, a shopkeeper, Marino Di Bernardini, said, complaining about the episodic splendor of this town as the summer residence of Popes.

title: Lumber Importers Bitter on 10% Tax
description: While domestic producers of lumber and plywood have warmly endorsed President Nixon's economic program, importers have complained bitterly about inordinately harsh inequities resulting from the 10 per cent import surcharge and are asking the Government for relief.

title: Camden Calls State Police As Riots Flare a 2d Night
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Aug. 20Bands of Puerto Rivan youths threw fire bombs, smashed dows and looted stores in downtown Camden business district tonight for the second, consecutive night.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (Reuters) Soviet ships may use Malta's drydock facilities as part of measures designed to help her overcome economic difficulties, the Tass press agency reported today in a dispatch from Valletta.

description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 20 (AP)A former Charlie Company platoon leader testified today that he came across the bodies of civilians soon after entering Mylai but did not report his discovery to Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the company commander.

description: CHICAGO, Aug. 20In an unlikely meeting of legal minds, assistant attorneys general from Massachusetts and Minnesota and the attorney general of New Mexico gathered here this week with leading civil rights lawyers and antiwar activists to map a joint assault on the war in Vietnam.

title: Youths Learn of Wilds in Parks
description: Checking his compass and the instructions in his guidebook, 11yearold Ben Greene and eight other members of his Y.M.C.A. Day Camp group proceeded 20 paces south in a wooded area to Point 9.

title: Moscow Says China Fabricated Soviet Invasion Fear
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20The Soviet Union said today that Chinese leaders had fabricated concern over a possible Russian invasion to justify their antiSoviet line and their efforts to improve relations with the United States and other Western powers.

title: What's So Bad About Inflation?
description: Among all the confidence games going on in America today, the prize for political chutzpah must go to President Nixon for trying to, persuade the working man that all his troubles stem from inflation.

title: MITCHELL BLOCKS DISTRICTING PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Attorney General John N'Mitchell rejected today a plan for reapportioning Louisiana's legislative districts on the ground that it would discriminate against Negroes by diluting their voting power.

title: Soviet Research Rocket
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today a research rocketcarrying equipment built and developed by scientists from Russia and five other countriesto carry out geophysical research, the press agency Tass reported. Specialists from East Germany, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Bulgaria had joined in developing the rocket's scientific equipment.

title: Seven New Environment Aides Will Include Nonprofessionals
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency will announce in the next few days the appointment of seven regional directors.

title: Year of Legal Abortion
description: The first year of legalized abortion in New York City has brought a substantial decline in maternity mortality. Also down significantly are the city's total birth rate and its rate of illegitimate births. Equally important in social terms, the year's experience shows that women of all ethnic and racial groups have availed themselves of the opportunity to prevent unwanted births legallyand, many cases, at little or no cost. One happy incidental result is that all of this city's shelters caring for unmarried pregnant girls have this year reported a sizable drop in admission applications.

title: ARMY LISTS 36 MEN IN HELICOPTER CRASH
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Aug. 20 (AP)The United, States Army made public today the names of 36 of the 37 men aboard the helicopter that crashed near Pegnitz Wednesday, killing all aboard.

title: WALLACE EXTENDS COURT DEFIANCE
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 20 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama challenged another Federal Court order today by ordering the Calhoun County school board to open at least three more schools to prevent what he said was massive busing.

title: CIVIL DEFENSE LINK SET FOR 11 STATES
description: CONCORD, Mass., Aug. 20 (AP)Eleven states and the District of Columbia will become part of a new Federal Civil Defense radio network next year, Allan R. Zenowitz, regional director of the Office of Civil Defense, said today.

title: 0.6% for City Area
description: Bucking a national trend, the New York metropolitan area registered a sharp increase in consumer prices last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: No More Egg Taint Found
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) The Agriculture Department has found no further contamination of processed egg products from Southeastern plants since excessive amounts of dangerous chemical were discovered last Tuesday, it was reported today. Tainted eggs totaling 53,430 pounds from plants in North and South Carolina were barred for human consumption when six samples were found to contain excess residues of polychlorinated biphenyls, an industrial coolant.

title: TEAMSTERS HAVE MIXED FEELINGS
description: BOSTON, Aug. 20Charles Keenan spread his hands in a gesture of futility and said, Something had to be done. If your pay goes up and the cost of living wipes it out, what the hell do you need it for?

title: Cuba Host Again in '72
description: MIAMI, Aug. 20 (AP)The North American volleyball championships, now being played in Havana, will return to the Cuban capital in 1972, Radio Havana announced today.

title: Pakistan Designates a Lawyer As Defender of Bengali Leader
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 20 A leading constitutional lawyer was named by the Pakistani Government today to defend Sheik Mujibur Rahman, the imprisoned Bengali leader currently on trial for treason.

title: Deborah Lyeth Is Bride Here
description: Miss Deborah Dobson Lyeth, daughter of Mrs. John Mortimer Richardson Lyeth Jr. of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late John William Clarke of Chicago, was married yesterday afternoon to James Patrick DiCicco.

title: MISS BAUGH GAINS IN AMATEUR GOLF
Jewelry That's for the Young in Spirit
