Nasimo Sarges, Clifton Nicholson and Frank Del Campo all specialize in contemporary jewelry and belts, aimed particularly at modest pocketbooks and the young in spirit. Their collections include animal, fruit and flower themes, done in metal, suede and stained glass.

title: A Probing Role for the Courts
description: If there is a consensus in America today, it is a consensus that our system of criminal justice is in a state of crisis. I think there is a grave danger that we have been oversold on the benefits of judicial efficiency. In a great burst of wishful thinking, many of us seem to have decided that cutting down on court backlogs will cut down on crime. The theory seems to be that wouldbe criminals will in large numbers be deterred from unlawful actions by the threat of swift punishment, but not by the threat of remote punishment.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN AMEX TRADING
President to Meet Hirohito in Alaska
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 20President Nixon announced today that he and his wife would fly to Anchorage, Alaska, on Sept. 26 to welcome Emperor Hirohito and his wife.

title: Maureen Finch Bride of Law Student
description: LA CANADA, Calif., Aug. 20Maureen Finch, daughter of Presidential adviser and Mrs. Robert H. Finch, was married in this Los Angeles suburb tonight to John Elton Shaw, a former White House interne.

title: LOMBARDY LEADING IN U.S. OPEN CHESS

William Lombardy of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx, defeated International Grandmaster Larry Evans, Reno, In the 11th round of the United States Open Chess Championship at the Ventura Fairgrounds today. The victory gives Father Lombardy, an international grandmaster, undisputed possession of first place.

title: JOSEPH F. CARROLL
description: Joseph F. Carroll a retired towingcompany executive died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 160 East 48th Street.

title: Nixon and the Unions
description: On Labor Day last year, the nation's top union leaders and their wives were guests for dinner at the White House. There were friendly toasts and a torchlight military pageant on the South Lawn. It was described as the most elaborate Labor Day gesture that a President had made toward organized labor in years. There was speculation at the time that President Nixon and his political advisers envisioned the possibility of incorporating major segments of labor in the conservative silent majority supporting Republicans.

title: CATHOLICS WARNED ON HOLLINGS BRIDAL
description: CHARLESTON, S. C., Aug. 20 (UPI)The Right Rev. John Manning, vicar general of the Charleston diocese, today urged Roman Catholics not to attend the wedding of Senator Ernest F. Hollings to Rita Louise Liddy, his research assistant, tomorrow.

title: NATO's Malta Headquarters Ordered Moved to Naples
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 20 (Reuters) The North Atlantic Treaty Organization has ordered tits Mediterranean naval headquarters transferred from Malta to Naples.

title: Le Fabuleux Syndicated In U.S. for $2Million
description: PARIS, Aug. 20Le Fabuleux, a 10year old chestnut stallion who won the 1964 French Derby, has been bought for more than $2million by a syndicate of American breeders and will be flown to the United States next Wednsday.

title: Prague's Tragic Anniversary
description: Just three years ago the armies of the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites invaded Czechoslovakia, touching off a spontaneous national political resistance that won worldwide admiration and forced brieflya major Kremlin retreat.

title: MRS. LEO A. FRANKLIN
description: Mrs. Carolyn Hastings Franklin, the widow of Leo A. Franklin, who had been a merchandising executive of Brooks Brothers, died on Thursday at a nursing home on Staten Island. She was 91 years old and lived at 128 Felton Street Stapelton, S. I.

title: HARRY MAZE IS DEAD; EXCITY COUNCILMAN
description: Harry Maze a former member of the City Council died yesterday at his home. He was 69 years old and lived at 5518 Clarendon Road Brooklyn.

title: Laver Defeats Rosewall
description: FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 20 (UPI)Rod Laver, defending champion and No. 3 seeded player at the Colonial professional tennis tournament, advanced to the semifinals today with a 75, 57, 62 victory over Ken Rosewall, a fellow Australian.

title: G.M. Division Plans Layoff
description: DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP)The Fisher Body division of the General Motors Corporation confirmed today that 200 of 7,000 workers at its central engineering plant in suburban Warren would be laid off. A G.M. spokesman said the cutback was planned several weeks ago and had no connection with President Nixon's new economic program.

title: B52'S JOIN DRIVE TO SLOW ENEMY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 21 (AP) Six waves of United States B52 bombers pounded South Vietnam's embattled northern front today in steppedup raids designed to slow a 10dayold North Vietnamese offensive.

title: Mrs. King Gains Semifinal
description: LAKE BLUFF, Ill., Aug. 20 (UN) Topseeded Mrs. Billie Jean King defeated Leslie Hunt of Australia, 76, 62, today in quarterfinal matches of the $20,000 Virginia Slims clay courts tennis championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:I am a faculty member in the Pharmacology Department of the City University's Mount Sinai School where I am conducting research on nerve transmitters and morphine addiction. Our laboratory is well equipped, and I am able to draw on the knowledge and advice of several learned colleagues. Conditions in our laboratory are therefore, quite conducive to doing firstclass research, and we are making progress.

title: Airliner Carrying 50 Loses Its Landing Gear, but Lands
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20 (AP) An Allegheny Airlines propjet carrying 50 persons crash landed at the Greater Pittsburgh Airport tonight after losing its landing gear during an earlier touchdown attempt in Parkersburg, W. Va., an airline spokesman said.

title: Padres Halt Met Rally in 9th And Deal Koosman 32 Loss
A Day Care Center That May Be Copied Around the Country
description: WASHINGTON  A day Care center that was opened here this summer for the benefit of 50 children of employes of the United States Office of EduCation is intended as a model for other employers throughout this country.

title: THE MAYOR VISITS CRIMINAL COURTS
description: State Supreme Court Justice David Ross administrator of the city's Criminal Court told Mayor Lindsay yesterday that by the end of the year no case in Those lower courts should take longer than three or four weeks for disposition.

title: DuPont Glare Finds Accounts Differ
description: DuPont Glore Forgan, Inc., reported yesterday that a newly completed audit of the operations of its predecessor organization had disclosed unresolved differences of $86million in its accounts.

title: PRICE MAXIMUMS PUT ON FUTURES
description: Responding to President Nixon's price freeze, the Chicago Board of Trade established yesterday maximum trading prices for soybean oil, soybean meal, silver and plywood futures.

title: W. H. Lawrence And Mrs. Eidal Marry on Coast
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., Aug. 20 The marriage of Mrs. Jacqueline Templeton Eidal of Phoenix, Ariz., to William Howard Lawrence of Washington, national affairs editor of the American Broadcasting Company, took place here at noon today. The Rev. Preston Price performed the ceremony in the United Methodist Church.

title: BURRHANN REACHES JUNIOR TENNIS FINAL
description: John Burrmann of Chula Vista, Calif., and John Lucas of Durham, N. C., teammates on the United States Junior Davis Cup squad, will meet in today's final of the fourth annual Columbia tennis championships for juniors and boys at Baker Field.

title: SIDNEY J. FLAMM
description: Sidney J. Flamm presider and general manager since 1959 of radio station WMMM and of WGFJFM both of Westport Conn., died yesterday of a heart attack in Hackensack (N. J.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 1364 Somerset Road, West Englewood, N. J.

title: Merger of Unions Blocked By U.S. Judge in Capital
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 20 (AP)  A Federal judge has blocked a proposed merger of District 50 of the Allied and Technical Workers Union into the United Steelworkers of America.

title: POLICEMAN SLAIN HALTING A HOLDUP
description: A plainclothes policeman about to start his tour of duty last night was fatally wounded after he shot to death one of three man he surprised holding up a luncheonette in Queens Village.

title: The Ecology of the Slums
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps the national chairman of a major political party should know better than to try to assume a nonpartisan stance in any public forum. Or perhaps after decade in this capital he should have learned that when sincerely motivated people develop a clearcut, welldefined issue they are jarred by attempts to muddy that issue by placing it into a broader social context.

title: Roundup. Jenkins Posts 20th Victory
description: I The plane didn't crash, so Ferguson Jenkins yesterday I became the first National League pitcher since Warren Spahn to win 20 games in five consecutive seasons.

title: Market Place :C.P.A's sloew With Answers
description: You probably think that, if there is anyone who would be quick to respond to a request for his financial circumstances, it would be a certified public accountant.

title: GLEASON'S PETITION HELD FILED ON TIME
description: Thomas W. Gleason Jr. won a Federal Court ruling yesterday that he hopes will restore his name to the ballot in the Democratic primary for New York County surrogate.

title: Books of The Times
description: Devotees of Ivy ComptonBurnett (they must be numerous enough to form a society) are familiar by now with the standard publicity handout that shows the novelist as every inch the dour Victorian schoolmarm. Looks were never more deceiving. Dame Ivy, who, died two years ago at the age of 85, after finishing her 20th novel, is, in fact, a revolutionary figure in modern literature. With a magic all her own, for the last half century, she has broken through the conventions of fiction to turn the English comedy of manners into a stunning parody of itself. I find it curious that the subversive element of her vision what one might call her antiEstab lishmentism  has so far escaped her English critics, who tend to regard her as only a slightly more waspish Austenesque interpreter of the human comedy. Like Jane Austen's, of course, her series of novels (set in Edwardian England at the beginning of the century) has unity of time and place, and like hers it deals with the landed gentry. But a dissimilarity of intent suggests itself to me in the modern novelist's disregard for texture in contrast to Miss Austen's carefully wrought regionalism. Dame Ivy's novels are, in fact, descriptively bare: Like the abstractionist painter, she depends on the telling stroke (one dares not skip a word in her slim novels). Her major innovationnarration through conversationleaves the author no opportunity to comment directly on the action, to moralize. Static figures in a landscape, her characters are revealed by what they say, not what they do or think.

title: Patient Is Hostage As Gunman Seizes Drugs at Hospital
description: A gunman took 464 methadone tablets from the Beth Israel Methadone Clinic at 29 West 15th Street yesterday morning and then fled with patient as a hostage. The patient was later released unharmed.

title: PATH Aide Urges Week's Trial of Free Fares
description: A commissioner of the Port of New York Authority has advocated free or reduced fares during the offpeak hours on PATH, the authority's commuter railroad between New York City and New Jersey points.

title: Nazi Camp Survivor Slain Here; Policeman Killed Foiling Holdup
description: Two gunmen walked into Brooklyn luncheonette and candy store yesterday and asked for a piece of apple pie. Mien they were told that there was only ?? pastry, they shot the owner to death and critically wounded his wife.

title: ANGELS TRIUMPH OVER YANKEES, 60, ON A FIVEHITTER
Weeks Auto Output Rises
description: DETROIT, Aug. 20 (UPI)The United States auto industry increased production this week to 132,017 passenger cars, the largest output since midJuly when model changeover hit its peak, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Dinner to Salute Nixon
description: BOSTON, Aug. 20 (AP)The Republican State Committee announced today a $500ahead salute to the President fundraising dinner Nov. 9. It will feature a closedcircuit address by President Nixon and will be held in Framingham.

title: JUDICIAL CHANGE URGED BY BURGER
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 20 (AP)The Chief Justice of the United States said today that the nation's judicial machinery must be modernized to have any chance of keeping up with the tremendous increase in legal actions.

title: NewIssue Market Shows an Increase In Active Trading
description: The newissue market advanced this week in steppedup trading, but neigher prices nor volume gained proportionately as much as on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN SLOW TRADING
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miners and Peasants Move Against Rebels in Bolivia
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 20More than 35,000 peasants and armed miners were reported marching tonight against rightist army rebels who had earlier proclaimed Gen. Hugo Banzir president of Bolivia in place of President Juan Jose Torres Gonzales, a leftist.

title: ANTITHIEU ACTION BY U.S. DOUBTED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Nixon Administration expressed regret today over the withdrawal of General Duong Van Minh from the South Vietnamese presidential race.

title: Art: The English and the Florentines
description: FLORENCE, ItalyOnly museum like the Pitti Palace, whose holdings are so vast, could mount almost completely from its own collections an exhibition so scholarly and esoteric as the current summer offering, Ar tistic and Cultural Relationships Between Florence and England From the 16th Century to the 20th Century.

title: I.R.S. WILL BE READY FOR QUERIES MONDAY
description: Although Internal Revenue Service offices in such scattered cities as Andover, Mass., and Albany began answering questions about the wageprice freeze yesterday, I.R.S. officials here, as in most other areas, said they would not be ready for their new task until Monday.

title: Lindsay Aides Busy in New Hampshire
description: Overtures on behalf of a LindsayforPresident campaign in New Hampshire and indications that mayoral aides are weighing an entry into that state's March 7 primary were cited yesterday by several leading New Hampshire Democrats.

title: Nuptials for Abby Jean Pirnie And Abbott Bennett Lipsky Jr.
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 20 The marriage of Miss Abby Jean Pirnie to Abbott Bennett Lipsky Jr. took place here today in the Rotherwas Room of the Mead Art Building at Amherst College, from which the bridegroom expects to be graduated in January.

title: Leaders Sign Constitution of Loose Arab Federation
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 20 The leaders of Egypt, Syria and Libya signed a constitution today for a loose Federation of Arab Republics that they said was dedicated to Arab Socialism and the liberation of territories occupied by Israel.

title: Gateway to Peace in Berlin
description: The decision of Soviet and Western ambassadors go into two more weeks of marathon sessions on top of the intensive talks they have had in the past two weeks, indicates a determination on all sides to try to complete a new fourpower agreement on Berlin by September.

title: Smuggling Suspect Held Here Wanted By Scotland Yard
description: An Englishman arrested in connection with a $3.5million hashishsmuggling plot found out yesterday that he couldn't trifle with Sotland Yard.

title: WRIT IS SECURED FOR JIM FRENCH
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20  Conspicuously absent from the $113,700 Travers tomorrow will be Jim French, who was impounded today by the sheriff of SaratogaCounty on a writ of attachment secured by the Citizen's Union Bank and Trust Company of Lexington, Ky.

title: Henry Gradstein, Principal. Of P.S. 152 in Queens, Dies
description: Henry Gradstein principal of Public School 152 Woodside Queens, died yesterday in Long Beach (L. I.) Memorial Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old and lived at 13810 77th Avenue, Kew Gardens Hills Queens.

title: HARRY W. ROSE
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 20Harry W. Rose who retired as a divisional sales manager for the American Cyanamid Company in 1952 after 15 years of service, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 75 years old and lived at 616 East Lincoln Avenue.

title: 3 Killed in Plane Crash
description: AUGUSTA, Me., Aug. 20 (AP) A Downeast Airlines plane carrying eight persons crashed last night in dense fog on an approach to Augusta State Airport. The Federal Aviation Ad ministration said that the pilot, Dwight French, and two of his seven passengers has been killed. The dead passengers were not identified.

title: Bank of Japan Again Shores Up Yen
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 21 The Tokyo stock market appeared to be recovering a measure of calm today after a hectic week. But in the foreign exchange market this morning the Bank of Japan was forced to buy up $340million more to keep the yen at a level close to the official rate, 360 yen to the dollar.

title: Photos Are Used to Evaluate Cleanliness of City's Streets
description: The Sanitation Department is using photographs of clean and dirty streets in Manhattan in an experiment intended to find out if there are more effective ways to deploy its forces.

title: Trevino Back on Links
description: EL PASO, Tex, Aug. 20 (UPI) The United States, British and Canadian Open champion, Lee Trevino, played his first! round of golf today since his appendix was removed in an emergency operation Aug. 10. He shot a 70.

title: Albany Reports a Rise In Joblessness to 6.1%
description: ALBANY, Aug. 20 (AP)The unemployment rate in New York State climbed to 6.1 per cent during July, the Labor Department reported today. A total of 515,000 people were out of work.

title: Bridge: Little Known Psychic Signal Has Interesting Possibilities
description: Psychic bids and deceptive plays are wellknown, but little attention is given by bridge writers to the possibilities of the phychic signal. An interesting possibility is shown in the diagramed deal, an amendment of one that appeared in a European magazine.

title: Charles Colby Hewitt 3d Weds Miss ShelaghMichael Condon
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20Miss ShelaghMichael O'Malley Condon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Condon of Larchmont, N. Y., was married here this morning to Charles Colby Hewitt 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Colby Hewitt Jr. of Wellesley Hills.

title: U.S. Checks Puerto Rico In Cuba, 30
description: MIAMI, Aug. 20 (AP)The United States volleyball team defeated Puerto Rico, 30, tonight for its third straight victory in an Olympic elimination tournament being held in Cuba. Havana Radio reported they winning scores were 157, 154 and 158, with Vincent McFarlane, Dan Patterson and Larry Wendell showing up well for the American team.

title: Nostalgia Products Will Be Marketed By a New Company
description: The formation of a new company to market nostalgia was announced yesterday. The company, known as the International Memorabilia Corporation, will be headed by Joe Franklin, a host for radio and television programs on WOR in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Patrick McVeigh uses William Shannon's mistake as a springboard to a few of his own [letter Aug. 13]. To say that the Government of Northern Ireland is no more unfair than that of Dublin's, is not only inaccurate but dishonest and relies on the ignorance of most Americans on this subject.

title: Wilson Asks Commons Debate on Ulster
description: LONDON, Aug. 20Harold Wilson, reflecting Labor party discontent with Government policy, asked Prime Minister Heath today to call Paraliament back from recess for a debate on the situation in Northern Ireland.

title: DAVE HILL TAKES LEAD BY STROKE
Controversy Within Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 20Defense Minister Dayan's call for a permanent Israeli role in governing the occupied territories caused controversy today within the Cabinet.

title: Nixon Plans WelfareWork Experiment
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 20Welfare clients in some parts of New York, California and Illinois will be required to take public service jobs or lose part of their welfare grants under a demonstration project announced today by President Nixon.

title: 0.2% Across Nation
F.B.I Man's Promotion Raises Question of Hoover Successor
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20J. Edgar Hoover, has appointed the 58yearold head of the internal inspection, division of the Federal Bureau. pf Investigation to the No. 3 spot in the agency.

title: Erie Train Service Restored
description: WASHINGTON, Aug, 20 (UPI) Amtrak has announced that intercity passenger train service will he restored to Erie, Pa., effective today, as part of the New York Cleveland Chicago run.

title: Floods Force Evacuations Of East Pakistani Towns
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 20  Torrential rains throughout East Pakistan have brought major rivers well over danger limits. Many towns and villages are flooded and tens of thousands of persons have evacuated their homes.

title: Miss Weir Is Upset Victor In Title Water Ski Slalom
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Aug. 20 (UPI)Christy Lynn Weir of McQueeney, Tex., upset Mrs. Liz Allan Shetter, the defending champion, today to win the women's slalom title at the 29th annual national water ski championships at White Sulphur Lake near here.

title: Bold Reason Is Travers Pick;; Oldest Stakes Worth $113,700Winner to Get $68,220; Charts of Races at Saratoga 01971, by. Trianzle Publications. Inc. (The Morning Telegraph) Friday, August 20. 17th day. Weather cloudy, track fast.
Sears Rolls Back Some Rises In Christmas Catalogue Prices
description: Sears Roebuck & Co., the country's largest retailer, announced yesterday that it would roll hack some higher prices in its already printed Christmas catalogue to comply fully with the President's price freeze.

title: NORTH AND SOUTH HOLD FIRST TALKS SINCE KOREAN WAR
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 21Red Cross officials of North Korea and South Korea met at this neutral armistice camp at noon yesterday in the first step toward talks to solve the problem of families divided by the Korean war.

title: Detroit Policeman Killed
description: DETROIT, Aug. 20 (AP)An offduty Detroit policeman was found shot to death today at the rear of a building on Detroit's East Side. The victim was Patrolman Ulysses Drown, 28 years old.

title: Antiques: The Fun of Benefit Sales
description: Benefit antiques auctions are now in season in the rural areas that attract summer colonies.

title: HOME SALES SEEM LITTLE AFFECTED
description: Real estate dealers and brokers and home buyers and sellers are confused and worried about how the 90day wageprice freeze will affect the sale and resale of houses, since housing prices are frozen too.

title: HOFFA REBUFFED IN BID FOR PAROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The United States Parole Board denied a parole today to James R. Hoffa, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and said it would review his case again next June.

title: L.I. Girl Just Wed to Russian Says She Must Leave Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (AP)An American Jewish girl who married a Soviet medical student Tuesday said today that she would have to leave the country when her visa expires Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Life Cites Gain
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that the life insurance it issued in the first half of 1971 rose 7.8 per cent from the yearearlier level to $6.25billion. Group life policies accounted for $1.13billion, up 34 per cent.

title: DALLAS TRIUMPHS ON CLARK'S KICK
Dun &
description: Can the nation's largest creditreporting agency continue to issue reports containing a corporation president's criminal record after he has been pardoned by the Governor and his conviction vacated and expunged from the record?

title: Samuels Livid as OTB Suffers New Breakdown
description: Like a mule that won't gallop, offtrack betting's balky computer system rolled over on its back again yesterday.

title: Acquittal Is Ordered Were For 1 of 5 in Usury Trial
description: A judge ordered the acquittal yesterday of one of five defendants in a trial on loansharkconspiracy charges.

title: JACOB J. BRANDT
description: Jacob J. Brandt, a retired printing executive, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: Money Dealers Stress Costs and Risk
description: A student planning to begin school in Britain next month sought this week to purchase Japanese yen to exchange later for pounds, But he was dissuaded from doing so by his Chicago bank, which pointed out to him the costs, difficulties and even risks that such a transaction in ??

title: DR. WILLIAM CARLO
description: Dr. William E. Carlo professor of philosophy at the University of Ottawa Graduate School who was an authority on neoThomist studies, died yesterday of cancer in Ottawa. His age was 49.

title: Pretax Corporate Profits Up $3Billion in Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Corporate profits before taxes in the second quarter were up $3billion from the first quarter and $6billion from the year earlier quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Tempest Class Sail Put Off
description: MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 20 (AP)The fourth race in the Tempest Class sailing world championship was called off today because of lack of winds. Heading the standings after three races are Clifford Norbury and Tim Copsy of Britain.

title: Executive Changes
description: Iowa Beef Processors, Inc., announced yesterday the election of J. Fred Haigler as president. Mr. Haigler, formerly senior vice president, succeeds Roy Lee Jr., who will continue as director and may do some consulting, the company said.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:It is inconceivable that the cries of anguish from South Asia will keep falling on deaf ears. Eyewitnesses of the conditions of East Pakistan refugees and journalists all refer to the indifference of the global community As always it is the children who are the most vulnerable victims of catastrophe.

title: Delay on Penn Central
Steps to Float Currencies Taken in Western Europe
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 20West European countries took individual steps today to let their national currencies float against the dollar, at least partly, when foreign exchange markets reopen Monday.

title: BusinessEquipment Industry Is Neutral on Imports
description: The businessequipment in?? neither railed at nor ?? about President Nixon's ?? economic policy but in general kept a low and noncommittal posture.

title: Good Wines At Low Cost If You Know How to Shop
description: Anyone considering the purchase of some good Bordeaux wines for immediate drinking might give some thought to the 1967 vintage. Most of the bestknown chateaux are in the shops now, are ready to be enjoyed and, considering the astronomical prices of so many wines, are genuine bargains.

title: A Selective Freeze Is Called Possibility By Secretary Stans
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 20 (AP) The Nixon Administration is considering a selective wageprice freeze and other options short of lifting all restraints when the nearly allinclusive freeze ends Nov. 12, Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans said today.

title: City Will Strongly Oppose Giant Incinerator in Jersey Meadows
description: New York City will actively oppose the giant incinerator that New Jersey plans to build in the Hackensack Meadows, arguing that the facility would make it impossible for the city to meet air quality standards.

title: Intelsat Agreement Signed By Delegates of 54 Lands
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20Representatives of 54 nations signed a permanent charter for the International Telecommunications Satellite Organization (Intelsat) in ceremonies at the State Department today.

title: International Looks Wide, Open
Teachers'Wage Rise Canceled by Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La. Aug. 20 (AP)The Louisiana administration acted today to cancel a decision by the state education superintendent, William Dodd, to grant school employes a $400ayear increase despite President Nixon's wage freeze.

title: American Airlines Receives 11 Million In '65 Insured Loss
description: One of the largest jury' awards ever made in an airline negligence suit was completed yesterday with the delivery to American Airlines of the second of two checks totaling almost $11million.

title: New Career Grant Made
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 (AP) A $30,000 grant to help unemployed scientists and engineers in King County, Wash., find new careers was announced today by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. The county includes Seattle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKTON GAINS FINAL IN TENNIS
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 20Richard Stockton of Garden City, L. I., reached the final round of the 72d Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today by upsetting sixthseeded Colin Dibley, Australia's No. 1 player, 64, 36, 63, 63, before a capacity crowd of 2,500 at Merlon Cricket Club.

title: Political Detainees Listed by Egyptians; 380 Reported Held
description: CAIRO, Aug. 20Lifting a shroud of secrecy over securitypolice practices, the Minister of the Interior, Mamdouh Salem, disclosed today that 380 persons were in detention for political reasons. Thirteen thousand have been politically isolated for 10 years, he added, and 160,000 have been forced to go abroad.

title: Priest Is Mayoral Candidate
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Aug. 20The Democratic Town Committee has endorsed the Rev. Charles Cobb, a Roman Catholic priest, as the Democratic nominee for Mayor in the November election. Father Cobb, assistant pastor of St. Rose's Church, said that we have looked outside the church and see that the needs of the community are not being fulfilled. The Republican nominee for Mayor is the incumbent, Robert Schultz.

title: Cuban Who Stole MIG in 69 Is Held On a Drug Charge
description: A Cuban refugee who defected to the United States in a MIG17 fighter in 1969 was arrested here last night after the police said he tried to sell marijuana to a cab driver.

title: ANTIWAR STUDENTS LAUDED BY ELLSBERG
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 20  Daniel Ellsberg said last night that student antiwar activities were responsible acts and set an example for him in his release to the American press of the Pentagon papers.

title: East Village Theater to Show Old Musical Films Exclusively
description: A refurbished playhouse in the East Village is about to offer something new in vintage screen fare. Starting tomorrow. Theater 80 St. Marks will become what may be the only showcase ever devoted entirely to movie musicals.

title: Dayan View on Occupation Sharply Criticized by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20The State Department took sharp issue today with the Israeli Defense Minister, Moshe Dayan, over his proposal that Israel promptly establish permanent government in the Arab territories occupied during the 1967 war.

title: Music: Mozart for Five
description: Tucked away inside this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall is a Mozart piano concerto festival, one of the brightest ideas to strike anyone at Lincoln. Center in some time. Thirteen concertos, or about half of Mozart's output, are being heard, and on Thursday night it was the turn of the three 1782 works numbered K. 413, K. 414 and K. 415, as melted down to piano quintet size by the composer.

title: BETHLEHEM SETS RECALL AT MILLS
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second largest steel producer, said yesterday it would resume steelmaking operations next week at its large mills in Johnstown, Pa., and Sparrows Point, Md. As many as 10,000 workers could be recalled, according to industry sources.

title: GALLEY SENTENCE IS CUT TO 20 YEARS FROM LIFE TERM
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga, Aug. 20The life sentence of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was ordered reduced to 20 years today by Lieut. Gen. Albert O. Connor; the commanding general of the Third Army.

title: Scott Meets With Suslov
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 20 (Reuters) The United States Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, met today with Mikhail A. Suslov, the chief Soviet Communist party ideologist, in the Kremlin.

title: Black Nuns Seek Community Rule in Schools
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 20Black Roman Catholic nuns have begun a drive for what has been a goal of blacks outside the church for some time  community control of schools.

title: Waylande Gregory, Sculptor With Work at 39 Fair
description: WARREN TOWNSHIP N. J., Aug. 20 (AP)Waylande Grelgory, well known for innovations in ceramic sculpture, died Wednesday. He was 68 years old.

title: Palafox Gives U.S. a Split In Stevens Cup Tennis
description: The United States and Australia split the first two singles matches in the challenge round of the international senior team tennis competition for the Stevens Cup yesterday at the Town Tennis Club in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Tops Fiji Islands, 21, In Women's Field Hockey
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Aug. 21 (Reuters)The international women's field hockey tournament opened today with England, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and the United States notching firstround victories.

title: COPPER KAHN WINS IN JERSEY SHOW
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 21 A year ago, an aging bay gelding, Copper Khan, wasn't doing much more than taking up space in Ralph J. Caristo's Glen Head, L. I., stable.

title: Layer, Riessen Gain Final
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 21 (Reuters)  Rod Layer, trying to break out of a slump; and Marty Riessen, hottest American in tennis, reached the final of the $50,000 Colonial national professional championships tonight.

title: Peace Corps First in $100,000 Race
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21Officials of Liberty Bell Race Track still thank the bigname trainers and jockeys who come here. After today's $100,000 Hobson Handicap, they probably received a you're welcome in return. The track staged Pennsylvania's first $100,000 race, and it was good one. While Never Bow and Well Mannered wore themselves down dueling for the No. 1 spot, Hobeau Farm's Peace Corps came from back of the pack and won by 11 lengths. He shaved 2 2/5 seconds off the track mark for 1 VI miles.

title: New Economic Policy
description: To the Editor: President Nixon is to be congratulated for finally facing up to the economic crisis in America by adopting the wageprice freeze. May I suggest that New York State would be well advised to do its share to hold the line on consumer prices and seriously consider rolling back the recently increased sales tax in New York City from 7 per cent to 6 per cent. Indeed, since the President's order apparently prevents mandated salary increases to municipal and state employes, the sales tax might be reduced further, all the time aiding the purchasing power of the beleaguered consumer.

title: Fluri Upset in Final
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21 (UPI)Unseeded John Wilkerson of Houston beat topseeded Gene Fluri of St. Louis today, 63, 63, 62, to take the men's singles championship of the American Tennis Association's national tournament.

title: Secretary Fields Well, But Bat Foils Tryout
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug. 21 (UPI)Good field, no hit, is the way the scouts would talk about Jackie Jackson, the 23yearold first basewoman who got a tryout today with the Pittsfield Senators of the Eastern League.

title: Randolphs Have Son
description: NEW VERNON, N.J., Aug. 21A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Franklin A. Randolph on July 20 at Morristown Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Randolph is the former Miss ?? Hoover Hill, daughter of Mrs. H. O. Hansen of New ?? ?? late Dr. Scott Hill.

title: CITY BIDS P.S.C. CUT UTILITIES COSTS
description: The city has urged the state Public Service Commission to use the current national price freeze as an opportunity for cutting operating costs in electric, gas and telephone utilities and for seeking longterm solutions for growing fuel and energy shortages and commmunlcations problems.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
77 HOUSING LOANS HEED IN DEFAULT
description: Seventyseven of the loans under the city's controversial Municipal Loan Program for housing rehabilitation are in default to the extent of $1.4million, City Controller Abraham D. Beame declared yesterday.

title: ALLISON BROTHERS TOP FIELD FOR 500
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 21 (AP)Richard Petty is assured of his first $200,000 season, but there are at least eight other drivers cofavored with him in tomorrow's Talladega 500mile stock car race.

title: D.F.G. ELIOT, SERVED WESTERN ELECTRIC
description: ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 21 Douglas F. G. Eliot, who retired in 1952 as a vice president of the Western Electric Company for purchasing and traffic, died today in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood. He was 84 years old and lived at 10 1Hillside Avenue.

title: Mrs. McCarthy Has Son
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Colman McCarthy Aug. 11 at the Columbia Hospital for Women here. Mrs. McCarthy, whose husband is a member of the editorial page staff of The Washington Post, is the former Miss Mavoureen Maura Deegan of New York. The child will be named Edward.

title: Sample Items From a Political Diary Published by Intellectuals in Soviet Union
PRESIDENT'S MOVE LAUDED IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21President Nixon's decision to greet Emperor Hirohito in Alaska next month was welcomed here today as a gesture designed to take some of the strain out of JapaneseAmerican relations.

title: A's Rout Red Sox, 41
CHINA POLICY STIRS RUFFLE IN OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 21The question of whether there can be a two China policy in the Canadian parliamentary press gallery has produced the first ruffle in Canada's relations with the People's Republic of China.

title: Brooklyn Transit Study Urges changes
description: A study prepared by the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn has made recommendations for sweeping changes in they public transportation system in central Brooklyn.

title: Pamela Lusby, Teacher, Married
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 21Miss Pamela Lusby and Scott Robert Christensen were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Ernest W. Johns, the rector.

title: Jersey Mayor Backs Curb
description: ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 21The president of the New Jersey Conference of Mayors wired President Nixon today voicing approval of the aims and objectives of the President's new financial policies. Mayor Thomas G. Dunn of Elizabeth is president of the conference, which represents most of the 567 mayors in the state. The message was issued from the executive headquarters of the group here.

title: DIKEMAN SCORES IN SHIELDS SLOOP
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 21Roswell C. Dikeman salted his Shields Class sloop, Caveat, to victory in a shifting breeze on Long Island Sound today as a fleet of 106 raced under the auspices of the American Yacht Club in the summer's 28th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta.

title: Although Names Are Ominous, Bloodhounds Are Friendly Doss
description: The bloodhound is scenting king of the dog world. He has the keenest nose of all breeds. His identifications are accepted in a court of law. Despite his ominous name, he is a gentle, friendly animal. Had the bloodhounds caught Eliza fleeing across the ice in Uncle Tom's Cabin, they would have kissed her, for many are trained to identify their quarry in this fashion.

title: Criminals At Large
description: The invasion of privacy theme is relatively new. It is, after all, only within recent years that people have become aware of the network in which they are wrapped from birth to death; and only within even more recent years that it has become a cause for concern. Nowadays even socially insensitive citizens are beginning to worry about the files of the F.B.I., the I.R.S., the Armed Forces and other Governmental agencies.

title: MOORE, GREED TAKE EASTOFRYE SAILS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 21 Harry L. Moore, with the Shields sloop Patience, and James Greed, with Pinot Noir iin tne Soling Class, were winners of 6.5mile races off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today. It was the 31st championship regatta of the season for Yacht Racing Association fleets based east of Rye.

title: The Nation
description: The President made a new economic policy out of all the things we had been saying weren't needed and couldn't work, and ft turned the country around overnight. That wry comment by a high Administration official came after President Nixon startled the world last week by unveiling the most activist program for United States economic revival since Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal nearly 40 years ago.

title: Mauger Triumphs Easily In European Motorcycling
description: WEMBLEY, England, Aug. 21 (AP)  Ivan Mauger, New Zealand's world champion, raced to victory in the European final of the world motorcycle speedway championships today, collecting 14 out of a possible 15 points.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: IDON'T feel any compulsion, as the director of Shaft, to defend the artistic aspects of my film. As a black artist, however, believe it is important to help sharpen our perspectives about the portrayal of black people in motion pictures and Shaft in particular.

title: Education
description: It might have been one of those exercises in ecumenicity, one of those Sunday morning devotionals in the East Room of the White House. There was Richard M. Nixon, Protestant, listening with tacit approval last week as Terence Cardinal Cooke, Roman Catholic, fired every weapon in his sermonic armory at the Supreme Court and at several other targets which Catholics contend impede their efforts to provide for the full education of their children.

title: The Elixir
description: Try to imagine what a fantasist Like Robert Nathan, who can find pixies in Central Park, could originate in Stonehenge. The mind fairly reels  as the author intends it shouldwhilst a vacationing history professor uses the monumental Droidical calendar as the launching pad for a journey through time. Naturally, the professor has the assistance of one of Nathan's standbysa gossamer heroine made out of moonmist and other secret ingredients.

title: When Will They Stage Opera for Its Music?
description: SOME of the new productions done last season by the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan lead me to believe that each company may finally be approaching acceptable styles of opera staging after God knows how many false starts, wrong turns and absolute dead ends. Ironically, the result of these achievements should be a greater emphasis upon the music instead of what passes for theater upon the operatic stageand about time, too. Fashion has dictated otherwise for several seasons, but surely no one can doubt the primacy of music after the electrifying Das Rheingold Georg Solti conducted last April in Carnegie Hallwithout staging, scenery or costumes yet with firstrate soloists and the magnificent Chicago Symphony. It was not only the season's most sensational concert but the operatic peak well.

title: Australia Leads U.S. In Stevens Play, 21
description: Australia took a 21 lead over the United States in the Stevens Cup senior team challenge round yesterday when Bob Howe and Jim Gilchrist defeated Gustavo Palafox and Tony Vincent in the doubles match, 36, 46, 75, 108, 60, at the Town Tennis Club.

title: MAGOON CAPTURES COAST HYDRO RACE
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Aug. 21 (AP)Dr. Bill Magoon, a Miami Beach eye surgeon, led from start to finish today in capturing the 188mile Long Beach Henessey Cup offshore powerboat race.

title: Husky galoot with a golden tongue
description: The attribution of extraordinary intellect, of geniuslevel LQ., to a fictional character, especially a hero, can be hard for a reader to swallow. Either it strains our credulity or it seems to arrogate brains to the writer, which may be accurate but a little too frank. He had better have them. He'd better convince. He'd better make it not matter, perhaps. Give the poor hero some pleasing qualities too.

title: The Need for Fairness
description: After the first wave of excitement set in motion last Sunday by President Nixon's dramatic announcement of his new economic policy, the Administration is buckling down to the difficult task of developing a stabilization program that will work effectively after the present ninetyday freeze on wages, prices and rents.

title: What is believed, taught and confessed; Dom Helder Camara and a 12thcentury representation of the doctrine of the Trinity as affirmed in Constantinople in 381 A.D.; The Emergence of the Catholic Tradition (100600); Vol. I of The Christian Tradition: A History of the Development of Doctrine. By Jaroslav Pelikan. 394 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $15.
description: When you drive out of a city, the contours of the buildings begin to look very different as you get farther away. Edifices that were very imposing at close range may look relatively insignificant from a distance, while other features, at first hardly noticed, begin to stand out clearly and to take on importance. It is much the same with the Christian tradition. Issues and doctrines that once claimed attention may later fade away while other elements in the tradition, hitherto unnoticed, thrust themselves upon us.

title: MRS. KING, MISS DURR REACH TENNIS FINAL
description: LAKE BLUFF, III., Aug. 21 (AP)Top seeded Miss Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., and thirdseeded Francoise Durr of France scored semifinal victories today in the $20,000 Virginia Slims clay court tennis tournament.

title: Per Fredrik Naess Weds Miss Lerner
description: POINT Oapos; WOODS, N.Y., Aug. 21  Miss Christine Lerner was married in this Fire Island community this morning to Per Fredrik Naess, a senior at Trinity College in Hartford. The Rev. Charles WyattBrown performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Point O'Woods Church.

title: MRS. WILLIAM STOKELY
description: NEWPORT, Tenn., Aug. 21Mrs. William B. Stokely, widow of one of the four founders of Stokely Brothers, Inc., the foodprocessing concern, died yesterday. She was in her nineties.

title: Constance Talmage Married to Artist
description: GATLINBURG, Tenn., Aug. 21  The marriage of Miss Constance Thorne Talmage to Stanley Gordon Wetmore Jr., took place here this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church. The Rev. William O. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: The jeaning of America
description: Denim or velvet, plain or decoratedjeans are the current uniform of the young in spirit. They used to be an antifashion statement, but now you can go into shops and buy jeans that have been studded, patched, appliqued or even handpaintedand signed by the artist, of course. Antiestablishment? Sure. But antifashion? Hardly. Jeans have become a fashion in their own right.

title: Art
description: WITH the special intensity of one who grew up in a small town, where cars are a way of life, and one who later moved to the city, where they are a curse, I both love and hate automobiles. Which is one reason I arranged for a ride out to Hempstead the other day to see Art Around the Automobile, a dandy little summer show (set to close later this week) at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery. Well, in general, the exhibition stimulated the part of me that does really like cars, and the experience of getting to and from it confirmed the other part of me that often wishes they would all just

title: Pneumatic Tubes To Carry Refuse In Disposal Test

title: Bettina Fuchs, F. J. McCarthy Wed in Suburb

Fuchs, to Frank Johnson McCarthy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julien Binford McCarthy. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Gregg, assisted by the Rev. Edward T, Adkins.

title: Bede Scully, ExChaplain Of Catholic War Veterans
description: The Rev. Bede Scully, a Capuchin priest and resident chaplain at the Wassaic (N.Y.) State School, who was a former national chaplain of the Catholic War Veterans, died Thursday of a heart attack in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. His age was 64.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The description of life in Gloucestershire given by Robert G. Deindorfer in the article about buying a cottage in Lower Slaughter (Travel section, Aug. 1) is reminiscent of every city, town and village in England. I found the same 19thcentury attitudes and life styles that exist in his West Country village during the 20 months I spent in the Midlands. The quaintness momentarily overtakes you, but I urge Mr. and Mrs. Deindorfer to spend the cold, unyieldingly damp months of winter in their mellow stone abode. I not only urge, I dare them. Have you ever tried keeping warm with one fireplace (it heats only one room, you know)? Try taking a bath (showers are nonexistent) in 40 or 50degree temperatures. You won't take, many, especially with the wintry winds that blow through the upper tubdrainfor all the water pipes climb like snakes up the exterior walls. Naturally, the water may sometimes freeze up, compelling you to lean out the frostladen window and pour hot water over the pipes in the hopes of thawing them out.

title: Izod Golf to Begin Nov. 14
description: HILTON HEAD, S. C., Aug. 21 (UPI)The fourth annual Izod international invitation golf tournament has been scheduled for Nov. 14 to 20, at the New Palmetto Dunes Country Club. The event will bring together the 37 champions of the Professional Golfers Association sections for $10,000 purse.

title: New Brooklyn Poly Head Undaunted by Problems
description: The new president of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute hopes to build the best institute in the nation, one that will provide students with as good an education as they can get, and one that will also provide stimulating environment for the faculty.

title: KELLY'S YACHT WINS IN LASER CLASS SAIL

title: AROUND THE
description: Keep up with lawn chores. If a new one has been seeded, keep it moist until germination.... Plant colchicums.... Dry strawflowers and herbs; ,cut them in the morning.... title: 5 RADICAL PRIESTS STIR CONTROVERSY
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 21The recent disclosure of forged documents presumably used in the ordination of five members of, a group of priests called the Contemporary Mission has brought to a head the summerlong dispute here between the priests and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Louis.

title: MINING OF TRIAL MAY HELP ALIOTO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21The Washington State Supreme Court granted a request this week to move the trial of a damage suit from Seattle to Vancouver, Wash., and thereby may have given Joseph L. Alioto a lift in his campaign for reelection as mayor of San Francisco.

title: Bridge When your head's on the block, use it

If you seem headed for a sticky end do not submit tamely. Do something violent and unexpected, and you may escape the block.

title: The Soledad Story Opened in Death
description: In January, 1970, a fight broke out in a prison yard at the Soledad Correctional Training Facility, a state prison in California's lush Salinas Valley. Trying to quell the disturbance, a white guard shot and killed three inmates, all black.

description: For Harold L. Strauss, the newly elected president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce, the focus of his efforts for the next year will be on transportation, transportation and transportation.

title: Drama Mailbag

Its theme is noble and its intentions exalted, but these are expressed without skill, penetration or wit.

title: For Young Readers
description: At the age of 11 Olaudah Equiano was kidnapped from his family in Benin and tossed onto a slave ship bound for America. He passed from a Virginia planter to a British naval officer and then to a Philadelphia merchant operating in the West Indies from whom he was able to buy his freedom at 21. In 1789 he published an autobiography, which is among our earliest slave narratives. It is also one of the most important, offering a rare picture of an 18thcentury African childhood as well as a bondsman's daily round in the Caribbean.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I fully appreciate the feelings expressed about air fares to the West Coast  because our children live in California. Recently I wrote letters about the air fare question to the Civil Aeronautics Board and the three major airlines flying to the West Coast. The C.A.B.'s reply leads me to the conclusion that it is up to the airlines to offer attractive fares. The airlines apparently are willing to fly a regular service with almost empty planes; this will. change as soon. as their shareholders and/or directors make some urgently, needed changes in personnel. OtherWise I believe the day will come when the domestic, airlines will belong to the Government or cease to exist, as we have seen recently with the American steamship lines crossing the Atlantic with passengers. It is sad, but some people will only learn the hard way. If Mrs. Friedman indeed. forms a group; as proposed, we shall be glad to join.

title: LETTERS

description: A good way to learn to speak a foreign language is to imitate the way a foreign speaker speaks English. title: NO RANCOR

At the screening I attended, in the large TransLux West Theater, the packedin audience, about 90 per cent black, loved every minute of the film, cheering Shaft on in his adventures and heartily booing when he took on a white girlfriend. But there was no racial rancor in this enthusiasm or in the movie itselfand it is this, unfortunately, that Riley seems to regret.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21Before a record crowd of 30,011, William Levin's Bold Reason won the 102d running of the Travers today.

I., Aug. 21A comprehensive plan for the movement of all petroleum products onto and through Long Island  resolving the problems of oil spillage, safety hazards and transportationhas been stymied for almost two years by local community opposition. description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Aug. 21The art of making Chinese won ton soup and dancing to Indian drums or Irish bagpipes flavored this town's first major heritage fair this week at the Heckscher Ball Park off Route 25A.

title: The Galbraith Plan
description: ONE of the plain lessons of the last 20 years is that where equality for blacks, other minorities and those so treated is concerned, good intentions are not enough. Nor is a serious commitment to reform which fails to specify the exact change to be achieved. Nor is any measure which does not have the force of law. Twenty years ago, most Americans, including many Southerners, accepted the principle of equality in educational opportunity and believed school segregation should some day be brought to an end. And most affirmed the right of all citizens (all literate citizens, in any case) to votesometime. And most believed that discrimination in access to restaurants, hotels and other public facilities should some day be ended. There was no lack of speeches affirming these goals. Nothing happened, however, until exact requirements were specified, and timetables for compliance were laid down, and those that did not comply were made subject to the force law. been taken, Southern schools and public facilities would still be wholly segregated and black voters south of the MasonDixon Line would still be few and courageous.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ECONOMIC INDICATORS: Private housing starts set record in July when residential building units reached an annual rate of 2,218,000 dwelling units, 10 per cent above the June rate and 38 per cent higher than July, 1970... Industrial production declined 0.8 per cent in July to an index level of 106.0, compared with 106.9 in June and 107.0 in May.... Personal income dropped $11billion in July to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $859billion, following an unusually high June figure that resulted from onetime retroactive Social Security payment totaling $13.25billion.... Second quarter G.N.P. was $1,04I.3billion, $800million more than July's preliminary figures.... Corporate profits in the second quarter rose $3billion to $82billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate.... New orders for durable goods rose 3.5 per cent in July to $31.7billion, but shipments declined 1.7 per cent to $32.1billion.

title: Study Finds Westchester Zoning Laws in Jeopardy

Davis of Cazenovia, N. Y. Msgr. Martin J. McDonough performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church.

This, of course, goes far beyond the ninetyday freeze on privatesector wages and prices.

title: RESPECT
Albright Names Mat Coach
description: Harry G. (Pepper) Humphreys, formerly of Sykesville, Md., and an Albright alumnus, has been appointed head wrestling coach at Albright College for the 197172 season. A 1960 graduate of Albright with the bachelor of science degree in mathematics, he was a member of the varsity wrestling team as an undergraduate.

title: Garelik's Proposal Seeks to Improve Safety in Subways
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik called yesterday for five measures to avert subway disasters and breakdowns such as the one last Wednesday in which 6,000 riders were trapped on three IND trains under the East River.

title: Informers on Underworld Get New Life From U.S.
description: A number of informers who fear reprisals for their testimony against the underworld have been given new names, new homes and new jobs by the Federal Government.

title: Yale Post to Mrs. Barnett
description: Mrs. Joni Barnett, a member of the Yale athletic staff for the last two years, has been named director of physical education for women. Mrs. Barnett has worked with the girls synchronized swimming club at Yale for the last two years and will continue to do so. She replaces Martha Aly, who resigned recently.

title: Frances Kennaugh Wed
description: TAOS, N. M., Aug. 21Miss Frances Mann Kennaugh was married here this morning to John Robert Speirs in St. James Episcopal Church. Canon Albert J. duBois performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of the Rev, and Mrs. Robert Q. Kennaugh of Taos and Corsicana, Tex. Her father, an Episcopal priest, assisted in the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Speirs of Scarsdale, N. Y. Mr. Speirs is executive vice president of the Lennen & Newell advertising agency in New York, where the bridegroom is with the William Esty advertising agency.

title: The Last Word: H. Bustos Domecq on Automation
description: The nuclear age, the curtaindrop on colonialism, the rise of the militaryindustrial complex, the challenge of the left, the zoom in the cost of living and concomitant shrinking the pay envelope, the Papal call to peace, the threat of the devaluation of the dollar, the spread of sitdown strikes, the proliferation of supermarkets, the conquest of space, the population shift from rural life to city slums, the passing of rubber checksall these spell quite an alarming panorama and, when you come right down to it, give the man of the seventies food for thought. But the diagnosis of evils is one thing, the remedy another. Without wishing to venture in prophecy, we nonetheless make bold to suggest that the recent importation of Idlers into the Argentine Republic with a view to their ultimate manufacture here, mayin acting as a form of sedativegreatly contribute to the lessening of tensions so widespread in the nation today. The supremacy of the Machine is a fact no one any longer disputes; the Idler, it turns out, is but one more step in this inevitable process.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Re the article about dune buggies (Travel section, July 11):

title: Coins
description: JOHN JAY PITTMAN of Rochester was officially inducted as president of the American Numismatic Association at that organi zation's 80th anniversary convention in the WashingtonHilton. Mr. Pittman succeeds Herbert M. Bergen of Fullerton, Calif.

title: PATTERSON GAINS 10ROUND VERDICT
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 22 (UPI)Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion won a unanimous 10round decision over Vic Brown tonight for the sixth consecutive triumph in his latest comeback effort.

title: South Ozone Park to Push Fight Against Renewal Despite a Loss
description: Angry homeowners from South Ozone Park, after a firstround defeat at City Hall last week, have promised to continue their fight against a proRimed city urban renewal plan in their community.

title: 1 KILLED, 2 SHOT IN CAMDEN RIOTS
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 21This riottorn Delaware River city was calm today as officials sought ways of averting a repetition of two nights of rockthrowing, looting, firebombing and sporadic gunfire by Puerto Ricans angered over alleged police brutality.

title: U.S. EDGES BRITAIN FOR A RIFLE TROPHY
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP)The United States rifle team staved off a rally by Britain, the defending champion, in the 1,000yard matches today to capture the Palma Trophy match in the National Rifle Association competition.

title: Art
description: WHEN I began to try to paint only what I saw in front of me, I felt lonely among New York artists. Of course, I was not the only realist on the scene in 1960, and since then a rather large number of realist painters have come alohg. But it must be emphasized that each artist paints his own idea of realism, and the differences among the kinds of realists are as great as among the kinds of abstractionists. I still feel very much alone with kind of realism.

title: Upgrading of Airport in Flushing Is Urged
description: A confidential study prepared for the city Department of Marine and Aviation calls for an $11million upgrading of Flushing Airport, the only facility within the city devoted exclusively to private and business aircraft.

title: Innis, Back From Africa, Asks Aid for Black Interests There
description: Roy Innis, director of the Congress of Racial Equality, yesterday urged massive black American support for black African interests, including a Washington lobby, trade agreements, domestic assistance and arms.

title: LAPOINT IS FIRST IN SLALOM EVENT
description: DELAWARE, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP)Kris LaPoint, of Castro Valley, Calif., outclassed a field of 34 of the nation's top slalom skiers today to win the men's title at the national water skiing championships on White Sulphur Lake near here.

title: U.S. is Urged by Quakers To Drop '2 China Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.The American Friends Service Committee said tonight that, with President Nixon going to Peking, the United States should drop its two China plan, vote to seat China unconditionally in the United Nations and withdraw military support from Taiwan.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Let no one expect to make his fortune  or his reputationby selling America short.

title: Cuban Pilot Who Flew MIG17 Here in 1969 Is Acquitted of Marijuana Possession Charge
description: Charges of possessing marijuana, filed against a man who in 1969 flew a Sovietbuilt jet from Cuba to the United States, were dismissed yesterday by Criminal Court Judge Nicholas E. Delagi on the ground that the police search was illegal.

title: When the Big Blue Crabs Are Running, Everything Stops In Maryland
description: CRISFIELD, Md.The big blue crabs are in season along Maryland's Eastern Shore and when the blues are running, virtually everyone tosses aside all responsibilities and heads for the Chesapeake. Nothing. but nothingis more important than crabbing hereabout when the big blues are in season.

title: SOLEDAD BROTHER AND 5 ARE KILLED IN PRISON BATTLE
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 21Three inmates and three guards were killed here this, afternoon as George Jackson, one of the Soledad Brothers, attempted to escape from this maximumsecurity prison.

title: Jeanette Rynne Bride Of Michael M. deRham
description: TUXEDO. PARK, N. Y., Aug. 21  Miss Jeanette Marie Rynne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rynni, was married here this afternoon to Michael Meredith deRham, son of Frederic Foster deRham of Casey Key, Fla., and Mrs. Blagden deRham of Tuxedo Park.

title: Miss Whitney Read McKendree Wed to Barry Gardner Moore
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 21The Round Hill Community Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Whitney Read McKendree, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Gillett McKendree, to Barry Gardner Moore, son of Mrs. Edward Brooks Moore of Barrington, R.I., and the late Mr. Moore.

title: VIKINGS VICTORS OVER BEARS, 3414.
MADISON AVE.
description: The television commercial is the most intrusive form of sell ever invented. It's doortodoor selling with a key to the front door. Most of what comes on that screen is watched  and heeded  by every member of the family right down to the toddler who twiddles the knobs and makes blizzards of the picture.

title: City Finds Illegal Lead Content In 13 Brands of Interior Paints
description: Health Department tests have found excessive lead content in samples of 13 brands of paint intended for interior use, the city's Health Services Administration announced yesterday.

title: Jersey Mayor Retracts Invitation to Cuba Nine
description: BRIDGETON, N. J., Aug. 21 (AP)Mayor Bertram R. B. Aitken said today he had withdrawn an invitation to Cuban baseball team to play here until the United States establishes diplomatic relations with Cuba.

title: MISSISSIPPI PRISON IN U.S. CRUELTY SUIT
description: GREENVILLE, Miss., Aug. 20 The United States Justice Department has joined civil rights attorneys in a Federal suit against officials of Parchman, the Mississippi State Penitentiary.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Since impoverished, landlocked Bolivia won independence from Spain in 1825, the Latin American nation has endured more than 180 uprisings against the 150 governments that have ruled the country.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The United States must soon face the fact that it is living on its research and development capital and the account is beginning to run low. If we fail to acknowledge this, our technological affluence will be lost.

title: 11 CANDIDATES VIE IN CLEVELAND RACE
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 21There are more mayoral candidates this year in Cleveland than there are beer cans floating in Lake Erie. At least, it seems that way.

title: BRITISH WILL HOLD INQUIRY ON ULSTER
description: LONDON, Aug. 21The British Government today announced an inquiry into allegations of brutality by troops in Northern Ireland.

title: Killing of 9 Police Here Nears Record
description: More New York policemen were slain in the line of duty in 1930 than in any other year in the history of the department but if present trends continue, 1971 could become the most deadly year ever.

title: Deputy Hanover Wins Pace
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 21Deputy Hanover, driven by Eldon Harner, won the $10,000 Asbury Park Pace today before a crowd of 11,000 at Freehold Raceway. Deputy Hanover paid $9.80, $5.80 and $3.60 for $2 across the board.

title: Meany Calls a Meeting Of Lawyers for Unions
description: WASHINGTON, Aug., 21Labor union attorneys from across the nation were summoned today to meet in Washington next Thursday to discuss what legal actions might be taken to thwart the Nixon Administration's freeze on wage increases.

title: Rangers Stars Operate Hockey School for Boys
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Aug. 21It was graduation day on a recent morning, and the youngsters wore their freshly laundered uniforms and shiny skates. They sweated nervously. Their proud parents were even more tense.

title: Alan King to Receive A B'nai B'rith Award
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 21Alan King, the comedian, will be awarded the Citizen of the Year Award on Sept. 22 by the B'nai B'rith chapter here.

title: VANHAGENCAPTURES SHIELDS CLASS RACE
Excerpts From Democrats Statement on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Following are excerpts from a statement by the Democratic National Committee on President Nixon's new economic policy, printed today as a special report in the party's biweekly newsletter, Fact:

title: Lutheran Leader Elected
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21 (AP) Mrs. Dorothy K. Van Loo of Menasha, Wis., has been elected president of the Lutheran Church Women, the 260,000member auxiliary of the Lutheran Church of America. Mrs. Van Loo, who succeeds Mrs. Bernard Spong of New York City, was elected Tuesday at the group's triennial convention here.

title: Grandmother Retains Title in Pocket Billiards
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP)Mrs. Dorothy Wise of San Francisco captured her fifth straight United States open pocket billiards championship today by defeating Mrs. Geraldine Litcomb of Cincinnati, 75 to 37, in 29 innings.

title: Propriety of Space Shuttle Contract Is Questioned
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The first hint of scandal is beginning to touch the space agency's multibilliondollar space shuttle program, which is at least five years away from blastoff.

title: New Economic Policy
description: To the Editor: Your continuous advocacy of some form of pricewage controls, which have now been officially adopted by the President, strikes me as shortsighted.

title: JAMES E. M'NAMARA
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 21  James E. McNamara, vice president of the Scientific Aetna Corporation of New York, photoengravers, and a former vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the advertising agency, died Thursday of an internal hemorrhage in White Plains Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 4 Barnaby Lane.

title: Jane B. Wigglesworth Is Married
description: MANCHESTER, Mass., Aug. 21Miss Jane Booth Wigglesworth and William Joseph Lescure 3d were married here this afternoon in Emmanuel Episcopal Church by the Rev. Rollin Fairbanks. He was assisted by the Rev. Daniel Randall Magruder.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Music
description: LENOX, Mass. FOR the first time in some years, the Berkshire Music Center at Tanglewood has an opera department again. Called the Music Theater Project, it is modestly budgeted, housed in the West Barn, a problematic but apparently stimulating structure, and its work is carried on under the direction of Ian Strasfogel by 20 holders of National Opera Institute fellowships, nine of them singers, the others on the technical and dramatic staff.

title: Soviet Finds Turtles Back From Space More Active
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 21 (UPI)Turtles fired into space in medical experiment came back thinner but more active and hungry, a Soviet scientist said this week.

title: Kenzo Matsumura Dead at 87; Led Japanese Mission to Peking
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21 (UPI)Kenzo Matsumura, the politician who mapped the revival of Japan's trade with Communist China, died today. He was 87 years old.

title: New Economic Policy
description: To the Editor: Mr. Nixon's new economic policy is neither new nor politic. At best, it's a shortterm emergency treatment. At worst, it ignores the basic problem that's at the root of inflation, unemployment and dollar devaluation.

title: Cost Controls Backed
description: If the nation's utilities really wanted to hold down their rates, they would keep close tab on their construction costs. Then, if they were really interested in keeping down such costs, they should look to cost specialists.

title: Mark Lane and 8 Arrested For Westmoreland Protest
description: BOISE, Idaho, Aug. 21 (UPI) Mark Lane, the author, and eight other persons were arrested on charges of disturbing the peace yesterday for staging a noisy antiwar protest at a motel where Gen. William Westmoreland was speaking. Those arrested included three Air Force men and four women.

title: Park Is Closed to Cars On Wednesday Nights
description: Parks Administrator August Heckscher has closed Prospect Park in Brooklyn to vehicular traffic on Wednesday evenings from 7:30 P.M. to 10 P.M. through Sept, 1 to allow bicyclists and strolers more opportunities to fully enjoy the park.

title: Urgent subjects, passionate author
description: In Brazil a child dies every 42 seconds; 85 die every hour; 2,040 children die every day. Yet the United States spends less than 1 per cent, the minimum requested by the United Nations, of its gross national product to diminish this rate of dying in aid to all of the Third World nations, including Brazil. At the same time, largely because of the miserable prices imposed on raw materials imported from countries like Brazil, the capital we gain from them is about twice the capital we invest. No wonder we still call Brazil a Good Neighbor.

title: Falcons Topple Broncos
The Nation
description: It all seems like an exercise In futility, said one observer last Friday as the courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina ended its first week. More than 20 former soldiers from the captain's Charlie Company had marched to the witness stand in the tiny courtroom at Fort McPherson in Atlanta to recount the slaughter of unresisting Vietnamese civilians at Mylai 4 on March 16, 1968. What they related was a replay of the testimony they had given at the courtmartial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. at Fort Benning last winter. It again implicated Colley deeply. But it implicated Captain Medina hardly at all.

title: The Berlin Indictment
description: This German novel about a military scandal is low in the suspense vital to the fiction of intrigue but is interesting nonetheless for the samplings it takes of the West German social climate.

title: President of the A.K.C. Given Leave of Absence
description: Alfred M. Dick, the president of the American Kennel Club since March, 1968, has requested a leave of absence for the remainder of his term, which expires on March 14, 1972. The leave has been granted by the board of directors.

title: Off track Unit Signs Seven New Leases For Betting Shops
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation signed seven new leases for betting shops last week, lifting the total to 47. Eighteen sites are operative.

title: Recordings
description: No line is more difficult to draw than the one separating noise and music. (Not that we aren't faced every day with similar puzzles: at what point does a smirk become a smile, or a man's knapsack a purse?) Nowadays, music seems to raise such borderline issues with increasing urgency, and not only in pieces that exploit computers and other electronic machinery. Penderecki's Utrenja, The Entombment of Christ, which RCA has issued in a splendid performance by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy, uses only the most traditional soundmaking devices: chorus (the Temple University Choirs), vocal soloists (Stefania Woytowicz, Kerstin Meyer, Seth McCoy, Bernard Ladysz and Peter Lagger), and ordinary orchestral instruments. Penderecki once told this writer that the traditional orchestra was on the way out, but he regretted it and wished to hurry to write for it while the great instrument still existed.

title: Oh, Give Me a Home Where the Tennis Buffs Roam And the Shrinks and Sinologists Play
description: Where in the world are all your people this summer? At least three times in the last several years you have dispatched staff men to Outer Cape Cod to recount how psychiatrists spend their traditional August holidays in Provincetown, in Wellfleet, and, particularly, in Truro, where I am now rusticating in reasonably good mental health. know where the author of one of those exposes, Robert Clurman, is at the moment: Instead of writing about psychiatrists, he is playing tennis on my court. The odd thing is that he is playing by himself. He serves a bunch of balls from one end, strides briskly around the net, and serves them back, all the while muttering to himself what sounds from my bugeyed observation post like Oh, hacker! Do he

title: Keeping Up With Housing
description: SAN DIEGORobert H. Walter is an energetic and determined 53yearold builder who in 1962 set out to carve himself a large chunk of the housing market.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In discussing the relative sluggishness in the business recovery, Thomas E. Mullaney (July 25) noted that public expenditures have not kept pace with the potential that might normally be induced by sharply increased incomes.

title: Aaron Passes Cobb
IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIt will be disappointing to many Americans that Duong Van (Big) Minh has withdrawn from the South Vietnamese presidential campaign. On the face of it, his stand for peace and reconciliation seemed to offer more hope than President Thieu's hardline position against any, concessions to end the war.

title: Don't Give My Regards To Broadway
description: LIKE any other actor, I wanted a Tony award ana my picture in Sardi's. I don't know when I got over that, or if I really have. I do know that the process of getting there, and what I saw of life at the top, forced me out of New York and into a more exciting life than I could have imagined.

title: Miss Wade Wins to Give Britain 11 Tie With U.S. in Wightman Cup Tennis
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 21 (UPI)  Virginia Wade of England used her booming serve today to beat Julie Heldman of New York, 75, 75, after young Chris Evert defeated Winnie Shaw of Scotland, 60, 64, as the United States and Britain divided the first two singles matches in the 43d annual Wightman Cup tennis competition.

title: NixonHirohito Meeting
description: The announcement that President Nixon will fly Anchorage, Alaska, next month to greet Emperor Hirohito and his wife is welcome news. As Mr. Nixon said in his statement, the meeting will be a means demonstrating that fundamental respect and friendship which forms the basis of the relationship between our two countries.

title: Television
description: A PRESS release from an outfit called Pier V Productions, Inc., announces plans for the television taping of Protect Yourself, a series of programs designed to teach viewers how to defend themselves against any and all kinds of physical attack and armed assault. Perhaps, the thought occurs, one segment could be designed to teach television critics how to defend themselves against press releases.

title: POSTING DELAYED ON OCTANE RATING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Gasoline refiners and marketers have won an indefinite delay in the promulgation of a Federal regulation requiring octane ratings to be posted on pumps in gasoline stations.

title: Eileen M'Carty Is Bride on L.I. Of James Rubin
description: CEDARHURST, L. I., Aug. 21Miss Eileen Marie McCarty, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. McCarty of New York and Woodmere, was married here this afternoon to James Anthony Rubin, son of Mrs. Robert H. Rubin of New York and the late Mr. Rubin.

title: Scottish Terrier Best
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Aug. 21Ch. Gaidoune George W. Bear, Scottish terrier, owned by Helen B. Gaithers, took top honors today at the 28th annual Finger Lakes Kennel Club show at Cornell University. It was the third best for the Scotty and the 10th Terrier Group award.

title: Again It's Town Hall TonightMaybe Every Night
