description: A YEAR ago, hardly anyone in the music business thought Town Hall had any future as a concert hall of consequence in New York. In the 14 years it has been owned by New York University, it fell into sad estate, abandoned by the great names in music who had once made it a mecca for the finest in recitals and chamber music, disdained by debutants in search of a prestigious setting for their introduction to the New York musical

title: Boston U. Names Thomas
description: BOSTON, Aug. 21 (AP)Kevin Thomas, one of Boston University's best basketball players, was names may as head coach of the Terriers freshman team.

title: CanAm Race in Ohio Will Be on TV Today
description: Today's CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup race at Lexington, Ohio, will be carried on nationwide television, live on most stations and taped for delayed broadcast on stations with previous commitments.

title: U.S. WEIGHS POLICY ON EXPROPRIATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The State and Treasury Departments are reported to be divided over United States policy toward foreign countries that expropriate private American holdings.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Anthony Mancini's account of his pilgrimage to the birthplace of his father in Italy (Ethnic Travel, Travel section, Aug. 1) was delightful reading but erroneous in a small, aggravating detail. The region is Abruzzi, not Abruzzo. The comprehensive fivevolume Times (of London) Atlas of the World clearly labels the region Abruzzi. Moreover, Dennis Mack Smith, a Fellow of the Royal Historical Society and an authority on Italian history, deals with the Abazzi region in his history of Italy, published by the University of Michigan. I, also, am the son of an Italian, and the error questioned not simply the accuracy of AngloSaxon sources but also of my father who, when I was a child, often recited to me a Limerick that went:

title: Water Director Defended
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 21An aide to Governor Reagan defended today the state water resources director, William Gianelli, against criticism by the Nader panel. He also criticized the release of the study group's report on the state water project without first making copies available to the Reagan Administration.

title: Clark T. Foster, an Officer Of Johnson &
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 21Clark T. Foster, vicepresident and a director of Johnson & Higgins, New York insurance brokers, died today of cancer in Hackensack Hospital. He was 50 years old and lived at 133 Lawrence Road, Mahwah.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Meanwhile, the market's technical analysts were pondering the implications of a gap in the market averages created by Monday's explosive runaway in stock prices.

title: Reader's Report
description: I missed Edita Morris's PeterPannish story of childhood in Sweden when it was first published in 1943 (I was traveling abroad at the time). So it is pleasant surprise to come upon this revised version.

title: OBSERVER
description: NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 21It was summer. August. Wet, dank, mossy, steamy, burnedup, crabgrassy August, the month when every psychiatrist in America closes his couch and vacations. And everybody else, if the evidence here can be believed. Accountants, prizefight promoters, television cameramen, student radicals, customs inspectors...

title: MERCHANTS TO ASK MORE PROTECTION
description: Merchants on Church Avenue in East Flatbush, outraged and fearful after the apparently senseless murder Friday of luncheonette owner and the wounding of his wife, are planning to meet this week to demand better protection for their changing neighborhood.

title: Giacomin and Villemure Accept Ranger Terms
description: Goalies Ed Giacomin and Gilles Villemure, winners of the Vezina Trophy last season, have agreed to terms with the New York Rangers for the 197172 season.

title: Stamps
description: FOUR design unveiling ceremonies were staged in as many cities on Aug. 6 of the four Historic Preservation stamps that will be issued October 29 at San Diego, Calif., during the conference of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.

title: NADER UNIT FINDS COAST LAND ABUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21A Ralph Nader study group charged today that a massive interlocking economic and political power structure governs California's land and water resources and threatens to plunder the state of its basic wealth.

title: In the Fields of Normandy Horses Are Human Beings
description: SAINT GERMAIN LE VIEUX, France, Aug. 21 Bernard Grignola, the selfappointed Jimmy Cruise of France, leans against a fence on his 200acre farm here in the heart of the bluegrass country of Normandy, looks out on a pasture where several of his trotters are grazing alongside lazy cows, and dreams.

title: A Survey of Youths Puts Lindsay in Front of Nixon
description: NORTHFIELD, Ill. Aug. 21A national political survey of topranking high school graduates, conducted in June by the Merit Publishing Company, showed that Mayor Lindsay of New York would get 46 per cent of their vote if he ran against President Nixon in 1972. Mr. Nixon would receive 36 per cent, the survey showed.

title: TWINS SET BACK BY ORIOLES, 4 TO
Speedy Zephyr and Barbizon Streak Are Victors in Divided Ventnor Handicap
13YEAROLD WINS IN TRAPSHOOTING
description: VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 21 (AP)A 13yearold boy from Grosse Point Farms, Mich., Danny Craite, won the President's Cup today on the second preliminary day of the 72d annual Grand American Trapshooting Tournament.

title: Pilot Lands His Plane On Palisades Parkway
description: NEW CITY, N.Y., Aug. 21 Max Corvington of 36A Mile Road, Suffern, a 33yearold student pilot, landed a light plane on the Palisades Interstate Parkway in heavy northbound traffic a mile south of here at 11 A.M. today, without injury or damage to the plane or passing cars.

title: Memory Lane Pays $7.60
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Aug. 21 (AP)  Warren Vedilago guided Memory Lane to his secand straight victory today in the $2,200 feature at Finger Lakes Race Track.

title: GRENADES KILL 10 AT MANILA RALLY
description: MANILA, Aug. 21Terrorists hurled explosives at a rally of the opposition Liberal party tonight, killnig 10 persons and wounding 66. Among the wounded were all eight of the party's senatorial candidates in the November elections, in which they are scheduled to face the candidates of President Ferdinand Marcos Nationalist party.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Here on the premises of what may be the oldest hardware supply house in New York at Second Avenue and 53rd Street, there exists below a damp basement, a cold spring foaming and churning.

title: Errant Walk Draws Fine
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 21 (AP)Charlie Metro, Kansas City Royals scout, was fined a $25 today on charges of disorderly conduct and jaywalking. He was cited yesterday morning after the police said he stepped] into traffic and nearly caused! an accident. The police also said he used profane language.

title: 3 Children Die in Fire
description: INKSTER, Mich., Aug. 21 (AP) Three children were killed and a fourth burned critically today in a fire at their home in this Detroit suburb. A baby sitter escaped with minor burns. Killed were Stacy Bonham, 8 years old, and his sisters, Carla, 3, and Faith, I. Their 6yearold sister Stephanie was hospitallzed.

title: From All About Eve To All About Anne
Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Having read The Times of July 25 cover to cover concerning largely crime, violence, murder, etc., etc., and then the two contrasting articles on Newark and Greece in the Magazine, you have sold me on buying a oneway ticket to Athens.

title: Ky Again Delays Decision On Whether to Campaign
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 22  Vice President Nguyen Coo Ky, who is now officially on the presidential ballot, attacked President Nguyen Van Thieu today for scheming to retain power but said he had not decided whether to campaign actively against Mr. Mien.

title: Recordings
description: ELTON JOHN is small, plump and talkative, and he lives with a friend and 30 pairs of boots, nine floors up in a monstrous complex of apartment blocks, not far from Hyde Park. He is domestic by nature and spends much of his spare time in cleaning up, tidying and polishing. Whenever he feels especially depressed, he calms himself on the ironing hoard: It takes my mind off things; then I can begin again.

title: On Taxes: Skepticism
description: While the general reaction to the tax proposals in the President's program to spur economic revival is that they sould be good for business, the men whose business is taxes are not sure the package will turn out to be quite as attractive once the contents are examined closely.

title: Detergent Solution Used in Baby Baths Viewed as a Peril
description: Hexachlorophene, a common ingredient in many germicidal products recommended for the bathing of infants, can be absorbed through the child's skin in quantities approaching potentially toxic levels, a team of doctor's and pesticide researchers has found.

title: FreshPicked Corn One of L.l.'s Joys
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. Lo Aug. 21In this land of green lawns and twolane blacktop driveways, there are few things as predictable as a barbecue. And devotees of the outdoors all over Long Island wouldn't consider a summer dinner complete without a large supply of fresh sweet corn.

title: Mansfield Voices Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 (AP) The South Vietnamese presidential election is shaping up as a farce that will result in new Congressional efforts to slash aid to that country, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today.

title: But Love Story Was 42 Years Ago...
description: THE blades of my chopper whipped white dust into spuming frenzy on remote Tibetan mountainside. When at last there was silence, and the snow settled back onto itself exhausted, I spotted hima furcoated figure hunched into a snowdrift, his pate gleaming in the Himalayan sun. And now Associate Professor of Classics and Comparative Literature groaned until the whole mountain shook.

title: Surfing Said to Be Losing Popularity
description: AMITYVILLE, EL, Aug. 21 The surf pounds at Gilgo Beach as hard as it did in 1968, the height of the surfing boom on Long Island, but only a handful of the faithful still ride that surf.

title: QUEENS TO RETAIN ITS TRAFFIC UNIT
description: A special 146 man police traffic unit in Queens has won a reprieve from disbandment because the Police Department has convinced the city that it's a moneysaving force.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE country was moving again. That much seemed certain. The belief alone probably was enough power the biggest twoday rally in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. After the President's dramatic Sunday night television announcement of a new economic policy, the stock market advanced the next day 32.93 points, as measured by the DowJones industrial average, with 31.73 million shares changing hands.

title: H.U.D. Citing Court Ruling's Denies Parochial School Aid
description: PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 21 (AP)  The Department of Housing and Urban Development has barred the use of $155,000 in Federal funds for three parochial school programs, Portland Model Cities officials reported this week.

title: Monetary Uncertainty
description: PARISWider fluctuations in currency values, the gradual movement of the world into three or four currency blocs, perhaps later some new internationally agreedupon standard for monetary values and slower growth in world trade.

title: Huntington's Incinerator Topic of State Hearings
description: RONKONKOMA, L.I., Aug. 21  The Huntington town incinerator, with its three brick stacks, is hidden among hills and tall trees in East Newport, near farms, an orchard and housing development with large green Yawns.

title: Royals Down Senators
Stamps
description: THE third of Canada's 1971 stamps for the seasons will be released September 3 the Maple Leaf in Autumn.

title: BROOKLYN SALESMAN IS SLAIN BY WOMAN
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn salesman was fatally shot late yesterday afternoon while at work in Kerner's Variety Store at 882 DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant section.

title: Israel Devalues by 20% And Plans Price Controls
description: JERUSALEM, Sunday, Aug. 22Israel devalued her currency by 20 per cent today in an attempt to keep the recent United States economic measures from widening her already massive trade deficit.

title: Packers Halt Dolphins, 107
WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: There will be only a ripple in the flow of textile and apparel products from abroad as a result of the President's imposition of a 10 per cent surcharge on imports, according to Alfred Flug, a large importer of children's dresses and sportswear. With a higher duty there must inevitably be a price increase on the imported products but it will not be of such proportions as to destroy the demand.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Paul Samuelson ought to be ashamed of himself. A Nobel Prize winner writes in The New York Times what he wouldn't dream of putting into his own elementary textbook.

title: Chiefs Win, 277
Mrs. Staple Has Sort
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Staple of New York and Deal, N.J., on Aug. 1 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Staple is the former Miss Nanci Klein, daughter of Mrs. Arthur G. Klein and the late State Supreme Court Justice Klein.

title: Cambodia Reoccupies Base
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 21 (AP)The Cambodian high command said today that Government troops yesterday reoccupied a major enemy base at Peaglong, 20 miles west of Pnompenh, after intensive bombing and strafing by allied warplanes. A spokesman said that there were no reports of casualties on either side.

title: City Gives Plastic Industry Guidelines on Container Tax
description: New York City's Finance Administrator, Richard Lewisohn, said yesterday that he had issued guidelines to the plastic industry on compliance with the city's new container tax.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Herman Hickman coached the Yale football team against Harvard for the first time, he was so awed by the grandeur, of it all that he delivered the strangest pregame pep talk in the history of this ancient classic. He recited in full the classic address of Spartacus to the Gladiators.

title: Jaehne Army Golf Captain
description: WEST POINT, N.., Aug. 21 Gordon Jaehne, who carded over 80 only twice in his first year of varsity golf at the United States Military Academy, has been named captain for the 1971 and 1972 season.

title: Seattle Ferry Commuting Hailed
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 20Charles P. Moriarty Jr. hoisted a foot onto a chair, leaned on his knee and gazed out the window of his 28th floor office in the SeattleFirst National Bank building across the blue waters of Puget Sound dancing in the summer sun.

title: Joy in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI  As television entertainment, a speech by the President about economic policy could not normally hold a candle to the Super Bowl.

title: North Korea Offers 3 Alternate Routes For Reunification
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21 (AP)North Korea proposed today that the two nations of the Korean peninsula be reunited on democratic principles and by peaceful means by the efforts of the Korean people themselves without interference of outside forces.

title: Miss Bertal Has Wedding
description: CLERMONT, N.Y., Aug. 21 Miss Jocelyne F. Bertal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Antoine Bertal of Joinville le Pont, France, was married here today to Charles C. Townsend Jr., treasurer of the IBM World Trade Corporation in New York. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Richard VanderBorgh of the Dutch Reform Church. He was assisted by the Rev. J. E. Lindsey of St. Luke's.

title: Royal Signal Scores
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 21 (AP) Mrs. Lawrence W. Knapp Jr.'s Royal Signal sped to her fourth straight victory and first stakes conquest of the year today in the $29,650 Endine Handicap as Delaware Park reopened for a 32day meeting.

title: PEKING EXPLAINS WARNIER U.S. TIES
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 21To explain and defend its new, more friendly approach to the United States, the Pelting Government is using an article written by Mao Tsetung 31 years ago that expounds the united front tactics employed by the Chinese Communists during the Japanese war.

title: How a 190Foot Mushroom Grew in Orebro, Sweden
description: OREBRO, SwedenTowers with bars or restaurants on top of them are shooting up in cities all over the world. Such contemporary beanstalk phenomena In Atlanta, Seattle and Flushing Meadow come to mind, not to mention Monsieur Eiffel's erectorset marvel in Paris. But there's a littleknown and quite fantastic mushroom in this Swedish city that's worth a detour the next time you happen to be in Scandinavia. It's a combination water tower, restaurant and TV antenna that for the first time put Orebro on the map. The amazing thing is that the tower ever went up.

title: Shy Marshal Shot By City Patrolman After Car Incident
description: An offduty patrolman shot and slightly wounded a Federal sky marshal early yesterday morning on the Van Wyck Expressway service road after a traffic incident. The marshal alleged to have drawn a pistol.

title: Japan Still Holds Firm on Maintaining Value of the Yen
description: TOKYO, Aug. 21The Japanese Government appears to] be clinging to the view that, for the time being at any rate, a 10 per cent surcharge on exports to the United States is preferable to revaluation of the yen.

title: AMHERST HONORS EMILY DICKINSON
description: AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 21Amherst is preparing for a threeday celebration next weeks to honor Emily Dickinson, who lived here from 1830 to 1886 in a brick mansion behind a row of hedges on Main Street.

title: EVERETT B. VREELAND
description: TOWACO, N. J., Aug. 21 (AP)State Assemblyman Everett B. Vreeland died last night. He was 60 years old.

title: BESET BY A DROUGHT, AFGHANS ASK GRAIN
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 21 (AP)Reports reaching here say that in some parts of droughtravaged Afghanistan people have started eating grass, while other people have begun mass migrations in search of food and water.

title: Mrs. Charles R. Walgreen, Widow of Chain's Founder
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (AP)Mrs. Myrtle Norton Walgreen, widow of Charles R. Walgreen, founder of the Walgreen drugstore chain, died yesterday in her home here at the age of 92.

title: The Nation
description: HOBSON CITY, Ala.  After signing his third antibusing order in less than a week, Gov. George C. Wallace held an impromptu news conference last Wednesday for the throng of journalists who had come to this allblack city to watch him ritualistically challenge the Federal, Government again.

title: Miss Sarah Bruce Howe Is Married
description: NEWPORT, R. I, Aug. 21 The marriage of Miss Sarah Bruce Howe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Calderon Howe of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York, to Anthony Thomas Oppersdorff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Oppersdorff of New York took place here this afternoon.

title: YOUTHS TO ADVISE COUNTY OFFICIAL
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 21A group of young Westchester County residents who say they want to be involved in, but not compromised by, local politics organized a youth advisory committee to the County Executive this week.Jeffrey A. Volk, the committee's chairman, will be to narrow the focus of each study so that members can make concrete suggestions. For example, task force studying consumer protection might concentrate on financial credit institutions or on sales of fresh fruit and meat.

title: Law
description: LOS ANGELES  After his arraignment in Federal District Court here last week, Daniel Elisberg told newsmen he was looking forward to his trial. I think it will be very instructive for the people of this country, he explained. The issues that are going to be raised are issues of great concern... they are issues of life and death, war and peace. They're incomparably more important than what happens to me.

title: Nixon Names 6 for Study Of U.S. Aid to Pakistanis
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.. Aug., 21 (UPI)  President Nixon named a panel of six today to review steps already taken by the United States to help the millions made homeless by the civil war in East Pakistan and to make recommendations for further assistance.

title: Carolyn Richardson Bride of Surgeon
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 21Miss Carolyn Lee Richardson, daughter of Mrs. Sheppard Richardson of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Kennebunkport, was married here at noon today to Dr. Rene M. Gouldner, a surgeon of Wichita, Kan.

title: State Begins 50c Weekly Lottery Jan. 5
description: ALBANY, Aug., 21 (AP)New York's switch from a monthly to a weekly state lottery will begin next Jan. and the ticket price will be cut from the present $1 to 50 cents.

title: Dance
description: ALEXANDER PUSHKIN was a genius, a fact the nonRussianreading world has had to accept on faith as a result of the untranslatability of his poetry. Certainly, he was Russia's greatest poet. That this great figure in 19thcentury Russian literature, who was identified with the progressive currents of the art and politics of his day, was also a staunch defender of the ballet, is a point worth considering as relevant to our time.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I have a married son in San Francisco and am interested in the project proposed by Mrs. Friedman. I would be willing to help in the formation of a group. Meanwhile, I suggest that parents looking for cheap flights to California become members of the United European American Club, 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10036. Family membership is $25 for the first year, and the club offers trips to California at reduced rates.

title: Science at Work For You
description: A PLANT Science Field Day doesn't sound like a picnic outing or country fair, but that was the mood recently at Lockwood Farm in the Mt. Carmel section of Hamden, Conn. The 61acre farm is the center for field experiments of the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station and once a year it opens the gates for its neighbors to let them see what is going on.

title: HENRY IS VICTOR IN A.A.U. DIVING
Article 1  No Title
description: TRENTON, Aug. 21 (UPI)Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that from the New Jersey state lottery for the first six months of the year amounted to $33million, exceeding the original estimate by $18million.

title: U.S. Steel Pays $15,000 In Penalty for Pollution
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 21 (UPI)A state pollution cleanup fund has received its first paymenta $15,000 penalty paid by the United States Steel Corporation for waste discharges into a slough in the SacramentoSan Joaquin Delta.

title: Movies
description: AN unpredictable friend of mine recently got briefly involved in writing for one of those pseudoscience pulp magazines that specialize in documented articles on such phenomena as flying saucers, religious miracles, E.S.P. and ancient tomb curses that come true on unwary archeologists. The work, as my friend learned, consisted in taking some homely (real or imagined) news item and, by making it seem to substantiate a popular superstition, turning it into a really lush, authoritativesounding pack of lies. The documentary props would be quotes from makebelieve scientists in places like Dressle.n or Leningrad and photographs lifted from foreign periodicals (not covered by U.S. copyright laws) and in geniously recaptioned.

title: Education
description: It was just a few years ago that the free university movement swept across the country in the wake of the 1965 student uprising at Berkeley. Created by dissident students and faculty members, the free universities were intended oftenbut not alwaysas countercampuses to existing institutions.

title: Architecture
description: AND then there's the tradeoff. It's subtler and more complex than the giveaway. The giveaway has no pretensions; somebody has gotten something for nothing, usually at someone else's expense. In the tradeoff everyone, supposedly, gets something. It is conducted on a much higher plane. The illusion is that one has sold one's soul, or bits and pieces of it, for a worthwhile purpose. It ls the giveaway with conscience balm.

title: Peace Coalition of Clerics Weighing New Goals
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 21Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh spoke by telephone today to 500 delegates of an antiwar coalition at a time when the group is debating its future priorities toward war and domestic issues.

title: METS BEAT PADRES, 21, ON HOMER BY JONES IN NINTH
DUAL ENROLLMENT PRESSED BY JEWS
description: The American Jewish Committee urged President Nixon yesterday to convene educational and religious leaders to consider dual enrollment as a means of coping with the financial problems of parochial schools.

title: The Fellowship of Christian Athletes: A Love Cult That Continues to Grow
description: ESTES PARK, Colo., Aug. 21The young athlete stood in front of the audience, tall and graceful basketball player if ever there was one.

title: W. M. Carroll Weds Jonatha Foster
description: DELMAR, N. Y., Aug. 21In St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church here today, Miss Jonatha Beth Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Harman Foster, was married to William Michael Carroll, son of Mrs. Joseph La Bello of Delmar and William Carroll of Voorheesville. The Rev. Richard Broderick performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Puerto Rico Plans Referendum on Role In Elections of U.S.
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Aug. 21After months of debate, the two major political parties here have agreed to hold a referendum to decide whether the commonwealth government should ask Congress to give residents of Puerto Rico the right to vote for President.

title: Ground Fighting Slows
description: SAIGON, Aug. 21 (AP)Ground fighting slowed down on South Vietnam's northern front today, but the North Vietnamese kept up shelling attacks and United States B52 bombers countered with seven raids.

title: Medicine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis B. Russell Jr. are holding open house in their Indianapolis home today. The occasion: The third anniversary of Mr. Russell's heart transplant. He may also, of course, use the occasion to do some discreet politicking, for he is the Democratic candidate for CouncilmanatLarge.

title: Bedford Defeats Shorter At Two Miles in Stockholm
description: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 21 (AP) Dave Bedford of Britain defeated Frank Shorter of the United States today in the twomile run at an international track and field meet. Both were timed in 8 minutes 37 seconds.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on the gradual elimination in our city of elevator operators [Elevator Men Are Losing Final Bastion, Aug. 8] contributes to the pessimism of an inexorable trend by its overemphasis of the arguments of the shortsighted pennywise cost efficiency experts and by its cavalier dismissal of the arguments, of the long term rank and file tenants.

title: Princess Pout Rallies From Last to Take $116,400 Lindheimer at Arlington
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 21 (UPI)Mrs. June McKnight's Princess Pout went from last at the foot of the backstretch to win the $116,400 Benjamin F. Lindheimer Handicap, from pacesetting Wing Out by a nose today.

title: TwoChina Drive in the U.N.
description: Now that the United States has unveiled the strategy It intends to employ in its effort to provide United Nations seats for both Taipei and Peking, chances for success in what promises to be a close General Assembly vote undoubtedly have been improved. Evidence that major fight would be waged by the Nixon Administration was essential to influence waverers on the twoChina proposal. The approach Washington plans to take should help persuade skeptics that the Administrations eageness to achieve detente with Peking will not cause it limit itself to a token battle in defense of Taipei's seat.

title: A Future for GATT?; The U.S. Is Called A Sinner Among Sinners
description: GENEVAWas the imposition of a 10 per cent surtax on imports overkill?

title: Suburban Women at Work
description: The exodus of big business from the city to the suburbs is transforming the status of women in the labor force out where the crabgrass, and the little league playing fields begin.

title: A Fall Of Angels
description: Here is a warmweather trifle that asks the following question: Can three live as happily as two? It needn't take Abigail Van Buren to puzzle out the answer to that one, but Miss Savage's heroine seems deficient in the basic metabolism necessary to survival. Still beautiful, albeit a bit long in the tooth, successful (a dress designer) Helena Strider offers no resistance to the swinger who moves in to share her hotel cottage and husband on Montego Bay; her only nonnegotiable stipulation is a refusal to share her clothes closet.

title: Gardens
A Better Idea at Ford
description: Ford tiene una idea mejor.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Despite persistent unemployment in the economy, headway is being. made around the country in prisoner rehabilitation programs built on a concept known as work release. This is a process in which a prisoner, usually nearing the end of his term and eligible for parole, is released from prison during the day in order to work and returns to prison at night.

title: Tennis Hall Votes To Induct Seixas And Mrs. Darden
description: Vic Seixas and Althea Gibson Darden, both winners of the United States and Wimbledon championships, have been elected to the National Lawn Tennis Hall of Fame at Newport, R. I.

title: CITY OPERA TO OPEN WITH MAKROPOULOS
description: Tickets for the New York City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater will go on sale tomorrow at the theater boxoffice at Lincoln Center.

title: Toll in Typhoon Sinking 88
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 21 (UPI) The Marine Department said today that 88 persons had died in the sinking of a ferryboat during a typhoon Monday.

title: COMMUNITY AIDED BY POLICE TEAMS
description: It's been a lot quieter around here since they started that neighborhood police team, said Jay Broder as he stood behind the elevated counter in his father's dress shop looking out on the busy corner of Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway, in Brooklyn.

title: Television
description: FOR all the rest of us eveningnews devotees, last April wasas Walter Cronkite used to say in his old You Are There intro"a day like any other day. That meant our favorite TV newscaster was doling out virtually nothing but the doleful: in Vietnam, Fire Base 6 was again under heavy enemy shelling; the Pakistani civil war was into its 13th bloody day; Representative Hale Boggs was blasting J. Edgar Hoover for allegedly wiretapping Congressmen's phones; Government investigators had uncovered pervasive corruption in the narcotics division of the New York City police department.

title: Oilers Beat Eagles, 21.17

The Fund of Funds he named it, and the money poured in; Do You Sincerely Want to Be Rich?; The Full Story of Bernard Cornfield and lOS. By Charles Raw, Bruce Page and Godfrey Hodgson. 400 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $8.95.
description: About a year ago, on a warm afternoon toward the end of May, I found myself talking with a portly, grayhaired man who lives in what I consider to be Utopia. He was a movie actorhow else could one afford to live in Utopia?but he was nice enough to meet me at the railroad station in Lugano, in the Italian corner of Switzerland. Then, in his tan Mercedes, he drove me up to his villa in the hills overlooking the town, and he escorted me out onto a balcony that overlooked the lake far below, an intoxicating blue, and he rang a bell that produced a tall and icy glass of Tuborg on a silver tray, and a box of authentic Cuban cigars, and he said, Now what can I tell you?

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Montauk Casting Party
description: MONTAUK, L. I. We had been tossing plugs toward the high cliffs a few miles west of Montauk Point along Island's Atlantic shore for more than a hour with no success when a bluefish took my lure; in a few seconds the water was boiling with frantic, silvery menhaden and pursuing blues and all hands were fast to fish.

title: Foreign Diplomats Think '2 China Plan Will Force Early Showdown in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 Foreign diplomats say that they believe that the United States proposal this week of its own agenda item on Chinese representation in the United Nations is likely to force an early showdown on Washington's two China approach.

title: France and Gold
description: PARIS, Aug. 20  The French Government confirms the maintenance of the franc at its parity of 160 milligrains of fine gold.

title: SCIENTISTS ADVISED U.S. NOT TO BACK SST
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21The United States Office of Science and Technology has released a report by a committee of leading scientists recommending that the Government not support development of the supersonic transport plane..

title: HIDDEN SPENDING LAID TO PENTAGON
description: The Pentagon conceals millions of dollars in public relations expenditures from Congress each year, Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, charged yes. terday.

title: Sara Leland Scores Triumph In Ballanchine's Who Cares?
description: Among the ladies and gentlemen of George Balanchine's evanescent Who Cares?, Sara Leland sparkled prettily Friday evening at the State Theater. The work is one of the New York City Ballet's treasures, and Miss Leland treated it as such.

title: Reader's Report
description: Horatio Stubbs, the hero of this novel, first appeared in an earlier book: The HandReared Boy, and though he is no longer an English student but now an English soldier, lie still has primarily one thing on his mind. Whether on embarkation leave in England, on bivouac in India, or in the thick of the Burma campaign of 1944, Stubbs must be the randiest private in the ChinaBurmaIndia theater of operation. His zest for whoring declines only during bouts of dysentery.

title: John H. Miller Marries Ellen Church
description: HASTINGS, N. Y., Aug. 21 Miss Ellen Booth Church and John Hiram Miller were married here today at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norval Church. Mr. Church is professor emeritus of music education at Columbia University, where he taught for 38 years and is now a lecturer on orchestral conducting.

title: Dietz Reaches Single Sculls Final in European Rowing
description: LAKE BAGSVAERD, Denmark, Aug. 21 (AP)Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club was the only American to reach the finals of the European rowing championships today.

title: Play Pretty Victor
description: MIAMI, Aug. 21 (AP)Tartan Stable's Play Pretty, the favorite, rallied from eighth place going to the far turn and went on to score a 2 victory today in the $10,000 added Okalee Handicap at Calder Race Course.

title: Disciple of Sailmaking King Success in His Own Realm
description: When Charles R. Ulmer decides to procrastinate from his sail loft on City Island, he does it with style.

title: ANGEL RUN IN 13TH TOPS YANKEES, 21
description: ANAHEIM, Calif, Aug. 21Aware that they could gain half a game on second place because Boston lost while Detroit won in afternoon games, the New York Yankees sent Stan Bahnsen against the California Angels and Tom Murphy tonight.

title: Indians Halt White Sox
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENSOne link between President Nixon and his principal foreign policy adviser, Henry Kissinger, is their joint respect for the late General de Gaulle. Each entertained particularly high regard for the great Frenchman when this was by no means a popular U.S. prejudice and before they had ever met each other.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  Gen. Duong Van Minh tried last week to show the world what a farce he thinks the Vietnamese Presidential elections are by pulling out and leaving President Nguyen Van Thieu all alone in a rigged contest.

title: NOISECONTROL CODE FACES TOUGHENING
description: The city administration's proposed noisecontrol code, providing for fines and jail terms, has been set for a public hearing Sept. 9 at 10 A.M. by the City Council.

title: Lombardi, Trippi Enter Haiti
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (AP) The late Vince Lombardi, who coached the Green Bay Packers to the top in the National Football League in the midnineteensixties, and Charles Trippi, a former backfield ace for the old Chicago Cardinals, have been added to the United SavingsHelms Major League Football Hall of Fame.

title: BLACKS TO DECIDE MISSISSIPPI RACE
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 20For the first time since Reconstruction, the black voters of Mississippi are in a position to determine the outcome of a statewide election.

title: Fryman Tops Dodgers, 30
Pro and Con in a Bitter Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21Behind the argument over strip mining there lies a maze of complex public issues and private interests that the combatants on both sides agree touch on the most serious environmental questions in the country today.

title: For Young Readers
description: There are more than 6,000 American autobiographical or semiautobiographical slave narratives dating from the earliest years of the 18th century. They were written or dictated by slaves and exslaves, and have been preserved in book form, in church and court records, in diatribes and in the files of such leading abolitionist publications as The Liberator and The Liberty Bell. As source material, the narratives have certain weaknesses. Most were dictated by the slaves and written down by other persons, many of whom opposed the institution and gathered the material for its use as antislavery propaganda. Other narratives, especially those transcribed by the members of the Federal Writers Project of the Works Projects Administration (193638), were dictated or written by exslaves, no longer in the situation, and most of whom experienced slavery only as children.

title: DR. ARTHUR S. KOOB
description: Dr. Arthur S. Koob, a dentist in Brooklyn for more than 50 years, died Thursday in Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens. He was 75 years old and lived at 148.19 87th Avenue, Jamaica, and had an office in Ridgewood, Brooklyn.

title: GEORGE C. MILLER
description: George C. Miller, retired vice president of R. Markey & Sons, weighers, samplers and inspectors of raw commodities, died Friday in Deepdale General Hospital, Douglaston, Queens. He was 74 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens, and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: The Nation
description: Now they're trying to discredit Angelo, said City Councilman Robert I. Postel sadly last week. They're trying to make him out as a simple stumblebum who was wired for sound and failed to turn it on to record bribe offers. He's a dese, dem and does kind of guy, but he's a beautiful guy, solid, honest and his information checks out.

title: Jenkins, 20Game Victor Again, Lacks Only Identity
description: Sandy Koufax didn't do it, Bob Gibson didn't do it, Whitey Ford didn't do it, Don Drysdale didn't do itwin 20 games for five years in a row. But Ferguson Arthur Jenkins, a 6foot5inch, 27yearold Canadian, did It when he pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 32 victory over the Houston Astros on Friday, and he is only the second pitcher in the last generation who has done it.

title: SHANGHAI
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 21In the present delicate state of Chinese American relations, one problem is that the few Americans permitted to visit here are not qualified to fudge or even understand many of the things they are shown. China's use of needles instead of drugs as anesthetic in major surgery is only an illustration of the problem, but pending the day when experts are allowed to come back to China, the amateurs will have to report as best they can.

title: Bows and Arrows Barred
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21 (Reuters) The Los Angeles City Council has banned bow and arrow hunting inside the city limits. Archers were previously allowed to roam the hills in the northern part of the city to restrict the size of deer herds. The ban was imposed this week after residents said the bows and arrows endangered lives.

title: After the final Apollo flight, says an astrophysicist, we should deploy
description: ANOTHER Apollo mission has been completed successfully. Its findings will allow us to move one step closer toward an understanding of the moon, the earth and our solar system. Yet the program is drawing to an end; there will be only two more such flights. Budget limitations and the desire of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) to move forward with another type of manned flight program will put an end to the U.S. exploration of the moon after 1972.

title: New Economic Policy
description: To the Editor: Both critics and supporters of President Nixon's recent wageprice economic package have emphasized getting the economy moving again, with little or no effort to examine whether the implications of a growing economy are in fact desirable.

title: Ripening
description: The early asters come to blossom, goldenrod gilds the old pastures, ironweed and Joe Pye weed show color. Queen Anne's lace begins to fade but bouncing Bet, the ubiquitous wild pink, keeps the country roadside white with blossom. Bouncing Bet will bloom almost as long as the late asters, till hard frost comes. The wasteland sunflowers are bright as dandelions were in May, bright as the goldfinches that have begun to rag out the graying thistleheads.

title: Mary Laura McGannon Is a Bride
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 21Miss Mary Laura McGannon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. McGannon, was married here today to William C. Kollman 28, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Kollman of Wilton.

title: Six Golfers Earn Berths On British Ryder Team
description: LONDON, Aug. 21 (Reuters) Six British golfers today clinched berths on the team that will meet the United States in the Ryder Cup matches next month by finishing in the top places in the British Professional Golfers ASsociation Order of Merit.

title: Alexandra Tenney, Williams '72, Affianced to Arthur G. Potts Jr.
description: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y., Aug. 21Mr. and Mrs. Daniel G. Tenney Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., and Paul Smiths have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Diane Tenney, to Arthur G. Potts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Potts of Danbury, Conn.

title: In the Mailbox
description: TO THE EDITOR: You have unintentionally wounded the pride of every Canadian nationalist. In your listing Aug. 15 of champions of the recently concluded PanAmerican Games, you show the women's high jump winner, Debbie Brill, a Canadian, as a member of the United States team.

title: 45 Acres of Art, A Lighthouse, A Steamboat and A Bevy of Dolls
description: SHELBURNE, VT.  The artist has many ways of expressing himself, and most museums focus on just a few of them. In this Vermont village, however, seven miles south of Burlington, the Shelburne Museum exhibits art in whatever guises its cofounder, Electra Havemeyer Webb, saw itand the exhibits cover 45 acres.

title: Why Starr, Unitas Quit Waiver List Unclaimed
description: Two of the most famous players in pro football, John Unitas of the Colts and Bart Starr of the Packers, were placed on waivers recently, which, in theory, meant that any other team could have picked them up for a $100 fee. But none did. The same was true of George Blanda shortly before his great season for Oakland began last year.

title: Morgan State on the Air
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 21 (AP)Morgan State College, a perennial black football power, announced today that radio stations in three East Coast states would broadcast the Bears 11 contests this fall. The college said the games would be available to an estimated 27 million persons over stations WBAL in Baltimore, WHAT in Philadelphia and WLIM in New York.

title: Suffolk Lays First Pipe For a Vast Sewer Zone
description: WEST BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 21The first length of pipe for what will ultimately become Suffolk County's largest sewer district was laid in the ground this week by County Executive H. Lee Dennison amid a continuing controversy over the function and even the existence of sewers.

title: Jocelyne Nash Wed in Suburb
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 21Miss Jocelyne Maggiar Nash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Nash of Los Angeles and Paris, was married here today to David Albert Tufts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tufts of Old Greenwich.

title: Larchmont Sailors Take 3d
description: MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 21 (AP)T. for Two, skippered by M. Jackson and J. B. Sturton of Britain's Hayling Island Sailing Club, won the fifth race in the Olympic Tempest Class world championship today. Winds were moderate.

title: EAST EUROPE TRADE PROPOSED TO SEOUL
description: SEOUL South Korea, Aug. 21  Rumania and Yugoslavia have proposed to start trading with South Korea in response to Seoul's policy of establishing commercial relations with nonhostile Communist countries.

title: OTTO SNYDER
description: NAPLES, Fla., Aug. 21Otto Snyder, who retired in 1950 as president of the New York Power and Light Company, a !division of the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, of which lie had been vice president and director, died Friday at the age !of Si.

title: PAGANINI OFFERED IN PARK CONCERT
description: Paganini is the perfect outdoors summer composer  his icy tunes frosted with plenty of technical razzledazzle cut through even the most humid evening air. The composer's bracing Fourth Violin Concerto was the featured work in the New York Philharmonic's third and final round of the city's parks this month, and the first performance took place in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx on Friday night with Ruggiero Ricci as the soloist.

title: Jersey Girl Wins in Contest
description: FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 21 (UPI)A 20yearold girl from Trenton won the Miss Polish America contest today at Palisades Amusement Park. Tlie winner, Anita Nowicki of 2308 Liberty Avenue, who is 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighs 128 pounds, gets a trip for two to Puerto Rico and a oneyear scholarship to the New York Academy of Theatrical Arts. The first runnerup was Basia Lukasik, 19, of 3533 Condor Road, Levittown, L. I., and the second runnerup was Diane Peterson, 20, of 60 North Street, East Paterson, N. J.

title: Pilot Links Jumbojet Accident To Error in Report on Runway
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 (UPI)The pilot of the 747 jumbojet damaged on takeoff here July 10 in the worst accident to a 747 so far says he was informed that his runway was 9,500 feet long when it was actually 1,000 feet less.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Your cover story on auto theft as a growth industry ("Stealing Cars Is a Growth Industry, by Peter Hellman, June 20) must have been helpful to neophytes having dif ficulty getting the hang of this interesting business. The illustrations of the necessary, easilymade tools were clear and reassuring to any clever youngster wondering about entering this exciting field.

title: Letter From Paris
description: A case can be made for thinking of literature as a single library, perhaps an imaginary library built next door to Malraux's musee imaginaire. In it you'd find the books of the authors of the day, foreign as well as native, and of course all the classics. When nothing much is happening in contemporary letters you've always got the recourse of reading translations of other people's promising young, or of retreating a generation or two into the past.

title: Cindy Ferro to Defend Laurels In Junior Golf Opening Friday
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship which was postponed last month, will be held at the Tammy Brook C. C., Cresskill, N. J., on Friday.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Investors who had a difficult time of keeping track of stock prices last Monday might be heartened to know that even some computers were hard pressed to believe some of the numbers they were told to process.

title: Art
description: A CURRENT exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art called Thomas Wilfred: Lumia, took me right back to a classroom in San Antonio, Texas, where, in a voice shifting back and forth between a piping soprano and a shaky baritone, I delivered a sensationally successful report in the weekly Current Events class held by a teacher named Miss Ada Miller. Miss Miller, whom I remember as a Wagnerian blonde, gave me 100 for my report on an invention that was going to take the art world by storm Thomas Wilfred's clavilux, a keyboard instrument on which the player composed fugues, sonatas, and ballades in terms of mobile light projections

title: Coast Air Commuter Service Booming
description: LOS ANGELES  McDonald Chapman, a Los Angeles businessman, discovered 5 years ago how to beat the traffic jams that coagulate Southern California's freeways each morning and afternoon. He decided to live In San Diego, 100 miles to the south, and commute by air.

title: CITY TO HIRE 550 WITH U.S. FUNDS
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that applications would be taken starting tomorrow for the first 550 of 3,000 public service and city government jobs being financed under the Federal Emergency Employment Act.

title: French Gang Making a Science Of Forging PariMutuel Tickets
description: PARIS, Aug. 21The French police have uncovered a remarkable ring of forgers who have been using the most relined chemical techniques to falsify horse racing tickets and defraud the tracks.

title: Mr. Morton's Grand Tour
description: An official trip that no taxpayer should begrudge Secretary of the Interior Morton's monthlong journey through the West. As the first Easterner to hold his position, Mr. Morton is reportedly trying to steer a course between concern for preserving nature's bounty in the West and eagerness to develop it economically in the tradition of so many of his predecessors. Pressures from both environmentalists and developers are unavoidable, but a tour of the West's grandeurs should go far to strengthen the conservationist side of the Secretary's nature.

title: Feminist Protest March Due Thursday
description: Contending that the nation has failed to respond in the last year to the demands of the women's movement, thousands of women plan to march again on Fifth Avenue this Thursday, the first anniversary of the Women's Strike for Equality.

title: $510,000 Yearling 6th In Debut as 2YearOld
description: NEWMARKET, England, Aug. 21 (AP)  Crowned Prince, the colt who cost a worldrecord $510,000 as a yearling, finished sixth in his racing debut today.

title: National Notes
description: A major selling point in the drive toward welfare reform has been the idea that putting welfare recipients to work would save money. But last week the Community Council of Greater New York came to the opposite conclusion: In a detailed analysis, the council said that even though it might be socially more desirable if welfare mothers went to work, such a course actually would cost the state morenot lessmoney.

title: Uncontrollable. Growth, Poverty, Unemployment and Pollution Make Mexico's Capital a City in Crisis
description: MEXICO CITY  This capital, the largest urban center In Latin America, is suffering one of the worst crises of its 450year history an uncontrollable growth rate, widespread poverty and unemployment and a severe pollution problem.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Lawrence S. Ritter's myopic look at the costs of social improvements in the nineteen seventies (Social Goals Called Costly to Taxpayer by Robert D. Hershey Jr., July 26) is invalid.

title: Young Prospect Park Anglers Get Fish and Bonds
description: It sprinkled on the day of the big fish fry in Prospect Park, but the rain and threatening skies could not keep more than 600 young fishermen from claiming their prizes in the 20th annual Junior Angler Fishing Contest.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The Abruzzo article really captured the saporethe flavorof this delightful region. I have less tender roots than Mr. Mancini (an aunt by marriage lives in Lanciano), but have made three visits to the areas he mentions. In the spring, on Wednesdays, the butchers of Lanciano barbercue whole pigs, place them on glasscovered cutting boards outside their shops, and sell slices of herbflavored, crustyskinned pork by the kilo ears, tails and snout included. Also in this season, the women make fiatone, a pie made of all kinds of cheeses; it is forbidden to eat fiatone without wine! If you are beginrdng to get an overstuffed feeling from reading ,this, there is Centerba (literally 100 herbs), a cross between creme de menthe and Fernet Branca bitters, to help you digest. Digestion is a central topic of conversation. But then the maeocchio, or evil eye, may be the cause of your malaise: A female, whether family or friend, is called upon to perform the curseabating rite, a practice which the Roman Catholic Church condemnS. Water is placed in a dish, prayers are said, a drop of olive oil is then poured. If the oil spreads on the water, the evil eye is the problem. If the drop remains intact, you are sick. Your hosts will rarely admit to having overfed you.

title: Anne Helmers Has Wedding
description: The marriage of Miss Anne Helmers, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dag Helmers of Djursholm, Sweden, to James Baker Sitrick of New York, took place yesterday in Stockholm. The ceremony was performed in the Danderdys Lutheran Church by the Rev. BrorAxel Lindorn.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I would like to support the complaint made in the letter by Mrs. Claire Friedman (Travel section, Aug. 8), who finds it expensive to fly out. West to visit her children. [Mrs. Friedman. proposed the formation of a group that would enable Easterners with family ties in the West to fly there more cheaply.] The fare to. visit my son and his wife in Denver is outrageous. I can go to Europe on a charter flight with one of the organizations I belong to for the same amount. I know that if fares were reasonable I'd make it. to Denver every other month. If the kids get a special rate, why not everybody else? Why not try it for a while? Better than empty seats. Cut down the cute meals; on a three or fourhour trip one doesn't need a hot meal. I remember taking sandwiches on a New York San Francisco flight when it took more than five hours.

title: MRS. KENNETH COFFIN
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn, Aug. 21Mrs. Norma DeVany Coffin, widow of Kenneth Ford Coffin, a New York architect, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital. She was 76 years old and lived at 50 Sound Beach Avenue.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I was fortunate enough to see The Two Gentlemen of Verona in Central Park, and I cannot begin to express what a brilliantly funny and marvelous evening it was in every department: the brilliant lyrics of John Guare and the equally brilliant music of Galt MacDermot, the choreography of Jean Erdman, the direction of Mel Shapiro, and the cast.

title: INDIANS PROTEST UPSTATE HIGHWAY
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 21  The Council of Chiefs of the Onondaga Indian Nation has filed formal complaint with the District Attorney, here, demanding that he stop the state from building a third lane on a highway cutting through their reservation.

title: RICHTER CONDUCTS A VIVID REQUIEM
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall was distinguished on Friday night by a performance of Mozart's Requiem led by Karl Richter, the German organist and conductor.

title: Books:
description: For the perplexed, white businessman or other economic planner who has been wondering what do they want, here is a substantial body of answers from the black sector.

title: Biaggi Urges Nixon to Aid Northern Ireland Refugees
description: Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, announced yesterday that he had requested President. Nixon to immediately send aid to the refugees fleeing from Northern Ireland.

title: California Placed on Probation; McAlister's Appeal Is Denied
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 21 (UPI)The University of California was placed on indefinite probation today by the executive council of the National Collegiate Athletic Association for five athletic rule violations.

title: OPEN TO QUESTION
description: To THE EDITOR: It is regrettable that Clayton Riley's often penetrating writing is frequently vitiated by slipshod observation and wild extremes of rhetoric.

title: We read everything he wrote and panted for more
description: From the way I have marked up this new translation of the book, it would seem as if I had never read it before; yet this must be the seventh or eighth time I have done so. Though it is not the greatest book ever written, it is closer to me than any other book I have read. Hamsun is the author I deliberately tried to imitate, obviously without success. am not alone in this fatuous worship of Hamsun. He seems to have been to those of my generation what Dickens was to the readers of his time. We read everything he wrote and panted for more.

title: JUDGE NOMINEES IN QUEENS SUED
description: A Federal suit seeking to invalidate the bipartisan Democratic and Republican nominations for three Queens judgeships was filed last week by Jules B. Kroll, a lawyer from Hoiliswood, Queens.

title: BROWNE SHARES TITLE WITH EVANS
description: VENTURA, Calif., Aug. 21Walter Browne an Australian grandmaster, and Larry Evans of Reno, an international grandmaster, were named cochampions today in the final round of play at the United States Open Chess Championship at the Ventura Fair Grounds in Seaside Park here.

title: Toughie Brasuhn Dies; Early Star of Roller Derby
description: Marjorie Brasuhn Monte, known to millions of Roller Derby and television fans in the nineteenforties and early fifties as Midge (Toughie) Brashun, died unexpectedly on Aug. 9 in Honolulu. She was 48 years old.

title: ROBERT E. GURVITZ
description: Robert E. Gurvitz, head of the Forum Group, Ltd., a New York public relations firm, died of a heart attack Friday in Bellevue Hospital. He was 44 years old and lived at 20 Robin Court, Plainview, L. I.

title: Offduty Police Join in Search for a Killer
description: Fellow policemen reported on their day off yesterday to join in the search for two youths wanted in connection with the shooting of a patrolman who was slain while trying to foil a store holdup Friday night in Queens.

title: You, Too, Can Hobnob With The Nobility For $6,360
description: LONDONOnce upon a time in Merry Old England, which, as everyone knows, is full of lovable lords and ladies who look a bit like Cary Grant and Deborah Kerr, there lived a kind godmother who felt sorry for all the Cinderellas of America (and especially Dallas) who never got asked up to the castle for tea.

title: Mollie Massie Virginia Bride
description: RICHMOND, Aug. 21Miss Mollie Taylor Massie was married here today to Joseph Patterson Lawson Jr.

title: The Nation
description: A year and a half ago, distressed by television commercials stressing big cars and hightest gasolines, the Friends of the Earth, an environmental protection organization, appealed to the Federal Communications Commission for equal television time to broadcast antipollution messages. As a precedent, the group cited the fairness doctrine which required TV stations to match cigarette commercials with anticigarette messages.

title: The many guises of the hamburger
Miss Corris Is Fiancee Of Navy Dental Officer
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 21The engagement of Miss Barbara Ann Corris to Lieut. Joseph Di Gianni, Dental Corps, U.S.N., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John J. Corris. A spring wedding is planned.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I refer to an article Hotel Business Here Stays in Doldrums (Aug. 10).

title: What the Black Woman Thinks About Women's Lib
description: THEY were always there. Whenever you wanted to do something simple, natural and inoffensive. Like drink some water, sit down, go to the bathroom or buy bus ticket to Charlotte, N. C. Those classifying signs that told you who you were, what to do. More than those abrupt and discourteous signs one gets used to in this countrythe door that says Push, the towel dispenser that says Press, the traffic light that says No"these signs were not just arrogant, they were malevolent: White Only, Colored Only, or perhaps just Colored, permanently carved into the granite over a drinking fountain. But there was one set of signs that was not malevolent; it was, in fact, rather reassuring in its accuracy and fine distinctions: the pair that said White Ladies and Colored Women.

title: Chess
New Economic Policy
New Economic Policy
description: To the Editor: A critical aspect of the President's change in the economic policy is being consistently overlooked by the press and the public. The President has acted on dictatorial powers.

title: BROOKLYN FIGHTS TO SAVE HOUSES
description: For more than half a century a small community in the northern section of the East New York district of Brooklyn has slumbered while its residents, of low and modest incomes enjoyed singleand doublefamily houses with trees and lawns.

title: MISS PANDE WINS TENNIS AT MERION
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 21Eliza Pande, nonseeded contender from Palo Alto, Calif, made a brilliant turnabout today in winning the 72d Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship by 06, 62, 63 over topseeded Mrs. Lesley Bowrey of Australia before a capacity crowd of 2,500 at Merion Cricket Club.

title: COSMOS, METROS PLAY HERE TODAY
description: The New York Cosmos, three games away from ending their first regular season in the North American Soccer League, will try again today to post their first victory against an expansion team when they meet the Toronto Metros at Yankee Stadium. Game time is 6 P.M.

title: Drama Mailbag MEMORABLE
description: To THE EDITOR: While in London recently, I was fortunate enough to see a preview performance of Tyger. It was one of my most memorable theatrical experiences.

title: BELGIAN 2MILER SETS WORLD MARK
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 21 (AP)Emile Puttemans, a 24yearold Belgian, set a world record of 8 minutes 17.8 seconds for the twomile run today, in the highlight of the Scottish Highland Games.

title: Burtis's Gauchero, Victor in Hempstead Harbor Sail
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I. Aug. 21Alan Burtis Guachero, which last weekend won the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship, today returned to Hempstead Harbor to capture class honors among 10 starters.

title: DAVID WEXLER, 70, MT. SINAI TEACHER
description: Dr. David Wexler, an ophthalmologist who was an authority on ocular pathology, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after surgery. He was 70 years old and lived at 196 East 75th Street.

title: HILGENDORF VICTOR AT NARRASKETUCK
description: AMITYVILLE, L.I., Aug. 21 David Hilgendorf won in the Firm Class today as the Narrasketuck Yacht Club's annual weekend invitation regatta got under way. A fleet of approximately 150 craft started under a southwesterly wind which blew steadily at 16 knots.

title: Blanda's Two Field Goals and 35Yard Scoring Pass Help Raiders Win, 207
Epidemic in Kashmir
description: SPINAGAR, Koshmir, Aug. 21A gastroenteritis epidemic has claimed nearly 200 lives in the vale of Kashmir since June. Reported deaths are still averaging four a day and and hospitals are crowded with several hundred thousand patients.

title: A Show With Only Bugs? No, No, Gnat Gnat
description: IT was a little disconcerting. I had never before interviewed a Broadway producer who was Wearing three layers of screening over his face, a safari pith helmet, asbestos gloves and who was carrying a large butterfly net.

title: MYSTIC WILL OFFER NAVIGATION COURSE
description: Courses in celestial navigation, meteorology and astronomy will be conducted at the Mystic, Conn., Seaport Planetarium this fall. The courses are open to students 18 years of age and older.

title: Bomb Delays L.I.R.
description: A sixinch pipe bomb on the Long Island Railroad tracks in Forest Hills, Queens, caused a twohour suspension in service between Woodside, Queens, and Great Neck, L. I., last night before the police disarmed the device. The bomb was spotted by a railway employe at 5:35 P. M. It remained on the track until it was removed by members of the police bomb squad two hours later.

title: Coal Rush Is On as Strip Mining Spreads Into West
Weiskopf, at 204, Leads By 3 in Philadelphia Golf
Hawthornehaunted vignettes
description: David Plante's second novel (his first was The Ghost of Henry James) is full of ghosts from Hawthorne. Elements of The House of Seven Gables, The Blithedale Romance, and The Marble Faun come in and out of focus throughout the book. For scholars, it could be fascinating (and, perhaps, illuminating) to discover familiar motifs embedded in a romance of the present decade. When the literary detective work is over, Slides must be judged for itself, not in the glow of Hawthorne.

title: LOUIS C. WHITE
description: SMITHTOWN. L. I., Aug. 21 Louis C. White, a civil engineer, died on Thursday. He was 78 years old and lived on Estate Road.

title: Medicine
description: Ever since 1776, when Lazzaro Spallanzani found that human sperm could be frozen and then thawed out and revived, biologists have predicted a day when a man might have his semen put into cold storage and, perhaps after his death, used to beget a child.

title: GETTYSBURG SITE IS BOUGHT BY U.S.
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 21 The United States Government has purchased one of the most popular tourist attractions in Gettysburgthe National Museum and Electric Mapfor $2,350,000, the largest and most significant acquisition the Government has ever made at the national park here.

title: Crotty Skips Fordham, To Attend Notre Dame
description: Peter Crotty, the 6foot9inch basketball star at St. Agnes of Rockville Centre, L. I., will join Coach Digger Phelps at Notre Dame next month.

title: Marilyn A. Hofmann Is Affianced
description: RYE N.Y., Aug. 21The engagement of Miss Marilyn A. Hofmann to Robert Keith Harrison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison of Union City, Ind., has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Herbert A. Hofmann. The wedding is planned for Nov. 27.

title: HOSPITAL TO GIVE INSURANCE DATA
description: AMITYVILLE, LI., Aug. 21 Last year, a Nassau County policeman was sent to the Brunswick Hospital Center here after the first of two operations on a shattered hip. He faced a minimum of six months in the center's rehabilitation hospital and anticipated a lifetime of bankruptcy.

title: The right man to keep a diary
description: During its brief, feverish career, the Weimar Republic had few passionate defenders. Among the most interesting of these was Harry Kessler, aristocrat and democrat, diplomat and esthete, natural stylist and acute observer. They called him the Red Count, and the epithet neatly captures the conjunction, rare in Germany's illfated republic, of social eminence and advanced political and artistic views.

title: WATERBURY FEELS RACIAL TENSIONS
description: WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 21Puerto Rican leaders in this industrial city of 111,000 people say they will not be able to control their community of 7,000 much longer if the city administration does not relieve the mounting tension between them and the police.

title: UNE DE MAI TRIUMPHS;
Art to Handle: Barcelona's Whimsical Doorknobs
description: There must be something in the air in Spain's second city to encourage creative playfulness, not only in the works of its famous native sons, Gaudi and Miro, but in its everyday objects as well. Among the doorknobs observed by one casual stroller, for instance, were an octopus, a corkscrew, a thermometer and manometer and a stein of beer.

title: PAKISTAN SAYS ARMY KILLED 51 IN THE EAST
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 21  The Pakistani radio reported today that Pakistani troops attacked a hideout of Indian agents in the Sundarbans forest area in East Pakistan yesterday, killing 51 and capturing 9.

title: DAYAN CLARIFIES OCCUPATION VIEW
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 21Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that any settlement with the Arab countries should allow Israel to retain some occupied areas in the Sinai Peninsula, the westbank area of Jordan and the Golan heights in Syria.

title: The World
description: SYDNEY  The announcement that Australia will withdraw the bulk of her troops from Vietnam by Christmas has inspired a reappraisal in this country of the Australian role in the war, the alliance with the United States and the national purpose in general.

title: Is China using the barbarians (Russia) to control the barbarians (America); China And Russia; The Great Game. By O. Edmund Clubb. Illustrated. 578 pp. New York: Columbia. University Press. $12.95.
description: The advent of PingPong diplomacy and of the new but extremely cautious approaches that Washington and Peking are making toward a mutual accommodation cast the light of urgency on the analysis of SinoSoviet relations. For a little more than two decades America's posture toward China has been inflexible. While the vagaries of SovietAmerican relations were a not unimportant element in the SinoSoviet dispute, that dispute did not play any necessary role in American policy planning. The State Department sat, watched and waited. Constrained by a policy evidently made as much by Chiang Kaishek as by the American President, the United States did not feel free even to establish relations with Mongolia, which in the late fifties and early sixties would have been a valuable listeningpost in the SinoSoviet conflict.

title: COPTER MISSIONS HALTED NEAR DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 21 (UPI)  The United States command has grounded American observation helicopters along the demilitarized zone because of intense North Vietnamese antiaircraft fire, military sources said today. Pour United States helicopters were shot down yesterday.

title: Home Improvement
description: ORNAMENTAL railings and columns made of wrought iron have long been popular as a means of protecting against falls, as well as for enhancing the decorative scheme on the inside or outskie of many homes. They are used as hand rails on indoor and outdoor steps and stairways, as ornamental railings (with or without columns) around indoor balconies or outdoor patios, as safety rails around raised porches or sun decks, as supports for awnings, patio roofs and carports, and even as interior room dividers. Unfortunately, however, wrought iron has always posed a maintenance problem especially when used around the outside where it is constantly exposed to the

title: RONDON DEFEATS JONES AT CARACAS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 21 (AP)  Vicente Paul Rondon of Venezuela retained his World Boxing Association light heavyweight championship with a unanimous decision over Eddie Jones of Los Angeles tonight.

title: Fish Market Raided in Sicily
description: PALERMO, Sicily, Aug. 21 (AP)The police raided a fishmarket in nearby Porticello today and confiscated more than five tons of fish in a predawn raid aimed at disrupting the Mafia's control of the waterfront.

title: Patricia Kitchell Wed to C. J. Kubie
description: BEDFORD, N. Y., Aug. 21 Miss Patricia Sue Kitchell and Christopher James Kubie were married here this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Chapel in the Woods. The Rev. Alfred D. Moore or the First Congregational Church of Chappaqua, performed the ceremony.

title: 25 Draft Office Raiders Held in Jersey and Buffalo
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation foiled antiwar raids on Federal offices in Camden, N. J., and Buffalo over the weekend, arresting 25 people, including two Roman Catholic priests and a Lutheran minister.

title: MISS POTTER WINS FOR DIVING SWEEP
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Cynthia Potter of Houston took the three meter I springboard title at the National Amateur Athletic Union diving championships today to complete a sweep of the three women's events.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the year 1919, the observation of solar eclipse by a team of British scientists served to dramatize for a thunderstruck world what has been widely accounted one of the most extraordinary intellectual feats in human historyAlbert Einstein's postulation of the General Theory of Relativity, whereby he proved that Sir Isaac Newton's world of mechanical absolutes was merely an illusion. Yet for all the wonder of Einstein's revelations, it is difficult to look back upon his career without feeling twinges of contempt for a world that elevated a theoretical physicist to the role of a messiah. For has it not been the sad lesson of the 20th centurywas not Einstein's own career sufficient demonstrationthat to master the subtleties of time, space, and matter is not the same as comprehending the vagaries of human affairs? Looking back now, does it not seem absurd that the world beat a path to the absentminded professor's door and thrust at him the roles of political leader moral arbiter, and healer of the lame and the halt?

title: 6HITTER HURLED BY MESSEREITH
Brooklyn Man Slain in ??
description: A 33yearold Brooklyn man was shot and killed by an unknown assailant early yesterday as he sat in his parked automobile at Hart Street near Tompkins Avenue in the Bedford Stuyvesant section. The police said that Eugene Feliciano of 741 DeKalb Avenue had been shot in the back of the head. The assailant approached the car at 12:45 A.M. and fired three shots from a revolver, according to the police.

title: Curfew Is Continued in Quiet but RiotTorn Camden
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 22Mayor Joseph M. Nardi Jr. announced today that he and leaders of the Puerto Rican community had agreed to continue a state of emergency clamped on this city following two nights of looting and burning by angry Puerto Rican youths late last week.

title: Westbury Poloists Win, 75, As Rizzo Scores Four Goals
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 22Dave Rizzo scored four goals and led the Westbury polo team to a 75 victory over Brookville today at Bethpage State Park.

title: RAYMOND G. SCOLLIN, EXMARINE GENERAL
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Aug. 22 (AP)Brig Gen. Raymond G. Scollin, who retired in 1946 as the youngest general in the Marine Corps, died Thurs. day while visiting relatives in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 66 years old and lived here.

title: Britain Plans to Kill 3,000 Seals on Farne Isles
description: LONDON, Aug. 22  Three thousand gray seals on the Fame Islands, off the northeastern coast of England, will be killed over the next three years because of overpopulation.

title: Mostel Will Recreate Role of Tevye on L.I.
description: Zero Mostel who created the role of Tevye in Fiddler on the Roof on Broadway, is going to play it in stock starting Oct. 2G in a fourweek run at the Westbury (L. I.) Music Fair.

title: Parachutist Dies in Mishap
description: FULTON, N. Y., Aug. 22 (AP) Frank G. Leone, 22 years old, of West Babylon, L. I., was killed in a parachuting accident over the Oswego County Airport, the state police;said. He became entangled in the lines of his main parachute when it opened, and activated his reserve, according to the police, but it was too near the ground for it to be effective. He had jumped 3,400 feet out of a single engine aircraft.

title: Miss Duorr Upsets Mrs. King
description: LAKE BLUFF, Ill., Aug. 22 (AP) Thirdseeded Francoise Durr of France upset topseeded Billie Jean King, leading American player, 64, 62, to win the $20,000 clay court tennis tournament today.

title: Chinese Mission in Malaysia
description: KUALA LAMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 22 (Reuters)The first Chinese Communist trade mission to Malaysia arrived here today and received an enthusiastic welcome at the airport from a crowd of 5,000, mostly ethnic Chinese. The 13member group, led by Chang Kuangtou, a member of the Council for the Promotion of International Trade, is the guest of Malaysia's state corporation, Pernas.

title: PLANS FOR OUTLAYS ON PLANTS DECLINE
description: Appropriations for new plants and equipment by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers declined during the second quarter of the year to their lowest level since early 1965, the Conference Board announced yesterday.

title: TAIWAN RECALLS ITS FARM MISSIONS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 22 Fifty Chinese Nationalist agricultural technicians packed their belongings over the weekend at farming stations throughout Sierra Leone. Taipei broke off diplomatic relations with the West African nation Friday and announced that it was withdrawing its agricultural mission.

title: Graebner Wins Penn Tennis
description: HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 22 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York, the secondseeded player, regained the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today by defeating Richard Stockton of Garden City, L. I., 62, 6.4, 67, 75.

title: The Voters Vs. House Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22A public opinion survey indicated today that the voting records of 10 House leaders of both parties had not reflected their constituents views on such key issues as Vietnam, the draft and the supersonic transport.

title: Service Lapses Cost Telephone Company $160,000 in Month
description: ALBANY, Aug. 22 (AP)The New York Telephone Company has had to make refunds totaling $160,000 to nearly 27,000 customers because of service interruptions during May, mostly in New York City.

title: Capital Meeting Is Told of Nationwide Lindsay Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Lindsay for President activity in 15 major cities and on more than 300 college campuses was reported here today at a midAtlantic conference of youthful Lindsay supporters.

title: Bitterness Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The International side of President Nixon's new economic policy is being viewed increasingly here and abroad as an act of nationalism that may leave bitter feelings in other countries for a long time to come.

title: Plane Sent for Paz
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 22 (Reuters)A chartered plane arrived here tonight to fly Mr. Paz back to his country after almost seven years of exile. He has been living here since he was toppled by a military coup in November, 1964.

title: Namath Goes Home To Do Some Mending
description: Joe Namath, the New York Jets' quarterback, was released from Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday two weeks after he underwent surgery for the repair of damaged ligaments in his left knee.

title: Surtax Seen as a Threat To Airlines and Port Here
description: New York's Economic Development Administrator said yesterday that President Nixon's new economic measures might cause serious hurt to the city's maritime and aviation industries.

title: A Stickler for Details George Furth Berlinger
description: Except for a 5 P.M. tennis date at the home of a friend, George F. Berlinger spent his first day as the state's Welfare Inspector General at his estate in Purchase, Westchester County. He worked on plans for his new staff and helped entertain his stepgranddaughter, Carrie Kemp

title: Warden Tells of Gun
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 22George Jackson had a gun when he returned to his cellblock from a visit with a lawyer yesterday, Louis S.
