Nelson, warden of San Quentin Prison, said at a news conference today. Jackson and five others were killed when he attempted to escape immediately on reentering the cellblock.

title: Kevin Bell Marries Miss Mary L. Sara
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 22Miss Mary Linda Sara was married here this afternoon to Kevin Henry Bell. The Rev. Robert Panek, the key. Wallace Harris and the Rev. William Tobin performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle, of which the bride is a graduate.

title: Riding Tune Triumphs
description: SALEM, N. H., Aug. 22 (AP),  Jayeff Stable's Riding Tune won the $10,000 Old Man of the Mountain Purse before a crowd of 16,774 at Rockingham Park today.

title: FRENCH PREMIER DEFENDS POLICY
description: PARIS, Aug. 22Francois Mitterrand, who is trying to make a comeback as France's main Opposition leader, has received a letter from Premier Jacques ChabanDelmas and the rest of France looked over his shoulder today while he read it.

title: Political Suicide in Saigon
description: The presidential election and the whole constitutional system built painstakingly in South Vietnam over the past five years at the cost of 45,000 American lives now are being turned into a farce by President Thieu's clumsy maneuvers to assure his return to office with a large majority. Continued connivance by the American Ambassador in these extraordinary tactics, designed to create the appearance of a contested election, will disgrace the United States before the worlda disgrace compounded by Vice President Ky's decision to withdraw from the race whether or not his name remains on the ballot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MILTON J. GOELL
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 22  Milton J. Goell, a retired New York lawyer, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 119 East Hartsdale Avenue.

title: EXPANSION URGED FOR CHILD CENTERS
description: A study for the State Council of Economic Advisers, citing budget restraints, called yesterday for substantial expansion of daycare programs here by reaching more children with good day care rather than relatively few with enriched but costlier efforts.

title: Soviet Calls Nixon Trip A Blow to Indochinese
description: HONG KONG, Monday, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The Moscow radio said today that China had dealt a blow to the Indochinese peoples by inviting President Nixon to Peking for talks.

title: Miss Jackson Fails Tryout
description: PITTSFIELD, Mass., Aug 22 (UPI)Jackie Jackson, a cost analyst from Bethesda, Md., returned home tonight after failing in her tryout with the Pittsfield Senators of the Eastern League.

title: 3 More Bombings Reported
description: MANILA, Monday, Aug. 23 (UPI)Three new bombings were reported in Manila last night but there were no injuries and damage was slight. The targets were the main water pipes between Quezon and San Juan, the Manila City Hall and the office of the governmental commission on elections. The police attributed the bombings to urban terrorists.

title: U.S. Senior Netmen Defeat Australia, Keep Stevens Cup
description: The United States retained the Stevens Cup yesterday by defeating Australia, 32, in the challenge round at the Town Tennis Club. The Americans won the concluding two singles matches of the senior team competition.

title: Tickets for Fall Season Of City Opera Go on Sale
description: Seats for all performances of the New York City Opera's fall season, Sept. 2 through Nov. 14, go on sale today at the New York State Theater box office in Lincoln Center. Prices range from $1.50 (fifth ring) to $7.95 (orchestra and first ring).

title: No Great Loss, G.O.P. Says of Lindsay's Shift
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP)The Republican party bid a biting farewell to Mayor Lindsay of New York today and predicted his switch to the Democratic party would kill the Presidential hopes of Senator George McGovern of South Dakota.

title: Mrs. Eunice B. Dowd Wed to R. A. Huettner
description: MADISON, N. J., Aug. 22 The marriage of Mrs. Eunice Bizzell Dowd of Chatham to Richard Alfred Huettner of Madison took place here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church. The Rev. Donald S. Bachtell of the Madison Presbyterian Church performed the cerel mony.

title: 2 Berrigans Prisoners For More Than a Year
description: The Rev. Daniel Berrigan and the Rev. Philip Berrigan, brothers who are Roman Catholic priests, have been serving Federal prison sentences for more than a year for the destruction of draft records in Baltimore in 1967 and in Catonsville, Md., in 1968.

title: Lillian S. Isseks Bride of Lawyer
description: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 22At Temple Sinai this afternoon, Miss Lillian S. Isseks, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Abraham S. Isseks, was married to Charles A. Judelson, son of Mr. and Mr. and Mrs. Jack Judelson. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert S. Port. He was assisted by Rabbi Moshe V. Goldblunt.

title: Books of The Times
description: The threat of road construction using up the city's public lands has been replaced over last decade by the growing demand of the Board of Education for school space, Parks Commissioner August Heckscher said yesterday.

title: Buggy Nuts Gather in a Connecticut Park
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., Aug. 22  Deep in the 4,000acre White Memorial Foundation Nature Preserve here in the foothills of the Berkshires it was quiet and peaceful and the steaming city seemed worlds away.

title: SUTTON SUPPORTS JUSTICE BACKER
description: Borough President Percy E. Sutton joined with a group of seven Reform Democratic leaders yesterday in endorsing the candidate of the Manhattan Democratic executive committee for surrogate in the Sept. 14 primary, State Supreme Justice Frederick Backer,

title: Books of The Times
description: To someone under 30 it would be difficult to explain just who Walter Winchell is. Gossip columnists continue to purvey their anecdotes about the famous and the transitory, but as much as any one man Walter Winchell invented the gossip columnand perhaps more than any other columnist used it as a platform for his own prejudices and as a vehicle for personal power. Harsh words, perhaps, especially about a man now in his sevdnties who in his heyday made enough enemies for 10 men and whose declining years were marked by personal tragedy. None theless, as Bob Thomas shows in Winchell, his was a story of power corrupting, of personal vindictiveness sometimes substituting for the journalist's goals of truth and objectivitygoals, that are, of course, not always realized.

title: There Must Be a Public Trial
description: Attorney General Mitchell has decided not to bring evidence before any Federal grand jury on Kent State. But the Scranton Commission found the Kent State killings were unnecessary, unwarranted and inexcusable.

title: Militant Youths Are Old in Fight on War
description: Many of the 25 people arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in two separate incidents in Buffalo and Camden, N.J., are young. But many of them, despite their youth, are already longtime members of the antiwar movement. For them, the movement is a fulltime commitment.

title: LAVER TOPS RIESSEN IN FIVESET FINAL
description: FORT WORTH, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Rod Laver found his backhand and with it his first tournament victory since midMay tonight, defeating Marty Riessen of Tucson, Ariz., in the final of the Colonial National professional tennis championship and gaining second place in the milliondollar World Championship of Tennis series.

title: Bonnita Jaffe Wed To Randall Kavet
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Aug. 22 Miss Bonnita Dawn Jaffe and Randall N. Kavet were married here this afternoon at Temple Sinai by Rabbi Martin Siegel.

title: CREDIT MARKETS WEIGHING COURSE
description: The credit markets, after rushing poll mell toward lower interest rates early last week in an enthusiastic response to President Nixon's new economic programs, have settled back to figure out the longrange impact of the Administration's dramatic measures.

title: Foreign Investments and Tourism Rise
description: PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 22After stagnating throughout the Sixties, Haiti's economy is at last enjoying the beginnings of an economic boom, with tourism and foreign investment increasing rapidly under the fourmonthold government of President JeanClaude Duvalier.

title: 3 Escape Into West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Aug. 22 (Reuters)Three East German youths from Saxony crossed the heavily fortified East German border into West Berlin today. A fourth member of the group was arrested by East German border guards.

title: Flor De Sombra Scores
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 22 (AP) Flor De Sombra of Briardale Farms won the $31,100 Parlo turf Handicap at Delaware Park today.

title: DEMIDDI RETAINS CROWN IN SCULLS
description: LAKE BAGSVAERD, Denmark, Aug. 22 (AP)Alberto Demiddi of Argentina and eight powerful newcomers from New Zealand helped prevent a clean sweep by East Germany today as the European rowing championships ended.

title: Leedmore Is Polo Victor
description: TOUGHKENAMON, Pa., Aug. 22Jules Romph scored three goals today to lead Leedmore of Middleburg, Va., to a 75 victory over Mallett Hill of Cochranville, Pa., in a firstround game of the Polo Pony Memorial Tournament at the Brandywine Polo Club.

title: Lions Beat Colts in Last 18 Seconds, 2320, Before 91,745 at U. of Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 22 The Detroit Lions beat the Baltimore Colts, 2320, by scoring with 18 seconds left today in the University of Michigan stadium before a sweltering crowd of 91,745, This assembly probably was the largest that will watch a pro football game this season, and it produced impressive economics.

title: African Ruler Full of Surprises
description: BANGUI, Central African Republic, Aug. 14  Even more than most of its neighbors in Africa, this former French colony is a oneman show.

title: Failure of State to Sell Bonds To Cost Extra $6.1Million
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday the state will have to pay an extra $6,143,000 in interest costs because of failure last spring to sell $70million in bonds for the giant State Capitol Mall in Albany.

title: Bingham Nephew Sought As a Visitor of Jackson
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 22The police were searching tonight for the grandson of a former Governor and United States Senator in connection with an escape attempt from San Quentin prison that ,ended in six deaths yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the Cultural Revolution: I
description: HONG KONGWhat are the aims of the men who lead China now? What will be the aims of China's probable leaders tomorrow? The answers to these questions have a crucial bearing on the fate of the world in the last quarter of the twentieth century.

title: POLICE IN BROOKLYN HOLD 3 IN SHOOTING
description: Policemen surrounded a building in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn for more than an hour last night after they found a man paralyzed from the waist down by a shotgun wound.

title: Carl Salamensky, 38, Recipient In a Kidney Transplant, Dead
description: NEWARK, Aug. 22 (AP) Carl Salamensky, who underwent a kidney transplant a [month ago, died last night in Beth Israel Medical Center. Mr. Salamensky, who was 38 years old, lived in Wayne, N. J., where he was personnel placement director at William Paterson College.

title: FETE ON HART ISLAND AIDS ADDICT CENTER
description: About 18,000 people, most of them young, visited the third annual Festival of Life on Hart Island in Long Island Sound yesterday. The drugfree outdoor festival of rock music and concessions was held to raise money for Phoenix House, which supervises a narcotics rehabilitation center on the island.

title: ACTIVITY SLOWS FOR EUROBONDS
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 22In the absence of fixed parities and foreign exchange markets, both the mood and activity on the longterm Eurocapital markets were depressed last week.

title: 2 Cars Hit and Kill Woman
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, LI., Aug. 22A 20yearold Brooklyn woman was killed here last night wizen she was struck by two cars as she walked down the Jericho Turnpike. The Suffolk County police said that the victim, Barbara Ellen Connell, of 741 45th Street, Brooklyn, was killed at 10:45 P.M., when she was struck by the vehicles as she walked down the center of the highway. No charges were filed against the drivers.

title: Marilyn Schwartz Bride of M. J. Axler
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Aug. 22Miss Marilyn Ruth Schwartz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Saul A. Schwartz, was married here this afternoon to Marvin Jay Axler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Axler of Philadelphia. Rabbi Aaron H. Blumenthal, assisted by. Cantor Joseph Amdur, performed the ceremony at Temple ErnanuEl.

title: Queens Man Drowns
description: FREEPORT, L. I., (AP)Thomas Hendrix, 75 years old, 19109 109th Avenue, Hollis, Queens, drowned here today when he fell into the water helping to tie up a boat,

title: KY LEAVES RACE DESPITE U.S. PLEA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 23Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky withdrew from the presidential race today because of what he called President Nguyen Van Thieu's designs to rig the elections.

title: Hadassah Head Scores Critics Of Israel's Domestic Policies
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 22The head of the largest Zionist organization in the world criticized American Jewish leaders today for what she called their summit sermonizing about Israel's domestic problems.

title: PRESTON TISCH HEADS UNIT ON CONVENTIONS
description: Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the appointment of Preston Robert Tisch as chairman of a newly created corporation that will build and operate the nation's largest convention center, on the western midtown waterfront.

title: COSMOS WIN, 20, TO GAIN PLAYOFFS
description: The New York Cosmos, in their first year in the North American Soccer League, clinched a playoff berth in the 8team loop In Yankee Stadium last night by defeating the Toronto Metros, 20.

title: Unity of Christ and Satan A Tenet of Religious Cult
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 22 New Yorkers, renowned for their ability to stare through almost anybody, have been doing doubletakes on Fifth Avsenue at young persons dressed in black or gray with the signs of Satan on the points of their collars.

title: Roundup: Cards Win, 2 Leaders Bow
description: The National League's socalled pennant contenders were reduced to reluctant dragons yesterday when five of the six top teams lost.

title: Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge Is Dead at 78
description: CLAYTON, N. Y., Sept. 22Mrs. Pauline Morgan Dodge, a former president of the New York City Young Women's Christian..Association and the wife of Cleveland E. Dodge, the, philanthropist, died today of a coronary attack at their summer home on Wild Goose Island in the St. Lawrence River. She was 78 years old and resided also on Dodgewood Road in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Soviet Says Mars Probes Are Studying Solar Wind
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)Two Mars probes launched by the Soviet Union in May are making studies of the solar wind, Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, reported today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It's much too hot to think about hockey; the ice melting so fast that gin tastes like KoolAid, but Ed Giaconiiii and Gilles Villemure have become the second and third Rangers to ink their pacts for the upcoming campaign. So what, you say, good Lord, it's only August. Only August indeed. In 18 days the Rangers open their training season; before we can get a refill Emile (the Cat) Francis will be crinkling the skin around his eyes and saying, with portentuous wisdom, hockey is a slippery game, it's played on ice.

title: Campbell Recalls a Soup Alter Botulin Is Detected
description: The Campbell Soup Company announced yesterday that it was recalling all chicken vegetable soup packed by its Paris, Tex., plant as a precaution after the discovery of botulism contamination in part of one day's output there.

title: He Believes That Four Walls Create More Than a Room
description: Many interior designers are content with a healthy stable of wealthy and prominent private clients. But not Angelo Donghia. He wants more than that, and he's striking out in several directions all at once to get it.

title: Stewart Triumphs in Ohio CanAm Race
description: LEXINGTON, Ohio, Aug. 22 Jackie Stewart, the hardluck kid of the 1971 CanAm series, won a race today that was itself a hardluck derbythe Valvoline CanAm, 192 miles over the twisty MidOhio Sports Car Course.

title: EGYPT WILL TRY 91 ON TREASON CHARGES
description: CAIRO, Aug. 22Ninetyone former officials will be tried on charges of high treason for an alleged conspiracy last May against President Anwar elSadat, it was disclosed here today through publication of the indictment.

title: REBELS IN BOLIVIA CRUSH RESISTANCE AND INSTALL CHIEF
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 22An antiCommunist grouping of military and civilian leaders today crushed the last resistance from supporters of Gen. Juan Jose Torres Gonzales, the head of Bolivia's leftwing Government.

title: Rich Market Is Seen for U.S. Products
description: Eastern Europe offers a lucrative market for American textile technology and machines and possibly raw materials, according to Robert A. Levinson, chairman of Duplan Corporation, said last week. But assistance to these countries will require organization of an agency or company to coordinate a complete package that can be sold to them.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The following is, a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Henry of U.S. Retains Lead In World Dragon Class Sail
description: MEDEMBLIK, the Netherlands, Aug. 22 (AP)Bill Henry of the United States clung to his lead today in the general standing of the Dragon Gold Cub, the unofficial world championship in Dragon Class sailing.

title: GENTRY WINS 1OTH AIDED BY M'GRAW
description: Making his first start in 12 days following a back injury, Gary Gentry, the New York Mets righthander, hung on to pick up his 10th victory yesterday, defeating the San Diego Padres, 42, before a crowd of 24,834 at Shea Stadium.

title: Mediator's Effort Aids in Calming Camden
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 22At 4:30 A.M. yesterday, an aide of Gov. William T. Cahill telephoned the North Bellmore, L. I., home of Dr. Irving Goldaber, a sociologist noted for mediating community antagonisms in 30 cities.

title: OUTLOOK ON STEEL STIRS OPTIMISM
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 22The steel market outlook brightened last week.

title: Barbara Jean Gantz Is Married To Donald Klein, Law Student
description: Miss Barbara Jean Gantz, a senior at Finch College was married here yesterday to Donald Stuart Klein, a graduate of Lehigh University who is studying law at St. John's University. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony in the Versailles Room at the St. RegisSheraton Hotel.

title: Indonesian Colonel Held
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  A lieutenant colonel in the Indonesian Army and twothirds of his battalion have been arrested for alleged secret Communist ties, the Antara news agency reported today. Antara said the battalion commander had pledged his loyalty to the banned Indonesian Communist party in central Java in 1965.

title: Screen: Coutard Focuses on Vietnam in 'Hoa-Binh':Rhetoric of War Fades in Face of Reality Boy Left to Find Way in a Scarred World
description: Among cinematographers younger than 50 there is probably none more internationally famous or more justly famous than Raoul Coutard, who has photographed most of the greatest films of Franois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard. So highly is Coutard regarded that some critics unfriendly to the French New Wave have speculated that the real genius behind films like "Une Femme Est une Femme" and "La Chinoise" was the photographer and not the director at all. For this line of reasoning to be laid to rest, I suppose it would be necessary for Coutard to make his own movie, and this he has now done. It is called "Hoa-Binh," and it opened yesterday at the Lincoln Art Theater.In many respects it is very much a photographer's movie. Looking not at all like Truffaut or Godard, it is full of muted colors, striking images that seem to have been included for their own sake, and details held in splendid isolation  as the camera rather than the eye might see them. All of which gives "Hoa-Binh" a curiously old-fashioned and rather artlessly handsome look not entirely inconsistent with the moods of its storywhich is, however, set in the midst of the modern and unlovely reality of contemporary South Vietnam.Although it was made under the shadow of, and is necessarily about, the war in Vietnam, "Hoa-Binh" goes to almost excruciating lengths to avoid propagandistic persuasion. And although its locations are actual and its actors mostly amateur, it has a story, and its reality is the reality of fiction and not of documentary.The hero is named Hung, an 11-year-old boy whose father goes off to join the Vietcong and whose mother shortly afterward is hospitalized with terminal cancer. The sole protector of his baby sister, Hung soon leaves the unfriendly cousin with whom he has been placed and begins to make his way in the young-people's free-enterprise world of Saigon. He tries his hand at stevedoring and gambling, at which he does well; and at shoe-shining and newspaper-selling, at which he does badly.In general, the children's fortunes decline, but in the knick of time a nurse, a total stranger, takes them in, gives Hung shelter, gets him a job, and places the baby in a nursery. Meanwhile from the North, Hung's father begins a journey home, to deliver messages and to begin again with what is left of his family.I'm not sure that any movie based on a fiction so limited and, in a sense, so gratuitous, could be wholly satisfactory. "Hoa-Binh" adds to its simplicities a kind of hapless awkwardness in execution, in the mechanics of simply carrying a scene through. And at the same time it introduces ideological materiala humane justification of the American presence overheard from an Army sergeant while Hung shines his shoes; an organizer's lucid promise of Vietcong victory while United States jets roar overheadthat it is not really prepared to digest except in terms of obvious ironic illustration of the futility of high thought in a world of low feeling and of intensely personal privations.But "Hoa-Binh" ultimately succeeds beneath the play of ideology, and despite its structural crudities, and even despite the indulgences that Coutard sometimes allows his camera. For it is a deeply honorable work, as honorable in its refusal to place blame as in its decency in the face of human suffering. In this it achieves a moral reticence that approaches asceticism and that is as beautiful to watch in the movies as anywhere else.You can see it most clearly perhaps in the lovely performances of Phi Lan as Hung and Xuan Ha as his young mother. If you watch their eyes you will see that their looks and glances, wonderful in themselves, are used not to externalize suffering and so engage the audience's sympathy, but to communicate and so build a world of shared understandingeven though that understanding may include not only love but also fear and hate.The result is a self-sufficiency that begs no responses, but that is moving in some of the ways that film can be movingwithout at the same time losing its bearings and pretending that it is life. Anyone can imagine a dozen movies about Vietnam, full of searing indictments and heartbreaking revelations. But "Hoa-Binh" is none of these. With all its faults it is something very much better, more complete, more secret, more genuinely in touch with the mysteries of human perception.

title: Paris: Memories of avichy childhood
description: PARISPast crime is the spice of present tranquillity. Nothing makes the beach softer than a reminder of the bombs that exploded on it a quarter of a century ago. These reasons explain the current success of La Guerra a Neuf Ans (War at Nine), a slight volume by Pascal Jardin, typical of midsummer literature. A childhood in Vichy makes a good story if the child's father happens to be the Chief of Cabinet of Premier Pierre Laval. The book provides a number of vivid thumbnail sketches of life in the Victorian spa, which, overnight and for less than four years, served as the capital of occupied France.

title: BOLDER PROGRAM URGED FOR JAPAN
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 22  A bolder and less political international economic posture should be adopted by Japan, American businessmen told their Japanese counterparts here this weekend. The yen should be revalued upward, the Americans said, but that is not enough.

title: Agnew Says He Is Not Worried About Talk of Being Replaced
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) Vice President Agnew said today that he was not bit worried about talk that Treasury Secretary John B. Connally, a Democrat, might replace him at President Nixon's running mate next year.

title: Giants Catch It After Game, Too
ACCORD ON BERLIN EXPECTED TODAY
description: BONN, Aug. 22The envoys of the four powers responsible for Berlin are expected to complete drafting an agreement on improving conditions of the divided city tomorrow. They are to meet in the West Berlin residence of the American Ambassador, Kenneth Rush.

title: U.S. Reports 2 Attacks on Bases in North Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (AP)A United States command spokesman said that American planes made two strikes at antiaircraft and missile bases inside North Vietnam today.

title: SOUTHGATE OPEN TO PAM BARNETT
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 22 (AP) Pam Barnett of Charlotte;. N.C., scored her first tournament victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today by shooting a fourunderpar 68 in the $20,000 Southgate open.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO PLAN NO NEW LANSKY VISA
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 22 (AP)Usually informed sources said today that the Government had decided against extending the tourist visa of Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial leader, who has been living in Israel for the last 13 months.

title: Shaw Lifts Bills to Victory In Heisman Trophy  Game
description: O. J. Simpson and Jim Plunkett, the Heisman Trophy winners in two of the last three years, met for the first time as highly paid and heralded pro football stars as the Buffalo Bills beat the New England Patriots, 2814, at Buffalo yesterday.

title: An Antiquated Balance of Power
description: Shortly after he assumed the Presidency, Mr. Nixon said, I want to emphasize that we believe it is possible to control inflation without increasing unemployment in, certainly, any substantial way. And he added that he would not try to accomplish that feat by urging labor leaders or businessmen to restrain their wage and price decisions, because much as these men might personally want to do what is in the best interests of the nation, they have to be guided by the interests of the organizations they represent.

title: GUERRILLAS BOMB PRISON IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 22 (AP)  Guerrillas blasted in the main doors of Belfast's Crumlin Jail today despite the presence of a strong police and army guard.

title: Futures Trading Is Clarified
description: New York and Chicago commodity exchanges have dispelled most of the confusion about the status of their trading operations under the Government's price freeze, mainly through their own initiative, not Washington's.

title: American Bride of Russian Stays in Soviet to Seek Visa
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (AP)Mrs. Valery Krenniov, formerly Debbie Brackman of Great Neck, N. Y., who has been doing battle with Soviet bureaucrats since her marriage to a Russian last Tuesday, said farewell today to the 70 United States students she came to Leningrad with in July on an exchange program.

title: A Church Study Finds a Conspiracy
description: The killing of four students at Kent State now stands as a classic example of justice delayed, circumvented and mocked. Very few tragedies like this are so extensively photographed, and very few occur in conditions where so many witnesses are able to provide investigators with so much invaluable information. Unlike the inexcusable shootings at South Carolina State in 1968, and Jackson State in 1970, the killing at Kent State took place in broad daylight beneath a brilliant sun. Consequently, we have an almost stepbystep record of what happened on May 4, 1970, and this record suggests that the shooting began as the result of a planned and prearranged act involving a certain number of guards men.

title: CURRENCIES FACE CLOUDED OUT LOOK IN TRADING TODAY
description: LONDON, Aug. 22,Confused and indecisive trading is expected tomorrow when European foreign exchange markets reopen with a hodgepodge of fixed and floating exchange rates.

title: Slain Storekeeper's Mourners Grim
description: A grim procession of several hundred angry Jewish mourners followed the body of Beno Spiewak yesterday through the East Flatbush neighborhood where he was murdered in his candy store Friday.

title: Advertising:
description: As the first shock waves of President Nixon's wageprice freeze fall over the advertising community, policies as to individual and corporate postures are beginning to be set. Many people in the field believe that the attitudes of agencies will be allimportant in this regard and the various media are waiting for those attitudes to jell as they prepare their own positions.

title: Guerrillas Kill 2 G.I.'s
description: SAIGON, Monday, Aug. 23 (Reuters)Two American soldiers were killed and four wounded whon their armored cavalry unit Vms attacked by some 30 guerrillas about 20 miles northwest of Saigon, a United States military spokesman said today. The Americans were protecting bulldozer crews knocking down trees beside Highway 1 yesterday afternoon.

title: U.S. Auto Men See Unfairness In Tokyo's ExportImport Policy
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22 Total Tora! Tora!, a vice president of the Ford Motor Company said last Monday, would be appropriate for the occasion. He had a smile on his face.

title: MAN TEAM WINS FROM U.S. IN FINAL
description: HAVANA, Aug. 22  The United States volleyball players met Fidel Castro tonight, but they also met their match in superb., squad of Cubans, who won a berth to the 1972 Olympics Games with a thriling victory over the Americans.

title: The Floating Dollar
description: When the foreign exchange markets reopen in Europe today the world will be launched upon an experiment that once was considered only the wild dream of economistsa floating international monetary system. Almost incredibly for a conservative Republican President, Mr. Nixon has suspended convertibility between the dollar and gold and is permitting supply and demand in world markets to determine the value of the dollar. And if the dollar is floating, the world monetary system is floating.

title: Ancient Statue and Bust Uncovered at Acropolis
description: ATHENS, Aug. 22 (AP)American and Greek archeologists digging in the royal colonnade at the foot of the Acropolis have found a marble statue of Hercules as an adolescent and a bust of the Roman Emperor Antoninus Pius.

title: Bridge: Sharif Plays CliffHanger But Eacapes Disaster in End
description: Omar Sharif who snatches any opportunity to play bridge afforded him by his filmmaking schedule, recently took part in a Swedish tournamentin Paris.

title: Midtown Driver Is Slain While Fleeing From Gunman
description: A 40yearold man was shot to death in midtown last night as he and his wife tried to speed away in their car from a couple that were apparently trying to rob them.

title: Campaigning Is a Family Affair for a Saigon Deputy
description: PHANRANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 17  Ton That Hieu, an antiGovernment Deputy running hard for reelection, knows what a man cannot say to the voters. He came back to his campaign headquarters yesterday with a dark red face and an uncertain step.

title: Chess: Forintos Wins Tournament In Memory of Countryman
description: Geza Forintos, a Hungarian international master, gained 11 of 15 points in winning a tournament held recently at Baja, Hungary, in memory of Dr. Lajos Asztalos. Vladimir Bagirov of the Soviet Union was second with 95, Viktor Ciocaltea of Rumania and Levente Lengyel of Hungary, the only grandmaster in the event, tied for third at 96.

title: Wallace Plans to Issue New Edicts on Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace said today he would issue additional orders next week against the busing of Alabama school children in a challenge to President Nixon to prove that he means what he says about busing.

title: Upturn Seen in Connecticut Economy, But Even Most Optimistic Are Wary
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 22Several signs of economic recovery have begun to appear in Connecticut.

title: Chief Welfare Inspector Is Named by Rockefeller
description: George F. Berlinger, vice chairman of the New York State Board of Social Welfare, was named by Governor Rockefeller yesterday as the state's first Welfare inspector General, with broad powers to investigate alleged frauds, inefficiencies and abuses in all state and local welfare operations.

title: Peking Says Nixon's New Policy Places Burden on the Workers
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 22Commenting today for the first time on President Nixon's new economic policies, Peking called them reactionary measures shifting the financial and economic crisis onto the workers.

title: U.S. Canoeists Win Title
description: DARTMOUTH, Nova Scotia, Aug. 22 (Canadian Press) Marsha Smoke of Washington, D. C., won all three women's events to lead United States to a 6044 victory over Canada in the North American canoe championships on Lake Banook. Americans won 8 of the 13 races.

title: Democrats Critical of Lindsay's Tour Style
description: Some influential Democrats say privately that they have warned Mayor Lindsay's top aides to tone down the campaignstyle inspection tours that the Mayor has been making almost daily, and step up the image of a hardworking, deskbound administrator. One leading Democrat went so far as to suggest that Mr. Lindsay begin daily cabinet meetings at 6 A.M., and receive daily productivity, and efficiency reports from his commissioners.

title: Ballet: 2 Join Dances
description: While he was creating Dances at a Gathering, Jerome Robbins explained to his cast that the people in the ballet were all friends. He might have added that they had better be, since they would end up having to learn most of one another's parts as well as their own. From the time the work was first presented two years ago, it has seen a variety of cast changes and distributions of parts of the choreography. Several occurred over the weekend at the State Theater as the New York City Ballet's Helgi Tomasson and Earle Sieveling made first appearances in the work.

title: REVISED IMPORTS BRING SURPRISES
description: In addition to the jolt given importers, the 10 per cent increase of import duties included in President Nixon's emergency economic measures has produced some surprises for consumers.

title: Shumway Gets Prize For Implant Research
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 22 (UPI)Dr. Norman Shuniway, the Stanford University heart surgeon, received today the Rene Leriche prize for research into heart transplantation, Tess, the official Soviet press agency said:

title: Boozer Rushes 110 Yards, Scores Two Before 70,874
description: NEW RAVEN, Aug. 22 In fulfilling Joe Namath's prophecy that they would kill the Giants, the Jets used the torture method today in a 2714 victory.

title: Americans Take Doubles
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 22 (AP)The doubles team of Mrs. Mary Ann Eisel Curtis and Valerie Ziegenfuss defeated Britain's sistercombination of. Mrs. Christine Janes and Nell Truman today, 61, 64, and evened the sevenmatch Wightman Cup tennis competition, 22. The concluding matches will be played tomorrow.

title: SUSPECT IN SLAYING OF POLICEMAN NAMED
description: Queens detectives yesterday released the name of one of the Brooklyn youths sought for questioning in the murder on Friday evening of Patrolman Kenneth Nugent during the holdup of a Queens luncheonette.

title: Carol Shoshkes, Student, Married
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 22Miss Carol Joyce Shoshkes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Shoshkes of South Orange, was married here this afternoon to Paul Michael Petigrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman 13. Petigrow of Maplewood.

title: Underground ATest Is Still Set For Aleutians but Is Not Final
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 The Nixon Administration is pressing ahead with plans to explode a nuclear warhead in the Aleutian Islands despite the pleas of some scientists and ecologists that the test is either unneeded or harmful to the environment.

title: Jackson Called Blacks'
description: George Jackson was often described as a symbol, and he was. For, many blacks, he was a clear reflection of the rising tide of discontent that they now hold with the judicial system as a whole.

title: INDIANS'
description: PUYALLUP, Wash., Aug. 22  A demonstration by nonIndians against special fishing rights for Indians was conducted peacefully in the Puyallup River just west of here today.

title: Most in Urban Study Favor End Of Church and School Tax Relief
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22A survey of people living in 10 cities shows that a majority favors removing the taxexempt talus of churches and private schools and colleges.

title: Henderson CourtMartial Scheduled to Begin Today
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 22 (AP)The courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson, accused of willfully failing to investigate reports of the Mylal killings, will open tomorrow before seven senior officers.

title: CRENSHAW GETS 280, WINS AMATEUR GOLF
description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Aug. 22 (AP)Ben Crenshaw of Austin, Tex., converted a twostroke deficit into a twostroke victory today in the Eastern Amateur golf tournament when Joey Dills of Muskogee, Okla., faltered on the 18th hole with a double bogey six.

title: Refugee Count Rises in India
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 22 (UPI) The number of East Pakistani refugees who have entered India is believed to have reached eight million, Govern ment officials said today.

title: BLACK CATHOLICS SEEK ARCHBISHOP
description: DETROIT, Aug. 22  Black Roman Catholic priests and lay leaders announced here today that they would provide a black archbishop for the Archdiocese of Washington.

title: To Say That Girdles Are Doomed May Be Stretching the Point
description: Is the girdle going the way of the whaleboned corset? Or the pushup bra of the forties? Or the waistcincher of the fifties?

title: Copter Crash Kills U.S. Pilot
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  A United States Army helicopter crashed near Bad Brueckenau in northern Bavaria yesterday and the pilot was killed and a crew member and a passenger were seriously hurt. It was the second Army helicopter to crash in West Germany in four days. On Wednesday. 37 soldiers were killed in the midair explosion and crash of a helicopter.

title: Ewbank Proud Thompson Didn't Swing at Tarkenton
description: NEW HAVEN, Aug. 22For a man who is the son of a Methodist minister and who was named after the first Methodist missionary to this country, Francis Asbury Tarkenton gets into a lot of trouble with the Jets.

title: Political Coalition That Elected Mayor and 3 Councilmen in Berkeley Is Suffering Deep Divisions
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22 Deep disagreements have appeared in the political coalition that succeeded last spring in electing a mayor and three members of the City Council here.

title: Archeologists Find a Roman Imperial City Under a Yugoslav, Market Town
description: SREMSKA MITROVICA, Yugoslavia, Aug. 19Along Matije Gupca Street, a quiet residential thoroughfare in this undistinguished market town, the back gardens are full of halfnaked Americans and Yugoslays digging for an imperial Roman city that vanished 1,400 years ago.

title: MURPHY CAUTIONS TOPLEVEL AIDES A SHAKEUP IS DUE
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he was fed up with the inadequate response of most of his 235 top commanders to his order that they root out corruption in the department.

title: BROADWAY TOASTS PROFIT FOR 197071
description: Broadway shows made a profit of $1,888,198 during the 197071 season, it was announced yesterday by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. The Attorney General's statistical summary of the season was based on 69 Broadway productions registered with his office. This included shows running in New York during the year ending May 31, 1971, and also previous Broadway productions receiving income from road companies and other

title: Analysts Hail Nixon's Move
description: President Nixon's new economic policy should produce substantial acceleration in domestic business activity, whatever turmoil it leads to in the international money markets.

title: Pentagon: No Sale
description: In the wake of The Selling of the Pentagon, the revealing television documentary produced by the Columbia Broadcasting System, the Defense Department went to great lengths to deny that military personnel had in fact violated longstanding regulations prohibiting officers from engaging in political propaganda. The Pentagon maintained that the officers shown, apparently beating the drum for Administration military and foreigh policy, had been quoted out of context.

title: Two Quebec Villages in the Path Of New jetport Await Their Doom
description: STE. MONIQUE, QuebecThe people of this village 25 miles north of Montreal have draped a huge banner across the front of their church heralding the 100th anniversary of the town's founding.

title: Guerrilla Raid in Pakistan
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Aug. 22 (AP)East Pakistan secessionist forces attacked and set ablaze a police station and another government building in Holhajang, 30 miles from here, according to reports reaching here today. The reports said that the guerrillas made government forces retreat after fierce gunbattle Friday night. They then moved into the two buildings and burned them to the ground.

title: Adrienne Koch, Historian, Dies; Wrote on America of 17651815
description: Dr. Adrienne Koch, professor, scholar and historian of America's formative years, died Saturday of cancer in Doctors Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: REV. CHARLES CLARK, REGO PARK PASTOR
description: The Rev. Charles J. Clark, pastor of ResurrectionAscension Roman Catholic Church in Rego Park, Queens, since 1967, died Saturday in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, LI., apparently of a heart attack. His age was 58.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD PRODUCTION GAINS IN PAR EAST
description: ROME, Aug. 22The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization reported today that total food production in the Far East was rising at a rate comfortably ahead of the population growth.

title: SEALYHAM TAKES ANNAPOLIS BEST
description: SANDY POINT, Md.Ch. Jenniis' Dougal, a 4yearold Sealyharn terrier was Judge Donald M. Booxbaum's choice today as best in show at the Annapolis Kennel Club's 20th all breed event.

title: Chinese Reds in Bucharest
description: VIENNA, Aug. 22 (UPI)A high Chinese Communist military delegation arrived in Bucharest today for talks with Rumanian leaders. The Rumanian press agency, Agerpress, said the delegation was led by Li Tehsheng, an alternate member of the Politburo of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party and chief of the political department of the Chinese People's Liberation Army.

title: Finding Exotic Wares From Faraway Places
description: The melting pot characteristics of this city are evident not only in the variety of foreign restaurants or the babble of languages one hears on the street, but also in the collections of ethnic handicrafts one finds in more and more shops and department stores. Israeliborn Ehud Kavish and his Americanborn wife, Naomi, had come to the conclusion last spring that one thing New York lacked was a shop devoted entirely to the crafts of Israel. So they opened their Galit Galleries in April, on the parlor floor of a brownstone at 246 East 51st Street, where, in an attractive setting they designed themselves, they offer a cross section of handmade Israeli objects. Among the wares are pottery, wall hangings, glass, jewelry and metalwork. In the back of the shop is another space devoted to paintings, graphics and sculpture.

title: ECOLOGY REPORTS CRITICIZE MINES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22The United States Bureau of Mines has just published two reports that are bluntly critical of practices in the coal industry that the agency says have injured the health or shortened the lives of thousands of persons and caused millions of dollars in damage to private property.

title: City's Workers Top Industry's in Pay
description: A Federal survey has indicated that New York City's municipal maintenance workers have averaged pay rates well above private industry'smore than 60 per cent higher for carpenters, electricians and plumbers, and 36 per cent higher for automotive mechanics and painters.

title: TALLADEGA 500 WON BY BOBBY ALLISON
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 22 (AP)  Bobby Allison threaded his way through an early traffic jam, survived a lastlap wreck by Pete Hamilton and then beat Richard Petty across the finish line by 2.1 seconds today to win the Talladega 500 stockcar race.

title: Rebels Attack Burmese Base
description: RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 22 (Reuters)  Five Burmese soldiers were killed and an ammunition carrier was destroyed when 100 leftwing rebels attacked an army base southeast of here, the newspaper Guardian reported today. The paper said the rebels, equipped with bazookas, lost three killed and many wounded during the twohour clash about 150 miles from the capital.

title: 14YearOld Wins Golf Title
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 22 (AP)  Nancy Lopez, 14 years old, won her third straight New Mexico women's golf title yesterday, defeating Mrs. Donna Sauve, 13 and 12, in a 36hole match play final.

title: New York Pair Wins Title In World Tempest Sailing
description: MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 22 (AP)Glen Foster and Peter Dean of New York won the world championship today in the new Olympic Tempest Class, finishing second in the concluding race. The winners collected 45.7 points.

title: Israel Honoring Lipchitz With 2 Sculpture Shows
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 22 A young artist is pursued by Furies; an old artist is pursued by questions. Jacques Lipchitz, a giant of modern sculpture, has kept well ahead of both in his 80 years.

title: Manila Holds 3 in Blasts
description: MANILA, Aug. 22Luzvimindo David, secretary general of the Maoist Kabataang Makabayan (Patriotic Youth), and two men who said they were a radio and television commentator's bodyguards were held for questioning today about the explosions that killed 10 persons and injured 74 at a political rally last night.

title: 4 Safe on Damaged Plane
description: MIAMI, Aug. 22 (AP)An amphibious aircraft with four persons aboard lost one of its floatation pontoons today when it hit the wake of a boat in Biscayne Bay during a takeoff for Miami the Coast Guard said. All aboard abandoned the craft without injury and rowed to shore in a rubber dinghy.

title: Karen Kuhn Bride Of Stuart Troyan
description: Miss Karen Joyce Kuhn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kuhn of Lawrence, L.I was married here last evening to Stuart Alan Troyan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexamtk Troyan of Bayswater, Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: PERCY RAPPAPORT, ACCOUNTANT, DIES
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 22Percy Rappaport; retired partner of the international accounting firm of Price Waterhouse Sc Co., who had Served as Assistant Director of the Bureau of the Budget from 1955 through 1957, :died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 7 Greenview Way.

title: Alvarez Wins Utica Tennis
description: UTICA, N. Y., Aug. 22Lito Alvarez of Argentina defeated Steve Turner of New York, 61, 64, 75, today to win the Utica satellite tennis tournament. Alvarez and Turner qualified for the United States Open to be held at Forest Hills Sept 1 through 12.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Joint meeting of Special Committee on Apartheid, Special Committee on Colonialism and Council for Namibia (SouthWest Africa) 3 P.M.

title: Personal Finance
description: New attitudes about morals and the fight against sex discrimination have led to some interesting changes for young people to realize. There are also some eye openers for businessmen in dealing with women employes.

title: A Gun Battle With Police Ends Weapons Raid on Coast Store
description: HAWTHORNE, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)A burglar alarm foiled a weapons raid on a war surplus store last night and set off a 25minute gun battle between the police and six raiders, including two women.

title: POLK COUNTY WINS 2 HUNTER CROWNS
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 22 Polk County, a 6yearold bay gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Busk Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., scored a double today at the closing session of the 77th Monmouth County horse show.

title: Advertising:
description: Anyone familiar with the glorious taste of the 3.2 beer served to our nation's servicemen on post will thrill to the memories recalled in a new ad campaign by Winters National Bank and Trust Company of Dayton, Ohio.

title: Une de Mai Owners Find U.S. Dollars a Good Bet
description: Roosevelt Raceway handed Count Pierre de Montesson and Pierre D. Allaire a check for $62,500 Saturday night, and the Frenchmen didn't mind at all receiving American dollars during this period of international monetary turmoil.

title: FUQUA SEEKS MAKER OF SPORTING GOODS
description: Fuqua Industries, Inc., a diversified concern based in Atlanta, announced last night that it had agreed in principle to exchange Fuqua common stock worth about $9.3million to acquire the Ajay Enterprises Corporation.

title: U.S. Drops War Briefing
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 (UPI)The United States command in Vietnam did not send a spokesman to the Sunday allied war briefing for the first time in more than six years, citing poor attendance. Correspondents at the session protested what they called an arbitrary decision by the command to abolish the Sunday briefings.

title: Guns for Sale
description: In Brooklyn, a gun killed a sixtyyearold candy store owner because he could not fill the gunman's order for apple pie. In Queens, a plainclothes policeman was shot to death in an attempt to foil a luncheonette holdup. In the Bronx, a hotel manager was slain by a disgruntled guest in a dispute over a room key. In Manhattan, a patrolman, called to settle a dispute, escaped death only because a gun pointed at his back misfired. Beno Spiewak, the Brooklyn murder victim, had survived the horrors of a Nazi concentration camp only to be cut down by the horror, of a society gone guncrazy.

title: Japanese Admit Their Easing Is Going at Too Slow a Pace
Texas Governor May Go to High Court on Pay Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22Gov. Preston E. Smith of Texas said today that he would go to the Supreme Court if necessary to protect from President Nixon's wageprice freeze the pay rises scheduled for his State employes on Sept. 1.

title: Environment Bills Stalled By Legislative Lobbyists
description: For the third year in a row environmental bills by the hundred were introduced in state legislatures across the country, but this year the bills ran into more determined opposition, mainly from industry lobbyists.

title: Teacher's First Real Vacation Ends in Tragedy
description: Stephen Borg was a junior high school science teacher who very seldom took a vacation be cause his father, a dairy farmer, was ailing and in his spare time Mr. Borg had to help on the farm in Mansfield, Pa., near where he lived.

title: NCNB Plan Approved
description: The NCNB Corporation, par ent company of the North Caro lina National Bank, Charlotte, said yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved formation of its previously an nounced joint investmentadvis ory venture with Calvin Bul lock, Ltd., of New York.

title: Saigon Troops Claim 37
description: SAIGON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)A South Vietnamese armored column ran into a strong North Vietnamese force one mile out side a fire base near the de militarized zone yesterday and killed 37 enemy soldiers in a fierce engagement, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said today. Government losses were put at four killed and 25 wounded.

title: ALBERTO G. ANTOLINI, ALLIED AIDE IN ROME
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 23Alberto G. Antolini, who headed the economic section of the Allied Control Commission for Italy in the final year of World War II, died yesterday in Highland Park Hospital. He was 65 years old and had re cently returned from Italy to the Chicago area, where he had been general manager of the central division of Bigelow Sanford, Inc., at his retirement in 1968.

title: Masiello, on Bail in Two Cases, Convicted of Bribing I.R.S. Man
description: John A. Masiello, described in the past by Federal and state officials as an alleged Mafia member, was convicted by Federal Court jury yesterday of bribery and conspiracy to bribe an Internal Revenue Service agent.

title: MURPHY TO CHECK ON AIDES'
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday ordered the 172 top commanders of the Police Department to fill out threepage questionnaires about their personal finances.

title: Deceit Laid to Colonel at Trial In CoverUp of Mylai Killings
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 23  Col. Oran K. 1Tenderson, the highest ranking Army officer to face a courtmartial on charges arising from the killings at Mylai 4, was described today as a man who followed a pat tern of deceit in trying to cover up the mass slaying.

title: Woman Strangled at Stamford; 5th Victim There in 3 Years
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 For the fifth time in the last, three and a half years, the body of a woman strangled with a brassiere has been found near the Merritt Parkway here.

title: Heart Attack Fells Chief
description: OCEAN GROVE, N. J., Aug. 23Police Chief David Lake died of an apparent heart at tack here this morning as he was chasing an unidentified man suspected of having broken into a hotel. He was pro nounced dead at Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. Chief Lake was 60 years old and had suffered from a heart condition. He headed the police force here for the last 10 years.

title: Jean Sauvagnargues
description: PARIS, Aug. 23In Jean Sauvagnargues, France has had a well prepared negotia tor on Berlin. Though he has been ambasasador in Bonn only since last year, Mr. Sau vagnargues interest in and knowledge of things German go back to his student days when he received a degree in German language and litera ture from the prestigious Ecole Normale Superieure.

title: Physicals Go On Despite Draft Lapse
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Selective Service System said today that it would begin giving preinduction physical examinations Sept. 1 to about 250,000 19yearolds who drew numbers 1 thruogh 50 in the Aug. 5 lottery for the 1972 draft.

title: South African Trial Adjourns
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  The trial on terrorism charges of the Anglican Dean of Johannes burg, the Very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh, was adjourned today until Sept. 7. The dean, 59 years old, faces 10 charges under the sweeping Terrorism Act, including supplying money to banned persons and groups.

title: Abrams Endorses Bid by McGovern For'72 Nomination
description: Senator George McGovern's, candidacy for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination was endorsed yesterday by Bronx Borough President Rob ert Abrams, who pledged him self all the way, regardless of Mayor Lindsay's possible can didacy.

title: U.S.TOPS BRITAIN AT INIGHTMAN NET
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (AP) Sixteenyearold Chris Evert, her backhand devastating, broke five of Virginia Wade's seven serves today and scored suprisingly easy 61, 61 deci sion over Britain's top woman tennis player to give the United States the Wightman Cup for ;the 36th time in 43 years.

title: City Police Test Copter for Patrol Duty
description: The green and white heli copeter swung out from Fort Wadsworth Army base yester day, dipping and banking over the tree shaded lanes and backyard swimming pools of the 120th precinct in Staten Island, on the first day of the Police Department's search andapprehend mission direct ed at auto thieves, car strippers and house breakers.

title: Moving on Police Corruption
description: Police Commissioner Murphy, step by step, has clearly committed himself to the long, hard fight to change the unhealthy climate that has permitted corruption to flour ish within the New York City Police Department. The evidence of his commitment has steadily accumulated.

title: 6 Coal Miners Sue U.S. on Disability Examination
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23  A group of disabled Kentucky coal miners sued the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare here today in an at tempt to force the Social Se curity Administration to end a restrictive physical exami nation that the miners say has denied Federal disability bene fits to thousands of miners with symptoms of lung disease.

title: Aid to the Campuses
description: In its prevacation rush, the Senate cleared the most extensive measure ever proposed to aid higher educa tion. The $16billion authorization points the way toward substantial subsidies for students and institutions. promises to avert a disastrous decline in the economic and academic strength of America's colleges.

title: Statehood Proposal for City Assailed in Report
description: Proposals that New York City become the 51st state were de scribed as fraudulent, irre sponsible and a hoax in a report prepared by Governor Rockefeller's Division of the Budget in Albany.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Blueprint for a Great Depression

title: Dollar Shows a Moderate Rally In Cautious Transactions Here
description: The dollar rallied in mod erately active trading in the New York foreignexchange market yesterday. Dealers de scribed the trading as cau tious and probing. They warned that it was still far too early to make any judg ments about the pattern of for eignexchange rates that would emerge from the current period of turmoil in world markets in which most of the principal cur rencies are floating in rela tion to each other.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Drops to 5Year Low
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23 (UPI)United States troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 2.800 men last week to a fiveandonehalfyear low of 220,100. The mili tary command confirmed to day that the Seventh Fleet force off the coast had also been cut hack.

title: Wage and Price Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Following is the fourth set of official questions and an swers issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90 day freeze on wages and prices:

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS VOLUME GAINS
Three Missing Girls Found
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H. Aug. 23 (UPI)Three young girls, who became lost over night while hiking on Snow's Mountain, were found un harmed today. They are iden tified as Amy Sosman, 11 years old, of Lexington, Mass., and Kathy and Diana Munson, 10, of Westport, Conn.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Inflation's Vanguard

title: Market Place: Dollar Averaging In Fund Buying
description: There's a saying in Wall Street that mutual funds are sold, not purchased. What they mean by that is that most of us don't run down to our corner securities deal er and beg him to sell us the Up Up and Away Fund not since the bear market, anyway.

title: Nixon Plan May Prove a Bonanza for Metals
description: It became increasingly clear yesterday that President Nixon's new economic program, at least in its early stages, could be an even larger bo nanza for American pro ducers of most basic metals than analysts originally had estimated.

title: DOLLAR IS STRONG AS MONEY TRADING RESUMES ABROAD
description: LONDON, Aug. 23 The United States dollar held its own today as European foreignexchange markets re opened, after having closed in reaction to President Nixon's economic pronouncements of Aug. 15.

title: STEELERS BEATEN BY BENGALS, 2013
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (AP)Cincinnati scored four of the first five times they had the ball tonight and the Bengals defense held off a Pittsburgh, Steelers rally for a 2013 Na tional Football League presea son victory.

title: E.E.C. TO URGE U.S. TO SHIFT SPENDING
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 23The European Common Market will tell the United States tomor I row that it cannot expect to I solve its balanceofpayments problem simply by running surplus on its trade with the rest of the world.

title: Mr. Nixon's Choice in Vietnam
description: Expressions of deep regret are scarcely a sufficient response by the White House to the political bungling by President Thieu, which now leaves him embarrassingly unopposed in South Vietnam's presidential election. What is needed is the kind of fresh thinking and bold reversal of established policy that President Nixon has exhibited recently in his approach to China and the economy.

title: 2 Men Given 5Year Terms In Selling of Stolen Stocks
description: A Georgia lawyer and Brooklyn man each got fiveyear prison sentences in Man hattan Federal Court yesterday for conspiring to market $350, 000 worth of stolen stocks.

title: Canada and U.S. to Confer
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 23 (UPI)Canadian and United States Finance and Treasury Depart ment officials are to meet in Washington in a few days to discuss Canada's bid for ex emption from the new United States 10 per cent import sur charge, Finance Minister Edgar Benson said today.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Pearl Harbor Remembered

title: City Educator Named To Virgin Islands Post
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Aug. 23  Gov. Melvin H. Evans announced today the appointment of Dr. Harold C. Haizlip, director of the New itincoln School, a private school in New York City, as Commissioner of Education for the United States Virgin Islands.

title: Judge Orders Charity Gift
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 23 (UPI) A man convicted of income tax evasion was told today by United States District Judge Timothy S. Hogan to contribute $20,000 to charity during the next two years. Judge Hogan had originally sentenced John F. Wetterich to three years in prison but later suspended the term and placed him on proba tion on condition that he give $20,000 to charity.

title: Bonn Welcomes Agreement
description: BONN, Aug. 23The West German Government today welcomed the draft Berlin agreement. The four re sponsible powers have earned our respect for what they have achieved, Foreign Mini, ster Walter Scheel declared in a statement..

title: East Bloc Hopeful
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 23East Eu ropean officials view the Berlin agreement as an essential step toward the convening of a long sought European security con ference.

title: Bridge
description: The Summer National Championships of the Ameri can Bridge Association, the organization for black play ers, ended Sunday in Phila delphia and was one of the biggest tournaments in the association's 39year history.

title: SECURITY PARLEY HELD SOVIET AIM
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23The Big Four agreement on Berlin was regarded by Western diplomats today as a sign of Soviet will ingness to make significant concessions to gain Western support for a European security conference and other Soviet efforts to reduce tensions in Europe.

title: New Park Fountain Is Spray Thing and a Play Thing
description: The city's newest piece of playground equipment, a water spray for children that also serves as a decorative park fountain, was unveiled yesterday in Jackson Square Park at Eighth Avenue and Horatio Street by Parks Ad ministrator August Heck scher.

title: Leikowitz Proposes Guidelines On Conversion to Cooperatives
description: The office of State Attorney General Louis S. Lefkowitz has proposed a new policy designed to clarify the methods by which tenants may initiate negotia tions with landlords to convert their residences to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: PATRICK J. HICKEY
description: Patrick J. Hickey, who re tired as deputy collector of customs in the warehouse divi sion of the Port of New York in 1963, died Sunday in Mon ticello, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived at 199 Fenimore Street, Brooklyn, and in Small wood, N.Y.

title: Kilted Champion Arrives for Bout
OBSERVER
description: He adds that the number of soldiers there now is already well below quarter million, that it will be 184,000 or lower by Dec. 1 and that the re maining American troops will continue to engage in fighting when necessary to protect American lives.

title: ULSTER CATHOLICS AND DUBLIN START UNIFICATION DRIVE
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 23Premier John Lynch of the Irish Re public and opposition members of Northern Ireland's Parlia ment announced tonight a cam paign of civil disobedience to bring about the unification of Ireland.

title: U.S. Role Assailed
description: PARIS, Aug. 23The Viet cong delegation to the Paris peace talks charged today that tits Nixon Administration was attrying out a new electoral farce to maintain the warlike Nguyen Van Thieu group in power.

title: ACCORD ON BERLIN DRAFTED BY BIG FOUR AMBASSADORS; EASING OF TENSIONS IS SEEN
description: BERLIN, Aug. 23The Unit ed States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France reached an accord here today on the draft text of an agreement on the future of West Berlin.

title: Pacific Coast Reaction to Economic Program Is Mixed
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 20The cab driver, middleaged and stocky, glanced over his shoulder and asked:

title: Life and Death: 3 Hours Of a Policeman's Tour
description: A 29yearold patrolman de livered a baby boy in a dimly lighted Brooklyn tenement early yesterday and, six blocks away and less than three hours later, shot and killed a man brandish ing a gun as he fled from an other shooting.

title: Policeman and Friends Accused Of Securities Thefts of $237,218
description: A young New Hampshire policeman and two other men, brothers, both recent graduates of Fordham University and one of them a teacher at George Washington High School, were arrested yesterday on charges of defrauding a Wall Street brokerage concern of almost quarter of a million dollars.The Manhattan District At torney's office said that the three  all childhood friends from Staten Islandused series of aliases and false bank and stock accounts to steal total of $237,218 from Smith, Barney & Co., Inc., of 20 Broad Street on two different oc casions during 1968 and 1969.The men, all of whom are married, were scheduled to be arraigned in Manhattan Crimi nal Court. Leonard Newman, chief of the frauds bureau in the District Attorney's Office, said they were expected to plead not guilty and to be paroled in their own custody to await a hearing on Sept. 27.All three were charged with criminal possession of stolen property and falsifying busi ness records, both in the first degree, and grand larceny and forgery, both in the second degree. Each crime is punish able by up to seven years in prison.The key figure in the com plicated plot, Mr. Newman said, is 26yearold Robert Braine, of 16 Bowie Place, in Staten Island, who worked, while at tending night school at Ford ham, as supervisor of customer records at the brokerage com pany.The other two suspects are his younger brother, Ronald Braine, 24, of 269 Brehaut Ave nue, in Tottenville, S.L, who was also graduated from Ford ham in 1969, and who is now teaching English at George Washington High School, and James J. Cahalane, 26, a police man in Amherst, N.H., and a parttime student at the New Hampshire College in nearby Manchester.

title: Anniuersaries
description: BLOOMIrwin M. , Mary A. (Arkin) Ioy fully announce their 40th year of wedded bliss, celebrated on Aug. 23, 1971.

title: PUBLISHERS SEEK GUIDES ON FREEZE
description: Publishers have taken steps to freeze the prices on their backlists and on paperback re prints, but there is uncertainty in the book industry how to price new titles to conform to President Nixon's program to blunt inflation.

title: 24 Suffer Injuries At Westbury Track When Patrons Panic
description: More than two dozen per sons were injured last night when a Roosevelt Raceway crowd panicked and stampeded because of a loud, hissing noise as gas escaped from a carbon dioxide tank in a soft drink area.

title: Notre Dame Is Censured for Letting Football Coach Administer Aid Program
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) The National Collegiate Ath letic Association said today it had censured Notre Dame Uni versity for administration of its financial aid to studentathletes program.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23To many Americans, white and black, it will seem unlikely that the San Quentin prison authorities set up the killing of George Jackson, one of the so called Soledad Brothers, particularly since several guards also were killed. But many others, mostly black, per haps, but not a few of them white, will not find it hard to agree with his mother.

title: CHINESE MISSION VISITS RUMANIANS
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 23China has emphasized her sup port for Rumania at a time of particular tension between Bu charest and Moscow by send ing a military delegation to visit Rumania.

title: TEENAGER INDICTED IN A BRONX SLAYING
description: A teenager described as member of a South Bronx youth gang known as the Savage Nomads was indicted yesterday by a Bronx grand jury on charges of murder and possession of illegal weapons in connection with the fatal stab bing last month of a 51yearold man.

title: 76 Enemy Dead Reported Found Alter B52 Raid Near the DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 24 (AP)United States B52 bombers have been credited with their first big success in the intensified bomb ing campaign against the at tacking North Vietnamese troops along South Vietnam's northern frontier.

title: 3 OneActers Open Oct. 27
description: Louis and the Elephant, three new oneact plays pre sented as a comic circus, will open here on Oct. 27 at an Off Broadway theater still to be selected. Eddie Lawrence, the actor and comedian, wrote the plays, to be staged by John Marley and produced by Edgar Lansbury, Stuart Duncan and Joseph Beruh in associatior with Nan Pearlman.

title: LICENSE RULING DIVIDES THE F.C.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Federal Communications Commission, recently ordered by the courts to give challenge applicants for broadcast li censes a fair competitive hear ing against established broad casters; has awarded a dis puted TV license in Moline, Ill., to a station that admitted ly failed to meet its own pro gram promises and tried to sell its license earlier for a quick $4.5million profit.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Nonresident small game hunters in New York State, who last year were com plaining bitterly that it cost them $35 each to go rabbit hunting, will be pleased to know that the fee for a smallgame license is now $18.

title: Pyotr Andreyevich Abrasimov
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 23 The Soviet representative at the Berlin negotiations speaks with considerably more au thority than the average Soviet envoy. Pyotr Andre yevich Abrasimov, who has spent nearly nine years as Ambassador to East Ger many, is a full member of the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee and is well acquainted with the top Kremlin leaders.

title: Emergency in Honolulu Declared in Dock Strike
description: HONOLULU, Aug. 23 (AP) Describing the 51dayold West Coast dock strike, as having placed a strangle hold on Hawaii. Mayor Frank F. Fasi declared a state of emergency in the city and county of Honolulu today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism, subcommittee on Caribbean territories  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: COURT ORDERS POLL ON UNIONS MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP)A Federal appeals court called today for a membership referendum on a proposed merger of District 50, Allied and Technical Workers union and the United Steelworkers.

title: QUAKER OATS NET SHOWS A DECLINE
description: Net income of the Quaker Oats Company, including ex traordinary charges, fell to $24,179,000, or $1.87 a share, in the fiscal year ended June 30.

title: OWNER IS ACCUSED OF BURNING HIS SHOP
description: The owner of a leather goods store on West 125th Street was arrested and charged with arson last night after a fire that started in his store spread to two adjacent stores.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Raise Duty 50%

title: City to Try New Litter Baskets
description: The city began an experi ment yesterday with three new types of streetlitter baskets to find out if there is a better way of containing trash than, in the old standard wiremesh baskets.

title: Threats Reported By Pennsylvanians In Hunger Dispute
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa. Aug. 23Adams County commissioners have reported being threatened with violence unless they adopt the Federal food stamp pro gram to feed 1,800 persons on public assistance and 1,200 Southern migrant and Puerto Rican fruit pickers.

title: BOND PRICES CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: Bond prices, which had started to sag late last week, staged a broad retreat yester day and interest rates moved up rather sharply.

title: Purchase of 2 Ward Stores Weighed
description: Alexander's, Inc., one of the metropolitan area's largest re tailers, is discussing the pos sible acquisition of two store properties that have been oper ated for some years by Mont gomery Ward in New Jersey. This was confirmed yesterday by a spokesman of Montgomery Ward & Co., who said, how ever, nothing has been final ized.

title: Experts on Computers Hear a Plea From Tito
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Aug 23President Tito asked computer scientists meeting here today to use their skills to liquidate man's problems, not his civilization, and called for a merging of the exact and humanistic sciences to build a better society.

title: Reordering Budget Priorities
description: The danger of a state's rights rebellion against Presi dent Nixon's wageprice freeze appears to have evapo rated. Decisions by Texas and Louisiana to go ahead with scheduled pay increases for teachers and other public employes have been canceled in response to warnings by their legal authorities that such defiance would make the states outlaws.

title: YANKEES LOSE, 82, TO A'S BUT FINISH SCORING DROUGHT
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 23The fact that the New York Yankees scored tonight was more noteworthy than the fact that they lost to the Oakland Athletics, 82, before of crowd of 4,972 in perfect weather.

title: Guns and Yeats
description: DUBLINBut it's no use, says he. Force, hatred, history, all that. That's not life for men and women, insult and hatred. And everybody knows that it's the very opposite of that that is really life.

title: Apollo 15 Thermometers Show Heat Rise Below Moon Surface
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)The temperature beneath the moon's surface increases about one degree per foot, two geolo gists reported today.

title: Big Board Fines 2 ExAmott Men $50,000 Apiece
description: The New York Stock Ex change disclosed yesterday that it had levied fines of $50,000 against each of two former registered representa tives and voting stockholders of Amott, Baker & Co., member firm that toppled into liquidation 20 months ago.

title: Robert Kennedy, 17, Fined for Loitering; Pleads No Contest
description: HYANNIS, Mass., Aug. 23 (UPDRobert F. Kennedy Jr., 17yearold son of the late New York Senator, was ordered to pay $50 in court costs on loitering charge today after he allegedly spat ice cream into a policeman's face. He was ar rested last night, about two weeks after his probation ended for a marijuana offense.

title: U. of California Adamant
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 22 (UPI)The University of Cali fornia refused yesterday to de clare two student athletes in eligible for the 197172 season in order to reduce an indefinite N.C.A.A. ordered probation to a period of one year.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Continental Corporation, parent of the Continental Insurance Companies, has elected Milton W. Mays president. He succeeds Nathan H. Went worth, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Mays will also continue as president of the Continental Insurance Companies, a post he has held since Dec. 1969.

title: Nixon Is Said to Have Told Chiang In April of Shift in China Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23President Nixon was reported today to have advised President Chiang Kaishek late last April that the United States planned to support the seating of Pe king in the United Nations this fall.

title: Astronauts to Receive City's Tribute Today
description: Col. David R. Scott, Lieut. Col. James B. Irwin and Major Alfred M. Worden, the Apollo 15 astronauts, ar rived in New York yester day and will be honored here today with a motorcade and a medal presentation at City Hall.

title: Strikers Bow to Freeze
description: LEHIGHTON, Pa., Aug. 22 (UPI)Citing President Nixon's wageprice freeze, about 150 striking teamsters voted Sunday to return to their jobs at Inter state Trucking without a new contract.. Al Abruzi, Local 773 president, said the teamsters voted 96 to 28 to end the strike, which began in July. He said the union had not accepted the company's latest offer but ne gotiations would continue.

title: Bay State Lottery Gains
description: BOSTON, Aug. 23 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate gave final approval today to a bill creating a state lottery. The 21 to 15 rollcall followed sev eral hours of debate during which a number of minor amendments were adopted.

title: Shuvee Wins at Spa and Raises Earnings to $801,818, a Record for Mares
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 23Shuvee elevated her self to the topmost rung of the filly and mare division in earn ings when she won the $44,100 Diana Handicap today.

title: Jury Recesses in Trial Of Rattenni and 3 Others
description: A jury deliberated for nearly two hours last night in the trial of Nicholas Rattenni and three other defendants charged with a loanshark conspiracy in Yonkers.

title: Cambodian Advance Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 23 (Reuters)  A military spokesman reported that Cam bodian troops, supported by air strikes, advanced northward today along Route 6 after hav ing killed 60 North Vietnamese in fierce fighting 60 miles from the capital.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE COLLECTED ESSAYS OF LESLIE FIEDLER. Two volumes. 562 and 560 pages. Stein and Day. $12.50 each volume.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: No Import Tax

title: Black Separatist Seized
