description: MEMPHIS, Aug. 23. (AP)A black militant who was being sought last week in (Jackson, Miss., when a gun duel between police and Ne groes broke out at the head quarters of the Republic of New Africa, was apprehended here tonight.

title: Warden Reports Jackson Concealed Gunin His Hair
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 23Stephen Mitchell Bingham, 29 years old, a product Milton Academy, Yale Univer sity, BoaIt Hall Law School the University of California, grandson of a Governor Senator, nephew of a United States Representative, was sought today for questioning about a gun.

title: Howard Freas, Chairman Of I.C.C. in '58, Dies at 71
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Howard G. Freas, a former chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission, died today of an apparent heart attack at a Bethesda, Md., hos pital. He was 71 years old.

title: Texas Bows to Pay Freeze As Governor Is Overruled
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 23The State Attorney General, Crawford C. Martin, ruled today that Gov. Preston E. Smith did not have the authority to set aside President Nixon's wage freeze order as it ap plied to state employes and teachers. Governor Smith said he would abide by Mr. Mar tin's ruling.

title: U. N.Women Are Too Diplomatic to Complain About Sex Bias
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Most women delegates look on their assignments at the United Nations as nearly ideal, but they also object that antifeminine feeling is alive and active here.

title: I.R.S. to Handle Calls On WagePrice Freeze
description: The Internal Revenue Serv ice announced yesterday that it had set up special metropolitan area telephone numbers for inquiries or complaints concerning Presi dent Nixon's 90day wage price freeze.

title: Imports of Apparel Seen as Continuing Despite Surcharge
description: The 10 per cent surcharge on imports will not stop the flow of apparel from abroad, Lazare Teper, research direc tor of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, said yesterday.

title: Danbury Bandit's Widow Is Given 10 Years in Prison
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 23 (AP) Nancy Pardue, widow of the Danbury bomber and bank rob ber, John R. Pardue, was sen tenced to 10 years in prison today for smuggling a sawed off rifle to her husband.

title: Lindsay Unit Set for New Hampshire
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A LindsayforPresident organ ization is now being organized in New Hampshire to enroll young voters and provide statewide support in an ex pected primary campaign, national organization of youth ful Lindsay supporters an nounced here today.

title: Big Board Appoints
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday the appointment of Vincent P. Moore Jr. as a vice president in its electronicsystems center, which develops and operates automation programs. Mr. Moore, 45 years old, will head the center's development de partment.

title: Roundup: Pizarro Defeats Reds, Just Like in 1960
description: Juan Pizarro beat the Cin cinnati Reds again yesterday 11 years later.

title: PANTHERS VIEWED AS INEFFECTUAL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) A divided House Internal Secu rity Committee described the Black Panthers today as rant ing revolutionary radicals to tally incapable of overthrowing our Government by violence.

title: eattle Broker Captures Dragon Gold Cup in Sailing
description: MEDEMBLIK the Nether nds, Aug. 23 (AP) Bill enry of Seattle won the Dra n Gold Cup, the international campionship in the Dragon Bing class, today.

title: YAHYA SEEKS DONORS TO STOCKPILE BLOOD
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 23 Pakistan's President, Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, has asked his countrymen to donate blood for all contin gencies, and political observ ers herb saw the appeal as veiled warning that war with India might be imminent.

title: GRAEBNER GAINS AT EASTERN NET
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 23Clark Grammer , of New york, the secondseeded player, advanced easily, but third ranked Tom Gorman Of Seat tle liad to struggle in a three set match today as the $20,000 Eastern grass courts open championships began at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: SEARS EARNINGS RISE TO RECORDS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the nation's largest generalmer chandise retailer, had record sales and earnings in the sec and quarter and half year ended July 31 on a sales gain of more than seven per cent. Earnings rose 18.1 in the quar ter and 15.4 per cent in the half over the respective year earlier periods.

title: I.T.T. SETTLEMENT OF SUIT FILED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reuters)The Justice Depart ment filed today proposed con sent judgments that, if approved by the courts, will end antitrust actions challenging the acquisi tion by the International Tele phone and Telegraph Corpora tion of the Canteen Corporation, the Grinnell Corporation and the Hartford Life Insurance Company. The court filings are in keeping with the settlement announced July 31.

title: JUDGE BACKS SUIT ON CAMPAIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 A Federal district judge dis missed today Democratic and Republican efforts to prevent Common Cause, the citizens lobby, from attempting to en force existing limits on cam paign contributions and spend ing.

title: JAPANESE DECIDE NOT TO FLOAT YEN
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 24Relieved by the relative sta bility shown by West European exchange markets yesterday, the financial authorities here have concluded that for the time being they can keep the Tokyo exchange open without, floating or revaluing the yen.

title: Unprecedented Challenge: Staging a Bernstein Mass
description: Gordon Davidson and Al vin Ailey, responsible for creating the stage action of Leonard Bernstein's new Mass, which opens the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washing ton on Sept. 8, paused to re flect on their work. They had been laboring for six days, and on the seventh they were busier than ever.

title: Apparatus to Administer the WagePrice Freeze Takes Shape Under Connally
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23After a week of confusion, the Government's apparatus for ad ministering the 90day freeze on wages and prices has begun to take shape.

title: SILVER PRICES OFF IN HEAVY TRADING
description: In a fairly heavy trading ses sion, silver futures closed 4 to 4.1 cents a troy ounce lower yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange.

title: Buffalo's Draft Raiders Explain Their Motivation
description: O.K. The war goes on. Viet namization is found to be an other lie. In a long statement opening with those words, the five persons arrested for raid1 ing a Selective Service office in Buffalo over the weekend, explained their motives yester day.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Allaying the Symptoms

title: Theater: Gorki's Enemies, Set Before Revolution, in London
description: LONDON  Whatever hap pened to Maxim Gorki? Here is a playwright who is very evidently one of the masters of the 20th century, yet in the West he is hardly known, and even in his native Rus sia he is still not very much performed. The reason for this neglect is perfectly evi dent. Gorki's idealistic form of socialism is hardly favored in East or West.

title: DR. WILLIAM W. CORT, PARASITOLOGIST, 84
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Aug. 23 Dr. William W. Cort, a para sitologist who played a leading part in the struggle against hookworm disease, died Satur day. He was 84 years old.

title: Legal Marijuana Opposed
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 23 (AP)Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie said today that there was no case for legalizing the use of mari juana and added that until the prohibition of marijuana ended there must be penalties. Mr. Ogilvie testified at a hearing of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse.

title: Campbell Was Quietly Recalling Contaminated Soup Before It Learned of Botulin
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A Food and Drug Administration official said today that the Campbell Soup Company had known a batch of its chicken vegetable soup to be contami natedbut not by botulin several weeks ago, but had not made a disclosure because it feared unfavorable publicity.

title: Marcos Suspends Rights of Suspects In Rebellion Cases
description: MANILA, Aug. 25  Presi dent Ferdinand E. Marcos, act ing today to stem what he called an armed insurrection fol lowing the bombing Saturday night of a Liberal party rally here, suspended the right of habeas corpus for all those ac cused of rebellion or insurrec tion.

title: U.S. REJECTS RISE IN PRICE OF GOLD
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Administration firmly re jected today a change by the United States in the official price of gold as part of a settle ment of the present interna tional monetary turmoil.

title: RESIDENTS FIGHT SITE FOR SCHOOL
description: Homeowners and business men threatened court action yesterday to block for four or five years the building of a new public school in the East New York section of Brooklyn if their property was selected for the school site.

title: Treasury Bills Yields Fall at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Gov ernment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: Bingham's Parents Say He Is Opposed To Violent Actions
description: SALEM, Conn., Aug. 23 (AP) Stephen M. Bingham, sought for questioning in connection with the San Quentin Prison shootout that left six dead, was described by his mother today as wholly committed to nonviolence. His father agreed.

title: Yields Are Illustrated For Connecticut Taxes
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 23Fol lowing is a table of the major tax increases in the bill Gov. ernor Meskill signed today, and their estimated annual yield:

title: NEW ARAB GROUPING CRITICIZED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reu ters)The State Department to day described as unfortunate a statement by the newly formed Federation of Arab Republics, consisting of Egypt, Libya and Syria, that it would not nego tiate with Israel.

title: Drama by Craft Scheduled
description: Out of Control, a play by Martin Craft depicting a con flict between a young criminal and a cynical lawyer, will open on Sept. 9 at the Actors Play house, 100 Seventh Avenue South. The producerdirector is Marlow Ferguson. A short com edy by Mr. Craft, The Marri age of the Telephone Company Man, will precede the drama.

title: Jobless Rate for Youths Rises to 17.3% in Summer
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The summer unemployment rate for youths edged up this year to 17.3 per cent although there were 100,000 more young people with jobs in the last two months than in the summer of 1970, the Labor Department said today. The Bureau of Labor Statistics said there were 2,365,000 jobless youths aged 16. to 21 during June and July, an increase of 280,000 over the same period in 1970. The num ber of youths with jobs rose to 11.3 million as the youth labor force increased by 390.000.

title: Advertising:
description: The going was great yes terday for Carl Ally, Inc., as it picked up the lion's share of the advertising account of Pan American World Airways.

title: NIXON AND PORTER TO CONFER ON PARIS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23President Nixon will con fer here tomorrow with his new chief delegate to the Paris peace talks, William J. Porter.

title: Giants Woe: Passive Resistance
description: The Giants aren't pushing the panic button, but they aren't pushing anything else eitheropposing players, for example and that's their trouble cuts in mind, Webster wants to get a better look at many of the newcomers.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Insurers Allowed Some Rate Rises Under New Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23A ruling by the President's Cost of Living Council today will allow insurance companies to raise premiums on the majority of casualty and liability policies on homes, automobiles and oth er property despite the 90day freeze on prices.

title: U.S. BOARD WILL ACT ON MORTGAGE RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The Federal Home Loan Bank Board served notice today that it would move against rises in mortgage interest rates as backup to President Nixon's new economic policies.

title: U.S. Women Bowlers Win
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (AP) The United States team rolled a record sixgame series of 4,656 today to win the four woman team title in the World Bowling Championships. Dixie Burmeister of Houston paced the victors with a 1,197 series featuring a 224 high game.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Toward Tariff Wars?

title: Advertising:
description: Two months after resigningas president and creative director of Richard K. Manoff, Inc., Hanno Fuchs was appointed to a new creative directorship. This time he's vice president of Grey Advertising and he'll be working on the most talkedabout account of the summerthe Ford Motor Company's Pinto, Maverick and Mustang lineswhich Grey won last week.

title: STOCKS MOVE UP AS VOLUME RISES
description: The Nixon rally was alive and well in Wall Street yester day.

title: Becks, in Brazil, Work Despite Trial
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, Aug. 23Early on each of the cool, clear mornings that mark this time of year on the Brazilian central plateau, Julian Beck and his wife, Judith Malina, begin a daily routine of work on what they call the most important proj ect yet undertaken by their Living Theater group.

title: John E. P. Morgan Dies at 76; Developed Sun Valley Ski Area
description: ST. PAUL. Aug. 23 (AP) John E. P. Morgan, designer of the first chair lifts for skiers and developer of the Sun Val ley, Idaho, ski area, died yes terday at Miller Hospital in St. Paul. He was 76 years old later was named Sun Valley. In designing the first chair lift, which went into operation in 1936, he modified an apparatus he had seen used to haul bana nas in Honduras.

title: State Offers Plan to Set Phone Service Rules
description: ALBANY, Aug. 23 (UPI)The Public Service Commis sion announced today a pro posal to establish minimum standards for telephone in stallation operation and main tenance that would include penalties in cases of non compliance.

title: KERKORIAN REPAYS HIS EUROPEAN LOANS
description: Kirk Kerkorian, the financier and controlling stockholder of Metro Goldwyn Mayer, Inc., and Western Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday that he fully repaid all his European bank loans on July 12 and Aug. 10 in accordance with pre viously stated plans.

title: Giants Triumph Over Mets, 54
description: The New York Mets survived Willie Mays and Willie Mc Covey last night but they didn't have too much luck with a 27yearold relief pitcher named Jerry Johnson, who sealed a 54 victory for the San Fran cisco Giants before 42,293 per sons in Shea Stadium.

title: Manhattan Life Sues Prudential, Charging an Antitrust Violation
description: The Manhattan Life Insur ance Company, a relatively small New York insurer, dis closed here yesterday that had filed an antitrust suit against the world's largest in surer, the Prudential Insur ance Company.

title: The Concorde Will Visit Latin Lands Next Montn
description: PARIS, Aug. 23The Con corde, the FrenchBritish super sonic airliner, will make its longest test flight when it goes looking for business in South America next month.

title: Tokyo Governor, Here on Visit, Asks Global Parley
description: Tokyo's Governor, Ryo kichi Minobe, visited City Hall here yesterday to pro pose a conference in Tokyo of chief executives of the world's major cities in 1972 or 1973 to discuss growing urban problems.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When Merlin Olsen was a rookie tackle on the Los Angeles Rams, the coach of the defensive platoon was Harland Svare, the onetime linebacker for the Giants. The Giants went West for an exhibition game and Svare was positively ecstatic about his prize pupil, Olsen. He made sound as if Olsen would singlehandedly demolish the Giant offensive line and smother all ballcarriers.

title: U.S. Officials Aligning Desegregation Steps With Nixon Antibusing Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23After a period of uncertainty and confusion, the Federal of ficials who deal with school desegregation are now moving to bring their actions in line with President Nixon's anti busing stance.

title: Honesty Instead of Coyness in BacktoSchool Clothes
description: It's that time of the year again. Any day now it will be September and time for school. Baby undoubtedly needs new shoes: also dresses and slacks and raincoats and everything else little boys and girls are made of. The parent who is reluctant to face the hurlyburly of shopping trip might quickly send for the cata logue of a mail order house call ed Under the Name of Sanders (825 West End Avenue, New York 10025, telephone 8663682). It's an attractively illustrated collection of clothes for chil dren up to size 8 and includes a few things for babies, too.

title: Riggins Wise No.1 Pick, Runner Convinces Jets
description: To the Jets firstround draft choice, happiness is having his name on the back of his green andwhite jersey.It's nice, John Riggins said. I never had my name on my jersey in college. And in the game, I heard some of the Giants saying, We're going to stop Riggins. It made me feel good. At least they knew who I was.But they weren't able to stop him easily. He rumbled for 73 yards in eight carries, a 9.1 average, in the Jets 2714 hum bling of the Giants before 70,874 fans at Yale Bowl on Sunday.When the Jets resume their exhibition schedule next Mon day night against the Chiefs in Kansas City, it will be a home coming for the 230pound run ning back from Centralia, Kan., who broke Gale Sayers's rush ing records at Kansas Univer sity.My parents and my two brothers will be there, he said. It's nice to be going home af ter coming off a good game.Until his speed and power ex ploded against the Giants, the ffoot2inch Riggins had skep tics wondering. Had the Jets made a mistake in choosing him ahead of all the other running hacks in the National Football League draft, notably John Brockington of Ohio State, now a starter with the Green Bay Packers?But in the exhibitions with the Detroit Lions and the Oak land Raiders Riggins was ad justing to the Jet offense after having spent a month with the College AllStar squad.

title: Podell Says Inquiries for an Airline Were Proper
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Aug 24  Representative Ber tram L. Podell said here today that he had made inquires to Government agency on behalf of a former client of his law firm, but denied any wrongdo ing in the matter.

title: 34 Die as Korean Prisoners Invade Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 23 A group of 23 prisoners from a South Korean Air Force stock ade invaded Seoul today and caused several hours of fear and confusion as the Govern merit initially mistook them for North Korean commandos.

title: Integon Corp. Is Canceling Rise in Quarterly Dividend
description: A dividend increase an nounced by the Integon Corpor ation on Aug, 4 has been can celed.

title: U.S.SOVIET TRIP IN SPACE STUDIED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The commander of America's Apollo 15 moon landing said today that the United States and the Soviet Union hoped to begin planning this fall for a joint flight.

title: SANDERSON LEADS QUALIFYING AT 71
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 23Tom Sanderson, a lean 6 footer from the inland Califor nia community of Escondido, was the only player to better par today in the qualifying round of the $63,000 Liggett and MyersConcord Open.

title: Israelis Clash With Police
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 (AP)Several hundred Middle East ern Jews who charge that Israel discriminates against them fought with the police to day in downtown Jerusalem. Six policemen and several dem onstrators were reported in jured and a number of arrests were made.

title: O's and A's Get O.K.'s to Print World Series Tickets
description: The Baltimore Orioles and the Oakland Athletics got the go ahead yesterday from Commis sioner Bowie Kuhn to print tick ets for the 1971 World Series at 1970 prices.

title: Faster Branching Allowed For SmallLoan Concerns
description: William T. Dentzer Jr., New York State Superintendent of Banks has announced that most smallloan companies in the state would in the future be permitted to open new branch es at the rate of one a month, instead of one a quarter, which is the rate allowed by current Banking Department regula tions.

title: CONNECTICUT TAX ON INCOME ENDED
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 23  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today signed a bill repealing the state income tax and substituting a revenue package that increases the sales tax to 6.5 per centthe highest levied by any state.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Intransigent Union Heads

title: Berlin Cold War Days: From Crisis to Crisis
description: Fourpower talk on Berlin has stretched sporadically over 26 years, since the end of World War II and the beginning of the cold war.

title: 72,000 Jobs in Michigan Seen if Car Tax Is Ended
description: BOYNE MOUNTAIN, Mich., Aug. 23 (UPI)Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Mich igan, said today that repeal of the 7. per cent auto excise tax could create as many as 72,000 new jobs in Michigan.

title: 40% Show Disease Traces
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The Government said today it had found evidence of black lung disease among 40 per cent of the first 4,200 coal miners examined in Pennsylvania and West Virginia as part of a na tional survey.

title: Notes on People
description: Miss Bernadette Devlin, the youngest member of the British Parliament and a po litical activist in Northern Ireland, gave birth to a 6 pound 2ounce daughter in Magherafelt, Northern Ire land.

title: U.S. Watching Bolivia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (Reu ters)  The State Department said today that the United States was studying develop ments in Bolivia, but the de partment declined comment on possible recognition of the new military government. Rob ert McCloskey, the depart mental spokesman, said it has been a practice of the United States not to make an auto matic response to the over throw of governments.

title: CONSUMERS SHOWED PESSIMISM IN JULY
description: Consumers in the Chicago area voiced pessimism in bank survey about future busi ness a short time before the President announced his new economic program, the Conti nental Bank, which conducted the survey, said yesterday in Chicago.

title: DR. JEANNE PROSSER OF DARTMOUTH DIES
description: HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 23Dr. Jeanne Melchior Prosser, assistant professor of history at Dartmouth College, died Sat urday after a long illness. Her age was 43 and she was the wife of Dr. Reese Trego Pros ser professor of mathematics at Dartmouth.

title: A Japanese Industry Watches U.S. Birds
description: The Japanese are trem en dously worried about the vanishing tribes of eagles, cranes, pelicans, trumpeter swans and some songbirds in the United States.

title: Knesset in Sour Mood on Devaluation
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 23The waitress at the restaurant in the Knesset (Parliament) had an unanswerable comeback to the customer who complained that her eggplant salad had gone sour.

title: Adirondack State Park Residents Await Development Agency With Mixed Feelings
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Aug. 23  Residents in the Adi rondack State Park are await ing, with a mixture of fervent hope and vehement opposi tion, the day next week when a new state agency will be established to regulate de velopment in the sixmillion acre area.

title: Campaign Ups and Downs Stir Cynicism on Streets of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23Presidential elec tions with only one candi date? It's funny, a 48yearold locksmith said today. But it's not right. Really, cannot say which man is good, or bad.

title: S.E.C. Says Price Freeze Includes FundAdviser Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Securities and Exchange Com mission said today that the fees paid by investment com panies to their investment ad visers cannot be raised during the wageprice freeze. The an nouncement was made in a let ter to David Silver of the In vestment Company Institute here.

title: Peking Assails Moscow For Tension in Balkans
description: HONG KONG, Tuesday, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  Chinas Acting Foreign Minister Chi Pengfei, in an indirect attack on the Soviet Union, has de nounced imperialism for creating tension in the Bal kans with military exercises.

title: MISS PANDE VICTOR IN U.S. FIRST ROUND
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 23 Eliza Pande of Palo Alto, Calif., began defense of the United States women's amateur grass court tennis champion ship with a 60, 63 victory over Mrs. Sharon Banzhaf of Milwaukee today at the Wil mington Country Club.

title: Heath Bars Special Session
description: LONDON, Aug. 23Prime Minister Heath today turned down a request by the Labor party for a recall of Parliament for a debate on Northern Ireland.

title: Inside the Cultural Revolution: II
description: HONG KONG During a prolonged mass campaign like the cultural revo lution, it is a practice of the Chinese leaders to sum up experience period. ically. The cultural revolution group under the central committee of the party was in charge of day to day leadership of that vast and complex movement. The group was headed by Chen Pota.

title: Roger William Jackling
description: LONDON, Aug. 23Within the Foreign Office, Sir Roger William Jackling, Britain's Ambassador to West Ger many, is known as Cracker jackling. Sir Roger, who is 58 years old, has spent most of his diplomatic career in economic affairs but had amassed such a reputation that, when the post in Bonn became vacant in 1968, he was a leading candidate.

title: WarBurdened Economy Hampers Egypt's Scientific Research
description: CAIRO, Aug. 15President Anwar elSadat recently made a ceremonial visit to the labora tories of the atomicenergy es tablishment near here and praised the research workers role in the Egyptian economy and urged them to greater ef forts.

title: Ford Presses Japan Talks
description: TOKYO, Aug. 23 (AP)Will Scott, a vice president of the Ford Motor Company, and Kohel Matsuda, the president of Japan's Toyo Kogyo Com pany, began the final round of negotiations today on a proposed business tie up be tween the two auto makers, the Kyodo news service re porrted.

title: Florida Prison Disorder
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP)Inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution here ransacked a commissary, broke windows and jimmied open doors today before prison of ficials regained control without force, officials said. The dis turbance concerned illdefined grievances involving commis sary operations, the library, hair cutting policies and food.

title: Washington Grades Restaurant Sanitation: Below 70 Fails
description: WASHINGTON  You can have a brand new kitchen, meeting every regu lation in the world, and you still may be serving your customers rotten food, Jacques Blanc, a restaura teur, observed the other day.

title: FireBombing of Puerto Rican Offices Stirs New Fear in RiotTorn Camden
description: CAMDEN, N.I., Aug. 23The social and political head quarters of Camden's Puerto Rican community was heavily damaged by a twoalarm fire early today after an apparent firebomb atback. The incident aroused fear that tensions in this battered city might boil over again after two nights of relative calm.

title: Three Experts Endorse LongRange Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (UPI)Three former wage price administrators urged the Government today to impose longterm controls on at least basic industry and big unions before President Nixon's 90day freeze ends.

title: South African Stand
description: PRETORIA, Aug. 23  South Africa announced tonight a double foreignexchange mar ket, with the gold parity of the rand unchanged.

title: Satire on Gotham to.Open
description: Wild and Wonderful, musical satire on the contem porary New York scene, will have its premiere at the Ly ceum Theatre on Nov. 9. The book for the production was written by Bob Brotherton and Bob Goodman; the music and lyrics were the work of Mr. Goodman. Rick Hobard is the producer and Burry Fredrik will direct. Ronn Forella is the choreographer.

title: Kenneth Rush
description: BERLIN, Aug. 23  In the twopage biography distrib uted by the United States Embassy in Bonn, Ambassa dor Kenneth Rush is listed as belonging to golf clubs on both sides of the Atlantic, dozen in all.

title: Women's Liberation Groups Charge Mayor With 6 Years of Prejudice During His Tenure at City Hall
description: Women's liberation groups here accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of six years of prejudice against women dur ing his tenure at City Hall. And they wondered aloud whether they could anticipate a different treatment from whatever national political coalition he may help form in his new role as a Democrat.

title: Castro, No. 1 Fan, Is Proud of Cuba In Volleyball Test
description: I did not want to come because I thought it might put more pressure on you, Castro told Rudy Suwara, the captain of the American team, on the floor of the col iseum. But I could not stay home.

title: A rab in Israel's Cabinet Urges Coexistence in Hadassah Talk
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 23  A, Palestinian Arab told an audi ence of 2,500 American Jewish women today that Arab patriot ism cannot be based on hos tility to Israel.

title: Vesco Makes Final Effort To Avoid S.E.C. Testimony
description: Robert L. Vesco, chairman of the International Controls Corporation and Investors Over seas Services, Ltd., made an 11thhour attempt last night to avoid having to comply with court order to testify today be fore the Securities and Ex change Commission.

title: Talks in Progress With Champale
description: The CocaCola Bottling Com patty of New York, Inc., the largest softdrink bottler in the, world, announced yesterday is negotiating to acquire Champ ale, Inc., one of the leading! producers of malt liquors in this country.

title: KY'S WITHDRAWAL REGRETTED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23The Nixon Administration expressed its official regret today over the withdrawal of Vice Presi de it Nguyen Cao Ky from South Vietnam's presidential race and said it was studying the implications of the South Vietnamese election.

title: 2 in Newark Jail Fall to Their Deaths In Escape Attempt
description: NEWARK, Aug. 23  Two prisoners attempting to escape from the Essex County jail by using a rope made of bed sheets fell to their deaths today.

title: Grand Jury Set for 11 Separatists in Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 23The 11 members of the Repub lic of New Africa charged with slaying a Jackson police lieutenant and the wounding of another policeman were bound over for grand jury action at a preliminary hearing here today.

title: Indonesia Devalues Rupiah 10% And Slashes Taxes on Exports
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 23 Indonesia devalued its cur rency, the rupiah, today by 10 per cent.

title: Dee Wedemeyer Is the Bride Of Donald Carse Jr., Banker
description: The marriage of Miss Isa belle Dolores Wedemeyer, a reporter for The Associated Press, to Donald Rede Carse Jr., an assistant treasurer in the international division of the Bankers Trust Company, took place in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday. The cere mony, performed by the Rev. Dr. Charles Bartow, was fol lowed by a reception at the Union Club.

title: 58th St. Fire Called Arson
description: The Police and Fire Depart ments said that an arsonist set fire to the vacant fourthfloor loft of a building at 110 East 58th Street last evening. The fire, according to Battalion Chief Edward Kolletta, had ap parently been intentionally set with lacquer thinner. The building houses offices of the Holmes Protective Agency and a Finast supermarket.

title: Rx for the Economy: Will It Work?
description: Curb the Unions

title: Guild Chief Protests Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) Charles A. Perlik Jr., presi dent of the Newspaper Guild, resigned from a Federal com mission today in protest against President Nixon's new wage and economic policy. Mr. Per lik resigned from the National Commission on Libraries and Information Science.

title: Thieu Says Election is On Despite Ky's Withdrawal
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 23President Nguyen Van Thieu met with his closest advisers at the palace this evening and one participant said they discussed Vice Presi dent Nguyen Cao Ky's refusal to run in the presidential elections.

title: NAVY SAYS ITS SHIP CAUSED OIL SLICK
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 23 (UPI)The Navy conceded today that one of its ships had caused an oil slick that floated off 30 miles of coastline, threatening an oceanfront stretch that includes President Nixon's private beach.

title: TRAINHAN IS KILLED, TWO HURT IN CRASH
description: The flagman on a Penn Cen tral freight train was killed and two other crewmen were seriously injured at about 10 A.M. yesterday when the train crashed into a string of box tars in a tunnel in Brooklyn.

title: BOLIVIA STRAFING KILLS 8 STUDENTS
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 23Army and air force units today bombarded the central tower of the University of San Andres, where leftist students made a last stand against the anti Marxist revolt here.

title: Pro Exhibitions Plugging Holes in College Budgets
description: Pro football came to the campus last weekend and just about broke the box of fices. At the first pro game in the University of Califor nia's stadium at Berkeley, 67,739 saw Oakland beat Los Angeles. The Jets and Giants filled Yale Bowl's 70,874 seats for the third straight year, while 91,745 attended the first pro game, Detroit against Baltimore, in the University of Michigan's sta dium at Ann Arbor. This Sat urday another college foot ball shrine, Notre Dame Sta dium at South Bend, Ind., will play host to the pros for the first time, and the Giants and Eagles will play their annual game in Prince ton's Palmer Stadium.

title: Canadian Shipyard to Growl
description: JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Aug. 23 (Canadian Press)A shipyard at Marystown, New foundland, is to be expanded, tat a cost of $50million to $60 million, to build vessels of up to 230,000 tons, Premier Joseph Smallwood announced today. Ho said Federal financial aid would be sought for the yard. Upon completion it would be told by the province to Gander Shipping Enterprises, Ltd., a subsidiary of Panamerican, Ltd., of Zurich, Switzerland.

title: Rumania Wins, 32, From Brazil, Gains In Davis Cup Play
Pirates List Details
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 (UPI)  The Pittsburgh Pirates an nounced today that tickets for games 3, 4 and 5 of the Na tional League championship series will go on sale Sept. 13.

title: Roundup: Braves Rally With 15 Runs Off Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who administered a 154 beating to the Atlanta Braves in the second game of a double header sweep Monday night at Atlanta, received a return mauling from the Braves last night, 155, as hits continued to fill the air at Atlanta Sta dium.

title: District Reserve Banks Get Authritiy on Holding Units
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters)The Federal Reserve Board today gave district Fed eral Reserve banks the au thority to approve formation of a onebank holding company under simplified procedures to help handle applications.

title: Bicentennial Group Includes an Island As Site for Fair
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Philadelphia Bicen tennial Corporation said today that it had picked a 1976 expo sition site encompassing areas of Philadelphia and Camden and an island in the Delaware River.

title: Marcos, Accusing Reds, Vows to Eliminate Subversion
description: MANILA, Aug. 24President Ferdinand E. Marcos asserted today that Communist subver sives planned to burn Manila and to kidnap Government leaders. He vowed to liquidate the Communist apparatus.

title: Bridget Riley Retrospective:An Op Artist's Repertory
description: LONDON  Bridget Riley's international reputation as a leading op artist was af firmed in the 1965 Museum of Modern Art exhibition The Responsive Eye. Since then, her renown has grown even more. In addition to the con siderable attention she has received in numerous exhibi tions and in art journals, she won the international prize for painting at the Venice Bi ennale of 1968.

title: Two Family Court Judges Appointed in Westchester
description: ALBANY, Aug. 24 (AP) Richard J. Daronco of Pelham and Vincent Guarahian of Som ers, both lawyers, have been appointed judges of the West chester Family Court, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.

title: Dr. Wallace Eckert Dies at 69; Tracked Moon With Computer
description: Dr. Wallace J. Eckert, a former executive of the Inter national Business Machines Corporation and professor of celestial mechanics at Columbia University, died yesterday in a nursing home in Englewood, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived at 216 Leonia Avenue, Leonia, N.J.

title: Koreans Fear Setback
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Aug. 25South Korean Government officials and business leaders agreed yesterday that President Nix on's economic policy would cause a substantial setback for the Korean economy, particu larly the nation's ambitious ex port drive.

title: Strikers Are Rebuffed In BacktoWork Offer
description: EL DORADO, Ark, Aug. 24 (AP)Officials at the Great Lakes Chemical Company re fused today to allow mem bers of Local 434 of the Oil Chemical and Atomic Work ers Union, who had been on strike for 14 months, to re turn to their jobs.

title: Giants Top Mets, 32
description: Like death and taxes, Juan Marichal is inevitable and often painful, and he was both last night as he pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 32 vic tory over the New York Mets before 47,630 persons in Shea Stadium.

title: Fear Not, Home Canners, but Follow the Directions Carefully
description: With the recent disclosures of botulin contamination in some commercially made canned products, home can ners may have some qualms about the potential dangers they could be bottling. How ever, successand safety in homecanning can be as sured if certain rules are un derstood and followed faith fully.

title: Animals Slaughtered in Harrison Children's Zoo
description: HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 24 Most of the animals in the children's zoo at West Harrison, Memorial Park were killed and mutilated in an attack by van dals last night.

title: Senate Republican Floor Manager Denies That Campaign Spending Bill Has CostofLiving Loophole
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  A Republican Senator said today that the costofliving amend ment to the campaign finance bill approved earlier this month would not permit any unexpected increase in candi dates spending ceilings in 1972.

title: CHINESE ENTERING VENICE FILM FETE
description: VENICE, Aug. 24  The Chinese are coming! Such is the most astonishing an nouncement of the 1971 Venice Film Festival, which opens tomorrow evening at the Cinema Palace on the Lido.

title: CABINET IN ATHENS BEING REORGANIZED
description: ATHENS, Aug. 24Premier George Papadopoulos cleared the way today for expected Cabinet changes by asking for resignations of the entire Cabi net.

title: Charleston, W. Va., Man Is Held After 7 Are Shot
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 24 (AP)The police arrested a man with a shotgun tonight after a shooting spree in a pub lic housing project in which seven persons, some of them children, were wounded.

title: Tanzania Accuses Uganda
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 24 (Reuters)Tanzania to night accused Uganda of send ing tanks and troops across the border and said fighting was continuing.

title: Youth Gives Up in Slaying Of Policeman in Queens
description: A 19yearold youth wanted in the murder of a patrolman Friday night surrendered early yesterday to a detective stand ing in front of a precinct house in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: RAHIM CONQUERS GORMAN IN UPSET
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 24Upsets continued in the $25,000 Eastern grass courts tennis championships today with the defeat of thirdseeded Tom Gorman of Seattle and seventhseeded pancho Gonzales of Malibu, Calif., at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.,

title: EQUINE DISEASE A THREAT UPSTATE
description: PARISH, N. Y., Aug. 24 State health officials are mov ing to head off a threatened outbreak of a sleepingsickness disease, Eastern equine enceph alitis, in a 12,000acre area near this Oswego County village after verifying the death of one horse from the disease.

title: South Korean Defense Chief Is Replaced After Mutiny
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 24President Park Chung Hee today appointed Yoo Jae Heung, a retired lietueneant general, to replace Defense Min ister Jung Nae Hiuk, who re signed yesterday following a mutiny of air force criminals that resulted in 38 deaths.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Central Savings Bank of New York an nounced yesterday the election of Dr. Verne S. Atwater as president and chief executive officer. He will succeed James Bloor, who was elected chairman of the board of trustees. Dr. Atwater was previously president of the Westinghouse Learning Corporation.

title: Suddenly, on Tour, A Call to Conduct
description: James DePreist, a ruggedly handsome, baldish man with the shoulders of a linebacker, wanted to explain how he had become a sports hero. It was as easy as opening a book. When the 34yearold musician went to conduct the Los Angeles Philharmonic earlier this month, he picked up the concert program and found himself glorified as a former college football star. Instant muscles.

title: Army's Finish Beats Navy For Title in Rifle Match
description: CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI)The national rifle and pistol shooting championships ended today with the United States Army staging an impres sive finish to defeat the United States Navy and win the trophy team match.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Ron Johnson Faces Surgery
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 24The Giants, who have been losing players and games with regularity the past few weeks, incurred an other problem today when they learned that Ron John son would need surgery to correct a thigh injury suf fered in a basketball game two months ago.

title: JUDGE BIDS SCHOOLS DISREGARD WALLACE
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 24 (AP)Two Alabama school sys tems must carry out courtor dered desegregation plans re gardless of directives to the contrary from Gov. George C. Wallace, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: ROQUEPINE TROT LOSES A STARTER
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 24  As had been expected, Tidal ium Pelo of France will not start at Roosevelt Raceway in next Saturday night's Roque pine Trot, the $30,000 sequel to last Saturday's $125,000 In ternational.

title: Canada Dry Elects New Chief Officer
description: Richard C. Beeson, 43 years old, has been elected president, chief executive officer and a director of the Canada Dry Corporation. He formerly was executive vice president of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Cor poration.

title: Advertising:
description: The people at the Ford Mo tor Credit Company this week launched their first na tional advertising campaign to get us to finance our Ford cars and trucks; through them.

title: Kresge Profit Rises 34%;
description: The S. S. Kresge Company, which operates 1,103 stores, rang up record sales and earn ings in the second quarter and half year ended July 28, accord ing to results reported yester day.

title: U.S Bars an Extension Of Overseas Borrowing
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Treasury Department de partment decided today against extending a $500million over seas borrowing it had made earlier in an effort to soak up dollars from Europe.

title: Education Reform Is Urged on Israel To Aid Race Amity
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 24  An American educator and author warned today that unless the educational gap between the Oriental and Western youth in Israel was narrowed there was a clear danger that the dispar ity would turn into genuine racial prejudice and tear the nation apart.

title: Merger News
description: The PerkinElmer Corpora tion announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to ac quire the Fusite Corporation, a maker of hermetic seals used in the refrigeration and air conditioning industries, through an exchange of stock worth about $24.5million. Under the agrement, PerkinElmer, a lead ing manufacturer of laboratory analytical instru ments, would acquire Fusite for approximately 480,000 of its common shares. PerkinElmer recently an nounced an agreement in prin ciple to acquire Metco, Inc. of Westbury, L. I., a maker of medical equipment. Perkin Elmer had sales of $203million in its fiscal year ended July 31, 1970.

title: Murphy to Transfer 30 From Harlem
description: Police Commissioner Patrick, V. Murphy, in a further effort to root out corruption in his department, will transfer today a substantial number of the plainclothes patrolmen assigned to the Harlem area.

title: Unit of Big Board Delivered Record Stock Total Monday
description: The New York Stock Ex change said yesterday that its Central Certificate Service de livered a record total of $160 million worth of securities Mon day.

title: 16 ECONOMISTS CALL FREEZE INEQUITABLE
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 24A group of 16 economists, several of them former advisers to the Nixon Administration, criticized wage and price controls today as inequitable, wasteful, inef ficient and destructive of per sonal freedom, and called on the President to rescind them.

title: Bill Asks Tax on Detergents
description: BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UPI)The Committee on Taxation sent to the House today legislation im posing a 10 per cent sales tax on detergents and other clean ing products containing more than 8.7 per cent phosphates. The committee altered the bill as reported by the Committee on Naural Resources, which had proposed a statewide ban on the sale of detergents con taining more than 10 per cent phosphates.

title: The Talk of Liberty
description: LIBERTY, Wash.The mid day sun is warm, and the smell of hot pitch from the pines across the small clearing. Underfoot, the dry grass cracks at every step. Clacking grasshoppers flutter ahead. Williams Creek, a re spectable little stream even in late August, runs pure and clear on the south side of the settlement. Chil dren play across it there near the rusting dredge that stands alongside the ugly scar that it made in a place of natural beauty.

title: Protege of Daley Indicted With 13 in Panther Case
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 24State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan, a political protg of Mayor Richard J. Daley, was named today in a longsuppressed indictment by a special grand jury on charges of conspiring to prevent the prosecution of eight Chicago policemen who raided a Black Panther apart ment on Dec. 4, 1969, and killed two of its occupants.

title: Linda Tuero Defeated
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 24 (UPI)A British teenager, Cor rine Molesworth upset Linda Tuero of New Orleans, today in the opening round of the $20,000 Virginia Slims women's tourney at the Casino. Miss Tuero, ranked 11th in the United States, was unable to hold her serve and bowed to the 19yearold from Devon, England, 61, 64.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Mark Donohue is ready to go Grand Prix racing. And he wants very much to go. Al though neither he nor his car owner, Roger Penske, has said anything for publication about Grand Prix plans, they do have a car lined up for the Canadian Grand Prix on Sept. 19 and the United States Grand Prix on Oct. 3. In fact, Donohue has been testing the car, a McLaren M19, in England.

title: Laver, Emerson Gain Final
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 24 (AP)Rod Laver and Roy Emerson gained the final of the $10,000 pro tennis tournament today. Laver defeated Cliff Drysdale, 64, 60, and Emerson ousted John Newcombe, 62, 62.

title: Suffolk Legislators Vote A Shoreline Zoning Plan;
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Aug. 24 An amendment to the Suffolk County Charter giving the county a strong voice over the zoning of all its shorefront areasmore than 1,000 miles was approved today by the County Legislature.

title: Duty Viewed as Ending Imports of Manmade Fibers
description: The additional 10 per cent duty on manmade fibers can effecitvely cut off the supply from abroad, it was asserted yesterday by Charles E. Rodg ers, Jr., president of Textile Fi bers Inc., a large importer here.

title: Veteran in Danang Dies In Immolation by Fire
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24 (Reuters)  A 37 year old war veteran and a father of six children burned himself to death in Danang today, saying he wanted to defend the democracy and freedom of South Vietnam, informed sources said here.

title: CIVILIAN RULE HINTED FOR EAST PAKISTAN
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 24Pakistani Government sources said today that a civil ian would probably be appoint ed soon to replace the present military governor of strifetorn East Pakistan.

title: Stage: Vain Victory, Campy Transvestite Musical Spectacle
description: Dark Victory. Bright Victory. Victory at Sea. And now we have Vain Victory: The Vicissitudes of the Damned c. 1971, the latest furbelow from Jackie Curtis.

title: Uganda Reports Border Clash With ChineseLed Tanzanians
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 24 (Reuters)President Idi Amin of Uganda said today that fighting had broken out between Ugandan forces and Tanzanian troops led by Chinese Officers.

title: Miss Neeld in Semifinals
description: NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 24 (AP)  Topseeded entries Nancy Neeld of Albuquerque, N. M., and Mrs. Betty Rosen quest Pratt of Winter Park, Fla., advanced to the semifinals of the national women's senior tennis championships with straightset victories today at the point Judith Country Club.

title: Welfare Inspector General
description: Created in the vindictive climate of the last session the State Legislature, the post of Welfare Inspector Gen eral could conjure up the danger that needy welfare re cipients will be harassed and that other eligibles among the poor will be dissuaded from applying for the assist ance rightfully theirs. That danger has been substantially reduced by Governor Rockefeller's appointment of George F. Berlinger as Inspector General.

title: SHOPPING SITE SET FOR CHILD'S NEEDS
description: A new onestop, discount shopping center strictly for chil dren's needs is being planned for an October opening in High land Park, Ill., near Chicago, by the Children's Bargain Town division of Interstate Stores, Inc., based in New York.

title: WagePrice Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Following is the fifth set of official questions and an swers issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90 day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Museum to Exhibit Jade From Mayan Civilization
description: Seven pieces of jade adorn ments made during the clas sic period of Mayan civiliza tion, 300900 A.D., will be exhibited at the American Museum of Natural History during September as the Exhibit of the Month.

title: Rule on U.S.Owned Patents Revised to Aid Developers
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP)President Nixon an nounced yesterday a revised policy on Governmentowned patents to permit a potential developer to have an exclusive license on such products.

title: WITNESS PLACES MEDINA IN MYLAI ExRadioman Says Captain Was in Area of Killings
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 24  Capt. Ernest L. Medina's contention that he was unaware of the slaying of South Viet namese civilians at Mylai until more than 100 had been killed by his troops was challenged to day by the testimony of a wit ness. The witness said the cap tain was within 90 feet of the killing of eight to 12 women and children shortly after he entered the village.

title: Federal Government Is Sued Over Miller Field
description: Staten Island's biggest piece of Army surplusthe 213 acre expanse of Miller Field, a former Army aviation baseis up for grabs, but the city, ac cording to angry islanders, is not grabbing hard enough.

title: 2 More Major Fires in Harlem Make a Total of 3 in 12 Hours
description: Two multialarm fires broke out in Harlem early yesterday, making a total of three large fires in that area in a 12hour period.

title: DRAFT RAID SEEN RESULT OF A TIP
description: EAST CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 24A 32yearold contractor, described by sources close to the local antiwar movement as a strong possibility as the informant who led Federal agents to draft raiders here last weekend, refused smilingly tonight to comment on the ac cusation.

title: John Coleman Weds Linda Greif
description: Miss Linda Greif and John M. Coleman were married here last night at the 21 Club by the Rev. Dr. Nathan Peril man, rabbi of Temple Ema nuEl.

title: RUDO BIRD, $7.60, 6LENGTH VICTOR
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24A familiar combina tion presided over the main race on today's card, when Laffit Pincay guided William Levin's Rudo Bird to victory The victor is trained by Angel Penna, and it was Levin, Pincay and Penna who were in the winner's circle on Saturday when Bold Reason won the $110,700 Travers.

title: McGovern to Use the Economy, Not the War, as His Main Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  Senator George McGovern said today that the economy had replaced Vietnam as the main issue in his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation.

title: Hussein Resists Pressure on Guerrillas'Behalf
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 King Hussein of Jordan has declared that pressures on his country from other Arab states will neither affect us nor will they make us change our policy.

title: China's First Order of Priorities
description: SHANGHAI, Aug, 24After wan dering around China for six weeks, this reporter has the impression that the sleeping giant is awake all right, but is not really very interested in shaking the world.

title: Voloshen, Influence Peddler, Dies at 73
description: Nathan M. Voloshen, lawyer lobbyist, friend of high public officials and convicted in fluence peddler, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital two hours after he was admitted to Its Ames Coronary Intensive Care Unit. He was 73 years old and lived here at 10 Park Avenue.

title: 2 BLACK TROUPES DANCE IN FESTIVAL
description: The Manhattan Theater Club in its festival of black dance companies presented on Mon day an early evening perform ance of the Rod Rodgers Dance Company and a 10:30 perform ance of the Glen Brooks Afro American Dance Theater. The approaches were different but shared a similar concern with social themes.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In one bold stroke that suspended the largely ceremo nial link between the United States dollar and gold, Richard M. Nixon has cut the Gordian knot of international finance. The Bretton Woods system which until now has defined currency values both in terms of the dollar and of gold at its official price of $35 per ounce has been set adrift by Amer ica's unwilling ness to redeem foreignheld dollars for gold.

title: 8 Accused After Charging AntiSemitism in Rome
description: ROME, Aug. 24  The po liie today charged eight per son's with having disrupted an outdoor performance of a play here last night because of what the protesters felt to be anti Semitic overtones.

title: Laver Joins Five Others In Passing Up U.S. Open
description: Rod Laver joined three other former Forest Hills winners yesterday when he withdrew from the United States Open tennis championships that be gin next Tuesday.

title: Julie Eisenhower's Toe Broken by Book Cart
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. Aug. 24 (AP)Mrs. David Eisen hower's toe was broken to day in her second day as a tteacher at Atlantic Beach Elementary School when a heavy cart loaded with school books rolled over her foot, school officials said.

title: BOTULISM SCARE IS TAKEN CALMLY
description: A few wary metropolitan area shoppers returned cans of Campbell's chicken vegetable soup to their supermarkets yes terday, but in general the dis eovery of deadly botulin con tamination in some cans of the soup packed in Texas had little effect on sales here.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: A loss of more than 3 cents a bushel in soybean futures was erased during a late rally on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Mr. Nixon's Paper Standard
description: By far the most startling part of the President's new economic program is the decision to suspend gold pay ments against dollarsan act that, among other things, removes the un derpinnings from the world's money.

title: George T. Washington Is Dead; Former Judge of Appeals Court
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug, 24Judge George Thomas Washington, who retired as senior member of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in 1965, died at his home here on Satur day. He was 63 years old.

title: Sales Up at Most Chains
description: Chainstore sales in July rose 8.7 per cent from July, 1970, according to a survey of lead ing chain organizations in the country. In the first seven months of this year, the chains topped the yearearlier level by 9.6 per cent.

title: MIDAUGUST SALES OF G.M. DECLINED
description: Reports from Detroit indi cated yesterday that sales of new cars in the midAugust period would be down from the 1970 level.

title: Cuba Offers Aid to Left
description: MIAMI, Aug. 24  Cuba formally offered firm and de cided moral and material sup port to Bolivian revolution aries today in their liberation struggle against Bolivia's new military Government, the Cuban radio said.

title: Monday Night Fights
description: Los Angeles' Jos (Mantequilla) Napoles, 153 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Jean Josselin 153 France, 5 rounds; Ruben Olivares, 123, Mexico City, knocked out Valentin Galeano, 123, Paraguay, 9; Rafael Herrera, 118, Mexico City, outpointed Chucho Castillo, 118, Mexico City, 12; Fernando Cabanela, 112, Manila, the Philip pines outpointed Halimi Gutierrez, 112, Mexico City, 12.

title: A'S SUBDUED, 10, BY STOTTLEMYRE
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 24 Mel Stottlemyre made a first inning run stand up as the New York Yankees won a brilliant pitching duel from Vida Blue and the Oakland Athletics, 10, before a crowd of 18,288 in the Coliseum tonight.

title: Waller Wins Runoff In Mississippi Upset
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24 William L. Waller, a relative newcomer to politics, upset Lieut. Gov. Charles L. Sullivan and won the Democratic nomi nation for Governor of Missis sippi in today's runoff primary.

title: Grant Adams, Director Since'57 Of United Hospital. Fund, Dead
description: Grant H. Adams, since 1957 executive director of the United Hospital Fund, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital follow ing a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 679 Ridgeway Street in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: PRICES OF BONDS REGISTER A GAIN
description: Bond prices bounced back from a wave of profit tak ing and advanced yesterday, spurred in part by news that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had taken additional steps to hold down interest rates for the housing market.

title: The Screen:Thermidor
description: Back in 1964 a documen tary by Tinto Brass called Ca Ira, scheduled for the second New York Film Fes tival, was withheld by au thorities in Italy and thus deprived of a showing. Yes terday the same movie, re titled Thermidor (after the 11th month of the French Revolutionary calendar), with a new English narration and with some attempt at updat ing made by its American dis tributor, opened at the Fifth Avenue Cinema. Thermidor attempts a survey of the more spectacular circles of the cen tury, and one can see how the Italian Government might feel diffident about yet an other starring role for the country's modern history.

title: Indian Cricketers Gain First Victory in England
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reu ters)Thousands of jubilant Indians swarmed onto the field at the Oval today when India won an international cricket match in England for the first time and captured the series of three matches, the first two of which were drawn.

title: Nixon's Private Beach Is Fouled by Oil Slick
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPIPart of 30 milelong oil slick caused by a Navy error washed ashore at the Western White House today, fouling President Nix on's private beach.

title: MESKILL DISPUTED ON CUTS' LEGALITY
description: HARTFORD, Aug. 24Lead ing Democratic legislators, handful of mayors and Con necticut's principal teachers' organization, today questioned the legality of Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's sharp reduction in grants to municipalities.

title: Israel Calls U.S. Lexicon Unfortunate
description: JERUSALEM, Aug, 24  According to Israel's Foreign Ministry, the harmful was harmful and the unfortu nate was unfortunate, and the United States State De partment should listen little.

title: High Peking Aide to Go to Tokyo To Attend Funeral of Statesman
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 24 China has named one of her highestranking and most ex perienced diplomats to attend the funeral of a Japanese po litical leader. The move is ex pected to result in new diplo matic contacts between the Tokyo and Peking Govern ments at a time when each has been, voicing concern about the other's power and the other's relations with Washington.

title: Beware the Common Market
description: LONDONThe great debate taking place in Britain over joining the Com mon Market has begun to reveal a concern with issues other than eco nomic and political advantages. To the more conventional arguments over sovereignty, the role of sterling, the balance of payments and future growth rates, there is now to be added a mounting concern about the effects on the quality of life, a concern that is illustrative of the widening rift of the premises by which public events are currently being judged on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: Blasts Rip Ammunition Dump At U.S. Base at Camranh Bay
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 25 (AP)A series of explosions today ripped through the ammunition dump at Camranh Bay, the big United States base 190 miles northeast of Saigon.

title: ONE GROUP BACKED FOR ACCOUNTANTS
description: Investors who have been questioning the methods by which accounting principles are established have a new ally within the accounting profes sion itself.

title: Taipei Expects Difficulty
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Wednesday, Aug. 25Nationalist Chinese officials foresee a difficult transition period while Taiwan exporters try to adjust to the new American economic poli cies, especially the 10 per cent surcharge on imports.

title: China Will Purchase 6 British Jetliners In $48Million Deal
description: LONDON, Aug. 24Britain will sell six Trident jet airlin ers to China at a price of 20million ($48million).

title: POWER PURCHASE URGED BY MAYOR
description: Mayor Lindsay directed city officials yesterday to negotiate to buy 1.8 million kilowatts of electricity from the Power Au thority of the State of New York for municipal use here and for city help to industries that would hire and train low skilled persons.

title: Amis Upsets Cloud to Gain In Eastern Junior Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 24Robert Amis of Ad ina, Minn., upset Robert Cloud of Menands, N.Y., 60, 36, 63, today to join William Durham of Australia and Chip Fisher of Palo Alto, Calif., in the fourth round of the Eastern junior tennis championships.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Decline at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was a newsreel shot that moved briefly across the television screen the other day in a much too casual presentation. It showed flames licking hungrily up the walls of Connie Mack Stadium and thereby expediting the destruction of this abandoned Philadelphia ball park. Nothing much was left anyway except memories and they will fade into the archives of the historians.

title: 33 Seized in Drug Raids
description: MANCHESTER, N.H., Aug. 24 (AP)The state and local police rounded up 33 persons today in a sweep designed to cripple the illegal sales of drugs in New Hampshire's largest; city. Attorney General Warren Rudman said that the joint police action followed two months of investigation by the state police.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City and State Democrats Confer on Subway Fare
description: Top state and city Democrat ic officials met yesterday at City Hall in the first of a series of meetings exploring ways to save the 30cent sub way fare.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The latest discovery of lethal botulin toxin in canned soup has evoked another public out cry over the effectiveness of Federal food Inspection and brought demands for a Congres sional investigation. Yet such investigations into food safety have been going on sporadi cally since Lincoln Steffens wrote an expos on the meat industry at the turn of the century, and one is under way even now by the House Subcommittee on Public Health and Environment.

title: SAMUEL S. BACKLAR, LAWYER, STATE AIDE
description: Samuel S. Backlar, a lawyer here since 1925 and a former special state assistant attor1 ney general, died Monday at his home, 585 West End Avenue. His age was 78.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ULSTER RULES OUT ANY UNITY MOVES
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 24  Brian Faulkner, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, speaking in Belfast, bluntly warned the Irish Republic today that his Government would stand firm against any attempt to unify the two Irelands.

title: Group of Ten to Meet
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 24 (UPI)  Finance Minister Edgar Benson announced today he would call a meeting of the ministers of the Group of Ten in midSep tember possibly in London to discuss President Nixon's new economic measures.

title: DOW RISES BY 11.75 TO END AT 904.13
description: Steel, railroad, savingsand loan and glamour issues helped to power the stock market for ward yesterday in a broad ad vance. The trading pace and block activity also picked up noticeably.

title: East Germans Approve
description: BERLIN, Aug. 24 (Reuters) East Germany today officially welcomed the fourpower draft and pledged its aid in carrying it out, the official news agency reported in East Berlin.

title: 2 Armed Men Hold Up Bank In Brooklyn and Get $20,000
description: Two armed men with re volvers held up the Canarsie Branch of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company at 2082 Rockaway Parkway, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, relieved the bank guard of his 38caliber revolver, and then escaped with more than $20,000 in cash.

title: U.S. Extends Vaccination Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin said today that the Government would pay for vaccinating horses against sleeping sickness in eight addi tional states and the District of Columbia.

title: TROOPS IN VIETNAM ARE PUT ON ALERT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 24United States troops were placed on alert as a precaution ary measure today, reportedly because of fear of Vietcong at tacks aimed at disrupting the election for the lower house on Sunday.

title: Franklin, N. H., Accused
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The city of Franklin, N.H., was cited today by the Environ mental Protection Agency for violation of Federalstate water quality standards. The agency said that the city had been cited for discharging raw sew age into the Winnepesuakee River, a tributary to the Merri mack River.

title: Henderson CourtMartial Views Mylai Photos
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 24 The details of the slaying of South Vietnamese civilians at Mayla! 4 unfolded once again at the courtmartial today of Col. Oran K. Henderson, who is charged with covering up the killings.

title: Shakespeare's Infinite Variety Inspires Women's Lib Troupe
description: I'll exhibit a bill in the Parliament for the putting down of men.

title: Rattenni Is Freed, 2 Convicted in LoanShark Case
description: Nicholas A. Rattenni, reputed to be a major Mafia figure in Westchester County, was ac quitted yesterday while two of his codefendants were con victed in their trial on loan shark charges.

title: Officials Report Racial Angle in San Quentin Break
description: SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 24  There were racial aspects to the attempted prison break here last Saturday, officials said today.

title: Balaguer Wins Test Vote In Dominican Chamber
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Aug. 24 (Reuters) President Joaquin Balaguer won a vote of confidence in the Chamber of Deputies today in a rejection of accusations against the government by former President Juan Bosch.

title: Brooklyn Man Drowns
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y., (UPI) A Brooklyn man drowned here today as his wife and two children watched him from the shore, about 100 feet away. The body of the victim, Thomas L. Bozman, 25 years old, of 784 Prospect Street, was recovered. Mrs. Bozman, 24, said his canoe capsized .

title: Books of The Times
description: MYSTERIES. By Knot Hamsun. Translated From the Norwegian by Gerry Bothmer. 340 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $8.95.

title: U.S. ACTS TO CURB MORTGAGE RATES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Government announced to day a twopart action designed to halt the creeping rise in mortgage interest rates that began late last spring after steep decline.

title: Catholic Bishop Ordained
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 24 (AP)Msgr. Joseph R. Crow ley, 56 years old, was ordained today as auxiliary bishop of the Fort WayneSouth Bend Roman Catholic Diocese. He will assist the Most Rev. Leo A. Pursley, who has been head of the diocese since 1950.

title: Market Place : Reactions Vary On Sternco Tie
description: Any matchmaker would say it looked like an ideal mar riage. There was American Home Products, a diversified producer of drugs, food and household products, with an enviable growth record through new products, strong marketing and acquisitions.

title: Supermarket Employe Slain in a Holdup
description: An assistant manager of Bohack supermarket in Brook lyn was shot and killed by one of four holdup men yesterday, because, the police said, he was too slow in opening the store's safe.

title: Dell Cancels Book by Ellsberg But Simon & Schuster Steps In
description: The Dell Publishing Company has canceled a $150,000 con tract with Dr. Daniel Ellsberg on the grounds that he had failed to provide a 20,000word introduction to a book of his writings on the Vietnam war in time for its projected publica tion before the end of this month.

title: Soviet Team in Jakarta for Aid Survey
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 24 Eleven men and two women, part of a Soviet technical team, stepped off an Aeroflot plane from Moscow here today and stepped into a new chapter of economic cooperation between the Soviet Union and Indonesia:

title: Honda Seeks Red China Sales
description: Tokyo, Aug. 24 (AP)The Honda Motor Company, a major Japanese automobile and motorcycle maker, said today it was sounding out Commu nist China on the possibility of exhibiting its compact cars and motorcycles at a Canton trade fair next fall.

title: Janet Newberry Advances
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 24 Janet Newberry, topseeded contender from La Jolla, Calif., scored a 61, 62 victory on second match point over Susan Vinton of Sarasota, Fla., today in the first round of the United States women's grass court championship at the Wilming ton Country Club.

title: Manila Isn't Worried
description: MANILA, Wednesday, Aug. 25President Nixon's economic policy has caused only a ripple of concern in official circles here, but the export sector is worried over the effects of the 10 per cent surcharge.

title: 10 Escape at Rikers Island; Three Are Still at Large
description: Smashing through a solarium window, 10 prisoners used fire hose to lower themselves four stories in an escape before down yesterday from an infir mary on Rikers Island.

title: Dollar Slips a Bit as Caution Rules Foreign Exchange Here
description: After showing buoyancy Monday, the floating dollar dipped yesterday in moderate trading on foreignexchange markets here.

title: Cosmos Will Start Mate Here Tonight Against Montreal
description: Andy Mate will start at cen ter forward tonight when the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League meet the Montreal Olympics at the Yankee Stadium in the next tolast regularseason game for both teams.

title: Taxi Chief Tells of Plan for AllNew Urban Vehicle
description: FARMINGDALE. L. I., Aug. 24  Taxi Commissioner Michael J. Lazar of New York City said today that he would enlist the automobile industry, the government and the academic community in a com bined effort to produce an all new urban vehicle for the nation's cities.

title: DOROTHY GLASSER
description: Dorothy Glasser, an adver tising executive, died Monday in Mount Sinai Hospital follow ing a long illness. She lived at 229 East 79th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada to Scrap OnceDisputed Missile
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 24Canada plans to dismantle the Bomarc antiaircraft missiles whose in stallation nine years ago caused a national political controversy because they carried United States nuclear warheads.

title: Shop Talk
description: A bagel is to eat with lox, or with cream cheese, or both. At Zabar's, the epicu rean heaven at Broadway and 80th Street that draws stur geon and lox fanciers from all over the city, a bagel is also to wear. Not the real thing, of course, but an over sized, toastybrown bagel printed on a T shirt that proudly proclaims in or range letters that the wearer is a Zabar fan. The store has also had a second patterna mlange of vari ous foodsprinted on white cotton T shirts.

title: HARLEM DOCTOR TO DEFY PROTEST
description: The lawyer for a white doctor whose resignation was being sought by local protestors at Harlem Hospital for allegedly spitting on a black dietary aide said yesterday that the doctor would at some point return to the hospital because he was innocent of the charges.

title: Diphtheria Shots Given
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 24 (AP)  Schoolchildren lined up at the Health Department today for free immunizations against diphtheria and other diseases required for entering school

title: Baldwin Charges Jackson Was Murdered in Prison
description: LONDON, Aug. 24  James Baldwin, the American author, charged today that George Jackson had been murdered by the San Quentin Prison authori ties and not killed trying to escape.

title: $200,000 MatchPlay Golf Starts Today
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 24 Something is being added to the pro golf tour. A $200, 000 matchplay tournament, which sponsors hope will be come as important as the United States Open, the Brit ish Open, the Masters and the Professional Golfers' As sociation championship, will get under way here tomor row over the magnificent Country Club of North Caro lina course.

title: Newark Fire Called Arson
description: NEWARK, Aug. 24 (UPI) A fouralarm fire that burned through 12 threestory houses in this city's Central ward early today was the work of arsonists, Fire Department offi cials said. The Red Cross esti mated 71 persons had lost their homes in the blaze.

title: SovietIsraeli Contacts
description: The delicacy and difficulty of reestablishing Soviet Israeli diplomatic relationsbroken by Moscow during the Mideast sixday war of 1967are underscored by the glacial pace of recent progress toward that end.

title: Manhattan Is Expanding Out as Well as Up
description: It all began in 1683, when the British, who controlled Manhattan Island, feared an attack by the French and dumped dirt into the harbor at the southern tip of the is land, extending the shoreline so a platform could be built for guns.

title: Bridge: Rivals of Spingold Finals Will Meet Here Next Month
description: Four internationally fa mous experts will have an opportunity here in a month's time to gain revenge for their recent narrow de feat in the final of the Spin gold knockout team cham pionship in Chicago.

title: and Not Far Away, Animals to Feed
description: MONSEY, N. Y.  Forty five minutes from Broadway, in Rockland County, there's a day camp where city chil dren can feed, play with, or simply watch, such esoteric creatures as calves, piglets, lambs, sheep, kids, goats, rabbits, ducks and chickens.

title: One Jet Spends Day Off in Easy Chair
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 24Because their next game is not until Monday night in Cleveland against the Kansas City Chiefs, the New York Jets got an extra day off today and Earlie Thomas got a chance to try out his new easy chair.

title: 3 Young Persons Indicted In Fatal Holdup in Harlem
description: Three young persons arrested several weeks ago after their attempted holdup of a Harlem bar ended in a gun battle with the police and the shooting of a gypsy cab driver were indicted yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office on various counts of attempted murder and robbery.

title: Amex Weighs West Coast Branch
description: The Amereican Stock Ex change is considering an exten sion of its trading capacity to the West Coast in a move that could lay some of the ground work for the creation of a broad, national securities mar ket.

title: Hospital Association Elects
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) John W. Kauffman, executive vice president of Princeton (N.J.) Hospital, was named to day presidentelect of the American Hospital Association. The action came during a meet ing of the association's House of Delegates. Mr. Kauffman will take office Jan. 1.

title: 2 at Woodstock Festival Charged With Bad Checks
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 24Two concessionaires who sold nearly $100,000 worth of supplies at the Woodstock Mu sic and Arts Festival two years ago have been indicted on eight counts of grand larceny in connection with the issuance of allegedly fraudulent checks.

title: Kahane Plans Armed Patrols To Cut Crime in East Flatbush
description: Plans to help residents of East Flatbush arm themselves with 22caliber rifles, to set up nightly citizen radio car patrols and to post Jewish Defense League members with shotguns in local stores were announced last night by Rabbi Meir D. Kahane, head of the militant league.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ATHENS  Premier Papadopoulos, Greece's strong man, likes to say he can't understand why the West, which so strongly dislikes the Brezhnev Doc trine used to impose Moscow's ideol ogy elsewhere, should try to emulate what it abhors by contemplating its own Brezhnev Doctrine here.

title: Dollar Down in Calm Trading Against European Currencies
description: LONDON, Aug. 24 The dol lar weakened s'ightly today from yesterday's strong levels as it floated against major European currencies in con tinued calm foreignexchange trading.

title: 75 Demonstrate
description: Chanting George Jackson was assassinated, about 75 young people marched up and down outside the Manhattan House of Detention yesterday to protest Jackson's death.

title: Amex Prices Rise as Trading Gains
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished higher yes terday in accelerated trading.

title: Landlords' Lawyer Seeks to Shift Cases From Bronx Civil Court
