description: A lawyer who specializes in prosecuting landlords' claims against tenants asked permis sion in Bronx Supreme Court yes terday to bring his cases there rather than in Civil Court be cause, he said, Bronx Civil Court judges so disregard prop er procedures that he feels locked out and unable to open up the flow of business.

title: Brandt Praises FourPower Agreement on Berlin but Warns of Difficulties in Germans' Negotiations
description: BONN, Aug. 24Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that the tentative agreement on the future of West Berlin reached yesterday by the Big Four was a a big step but not a com plete one.

title: Man in the News
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 24 Until last Saturday evening, Col. Hugo Banzer Suarez was in police custody and his name was on a list of 60 per sons who were to be deported to Chile as plotters against the leftwing regime of Gen. Juan Jos Torres Gonzales.

title: Tax Office Starts Taking Questions About Freeze
description: The Internal Revenue Service yesterday took over the task of answering public inquiries and complaints about Presi dent Nixon's 90day wageprice freeze  a job it inherited from the Office of Emergency Preparedness.

title: Advertising:
description: With each passing day, agency executives seem to be asking more and more ques tions about the 90day wage price freezes And, as the number of questions increase, the scarcity of answers indi cates vast confusion within the field as to the effect of the President's Economic Stabilization plan on agen cies and their clients.

title: 3 Apollo 15 Astronauts Given Medals by U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 24  The first awards of a new United Nations Peace Medal were presented by Secretary General Thant to day to the three Apollo 15 astronauts during their visit here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. HEAD DENIES PARITIES ARE SET
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 PierrePaul Schweitzer, Manag ing Director of the International Monetary Fund, acknowleadged today that the fund's staff had made calculationsrelating to a possible future realigment of currency exchange rates.

title: Testing Suggests Chrome From Soviet Is Rhodesian
description: American producers of spe cialty steels, which are heavy users of chromium and have been pressing the Nixon Ad ministration to end sanctions against imports of Rhodesian chrome ore, have produced chemical tests purporting to show that some of the current imports of Soviet chrome ore may actually have originated in Rhodesia.

title: Galbraith Corrects Galbraith's Errors
description: NEWFANE, Vt.  Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith has never found it difficult to admit he was right, and he gets his comeuppance in a forthcoming book by Prof. John Kenneth Galbraith.

title: Cambodian Airlifts Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)  Several Cambodian infantry, battalions have been airlifted to the provincial capital Kom pong Thom over the last few days as other troops began an operation to open Route 61 leading to the city, a military spokesman said today.

title: Bob McKinley Among Victors In U.S. Open Tennis Trials
description: Bob McKinley of St. Louis, Bill Brown of Omaha, Chico Vasquez of Argentina and Dick Knight of Belvieu, Wash., won qualifying matches yesterday for the United States Open ten nis championships that begin next week.

title: A Parley With U.S. Alone Is Ruled Out by Ministers
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Aug. 25 A committee of Cabinet min isters decided here yesterday that Japan would revalue the yen only after multilateral ne gotiations, as part of an inter national realignment of curren cies.

title: STANS FORESEES STRICT CONTROLS AFTER THE FREEZE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Secretary of Commerce Mau rice H. Stans said today he thought that some form of man datory wage and price controls would be required to restrain inflationary pressures after the 90day freeze ends Nov. 12.

title: City Salutes the Apollo 15 Astronauts With a Parade and Gold Medals
description: With speeches, prayer and simple applause the city greet ed the Apollo 15 astronauts yesterday, expressing thank fulness for their return, pride in their attainment and a hope that the technology they per sonify can solve human prob lems on earth.

title: and Justice for Panthers
description: If anything were needed to point up the advantages of law over violence, it has been provided in the recent judicial treatment of the Black Panther party, drama tized by yesterday's indictment of high Chicago offi cials in the case of Fred Hampton, slain Panther leader.

title: EVENTS IN SAIGON STIR U.S. CONCERN But McCloskey Says There Is No Indication of Coup
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  The Nixon Administration was reported today to be apprehen sive over political stability in South Vietnam in the wake of the events that have left Presi dent Nguyen Van Thieu as the only candidate in the presi dental election next October.

title: Public TV Unit Aims to Centralize News Activities
description: The National Public Affairs Broadcast Center, object of intense interest on the tight little island of public televi sion production, has begun to put its future into focus And the public TV word corn ing into clearer view is cen tralization.

title: New Bolivian Chief Affirms U.S. Ties
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 24 Col. Hugo Banzer Surez, who assumed the presidency Sun day after a rightist rebellion, said today that his Government would maintain friendly rela tions with the United States and would not seek to restore ties with Cuba.

title: Chemical Pact Approved
description: RENSSELAER, N. Y., Aug. 24 (UPI)  Some 470 chemical workers who had been on strike for three months agreed today to a new twoyear contract calling for a 15 per cent raise. However, because of President Nixon's wageprice freeze, the workers at the chemical plant of the GAF Corporation will continue working under the old contract until the freeze ends. They now average $3.58 an hour.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL OF VALACHI IS FILED UPSTATE
description: The will of Joseph Valachi  who at Senate hearings In 1963 publicly disclosed the in ner workings of the Mafia has been filed for probate in Niagara County Surrogate's Court in Lockport, N. Y.

title: HETTY BEATTY
description: Hetty Burlingame Beatty, author of books for children, died of cancer on Monday in Christiansted, St. Croix, V. I., where she lived with her hus band, Lewis Whitney, a sculp tor and artist. She was 63 years old.

title: Julian Clarence Levi. Dies at 96; Oldest Alumnus of Columbia U.
description: Julian Clarence Levi, archi tect, watercolorist and philan thropist, who was Columbia University's oldest living alum nus, class of '96, died Monday in the artfilled apartment op posite Carnegie Hall that had b.een his home for 44 years. He was 96 years old.

title: 11 Makers of AirConditioners Told to Prove Assertions in Ads
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 One advertisement says that the Carrier Corporation's Round One central aircondi tioners are quieter and last longer. Another touts the Rheem central airconditioner as the quietest, most efficient cooling you can get.

title: Bank Robbery Suspect Held
description: A hardware salesman was arrested yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation in connection with the $250,000 robbery of a bank at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn in April. The arrest of Walter Ryan, 37 years old, 564 85th Street, Brooklyn was the third made in connection with the robbery, in which the bank manager and 13 others were held hostage overnight before the robbery of the National Bank and Trust Company.

title: GEORGE LEE DIES; MT. SINAI TRUSTEE
description: George Lee, a retired busi ness executive, died Monday after a short illness in Mount Sinai Medical Center, of which he had been an active trustee since 1940. He was 78 years old and lived in the Hotel Sur rey at 20 East 76th Street.

title: Tragedy at San Quentin
description: It is not possible yet to pin down the grisly sequence of events at San Quentin Prison last Saturday. Only the immediate consequences of the tragedy are clear: three inmates and three guards are deadsome shot, some slashed in the throat with a dull razor blade. The escape attempt, according to prison authorities, was led by George Jacksonhimself now deadwho was awaiting trial for the murder of a guard thrown over a third floor cellblock railing at Soledad Prison in 1970. The official theory is that the gun used to launch the attack was smuggled in to the prisoner by a lawyer only min utes before the outbreak.

title: Common Market Decries import Surtax as Unfair
description: GENEVA, Aug. 24  The European Common Market protested today that the United States' 10 per cent import surtax was unfair and called for its early removal. Otherlarge trading powers joined in condemning the surcharge.

title: Berlin: Island of Peace
description: For a quartercentury, Berlin has been an island of trouble in the center of Europe, the neuralgic point that has sent out flashes of pain every time a crisis developed in SovietWestern relations. The new Big Four draft accords now promise to make. Berlin an island of peace, even though it will still be divided by a wall and heavily garrisoned on both sides. The new agreement provides the first detailed, written statute governing key elements of West Berlin's relations with West Germany, East Ger many and the four occupying powers since the 194849 Berlin blockade and the attendant breakdown of four power cooperation.

title: Music: Marriner Bows
description: One of the subsidiary Pleasures of this summer's Mostly Mozart Festival has been observing the chame leonic changes that different conductors bring about in the resident ensemble, the New York Chamber Orches tra. Even more so than a permanently established or chestra, such an ad hoc group of firstrate freelancers quick ly comes to reflect the musi cal personality and technical ability of the conductor of the moment.

title: BAHAMAS OIL PLANS REFINERY EXPANSION
description: The Bahamas Oil Refining Company announced yesterday plans to expand its refinery at Freeport, Grand Bahama Island, from a current capacity of 250, 000 barrels a day to 450,000 barrels a day of lowsulphur fuels.

title: Bus Crawl
description: New Yorkers have become conditioned to suffering patiently whenever traffic congestion or double parking forces their cars or buses to crawl through downtown streets. But, while the inescapable may have to be borne stoically, there is no reason why bus passengers must submit in silence to yet another form of vehicular tor turethe deliberate slowdown of buses whose drivers have moved too far ahead of their schedule or perhaps simply want to wait for the ponderous pack in which they usually travel to catch up. Curbside conferences with dispatchers further slow the progress.

title: VESCO LOSES FIGHT, APPEARS AT S.E.C.
description: Robert L. Vesco, chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., lost his battle yesterday to avoid appearing before the Securities and Exchange Com mission.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTONThere are currently pending in both Houses of Congress legislative proposals of a kind which I believe would do immense damage to the security of this nation and to the cause of world order. These meas ures are known collectively as the war power bills.

title: Black Chiefs in South Africa Invited to Parley in Malawi
description: NKOTAKOTA, Malawi, Aug. 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  President H. Kamuzu Banda announced today that he had invited black African leaders from South Africa's bantus tans and the Johannesburg township of Soweto to next month's convention of the Ma lawi Congress party.

title: U.A.w., IN A SHIFT, PLEDGES TO ADAPT TO WAGE CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  The president of the United Automobile Workers, one of the most outspoken opponents of President Nixon's new eco nomic program, said today that his union would try to accom modate itself to the 90day freeze as a practical matter.

title: U.S. Reserve Assets Off By $221Million in July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 United States international monetary reserve assets de clined by $221million in July, the last full month before President Nixon's action sus pending convertibility between the dollar and gold, the Treas ury reported today.

title: P.S.C. Is Studying Charges by Hotels For Phone Service
description: The Public Service Commis sion said yesterday that it was investigating 21 hotels and mo tels throughout the state that might have overcharged guests for telephone service.

title: $1.25BILLION SALE OF U.S. NOTES SET
description: The Treasury announced plans late yesterday to raise about $1.25billion by offering fiveyear, twomonth notes at a special auction next Tuesday.

title: Advertising:
description: A biweekly journal that will offer business information in condensed form is about to be started. Called Boardroom Reports, the 16page newsletter will present reports on 37 business categoriesfrom accounting to Wall Streeton a rotating basis.

title: ANTONIO MELI LUPI, SIGNED PEACE PACT
description: ROME, Aug. 25  Marchese Antonio Meli Lupi de Soragna Tarasconi, the ambassador who signed Italy's peace treaty after World War II in 1947 in Paris, died in Parma yesterday. He was 86 years old and had been living in Rome and Parma since retiring in 1952.

title: Miracle Go Takes Opening Sail Of Manhasset Bay Race Week
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 25The defending Etch ells22 class champion, Randy Bartholomew of the host club, with Miracle Go, passed five boats on her trip back today and won the opening race of the 39th annual Race Week on Manhasset Bay.

title: Robert T. Burke, 48, Dies; U.S. Aide at Gambia Mission
description: Robert T. Burke, a career diplomat, died on Friday of an apparent heart attack at his post as Deputy Chief of Mis sion in Bathurst, capital of Gambia, the State Department announced yesterday. He was 48 years old.

title: Turbine Engine Produced
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 25 (AP)  General Motors an nounced today it has begun in itial production of a 325horse power gas turbine engine de signed for bus, truck and in dustrial use.

title: Clearwater Captain Accused Of Taking Shower in Public
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 25 (UPI)The captain of the sloop Clearwater, the sailing boat used by the folk singer Pete Seeger, and others to publicize pollution in the Hudson River, was arrested toddy for indecent exposure and resisting arrest.

title: U.S. PANEL WEIGHS TAX AID TO PUPILS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The President's Panel on Non public Education is considering a tax credit plan that would reimburse the parents of pri vate school children for their educational expenses.

title: Man Killed and 35 Hurt in Belfast Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 25A man was killed and 35 people, mostly young women, were injured today in the worst bomb blast in Belfast this year.

title: Police Break Up Rally
description: SAIGON, Thursday, Aug. 26 (Reuters)South Vietnamese policemen broke up an election rally behind Saigon's National Assembly building today and arrested an antiGovernment candidate for this Sunday's lower house election and at least 10 students.

title: Ellsberg Is Commended
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 25 The Association for Education in Journalism today narrowly approved a resolution com mending Dr. Ellsberg for a valuable contribution to the people's right to know.

title: Notes on People
description: Neil A. Armstrong, the first man to walk on the moon, resigned his highlevel desk job at the National Aeronau tics and Space Administra tion in Washington to become the first University Professor of Engineering at the Uni versity of Cincinnatia posi tion created especially for him.

title: GATT Sets Surtax Study
description: GENEVA, Thursday, Aug. 26 The world's leading trading powers decided early today to attempt to determine for them selves whether the United States was justified in taking protectionist measures to bol ster its faltering economy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Merger News
description: Former stockholders of the Piper Aircraft Corporation who turned in their Piper shares to the Bangor Punta Corporation in exchange for securities of Bangor Punta will be given an opportunity to undo the ex change, a Federal judge de clared here yesterday.

title: Roundup: Bunt Proves Slugger's Mettle
description: Frank Robinson is not usually considered the self sacrificing type, but when the proper occasion arises, he can lay it down as well as any man.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25President Nixon's New Economic Program is a smash hit so far; Dr. Gallup findS that 91 per cent of a sample of more than 500 had heard of the President's moves, with 46 per cent strongly ap proving and only 5 per cent strongly. disapproving.

title: ARGENTINA REDUCES VALUE OF PESO 6.38%
description: BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 25A 6.38 per cent devaluation of the Argentine peso in relation to the United States dollar went into effect today when the of ficial foreignexchange market reopened after being closed 11 days.

title: Queens Grocer, 65, Chases 2 Robbers, Kills One of Them
description: The 65yearold owner of a small supermarket in Queens chased two gunmen who had held him up yesterday after noon, intercepted their car, wrested a shotgun from one of them and in an exchange of fire mortally wounded the man.

title: Terrified East Flatbush Little Stirred by Slaying
description: To most of the people along Church Avenue in East Flat bush yesterday, the murder of Thomas V. Higgins in the local Bohack supermarket the night before was not much more than a conversational tidbitsome thing to shake one's head about, perhaps, but nothing to get very frightened about.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Striking Union Calls Dismissals Illegal At Modern Museum
description: Striking employes of the Museum of Modern Art filed charges yesterday with the Na tional Labor Relations Board, charging that the museum had violated the law by dismissing professional and other staff members during contract nego tiations.

title: Freeze Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Following is the sixth set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Books of The Times
description: THE BEAT GENERATION. By Bruce Cook. 248 pages. Scribners. $6.95.

title: Libel Suit Is Dismissed
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 (UPI) Judge James Meredith of Dis trict Court dismissed today Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes's $12million libel suit against Time, Inc., for an article in Life magazine that said the St. Louis Mayor had business and personal ties with gangsters. The judge's dismissal of the suit with prejudice means that it cannot be refiled.

title: S.E.C. Will Explore Need Of Single Stock Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it will conduct its own inquiry into the broad issues of the future membership, structure and regulation of the nation's securities markets. Fundamental questions, such as the need to develop a single, national system of securities exchanges, will be examined at public hearings, beginning Oct. 12. Other matters to be ex plored include whether all stock trades in all markets should be recorded on a single ticker tape, whether different types of securities markets justify different degrees of regula tion, and whether institutions such as mutual funds should be permitted to become ex change members.

title: Ballet West U.S.A. Draws A Record Audience in Vichy
description: VICHY, France, Aug. 25 (AP) Ballet West U.S.A. drew the largest audience of the season when it opened a twonight visit at the Casino Theater here last night.

title: ZeissIkon Plans to Shut Voigtlander Unit in 1972
description: BONN, Aug. 25  Voigt lnder of Braunschweig, West Germany's oldest camera mak er, will stop its production and close down in September, 1972, its parent company, ZeissIkon, confirmed today.

title: Empty Hospital Beds
description: Discussions of America's health care problems usually begin with the assumption that this nation suffers from severe shortages in all the basic human and material resources required in this field. But at the current meet ing of the American Hospital Association in Chicago much attention has been paid to the problem and costs of excess capacity.

title: Julie Eisenhower Ends FullTime Teaching Job
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP)  President Nixon's younger daughter, Mrs. David Eisenhower, has decided on advice from the White House doctor against resuming her fulltime teach ing job at an elementary school in Florida because of an accident in which her toe was broken, the Western White House said today.

title: Mexico Studies Trading
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Mexican Government has begun a study of the Mexico City Stock Exchange aimed at making investing in securities as popular as in the United States, the National Securities Commission said today.

title: Auden and Casals Writing Hymn to Peace for U.N.
description: An ode to world peace by W. H. Auden, the poet, with music by Pablo Casals, has been commissioned by Secre tary General Thant for the United Nations anniversary concert here on Oct. 24.

title: Defense Contractors Cut Top Security Clearances
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The nation's military and de fense contractors, at the re quest of the Defense Depart ment, report that they are quietly making substantial re ductions in the number of their employes who hold topsecret Government security clear ances.

title: Power to the MajorityWomen
description: I am one of those rare creatures, Congresswoman, and that may explain why I was invited recently to appear on a Bob Hope TV comedy show as part of an allfemale variety act. turned it down, of course, because see nothing funny about the scarcity of women political leaders in our country. In fact, I think it is a national scandal.

title: Chinese Reds Complete Rebuilding of Party at Provincial Level
description: HONG KONG, Thursday Aug. 26Peking announced today that Communist party com mittees had been formed in Szechwan, Tibet, Ningsia and Heilungkiang. The move com pleted the process of rebuild ing the party at province level, where party committees were smashed during the Cultural Revolution, and many of the party leaders were purged.

title: Youth Slain in East Harlem In a Drug Deal Argument
description: An 18yearold youth was shot and killed on an East Har lem street yesterday as he and two other young men argued over a narcotics transaction, the police said.

title: Explosives Stolen in Britain
description: LONDON, Aug. 25  More than 800 pounds of gelignite and 1.300 detonators were stolen from an explosives deal er near Reading, in Berkshire in Southern England yesterday.

title: MARKET'S RISE CUT BY PROFIT TAKING
description: The stock market's strong momentum was slowed yester day by profit taking. But popu lar averages posted gains and advances on the New York Stock Exchange outpaced de clines by better than a 4to3 ratio.

title: Court Is Challenged in Cairo Coup Trial
description: CAIRO, Aug. 25Angry shouts from defense attorneys challenging the legality of threeman revolutionary tri bunal disrupted the opening session this morning of the trial of the former Vice Presi dent, Aly Sabry, and other high officials arrested in May after a challenge to the leader ship of President Anwar el Sadat.

title: STEPHEN DUGGAN, 76, OF FIFTH AVE. COACH
description: TEANECK, N. J., Aug. 25 Stephen C. Duggan, who re tired in 1962 as executive vice president of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., of New York, died of a pulmonary attack yester day in Holy Name Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 152 Grayson Place.

title: Douglas and Cash Star in 'A Gunfight' With Apache Backing
description: "A Gunfight" was financed by the Jicarilla Apache Tribe. This, so far as I know, is the first time that a movie has been backed by Indians. The Jicarillas are now, as investors, in a class with Quaker Oats and Bristol-Myers, who are also making movies. Not surprisingly, these Apaches have made a Western, but a Western without Indians. It's the cowboys against the cowboys with no commercial message from the sponsor.The distributor, Paramount, by dropping the picture quietly into neighborhood theaters is obviously making a judgment about the movie's box-office potential. Enter the reviewer, hopeful to prove that the studio is myopic, the Indians are sage and the movie is a sleeper  like "Lonely Are the Brave," "Will Penny," "Ride the High Country," "The Ballad of Cable Hogue.""A Gunfight" reminded me just a little of "Ride the High Country." Like that Sam Peckinpah classic, Lamont Johnson's movie concerns two retired cowboys, compelled to return to action for one last time. Here the two are antagonists, ex-gunfighters, Kirk Douglas and Johnny Cash.Douglas is Will Tenneray, once infamous in Dodge City, but now settled into a boring respectability. He is paid to stand at a bar and "sucker fools to buy drinks." Cash is Abe Cross, a successful killer turned into a failed prospector. He is a loner, riding into the movie to the tune of an off-camera Johnny Cash title song ("It's an evil wind that blows . . ."). Everyone expects them to blow each other's brains out, and betting begins even before Douglas's son (his son, Eric) first cries, "Paw, Abe Cross is in town!"Although Douglas and Cash have never met, they know each other's inflated reputation. They have much in common, but of course they decide to duel  for the moneyand to justify the title of the picture. Survivor takes all, and as the advertisements say, spoiling the surprise ending, "Widow takes the body."Much is made out of the humor of the situation (although this is not really a comedy). These are two old teases  demanding money from a big-city reporter to let him take their picture pointing guns at each other. "Ain't this familiar?" jokes Cash.It is mostly the stars' presence that gives the movie authenticity  Douglas with his aging chin-dimple more and more resembling a bullet wound; Cash, his face corrugated, his voice rumbling and gravelly. They are a natural match: Douglas's grin hiding despair, Cash's frown concealing an inward ease.Their acting manages to be both laconic and forceful even as the movie grooves into clich. "You want to be Tenneray again," Douglas's wife explains his new will to kill. The direction becomes flaccidblurred foregrounds and smudged focus. The symbolism is stock. The gunfight will take place in a bullring, in itself a too-obvious notion made worse by earlier use of bullfight music as a pace-heightening device. Laurence Rosenthal has composed a symphonic score that is jarring to the simplicity of the moodlike playing the "Grand Canyon" Suite before an Edward Hooper landscape. Cash's tune would have been much more compatible as a running theme.Mostly what is missing is any detailing of the bond between fighters. Douglas tells his wife (an excellent performance by Jane Alexander) that if he kills Cash he will lose his last friend, but there is little to prove the statement. One is reminded again of "Ride the High Country." Joel McCrea and Randolph Scott, stripped to their sagging longjohns, were not tintype cowboys but real, salty people trapped by their choice of lives. "A Gunfight" merely goes through the motions.

title: New World Economic Balance
description: The United States' major trading partners, though stunned and angered by President Nixon's unilateral decision to upset the established rules of world trade and monetary exchange, are not rushing to retaliate.

title: SAMUEL SWERN
description: TRENTON, Aug. 25Samuel Swern, founder of the Swern &Co. depatment store and founder and president of the Stacy Savings & Loan Associa tion, died today in Mercer Hospital. He was 81 year old and lived at 333 West Eighth Street.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Because winning armies are expensive to assemble and risky to maintain, a country's best propaganda toolpound for pound and dollar for dollar  is a successful world class athletic team: an example of socialism in action or a testament to the vitality of democracy or living proof the people love the junta. Such a team, the theory holds, bolsters the will of the home folk, increases the respect of allies and uncommitted nations, and demoralizes the opposition.

title: 2 Brooklyn Children Injured When a Building Collapses
description: Two children were injured, one of them seriously, yester day afternoon when a building about to be demolished col lapsed, partly burying the two boys in Brooklyn's Coney Island section.

title: Employable Welfare Recipients Put to Work Cleaning Up Parks
description: On the Central Park Mall, in the green islands of Broadway above Lincoln Center, in play grounds and small parks, men from the welfare rolls were at work yesterday morning, clean ing up the city.

title: SURGE OF ATTACKS HITS ALLIED POSTS; MORE PREDICTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 26In a surge of attacks on allied installa tions yesterday, enemy forces shelled several American bases and sent explosions ripping through a huge American am munition dump at Camranh Bay.

title: Avoiding a Voter Hoax
description: Archaic and cumbersome voter registration regulations in this state, far too restrictive all along, threaten now to prove downright discriminatory in the case of newly enfranchised young voters. Unless the State Legislature adopts reforms, these regulations will probably prevent hundreds of thousands in the 1821year age group from participating in next year's Presidential primaries.

title: Federal Study May Affect City Nicotine and Tar Tax
description: One of the city's nuisance taxes based on cigarette tar and nicotine content may be affected by a reevaluation be ing conducted by the Federal Trade Commission. City Finance Administrator Richard Lew isohn said yesterday.

title: SHARES ON AMEX DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday after profit taking in the afternoon erased most of the session's earlier gains.

title: Prognosis on Johnson: He'll Be Walking Today
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 25Ron Johnson, the Giants' No. 1 running back, will be up and walking tomorrow, according to Dr. Anthony Pisani, the club's physician, who operated on the player's right thigh today to eliminate a deep blood clot.

title: U.S. Choirs' Czech Tour Ends With a Hallelujah
description: PRAGUE, Aug. 25An in formal and apparently highly successful experiment in EastWest relations ended this morning at Prague Air port, perhaps typically, with a rousing rendition of Han del's Hallelujah chorus.

title: Retail Chain Gains
description: The J. C. Penney Company, Ic., which operates many re tail stores, had record sales and earnings in the fiscal sec ond quarter and half year end ed July 31, the company re ported yesterday.

title: STUDENT ADOPTED BY HIS ROOMMATE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25 (AP) A judge has granted the adoption of Jack Baker, 28 years old, president of the University of Minnesota Stu dent Association, by his room mate, James McConell, also 28.

title: Rail Loss Widens
description: The trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday that the railroad's net loss in July widened sharply to $27, 953,761 from a deficit of $1, 835,384 in June. In July, 1970, the first month after the road filed for protection under the bankruptcy' laws, it had a loss of $33,924,696.

title: Thieu to Go Ahead With OneMan Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25  President Nguyen Van Thieu told his campaign managers today to proceed with plans for the October Presidential elections while American officials continued their efforts to try to salvage the appearance of a contested race.

title: CourtMartial Jury Hears Tapes Made at Mylai
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 25 The controversial assault by American infantrymen on the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 came to life in a court room here today in a dramatic taperecording of radio trans missions made during the attack.

title: Chinatown Man Accused of Bribing Five Detectives
description: The police arrested a 60year old man in Chinatown last night and charged him with of fering a $5,000 bribe to drop narcotics charges against him.

title: STEEL IMPORTERS APPEAL ON SURTAX
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Steel importers appealed to the Treasury today for an exemp tion from the new 10 per cent import surcharge, on the ground that steel imports were as much controlled by quotas as exempted products like sug ar, beef and oil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bar Urges Judge to Quit Panther Case
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25  The Chicago Bar Association urged today that Judge Joseph A. Power of the Cook County Criminal Court dissociate him self from further legal proceed ings involving charges against Cook County State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan and 13 other law enforcement officials. The bar group also asked that a judge be brought in from outside Cook County to hear the case.

title: Chess:Popovych Takes Laurels In National Congress Play
description: Dr. Orest Popovych, a pro fessor of chemistry at Brook lyn College and in the last year or so one of America's most successful tournament players, scored 71 to win the premier section of the Na tional Chess Congress, held in Cleveland the last week in July. In second place was Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York, with 61.

title: Agnew Denounces Nitpicking Critics Of Nixon Program
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 25 (UPI) Vice President Agnew opened a counterattack today on nit picking Democrats and labor leaders who had criticized Pres ident Nixon's wageprice freeze.

title: GALLINA'S 3 GOALS TIE COSMOS HERE
description: Andy Mate, who had been sidelined by a leg injury, started his first game at Yan kee Stadium last night and scored two goals, but the Cosmos were eventually tied, 33, by the Montreal Olympics.

title: Ugandans Reported Repulsed
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 25 (Reuters)  Officials said today that Tanzanian troops had repulsed Ugandan invaders before dawn today and that not one enemy is now on Tanzanian soil.

title: Raid Suspect Identified
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 25 (AP) One of five young persons ar rested during a weekend raid of Selective Service and mili tary intelligence files has been identified as a son of an exec utive of the Buffalo Bills foot ball team.

title: Ward Completes Talks
description: Montgomery Ward, Chicago, the retail  store division of Marcor, Inc., confirmed yester day that it had completed nego tiations to sell two of its New Jersey stores, in Eatontown and Edison  Menlo Park, to Alex ander's, Inc. Alexander's plans to renovate the stores and open them under its own name in the fall of 1972.

title: Ugandans Tell of Drive 10 Miles Into Tanzania
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 25 (AP)  Ugandan troops ad vanced nearly 10 miles into Tanzania during border clashes, a high Government source said today.

title: $500Million Damage Suit Filed Against EI Paso Gas
description: LAS VEGAS, Aug. 25 (UPI) William M. Bennett, a member of the California State Board of Equalization, has field a $500  million damage suit against the El Paso Natural Gas Company.

title: Market Place:Schenley Deal Raises Questions
description: Let's say you're a Schen ley shareholder and you didn't like the terms under which Glen Alden took over your company. That's your prerogative, but what could you do about it?

title: Not Simply Lib, but a Better Husband
description: ATLANTAAfter ten harried years of raising babies and borrowing money and postponing vacations, it was be ginning to look like we might see daylight. Both the children will be in school this fall, there is finally some extra money, we are in our first house, the insurance is paid up, and she was even planning to get a job simply so she could get out and talk to grownups again. But then she came home from the doctor's office on April Fools' Day and said she was expecting on Thanksgiving, which sounded like something out of Love of Life but was, she assured me, the absolute truth, and here we go again; dry heaves at dawn, sleepless nights, medi cal expenses, baby furniture, false labor pains and no vacation. It was a mistake, I say. I'll be sure to tell the baby, she replies. Why didn't she go to the Pill, or try the IUD? You have to remember, says one of her friends, smiling acidly, it takes two to make a baby. Well, yes, you're right, I know that, but.

title: 3 in West Virginia Are Indicted in Plot To Defraud the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  Former West Virginia Attorney General C. Donald Robertson, his brother and a former Federal housing official were indicted today on charges of conspiring to defraud the United States.

title: City's Investigation Unit A Center of Controversy
description: The City's Department of In vestigation is now embroiled in a series of charges and countercharges on how effec tively it is exposing corruption and mismanagement in the city.

title: Yankees Win
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 25 Steve Kline's wellcontrolled pitching and Bobby Murcer's three runs batted in led the New York Yankees to a 42 vic tory over the Oakland Athletics tonight, and gave them the series, two games to one.

title: G.I.'S Tar a Vietnamese Private After Thefts at Base
description: QUANGTRI COMBAT BASE, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 (UPI) American soldiers, outraged by a series of thefts and burglar ies in their barracks here, re portedly shot the tires out from under a truckload of stolen goods Monday and then beat and tarred the South Vietnam ese driver.

title: ACCORD ON BERLIN APPROVED IN BONN
description: BONN, Aug. 25The West German Government formally endorsed today the tentative agreement on West Berlin reached Monday by negotiators for the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.

title: Heat Causes Football Death
description: PRINCESS ANNE, Md., Aug. 25 (UPI)Earl Shores, an 18 yearold freshman, died yester day of heat exhaustion following football practice at the Eastern Shore campus of the University of Maryland. The autopsy re port was made public today.

title: CONTEMPT OF COURT BY WALLACE CHARGED
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 25 Attorneys for the N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., asked a threejudge Federal court today to initiate contempt of court proceedings against Gov. George C. Wallace.

title: CARL BLEGEN DIES; ARCHEOLOGIST, 84
description: ATHENS, Aug. 25Dr. Carl W. Blegen, the American arche ologist who made important discoveries of the palace of King Nestor and of scenes re corded by Homer, at Troy and Pylos, died last night after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: French Approve Draft
description: PARIS, Aug. 25The French cabinet today announced its approval of the agreement on Berlin. The agreement was called a balanced compromise by Lo Hamon, the govern ment spokesman.

title: Most Hospital Directors Accept Freeze
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25The na tion's hospital directors who are meeting here today are re acting gingerly to President Nixon's wageprice freeze, with most of them saying they are willing to go along with the Executive order.

title: Loan Board Postpones Decision on Lockheed Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)A decision on whether to grant a $250million Gov ernmentguaranteed loan to the financially troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion was postponed today by the board created by Con gress to deal with the issue.

title: Women's Rights Day Today
description: Mayor Lindsay, asserting that the 19th Amendment is a symbol of unfulfilled prom ise, has proclaimed today Women's Rights Day.

title: CUNARD ANNOUNCES DIRECTOR CHANGES
description: LONDON, Aug. 25Cunard announced changes in its directors today after Trafalgar House Investments claimed victory in its fight to take over the shipping group.

title: WORLDSWIMMARK SET BY M'BREEN
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Tom McBreen of San Mateo, Calif., set a world record of 4:02.1 in the 400meter free style tonight in the finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union swimming champion ships.

title: State Seeks to Stop Sewage Dumping by Circle Line
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz asked State Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin the Circle Line from discharging raw sewage into New York Bay.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Fibreboard Corporation announced yesterday the election of Melvin L. Levine as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Levine, formerly execu tive vice president, succeeds George W. Burgess, who becomes chairman and will continue as chief executive officer. Mr. Levine, 54 years old, prior to joining Fibreboard last year had been executive vice president of the United Fruit Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Anderson Rides Winner
description: YARMOUTH, England, Aug. 25 (UPI)  Pete Anderson, an American jockey on a three week British tour, made his second ride in England a win ning one by steering 41 chance, Capistrano, to a threequarter length victory in the Longshore Handicap today. Alcindoro, the 52 favorite, was second.

title: Japanese Viewed as Refusing to Crumble Under Pressure From Washington
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 26  Washington overestimated the effect of the Nixon shock here, a foreign diplomat said yesterday. It expected Japan to crumble and revalue the yen in a panic.

title: Man in the News
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25When Barnabas Francis Sears walks confidently into a courtroom, the first descriptive tag that comes to mind is grand fatherly. Short, silverhaired, a trifle portly, with twinkling brown eyes and a gentle smile, Mr. Sears prefers to be thought of as one of the last of the real country lawyers. At the moment it is doubtful that Edward V. Han rahan, state's at torney for Cook County, one of his assistants and 12 Chi cago police officers, would agree with either of these de scriptions.

title: Icebreaker Contract Set
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25. (UPI)The Lockheed Ship building and Construction Company, a subsidiary of the Lockheed Aircraft Corpora tion, has been awarded a $52.7million contract to build the world's most powerful icebreaker for the Coast Guard, the Department of Transportation announced today.

title: Badillo Innovates in His Diverse District
description: I've told all the Democrat ic Presidential contenders that if they have only one day to spend looking at urban problems, come to my district, Representative Her man Badillo said the other day. My district has it all.

title: Bingham Says Son May Have Unknowingly Aided Plot
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 25 The father of Stephen M. Bing ham, the attorney suspected of smuggling a gun into San Quen tin Prison last Saturday shortly before an attemped escape in which six persons were killed, said tonight that his son could have been the unwitting instru ment of an escape plot.

title: Fire Kills Handicapped Man
description: Edward Wong, a 60yearold man confined to a wheel chair, died shortly before noon yester day when a fire, of unknown origin, broke out in his fifth floor apartment of the sixstory building at 52 Kenmare Street, near Mott Street. Officials re ported that the fire was con fined to Mr. Wong's apartment.

title: Speedy Computer Printer Developed by ScanOptics
description: ScanOptics, Inc., of East Hartford, Conn., announced yesterday that it had developed a new highspeed line printer for computers using a nonim pact technique.

title: Betty Friedan Says a Woman Should Run Against Celler
description: Betty Friedan, the founder of the National Organization for Women, said yesterday that some woman, perhaps herself, would probably run against Representative Eman uel Celler of Brooklyn in next year's Democratic primary.

title: COAST LAND ABUSE CHARGED BYNADER
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 Ralph Nader charged today that California's mountains, deserts and seacoast were being as saulted by speculators who bulldozed thousands of lots that had littile or no prospact of be coming home sites.

title: Army Withdraws Witness At Medina's CourtMartial
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 25  The Government's case against Capt. Ernest L. Medina suffered a series of ma jor blows today.

title: News of Dogs
description: P. Carl Tuttle of Rector town, Va., wears two hats in the dog show rings. He's a leading exhibitor and he's in demand as a judge. Asked which role he finds the more demanding, Tuttle responded, Showing. When you judge, you win all the time. Not that his dogs haven't done their share of winning. His Ger man shorthaired pointer, Ch. Gun Hill's Mesa Mav erick, was best of breed 175 times and had 98 group placements. Four times Ricky, as he is called by Tuttle, was best in show and he took a dozen specialties, including the national twice.

title: SOVIET SAYS CHINA BARS BORDER PACT
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 25The So viet Union charged today that China had rejected construc tive proposals made by Moscow to settle disputed border questions in 22 months of talks in Peking.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Aug. 26, 1971
description: SECURITY COUNCIL Meets at 10:30 A.M. on question of mission to in vestigate Guinea's charges of Portuguese invasion threat.

title: Seoul Shifts Air Force Aide
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 25 (AP)The Government to day named Lieut. Gen. Ok Man Ho, deputy air force chief of staff, to succeed the outgoing chief of staff, Gen. Kim Doo Man. General Kim and Defense Minister Jung Nae Hiuk re signed Monday, assuming re sponsibility for the mutiny of 24 prisoners on an island air force prison earlier that day. Defense Minister Jung was re placed by Yu Jae Heung on Tuesday.

title: U.S. to Act Within 2 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The United States is expected to accept the draft text of the Berlin accord within two weeks, Administration officials said to day. The prediction followed a twohour meeting between Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Kenneth Rush, the United States Ambassador to Bonn.

title: For Ghetto Children, a Gift With Impact
description: It took some convincing on the part of the wife of the president of the World Bank, but it wasn't stealing that she had in mind when she said that she wanted children to be able to help themselves to books.

title: Thompson Quits Jets for God:
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 Steve Thompson does not dislike football and he doesn't classify himself as quote religious, but today the New York Jets' 6foot5 inch, 245pound firststring defensive tackle announced his retirement from the sport because of his beliefs in God.

title: SAFEGUARDS SET UP BY BOARD OF TRADE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 25 (AP)  The Chicago Board of Trade announced today the imple mentation of a system designed to detect financial problems of member firms at an early stage and to protect nonregulated customer funds that might be affected.

title: Numbered Account Triumphs by 2 Lengths in Spinaway at Spa
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25Numbered Account was reactivated today, and as a $5,000 supplementary nomi nation, won the hearts of the favorite players in the crowd of 17,187 fans who saw the 80th running of the Spinaway. Ogden Phipps's 2yearold filly, a Kentuckybred daughter of Buckpasser, opposed half a dozen others of her age and sex in the sixfurlong sprint and won by 2 lengths.

title: Mitchell Aide Got Unsecured Loan From Developer
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 25Assist Ant Attorney General Will R. Wilson Jr. acknowledged today that he had gotten a $30,000, unsecured loan last August ?? a bank. owned by Frank W. Sharp, a Houston real es tate developer who was under investigation by Federal author ties on suspicion of stock raud.

title: U.S.Thai Group Is Set Up To Deal With Drug Problem.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  The State Department announced today that the United States and Thailand were setting up a joint planning group to help deal with the drug problem.

title: Seaplanes Tried as a STOL Substitute
description: The city conceded yester day that the longheralded STOLport program was stalled as it began a study on setting up a seaplane service along the Northeast Coast instead.

title: Personal Finance: Repossessions Act
description: Irene Williams bought a set of automobile tires on the in stallment plan not too long ago. She couldn't afford to keep up the payments, so the dealer took the tires back. He also took the car.

title: Mostly Mozart Takes a Detour With Mostly Schubert Concert
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival being presented at Philhar monic Hall this month took a mostly Schubert detour on Tuesday evening in a concert played by a chamber ensemble headed by Alexander Schneider. Mozart was touched upon with the Quartet in F for oboe, violin, viola and cello (K. 370), after which came Schubert's String Trio in B flat and Trout Quintet.

title: BREWERY IN LONDON NEARS A TAKEOVER
description: LONDON, Aug. 25 (UPI) Maxwell Joseph, the hotel ex ecutive, appeared today to be the winner of the takeover battle for Trumans, the London brewery.

title: A Restaurant With a Short Pedigree, but a Real Thoroughbred
description: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 25 Martha's Vineyard has always played host to a varied crowd of summer visitors, but each major group tends to gravitate toward a favored section of this 150squaremile island, which is 45 minutes by ferry from Cape Cod.

title: Neighborhoods: Bronx Board Debates Parks' Deterioration
description: Are Bronx parks deteriorating because of poor equipment and lack of maintenance, or because they are repeatedly vandalized?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS GET GRANT TO HIRE SUBSTITUTES
description: An official of the personnel department of the Board of Ed ucation said yesterday that a total of 275 substitute high school, elementary and special school teachers would be hired for the fall term under a $17 million Federal grant New York City has received under flip Emergency Employment Act.

title: ErrorHuman and Political
description: It is not pleasant for anyone to have an oil slick washed up on his private beach, but if you are President of the United States you are in a better position than most to do something about it. As Commander in Chief of the armed forces, President Nixon had only to let it be known that gobs of oil had appeared on the sands of his Western White House at San Clemente to have sailors and marines arrive and pick up the stuff by hand which was fair enough since the oil had come from a naval tanker offshore.

title: Man Found Slain in Car, Believed to Be Policeman
description: The body of a man believed to be a police sergeant with the narcotics bureau was found by the police in Brooklyn early today slumped behind the steer ing wheel of a car, a gunshot wound in his head.

title: Woody Strode Brings Rich Talents to a Limp 'Black Jesus'
description: Woody Strode? Yes, yes, a thousand times yes. "Black Jesus?" No.It was a thrill yesterday to see the name of this exceptionally fine Negro actor elevated to solo star billing, after propping up many a film for years. Sadly, neither this Italian-made picture nor the role itself, primarily a matter of saintly symbolism, are up to him.Mr. Strode, with his keen, lidded eyes and strong, gaunt face, does a perfectly respectable job of portraying an imprisoned, tortured and executed visionary leader in an African country. His gentle spirit of nonviolence and agonized endurance under pressure are painfully real. The rest is not.The film is a shadow play, hardly a movie at all. Except for the opening and finale, it is glued to the inside of a prison, where the camera carefully measures every footstep and monosyllabic utterance. The picture is stark, studied and slow as a snail.This would be O.K. if we simply knew more about the characters. Who exactly are the brutal whites running the prison? The implication is that they are Belgian, although the commandant, played by Jean Servais, happens to be Dutch. Mr. Servais is excellent in the only entirely lucid characterization in the film.The third key role, apparently meant as a latter-day Barabbas, is that of a babbling, half-mad thief in the prison cell, played by Franco Citti.For that matter, how did Mr. Strode's martyr arise to leadership? And what is the real nub of the political conflict? The direction of Valerio Zurlini is so deliberately careful and overly detailed, much of it meaningless, that the film gets downright tedious. Finally, with the mixture of English and dubbed English, the dialogue has a curious, singsong quality.The face of Mr. Strode is memorable. It's not enough.

title: American Banks Step Up Borrowing of Eurodollars
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (Reu ters)  Eurodollar borrowings by United States banks rose $270million in the week ended Aug. 18 to $1,374,000,000 out standing, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeze on Rents Termed Threat to Housing Here
description: Six real estate groups, repre senting owners and builders in the city, said yesterday that President Nixon's 90day wage price freeze would cause an acceleration in the abandon ment of buildings.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 25George Bush, chief United States delegate to the United Nations conferred today with Secretary General Thant on relief for East Pakistan. Mr. Bush said he had named his deputy in the Security Council, W. Tapley Bennett, to head United States work with the relief task force now being set up by Mr. Thant.

title: Savings Units Set Record For July Mortgage Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  New mortgage loans by savings and loan associations were just under $4billion in July, down a little from June but a record for any July, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported to day.

title: Consumerism Rings the Bell
description: Telephone users in this state seem likely to get a bill of rights to protect them against having to pay a bill for inadequate service. The proposed safeguards underscore the degree to which rising consumer pressure and admin istrative changes in the Public Service Commission have turned that state agency into a watchdog for the public, instead of the supine servant of the utilities it once was.

title: 7 South Bronx Firemen Injured in Barrage of Bottles
description: Seven firemen were injured last night when they were showered with a barrage of bottles, bricks and other debris while responding to a large bonfire in the South Bronx.

title: Syracuse Police Official Wins Obstruction Case
description: SYRACUSE, Aug. 25 Charges against James Longo, deputy police chief here, were dismissed today by Onondaga County Court Judge Thomas Aloi.

title: Carty Beaten in Atlanta; 3 Policemen Suspended
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (UPI) Atlanta's Mayor, Sam Massell, said today a brawl that left the Atlanta outfielder Rico Carty with two black eyes, a split finger and bruises was blatant brutality. He suspended three policemen involved.

title: Schuyler Resigns Post Of Patents Commissioner
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  William E. Schuyler Jr. has submitted to President Nixon his resignation as Commission er of Patents, it was learned today. His deputy, Robert Gottschalk, is acting head of the Patent Office.

title: STATE ARTS UNITS GET $3.7 MILLION
description: The New York State Council on the Arts, which awarded grants to 100 arts groups earlier this year, announced yesterday that 142 more arts organizations in the State would receive $3,771,747 in aid. Funds approved so far by the council come to more than $5million.

title: Olmedo, Graebner And Riessen Gain In Eastern Tennis
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 25Alex Olmedo of Los An geles upset John Alexander of Australia today to leave only twoseeded players, Marty Ries sen of Evanston, Ill. and Clark Graebner of New York, in the quarterfinal field of the $25,000 Eastern grass courts champion ships at the Orange Lawn Ten nis Club.

title: LINDSAY APPEALS FOR GUN CONTROL
description: Mayor Lindsay, citing the murders of nine New York City policemen this year, ap pealed formally yesterday to Attorney General John N. Mit chell to support new Federal legislation to halt the traffic in handguns.

title: 12Month Sales Up
description: The Consolidated Foods Cor poration, a diversified producer of branded consumer goods and services, yesterday reported rec ord earnings and sales for its fiscal year ended July 3.

title: Mutual Fund Assets Grow
description: Total net assets of American mutual funds rose to $57.12 billion on June 30 from the yearearlier $40.59billion, Wie senberger Services, Inc., report ed yesterday.

title: REV. JOHN F. HAYES
description: The Rev. John F. Hayes, pas tor emeritus of St. Paul's Ro man Catholic Church, Court and Congress Streets, Brooklyn, died on Tuesday in Port Jeffer son, L. I. He was 67 years old.

title: East Germans to Cooperate
description: BERLIN, Aug. 25  Political sources in East Germany said today that the Government was committed to cooperate fully and speedily with the West Germans in filling out details of the draft accord on Berlin.

title: MARGARET CASE, 79, AN EDITOR OF VOGUE
description: Margaret Case, a contribut ing editor of Vogue magazine, fell or jumped to her death shortly before 8 A.M. yester day from the bedroom of her apartment at 535 Park Avenue to an inner courtyard below. She was 79 years old.

title: High Peking Official Is Greeted in Tokyo By Sato Spokesman
description: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 26 Wang Kuochuan, Peking's top official under Premier Chou Enlai on matters dealing with Japan, arrived last night to attend the funeral of a senior Japanese statesman and to promote ChineseJapanese ties at a time when Japanese lead ers are reevaluating the strength and reliability of their relations with the United States.

title: EXJERSEY LEADER INDICTED IN FRAUD
description: NEWARK, Aug. 25Walter H. Jones, a Commissioner of the Port of New York Author ity and one of New Jersey's most prominent Republicans, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of covering up a $2.4 million bank fraud in Bergen County.

title: Camden Antiwar Activists Say Trusted Member Was Informer
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 25 The antiwar activists arrested last weekend for allegedly trying to steal draft files here acknowledged today that one of their members had betrayed them to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but they did not name him publicly.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Voices New Doubts On Reopening Suez Canal
description: CAIRO, Aug. 25The Gov ernment of President Anwar elSadat is having serious sec ond thoughts about the value to Egypt and her allies of reopen frig the Suez Canal.

title: Cancer Lab Loses Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP)  The Government has withdrawn Federal recognition of and payments to the Ex foliative Cytology Pathology Laboratory, a unit of United Medical Laboratories, Inc., Portland, Ore., because of its lax handling of cancer detec tion tests.

title: City Voter Registration To Close Next Monday
description: Those who wish to vote in the Nov. 2 general election must register by next Mon day or during the special local registration period on Sept. 30, Oct. 1 and 2.

title: Con Ed Sees Urgent Need For Approval of New Plant
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has asked the Atomic Energy Commission for quick approval on starting up its new 873,000kilowatt nuclear plant at Indian Point to meet the crucial requirements for electricity here.

title: Ted Lewis, Showman, Dies at 80
description: Ted Lewis, the entertainer with the battered top hat who began his act with a shouted Js ev'rybody happy?, died of a heart attack at his home yes terday. He was 80 years old and lived at 115 Central Park West.

title: City Agencies Bid for 13,000 Employables on Welfare
description: City agencies have bid for 13,000 employable relief re cipients to work for them un der the new state law requir ing such persons to work out the amount of their relief grants if the State Employment Service does not find private jobs for them.

title: Canadian Calls for Parley
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 25Edgar J. Benson, Canadian Finance Min ister, said today that he had called a meeting of the Group of Ten finance ministers for Sept. 15 to discuss moves with in the International Monetary Fund to meet the dollar crisis. The meeting will probably be held in London.

title: Ryan Says U.S. to Test Paint for Lead Content
description: WASHINGTON Aug. 25 (UPI)The Federal Govern ment will soon begin analyz ing about 8,000 brands of paint and publicly disclose which can cause lead poison ing, Representative William F. Ryan, Democrat of Manhat tan, said today.

title: Constitutionality of Hatch Act Challenged by Federal Employe
description: An employe of the Veterans Administration is challenging the constitutionality of a law that prohibits Federal employes from running for elective office or working in election cam paigns.

title: 10Day Sales Down For Auto Industry
description: The Ford Motor Company turned in a strong selling per formance in the midAugust period, but it was not quite enough to prevent total sales for the entire industry to dip slightly below the 1970 level.

title: ATTACK REPORTED ON FILIPINO BASE
description: MANILA, Thursday, Aug. 26 (UPI)A Government spokes man said that Communist guer rillas attacked a regional mili tary headquarters early today and destroyed two Phillippine Air Force helicopters.

title: Seat War on Airlines Is Now Musical Chairs
description: Last fall, United Air Lines installed wider seats in its jets, touching off a seat war in which major airlines tried to outdo one another by providing more hip and leg room.

title: Peru Warns Paris on ATests
description: LIMA, Peru, Aug. 25 (Reuters) Peru will automatically break diplomatic relations with Paris if France explodes another nuclear bomb in the South Pacific in her current series of tests, President Juan Velasco Alvarado announced today. He said that a scientist's report stated that radioactivity from the explosions had caused high contamination of the atmos phere and could cause genetic damage.

title: Storm Hits Southern Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 25 (AP) Hurricane Chloe, weakened to a storm, hit Chetumal on the southeast coast of Mexico dur ing the night with 25milean hour winds and heavy rains, weather authorities reported today.

title: Top Black Official In Pentagon Quits Civil Rights Post
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The Pentagon's civil rights chief is resigning following re ports that Defense Department officials have been unhappy with his performance in office.

title: ECONOMIST URGES CURRENCY REFORM
description: Edward M. Bernstein, a Washington economic consult ant with close ties to the United States Treasury, called yester day for a basic reform in the structure of international fi nancial reserves.

title: Auto Theft Indictments
description: BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) A Federal grand jury has indicted three men from Norton on charges of conspiracy to receive and dispose of cars stolen in New York City. Joseph Brown, Juan Guzman Lopez, and Joe Guzman were named in the indictment. An drew Richardson, identified as a parttime minister in Spring field, was indicted on charges of receiving stolen cars brought from New Jersey.

title: Supreme Court Acts
description: MANILA, Aug. 25 (AP)The Supreme Court told the De fense Department today to show cause why the right of habeas corpus should continue suspended in the Philippines.

title: Loan Postponed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 The signing of a $42million loan to the Bolivian Govern ment from the World Bank and the InterAmerican Devel opment Bank, scheduled to take place here this week, has been postponed, State Depart ment sources said today.

title: NICKLAUS, PLAYER LOSE IN OPENERS OF $200,000 GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 25 Before golf's newest tourna ment was a day old, Jack Nick laus and Gary Player, two of the game's leading experts, were on their way home. Both were surprising victims in first round upsets as the $200,000 national matchplay champion ship began today.

title: OBSERVER
description: I was led into a room so secret that even the dust had to have security clearance. It was the hushhush Bush League Machiavelli Room at the Min istry of Absurdity. The shadowy Pro fessor Bosko, a figure so mysterious that even the President is forbidden to whisper his name, was slowly masticating a top secret cornedbeef on rye.

title: Mets Victors, 51;
description: Jerry Koosman won his first game in two months yesterday when he pitched the New York Mets to a 51 decision over the San Francisco Giants and abdi cated as the medical freak of the baseball season.

title: La Mama Opens Tour to Wide Acclaim at Dubrovnik Festival
description: DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia Shorn of the official State De partment backing it had sought the company of the Cafe La Mama in New York opened an abbreviated European tour at the Dubrovnik Festival the oth er night with the first of two scheduled performances.

title: ExTroopers Get Suspended Terms In Perjury Case
description: NORWICH, Conn., Aug. 25 Three former state troopers who were involved in a stake out shooting in which two un armed burglary suspects were killed were given suspended sentences today in Superior Court on perjury charges.

title: PRICES INCREASED ON VOLKSWAGENS
description: The prices of the two leading foreign cars sold in the United States, Volkswagen and Toyota, were raised as expected yester day in reaction to President Nixon's new economic policy increasing the import duty on automobiles to 10 per cent.

title: BLACK AND WHITE BACKED WALLER
description: JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 25 William L. Waller, who calls himself a redneck, won the Democratic gubernatorial nomi nation and almost certainly the Governor's office in yesterday's runoff primary with an un usual combination of black and white votes.

title: Federal Contract Is Signed For New Energy System
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25  The Department of the Interior announced today that its Of fice of Coal Research had signed a twoyear contract with the Avco Corporation for the de velopment of a system to gen erate electrical energy from coal through a process called magnetohydrodynamics, or MHD.

title: ADOPTION CASE PLEA REFERRED TO FULD
description: Judge Charles D. Breitel of the State Court of Appeals yes terday referred to the chief of the court a request by Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Polk to keep their 3yearold foster child Angela pending an appeal of a court directing them to return the child to an adoption agency.

title: Bridge:Book of Play All in Rhyme Recalls Best of Earlier Time
description: Nearly all the bridge litera ture of the thirties and for ties has been superseded in the last two decades. Bidding ideas have developed greatly, and even in the areas of play and defense there have been advances. But there is one obscure corner or bridge lit erature in which it is neces sary to go back to the thirties to find the best: poetry.

title: Revaluation of Yen Urged
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Japan Chamber of Commerce and In dustry asked the Governmeent and the Bank of Japan today to revalue the yen as soon as possible through multilateral consultations.

title: Dolphins Return Grant, Defensive End, to Giants
description: MIAMI, Aug. 25The Mi ami Dolphins said today they had returned Wes Grant, a defensive end, to the New York Giants.

title: Moscow and Peking Both Plan Official Visits to Paris in Fall
description: PARIS, Aug. 25  Chinese Communist and Soviet leaders will visit Paris this fall within a few weeks of each other, Foreign Ministry sources dis closed today.

title: A New Egalitarian Life Style
description: The first problem for all of us, men and women, is not to learn, but to unlearn. We are filled with the popu lar wisdom of several centuries just past, and we are terrified to give it up. Patriotism means obedience, age means wisdom, woman means submission, black means inferior: these are pre conceptions imbedded so deeply in our thinking that we honestly may not know that they are there.

title: In Museum's Flow of Events: Theater
description: The Guggenheim Museum's announcement that it will be renting out its auditorium (or, as the announcement puts it, opening its doors) to a fullfledged theatrical troupe for a normal run complete with previewshas inspired in many quarters the question Are the museums about to join Off Broadway? Members of the troupe and a representative of the mu seum give answers best sum marized as Well, no, not exactly, and Well, yes, in a way.

title: Amid Pomp and Nostalgia, Indonesia Awaits Juliana
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 25They are not called natives anymore. That was a word the colonialists used. They are Indonesians now, and fiercely proud of their 26 years as a free nation.

title: U.S. REPORTS DROP IN WELFARE ROLLS
description: WASHINGTON. Aug. 25  Despite an increase of more than $16million in public as sistance payments throughout the country last May, relief rolls dropped 37,000 from the prior month, according to the latest available Government statistics. It was the first drop in more than three years.

title: Argentina Chief Plans Visit
description: BUENOS AIRES (UPI)Ar gentina's President, Gen. Ale jandro Agustfn Lanusse ac cepted today an invitation to visit Ecuador. The President also plans visits to Chile, Peru, Paraguay and Brazil.

title: HADASSAH APPROVES GOAL OF $13MILLION
description: CLEVELAND. Aug. 25Ha dassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, adopted today a recordbreak ing goal of $13,267,355 for 197172 to maintain its vast network of medical and social service institutions in Israel and for programs in this coun try.

title: 60 EAST PAKISTANIS KILLED IN FLOODING
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Aug. 25 Sixty persons have died in widespread flooding in East Pakistan, the Government an nounced today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Every serious American fly fisherman should, from time to time, peruse a few issues of the monthly British maga zine, Trout and Salmon, if only to savor the seriousness with which anglers of the British Isles regard the sport.

title: Puritan Sportswear Holds Prices at Least to Yearend
description: The Puritan Sportswear Cor poration, men's sportswear di vision of Warnaco, Inc., said yesterday that it would volun tarily freeze prices on all its merchandise until at least the end of the year.

title: A MINNESOTA TEST ON WAR DISMISSED
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 25A stateauhtorized challenge to the constitutionality of the Vietnam war was dismissed to day by United States District Court Judge Earl R. Larson.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange omitted its usual weekly report.

title: Musicians From 60 Countries Staff 4Day World Orchestra
description: An orchestra composed of instrumentalists from 60 na tions will be assembled here in October under the aus pices of the Federation of PeopletoPeople Programs, and will play three concerts in four days under the di rection of Arthur Fiedler be fore disbanding.

title: 3 Sons of Policemen Arrested In Killing of 13 Animals at Zoo
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 25 Three sons of policemen were arrested today and charged with Monday's mutilation and killing of 13 animals at the Harrison Children's Zoo.

title: Computers Back at Work, So OTB's Handle Rises
description: Offtrack betting's com puters Went back to work yesterday, recovering from a breakdown that had kept them out of action for four straight racing days.

title: NOROTON Y.C. WINS MATCHRAGE TITLE
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 25Noro ton, Conn., Yacht Club de throned American Y. C. as the Long Island Sound Yacht Rac ing Association interclub match race champion today, winning the sixth annual William H. Taylor trophy regatta, 3 races to 1, by capturing two races from American Y. C.

title: GELSEY KIRKLAND PROVES DANCE SKILL
description: Gelsey Kirkland, one of the New York City Ballet's young est soloists, stepped into a true ballerina role Tuesday night at the State Theater when she ap peared in New York for the first time in the second move ment of George Balanchine's Bizet ballet, Symphony in C.

title: Knapp Panel Said to Have Proof of Graft in Harlem
description: The city commission investi gating allegations of police cor ruption has obtained photo graphic and taperecorded evi dence showing dozens of police men dealing with Harlem heroin dealers and gamblers, accord ing to sources within and out side the commission.

title: Vesco Testimony Ends
description: Robert L. Vesco, 36yearold chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., ended two days of testimony before the Securi ties and Exchange Commission yesterday.

title: Medicine Ball Caravan' Bows:Free-Wheeling Bus Is Followed Across U.S.
description: "Medicine Ball Caravan," which opened yesterday at the Plaza, is the filmed account of a free-spirited bus trip made last summer by 150-odd beautiful people, counter-culturists, musicians, Hog Farmers, hangers-on and hip entrepreneurs. Also along, not exactly for the ride, were assorted journalists, Franois Reichenbach, a French director, with (according to the Warner Brothers publicity sheet) a "crack 15-man film crew," and two studio accountants. For this last information I am indebted not to Warner Brothers but to Ron Rosenbaum, a Village Voice reporter, whose eyewitness articles on the caravan make an essential accompaniment to the movie.Led, more or less, by an immense, bearded, deep-voiced, aging disk jockey named Tom Donahue, the caravan set out from San Francisco in silver-painted buses carrying tie-dyed tepees, headed for points east (and eventually, the Isle of Wight) with the intention of giving concerts, confronting middle America, and incidentally making a movie. The movie begins in San Francisco, as, on the sound track, a choir of heavenly voices sings over the head of Tom Donahue in his broadcasting studio. But it ends, a little abruptly, at Antioch College in Ohio, where there was a confrontation, but not the one that had been expected.The ostensible reason for the caravan was, of course, to present concerts. What you see of the concerts seems to have little enough to do with the caravan. For the most part they feature imported big-name talent, B. B. King, Doug Kershaw, etc., and they are treated by Reichenbach as isolated, self-contained events. On the other hand, there are the caravan's "events": bathing in a giant bowl of Jello prepared by Wavey Gravey and the Hog Farm, pacifying the violent STP Family in Boulder, answering the activists at Antioch.The caravan's real problems came not from middle America, which, according to the evidence on the screen, seemed downright chummy, but from the youthful political left, which, despite a certain amount of camouflage, saw Warner Brothers and smelled a rat. Along the way an activist named David Peel attached himself to the caravan with the purpose of exposing it, and at Antioch there occurred a series of misadventures leading to spur-of-the-moment guerrilla theater, a nontheatrical knife attack on Peel and much violent argument over the not so profitable question of who was bought and who had sold; between the movie company and the counter culture, who was ripping off whom.In a case like this I would normally side against the movie company. The staged documentary is not on the whole an interesting form. But the concluding confrontations very nearly changed my mind, and after 30 seconds of listening to the ravings of an Antioch activist I was almost ready to love Warner Brothers.Movies like "Medicine Ball Caravan" tend to run to cinematic effect; and for Reichenbach this means heavy reliance on telephoto lens, split screen and a kind of Rorschach-blot doubling of images during the concertsso that B. B. King's profile duplicates itself and the materialized vibrations of the Cajun Fiddler's fiddle run out of the frame like railroad tracks. None of this is dreadful, but much of it has been seen before, and, like the film's many impromptu interviews with its own people, adds up to no experience.

title: Saigon Offensive Reported
description: SAIGON, Thursday, Aug. 26 (AP)South Vietnamese forces were reported to have gone on the offensive yseterday south of Danang in an attempt to head off an enemy attack on district towns.

title: CONCERN REBUKED ON BLIND IN NAME
description: A cosmetics company that uses blind workers to package its products was ordered by a State Supreme Court justice to stop using the corporate name Toiletries Packed by the Blind, Inc.

title: Advertising:
description: Today's the day that a group of advertising agencies will be visited by a few earnest, angry and deter mined women who belong to the National Organization For Women.

title: Editor Critical of Military Reported Arrested in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The political police have arrested Hlio Fernandes, editorpublisher of the right wing paper Tribuna da Impren sa, and suspended publication of the newspaper for 48 hours, a spokesman for Tribuna said today.

title: RIVERSIDE Y.C. WINS JUNIOR SAILING RACE
description: MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 25  Riverside, Conn., Yacht Club won the Everett B. Mor ris Memorial Trophy today when Douglas Wolfe, with Turner Hansel as navigator, sailed Destination to victory in the Beach Point Yacht Club's 15th annual overnight race for the junior distance champion by 7.37 on corrected time.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN PORK BELLIES
description: Pork belly futures advanced 27 cents to 45 cents a 100 pounds yesterday on the Chica go Mercantile Exchange in fair ly active trading. The Febru ary, 1972, contract, the most, actively traded, closed at $17.65 per 100 pounds up 33 cents.

title: High British Police Urge Tougher Jails
description: LONDON, Aug. 25Two Brit ish police officials, condemning dogooders and urging harsh treatment for violent criminals, have set off a political storm in volving Parliament, the Govern ment and civil liberties groups.

title: Student Group Rejects Blacks' Demand for Payments
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 25Delegates to the 24th con gress of the National Student Association have rejected de mands by blacks for continued reparations and have instead turned their attention to mobil izing the 18yearold vote.

title: Western Air Modifies Jets
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 (UPI) Western Air Lines said today it expects to become next month the first interstate air line to finish modifying its 727 jets to be virtually smokefree.

title: I.R.A. Denies Responsibility
