description: BELFAST, Aug. 25The offi cial wing of the Irish Republi can Army in Belfast tonight denied responsibility for the explosion at the offices of the Electricity Board of Northern Ireland.

title: Dollar in Further Decline;
description: LONDON, Aug. 25The dol lar slumped further against all leading European currencies to day as foreign exchange trad ing quickened. The markets were orderly but tense.

title: White House Confident
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25The Western White House expressed confidence today that the United States' trading part ners would not retaliate to counter the 10 per cent sur charge on imports.

title: Truer Hues for White House
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (UPI)Mrs. Patricia Nixon will begin refurbish ing the state rooms of the White House this fall, par ticularly in the Blue Room, where small receptions are held, and the Red Room, most dramatic of all the Formal salons in the execu tive mansion.

title: Saigon Plot Trial Is Put Off As Students Fail to Attend
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 (Reuters)A sched uled trial of 21 militant South Vietnamese students charged with proCommunist activities was indefinitely postponed to day because none of the 16 defendants free on bail ap peared in court.

title: LABOR DISPUTE CUTS NEWS'S DISTRIBUTION
description: About 400,000 copies of yes terday's late editions of The Daily News were not distri buted as a result of a labor dis pute between the paper and its driver members of the News paper and Mail Deliverers Union.

title: Bolivia Will Permit Dissidents to Leave
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 25 (Reuters)The new rightwing Government of Bolivia will give safeconduct passes out of the country to some 50 refugees who sought asylum in embas sies here after last week's coup against Juan Jos Torres Gon zales, the leftwing President.

title: 12 Flee to West Germany
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 25 (AP)Eight Czechoslo vaks and four East Germans fled to West Germany in the last two days, the Bavarian State Interior Ministry reported today.

title: Taiwan Book Pirates Seem Outflanked
description: The Government of National ist China, which normally tolerates book piracy as a dol larearning industry, has issued an order to confiscate all copies of an unauthorized facsimile edition of Irving Wallace's Nympho and Other Maniacs.

title: Nevada Gaming Panel Requests Hughes Fingerprints on Letter
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 26The Nevada Gaming Com. mission voted today that until Howard Hughes furnished It with a letter bearing his finger prints and naming the person responsible for his gambling licenses here, it would not ap prove new applications or shifts in names of persons on his licenses.

title: LOAN RATES CUT BY CHEMICAL BANK
description: The Chemical Bank, the fifth largest bank in New York City and the sixth largest in the nation, announced yes terday an immediate, across theboard reduction in its in terest charges on consumer loans and home mortgages.

title: Wallace Asserts He Holds U.S. Courts in Contempt
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 26Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that he held the entire Federal judici ary in utter contempt.

title: Big Board Halts Trading In 3 Federal Pacific Issues
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to suspend trading in three issues of the Federal Pa cific Electric Company because an inadequate number of shares were publicly held.

title: Boston's Biggest Bank Shifts Officers
description: The First National Bank of Boston, the largest bank in New England and one of the top 20 banks in the nation, announced yesterday a new management team to lead the institution and its parent holding com pany, the First National Boston Corporation, through the mid dle of the next decade.

title: Sustained Growth Seen In Economy in Rest of '71
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)The Commerce Depart ment predicted today a sustained period of growth for the remainder of 1971 and into 1972 for the national economy, but said the aircraft industry is in a tailspin that will prob ably deepen next year and possibly will not be reversed before 1975.

title: Thousands Attend Little Rock Rally for Wilbur Mills, Presidential Noncandidate
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 26  Thousands of Arkansans turned out tonight for a rally that was designed in large part to urge the rest of the nation to consider Arkansas' most renowned Congressman, Wilbur D. Mills, for President.

title: 6,000 March on Fifth Avenue to Protest Sex Bias
description: For the second year in a row, thousands of women marched on Fifth Avenue yesterday to celebrate the anniversary of women's suffrage and to press their demands for equality with men in every aspect of Ameri can life.

title: Wage and Price Questions and Answers
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Following is the seventh set of official questions and an swers issued by the Presi dent's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90 day freeze on wages and prices:

title: 4 Witnesses Called Before Grand Jury in Camden About DraftOffice Raid
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Aug. 26 After testifying before a Fed eral grand jury today, Robert W. Hardy tacitly confirmed the widespread suspicion that he was the informer who helped the Federal Bureau of Investi gation arrest 20 persons here last weekend for allegedly try ing to steal draft records.

title: Four Arrested in Brooklyn 20 Minutes After Holdup
description: Four men brandishing guns and knives were arrested in Brooklyn last night 20 minutes after they allegedly held up a grocery store in the Brownsville section and escaped with $300 in a green automobile.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: WIDE HUNT BEGUN IN POLICE KILLING
description: Once more this year the Police Department lowered the flags to half staff at all station houses in the city yesterday and began yet another man hunt for the killer of a police man.

title: Barbara Cook to Star In Musical Grass Harp
description: Barbara Cook will return to the Broadway stage after a long absence to star in The Grass Harp, a musical based on Truman Capote's novel. The production, to open Nov. 2 at the Martin Beck Theater, will be pre sented by Richard Barr and Charles Woodward of The ater 1972, collaborating with Michael Harvey.

title: Mr. Wilson's Sharp Dilemma
description: Assistant Attorney General Will R. Wilson Jr. was for at least two years a close associate and chief coun sel to Frank W. Sharp, a man whose financial manipula tions give those of his fellowTexan, Billie Sol Estes, an air of amateur innocence. Mr. Wilson, who repeatedly borrowed large sums of money from Mr. Sharp, besides giving him detailed advice, can only compromise the Nixon Administration if he remains as head of the Jus tice Department's Criminal Division.

title: Old Glitter Returns as 32d Venice Film Fete Bows
description: VENICE, Aug. 26The 32d Venice Festival opened last night under the direction of GianLuigi Rondi, the film crit ic of II Tempo, the Roman daily, who has promised to bring the annual event back into the international spotlight.

title: Mrs. Edwards Wed to Professor
description: Mrs. Dorothea Bingham Edwards of New York and Paul Whiton Cherington of Boston were married here yesterday at the Carlyle Ho tel by State Supreme Court Justice Theodore Kupferman.

title: TOP BID PLACES 2D IN GRANDNATIONAL
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26  Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Shadow Brook won the the $40,400 Grand National Steeplechase today by a dozen lengths over Mrs. Ogden Phipps's Top Bid. The 21/2 mile event, run for the 71st time, but for the first time in its history at the local course, at tracted seven contestants and six of them finished.

title: Philharmonic Plans Workshop, Its First, to Train Minorites
description: The New York Philharmonic plans an unprecedented one week Orchestra Repertory In stitute for black and other mi nority musicians beginning Sept. 7, under the direction of Richard Lert.

title: EXCOMMISSIONER IS INDICTED HERE
description: Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation in Mayor Robert F. Wagner's administration, was indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges that he failed to file Federal income tax returns on time for 1965 and 1966.

title: Bride: Jacoby Transfer Bid Wins Favor Among Young Stars
description: A convention that has gained considerable popu larity in recent years with experts, especially the young er ones, is the Jacoby trans fer bid.

title: Glaciers Are Profitable
description: OSLO, Norway (Reuters)  Unpolluted mountain water and ice cubes from 10,000yearold glaciers are earning foreign currency for Norway. One com pany supplies some Dutch ho tels with ice cubes from gla ciers and others are exporting bottled mountain water.

title: Lefkowitz Appoints Aide
description: Harvey E. Soicher, 36 years old, of Merrick, L. I., was ap pointed an assistant New York State attorney general yester day by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz. Mr. Soicher, a graduate of New York Univer sity Law School, is a former deputy Nassau County attorney.

title: I.R.S. HOT LINES KEPT BUSY HERE
description: The hot lines to the Inter nal Revenue Service handling queries and quibbles about President Nixon's wage  price freeze have been busy this week (11,400 incoming calls), but hardly sizzling (41 com plaints of violations).

title: City Voter Registration To Close Next Monday
description: Those who wish to vote in the Nov. 2 general election must register by next Mon day or during the special local registration period on Sept. 30, Oct. 1 and 2.

title: Durham and Nunez Reach Eastern Junior Net Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. William Durham of Australia, seeded first, and Frank Nunez ?? Rockaway, N. J., seeded ??ixth, reached the final of the Eastern junior tennis cham pionships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. Durham defeated Jeff Potter of Scarsdale, 62, 64. Nunez eli minated fourth seeded Gary Reiner of New Hyde Park, L. I., 64, 60.

title: Policy Allowing Some Teachers To Get Rises in Pay Is Clarified
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26The President's Cost of Living Coun cil issued a supplementary statement this evening to try to clear up confusion over the effect of the wage freeze on teachers and others employed in education.

title: A Devaluation of Dollar May Cause U.N. Deficit
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 26Devaluation of the dollar may give the United Nations a $4million to $5 million budget deficit, the or ganization's controller, Bruce Turner, estimated today.

title: Miss Alexandra Ramsay Married
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 26Miss Alexandra Morris Ramsay was married here to day to Raymond Anthony Di Luglio in a civil cere mony at City Hall. Nicholas Colasanto, former city man ager and vice mayor of Alex andria, officiated.

title: Thrown for a Giant Loss
description: The freeze obviously doesn't affect the New York Giants. The decision by the professional football team's ownership, reached after a huddle of accountants, is to flee New York City for the promised greener pas tures of New Jersey's projected sports complex at East Rutherford. The decision bespeaks an attention to bal ance sheets and profit statements that runs counter, to the assertion that professional football, for all its com mercialism, is really, deepdown, a sport.

title: Advertising:
description: For manufacturers of con sumer goods anxious to know when enough of their products are in the stores to begin a spottelevision campaign, LebharFriedman, Inc., has a new service de signed to come up with quick answers.

title: Police Raid 6 Smut Shops
description: The police continued their drive against pornography yes terday raiding six bookstores in the Times Square area and arresting the operators. Detec tives made arrests at 107, 150, 136 and 210 West 42d Street. Two other places were at 101 West 55th Street and 733 Eighth Avenue. The operators were charged with promoting obscenity, a misdemeandor.

title: MUNICIPAL BONDS INCREASE YIELDS
description: The market for taxexempt bonds, which had lagged badly this week, raised yields yester day to levels that could entice investors. A $100million Ohio offering proved a quick sell out.

title: Dominick Signs Contract With Perot Data Company
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas multimillionaire who took con trol of F. I. duPont, Glore For gan & Co. last December, has established a business relation ship with another Wall Street house, Dominick & Dominick, Inc.

title: SENATE UNIT SETS SECURITIES STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey and chairman of a banking subcommittee, said today the panel would hold the first of its longplanned hearings on securities industry problems in late September.

title: Merger News
description: The Flying Tiger Corporation announced yesterday that its subsidiary, the North American Car Corporation, has agreed in principle to acquire National Equipment Rental, Ltd., for $21million, consisting $10 million lion in cash and the balance in notes. As part of the trans action, North American agreed to acquire Can berra Management Corporation for $2 million. Canberra is owned by the executives of Na tional Equipment and its sole business is management of Na tional Equipment Rental, which is a subsidiary of American Ex port Industries, Inc.

title: TRIO SHARES LEAD IN CONCORD GOLF
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 26Dick Mayer, the 1957 United States Open champion from La Jolla, Calif., who has been a sometime player in re cent years, fired a 2underpar 70 today to share the first round lead in the $60,000 Lig gett & MyersConcord open golf tournament.

title: SHANGHAI
description: SHANGHAI, Aug. 26By all out ward signs, China has a stable Gov ernment, based on the moral authority of Chairman Mao Tsetung, the power of the People's Liberation Army and the experience and administrative skill of Premier Chou Enlai.

title: Senators Triumph, 83
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP)Larry Biitner, sparked a fiverun rally with a tiebreak ing single in the ninth inning tonight that carried the Wash ington Senators to an 83 vic tory over the California Angels. Two other rims in the inning crossed on basesloaded walks.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Policemen Slain in 1971
description: The detective: sergeant found slain in his car yester day, Joseph V. Morabito, is believed by the Police Depart ment to be the 10th policeman criminally killed here this year in the line of duty.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the National Football League was struggling for survival during its formative years half a century ago, Joe Carr, the first president, knew his infant organization could not begin to gain big league recognition until it had a New York outlet. In 1925 he could delay no longer.

title: U.S. Agent's Drug Charges Anger the French Police
description: PARIS, Aug. 26An Ameri can narcotics agent has charged that major heroin traffickers operate in the Marseilles area with a sense of security. The charge has touched off an angry protest by the French police.

title: U.S. Trend in Stadiums Is Away From the Cities
description: The trend in stadiums, as in corporate headquarters, is to locate in the suburbs.

title: MICHAEL DAVIS, A HEALTH EXPERT
description: Dr. Michael M. Davis, a medical economist who pio neered in efforts to establish health insurance and group medical practice, died Aug. 19 in Sherbrooke, Quebec. He was 91 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md., and George ville, Quebec.

title: 7 Women Share the Top Prize Of $1Million in State Lottery
description: A ticket held by seven women who work for the State Employes Retirement System in Albany yesterday won the state milliondollar lottery's top prize$50,000 a year for 20 years.

title: FOREIGN TIE VOTED FOR WILLIAM WITTER
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that its governing board had voted approval of an arrange ment by which a Belgian con cern would buy up to a 25 per cent interest in William D. Witter, Inc., a small member, firm of the exchange.

title: Drat! to Open at McAlpin
description: Richard Barr and Charles Woodward of Theater 1972 will open Drat! on Oct. 18 at the McAlpin Rooftop Theater. Pre views of the musical burlesque will be held beginning Oct. 12. Fred Bluth, the director, wrote the book and lyrics; the music is by Steven Metcalf. Bonnie Franklin of the cast of Ap plause will have a leading role.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Aug. 27, 1971 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Keating Responds Bluntly To Indian Criticism of U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 26Am bassador Kenneth B. Keating, apparently angered over what he considers Indian press dis tortions of American policy in the East Pakistan crisis, has begun to speak out bluntly in an attempt to stem the anti American tide here.

title: Ecumenical Movement in Ireland Finds History a Stubborn Foe
description: Some leaders of the major Protestant and Roman Catholic churches in Ireland have begun looking for ways to reverse centuries of antagonism be tween their faiths and to make religion into a healing force in their troubled land.

title: Cabinet Changes by Greek Premier Undercut Allies in 67 Coup
description: ATHENS, Aug. 26 (AP) Premier George Papadopoulos named a new Cabinet today. bringing in fresh faces and undercutting most of his closest collaborators in the coup d'tat four and a half years ago.

title: Zulu Chief's Call For Talks Rejected By South Africans
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, Aug. 26  The leader of South Africa's Zulus has called for a national multiracial con ference, but the Government rejected his proposal today as totally unnecessary.

title: After the Freeze
description: A good deal of the bellicosity seems to have gone out of the verbal warfare between organized labor and the Administration over President Nixon's wageprice freeze.

title: Books of The Times
description: UPSTATE. Records and Recollections of North ern New York. By Edmund Wilson. 386 pages. Illustrated. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $8.95.

title: Dodgers' Title Bid Put To Seaver Test Tonight
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers' desperate drive to overhaul the San Francisco Giants in the National League Western Di vision has been like shinnying up a greased flag pole. The Dodgers have trailed the Giants by as many as 11 games and as few as 3

title: CRIME IN LONDON SHOWS INCREASE
description: LONDON, Aug. 26  Scot land Yard, involved in a con troversy over soft treatment of violent criminals, announced today that serious crimes in London increased 6 per cent in the first half of 1971.

title: OTB IS REASSURED ON ITS COMPUTERS
description: Offtrack betting's schizo phrenic computers are on the threshold of stability, the president of Computer Sciences Corporation insisted yesterday.

title: Mayor Swears In City's First Woman Police Captain
description: The first woman captain in the city's Police Depart ment was sworn in by Mayor Lindsay yesterday. After the brief ceremony, in which Mrs. Gertrude Schimmel, 52 years old, glowed with pride behind her captain's badge, the Mayor and Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said the promotion recognized the fine work she has done for more than 30 years in the Police Department. The pro motion came on a day when women demonstrators marked the 51st anniversary of women's suffrage. Eleven women, led by Mrs. Betty Friedan, met in Mayor Lin dsay's office and won a prom ise of more female appoint ments and more attention to the status of women. Six dis rupted trading at the Ameri can Stock Exchange. Others paraded on Fifth Avenue as their mothers and grandmoth ers had done to win the vote. Mayor Lindsay said that, we have chosen this day to an nounce Captain Schimmel's promotion as a sign of our renewed commitment to equal ity for women in city govern ment and in every area of hu man life. But the fact was that it took lawsuits all along the way for the woman who made Phi Betta Kappa when she earned her A.B. in English at Htinter College to get the right to take the Civil Service tests. Congratulated by a group of women's liberation movement leaders in the foyer of the Mayor's office, Captain Schim mel said she did not belong to any women's liberation group, but, she added, I'm a sympa thizer.

title: Miss Lifschitz Bride Of Stuart M. Garay
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Aug. 26Miss Deborah Lifschitz and Stuart M. Garay were married this evening in the Great Neck Synagogue by Rabbis Jacob Denishefsky and Myron Fenster.

title: Bank of Japan Again Buying Dollars
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26  The Bank of Japan had to buy dol lars on the Tokyo exchange today  a total of $600mi1 lion  after a couple of days in which the flow was re versed.

title: Broadway's 7:30 Curtain: Longer Run
description: The 7:30 curtain Broad way's switch to Patron Sav ing Timehas won enough favor to be carried into its first full season this fall.

title: City Reports Welfare Frauds by 20,000
description: More than 20,000 welfare recipients in the last year have fraudulently obtained $1.5mil lion in duplicate relief checks, after swearing the originals were lost or stolen, Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman reported yester day.

title: New Violence at Coast Fair Follows Plan to Close Early
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI)Violence erupted to night for the third consecutive evening at the California State Fair.

title: Stage: Play for Families
description: Vinnette Carroll's Urban Arts Corps serves several theatrical purposes. It is a showcase for new, young (mostly black) talent, and it brings theater to the people performing shows in vari ous sections of New York City.

title: WOMEN OBSERVE THEIR FRANCHISE
description: Women's groups around the country yesterday observed the 51st anniversary of their right to vote by warning that they would use it against any Congress person who op posed or tried to weaken the proposed equal rights amend ment.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ashland Oil Inc., announced yesterday that George C. Hardin Jr. has been named president of Ashland Exploration, a newly formed division. The company said that the new division will consolidate the admin istration of Ashland's domestic and international oil and gas operations and will accelerate its expanding and production program. Mr. Hardin has been an executive vice president of the oil and gas division of the Ada Oil Company.

title: Cinemobiles Cutting Costs on Location Filming
description: HOLLYWOOD  For the last two years, huge stream lined buses  mobile film studioshave been altering location film production in the United States.

title: Plaza Plans Original Elegance in World of Tomorrow
description: The Plaza Hotel, that 18 story French Renaissance pile facing the Grand Army Plaza on Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, is to be re stored to its original ele gance and at the same time project the popular hostelry into the world of today and tomorrow.

title: Woman in the News
description: The monarchy in this country will stay as long as majority of the people want it, said Queen Juliana of the Netherlands in 1965.

title: Pravda Tries to Explain
description: The Soviet Union does, not have public foreign policy debates even remotely analogous to those this country is accustomed to having over Vietnam and other major issues. But the absence of such open controversy does not keep millions of intelligent Soviet citizens from thinking, about world events and asking questions.

title: Avon Recalls Baby Powder Found to Contain Bacteria
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Avon Products, Inc., said to day that it had begun a national recall of 14,800 cans of Avon Baby Powder because the Food and Drug Administration had found bacteria in it.

title: Carty, Eye Damaged, Charges 3 Policemen Blackjacked Him
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 26 (UPI) Rico Carty, the Atlanta Braves outfielder, said today he might have suffered permanent eye damage as the result of an altercation with three white Atlanta policemen.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Fishing Report

title: 74TH ST. TENANTS SETTLE DISPUTE
description: Tenants who alleged that their East Side luxury apartment building was rife with vice, lacked proper security and was in poor repair reached agree ment in court with the build ing's management yesterday.

title: Overnight Mail Service Planned in Some Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Postmaster General Winton M. Blount announced today plans for delivery of first class mail overnight within specified areas.

title: Burmese Trading Rubies for Toothpaste and Radios
description: MANDALAY, Burma, Aug. 12Burma, whose dazzling golden pagodas and wealth of precious gems remain untar nished by nine harsh years of military Socialism, is hawking some of her spare treasure in exchange for toothpaste, bras sseres and transistor radios.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials fell to 108.1 from 108.5 last week.

title: Where Seafood Is Superb But Costly
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their at mosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Reston Says China Won't Back Down On Major Issues
description: James Reston, vice president and columnist of The New York Times, ended his sixweek stay in Communist China yes terday and said he did not ex pect the Chinese to make con cessions on major issues when President Nixon visits Peking.

title: Anita Rio, 98, Soprano In Opera and Concerts
description: OLD SAYROOK, Conn., Aug. 26Anita Rio, a former op eratic and concert soprano, died here Tuesday at the age of 98.

title: Indians Top Brewers, 106
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 26 (UPI) Ray Fosse and Ted Uhlaender drove in three runs each and Roy Foster belted his fourth homer in five games tonight to power the Cleveland Indians to a 106 victory over the Mil waukee Brewers.

title: A Weekend Recipe
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Wounded Bridegroom Called Not Related to Senator Scott
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) A 27yearold man who was married hours after part of his right leg was amputated follow ing a shooting is not related to Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, the Senator's office said yesterday. It was reported Saturday that Wil liam P. Scott 3d of White Sul phur Springs, N. Y., was a nephew of the Senator.

title: Answers on Import Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Following is the first set of official questions and an swers issued by the Depart ment of the Treasury on the temporary 10 per cent import tax:

title: Computer Misuse in Poor Lands Is Seen
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Aug. 26Developing countries must have computers but still lack the training necessary to use them properly or the sophisti cation to resist aggressive sales men peddling expensive ma chinery, a panel of computer sci entists agreed here this week.

title: STATE CRIME UNIT SEIZES 50 IN RAIDS OVER 10 COUNTIES
description: The new State Task Force Against Organized Crime made its first widespread strike yes terday, directing the arrest of about 50 alleged gambling operators in 10 counties from the metropolitan area to Albany.

title: Rain Helps Orioles Win
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 26 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles dissipated a 60 lead, then rallied to beat the Chicago White Sox, 87, in a rain  shortened eight  inning game tonight.

title: U.S. Has Misgivings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP)  Expressing misgivings about a Texas desegregation plan involving extensive busing, of white, MexicanAmerican and black pupils, the Nixon Admiinstration sought a court order today requiring further study before the plan is im plemented.

title: Gas Law Signed in Caracas
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 26 (UPI)President Rafael Cal dera today signed a law creat ing a state monopoly for in dustrialization and export of Venezuela's vast natural gas reserves to United States mar kets. The law was passed ear her this month in Congress, which wrote major modifica tions into the legislation despite strong Government opposition.

title: Woman Candidate in South Vietnam Seeks Votes in a Rice Paddy
description: BINHTHANH, South Viet nam, Aug. 26  A well groomed, 52yearold busi nesswoman named Mrs. Ngu yen Thi Hai kicked off her sandals this morning, rolled the wide black trousers under her Vietnamese tunic dress, put a conical hat on her head and waded through a rice paddy  just to get some votes.

title: Rule on Jobs for Women
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Labor Department an nounced today proposed new regulations that would require Federal contractors to offer more jobs to women.

title: Bruins Give Bobby Orr 5Year, $1Million Pact
description: BOSTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Bobby Orr, the National Hockey League's premier defenseman the last four seasons, has signed a fiveyear contract with the Boston Bruins, the club announced today.

title: Honeywell Mapping Major Realignment
description: Honeywell, Inc., yesterday announced a major corporate reorganization that splits the company into two divisions.

title: New Fighting Along DMZ
description: SAIGON, Friday, Aug. 27 (AP)The Saigon command re ported new fighting along the demilitarized zone today and said that South Vietnamese troops had killed 15 enemy soldiers with the help of allied air and artillery strikes. Two South Vietnamese soldiers were reported killed and three wounded.

title: Spitz Keeps A.A.U. Title In 200Meter FreeStyle
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Mark Spitz of Sacramento, Calif., won his second 1971 National Amateur Athletic Union swimming championship tonight in defending his 200 meter freestyle title.

title: 6 Canoeists Start a 120Mile Voyage Along the City's Waterways
description: FORT SCHUYLER, the Bronx, Aug. 26Six: men, united by their reverence for nature and love of adven ture, slipped three canoes in to the Hutchinson River at dawn today to begin a five day, 120Mile voyage through the waterways of New York City.

title: Notes on People
description: A West Point graduate and winner of three Silver Stars as a combat commander in Vietnam said the Army had accepted his resignationon grounds he is a conscientious objectorafter having twice rejected it.

title: Woman in the Peace Corps Found Murdered in Liberia
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) Marsha Ann Ragno, 23 years old, a Peace Corps volunteer from Winthrop Harbor, Ill., has been murdered in Liberia, the corps headquarters here an nounced today.

title: Draw for U.S. Open Tennis Pits Newcombe Against Kodes
description: John Newcombe, the Wim bledon champion, will meet Jan Kodes, the French cham pion, in the first round of the United States Open Tennis championships as a result of the draw held yesterday for the $160,000 tournament. The draw was held in the General As sembly building of the United Nations.

title: Medina Counsel Seeks to Bar 2 Depositions on Mylai
description: FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 26The defense counsel for Capt. Ernest L. Medina tried today to exclude the deposi tions of two Vietnamese ser geants who had witnessed the Mylai slayings, declaring that if President Nixon wanted a fair trial for Captain Medina, the White House could force South Vietnam to let the ser geants come here and testify.

title: Armco To Layoff 363 More At Its Plant at Middletown
description: MIDDLETOWN, Ohio, Aug. 26 (UPI)Following layoffs of 400 summer employes last week, the Armco Steel corporation has announced that 363 regu lar employes would be laid off Saturday night.

title: Contaminated Fish Found In Southern New England
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Aug. 26 (AP)A spokesman for the Ralston Purin Company said that up to 15 tons a month of fish food suspected of being contaminated has been dis tributed in New England, most of it in southern New England.

title: 124 Held in Gambling Raids
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Aug. 26 (UPI)  Policemen from five states swept through 100 loca tions in the Providence area today and arrested 124 persons in one of the largest gambling raids ever staged in the East. State and local policemen were supported by state troopers from Connecticut New Hamp shire, Vermont and Massachu setts.

title: Korean Red Cross Aides Meet for a Second Time
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 26Red Cross officials of North and South Korea met here today at talks to arrange com munications and possible re unions between families divid ed by the partitioning of Korea.

title: Pennsylvania Adopts Lottery for '72
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 26 Gov. Milton J. Shapp today signed a bill establishing a statewide lottery and said that he expected tickets for a weekly drawing to go on sale in February.

title: Joachim Schultz Dies at 81; Founded Art Brush Concern
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., Aug. 26Joachim M. Schultz, foun der of the Delta Brush Manu facturing Corporation, a lead ing art brush manufacturer, died at his home here today. He was 81 years old.

title: GIANTS' HOUSTON EAGER TO WIN JOB ASDEFENSIVEBACK
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 26 Rich Houston has more seri ous things to worry about right now than the New York Giants moving to New. Jersey. In fact, that's the least of his worries.

title: Unions' Lawyers Oppose Court Assault on Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26Union lawyers representing affiliates of the A.F.L.C.I.O. generally agreed today to avoid a massive court challenge to President Nixon's 90day wage price freeze. A majority of the 135 union counsels attending the meeting at the federa tion's headquarters here said they believed that the best strategy would be to fight for labor's own legislative eco nomic program in Congress, according to sources who at tended the meeting.

title: Nader Unit Says Land Interests Wield Vast Power in California
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 A Ralph Nader study group charged today that the influ ence of land interests in Cal ifornia was so extensive that the state's form of government must fairly be described as corporate socialism.

title: 084358 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: SEASIDE HEIGHTS, N. J. (AP) This week's winning New Jersey lottery number was 084358.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN SLOW TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished lower yes terday in slower trading.

title: 30% of Giant Fans Live In Jersey, Study Finds
description: Where do Giant fans come from?

title: Brattleboro, a Town That's a Haven for Refugees From City Life
description: BATTLEBORO, Vt.Finding a native of Vermont in these parts is as difficult as finding a native New Yorker in Manhattan. There has been a quiet influx of city folk over the last decade and more arrive each year.

title: Inside San Quentin
description: SAN QUENTIN PRISONChaos de scended on San Quentin Prison July 20 in the wake of the murder of cor rectional officer L. G. Davis. He was killed while guarding an inmate on the second floor of Neumiller Hospi tal, and died at 12:20 P.M.

title: Printers Reject Offer
description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 26 (UPI) Printers rejected as inade quate today the latest Pitts burgh Press Company wage contract offer and continued a strike that has prevented the city's two daily newspapers from publishing for 105 days. By a vote of 371 to 4, members of Local 7 of the International Typographical Union voted to reject the proposal. The union has demanded a $62  a  week wage and fringe benefits in crease in a twoyear contract.

title: Nixon Plans 2 Stops Sept. 3
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP)President Nixon will make public appearances in Ohio and Illinois on his way back to Washington Sept. 3, the Western White House an nounced today. He will fly first to WrightPatterson Air Force Base near Dayton, Ohio, to help dedicate a new Air Force flight museum. Then he will go to Chicago to address a conven tion of the American Milk Pro ducers Association.

title: Pentagon Says It Ousted Black Over Lack of Rights Progress
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Pentagon confirmed today that it had sought and re ceived the resignation of its highestranking black official. Officials indicated that the ac tion had been taken because of highlevel dissatisfaction with his performance in office.

title: English Delay Cricket Tour
description: LONDON, Aug. 26, (Reuters) The governing body of cricket in England, the Marylebone Cricket Club: called off today England's scheduled tour this year of India, Pakistan and Ceylon because of the political disputes in those countries. The tour will be held next year.

title: Labor's Arrogance and the Freeze
description: WASHINGTONThe efficacy of President Nixon's wageprice freeze as a standstill measure against rising in flation and unemployment depends on three developments:

title: Nepal Leader Resigns
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 26 (Reuters)Prime Minister Kirti Nidhi Bista resigned tonight in the wake of criticism of the Nepalese Parliament yesterday by King Mahendra. The king granted a pardon yesterday to Bamraja Prasad Singh, who had been found guilty early this month of antistate activities and sentenced to 2 years in prison shortly after he was elected to Parliament.

title: Crash Kills Bronx Woman
description: NANUET, N. Y., Aug. 26 Mrs. Mae Gale, 59 years old, of 225 Ladorick Avenue, the Bronx, a passenger in a car operated by Daniel McAllister, 47, of 320 East 91st Street, was killed shortly after noon today when the car went out of control on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, and over turned three times near Exit 10 a mile north of here. Mr. McAllister was taken to Nyack Hospital, suffering from mul tiple injuries.

title: Lindsay Assails Giants; Economic Blow Decried
description: Mayor Lindsay led the pained reaction to the New York Giants' planned move to New Jersey by attacking the team's management as selfish, callous and ungrateful and pledging to fight to have both the New York Yankees and a profes sional football team in Yankee Stadium in 1975.

title: Performance of the Dollar Is Mixed in Trading on European Exchange Markets
description: LONDON, Aug. 26The dol lar turned in a mixed perform ance in European trading in foreign exchange today amid the crosscurrents of national financial developments.

title: NEON ATMOSPHERE TESTED BY DIVERS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 24 An experiment simulating deep sea habitation was reported to day by a University of Pennsyl vania scientist to have demon strated for the first time the feasibilityand perhaps de sirabilityof using neon as the primary atmospheric gas in ex ploring the ocean depths.

title: U.S.EXPORTS LAG BEHIND IMPORTS 4TH MONTH IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The United States suffered its fourth consecutive large month ly trade deficit in July, with imports exceeding exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: L. I. Creek Is Declared Sewer Now
description: RONKONKOMA, L. I., Aug. 26Fifteen years ago, trout abounded in Neguntatogue Creek, then a crystalclear, fourfoot deep brook flowing between treelined banks through the Town of Babylon and the Village of Linden hurst, down to the Great South Bay.

title: Demonstration Broken Up
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (UPI)  The police today broke up an attempt by backers of an antiAmerican candidate in Sunday's National Assembly election to organize a demonstration in front of the assembly building in downtown Saigon.

title: Pound Circulation Decreases 5.32Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended in thousands of pounds follows:

title: RealEstate Group on Coast Consents to S.E.C. Order
description: The Property Research Fi nancial corporation, a real estate syndication  group, said in Los Angeles yesterday that it had entered into a consent decree sought by the Securi ties and Exchange Commission to halt alleged violations of Federal securities laws, ac cepting the S.E.C.'s order with out admitting any violations.

title: U.S. War Deaths Drop to 10, Lowest for a Week in 6 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (AP)  The United States command announced to day that 10 Americans had been killed in combat in Indo china last week, the lowest weekly toll in six years.

title: Many Garment Makers Leaving City
description: Almost onefourth of the manufacturers of women's and misses' suits and coats here closed or moved out of the city during the last five years.

title: MarketPlace:Freeze Assayed By NeoOptimist
description: Back in June, Sam I. Naka gama, the engaging econo mist for Argus Research, seemed pretty bearish to lis teners of his littlepublicized speech in Chicago.

title: Col. William H. Warrick Dies; Headed Knickerbocker Greys
description: Col. William H. Warrick, U.S.A. retired, who for 39 years commanded the Knickerbocker Greys of New York, a military cadet corps, died Wednesday at his summer home at GlenBurni his summer home at Glen Bur nieonLake George, N. Y., after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived on Guion Road, Rye.

title: Birch E. Bayh Sr., 77, Dies; Led Capital Athletic Office
description: BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 26 (AP)Birch E. Bayh Sr., father of Senator Birch Bayh, Demo crat of Indiana, died in a nurs ing home here today. He was 77 years old.

title: Con Edison Gets Approval To Acquire Power Upstate
description: The Public Service Commis sion announced approval yes terday of the arrangements Consolidated Edison has made with an upstate utility to guar antee its customers in New York City and Westchester County an additional one mil lion kilowatts of power.

title: No Loophole After All
description: In its haste to recess earlier this month, the Senate passed a bill to limit campaign spending that included some ambiguous language. The result was a widespread impression that the bill would sanction expenditure ceil ings far higher, than those initially contemplated.

title: Brookldyn Festivities Provide Profits, Pleasure and pedestrian Mall
description: Mayor Lindsay received a friendly reception yeaterdy from hundreds of then women and children as he inspected an Operaticin Main Street fes tival on Grind Street in the Williamsburg section of Brook lyn.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.,  Jimmy Ligons, 140 pounds, Los Angeles, ??pointed Eddie Mazon, 142, San Diego, 10 rounds.

title: This Week Proclaimed A Puerto Rican Fiesta
description: Mayor Lindsay issued a proclamation yesterday des ignating this week as Puerto Rican Folklore Fiesta Week.

title: Spectators Battle Police At Soledad Case Hearing
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 26 Violence erupted in a crowded courtroom here today during a hearing on pretrial motions for the two surviving Soledad Brothers.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Fall
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 26 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $175million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.064 and average yield of 3.79 per cent, compared with last week's 99. 049 and 3.85 per cent. Today's $40million of 182day bills brought 98.064 and 3.96 per cent, against last week's 98.006 and 4.08 per cent.

title: Red Sox Snap 12 Game Hex by Royals, 70
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug, 26 (AP) Ray Culp pitched a sixhit ter as the Boston Red Sox foiled Kansas City's bid for a season series sweep with a 70 triumph over the Royals to night.

title: Neighborhoods: Laurelton in Queens Once Was Ideal
description: The Laurelton section of Queens looks like the setting for an old Doris Day movie. Private homes, modestly priced. Neat lawns, well tended gardens. Kids riding bicycles. Homeowners chat ting pleasantly on wellswept sidewalks.

title: MILLARD SHRODER
description: Millard Shroder, a builder whose projects included the SherryNetherland, Madison and Sulgrave Hotels, died last evening of cancer at his home. He was 81 years old and lived at 1192 Park Avenue.

title: Check of Schweitzer's Health Sought
description: The lawyer in charge of in vestigating State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer for the Court on the Judiciary will ask that court on Monday for permission to have a doctor examine the judge to determine whether he is, as his own lawyer contends, too depressed to submit to further questioning.

title: Violence Continues As Hunt Is Pressed For Ulster Bombers
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 26 (Reuters)More shoot ings and bombings were re ported in Ulster as British troops and the police pressed their hunt tonight for terrorists who killed one man and in jured 35 with a bomb yester day.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de pertinent store sales at $805 million, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $722million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,517,000, 000, up 8 per cent from $6, 956,000,000.

title: COWBOYS DEFEAT OILERS BY 2820
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 26 (UPI) Walt Garrison bulled over for two touchdowns and Cornell Green returned an intercepted, pass 40 yards for a touchdown tonight in leading the Dallas Cowboys to a 2820 victory over the Houston Oilers in a preseason game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sato, at Funeral, Shakes Hands With Peking Aide
description: TOKYO, Aug. 26Premier Eisaku Sato shook hands with a highranking Chinese Communist official today for the first time in his life, and said he hoped he would have an opportunity to meet the official again.

title: NameCalling, Drinking Cited
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 26  The Police Department's investiga tion of the fight revealed today that Smith and Turner had ac cused Carty of being one of those niggers that's been killing our policemen.

title: TORRES AND 31 FLY TO PERU AND EXILE
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 26  Juan Jos Torres Gonzales, the deposed President of Bolivia, flew off into exile in Peru to day after issuing a call to the Bolivian people to rise in arms again and recapture the Gov ernment.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES TRADED ACTIVELY
description: Prospects of a big crop this year influenced heavy selling of soybeans futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The prices of the nearby Sep tember, 1971, contract declined as much as 9 cents a bushel. Most other soybean futures de clined 7 cents a bushel.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Trash Cans
description: In this filthy city, any experiment in keeping the streets litterfree deserves a welcome. On. that basis we applaud the new privately financed trash baskets with their ad vertising messages. If, as their creators hope, these new receptacles prove more resistant to wind, vandalism and outright theft, so much the better.

title: City Will Start Regulating And Licensing Gypsy Cabs
description: The chairman of the city's Taxi and Limousine Commis sion, Michael J. Lazar, said today that his agency would begin establishing regulations in two weeks to license the city's socalled gypsy cabs for the first time.

title: Exiled Mafia Suspects Evicted by Landladies
description: LINOSA, Italy, Aug. 27 (Reuters)Fourteen of the 19 suspected Mafia leaders exiled to this tiny island near Sicily have been exiled againby their landladies.

title: Margaret Case Rites Set
description: A funeral service for Mar garet Case, a contributing edi tor of Vogue magazine, will be held privately in Geneva, N. Y., where she will be buried. A memorial service will be held here in September or October at a time to, be announced. Miss Case jumped Wednesday from her apartment at 550 Park Avenue, the police said. The Times inadvertently gave her address yesterday as 535 Park Avenue.

title: RICHARD T. HARRISS, A TEXTILE OFFICIAL
description: VIDALIA, La., Aug. 26Rich ard T. Harriss, president of the New York Cotton Exchange in 192526, died yesterday in Natchez, Miss. He was 92 years old and lived here.

title: Fire at Albany's New Mall
description: ALBANY, Aug. 26 (AP)  A fire of undetermined origin damaged the top five floors of a 23story building in the new South Mall state office building complex adjacent to the Capitoll late tonight. Six fire trucks were dispatched to the scene at 10:45 P.M.

title: Some Roots of the Violent Action by Puerto Rican Youths
description: During the recent riots and disturbances in Puerio Rican sections of Camden and Lake wood, N. J., and Waterbury, Conn., most of those involved, were teenagers and people in their 20's.

title: HANRAHAN PLANS TO STAY IN OFFICE
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 26State's Attorney Edward V. Hanrahan, who was indicted Tuesday on charges of obstructing justice after the shooting by police men of two Black Panther leaders in December, 1969, said today that he would neither resign nor take a leave of ab sence.

title: Boston Pops Will Make Debut at Carnegie Hall
description: The Boston Pops Orchestra, led by Arthur Fiedler, will play at Carnegie Hall for the first time in a special concert to be given next April 6 as part of the hall's 80th anniversary sea son celebration.

title: Nathan's Studies Price Freeze
description: Unless prices of major farm products rise sharply, earnings of Nathan's Famous, Inc., will be little affected by the wage price freeze, Murray Hand werker, president and chair man, told stockholders yester day. Raw agricultural products are not covered by the freeze.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE OFF FROM '70 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26  Rail freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Aug. 21 was be low the volume in the corre sponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage during the same period registered an increase.

title: Incorporation Announced By Chatham Holdings
description: The Incorporation of Chat ham Holdings, Inc., with An drew Fisher of Chatham, N. Y., and Raymond C. Kennedy of Hudson, N. Y. as shareholders, was announced yesterday. Mr. Fisher, who retired this year as executive vice president of The New York Times Company, is president of the new con cern. Mr. Kennedy, publisher of The Hudson Register Star, a daily newspaper, is treasurer.

title: 7 SKIPPERS POST 2D SAIL VICTORIES
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 25Seven double winners emerged from the second day's racing in Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 39th annual Race Week which drew 220 starters today.

title: Analysts Link Democrats To an Increase in Elitism
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Two analysts whose writings had an important impact on the 1970 political campaigns have warned that the label of litismand the political poison it connotes may be moving from the Republicans to the Democratic left.

title: Graebner Reaches Semifinals
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 26Secondseeded Clark Graeb ner of New York and the teen age star, Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., survived close calls today in the $25,000 East ern grasscourt tennis cham pionships.

title: Murphy Urged to Focus Drive On Street Crime, Not Corruption
description: A Democratic City Council man urged Police Commission er Patrick V. Murphy yester day to drop his drive against corruption and provide more police protection on the street.

title: MAYOR IS REELECTED IN NASHVILLE RUNOFF
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 26 (AP) Mayor Beverly Briley defeated challenge by a city council, man today and retained office in a runoff election.

title: Mariner 9 Flaw Fixed
description: PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI) A fuel consumption problem that threatened to cut short Mariner 9's orbit around Mars has fixed itself, scientists at Jet Propulsion Laboratory reported yesterday. Excessive gas consumption has stablized itself and is now normal, a ?? said. Mariner 9, launched May 30 from Cape Kennedy, Fla. is traveling at 6,398 miles an hour and is scheduled to go into orbit. around Mars Nov. 13. It will spend a year mapping the planet with television cameras.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ISTANBUL, TurkeyFor the past decade, in between two military coups d'tat, it just so happens that Turkey has had highranking generals as Pres idents of the republic, first Cemal Gursel and now Cevdet Sunay, senior retired officer and former chief of staff. It is no accident that this has been the case. The Turks are a martial people and the army plays a very special role in their tradition and so ciety.

title: Advertising:
description: Two former pages for the National Broadcasting Com pany started their own busi ness four years ago to pro duce and distribute public service radio and television spots for companies and trade associations.

title: Musa Nasir
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 (AP)  Musa Nasir, former Jor danian Foreign Affairs Minis ter, died today of heart failure at his home in the Israeli occupied Jordanian village of BirZeit. He was 75 years old.

title: Cahill Foresees Giants' Move Attracting Capital to Speed Meadowlands Project
description: The New York Giants' an nouncement that they will move to the Hackensack Meadow lands is a catalyst for the most valuable piece of real es tate in the world, Gov. Wil Liam T. Cahill said yesterday.

title: Mrs. Taylor Wins Regatta; Leader's Boat Capsizes
Wasserstrom Nuptials
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 26 Miss Nanci Wasserstrom and Stuart Michael Smith were married tonight at the Old Westbury Golf and Coun try Club by Rabbi David M. Eichhorn. The couple's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Louis Wasserstrom of Roslyn Heights and Mrs. Eleanor T. Smith of Leonia, N. J. Mr. Wasserstrom is president of Merrimac Graphic, Inc., in New York.

title: Palmer Downs Mike Hill by 3 Strokes
My Brother, George
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. 1.August in East Hampton is a lovely time. Gusts from the ocean hint fall, and the late summer sun casts a soft light over brown meadows, green potato fields and deep blue ponds. People fret over communal picnics, speculate over names included or left off weekend guest lists, and compare notes on the household help available in the local talent pool. In serious moments, a dis gruntled intellectual may talk of emi grating to Ireland, or the alienation of modern man and his ceaseless search for identity.

title: New Economic Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (UPI)Senator William Prox mire, Democrat of Wisconsin, announced today that another round of Joint Economic Com mittee hearings on President Nixon's new economic program would be held next week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ky Said to Expect Thieu Election Offer
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26Vice President Ngu yen Cao Ky was reported con fident today that deepening civil disturbances would force President Nguyen Van Thieu to abandon his plans to go ahead with a oneman presi dential election and that the President would come up with a compromise plan that would bring Mr. Ky and Gen. Duong Van Minh back into the race.

title: Stage: In London Season, Knights Have Their Day
description: LONDONDo you remem ber in South Pacific when they used to sing there is nothing like a dame? Well, in the London theater there is something remarkably like a dame, and it is called a knight. It is charming, this English habit of rewarding the country's eminent the atrical figures with titles with the odd exceptions of Paul Scofield, who has pre sumably refused a knight hood, and Anton Dolin, who for some obscure and totally insufficient reason has never been offered one.

title: Will Wilson Rebuts Texas Bank Case Allegations
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26As sistant Attorney General Will R. Wilson confirmed reports today that he had purchased stock through his own account for a Federal bank examiner who was checking a bank owned by Frank W. Sharp, a Houston developer and finan cier.

description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 25 The army revolt that has brought an anti  Communist Government to power in Bolivia grew out of a strong conflict of interests and ideology be tween sectors of the educated, Spanishspeaking middle class.

description: WESTBURY, LI., Aug. 27  A harnessracing first will be presented here tomorrow night when two millionaires com pete in the same race.

description: Computer Sciences Corpora tion was notified yesterday it had until Nov. 1 to get its off track computers functioning properly.

title: Riva Ridge 52, Pick in Hopeful
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 27  The Hopeful, the traditional feature on the clos ing day of the annual Sara toga meeting, will have its 67th running tomorrow, with a field of 10 listed to compete.

title: Shop Talk
description: In the conservationists' lexicon, jaguar is a nono, while ranchraised mink raises no quarrel. Since the restrictions on wild pelts have become prevalent, breeders have been experi menting with mutations that might please spottedfur de votes and still raise no problem about en dangered animals. The newest of these mutations is a socalled jaguar mink that comes from a single ranch in Fin land. After years of cross breeding white mink with the taupebrown shade known as Autumn Haze, the rancher has succeeded in getting an interesting pelt dappled with jaguar or leop ard markings. The spots are not all over the pelt as ?? proper spotted cats, but run in random brown stripes against the white.

title: Liberian Paper Criticizes Attitudes Under Tubman
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Aug. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)A pro Government newspaper said today that certain attitudes that were a danger to liberty and freedom had grown up un der the regime of President William V. S. Tubman, who died July 23 after having served since 1944.

title: REPORT DISPUTED BY MAYLAI FIGURES
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 27 The apparent disappearance of a formal investigation report on the death of civilians in the South Vietnamese hamlet of Mylai 4 produced contradictory testimony today at the court martial of Col. Oran K. Hender son.

title: NATIONAL FOLK FETE GOES ON IN VIRGINIA
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) Indians from the Great Plains, Swedish folk dancers from Kansas and septuagenarian blues musicians from the South are among the several hundred artists performing at the 33d National Folk Festival.

title: RUMANIA WORRIED BY SOVIET MOVES
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Rumania is displaying growing concern over what foreign dip lomats describe as a Soviet war of nerves against the regime of President Nicolae Ceausescu that has been in progress since midsummer.

title: Meany Opposes a Race for the Presidency by Lindsay
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  George Meany said today that he would oppose any effort by Mayor Lindsay of New York to win the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: VENICE FILM FETE FOCUSES ON IRAN:' Gav' Tells of a Farmer and the Killing of His Cow
description: VENICE, Aug. 27  The Venice Film Festival prides itself on revealing new talents. In 1951 it honored "Rashomon" with its Golden Lion first prize (now temporarily abolished) and thus introduced the Japanese cinema to the West. Since then it has sought to repeat this Marco Poloesque feat, welcoming motion pictures from unlikely lands, often more out of hope than sound judgment.Today it presented an Iranian film, "Gav" ("The Cow"), and at a news conference afterward its director, Daryush Mehrjui, related the history of its shooting and told of the general state of things cinematographic in Iran.Mysteriously SlainMore symbolic than sociological, the film tells of a farmer who owns the only cow of a rural community on the plains. He adores the beast and since it provides the only milk in the vicinity the other inhabitants share his worship, believing the animal to be sacred.While he is away the cow is mysteriously slain and the neighbors, fearing the owner's wrath, bury it, intending to tell him it has run off. When he returns and learns the news, he goes mad and metamorphosizes himself into the cow, shutting himself up in the stable, mooing and nibbling straw. His comrades tie him up to drag him off to a hospital, but he breaks away and throws himself into a ravine. Who killed the cow is not disclosed, but since a sinister trio of uniformed men, wielding scimitars, make nightly raids on the village, it is probably their act.Exhibited here without subtitles, "Gav" is doubly mysterious. But there is an honest purpose to its direction and acting, and it conveys effectively the sense of a primitive folk-legend, old but eternal.Japan is represented this year by Akira Kurosawa's "Dodeska-Den" (the title is the continual cry of a retarded boy who fancies himself a streetcar conductor). It is a Gorki-cum-Zola study of the human wreckage afloat in a settlement of dilapidated shacks.A dramatic power lifts the multiple tragedy above its oppressive materials, lending it a somber grandeur and relieving its murky gloom with compassion and some sudden shafts of ironic humor. What the film offers is a sort of contemporary Japanese version of "The Lower Depths," in treatment often more Russian than Nipponese.

title: STUDENT VOTERS AIDED IN MICHIGAN
description: DETROIT, Aug. 27The Michigan Supreme Court de clared unconstitutional today two sections of the state's elec toral law that have been used by some university communi ties to prevent students from registering to vote in their areas.

title: Canoeists, Battered by Wind and Wave, Push On
description: Following is a reporter's log of the second day of a planned 120mile canoe jour ney through the waterways of New York City. The trip is being made by six canoe ists, who, as of last night, were camped at Fort Schuya ler in the Bronx.

title: SPLITTORFF HOLDS YANKEES TO 3 HITS; ROYALS WIN BY 4 0
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27Be fore tonight's game between the Yankees and the Royals, a fivepiece rock n roll group, Together, thumped its sound through huge amplifiers in a 40minute concert from a flatbed truck at second base. As far as the Yankees were concerned, the truck could have stayed there.

title: Miss Davis's Bid for Bail Denied by Appellate Court
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 27 (AP)  The state District Court of Appeal refused today to grant Angela Davis a writ of habeas corpus or freedom on bail.

title: Jane Bastanchury in Final
description: SAN DIEGO, Aug. 27 (UPI) Jane Bastanchury of Whittier, Calif., defeated the defending champion, Martha Wilkinson of Anaheim, Calif., 1 up today to reach the final of the Trans Mississippi golf tournament. In the other semifinal, Lesley Anne Dwyer, of Zambia, de feated Melanie Schiller of Chi cago, 2 and 1.

title: Stewart Huston Dies at 73; A Director of Lukens Steel
description: COATESVILLE, Pa., Aug. 27 Stewart Huston, a vice pres ident and a director of the Lukens Steel Company, died to day in Coatesville Hospital. He was 73 years old.

title: Savings Bank to Expand
description: The first Nassau County of fice of the Greater New York Savings sank will open soon at 222 Front Street, Mineola.

title: 4 BIG OIL COMPANIES NAMED IN I.C.C. SUIT
description: DENVER. Aug. 27 (UPI) The Interstate Commerce Com mission yesterday accused four major oil companies and two interstate petroleum carriers of having illegally entered into re ciprocal purchasing arrange ments.

title: President's Power Play
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  Japan's decision to float the yen upward has reinforced Treasury Secretary Con nally's waitandsee strategy in the world monetary and trade crisis set off by President Nixon's choice of a bold power play to solve this coun try's international economic prob lems unilaterally  rather than by consultation and joint action on com mon problems with America's chief military and trade partners abroad. But if the Nixon move away from gold and a quartercentury of reci procal tariff cuts has aroused more enthusiasm than concern in Washing tion, the reverse is true abroad. Even in Administration quarters there is a growing feeling that it is essential to return rapidly to the root of inter national cooperation urged by Secre tary of State Rogers prior to mid August events that gave Mr. Connally his head in shaking up the world.

title: Brazil to Expel Living Theater Troupe
description: BRASILIA, Aug. 27 (AP) President Emilio G. Medici, under pressure from adverse world publicity, today ordered the expulsion from Brazil of the New York producer Julian Beck, his wife, Judith Malina, and 11 other members of their Living Theater company.

title: No, Breathe Easier
description: We are winning the war against pollution. And this is the biggest un told story in America today. It is a fact corroborated by evidence avail able to anyone who bothers to look at the results of chemical and physi cal tests that have been run for many years by private and public institu tions.

title: EnvoyAided Fund In an S.E.C. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Securities andExchange Commission said today that it is investigating a mutual fund that lists a brother of President Nixon as a director and the United States Ambassador to the Netherlands as vice presi dent.

title: Davis, Eager for Action, To Get In Against Chiefs
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 27 With Joe Namath's leg still in a cast, the New York Jets have only two quarterbacks working out in camp. So Bob Davis, the backup for Al Wood all, doesn't have to worry much right now about being cut.

Rochlis, who continues with the parent company as an executive vice president where he will supervise development programs for the boat division and remain president of the indus trial division. Mr. Fellows was formerly executive vice president.

description: The Leasco Corporation, which the Federal District Court in Brooklyn ruled on Thursday had filed a mislead ing registration statement three years ago in offering to buy Reliance Insurance Company stock, declared yesterday that it was reviewing the 128page decision before deciding whether to appeal the court ruling.

description: A growing and increasingly profitable company  Barton Brands, Inc., Chicago  will liquidate within a year under Section 337 of the Internal Rev enue Code, it was announced yesterday. Shareholders of the company, primarily a distillery, approved the plan at a special meeting in Chicago.

A similar resolu tion, though in a weakened concurrent form, has been reported from a House committee.

description: KUWAIT  The affluent col lege graduates of this Per sian Gulf sheikdom can be seen any day of the week gath ered in little groups on the beaches. When the heat dimin ishes at dusk they can be found lounging in the coffee shops of the expensive hotels or racing their Porsches and Jaguars on the waterfront boulevard near the United States Embassy.

description: Karen Sperling is, in her own words, a millionairess but not by much.

At pres ent he has a hand in two of the most potent hits in Londonhis own play, Old Times, which is in the Royal Shakespeare Company's rep ertory at the Aldwych The atre, and Butley, a new play by Simon Gray at the Criterion Theater, which Mr. Pinter has directed.

Cosmos 435 com pleted its first turn around the earth in 92.1 minutes on path that took it 313 miles from the earth at its farthest point and to within 175 miles of the earth at its nearest point.

Quinn, a professor of psy chology at Albertus Magnus College in New Haven. The Rev. Thomas F. Glynn, pas tor of St. Clam's Roman Catholic Church in East Haven, assisted.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP The Adminstration hinted today that it might move to placate powerful labor opposi tion to the wageprice freez by allowing workers to ?? later some of the hundreds ?? milloins of dollars in frozer pay increases.

title: The Yen Floats
description: Japan's decision yesterday to float the yen is a victory for economic rationalityand also for President Nixon's new economic policy. But it is a measure of the fervor with which the Sato Government sought to preserve the old increasingly unrealistic ratio of 360 yen to the dollar that the surrender did not come until the Bank of Japan was hit by an avalanche of dollars$1.25 billion pre sented for conversion in a single day. The deluge forced Japanese policymakers to realize that they were trying to fill a bottomless pot, a venture that could wreck Japan's powerful economy.

title: Auto Production Surges
description: DETROIT, Aug. 27 (AP)  Production of domestic autos jumped by 33,000 units this week as General Motors began its fullscale 1972model pro duction.

title: PHILLIPS CARLIN, BROADCASTER, 77
description: Phillips Carlin, a pioneer radio broadcaster whose career on radio and later on televi sion spanned 41 years, died of a heart attack at his home yes terday. He was 77 years old and lived at 744 Mulberry Point.

title: Brdidge:The Obvious Opening Lead Is Not Always the Best One
description: When to make an open ing lead in partner's suit and ?? not to is often a close question. From a morale point of view it is perhaps best to do the obvious and lead his suit, for a wrong decision on those lines will irritate him less than the converse.

title: Aides Cautious as Nixon Approves Accords on Berlin
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 27Administration offi Cials said today that the nego tiation of a fourpower draft agreement on western access to Berlin demonstrated the need to maintain strong American forces in Europe.

title: ExWest Point Linebacker Credited With Getting New York Giants to jersey
description: TRENTON, Aug. 27 New Jersey's success in getting the New York Giants to play foot ball in the Hackensack Mead owlands was conceived and masterminded here by the State Treasurer, Joseph M. McCrane, a linebacker on the Davis Blanchard team at West Point who once tried unsuccessfully to get the Philadelphia Eagles for southern New Jersey.

title: Palmer, Knudson Post Match Play Triumphs
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 27 Scoring his third consecutive round in the 60's, Arnold Palm er gained the quarterfinal round today in the $200,000 national match play champion ship. He beat Dave Eichel berger, a slim 27yearold Texan from Waco, by three strokes.

title: Stranded Train Passengers Hitch Rides in Queens
description: Thousands of subway riders who were forced to leave trains yesterday in Queens because of flooded conditions milled about in the streets for hours trying to get to Manhattan.

title: A.E.C. FORMULATING RULES ON POLLUTION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI)The Atomic Energy Com mission began preparing regu lations today that would allow it to suspend construc tion of any nuclear power plant that does not meets its environ mental standards.

title: Margaret BourkeWhite, PhotoJournalist, Is Dead
description: Margaret BourkeWhite, one of the world's preeminent photographers, died yesterday morning at the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital from compli cations after a long battle with Parkinson's disease, a nerve disorder. She was 67 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Medina Said to Have Felt He Lost Control of Troops
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 27An Army lie detector expert testified today that Capt. Ernest L. Medina was telling the truth when he said he had never ordered or de sired the killing of innocent, South Vietnamese civilians at Mylai.

title: Pennsy Audit Figures Put '70 Loss at $425Million
description: The Penn Central Transporta tion Company has filed audited figures with the United States District Court in Philadelphia indicating a loss in 1970 of $425.7million. Preliminary es timates fixed the loss at $431.2 million.

title: VALACHILEAYES ESTATE TO PEN PAL
description: Joseph Valachi, the Mafioso turned government informant, left an estate estimated be tween $5,000 and $10,000 in will probated Thursday in Ni agara County Court at Lock port, N. Y.

title: State Asks Court to Close Hotel for Polluting River
description: The State Department of Health went to court in Albany Yesterday to ask for the imme diate closing of a major Cat skill resort, the Flagler Hotel in South Fallsburg, which it ac cused of dumping sewage into the Neversink River, and other health violations.

title: Pennsylvania Gets New Law to Aid Nonpublic Schools
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27 Gov. Milton J. Shapp signed today a bill to aid nonpublic schools, which had been rushed through the legislature to re place the one the United States Supreme Court in June had ruled unconstitutional.

title: TRADE CURBS HIT COMPUTER SALES
description: LJUBLJANA, Yugoslavia, Aug. 27American restrictions on EastWest trade in strategic goods are seriously hampering United States manufacturers of computers and data processing equipment in what they see as a rapidly expanding market in the Communist countries of Eastern Europe.

title: Trading in Yen Halted in Exchange Market Here
description: Trading in the Japanese yen ground to a halt in the New York foreign exchange market yesterday, following the deci sion of the Japanese Govern ment to allow the currency to float in the market.

title: From Used Bottles to Useful Glasses
description: All those empty bottles that are thrown away every daymany of them made with good, sturdy glass in beau tiful tints and extraordinary shapes! If only there were some practical use they could be put to. There is, of cource. Just cut off the tops and what remains is a drinking glass, a vase, an ashtray or paper clip holder, a place to store pencils or what have you. But slicing off the top of bottle neatly, without shatter ing it or sustaining bodily harm, has been a tricky pro position for the unskilled. Now, however, probably spurred by all the talk about ecology and a jagged eco nomy, a number of gadgets have appeared so that, with a little practice and a lot of patience, a bottle, so long as it's round, can be cut into a glass.

title: STEP' WELCOMED
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Officials of the Nixon Admin istration reacted warily today to the Japanese decision to al low the yen to float and let market forces determine its value.

title: Two Canadian Airline Aides Visit Peking for Negotiations
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 27 (Reuters)Two executives of the canadian Pacific Airlines, which wants to fly to peking, are in china for discussions with chinese civil avition of ficials, an airline spokeman said today. He said the exec utivehad been looking at air port facilities.

title: Suspect Held in Nugent Slaying  Is Said to Be Seller of the Gun
description: A suspect who the police lieve was in the business of selling guns and narcotics to addicts was arrested yesterday as the man they think supplied the gun used in the Aug. 20 slaying of Patrolman Kenneth A. Nugent.

title: Failure of Charter Fights Strands Many in Europe
description: Hundreds of Americans, most of them college students, are stranded in Europe because charter airlines have refused to honor their return tickets.

title: Roundup: Pappas Notches No. 16 to Tie Career High
description: Despite the fact that Milt Pappas has been pitching in major league baseball for 15 years and is only 16 victories short of 200 for his career, the 32yearold righthander has never won more than 16 games in a season.

title: Increased Earnings Far A.T .&T . Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27A staff examiner for the Federal Communications Commission ruled today that the American Telephone and Telegraph Com pany should be allowed an 8 per cent rate of return on inter state service under today's fi nancial conditions.

title: The Talk of Havana
description: HAVANA, Aug. 20Along Malec Drive, a bony, whisk ered Jamaican who called himself Walker talked brash ly of life in two corners of the world, Harlem and Ha vana. He had been a bag man in Harlem years earlier, he said. Those were big money years, he added, sizing up two wom en, mother and daughter, who were approach ing. I was a big man around Lenox, Avenue. Made lots of bread.

title: Use of Newsprint Down In July and for 7 Months
description: Total United States news print consumption in July was 708,460 tons, 2.7 per cent less than was used in the same month last year, the American Newspaper Publishers Associa tion said yesterday.

title: Beame Halts Cleared Loan Vouchers
description: Controller Abraham D. Beanie refused yesterday to pay $560,000 on 21 cleared Municipal Loan Program vouchers to nine small con tractors rehabilitating slum housing until outside engineers verified that specificationi had been met and work had been completed.

title: How to Kill a Mountain
description: CANAAN, Conn.For years I had gone to Canaan Mountain on Satur days with my friend Jack Farr to explore and to hike through the sur rounding forest. For both of us it was an opportunity to enter a world of immense natural beauty, freed from the pressures of our work and from the clatter and turmoil of the cities where we lived. We became very de pendent on these Saturdays in the woods. If we missed one, the follow ing week dragged insufferably. We went throughout the year, snowshoe ing in the winter months. It was like repairing to a fountain of youth every Saturday morning and driving home that night after a ten or twelvemile hike feeling positively young again, recharged in body and spirit. The mountain and its environs became one of the focal points in our lives.

title: MAYOR SEES RISE IN TRAINEES' JOBS
description: Mayor Lindsay told members of his cabinet yesterday that the city had undertaken deli cate negotiations with the Civ il Service Commission and the unions representing the three uniformed services to open job opportunities for members of minority groups.

title: Notes on People
description: In need of a new Commis sioner of Parks and Recrea tion, Governor Rockefeller picked his second cousin, Alexander Aldrich, who once served as his executive as sistant. Mr. Aldrich, who is now president of the Brook lyn Center of Long Island University, will succeed Sal J. Prezioso, named by the Governor to succeed the soontoberetired John J. Burns as Commissioner of the Office for Local Govern ment in Albany.

title: Appeal to Judiciary
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Aug. 27, (UPI)  Vice President Carlos Goico Morales called on mem bers of the judiciary today to act to halt the wave of violence that has struck the country. The Vice President said that the police cannot control the parties responsible for the vio lence.

title: Newark's New Minority, the Italians, Demands Equity
description: NEWARK, Aug. 27  Spurred by the growing pow er of Newark's black major ity, the Italian community here has become increasingly conscious of its own identity and has begun demanding special consideration as the city's new minority group.

title: Romney Urges Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment and a member of the Cost of Living Council, pro posed today the establishment of a wageprice review board with power to curb inflation ary practices of corporations and unions, effective when the 90day freeze expires on Nov. 13.

title: PRICES ON AMEX REGISTER A GAIN
description: Advances outnumbered de clines by a narrow margin on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in light trading.

title: Weather Disrupts Sports Slate; Most Events Reset for Today
description: Yesterday's rain washed out most sports events along the East Coast, including the Mets Dodgers baseball game at Shea Stadium, which had an advance sale of 50,000.

title: Mrs. Philip W. Pillsbury Dies; Leader in Planned Parenthood
