description: MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 27 Mrs. Eleanor Bellows Pillsbury, a leader in national health ac tivities, died today of cancer at her home in Wayzata. Her age was 58. She was the wife of Philip W. Pillsbury, former president and chairman of the Pillsbury Company.

title: Massachusetts Polio Death
description: BOSTON, Aug. 27 (AP)A 62yearold Lowell woman has, become the first person in Mas sachusetts to die of polio in nine years. The cause of the death of the woman, who was not identified, was determined yesterday after laboratory tests by Boston pathologists.

title: Murphy Promotes an Inspector For Fighting Police Corruption
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday praised a police commander for his fight against corruption and then promoted him.

title: 55 PISTOLS ARE LOST ON WAY TO BROOKLYN
description: Fiftyfive 22caliber Beretta pistols shipped ten months ago from a wholesale sporting goods store in Kentucky to a firearms company here were reported missing yesterday by the transporter.

title: Small Pony Prize At Fairfield Show To Farnley HiLi
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 27 Fernley HiLi, owned and ridden by Sindy Paul of Abing ton, Pa., won the small pony hunter championship at the Fairfield County Hunt Club's junior horse show today even though he wound up his day's work with an injured leg.

title: Leading Indicators Made A Solid Advance for July
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)  The Government's leading business indicators, which tend to foreshadow future economic movements, showed a solid ad vance in July, the Commerce Department said today.

title: PANTHER IS LINKED TO JAIL BREAK GUN
description: SAN: QUENTIN, Calif., Aug. 27Prison officials reported today that a Black Panther leader once owned a gun that they said was used by George Jackson in an escape attempt that took six lives last Satur day.

title: Series of Charges Listed
description: SAIGON, Aug. 27 (AP)In its report today, the legislative committee charged that an army major had advised his men to vote for the incumbent speaker of the lower house Sunday.

title: CONTRACT AWARDS
description: The United Aircraft Corpora tion has received a $29.5million addition to a Navy contract for procurement of jet engines for the F14A aircraft.

title: Pennsylvania Passes Income Tax Of Flat 2.3% That Shapp Asked
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Aug. 27 The State Senate passed to night and sent to Gov. Milton J. Shapp a 2.3 per cent flat in come tax that he had recom mended to balance a budget of $3.2billion for this fiscal year.

title: Saigon Adds More Troops
description: SAIGON, Aug. 27 (AP)Two thousand more South Vietna mese troops moved into the Saigon area today to bolster security for the National As sembly elections.

title: End of Freeze Is Set For Midnight, Nov. 13
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP)George A. Lincoln, di rector of the Office of Emerg ency Preparedness, said to day that the 90day wage pricerent freeze would end midnight, Nov. 13.

title: June Havoc Resigns Post With New Orleans Troupe
description: June Havoc has resigned as director of the New Repertory Theater of New Orleans after having worked with the com pany for two seasons. Miss Havoc said that the funds avail able for the coming season were not sufficient for what she regards as firstclass theater.

title: STOCKS POST GAIN AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Stock prices steadied yester day in slow trading as the market rounded out another week of solid gains.

title: EDWARD R. DIONNE
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Aug. 27 Edward R. Dionne, a sales and advertising coordinator for the F. W. Woolworth Company, died of a heart attack today in Valley Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived at 105 Washington Place.

title: Egyptian Sees Threat to Arabs In Cooling Soviet Commitment
description: CAIRO, Aug. 27A cooling of the Soviet commitment to support the Arabs as a result of vexation over recent set backs is a matter of extreme concern to Cairo, Egypt's lead ing editor and political strate gist, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, conceded today.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz Revising Selling Methods
description: For most of its 109 years, F.A.O. Schwarz, the Fifth Ave nuebased toy chain, would re verberate during the Christmas and other major holiday peri ods with the sounds of anxious parents and the squeals of chil. dren, waiting for merchandise to come up from the basement stockroom. The lines of waiting customers would thicken and not everyone had enough pa tience to hang on.

title: TRAVEL SNARLED BY 4.1INCH RAIN; MORE DUE TODAY
description: Torrential rains created trans portation chaos yesterday for hundreds of thousands of trav elers in the metropolitan area.

title: HOW DOLLAR HAS DECLINED
description: LONDON, Aug. 27The dol lar reacted in mixed fashion against major European cur rencies today as foreign ex change dealers welcomed the Japanese decision to float the yen as a contribution to resolv ing the world currency crisis.

title: Mrs. Onassis in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, Aug. 27  Mrs. Aristotle Onassis and her sister, Princess Lee Radziwil, wife of prince Stanislaw Radziwill, ar rived here today by special Olympic Airlines plane from Athens to attend the funeral to morrow of Prince Edmund Radziwill. The late prince was one of the few members of the aristocratic family to have re mained here under the Com munist regime.

title: Merger News
description: The BristolMyers Company, a broadlydiversified concern with a $1billion sales volume in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and household products, an nounced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Zimmer Manufac turing Company, Warsaw, Ind., for approximately $79 million in common stock.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CITIES' EMPLOYES EARN TOP WAGES
description: Federal studies of municipal Jobs indicate that many work ers in 11 cities surveyed earn more than Federal and private employes for comparable office jobs.

title: Chad Radio Reports Coup Is Thwarted; Cairo Ties Broken
description: YAOUNDE, Cameroon, Aug. 27 (Agence FrancePresse)An attempted coup in Chad failed today and the Government broke off diplomatic relations with Egypt, which Chad ac cused of being behind the plot, according to a broadcast from FortLamy, the capital.

title: F. B. I.'s Chief OrganizedCrime Fighter Quits
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  James H. Gale, an assistant di rector of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and its chief or ganizedcrime fighter, has re tired, according to reliable sources.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Thirteen years ago, when the Dodgers and the Giants left New York for California, the sports fan was notified that the local franchise, like love and life, was not forever. The news went down very hard; some wept silently, others raged at perfidious management, a few saw the end America as we have come to know it, which was perfectly true. By and large, that move was a very fortunate one for. the, teams involved, for the game of baseball and for the country: It made the pastime truly national, brought the major leagues to millions of Americans for the first time and presumably enriched the O'Malleys and the Stonehams.

title: Liverpool Poor Discover Arts Center Brightens Life
description: LLIVERPOOL, England  Along the Merseyside docks the children and teenagers begin surging toward the Blackie at 2 P.M.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 A professor at the University of Michigan and two coin ventors have patented a me chanism to be used by psychi atrists, psychologists and so cial workers in diagnosing and correcting human rela tionships. Called Sam for short, the invention is a signal system for the assessment and modification of behavior. Dr. Ed win J. Thomas of the School of. Social Work and department of psychology at Ann Arbor and his former associates were granted Patent 3,600,826 this week. The research was funded by the Department of Health, Education and Wel fare.

title: Miss Westmoreland Bride in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Miss Katherine Stevens West moreland and Tyler Blair Weymouth were married here today in the Bethlehem Chap el of the. Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul (National Ca thedral). The Rev. Jack San ders, rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Green field, Mass., performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. James E. Thomas, a dean of Harvard University.

title: News Analysis
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 27 Soviet leaders, who have made con cessions to achieve a Big Four accord on Berlin, and who are reportedly near an agreement with the United States on limit ing defense strategic arms, are soon expected to begin a major diplomatic drive to convince the West of their desire to re duce tensions in Europe.

title: A JUDGE IN SAMOA LOSES BID TO STAY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Americin Samoans will have to get along with Gov. John M. Haydon Jr'nd suffer the loss of a judge they want to keep.

title: Johnson Has 63d Birthday
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 27 (AP) Former President Lyndon B. Johnson celebrated his 63d birthday quietly today at LBJ Ranch, 65 miles west of Aus tin. We know of no plans for him to go anywhere, said an associate at his Austin office. Mr. Johnson was born Aug. 27, 1908, in a small frame house near Stonewall.

title: Market Place: The Better Part Of Valor urged
description: Especially since the 1969 70 bear market debacle, investors everywhere have agonized over the question: Shall I manage my own in vestments or turn them over to a professional?

title: LEGISLATIVE UNIT IN SAIGON ACCUSES THIEU OF RIGGING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27A South Vietnamese legislative committee accused the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu today of numerous instances of election rigging.

title: SOVIET PRESS FREE, MOSCOW DEAN SAYS
description: The dean of the journalism school at Moscow State Uni versity said yesterday that the press of the Soviet Union was, freer than that of the United States.

title: LIMIT IS STRESSED
description: TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 28 After nearly two weeks of a stubborn and lonely effort to keep the yen pegged at 360 to the dollar, the Japanese Gov ernment announced that as of today the yen would be al lowed to float within unspeci fied limits against the dollar. The Bank of Japan would inter vene if the yen rose too high.

title: Filion Freehold Victor
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Aug. 27 (AP)Terry Braden, owned by John A. Murphy of New York and driven by Herve Filion of Montreal, won the $3,000 feature eighth race at Freehold Raceway today. The winner paid $5.20, $3.80 and $3 for $2 across the board. My Buddy was second, paying $4 and $3, with Lone Ranger third, at $4.40.

title: Ecuador Is Reported Displeased By Allende Talks With Leftists
description: QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 27 (Reuters)President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile, here on a threeday visit, has displeased Ecuadorean Govern ment officials by meeting pri vately with leftwing student leaders, who oppose the Gov ernment, sources in the Govern ment said today.

title: U ganda Reports New Fighting Along Border With Tanzania
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 27 New shooting broke out on the UgandaTanzania border this morning, the Uganda Gov ernment reported tonight.

title: Anaconda to Sell Mexico 51% of its Cananea Mine
description: The Anaconda Company, a major copper producer, said yesterday it will sell 51 per cent of the stock in its mining operation in Cananea, Mexico, to the Mexican Government and private investors in that country. Although the com pany did not place a value on the stock sale, Horacio Flores de la Pefla, Mexico's National Properties Minister, said his Government was paying $40 million over a fouryear period.

title: STORM DRENCHES MARYLAND COAST
description: OCEAN CITY, Md., Saturday, Aug. 28  A tropical storm called Doria, with winds of nearhurricane force, moved northeastward along the At lantic coast early today, dump ing heavy rains and causing flash flooding in Maryland and Delaware.

title: Bay State Jobless Rate Up
description: BOSTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) The unemployment rate in Mas sachusetts edged upward last month to 8.1 per cent of the work force, the staic Division of Employment Security said today. The ?? unemploy ment rate in June cent. The increase was ?? ??

title: Women's Day, World's Day
description: While celebration of the fiftyfirst anniversary of women's suffrage this week indicated some, falling off in the noisier aspects of the women's liberation move ment, the occasion was if anything more impressive than earlier demonstrations of strength. With the novelty fad ing, the more extravagant forms of demonstration have receded, leaving the emphasis where it belongs: on the incontrovertible case that inequality between the sexes does exist, that such discrimination is unjust and harm ful and that it should be erased by political means.

title: Antiques: Art Deco Show
description: The question of what kind of Art Deco collectors should be seeking is neatly raised in the current exhibition at the Minneapolis Art Institute.

title: Utah Railway Is Again Creeping Profitably
description: HEBER, Utah, Aug. 27  While Amtrak and the As sociation of American Rail roads were permitting the Wabash Cannonball and Cali fornia Zephyr to ride the steel rails Into the sunset, residents of this mountain girt community of 3,000 were establishing the Wasatch Mountain Railway.

title: Syphilis Cases Increase
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 27 (AP) The nation's level of reported syphilis cases continues to show an increase, the Center for Disease Control reported today. At the end of July, 13, 759 cases had been reported throughout the nation since Jan. 1. compared with 12,443 cases through the same month last year, the center said.

title: Eaton Corp. to Build Plant
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 27 (UPI) A $35million single and tan dem truck axle plant will, be built in Glasgow, Ky., by the Eaton Corporation, it said to day. The new plant is expected to begin operations in 1973.

title: U.S. POSTAL SERVICE IS ACCUSED OF BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) A predominantly black labor union announced today that it had filed suit charging the Postal Service with racial dis crimination in promotions.

title: OLYMPIA WORKS WEIGHS LAYOFFS
description: BONN, Aug. 27The Olym pia works of Wilhemshaven, one of the world's largest of ficeequipment manufacturers, announced today that the new American surcharge on imports may compel the conern to lay off several thousand workers.

title: Screen: Hippie Vampire:' Let's Scare Jessica to Death' Arrives
description: The thinking man's vampire movie, probably a secret dream for at least half the world's young filmmakers, tries to rise again in John Hancock's "Let's Scare Jessica to Death," which opened yesterday at the Criterion Theater. Although a disappointment generally, there are several things going for it; among them, the pleasantly aggressive title, which has, as is proper, only the most casual relation to the movie.The movie does have a Jessica (Zohra Lampert), just recovered from a nervous breakdown, who, with her husband (Barton Heyman) and a family friend (Kevin O'Conner) renounces the New York rat race and takes possession of a clammy old house in Connecticut. On their very first night they encounter Emily (Mariclare Costello), a young wayfaring hippie who has gotten into the house before them and whom they ask to stay a while. She stays and staysindeed, she will never leaveand after both men have been, well, bitten by her, it becomes apparent that Emily is none other than the 100-year-old vampire who occupies the depths of the local cove and has in the course of time made an impression on all the men in the nearby town.The local cove and the nearby town and the rest of the film's setting, along the Connecticut River below Hadlyme, are among the other pleasures of "Lets Scare Jessica to Death," which brings a rather discerning sense of place and season to its woods and its waters and the stairs and corridors of its ramshackle house. But toward its genre it develops rather less feeling, and after an initial homage to the traditional coffin crossing the water (in fact, a bass-violin case in the back of the couple's hearse-station wagon being ferried over the river) and a momentary camera angle out of Dreyer's great "Vampyr," it tends to lose much sense of what kind of movie it is.It therefore becomes several kinds of movie, sacrificing some of its best ideas to trivial shock effect, relinquishing even the slightest claim to suspension of disbelief and sending Zohra Lampert continually scurrying over a countryside occupied by creatures that look less like vampire victims than like science-fiction robots out of a different film in a different decade. You may not think it possible for a movie like this to say that at a certain point it ceases to make sense, but that is really what happens to "Let's Scare Jessica to Death" within a half hour of its beginning.Among the actors only Miss Lampert develops a characterization. And although she is beautiful and, as always, breathlessly appealing, she projects a personality too forcefully complex for a role that requires only sympathetic passivity in the face of persecution.

title: Nuptials Held for Susan Kirk Lesser
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 27Miss Susan Kirk Lesser, daughter. of. Mr. and Mrs. Howard A., Lesser of. New York and East Norwich, L. I., Was married mere this after noon to William Henry Hal termann Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haltermann of Kingston, N. Y.' The ceremony was performed in the Brookville Reformed Church by the Rev. Charles Robert Harrah. A reception followed at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley.

title: Lindsay Threatens to Evict the Giants
description: Mayor Lindsay threatened yesterday to evict the New York Giants from Yankee Sta dium should the city acquire title to the property as his ad ministration plans.

title: Mrs. Davidson Is Married on L.I.
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I, Aug. 27The marriage of Mrs, Susan Davidson to Glen H. Miller took, place in the First Presbyterian Church here to night. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alex S. Renton.

title: Ruling in California
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)The Supreme Court of California ruled today that college students over the age of 18 may register and vote in their college communities rather than at their parents home addresses.

title: Leo Kottke Sings And Plays Guitar At the Bitter End
description: Leo Kottke, an accomplished guitarist from Oklahoma, is making an appearance through Monday at the Bitter End, 147 Bleecker Street.

title: East German Comment
description: BERLIN, Aug. 27The East German Communist party said today that the Big Four in their draft accord on Berlin had agreed to reduce the West Ger man activities in West Berlin and had acknowledged es sentially that the allied sectors were not part of the Federal Republic.

title: Attorney Says Atlanta Trio Won't Get a Fair Hearing
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 27 (AP) The attorney representing three policemen accused of beating up Rico Carty of the Atlanta Braves said today that public remarks by the mayor and the police chief may have made it impossible for the officers to get a fair hearing.

title: M.T.A. Adds a Stop, 72d St., To Its 2d Avenue Subway Plan
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority unveiled a new plan for the Second Avenue subway yesterday that included a new station at 72d Street and an extension of the 48th Street station southward almost to 42d Street.

title: Yankees and Mets Oppose Sharing of Shea Stadium
description: Both the New York Yankees and the Mets expressed opposi tion yesterday to any idea of sharing the city's Shea Stadium after the football Giants aban don Yankee Stadium for New Jersey in 1975.

title: Mayor Welcomes Concern Backto City
description: Still resentful at the city's loss of 40 football players, May or Lindsay found comfort yes terday with 200 furniture mak ers, employes of a company that has returned to the City after finding the suburbs lad for business.

title: LOAN RATES CUT BY 2 MORE BANKS
description: The movement toward lower consumer lending rates gath ered force yesterday. On Thurs day evening the Chemical Bank announced an immediate, acrosstheboard reduction on both consumer loans and mort gages.

title: Business Chiefs Voice Hope over Decision by the japanese to Allow the Yen to Float
description: Japan's decision to let the yen float was welcomed in the international business commu nity yesterday as a potential first step toward restoration of normal world monetary and trading conditions.

title: Dr. Lee H. Sherwin Dies; Bellevue Graduate in 95
description: LAREDO, Tex., Aug. 27Dr. Lee H. Sherwin, believed to be the oldest living graduate of Bellevue Medical Center in New York, died today in Mercy Hospital of a coronary attack at the age of 98.

title: Drug Use in City Schools
description: The report by City Controller Beanie on the wide spread use of narcotics by New York City public school children deserves a more thoughtful and re sponsive reception than it has received from the Board of Education. The board's president, Isaiah E. Robinson, sought to dismiss the report's frightening findings by saying much of it was based on hearsay and cannot be substantiated.

title: U.S. AGENTS SEIZE IN SECURITIES RING
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 27 (AP) Federal agents arrested five persons tonight and seized more than $1million worth of stolen bonds and securities, the au thorities said.

title: Spitz and Ellie Daniel Set Swim Marks
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 27 (AP) Mark Spitz broke the world record in the men's 200meter butterfly for the second time today and Ellie Daniel equaled the world record she set in the preliminaries of the women's 200meter butterfly to highlight finals action in the national Amateur Athletic Union swim ming championships.

title: 2 FLEE WITH $16,000 IN WALDORFASTORIA
description: Three masked men with re volvers forced a hotel account ant to open a safe in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel early yesterday, and two of the men made off with about $16,000 of the $22,000 in cash they had stuffed into a paper bag.

title: Artist in Film
description: Margaret BourkeWhite used her camera as paint brush to portray first America and then the world with painful starkness. Starting with pictures of factories and indus trial processes, she was among the first to understand that towering smokestacks and meshing gears and tug boats pulling barges were the stuff of imaginative photographic art.

title: TAIWAN STEEL MILL TO GET AUSTRIAN AID
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 27 (UPI)The Nationalist Chinese Government has decided to build a $620million steel mill in cooperation with Austria's stateoperated steel company, it was announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY STORES CO. REPORTS DEFICIT
description: The City Stores Company, which includes in its operations W. & J. Sloane and Franklin Simon units, had slightly higher sales, but deficits continued in the quarter and six months ended July 31, the company re ported yesterday.

title: 28 Indicted in Camden Raid: Two More Priests Are Accused
description: The Federal grand jury in vestigating Last weekend's at tempted raid on the Selective Service office in Camden, N.J., handed up 28 Indictments yes terday against the 20 persons arrested during the incident and eight others named in the Government's original com plaint.

title: Kissinger Put in His Place
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif, Aug. 27 (UPI)President Nixon put Henry A. Kissinger, his national security affairs adviser, in political perspective today. Dur ing a picturetaking session with the President, Mr. Kis singer and Kenneth Rush Am bassador to West Germany, Ronald L. Ziegler the White House press secretary, quipped to camermen: That's Kissinger on the left. The President re marked, On the rightnever, on the left.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Trunk Shows Hit the Road and Spread the Fashion News
description: PITTSBURGH, Pa.  When Mrs. Ed ward Ryan of Frostburgh, Md., arrived at Joseph Horne's department store ear lier this week, she had no intention of buying anything. All she planned to do was get a look at the new fall fashions.

title: Mass Ousters of Black Students A Growing Integration Problem
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 27 Last fall, when this city's schools underwent massive in tegration, 500 very poor black youngsters were assigned to A.C. Flora High, a 1,700student institution nestled among tall pine trees in an allwhite, upper  middle  class neighbor hood.

title: Elly Ameling in Lieder
description: Well, if it takes a Mostly Mozart Festival to bring us a ration of summertime Schubert, that is one more thing to thank Mozart for At Philharmonic Hall on Thursday night, Elly Ameling confined herself to Schubert, in fact, and an unusually vociferous audience would not let the Dutch soprano leave without encores for both portions of her program.

title: DENNISTON SLATER, FANNY FARMER HEAD
description: Denniston Lyon Slater, chair man of the board of Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., died at New York Hospital on Thursday after a short illness. He was 41 years old.

title: GIANTS TAKE MARK OF 03 TO JERSEY
description: The Giants are do New Jersey todaybut only temporarily.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES RALLY IN TRADING
description: Soybean futures closed as much as 2 cents a bushel high er yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, despite a 3cent decline during liquidation of positions early in the session.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Allende Reported Ailing
description: GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Aug. 27 (UPI)President Allende of Chile interrupted a state visit to here today and it was re ported that he was indisposed and had been ordered to bed by his physicians. There were re ports that Dr. Allende had hurt his foot during a wreathlaying ceremony. Other reports said he was suffering from arthritis.

title: METS LOSE BIG ONE TO THE ELEMENTS
description: The New York Mets lost an expensive decision to the rain last night when the opening game of their final series with the Los Angeles Dodgers was rescheduled as part of a double header starting this afternoon at 2:15 o'clock.

title: Labor's Postfreeze Plan By PHILIP SHABECOFF
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., gave the first hint today of the economic machin ery that organized labor will seek as a successor to the Nix on Administration's 90day wage and price freeze.

title: Ted Lewis Mourned Here; Several Hundred Attend
description: Several hundred persons gathered at Temple Rodeph Sholom yesterday to pay their last, respects to Ted Lewis, the showman with the battered top hat who was best known for Me and My Shadow and When My Baby Smiles at Me,

title: Jim Turnesa of Golfing Family, P.C. A. Champion in '50, Dead
description: ELMSFORD, N.Y., Aug. 27 (AP)  Jim Turnesa, second of seven golfing brothers and former Professional Golfers As sociation champion, died of lung cancer early today. His age was 57.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pompidou Seeks European Effort Against Narcotics
description: PARIS, Aug. 27American complaints about the French effort to combat drug traffic drew a variety of retorts and some confirmation today.

title: Maladministered Welfare
description: The announcement by Human Resources Administrator Jule Sugarman that more than 20,000 welfare recipients fraudulently obtained $1.5 million in duplicate relief checks in the last year reveals a shocking administrative disarrayone in need of exploration by the state's new Welfare Inspector General. Some welfare cheaters appar ently received duplicate checks month after month with out creation by the welfare authorities of the most minimal safeguards or even any evidence of suspicion by the welfare staff.

title: The Sounds Of Home
description: Home is a coop in the east Sixties, and the sounds issuing therefrom can get pretty dis cordant. In the center ring we have the Harrison Claibornes, a pair of sexagenarians prolific enough to have procreated a mess of complications. Daugh ter Annie, the fourth of her hus band's wives, has her second child and her spouse's seventh. Son Stephen (whose wife is in love with her brother) wants to marry his stepdaughter. And to top it off, Paul and Jose phine, the Claiborne's butler and cook have given notice.

title: Kristin Baggelaar Married
description: ROSLYN ESTATES, L. I., Aug. 28Miss Kristin Anna Baggelaar and Donald Landis Milton were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. H. Bag gelaar. The bridegroom's parents are Arthur G. Milton, president and publisher of The Levittown Tribune, a weekly newspaper, and Mrs. Milton of Westbury. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Joyce of the Church of the Nazarene in Boston. The Rev. John Martin, a Roman Catholic priest of Uniondale, assisted.

title: Braves Sign Kauffman
description: BUFFALO, Aug. 28 (UPI)  Bob Kauffman, who led the Buffalo Braves in scoring, re bounds and assists last year, signed a multiyear contract to day with the National Basket ball Association club. Terms of the pact were not announced. Kauffman, acquired by Buffalo in a trade with the Philadelphia 76ers before last season start ed, averaged 20.4 points in 78 games with the Braves. He grabbed 837 rebounds and had 354 assists.

title: Candidate's Luck Expected to Be a Major Factor in South Vietnamese Parliamentary Elections Today
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28When the 250,000 registered voters in Saigon's First Constituency go to the polls tomorrow to vote for five members of South Vietnam's lower house, they will have 81 candidates to choose from.

title: A New European Man Runs France
description: PARIS.

title: Podgorny May Visit Hanoi
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28 (UPI)President Nikolai V. Podgorny will visit North Vietnam soon, Soviet sources said today. It would be the first official visit to Hanoi by a member of the Soviet leadership since Premier Alexei N. Kosygin attended the funeral of Ho Chi Minh in 1969.

title: Campus Balance Sheet
description: At the start of the academic year, the nation's campus es have moved into a new eraa world removed from the angry spirit of confrontation of the 1960's. Political battles have been superseded by economic fears. Ideo logical conflicts appear muted, overshadowed by bread andbutter issues.

title: How the Daughter of an Ancient Race Made It Out of the Australian Outback By Hitting a Tennis Ball Sweetly and Hard
description: BARELLAN, Australia. IT does not look like a very special place. The friendly peppercorns, alive with the steady burr of a thousand bees, stand sentry over half a dozen car hulks, rusty monuments to the affluence that came with vari ous peach and wheat crops of the nineteenforties and fifties. Beside them is a rectangular patch of bare red earth, surrounded by a wire mesh fence, and inhabited just now by a dozen strolling chickens and three large, bored dogs. Weeds sprout in it and broken bits of furniture litter it, but it is identifiable as a tennis court because of the gappy, timerotted net that drapes across its middle.

title: Pop Festival Disrupted
description: ELEY England, Aug. 28 (AP) A pop festival near here ?? into running fights be tween the police and young people today, leaving dozens injured, two with suspected skull fractures. Fighting appar ently broke out after members of groups known as Hell's An gels set themselves up as an unofficial security force.

title: Fans Could Have Used Gondolas
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 28 Midway through the fourth quarter of today's game be tween the Giants and Philadel phia, the field announcer told the crowd at Palmer Stadium, All major roads in this area are clear.

title: Regal Case, $31.40 Wins
description: DEL MAR, Calif., (AP) Howard Grant guided Regal Case to the lead in the final furlong to defeat Great Career, the favorite, by a head today in the $33,950 Del Mar Derby.

title: THIEU SAYS NATION WILL VOTE OCT. 3 ACCORDING TO PLAN
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 29President Nguyen Van Thieu said this morning that South Vietnam's presidential elections will proceed as scheduled on Oct. 3 even though only he would campaign.

title: Horse Show News
description: The American Horse Shows Association has found five trainers guilty of permitting drugged horses to enter the show ring.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON All across the country during the next few weeks, black children and white childrenand In some areas, other minoritieswill be going to school for the first time with substantial numbers of young sters of another race. And a great many of them will arrive by bus, despite the antibusing outcry by President Nixon, Ala bama Gov. George C. Wallace and a host of other politicians and Save Our Neighborhood School groups.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: When radicals are elected to the hated system
description: BERKELEY, Calif. APROPER perspective on the re cent Berkeley city elections might profitably begin with the statistics that have made the city the street  fighting capital of white radical America. The most diligent riot scorekeeper in town is Mike Culbert, the conservative executive editor of The Berkeley Gazette. Last year before an awed audience of 1,400 law  enforcement officials he presented a body count on the con frontations between radicals and the police in the city for the period June 1968June 1970. During that time, Culbert revealed, there were 23 sepa rate days of street fighting resulting in 2,206 arrests and 1,400 injuries (including 70 to cops); one person was killed and one was blinded. There was a total of five months of stateofemergency decrees from the Governor's office, 20 days of locally imposed curfew and 22 days of occu pation by the National Guard at a total estimated cost of $3.5million. (All of this, it should be pointed out, happened in a city of 120,000 people.)

title: Foreign Notes
description: Today Papadopoulos is strong er than ever before. That was how one Greek politician summed up last Thursday's Cabinet re shuffle by Premier George Papa dopoulos. In the sweeping shake up, the 52yearold former colo nel undercut most of his closest collaborators in the coup d'tat that brought him to power four and a half years ago. For him self he kept the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs.

title: CASTRO SEES FAILURE FOR BOLIVIAN RULERS
description: HAVANA, Aug. 28 (Reuters) Premier Fidel Castro said to day that Bolivia's new Govern ment would not be able to re tain power and the Bolivian people would not stop until they regained lost ground and took power by revolutionary means.

title: ITALIAN'S 4: 00.3 TOPS LIQUORI OVER MILE
description: TORONTO, Aug. 28 (Cana dian Press) Francesco Arese of Italy failed in his attempt to break his country's mile record tonight, but still posted a better time than Marty Liquori of Cedar Grove, N. J., and eight other milers at the Canadian National Exhibition meet.

title: Nixon on Weekend Cruise, Sees Coast Guard Rescue
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)  President Nixon watched a Coast Guard ?? rescue, trolled for marlin ?? went for a swim on a deserted island beach today during a weekend Pacific Ocean cruise aboard a borrowed 85foot motor wacht.

title: PALMER GAINS LEAD IN FALCON REGATTA
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28 John H. Palmer of the host Greenwich Cove Racing Associ ation gained the lead today in the seventh annual Falcon Class International regatta.

title: Man Killed in IND
description: An unidentified man, about 45 years old, was killed yes terday when he apparently jumped in front of a train at the Queens Plaza Station on the IND Jamaica line, the police reported. The police said power was cut off for 35 minutes after the 12:50 P.M. incident to allow rescue crews to remove the body from beneath a Jamaica bound E train. The body was taken to the Queens General Hospital morgue.

title: 6 WHO VISITED CHINA SHUT OUT IN L.I. TEST
description: FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 28More than 200 table tennis players, including six members of the United States team that recently played in China, com peted in the Empire State Table Tennis Championships at the State University here last week end.

title: Camping Boom in Europe
description: PARIS  Two American couples, meeting at a side walk cafe on the Left Bank one recent afternoon, com pared the cost of their Riviera vacations.

title: Reader's Report
description: Something in the insect seems to be alien to the habits, morals, and psychology of this world, as if it has come from some other planet, more monstrous, more energetic, more insensate, more atrocious, more infernal than our own. This observation of Maeterlinck is brought horridly home to a squad of British micronauts soldiers of science who have been miniaturized to quarter inch size in an experiment to beat the population explosion. These four chaps battle ants and centipedes, dine off grilled leg of earwig, and are finally dispatched to Rumania on a mission of microespionage.

title: QUIXOTIC
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Taiwan Wins Little League Final, 12 to 3
description: WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 28 (AP)Taiwan scored nine runs in the ninth Inning today to gain a 123 victory over Gary, Ind., in the Little League World Series championship game.

title: Criminals At Large
description: In most Gothic novels (a form as circumscribed as the cow boy movie or classic ballet) the story ends with a rational explanation of whatever spooks, poltergeists and other phenom ena were used. Somebody has been trying to drive the heiress mad, nine cases out of ten. But in Richard Matheson's HELL HOUSE (Viking, $6.50), the haunted house is really, demon strably haunted. There is a vicious ghost, or series of specters, on hand.

title: While Many Ignore Agony of Bengal
description: Much to her surprise, Mrs. Lawrence Copley Thaw, whose involvement with good causes had been pretty much re stricted to Manhattan and the sedate role of benefit hostess and fundraiser for the International Rescue Commit tee, ended up in Calcutta this summer doing relief work in an area where a disaster had actually struck.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: The replacement cost of automobile windshields has jumped so sharply in the last two years that unless the Administration's price freeze makes it impossible, the in surance industry predicted last week a continuance of what it called the upward trend in the cost of insur ance covering damage to cars.

title: Brewers End Orioles' Skein, 30;
description: BALTIMORE, Aug. 28 (AP) Lew Krausse and Ken Sanders teamed for an eighthitter to night that snapped a Baltimore Oriole winning streak at six games as the Milwaukee Brew ers beat the Orioles, 30, for a split of their doubleheader.

title: Buchanan, an Artist in the Ring, Carves Success by Not Taking Punches
description: GROSSINGER, N. Y.His workout over, Ken Buchanan peeled a tiny patch of adhesive from the bridge of his nose, revealing a small scab.

title: Malaysia and China in Pact
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 28 (AP)The first direct trade agreement between Ma laysia and China was signed to day, raising the possibility of diplomatic ties between the two countries.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ANKARA, TurkeyAmerican rela tions with Turkey have zigzagged up and down over the last quartercen tury. In 1946, after Stalin's Russia demanded cession of two Turkish prov inces and control of the Black Sea Mediterranean straits and the United States rushed the battleship Missouri to Istanbul, there was nothing but love.

title: Percy, Deploring Rift With India, Says U.S. Aid to Pakistan Has Been Exaggerated.
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 28Sen ator Charles H. Percy said to day that current United States military aid to Pakistan was peanuts and expressed dis may that exaggeration of this aid had contributed to the deterioration of relations be tween the United States and India.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: LESS than two weeks after President Nixon's an nouncement of a new economic policy, it had accomplished a primary objective: The upsetting of the Japanese yen. The decision to let the yen float upward in value came Friday after the Japanese float upward in value came Friday after the Japanese Government, which previously had spent $2billion to keep the yen at its relationship of 360 to the dollar, was forced to commit an additional $1.25billion.

title: M.B. A. by Mail
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.At Florida Atlantic University, graduate students of busi ness administration are in their milieu. Conference calls and business flights have superseded ivycovered halls as their classrooms.

title: Chess
description: DR. MAX EUWE, President of the International Chess Federation, stopped off in New York recently on his way to California, where he is to confer with U. S. officials at the annual U. S. Chess Federation business meeting. Questions put to Dr. Euwe by newspapermen in New York centered quite naturally on Bobby Fischer, on the arrangements for the forthcoming final Challengers' match between Fischer and Soviet exworld champion Tigran Petrosian, and on Fischer's chances to win the world title. Dr. Euwe reported that negotiations for the FischerPetrosian match were pro ceeding satisfactorily, although the site had not yet been selected, and said he thought Bobby had an excellent chance of becoming the next champion (6040 on Fischer, was the way he put it).

title: Pop Festival Disrupted
description: ELEY, England, Aug. 28 (AP) A pop festival near here erupted into running fights be tween the police and young people today, leaving dozens injured, two with suspected skull fractures. Fighting appar ently broke out after members of groups known as Hell's An gels set themselves up as an unofficial security force.

title: COLLINSON IS VICTOR IN 2 CLOSE MATCHES
description: ORADELL, N. J., Aug. 28 John Collinson, the medalist, of Navesink, won two close matches to advance to the semifinals of the New Jersey State Golf Association's junior championships today at the Hackensack Golf Club.

title: RIESSEN, BARTHES GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 28Topseeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., and Pierre Barthes of France scored quar terfinal victories today in the $25,000 Eastern grass courts championships, forced indoors by wet grounds to the West Orange Tennis Club.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS, CHIEFS IN FINALE TONIGHT
description: The New York Cosmos and the Atlantic Chiefs will meet at Yankee Stadium tonight in the last regularseason contest for both clubs, before they engage in a twoofthree North Ameri can Soccer League playoff se ries starting Thursday night in Atlanta.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Joe Pye's Weed
description: The morning mists of late August swirl and eddy, and the shades of the old herb doctors may be there, espe cially of Joe Pye, who would be appraising the crop of wild herbs at the river's margin and back at the pasture's uncut fence line. His namesake plant, which the botanists label eupatorium purpureum, is in full blossom in the damp lowlands, magentared and unmistakable. Not far off are its cousin plants, boneset and thoroughwort, and at the edge of the woodland is the froth of snowy snake root, all with their descriptive common names.

title: National Notes
description: In the wake of a series of similar revelations over the last few months, the fact that another food product was contaminated hardly came as a surprise. The story behind the fact, however, set many a souplover shivering.

title: Gleason Drops Candidacy For Manhattan Surrogate
description: Thomas W. Gleason Jr. has agreed to accept a Board of Elections decision that removed him from the race for Demo cratic nomination for New York County Surrogate.

title: FARMERS EXPECT BUMPER HARVEST
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28  Most Midwestern farmers were enter taining themselves this week at state fairs without more than the usual worries as fore casters predicted the largest corn and soybean crops on record.

title: College Football Rule Revisions Are Aimed to Reduce Leg Injuries
description: College football rules have undergone no major changes since last season although the National Collegiate Ath letic Association football rules committee indicated a growing concern over knee and ankle injuries in making some revisions for the com ing season.

title: New Feeder Airlines Serve Small Towns
description: MILWAUKEESix years ago, 15 Green Bay, Wis., business men, faced with the loss of their last remaining air link to the outside world, put up $100, 000 and started Air Wisconsin.

title: The Seaweed Bikini, or, My Day at a California Nudist Beach
description: CARPINTERIA, Calif.The instructions I had got ten sounded pretty simple. Exit 83 miles north of the Los Angeles Civic Center on U.S. High way 101 about three miles past Santa Claus Lane in Carpinteria. Turn right, then left. Park. Walk down a little trail to Sharks' Cove Free Beach.

title: Anne Palmer Wed to John Strother
description: MOORESTOWN, N. J., Aug. 28The marriage of Miss Anne Rice Palmer to John Frederick Strother, an associate with the New York law firm of Breed, Abbot & Morgan, took place here this afternon.

title: Amtrak Takes Over Public Information On Railroad Service
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) Amtrak, the new quasipublic corporation that runs the na tion's passenger trains, has clamped down on railroads re porting how their trains are doing.

title: Bengals Edge Cards, 2221
description: CINCINNATI, Aug. 28 (AP) Virgil Carter hit Eric Crab tree with an 11yard touch down pass in the last two minutes and Horst Muhlmann kicked five field goals to power the Cincinnati Bengals to their fourth straight National Foot ball League exhibition victory, 2221, over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: City Proposes a Steeper Glide Path for Jet Liners
description: In a move to reduce noise made by jet liners landing at La Guardia and Kennedy Inter national Airports, the city has asked the Federal Government to approve steeper descents.

title: South Carolina Poll Rates Muskie First And Lindsay Second
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 28 A presidential preference poll among South Carolina county officials has shown surprising strength for Mayor Lindsay of New York.

title: Bridgeport Completes Staff
description: The University of Bridgeport completed its football coaching staff for the 1971 season with the addition of Steve Bognar, a former Boston University all New England lineman, and Pete Diatelevi to Head Coach Ed Farrell's corp of assistants. Rich Benat, one of the leading ground gainers on last year's club, and Bob Harrison, the school's career leader in pass receptions in a single season, will be student assistants.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors are aware of the growing promotional effort of the Postal Service to in crease its businessmainly from philatelists, but hope fully with the intent of creating more stamp col lectors. As of July 1, the Postal Service took over the United States mails from the Post Office Department as a quasigovernment corpora tion, not directly answerable to the Congress for rates, but still dependent upon it for financial support until, hope fully, it can turn its heavily redinked ledgers to less eye straining black ink entries.

title: Bridge Flash Lamprey's coup
description: A DECLARER at the bridge table must sometimes ask himself, like Macbeth, Can such things be? He can often conclude that some thing is impossibleassum ing that the opponents are not beginnersand guide his play accordingly.

title: PARASITIC?
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: GONE FOREVER
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Elizabeth Nicholson Maine Bride
description: CASTINE, Me., Aug. 28 Miss Elizabeth Stokes Nichol son, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Nicholson 3d of Moorestown, N. J., and Cas tine, was married here this afternoon to Howland Wilson Abramson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold A. Abramson of Cold Spring Harbor, L. I.

title: Athletics Vanquish Senators, 106, as Bando's Grand Slain Breaks Game Open.
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 28 (UPI)Sal Bando, back in the lineup after missing three games because of an injury, drove in five runs with his fourth career grand slam and a single today as the Oakland A's routed the Washington Senators, 106.

title: Lisa P. Bergfeld Stamford Bride Of David Soleau
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 28Miss Lisa Pennock Berg feld, assistant to the dean at Branford College at Yale Uni versity, was married here this morning to David Scott Soleau, a Yale senior.

title: A Predicted Downpour Banished by Fair Skies
description: New Yorkers who had been warned by the weather man to prepare for another torrential downpour yester day morning were baffled when they woke up to balmy blue skies with fluffy clouds.

title: MANSFIELD TO PUSH TROOP CUT IN EUROPE
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 28 Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana said today that he would sponsor legislation at the next session of Congress requir ing President Nixon to reduce United States forces in Europe by 50,000 a year.

title: Patricia Deere Glover Bride of Dr. Ian Ramsey
description: Miss Patricia Deere Glover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Coleman Glover of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married in London yesterday to Dr. Ian Douglas Ramsay, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Alexander Ramsey of Barnham, West Sussex, England. The Rev. Edward Thompson performed the Anglican ceremony in the Church of St. MaryleStrand.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Broader Economic Philosophy
description: President Nixon's new economic policy has scored its first solid victory on the international front with the announcement by the Japanese Government that it would float the yen.

title: McNairs Take Net Title
description: MIDDLETON, Mass., Aug. 28 (AP)Fred McNair Sr. and Jr. won the national father and son tennis championship by up setting topseeded Chauncey Steele Jr. and Chauncey 3d of Cambridge, 119, 62, at the Northeast Indoor Tennis Center today.

title: Council Relaxes Rule on Auto Prices
description: is charged with investigating, has found many of the com plaints to be erroneous.

title: A personal journal, a regional history, the biography of a house
description: Although it has not always loomed as one of the major themes of his work, there is a deep and abiding strain of family piety in the writings of Edmund Wilson. It makes itself felt with particular force in those autobiographical evocations of the world of his youththe world of his parents and his teacherswhich re cur throughout his books and consti tute some of his very best writing. It gives to his sense of history, espe cially American history, both its special tone of elegiac regret and its sharp feeling of personal involve ment. It forms, moreover, the essen tial background to the recital of ex asperations and distaste which has come in recent years to dominate Wilson's accounts of his forays into contemporary life.

title: Stewart K. Materne Jr. Weds Miss Stuart McLendon
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 28Miss Stuart Telfair Mc Lendon and Stewart Kirk Materne Jr. were married here this afternoon. The bride is with the Chemical Bank in New York, where Mr. Ma terne is with the municipal bond department of the Mor gan Guaranty Trust Com pany.

title: For Young Readers: The historical Arthur, what there is of him
description: Unfortunately both Joseph P. Clancy's Pendragon and Geoffrey Ashe's King Arthur suffer by com parison with each other. Taken to gether they make an excellent book for young readers.

title: TENNIS TEACHERS TO CONVENE HERE
description: Tennis leaders across the country will converge on New York Labor Day weekend for the first national tennis teach ers conference at the Roosevelt Hotel and Vanderbilt Racquet Club. The conference coincides with the United States Open championships at Forest Hills. The conference is sponsored by the Tennis Institute to further the development of effective group teaching techniques.

title: Morelon Wins Title Cycling
description: VARESE, Italy, Aug. 28 (UPI) Daniel Morelon of France to night won the amateur sprint title at the world cycling cham pionships when he defeated Sergei Kratsov of the Soviet Union in straight rides. Kratsov caused an upset in the semi final when he eliminated More lon's teammate, Gerard Quin tyn, in three rides.

title: NIXON BACKS AIDE IN STOCK SCANDAL
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28The White House voiced confidence today that Will R. Wilson, Assistant Attorney Gen eral in charge of the Justice Department's Criminal Division, had acted properly in securing a $30,000 interestfree loan last year from the central figure in a Texas stock manipulation scandal.

title: Tourists Profitable to France
description: PARIS, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Foreign tourists in France last year spent $25million more than French tourists abroad, Marcel Anthonioz, Secretary of State for Tourism, has reported.

title: For Japan, a Temporary Setback
description: TOKYO As Japanese in dustry begins to assess its problems and options in the face of changed United States trade policy, it appears that Japanese exports to the United States may not be reduced and may indeed increase. It is rather clear in any event that the policy is unlikely to bring about a permanent re duction in Japan's export ability and may reinforce trends that are making for Japan's extraordinary gains in productivity.

title: N.A.I.A. Rules Out Basketball Dunking For '71'72 Season
description: The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics execu tive committee has voted to dis continue the use of the dunk rule for the 197172 basket ball season.

title: Faust let his oldyoung Willy sing, yawp and growl
description: Not very often since Whitman has our great Manhattan been celebrated with such love, gusto, comprehensive tolerance, andto come at once to the heart of the matterfully achieved art as in Irvin Faust's new novel. Our cit plein des rves, dreaming necessarily the avid dreams of industrial folklore that it recycles for the whole republic, Man hattan is itself the patriot's dream we sing about in better and worse songs than America the Beautiful.

title: 3 INDIAN HOMERS DOWN TWINS, 98
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 28 (AP) Ray Fosse belted a grandslam homer, Vada Pinson connected for a threerun shot and John Lowenstein smacked a tworun homer in powering the Cleve land Indians to 98 victory over the Minnesota Twins today.

title: RIPON STUDY SEES LOSSES IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The assistant Senate Repub lican leader, Robert P. Griffin of Michigan, and three of his party colleagues will lose their seats next year while only one incumbent Democrat will he de feated, a liberal Republican group predicts.

title: Reader's Report
description: Shifting gears from third to first person, and maintaining the action edgily in the present tense, F. X. Mathews keeps his gothic parable teetering on the brink of hysteria. A lonely 12 yearold, burdened with neur asthenia and sexual fanta sies, the boy lives with his parents and a girl cousin in the basement of his grand mother's house in a Maine vil lage. I love angels he re flects, angels are everywhere. Especially in his parish church, where he fancies that one gypsum seraph is shedding real tears.

title: James H. Kitler, Engineer, Marries Marilyn Sherman
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 28  Miss Marilyn Nancy Sherman, daughter of the Right Rev. and Mrs. Jonathan G. Sherman of Garden City, L. I., was married here today to James Harrington Kitler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Daniel Kitler of Norristown, Pa., in the First Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Donald L. Miner performed the cere mony.

title: DROP IN TOURISM HITS MIAMI BEACH
description: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 28 Serious concern over a steady decline in tourist trade per vades this resort city where only a few years ago success in the hotel business used to be commonplace.

title: FORDHAM'S ELEVEN DRILLS TOMORROW
description: Fordham's head football coach, James S. Lansing, will welcome about 73 candidates the largest number in 20 yearswhen varsity football camp opens on the Rose Hill campus tomorrow morning. The camp will mark the offi cial opening of Fordham's 91st year of intercollegiate football.

title: Daughter to the Golds
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Arnold P. Gold of Englewood, N. J., on Aug. 7 in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia  Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: Hickman Back on Duty
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP)A first basemanoutfielder, Ramon Webster, was assigned to Ta coma of the Pacific Coast League by the Chicago Cubs today to make room for Jim Hickman, restored to the roster after 15 days on the disabled list.

title: SpanishSpeaking Priests Seeking Hispanic Center
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 28  PA DRES, a national coalition of Spanishspeaking Roman Cath olic priests, based in San An tonio, Tex., is taking initial steps toward its first concrete project: establishing a national Hispanic cultural center.

title: COLOMBIA'S LEFT GREETS ALLENDE
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 28 Carlos Alberto Caldern spent two hours this morning holding up one end of a long, red ban ner outside the International Airport in Bogota. The banner read:

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: CALDER RACE WON BY I'M ADORABLE
description: MIAMI, Aug. 28 (AP)I'm Adorable, closing with a rush, won the $7,500added Viscaya Handicap at Calder Race Course today as the heavily favored, entry of Bolibhai and Pharaday finished second and third, re spectively. Taint was fourth.

title: Susan Ayres Wed to Henry Noble
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Aug. 28 Miss Susan Emery Ayres, daughter of C. Burgess Ayres, headmaster of the Gunnery, and Mrs. Ayres, was married here today to Henry George Stebbins Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. S. Noble of New Canaan. His father is a partner in Carlisle DeCoppet & Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange ?? copal ceremony was perfom ed in the Meeting House on the Green by the Rev. Wil liam P. Scheel, assisted by, the Rev. Haig Nargesian.

title: Concert in Queens
description: A program of Latin American and Latin American  inspired music will be presented at 3 P.M. today at the Music Grove in Forest Park, Queens. The Seuffert Band, conducted by George F. Seuffert, will dedi cate its program to the John F. Kennedy Library for Minori ties. The concert is sponsored by the Rheingold Breweries.

title: Canoeists Navigate Hell Gate Successfully and Finish Third Day at South Street
description: After successfully navigat ing the treacherous waters of Hell Gate, the six men who are canoeing New York City waters pulled in late yester day afternoon to set up their third night's camp at the South Street Sport Museum in lower Manhattan.

title: Chad Breaks Libyan Ties, Charging a Coup Attempt
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, Aug. 28 (AP)  Chad broke relations with Libya today following what it called a foreign directed attempt to overthrow the Government of President Franois Tombalbaye. Few de tails were being reported by of ficials here pending the out come of an investigation.

title: STRIKE OUT, A PACER, WIN RICH FOX STAKE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 28 (UPIStrike Out, two drivers guiding his fortunes, won both heats in the $68,619 Fox State for 2yearold pacers in the final session of harness races at the Indiana State Fair.

title: Art
description: THE recent announcement that the Jewish Museum intends to return to its earlier policy of emphasizing exhibits of Jewish interest rather than those dealing with radical forms of contemporary art has brought a strongly divided reaction from the public. The comments boil down to two positions.

title: Music
description: AS a longtime member of Columbia University's Music Department and, because of my retirement in 1970, not involved in the vote on Mr. Wuorinen's tenure, perhaps I may be permitted to reflect on his sweeping charges directed at this great university. Mr. Wuorinen prefaces his article with a disclaimer: it is not his individual case that rankles; he cites it only as a typical illustration of the inhumanity of a large bureaucratized educational organ, hostile to and callous about the arts. Yet this is an individual case indeed.

title: Marianne E. Visson Married in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 Miss Marianne Elizabeth Vis son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anatole Visson, was Married here this afternoon to Thom as Robert Jacka, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Jacka of Northport, L. I.

title: Miss Cleary Bride Of W. A. Durbin Jr.
description: POMPTON LAKES, N. J., Aug. 28  Miss Christine Margaret Cleary and William Anthony Durbin Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. James Kelly performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: L. I. Team Building Safety Car for U. S.
description: FARMINGDALE, L. I., Aug. 28A group of men in the corner of the Fairchild Hiller Corporation's vast Republic Di vision plant here are at work in an attempt to design and build two brandnew, built fromthegroundup automobiles by Christmas Eve.

title: Miss deCamp Bride in Jersey
description: MANTOLOKING, N. J., Aug. 28In St. SimonbytheSea Episcopal Church here this afternoon, Miss Margo Oliver de Camp and Douglas Robert Peacock, students at the University of Vermont, were married by the Rev. Richard Andersen.

title: Indians Say Trust in Nixon is Shaken
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The National Congress of American Indians said today that the confidence of Indian people in the Nixon Administra tion had been shaken by re cent actions of the Department of the Interior, including changes in the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

title: South's Schools to Open With More Integration and Less Tension
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 28Despite renewed controversy over bus ing, the public schools of the South are opening this year with more integration and less tension than ever before.

title: Uganda Accuses Tanzania In New Shooting at Border
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 28 (Reuters)  Tanzanian troops opened fire on Ugandan border positions for the second day in a row today, President Idi Amin of Uganda said.

title: City Voter Registration Will Close Tomorrow
description: Those who wish to vote in the Nov. 2 general election must register by tomorrow or during the special local registration period on Sept. 30, Oct. 1 and 2.

title: Louisa Wyeth Bride Of Christopher Peters
description: KATONAH, N.Y., Aug. 28  Miss Louisa Coffin Wyeth, a student at Boston Univer sity, was married here at noon today to Christopher Brooks Peters, who attends Harvard University. The Rev. Philip McNairy of St. Mat thew's Episcopal Church in Bedford performed the cere mony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Marion Sims Wyeth Jr. The bridegroom is a son of Mrs. Philip Farley of New York and Brooks Peters of Dublin.

title: Alfred Wyler, President Of Watch Company, Dead
description: RYE, N. Y., Aug. 28Alfred Wyler, founder and president of the Wyler Watch Corpora tion, died yesterday at his home on Beverly Road. He was 71 years old.

title: Stoke City Registers 10 Soccer Victory Over Arsenal on Goal by Ritchie
description: LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) Arsenal, seemingly unbeat able when it clinched the Eng lish League and Cup soccer double last season, suffered its third successive defeat today by losing to Stoke City, 10.

title: CathyCalhoun, 13, Clips Swim Mark; Spitz Wins 4th Title
description: HOUSTON, Aug: 28 Thir teenyearold Cathy Calhoun set a world record in the women's 1,500meter freeStyle and Mark Spitz won his fourth title to night in finals of the National Amateur Athletic Union swim ming championships.

title: The World
description: LA PAZ, BoliviaThe Bolivian Army revolt that raised an anti Communist Government to power here last week is similar in ori gin and spirit to the Brazilian military takeover of 1964.

title: Bartholomew and Hagedorn Top Ecthells22 Class in Breezy Race Week Sail
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 28Tropical storm Doria left choppy swells on Long Island Sound today, but 200 skippers were treated to some excellent sailing conditions in the third race of Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 39th annual Race Week.

title: CORRECTION SETUP OF STATE ASSAILED
description: The state's correction system Is in such disrepair, the ranking Democrat on the State Senate Finance Committee said yester day, that the term correction has become ludicrous and the expenditure of funds for arrest ing, prosecuting and convicting criminals is wasted.

title: COUNCIL TO ALLOW CAR PRICES TO TOP AUGUST DISCOUNTS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Cost of Living Council, in its latest move in President Nixon's program to bolster the econ omy, announced today how it will enforce controls over prices and wages that fluctuate sea sonally.

title: News of Dogs
description: For nearly a quarter of a century the dominant figure in the British dog show world has been Air Commodore J.A.C. CecilWright. Last Fri day, he was 85 years old and The Kennel Club, which he heads, staged a dinner to celebrate the occasion.

title: FRENCH ATHLETES CRITICAL OF COACH
description: PARIS, Aug. 28 (UPI)Trip ping over hurdles, dropping batons and missing markers, the French sometimes looked more like clowns than athletes at the. European track and field championships in Helinski. Now, the circus over, comes the reckoning.

title: Make mine falafel
description: Greekinspired souvlakia shops seem to have conquered the streets of Manhattan in just a few months. Literally translated, souvlakia are tidbits on a skewer. Although the Greeks have the name for it, the tidbits come from all over the Middle Eastfalafel, those spicy chickpea balls from Israel, lamb kebabs and highly seasoned lamb patties. They're served tucked into a pocket of Arab flat breadas easy to handle as their American cousins, the hot dog and the hamburger.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Congratulations and thanks for spreading the word about the need for city trees. [A HalfMillion Street Trees and More on the Way, Aug. 15.] Trees are our first line of defense against air contam ination, heat and noise. Turn into a treelined block or walk under a canopy of leaves and, instantly, you feel better. Why? Aside from the obvious aesthetic and property economic value of trees, they are the prototype airconditioners.

title: Sometimes Coaches Move Better Than Their Offenses
description: The ranks of college foot ball coaches, never known for stability, have undergone wholesale changes since last fall. More than a quarter of the 118 socalled major college teams have new men at the helm.

title: Miss Elizabeth Nichols Affianced
description: SYOSSET, L. I., Aug. 28 Mr. and Mrs. John Slocum Nichols of Laurel Hollow have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Jarvis Nich ols, to Richard Hershey Troy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Troy of Melrose, Mass. The wedding has been planned for Oct. 2.

title: 4,000 Fans Brave Doria to Hear 10th Philadelphia Folk Festival
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 28The tropi cal storm called Doria up staged all the other performers last night at the opening ses sion of the 10th annual Phila delphia Folk Festiyal on a 100 acre plot of land near Schwenks ville, midway between Phila delphia and Reading.

title: Shakespeare's World: A Stage for Study
description: VANCOUVER, British Co lumbia, Aug. 27After more than 300 years of study, one might have thought the works of William Shakespeare had just about been exhausted by scholars. Prof. T. J. B. Spencer of the Shakespeare Institute in England asked rhetorically here the other day, What more is there to do with Shakespeare?

title: Reinaldo Arenas was obviously taken with the pcaro
description: To the gallery of enduring uni versal types, the Spanish literary tra dition has contributed the pcaro, that roguish wanderer as untrappable as wind who outwits a wicked world that would enchain his very uvula. Reinaldo Arenas, a young Cuban author obviously taken with this figure of untrammeled freedom as Latin America's only hope of au thentic liberation, has chosen as the hero of his Hallucinations an amazing reallife adventurer: Father Servando Teresa de Mier.

title: FILMED TESTS DUE FOR DRUNK DRIVERS
description: The police will videotape sus pected drunk drivers in Queens starting Oct. 28 in a $42,000 Federally aided project designed to raise the conviction rate of suspected offenders.

title: Queens Lakes Delight Children and Irk Adults
description: Flooded streets, uprooted trees, snapped telephone and power lines marked many sec tions of Queens yesterday in the wake of the nearhurricane rain and winds that swept the city from Friday until early yes terday morning.

title: Caryn P. Cluett Becomes Bride Of R. P. Gregg
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28Christ Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Caryn Prudden Cluett to Robert Powell Gregg. The Right Rev. Nelson Burroughs, retired Bishop of Ohio and greatuncle of the bride, per formed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Seymour Flinn.

title: PRINCIPAL BEGINS TASK IN BROOKLYN
description: The first Puerto Rican to head a senior high school in New York City said last week that he intended to be a principal out in the com munity. rather than in the building or the office.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: An outstanding season is predicted for handbags, domestic and imported, and the import surcharge will have no serious effect.

title: The World
description: SAIGON  Perhaps success for the scenario written by American officials for the dra ma of Presidential elections here this October was too much to ex pect from the outset.

title: Soviet Arms to Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Lebanon will buy arms from the Soviet Union for the first time under a $52.7 million, fiveyear defense plan approved by Parliament on Thursday, the Communist news paper, AlNidaa, reported here today, quoting Dr. Elias Saba, Lebanon's Acting Defense Min ister.

title: Connally Feels Economy Will Keep Some Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 The second most influential man in the Nixon Administra tion leaned forward in his chair, took a small bite from the end of an unlit cigar, and said:

title: MAGAZINE DEALER GIVEN 30 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  An acknowledged homosexual, whose right to deal in maga zines aimed at male homosex ual preferences was supported by the Supreme Court twice, has been sentenced to 30 months to seven and a half years in prison for interstate transportation and mailing of obscene materials.

title: Coins
description: THE New Orleans booth at the American Num ismatic Association's 80th anniversary con vention in Washington never had a dull moment. The rea son: the historic old city will be host for the big show in 1972 and dealers, ANA dele gates and other visitors kept Louisiana's representatives busy answering questions on the city's plans for next year.

title: Miss Judith A. Havens Married
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 28 Miss Judith Ann Havens and John Kilburn Bullard were married here this after noon.

title: Old dreams and failures, new hopes and adventures
description: In the town I come from there lives a man I cannot speak to. The reason escapes me. Vaguely it con cerns an incident of long ago be tween this man and my father, a word or deed or misunderstanding that perhaps occurred not in the New Jersey place of my birth but rather in the. small Italian village from which both men had emigrated to America after World War I. It is also possible that the source of their discord extends beyond even them, having originated with their fathers or grandfathers. I do not know. All that I am sure of is that as a boy growing up on an island near the southern tip of New Jersey I was aware of ill feeling between this man and my father, their conspicuous silence as they passed on the street; and without seeking an explanation I understood it, felt it and accepted it as enmity from the old country.

title: Recordings
description: HE is not your runof themill rock star. No groupies cluster out side his door try ing to find excuses to get inside; no Englishaccented managers cluck about in con cerned overprotectiveness. Randy Newman, as a matter of fact, sitting in his room at the St. Moritz last week, a slightly paunchy, owlish 27 yearold, dressed in a butter flybedecked Tshirt, looked and sounded very much like the antithesis of a rock star.

title: Harrelson to Receive Tryout for P.G.A. Tour
description: Ken Harrelson, the former baseball player, and the last three United States Amateur champions are among the record 357 applicants seek ing playing credentials this year on the Professional Golfers' Association tour.

title: Barefoot Baedeker's Guide To Enclaves on Fire Island
description: FIRE ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 28 They share the same slender streak of sandthe same pristine seashore, marshy bay and salt wind but the 18 main communi ties of Fire Island are little islands unto themselves.

title: This is the way the world should be
description: Critics of the big cities, New York in particular, become more and more numerous and more and more vo ciferous. The latest recruit, on the other hand, Anthony Bailey, turns out to be one of the quietestand one of the most persuasive. So far as In the Village is concerned, his criticism of the cities is implied rather than stated, but he makes his case.

title: Et A1.
description: A shrewd and wellre searched analysis of Hitler as soldier. While the focus is on Hitler's strategieswhich, of course, were accepted by the puppet General Staff and shaped Germany's warMr. Strawson also discusses Allied planning. Especially interest ing is his, portrait of Stalin, who ruled with a similar, and perhaps even stronger, hand. Hitler gets credit for his suc cesses in 1940 and his assess ment of France's vulnerability, as well as his adoption of new methods in warfare. Finally, Hitler overextended himself and, as the war worsened, be came isolated from the facts and mentally unstable. The material is familiar, but Straw son writes clearly and judici ously.

title: The Catch in the Hatch Isn't What It Used to Be
description: PROVINCETOWN, at the tip of Cape Cod, is widely known as a summer haven for artists, hippies and the like. It has also been more prosaically designated, by the Federal Government, an economically distressed area. Of its yearround population of 3,000, at last report 400 were on welfare. Historically, most of whatever money does circu late in Provincetown has come from tourism and fishing. This hasn't been a banner season for either. There are plenty of Vacancy signs at the motels that fringe Cape Cod Bay, and the fishing business has been in the doldrums throughout New England. In the last decade, the number of commercial fishing boats regularly working out of Boston, for instance, has dwindled from more than 100 to 31, and the total annual catch there from 110 million pounds to 32 mil lion. But Boston has other resources to sustain it, and Provincetown, by and large, has only its fish and its tourists.

title: LEPRECHAUN WINS ETCHELLS22 RACE
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 28A forecast of high winds scared all but 16 skippers from Long Island Sound today when the Etchells22 class conducted the season's 30th Yacht Racing Association championship gatta. But the breeze was only 15 knots, southwesterly, and those who did venture out en joyed good racing.

title: RAIDERS TURN BACK FUMBLING PACKERS
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 28 (AP)Daryle Lamonica, in his first appearance of the year, passed 58 yards to Drew Buie for a touchdown and set up 32yard George Blanda field goal with three other passes tonight in leading the Oakland Raiders to a 1713 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Crystals: A Little Known Industry in Ferment
description: Computers harnessed to special furnaces at I.B.M.'s East Fishkill plant in the lower Hudson Valley are growing silicon crystal in gots in assemblyline fashion. After processing, millions of integrated circuit chips made from these computergrown crystals become the heart of the company's newest series of data processors.

title: Many Broken Hammers
description: Mr. Covin's novel is built around the attempt of some Spanishspeaking Americans to repossess, land granted to the conquistadores and later ex propriated by AngloSaxon emigrants to the Southwest. Ranged on the two sides of this retroactive approach to land reform are Good Guys and Bad Guys. Good Guys are poor MexicanAmericans looking for an even break, led by a mes sianic revolutionary. Bad Guys are fatcat ranchers and the gringo Establishment. Caught in the crossfire is a nice Spanish American sheriff, Miguel Fres quez, who tries to administer. law and order with common sense.

title: Totalitarianism is bad, nihilism is worse
description: Eugene D. Genovese belongs to that curious group of uncommitted committed who, while eschewing the narrow considerations of ideology, insist upon interpreting affairs ac cording to Marxist dialectics. He is firmly committed to the premise that class antagonism is the motor force of history, and these essays, largely are written in defense of this asser tion. With Henri LeFebvre, Genovese would argue that since the signifi cance of the class war is changing, the old dogmatism will no longer convince; and, like LeFebvre, he is sanguine that ultimately dialectics will win the day.

title: 31 Feared Dead as Jet Crashes Off Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sunday, Aug. 29 (AP)A Hungarian airliner crashed and broke apart last night in shallow water short of a Co penhagen airport runway, killing at least 12 of the 34 persons aboard.

title: SCHOOL BUS PACTS COME UNDER FIRE
description: Two members of the City Council charged yesterday that there were irregularities in the Board of Education's bidding procedures on school bus con tracts and called for an investi gation.

title: DEAN FFRENCH BEYTAGH
description: For almost a month the Anglican Dean of Johannesburg, the Very Rev. Gonville ffrenchBeytagh, has been on trial in Jo hannesburg for alleged ly plotting the violent overthrow of the South African Government, whose apartheid race policies he opposes. During that time the evidence has suggested that Allison Norman, 37, niece of the late Montagu Norman, for mer Governor of Bank of England and a leg endary figure in the world of high finance, supplied the dean with money for illegal or ganizations. Miss Nor man lives in London; so, last Monday, on the prosecution's request, the trial was adjourned until Sept. 7 so that testimony could be taken in London from her and five other witnesses.

title: Sharon A. Kane, Paul Korody Jr. Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Conn., Aug. 28 Miss Sharon Ann Kane and Paul Alexander Korody Jr. were married here this morn ing by the Rev. Bernard R. McIlhenney of Scranton, Pa., in the Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church.

title: I believe we will survive. That is our dream.
