description: Hymn to Peace

title: Polo Match at Bethoage Free to Children Under 12
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Aug. 28  Children under 12 years of age and accompanied by adults will be admitted free to tomorrow's polo match at Bethpage State Park.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: The week's mail was con fusing, to say the least.

title: Concord Golf Put Off Again As Storm Floods Fairways
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 28For the second suc cessive day play in the $60,000 Liggett & MyersConcord open golf tournament was postponed in the aftermath of the severe rain storm that swept the East ern Seabord the last 48 hours.

title: Foley's Folly Finishes First
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y. Aug. 28 (AP)Foley's Folly scored a 2length victory over Count Your Pennies today in the New York Breeders' Juvenile Fillies Stake at Finger Lakes. David Zambrana rode the 2yearold over the six furlongs in 1:15 45 for a payoff of $8.20 for $2.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT continued in July for fourth con secutive month. Imports exceeded exports by $304.1mil lion, slightly below deficit in June but more than in April and May.  Chemical Bank reduced interest charges on consumer loans and home mortgages.

title: Miss Markley Fiancee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Rodney W. Markley Jr., vice president of the Ford Motor Company, Washington Staff, and Mrs. Markley have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Cornick Markley, to James Monroe Williams Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jethro Henry Brooks of Solebury, Pa. Miss Markley is a graduate of the Sidwell Friends School in Washington and the Univer sity of Miami. Her fianc, a graduate of Blair Academy and the University of Vir ginia, is president of Graphic Consultants, Inc., in Alex andria, Va.

title: Television
description: TELEVISION has presented several be hindthescenes documentaries about the inner workings of our establish ments  the Pentagon, the welfare system, the fashion industrybut it has never done an indepth probe of baseball.

title: Garelik Suggests Police Unit to Fight Construction Theft
description: City Council President San ford Garelik called yesterday for the creation of a special police unit to help cut down on thefts of material and equip ment from construction sites in the city, which he estimated at $50million a year.

title: Brenda Christine Langdon Bride
description: HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 28Miss Brenda Christine Langdon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Kenneth Langdon of Fredericton, New Bruns wick, Canada, was married here today to Robert Thomas Phillips. Melvin Grupp, leader of the Queens Ethical Culture Society, performed the cere mony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Phillips 3d, parents of the bridegroom.

title: The Pentagon Blocks Arms Pact
description: A ban on worldwide nuclear testing by the Soviets and the United States is essential to a halt in the arms race among the superpowers. Nevertheless, testimony before the Senate subcom mittee on arms control has revealed that forces within the Pentagon are still blocking any serious attempts to reach this agreement with the Soviets.

title: Et A1.
description: A psychologist's hopelessly generalized and overambitious version of Learning From the Past. Specifically correcting modern psychological aptitude tests and values by applying lessons from the Greeks, the Middle Ages and the Renais sance (from the Greeks we get excellence, from the Renaissance the Renaissance spirit, etc.) . Psychology meets New School Cultural History in a sophomore classroom.

title: Miss Welles Wed to Actor
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 28The marriage of Miss Parmelee Welles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward O. Welles of Washington, to James Stewart Tolkan, an actor appearing in The Basic Training of Pavlo Hum mel at the Public Theater in New York, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. William Hayes performed the ceremony St. Eustace Episcopal Church.

title: LESLIE FELEKY
description: Leslie Feleky, a composer, pianist and arranger, died here Friday night of a heart attack. He was 59 years old and lived at 136 East 55th Street.

title: SAIGON REPORTS PREVOTING RAIDS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28 (AP)South Vienam ese headquarters reported to day that at least seven persons Were wounded and two Roman Catholic priests were kidnapped in 24 enemy attacks on the eve of elections for a new National Assembly.

title: Country Romeo Wins Sprint
description: STANTON, Del., Aug. 28 (AP) Joseph Kaplowitz's Country Romeo, an entry with Mrs. Samuel Pistorio's Stray Shell, outran eight other sprinters in today's feature at Delaware Park.

title: Dance
description: ONCE everyone  art ists and audiences both understood clearly the function of narra tive in ballet. Narrative was those little bits that glued the dancing together and sonietimes even influenced it. The hero would perhaps perform some hapless and charming dumb show for the heroine; she would then rise up onto her pointes and tear off a solo that would be a kind of emotional gloss on the resultant changes in her sit uation  or plight, as it was more likely to be. The for mat is similar to that of opera with its alternation of reci tative and aria. Whatever the story of the ballet might be, it had to offer good oppor tunities for dancing, and, come to think of it, this may be one of the reasons why so Many of the early ballet libretti involved royalty: they could always give a ball.

title: Luther of U.S. and Miss Gonzalez of Puerto Rico Win Titles in World Bowling
description: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28 (AP) Ed Luther of Racine, Wis., and Ashie Gonzalez of San Juan, Puerto Rico, captured in dividual titles today in the Seventh World bowling cham pionships.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: When the 1971 United States Open Tennis Cham pionships begin Wednesday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, many corporations will sym bolically step onto center court along with the players.

title: We Were Just Lousy, Says Angry Tarkenton After Giants Loss to Eagles
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 28 After listening to Fran Tarken ton and Alex Webster appraise the football team they quarter back and coach, one might get the idea they've been watching two different teams the past month. Maybe that's one of the Giants' problems.

title: L.I.U. to Study TV Use To Fight Air Pollution
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Aug. 28 Dr. Anthony Uzzo, as sociate professor of marine science at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island Uni versity, will conduct a feasi bility study on the use of television to monitor air pol luters.

title: Questions on the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28Following is the ninth set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on prices and wages:

title: McGrath Will Testify First On Deaths in City Prisons
description: Commissioner of Correction George F. McGrath is the first witness scheduled to testify at twoday hearings on the inci dence of death and suicide in city prisons, William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the City Board of Corrections, an nounced yesterday. He said Mr. McGrath would appear at 9:30 A.M. Tuesday at the New York County Lawyers' Association, 14 Vesey Street.

title: Miss Sarah Stever Married To Douglas William Marshall
description: RANDOLPH, N. K, Aug. 28  Miss Sarah Newell Stever, daughter of Dr. Hor ton Guyford Stever, president of Carnegie  Mellon Univer sity, and Mrs. Stever of Pitts burgh and Randolph, was married in the Randolph Church this afternoon to Douglas William Marshall, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Pryor Marshall of Kalamazoo, Mich. The Rev. Dr. Stephen Trowbridge Crary performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Music
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Solution Nears in Fight On Brooklyn Day Care
description: A ?? dispute in volving changes of racism and bureaucratic bungling continues to simmer in north eastern Brooklyn over the construction of a daycare center in a largely white neighborhood.

title: Sparkman, Taylor Victors In EastofRye Regatta
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28 Palmer Sparkman, sailing the Soling sloop, Lulu, and George H. Taylor, in the Flying Scot, Sea Cup, won races today in the season's 33d Yacht Racing Association championship re gatta for fleets based east of Rye.

title: Barbara Gene Lyng Wed
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Aug. 28 Miss Barbara Gene Lyng, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Henry Lyng of Westfield, was married this afternoon to Richard John Baroody Jr. at the Westfield Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Frederick E. Christian.

title: METHODISTS VETO SHARING OF POWER
description: DENVER, Aug. 28Efforts to redistribute leadership power in the world's largest international Methodist organization to the developing nations in Africa and Asia failed this week.

title: RAMS WILL OPPOSE PATRIOTS TODAY
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 28 (UPI)Tommy ProthrO, who battled Jim Plunkett to a stand, off in their threegame college's series, tangles with the Heis man Trophy winner again to morrowthis time as a pro when the Los Angeles Rams meet the New England Patriots.

title: Company Feels Queens Is Ideal Site for Business
description: Fifteen years ago, the Del monico International division of Elgin National Industries, Inc., opened a 20,000squarefoot, secondfloor loft in Long Island City to import and distribute consumer electronic and elec trical devices.

title: MAYOR IN JERSEY IS LINDSAY BACKER
description: TRENTON, Aug. 28The first New Jersey organization sup porting Mayor Lindsay of New York City for President has taken root in an outoftheway South Jersey community.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor, Barring a'73 Race, Says 8 Years Is Enough
description: Mayor Lindsay has decided not to run for reelection in 1973 because, he said, Eight years is enough for me and for the city. It's time for a new face. But he quickly added that he would try to influence the selection of his successor in City Hall.

title: Concerns Respect Dividend Freeze
description: Wall Street has taken in bullish stride the freeze on corporate dividends as part of President Nixon's eco nomic program.

title: Canadians Withdraw From America's Cup
description: The Royal Vancouver Yacht Club of Canada has notified the New York Yacht Club that it has withdrawn its challenge for the Amer ica's Cup in 1974.

title: Television
description: JEAN STAPLETON still feels acutely uncomfort able recalling a day more than 30 years ago when she went to buy a chicken for her mother who reminded her to have the tail end removed. Jean followed instructions. Cut off the pope's nose,  she directed, without thinking. The Italian butcher just looked at her coldly.

title: The Nation
description: NEW ORLEANS Mississip pians are at a familiar Southern crossroads.

title: Et A1.
description: A Black Muslim catechism: rebuttals to criticisms ad vanced by various writers; some explanation of Muslim beliefs, buttressed by Elijah Muhammad's claim that he will pay $10,000 to anyone who disproves his claims. Since, however, it is unlikely that anyone can prove that another man has not had conversations with God, the money is still around. This is a highly rhe torical defense of Muhammad's authenticity, unlikely to con vince skeptics.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: J. P. Nelson Weds Miss McMurray
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 28In the Holy Family Chapel at the College of New Rochelle this afternoon, Miss Kathleen McMurray, daughter of Dr. Joseph P. McMurray, president of the college, and Mrs. McMurray, was married to Jeffrey P. Nelson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Nelson of Elmira. The Rev. Killian Money, uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Cath olic ceremony.

title: Shinnecocks Plan Powwow on L.I.
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. Aug. More than 20,000 visitors ?? expected here next week end for the 25th annual Powwow at the Shinnecock Indian Reservation near Mon tauk Highway.

title: PRICEFREEZE FOG LIFTING IN NASSAU
description: MINEOLA, LI., Aug. 28$ The cloud of confusion hanging over the twoweekold national wageprice freeze has begun to dissipate in Nassau County.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: ARROGANT
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: FORBES IS LEADER IN U.S. TITLE SAIL
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 28 David Forbes of Epping, New South Wales, sailing Carabella, won the opening race of the United States 5.5Meter cham pionship regatta on Long Island Sound off Stamford Yacht Club today. The race was postponed two hours until the wind sub sided.

title: Temple CrossCountry Slate Begins With FourWay Meet
description: The Temple University cross country team will open its 1971 schedule on Saturday, Sept. 25 against West Chester, Trenton State and East Stroudsburg at East Stroudsburg.

title: ALY SABRY
description: Although they faced a penalty of death or life imprisonment, none of the defendants seemed worried when Egypt's mass treason trial opened last week in Heliopolis, the na tion's oldest city. The 12 alleged plotters present  of 91 charged with plotting to overthrow President Anwar elSadat last May  chatted, joked and waved from the bleacherlike prison ers' dock. Among them were two of Mr. Sadat's main oppo nents, former Vice President Aly Sabry and former Interior Minister Sharaway Gomaa. Mr. Gomaa provided a tense mo ment by accusing co defendant. Ahmed Hamel, former intelli gence chief, of betray ing the others by con fessing details of the conspiracy.

title: Movies
description: WE WERE, to say the least, de lighted to be the first Ameri can journalists to interview the celebrated Italian film maker, Gianni Sulpunto. The great ge nius had turned down all prospective interviewers since his arrival in New York a month earlier. But when he learned that we were filmmakers our selveswe showed him several extraor dinary snapshots of him and his 16 yearold protg, Maria Sant' Gria, cavorting shamelessly on the Via Ven etohe immediately ushered us into his luxurious hotel suite.

title: EMBARGO BY H.U.D. REPORTED EASED
description: The Housing and Develop ment Administration announced yesterday that the Federal De partment of Housing and Urban Development has lifted restric tions on requisitions by the city of additional properties in four urban renewal sites and was preparing to lift the re strictions in a fifth site.

title: Delaware, 902 Last Year, To Play 11 Games in Soccer
description: An 11game schedule awaits the University of Delaware soc cer team.

title: Gardens
description: BACK to school? A touch of home? Even a single plant is far more effective in mitigating the ste rility of a dorm room than a multitude of dayglow posters and India print bedspreads. It adds a sense of homeyness by removing the air of transience that so often lingers in these rooms.

title: ARMY AIDES GAIN IN CHINESE SHIFTS
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 28 The completion during the last week of the formation of provincial level committees of the Chinese Communist party reveals a na tionwide predominance of mili tary men in top posts.

title: Brooke Wins Junior Golf
description: IOWA CITY, Aug. 28 (AP) Richard Brooke, 19 years old, of Lakewood, N. J., won the 54th Western junior golf tour nament today by defeating Gary Grant, 19, of Indianapolis, 32

title: Campus View Is Positive Despite Fiscal Squeeze
description: College football begins a new season with an old problemmoneybut with a surprisingly positive outlook.

title: IN THE NATION
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said in Washington this week that he would not endorse anyone for the Democratic nomination for President before next summer's convention in Miami Beach. That statement reinforced a wide spread political opinion that Mr. Ken nedy is not and probably will not be an active candidate himself, but that he will do nothing to eliminate the possibility that the Democrats might turn to him at the last minute, as they so nearly did in 1968.

title: The Nation
description: These are not slayings. They are public executions, a veteran New York policeman said last week. New York is paying a terrible price for social integra tion, but nobody has the guts to face up to it.

title: WIDER U.S. TRADE WITH POLAND SEEN
description: WARSAW, Aug. 28The de cision of the United States Gov ernment this week to permit the sale of sophisticated petro leumprocessing technology to Poland is welcomed here as a significant change in political relations.

title: Pops in Boston And Ma Loves It
description: IN more ways than one, the Boston Pops rips me apart. On one level, somewhere around the gut, the reaction to the orchestra and its bubbly fare borders on acute revulsion. On another, struggling for Olympian objec tivity, it tends to get a bit mushy over the argument that the orchestra is bringing an awful lot of entertain ment and culturalbroadening to an awful lot of people. The key word, I suspect, is awful.

title: Is It Possible for a Woman to Manhandle the King's English?
description: When the 79th annual convention of the American Psychological Associa tion opens in Washington Sept. 3, the most astonishing psychological phe nomena will be the presiding officers. Instead of turning up as chairman or chairlady, each will have been trans muted into a sexually obscure chair person.

title: HONG KONG GETS AID FROM CHINA
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 28 China scored a small propa ganda victory over the Hong Kong Government this week by donating more than three times the amount initially allocated by the crown colony's own au thorities here for the relief of victims of a destructive typhoon.

title: At Last, He's Shaken The Seven Year Itch
description: TOM EWELL had a monkey on his back. The monkey was the huge success he had enjoyed as the ner vous, quite incredulous young husband in The Seven Year Itch who has a fling with the beauti ful girl upstairs while his wife is away for the summer. He first played the consciencewracked Don Juan on Broadway in 1952; Vanessa Brown was the temptation upstairs. Later he repeated the role in the movie, and this time Marilyn Monroe, who was then at the height of her film career, was The Girl.

title: REPORT SAYS SOVIET MISTREATED TATARS
description: LONDON, Aug. 28Mis treatment of two ethnic minor ity groups in the Soviet Union, the Crimean Tatars and the Volga Germans, is charged in a report published here today by the Minority Rights Group, a British research organization. Both peoples were deported to Central Asia by Stalin dur ing World War II, and their autonomous territories have never been reconstituted.

title: Et A1.
description: Few contemporary critics have matched the late Justin O'Brien's ability to transmit his enthusiasm for modern French writers, particularly Proust, Gide and Camus. As a translator of taste and skill, as a reviewer and scholar, O'Brien played a large role in making the works of these and other French authors known to Americans. It is un fortunate that, in collecting these random essays, his col league at Columbia Leon S. Roudiez wrote only a superfi cial assessment by way of in troduction.

title: Miss Christine Hadsel Is Wed To William J. Mares, an Author
description: ST. JOHNSBURY, Vt., Aug. 28  The marriage of Miss Christine Hadsel to William J. Mares took place here today. The Rev. James Nicholas, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the Presbyterian ceremony out doors on the 200acre farm belonging to the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. F. L. Hadsel.

title: SOVIET REBUKES ARABs' LEADERS
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 28The So viet Union, whose relations with the Arab world have undergone strains in recent weeks, today rebuked Arab leaders who favor contacts with the United States and who court Soviet support while crushing local Communist movements.

title: Home Improvement
description: THERE are very few home remodeling or carpentry projects that can be completed properly without use of at least one or two kinds of wood molding or trim (this includes baseboards, door and window trim, cove mold lngs near the ceiling, etc.). Even where major remodel ing is not contemplated, there are many instances when the home handyman will find it necessary to re place a badly damaged, rotted or cracked piece of old molding or trim.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOPPER IS WOUNDED IN QUEENS SHOOTOUT
description: A Queens shopper was wounded yesterday when he was shot accidentally during an exchange of fire between an offduty policeman and a gun man in Astoria.

title: Ottawa Aide Seeks Consumer Reform
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 28Canadi an television viewers one re cent evening watched Ronald Basford, the federal Minister of Consumer Affairs, waving two boxes of the same make of facial tissue he had plucked from the shelves of a local supermarket.

title: Richards Captures Lead In U.S. Modern Pentathlon
description: FORT SAM HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 28 UPI)Capt. Chuck Richards, an Army officer from Tacoma, Wash., jumped into a narrow lead today after the riding event in the opening day of the eightday United States modern pentathlon champion ships.

title: Miss Bastanchury Takes TransMississippi Golf
description: CHULA VISTA, Calif., Aug. 28 (AP)  Jane Bastanchury of Whittier, Calif., won her third TransMississippi women's ama teur golf tounrament in five years with a 7and5 victory over Lesley Anne Dwyer of Lu saka, Zambia, today at San Diego Country Club.

title: Karyn Schumacher Is Married to Ensign
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 28Miss Karyn Schumacher was married this evening to Ens. William Francis Cord ner Jr., U.S.N. The minister, the Rev. George Pere, per formed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: N.B.A., A.B.A. STARS SET FOR FUND GAMES
description: The Baltimore Bullets' Earl Monroe; Detroit Pistons' Dave Bing; Philadelphia 76ers' Fred Crawford and New York Knicks' Dave Stallworth head a National Basketball Associa tion delegation that will par ticipate in the second annual Charles W. Rochester Memorial Fund game Sept. 10 at St. John's University Alumni Hall Gymnasium, Queens.

title: Chou Declares U.S. Is Losing Preeminent Position in World;
description: PEKING, Aug. 28Premier Chou Enlai declared last night that the United States is on the verge of losing the pre eminent position it has enjoyed in world affairs since the end of World War II.

title: Et A1.
description: The British Admiralty called it one of the most courageous acts of all time  the midget submarine attack on the Ger man battleship Tirpitz in 1943 while she was anchored in a seemingly impregnable posi tion in a Norwegian fjord. Thomas Gallagher has combed the records, including the secret log of the Tirpitz, and interviewed survivors among the submariners, the Tirpitz crew and the Norwegian underground that fed metic ulously accurate information to the British. The result is a superior piece of World War II derringdo, suspenseful, vivid and written with a novelist's skill.

title: City Bank Negotiating Sale To Chile of Branches There
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 28 (AP)The First National City Bank of New York announced today that it was negotiating to sell its branches in Chile to the Chilean Government.

title: PINSCHER IS BEST IN BETHEL SHOW
description: BETHEL, Conn., Aug. 28 Ch. BoMar's Road Runner, a miniature pinscher, took top honors today at the 21st show of the Newtown Kennel Club.

title: Eventually you almost learn to love the guy
description: Not since St. Augustine or the Marquis de Sade has a chronicler been quite so hard on himself as Stuart Miller, who gives the impres sion of having been plucked from Modern Language Association forum while in the midst of delivering monograph on backbiting. Indeed, he is almost too bad to be true, and it is a tribute to Miller's narrative strength and dogged staying power that, for all his infinitely boring stretches indefinitely prolonged, we learn to live with, to like and almost, almost to love this wise guy, this snotnose, this selfserving selfhating academic careerist, this quintessen tial wretch of a Jewish son. (I went to see my mother for the first time in a year and a half  I hated her.)

title: The World
description: The average per capita income of the 36 million people of the Philippines is $200 a year. But an estimated 50 per cent of the country's wealth is in the hands of 5 per cent of the population; the median income is, therefore, probably closer to $50. A good part of the tax burden falls on the poor; the rich minority en joys a life of luxury in exclusive, heavily guarded communities near Manila. This lite also con trols the nation's political struc tureoften, it is charged, through corruption.

title: EUROPE IN DOUBT ON DOLLAR'S PATH
description: LONDON, Aug. 28European observers expressed doubts to day whether Western Europe and Japan were yet ready to concede to President Nixon all the advantages he seeks for the overvalued dollar.

title: SCIENTISTS ASSAIL VIETNAM METHODS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28Two of the latest meas ures used by the United States military against the enemy in Vietnam are causing new and, at times, widespread environ mental disruption in vast areas, two American scientists have charged here.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  From the point of view of nearly all United States citizens and businesses, what matters most about President Nixon's new economic policy is what happens during the wageprice freeze and, even more, what follows it.

title: Photography
description: NEW YORK UNIVER SITY'S School of Con tinuing Education, Washington Square, is offering a series of eve ning lecture courses and workshops for both beginners and advanced students this fall. To be coordinated by Cornell Capa, there will be a series of 11 lectures that will be held on Thursday evenings from Sept. 30 to Dec. 16. They will focus on photog raphy as a tool of the social conscience and will be con ducted by such prominent photographers and craftsmen as Berenice Abbott, Walker Evans, Roman Vishniac and Arthur Rothstein, to men tion only a few. The lectures will be held from 6:10 to 8 P.M. each Thursday.

title: HEAD OF COLLEGE READY FOR MOVE
description: When Milton G. Bassin as sumes the presidency of York College, the youngest of the City University's senior col leges, in September, he intends to continue his advocacy of college involvement in commu nity affairs, a policy estab lished when he headed the old est and largest of the univer sity's twoyear institutions.

title: Connecticut Girl Triumphs in German Figure Skating
description: OBERSTDORF, Germany, Aug. 28 (UPI)An exciting perform ance in the free program car ried Dorothy Hammel of Greenwich, Conn., to victory in the Nebelhorn Trophy figure skating competition today.

title: Et A1.
description: The climbing of the sheer south face of Annapurna by a British team in 1970. The au thor led the expedition, made up of some of Great Britain's best climbers, plus one Ameri can (chosen to facilitate fund raising). Employing all the latest techniques (wellde scribed for the buff), two teams made it to the top; one member of the party was killed in a landslide. While this account lacks the poetry of Maurice Herzog's story of the French expedition of 1950, it is properly exciting. Good show, chaps!

title: The Opening in the Park
description: THE TALE OF CYMBELINE, the New York Shakespeare Festival version of Shakespeare's Cymbeline, got two favorable, two mixed and three un favorable reviews. Mel Gussow: Director A. J. Antoon has changed the title to The Tale of Cymbeline. This is intended as the fairytale version, and since the play is playful and even fantastical the new direction seems entirely justified. But once past the once upon a time beginning, Antoon bounds off in diverse directions. This is not a Cymbeline transformed but Cymbeline with notions added. Some of Antoon's additions are inven tive. Some are gimmicks. Most of them are funeven if only for their own sake. The production is never uninteresting. And any Cymbeline is rare enough reason to go to the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. It closes tonight. For Walter Kerr, see Page 1.

title: Elderly Chinese Addicts Here Get Aid
description: A methadonemaintenance program is being conducted in Chinatown for an unusual group of elderly drug ad dicts, whose oldest member is an 86yearold man who began to smoke opium in 1896, when he was 11.

title: COURT TO DECIDE CONVENTION ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The political complexion of the 1972 Democratic National Con vention and, conceivably, even its choice of a Presidential candidate, will be significantly affected by the judgment of three Federal judges here.

title: Israeli Bowling Team Learning New Techniques in World Event
description: While the United Jewish Ap peal raises a quarterbillion dollars in this country almost every year, Israeli bowlers have found such generosity does not extend to the sporting, world.

title: Et A1.
description: An angry history of military stupidity through the ages. Mr. Fair considers commanders from Marcus Licinius Crassus to William Westmoreland who he claims, bungled their way to bloody losses. His favorite seems to be Ambrose Burn side, about whom Lincoln made the famous remark, which gives this book its title: He snatched defeat from the jaws of victory. For readers whose bag is human folly this should prove entertaining, although it is essentially a retread of secondary material.

title: PUERTO RICO WINS BABE RUTH SERIES
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 28 (AP)  Puerto Rico rallied for six runs In the sixth inning and routed Mount Healthy, Ohio, 123, today to become the first team from outside the United States to win the Babe Ruth World Series.

title: SCHOOL INTEGRATION GETS $22.5MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) The Office of Education has announced that it is giving $22.5million to 41 school dis tricts to help speed desegrega tion but said the funds would not be used to bus children.

title: First Woman President Heads National Student Association
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Aug. 28Once again, as they do every summer, members of the National Student Association gathered to survey the political territory of the United States, examine their ideals and talk about plans for the coming school year.

title: Bushnell, 4 Officials Cited By Eastern Football Group
description: Asa S. Bushnell, the former Eastern College Athletic. Con ference commissioner, and four recently retired gridiron offi cials have been honored for service to football.

title: Controller Levitt Reports Relief Frauds on the Rise Here, and Would Modify DeclarationofNeed System
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt made public yesterday a report estimating that there were nearly $4million in ap parent frauds by relief recip ients here who obtained 44,503 checks during 1970 to replace checks allegedly lost or stolen.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor

title: BROOKLYN TO GET DAYCARE CENTER
description: A $1.1million loan agree ment was signed last week be tween the director of a school for unwed mothers and the Na tional Bank of North America for the construction of a day care center in the Bedford Stuyvesant section of Brook lyn.

title: Sports Doctors Get Rx For Preventing Injuries
description: SEATTLE, Aug. 25A group of 40 doctors and coaches spent the last two days learn ing how best to prevent in juries and to treat the com mon ones that football play ers suffer  those affecting the knees, ankles, shoulders, head, muscles and tendons.

title: Alma North, $5.40, Wins Pageant Handicap at Atlantic City by 3 Lengths
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 (AP)East Acres' Alma North, carrying 121 pounds, took com mand near the halfmile pole under Frank Lovato and won the $29,223 Pageant Handicap by three lengths before 16,258 today.

title: The icy chic of Status Modern
description: Modern design has been a long time in coming into its own. Part of the problem has been its sup posed lack of elegance. It makes sense, then, that the achievement of what could be called Status Modern has come from France, since the French have always ex celled in elegance  from the perfection of their 18thcentury architecture, interiors and furni niture to their haute couture. They are on the way to winning the same reputation for their 20thcentury modern interiors. Even industrial materials such as steel take on an icy chic in this Paris apartment. It was de signed for Mrs. Raymonde Ze nacker, the director of the Dior Boutique, by Franois Catroux. The geometric rug running through the entire apartment underscores the simple, cubic forms of the fur niture. But it is the scale of the itemsthe, huge painting, tower ing cactus and primitive sculpture that is the key to this apart ment's dramatic impact.

title: Hodgins Rates Proximity Best Mare He Has Driven
description: Clint Hodgins, at 64 years of age, is the first to admit that he has slowed down. His once 40horse stable is down to seven and the trainer wouldn't have it any other way.

title: ITALY SET TO BEGIN PRESIDENCY RACE
description: ROME, Aug. 28High politi cal drama is about to start in Italy as the term of President Giuseppe Saragat runs out.

title: Rain Delays Tourney
description: WICHITA, Kan., Aug. 28 (UPI)Rain forced the post ponement today of the quarter final round of the National Baseball Congress tournament. Three games were rescheduled for tomorrow: Anchorage, Alas ka, vs. Boulder, Colo.; Mid lothian, Ill., vs. Wichita, and Eureka, Calif., vs. Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on the Ruppert renewal plan [Ruppert Re newal Plan Revised Drasti cally, Aug. 15] was a mas terly and factually accurate presentation. However, we believe it did not adequately state how strong and united the community opposition is and the basis for it.

title: Miss Jane Flues Is Married In Capital to Matthew Simchak
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 Miss Jane Sidney Flues, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Gilmore Flues, was married here this afternoon to Mat thew Stephen Simchak, son of Mrs. Morag MacLeod Simchak and Matt S. Szymczak, both of Washing ton.

title: The Last Word: The WellMade Novel
description: Auden's Age of Anxiety is also our Era of Dynamic Ob solescence. As Woody Allen remarked the other day, it doesn't help your faith in God when you can't get a plumber on a week end. When the family Disposall and the family Lark need re placement each 18 months, belief in all durabilities suffers a comparable erosion. Nowadays, if something is truly well made (by an artisan who takes pride in his work), it's as much a cause for wonder as rejoicing. The melancholy truism applies to the wellmade novelthe kind that, at first glance, seems destined to outlast its maker.

title: Congressmen Lose a Plea For Nuclear Test Report
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) United States District Judge George L. Hart has turned down a request by 33 members of Congress for access to a secret report that was said to have advised President Nixon to cancel a huge underground nuclear test Oct. 2.

title: BUSING PLAN STANDS IN LOUISIANA RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) Supreme Court Justice Thur good Marshall refused today to delay implementation of a school desegregation plan for Jefferson Parish, La., that would require the busing of 3,000 ad ditional children in New Orleans suburbs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wagner Campaigns in Harlem For District Leader's Election
description: In a rare political gesture, a former Mayor of the City of New York took to the streets of East Harlem yesterday to campaign for the election of a Democratic district leader who is running against the party's Manhattan chairman.

title: COMFORT?
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Japan, as Yen Floats, Embarks On Voyage to Unknown Lands
description: TOKYO, Aug. 28The foreign exchange market here quietly bid farewell to the currency rate of 360 yen to the dollar today and embarked on what the Governor of the Bank of Japan has called a voyage to unknown lands.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Polly Portenoy Becomes Bride Of R. S. Surrey
description: HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 28 St. Thomas Episcopal Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Mary (Polly) Riggs Por tenoy, a staff assistant in the department of community medicine at the Dartmouth Medical School, to Richard Sterling Surrey, a member of the class of '72 at Dartmouth College. The Rev. Colin Gracey, chaplain at North eastern University, performed the ceremony.

title: WEAVER, RODGERS GAIN
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 28 Arnold Palmer lost to Bruce Crampton by three strokes in the quarterfinals of the $200, 000 national match play cham pionship today.

title: MRS. KING BEATEN BY MISS MELVILLE
description: NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28 (UPI)Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals were up set in the singles semifinals of the $20,000 Virginia Slims ten nis tournament today and then were also beaten in doubles.

title: MidQueens Day Camp Ends 9th Year
description: Experience has proved to Mrs. Eva Sevita of Flushing that the best summer place for her three children is the MidQueens Day Camp.

title: Skiers Practicing on Plastic Snow Slopes in Italy
description: Plastic snow is providing skiers with practice slopes and offseason ski trails in three locations near Bergamo, Italy.

title: Braves Defeat Cubs, 43
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (AP) Marty Perez' runscoring single with two out in the ninth in ning gave the Atlanta Braves a 43 victory over the Chicago Cubs today, spoiling Ferguson Jenkins' bid for his 21st vic tory.

title: Irish Protestants Cool to Ulster
description: DUBLIN, Aug. 28  As an Irish Protestant, an exmember of the local urban council and with business and property here, I know the full meaning of freedom. I therefore wish to protest most strongly against the introduction of internment in the Mirth of Ireland, and in particular against the onesided way in which this is being im plemented.

description: To THE EDITOR:

description: To the Editor:

title: PHILS TOP GIANTS AFTER 52 DEFEAT
description: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28 (AP) Rick Wise, a pitcher, knocked in five runs with a pair of homers tonight as the Phila delphia Phillies beat San Fran cisco, 73, for a split of their twinight doubleheader.

title: BRUINS WILL START TRAINING SEPT, 12
description: BOSTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) The Boston Bruins, with Bobby Orr, superstar defenseman, signed for the next five years for a reported $1million con tract, will open training camp Sept. 12 in London, Ontario, team official said today.

title: Polls Indicate a Majority of Labor Union Members Support Nixon Economic Moves
description: The latest Gallup Poll indi cates that an overwhelming ma jority of labor union members in the United States support President Nixon's new econom ic program.

title: EUROPE IN DOUBT ON DOLLAR'S PATH
description: LONDON, Aug. 28European observers expressed doubts to day whether Western Europe and Japan were yet ready to concede to President Nixon all the advantages he seeks for the overvalued dollar.

title: Day in Life of a Pro Football Scout
description: DALLAS, Aug. 28 (AP)It was 3 A.M. and 10 degrees below zero in the tele phone booth in Moscow, Idaho.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Don't Forget to Pack Your Birthday Suit
description: ONE twilight evening earlier this month, while the temperature was a steamy 85 degrees, Lisa, a blond, 17yearold Westport, Conn., high school student, happened to go swimming with four of her friends at a secluded beach on Long Island Sound.

title: The Nation
description: CHICAGOThe eight Chicago policemen who burst with guns blazing into a Black Panther apartment at 4:40 A. M., Dec. 4, 1969, were on what might have been a routine search for illegal weapons, not unlike pre vious police operations against black street gangs in Chicago's crumbling West Side ghetto.

title: New Harlem Club Woos Young Voter
description: Below the sign on the window that reads, Give Us a Chance to Work With You for an Im proved Harlem, is another that reads: Malcolm X Independent Democrats.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: POISON IVY

title: Is Theater Dead? Not On Your Life
description: SCENE: A pleasant little graveyard just off Times Square. There are trees, bushes, lots of flowers. Birds sing. A man, evidently a gravedigger, leans on his shovel contemplating a new headstone which reads: HERE LIES THEATER, R.I.P. AND THAT'S FINAL. The bushes part and a cyclist appears. He dis mounts, props his bicycle against a tree and approaches the gravedigger.

title: 25 DEAD AS FERRY BURNS OFF ITALY
description: BRINDISI, Italy, Aug. 28At least 25 persons died and others may be missing after a Greek ferryboat carrying more than 1,000 people caught fire in the Adriatic Sea 25 miles from this port city today.

title: OBSERVER
description: If the Gallup Poll is to be believed, practically everybody in the country thinks better of President Nixon be cause of his wageprice freeze.

title: The Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO six men were left dead and three wound ed as the price of the black revolutionary George Jackson's attempt to escape from San Quentin Prison last Saturday. It was the bloodiest day ever at San Quentin and one of the bloodiest in the dismaying his tory of American prisons.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: With the publication on March 10, 1971, of the In stitutional Investor Study Report, the Securities and Exchange Commission, indi cated its acceptance of the fact that an old order is changing on Wall Street.

title: Astros Beat Pirates, 40, on 5Hitter by Wilson and 2 Key Singles by Watson
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) Don Wilson pitched a fivehitter and Bob Watson hit two run scoring singles tonight to pace the Houston Astros to a 40 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: BUCKS AND STARS WILL MEET OCT. 5
description: The Milwaukee Bucks and the Utah Stars will clash Oct. 5 in the first game ever between Na tional and American Basketball Association champions.

title: Goodby, Saratoga, And Hello, Belmont
description: America's racing Establishment packed up its old money, its diamonds and its thoroughbred horses over the weekend, thus ending the 108th season at the rustic old geraniumhung Saratoga track. By tomorrow, everybody who is anybody will be at Belmont.

title: LATE DOLPHIN PASS SINKS LIONS, 2824
description: MIAMI, Aug. 28 (UPI)Jim Kiick ran for three touchdowns, but it took a 13yard touch down pass from Bob Griese to Paul Warfield in the fading minutes to give the Miami Dolphins a 2824 victory over the Detriot Lions tonight.

title: U.S.Hopes the Elections Today Will Ease ThieuKy Problems
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28The Nixon Administration is known to, hope that tomor row's parliamentary elections in South Vietnam may provide political clues for solving some difficulties posed by the im pending oneman October pres idential race.

title: Medicine
description: At a hospital near Washing ton, D. C., a middleaged man complains that everything he eats tastes like garbage  another man recovering from an operation takes his first drink of ordinary tap water and spits it out, cursing its foul taste  a young woman re covering from a bout of flu says that a cheese omelet turns to sawdust in her mouth.

title: Taking This Photograph Got Me Locked Up
description: PEC, YugoslaviaIt was the first time I had been arrested as a spy by Communist police. My immediate reaction was one of pure, unmitigated fear. The main reason was that they kept closing gates behind me. You have never heard a heavy steel gate close until you hear one close be hand you when you are under arrest in a strange country. You think nothing could ever sound worseuntil you hear the man in uniform with a big red star on his cap turn the heavy bolt with his ring of jangly keys. That did sound worse.

title: Art
description: ARTISTS are mercurial spirits, easily pleased and just as easily cast down. They respond to a kind word with the sponta neity of a child unexpectedly proffered an ice cream cone, and like a child's, their re sponse is unaffected by the identity of the giver, who may be a critic, a colleague, or the village idiot it is all the same to them. Their pleasure is simple, direct, and unanalyti cala joy to see. But drop a hint that their work leaves something to be desired, that something more than an ex tended generation gap ac counts for the esthetic lag between their latest effort and Michelangelo's Sistine Ceiling, and you are in for it. They become boiling amalgams of fury, contempt, and despair.

title: MEDICAL SERVICE SCORED IN RAMAPO
description: RAMAPO, N. Y., Aug. 28  The death of a 15yearold boy while riding his motor bike his fanned a dispute that involves the Rockland County Medical Examiner's office, volunteer ambulance corps, private physi cians and police officials.

title: Obe's Old Soul Food Moves to a New Site
description: There was a lot of laughter and kissing, and the many loud pops of champagne corksplus sone tearsas friends and cus tomers of Obediah Green gath ered late Friday to open the new Obie's Restaurant at a Harlem crossroad, Seventh Ave nue and 135th Street.

title: ROLF STEINER
description: Rolf Steiner, ex Nazi Wolf Cub, ex seminarian, exForeign Legionnaire, exmerce nary, would make a virile character for a men's magazine article but his trial in Khar toum for abetting a black rebellion in the southern Sudan against the country's Arab Government has not produced the juicy headlines expected. There has been talk of foreign connivingby Israel, the Central In telligence Agency and British Intelligence on the side of the rebels but Mr. Steiner has emerged as a rather passive villain. When first brought to trial Aug. 2, he was expected to meet his fate quickly. But last week the trial dragged on and Mr. Steiner rose in court to ex press gratitude for an objective and fair

title: Namath Joins Jets At Training Camp For Missouri Trip
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 28 (AP)Joe Namath, smiling broadly and reporting that his injured left knee felt strong, rejoined the New York Jets tonight.

title: MOONEY'S BOAT WINS IN SAILING SERIES
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug. 28 Tim Mooney of the host Bay Shore Yacht Club captured the first race of the Cottontail Class national championship series today.

title: Fisherwoman Hooks Whale
description: BRISBANE, Australia, Aug. 28 (Reuters)Mrs. Agnes Tait, fishing for coral trout with an amateur fishing club in Great Barrier Reef waters off In nisfail, 1,700 miles north of here, hooked a 35foot hump back whale yesterday. Mrs. Tait was fishing from a deep sea launch when the whale surfaced behind

title: Movies
description: IF there is such a thing as a film that makes its viewer a better human beingand I dearly hope there isHoa Binh is it. It is the story, essentially, of two Vietnamese children: a boy, Hung, aged 11, and his sister, Xuan, oneandahalf. The time is not now or last year or tomorrow; the time is, simply and dreadfully, war. The action takes place between Hung's father's de parture to join the Viet Cong and his return, months later, to Saigon. In between, Hung loses his mother, must sur vive against terrifying odds in the warmauled city while also taking care of baby Xuan, and must not give up hope. It is a tall order for a little boy, but with some help and much hindrance from others, he does it. Hoa Binh tells it without the slightest histrionics, without striving for pathos, or excess of any kind.

title: EAGLES DOWN GIANTS, 2614;
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 28 Having been a political football the last few days, the New York Giants returned to the real thing today, and were beaten by the Philadelphia Eagles, 2614.

title: St. John's Fencers to Face Some Strong Early Rivals
description: St. John's University's fenc ing team, a surprising fifth in last season's National Colle giate championships of 44 en tries, will have 13 matches for 197172.

title: 15 TEAMS ENTERED IN POLO TOURNAMENT
description: TOUGHKENAMON, Pa., Aug. 28Fifteen teamsthe largest field in the history of the event will begin play Monday in the Gerald Balding Memorial eightgoal polo tournament at the Brandywine Polo Club.

title: Expected Sale of Beachfront in Eastern Suffolk Stirs Fears
description: WATERMILL, L.I., Aug. 28  One of the last major beachfront estates on Long bland's East End, the 238 acre Anne McDonnell Ford Johnson property, is in its last throes. The Johnson's must sell it and the residents of this quiet village fear the consequences.

title: Retired Nurses Take Refresher Course to Go Back to Duty
description: GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 28  When Mrs. Laverne Kelly put on her nurse's uniform for the first time in 15 years she did not recognize herself.

title: Et A1.
description: An American entomologist takes a twoyear sojourn in South Africa to work on a mosquito project that involves the viruses they carry. He learns on the job, works on local flora and fauna. Increasingly, however, he finds apartheid an affront to his conscience and so leaves. Worth writes frankly and with humor.

title: CHAIRMAN NAMED FOR AFRO STUDIES
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 28  The controversy over who would head the new Afro American Studies Department at Nassau Community College apparently came to an end this week with the appointment of Prof. Sylvester Wise of Hemp stead as chairman.

title: FAVOR TO HUGHES IS SEEN IN NEVADA
description: CARSON CITY, Nev. Aug. 28 Behind the Nevada Gaming Commission's refusal to grant new license applications of the Hughes Tool Company this week was the doubt that Howard R. Hughes, the mysteri ous billionaire, knew what was happening to his property.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Typhoon Lashes Kyushu
description: TOKYO, Monday, Aug. 30 (AP)Typhoon Trix lashed Ja pan's southernmost island, Ky ushu, early today with torren tial rains and 110mileanhour winds, injuring at least 16 per sons. The police said one per son was reported missing in the storm, and the Maritime Safety Agency said at least five ships were reported sunk or washed ashore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES DIVIDED OVER DAM
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  A conflict in the Department of the Interior has been sharpened by the disclosure of a memo random that pits one agency against another.

title: Central Park a Summer Fiesta As Puerto Ricans Look to Home
description: The buttons were embla zoned Puerto Rico en Mi Corazn, and the heartshaped message of love for the island and joy in its culture throbbed yesterday in the musiccharged air around the Central Park mall and bandshell.

title: Cream of A.A.U.'s Crop Chosen to Swim Abroad
Laver Subdues Newcombe In Hilton Head Final, 62,75
description: Rod Laver, who has bypassed the United States Open at For est Hills this week, captured the top prize of $15,000 in the fourplayer Tournament of Ten nis Champions that ended Sat urday at the Harbor Town Rac quet Club in Hilton Head, S. C.

title: JOHNSTONS EXCEL IN FOLK FESTIVAL
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 29  The sun shone yesterday on the three day Philadelphia Folk Festival after its opening was drenched Friday night on the 100acre Old Pool Farm near Schwenks ville.

title: COSMOS TRIUMPH OVER CHIEFS, 21
description: The New York Cosmos ended their first regular season in the North American Soccer League by defeating the At lanta Chiefs, 21, at Yankee Stadium last night before 2,714 fans.

title: Personal Finance: Consumers' Gains
description: The consumer  lately the beneficiary of a long string of laws designed to broaden his rights  didn't fare too well in Albany this year, de spite some advances in a few key areas.

title: Miss Dan Captures A Rich French Race By Length on Grass
description: DEAUVILLE, France, Aug. 29 Miss Dan, who finished sec ond to Fort Marcy in last year's Washington D.C. International at Laurel, won the $87,000 Grand Prix de Deauville today in impressive style to cap a month of racing in this channel resort.

title: Juliana Gets Big Welcome
description: BANDUNG, Indonesia, Aug. 29 (AP)Queen Juliana of the Netherlands was welcomed here today by a crowd that some observers put as high as 250,000.

title: Reaction of Industry Is Mixed In New Ruling on Patent Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The reaction of industry and business to the 2,500word statement of Government pat ent policy issued by President Nixon last Monday has been mixed. In general, comment is favorable on the expanded au thority given Federal agencies to grant exclusive licenses un der patents they own.

title: The Black Sash: A Protest That Refuses to Die
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, (AP)The 30 lightly clad white women with black mourning sashes stand silent ly holding placards. It's an other 24hour protest on a main street in Johannesburg. Commuters cannot help no tice the women, but most turn away. Others shout abuse; occasionally someone ac knowledges their protest with a friendly wave.

title: Ewbank: Chiefs' Game Just Another Tube Test
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 29  Resisting the temptation of an allout performance for national television, Weeb Ewbank will inspect his shuffled offensive and defensive lines and a group of rookie defensive backs and running backs tomorrow night when the New York Jets op pose the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: TWIN TIME FIRST IN DELAWARE TEST
description: STANTON, Dela., Aug. 29 (AP)  Twin Time, the only 3yearold in the race, carried Gene Mori's East Acres silks to victory over 10 older rivals today in the $58,600 du Pont Handicap at Delaware Park.

title: Msgr. James Halligan, 85, Dies; Chaplain for the Lost Battalion
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29Msgr. James, J. Halligan, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Wire here from its dedication in 1930 to his retirement last year, died today in NeW Rochelle Hospital after suffering an apparent heart attack at his residence, 129 Petersville Road. He was 85 years old.

title: First Section of 63d St. Tunnel Lowered to Bottom of East River
description: With 500 tons of rock on its roof to sink it, the first of four sections of the new 63d Street railroad and subway tunnel was lowered into a trench in the bottom of the East River yesterday without difficulty.

title: Canada Civil Servants Will Work en Francais
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 29 (Reu ters)About 29,000 federal civil servants are being told to work in French, in a one year experiment, designed to increase the use of Canada's second official language.

title: Marion Duke Bruckner Married
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 29Miss Marion Duke Bruck ner and Raymond Stanley Baxter 3d, who were gradu ated in June from Bucknell Christ Episcopal Church here. this afternoon in the Congre gational Church by the Rev. Frank N. Johnston, rector of Christ Episcopal Shurch here.

title: A Clarification
description: Reliance Insurance Company holders who tendered their stock to the Leasco Corporation in 1968 exchange offer are not able to rescind the deal under the terms of a 128page ruling issued last Thursday by Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Brooklyn Federal Court. Judge Weinstein, as reported in Saturday's edi tions, ruled that Leasco had filed a misleading registration statement and gave Reliance holders the right to damages if they had sold their Leasco package prior to Oct. 27, 1969, for less than $66. He did not provide for rescission or dam ages for those who sold after that date. The Times had said that the question for those sell ing after Oct. 27 had been left undecided.

title: MARCOS FOE GOES ON CAMPAIGN TRIP
description: ALABAT, the Philippines, Aug. 29  Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr., President Ferdinand E. Marco's principal political opponent, left Manila today on a barnstorming political tour by helicopter. He was the only op position leader who escaped injury when two grenades were thrown into a Liberal party rally in Manila Aug. 21.

title: For Detergents, a New Round
description: Laundry detergents, which have been making headlines over the last few months, are likely to make a lot more within the next few weeks. Direct as well as indirect guidelines are expected to come out of Washington on what may go into the wash.

title: Twin Bill in Cleveland Shared by Jets, Giants
description: The Jets and Giants will be in Cleveland on Saturday night to play in the annual charity exhibition double header at Municipal Stadium.

title: Hodgson and Stans Hint Control on Profits Is Next
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  Two high officials of the Nixon Administration indicated today that one element in the second phase of the President's eco nomic program might be Gov ernmentadministered controls on corporate profits and divi dends.

title: Massachusetts Aide Named
description: BOSTON, Aug. 29 (AP) John F. Kehoe Jr. of Milton, an F.BI agent for nearly 30 years and an expert, on or ganized crime, was named by Gov Francis W. Sargent tonight as the state's new commis sioner of public safety. He will succeed William F. Powers. Mr Kehoe, 51 years old, was in the Federal. Bureau of In vestigation from 1941 to 1970.

title: Sea Searched for Survivors
description: BRINDISI, Italy, Aug. 29 Scores of rescue vessels, in eluding an Italian Navy hover craft from Venice, were search ing a large area of the Adriatic Sea northeast of here today for survivors of the fire on a large Greek ferryboat yester day.

title: Small
description: In an industry of small com panies where survival has al ways been a problem, the United Kingsway Carpet Clean ers, Inc., has found a solution.

title: Libya Denies Role in Chad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 29 (AP)Libya denied charges to day that she was involved in an abortive coup against the regime in Chad of President Francois Tombalbaye, according to a report by Egypt's Middle East News Agency. Chad broke relations with Libya yesterday.

title: We Use Our Muscle
description: A few years ago I was asked to address the executives of a major American corporation. The announced subject was the longrange outlook for the American economy. The pres ident of the corporation introduced my presentation in this way:

title: Gold Role in Europe Suggested
description: HAMBURG, West Germany, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  France's Finance Minister, Valery Gis card d'Estaing, has suggested that European currencies be tied to gold.

title: Arts Abroad
description: NEW DELHIThe lore of crime and adventure has made every child familiar with the gunrunner and the rumrunner. But recognition is long overdue for their crafty colleagues who have become known here as the idolrunners of India. The idolrunners, who give every evidence of being highly organized gangs financed by smuggler barons, rob India every year of millions of dollars worth of ancient statues, miniature paintings, frescoes, basreliefs, manu scripts and jewelry.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: R. H. SIKES, JEWELL SHARE GOLF LEAD
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 29R. H. Sikes of Fay etteville, Ark., broke the course record by one stroke with 67 today but wound up in tie with Jim Jewell of South Bend. Ind., at the halfway point in the $60,000 Liggett and MyersConcord Pro Golf Tour nament. Each had a 142 total.

title: O'Dwyer Would Not Back Nixon, Jackson or Wallace
description: Paul O'Dwyer said yesterday that he would encourage the formation of a new political par ty if President Nixon, Senator Henry M. Jackson and Gov. George C. Wallace emerged as the 1972 Presidential candi dates.

title: FOUR IN ONE FAMILY DIE IN BRONX FIRE
description: Four of five children of the Same family died early yester day morning, when a fire swept their tenement apartment in the Tremont section of the Bronx.

title: Lord Oaksey, Presiding Judge At Nuremberg Trials, Is Dead
description: LONDON, Aug. 29 Lord Oaksey, who as president of the international war crimes tri bunal at Nuremberg passed the death sentence on 11 leading Nazis, including Goering and Von Ribbentrop, died yesterday at his home in Malmesbury, Wiltshire. He was 90 years old.

title: Lamonica Sees Action as Raiders Win
description: Daryle Lamonica, who used to set up George Blanda's hero ics by limping to the sideline, left the bench himself Saturday night and helped the Oakland Raiders post a 1713 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: Nepal Leader Reappointed
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, Aug. 29 (Reuters)King Mahendra of Nepal today reappointed Kirti Nidhi Bista, who resigned only three days ago, as Prime Min ister for the third time.

title: AREA CLEANS UP IN DORIA'S WAKE
description: Tropical storm Doria, which rampaged along the Eastern Seaboard over the weekend, was reported dying out over Canada yesterday, but the moppingup operation along its path in the metropolitan area was continuing.

title: JULY ORDERS OFF IN MACHINE TOOLS
description: A slight decline in new orders for American machine tools in July was announced yesterday in Washington, but the drop was not the disappointment it might have been for the severe ly depressed industry.

title: Imperiled Centers of Learning
description: The cutback in services by the city's libraries and museums cannot be shrugged off as a mere trimming of frills at a time of general belttightening. These institutions, far from being luxuries, are part of New York's lifeblood.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Integration Comes to Citadel of Southern Strategy
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 29 At approximately 7:30 to morrow morning, two yellow school buses will rumble past each other on Atlas Road in the suburbs south of Columbia and life in this Southern capital will never be quite the same again.

title: ATTACK ON POLICE KILLS ONE ON COAST
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 (UPI)A young man walked up to the Ingleside police sta tion and fired shotgun blasts through the front door tonight, killing a sergeant and wound ing a woman dispatcher.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Academic Lifeline
description: It is no secret that several private colleges in the metropolitan area, already in grave financial trouble, are threatened by the impact of the City University's open admission policy. While students are still ready to pay a premium for attendance at highprestige private institutions, the number is dwindling of those willing to buy their way into colleges that are academ ically and socially less attractive. Such reluctance greater now that these students are assured of admis sion to the tuitionfree, highquality public university.

title: Ellen Varmus Is Wedon L.I.
description: FREEPORT, L. I., Aug. 29 Miss Ellen Jane Varmus was married here at home this afternoon to R. Howard Bloch. The ceremony was performed by Police Justice Edwin J. Freedman of Free port.

title: ShotPut Mark Tied
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29 (Reuters)  Nadezhda Chizhova of the Soviet Union equaled her world women's shotput record with a distance of 67 feet  inch today.

title: Revson Starts Last, but Wins Elkhart Lake CanAm
description: ELKHART LAME, Wis., Aug. 29Peter Revson turned in Frank Merriwell performance today to win a CanAm race after starting from last place, but two cars helped him by re Revson also had to per suade another driver to get out of the way by tapping him three times from the side.

title: Van Hagen Top Performer In Manhasset Race Week
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 29Charles Van Hagen 3d, by winning today's Shields Class race, will also be awarded the Black Jack Trophy for the best percentage performance in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 39th annual Race Week and the Henry A. Alker Trophy for the outstanding perform ance by a member of the host club.

title: EGYPT PUTS DOWN IRON PLANT STRIKE
description: CAIRO, Aug. 29President Anwar elSadat disclosed today that a group of workers had staged a sitin strike at Egypt's important iron and steel plant in Helwan and had locked the gates to keep thousands of workers in the plant overnight.

title: Chess:
description: Earliest reports from the international tournament tak ing place in Goteborg, Swe den, indicate that a big upset may be in the making. At the end of seven rounds, Ulf Andersson of Sweden was in first place with 51, a full point ahead of Grand master Vlastimil Hort of Czechoslovakia.

title: Jackson Honored at His Burial; Panthers Attack Photographer
description: MOUNT VERNON, Ill., Aug. 29 (UPI)  George Jackson, the black inmate who was killed a week ago at San Quentin Prison in California, was buried here in a family cemetery plot today while supporters and members of the Black Panther party raised their fists in black pow er salutes.

title: CREDIT MARKETS SEE MORE GAINS
description: The credit markets, which have chalked up sharp gains since President Nixon an nounced his package of new economic policies two weeks ago, seem poised to extend their advance.

title: CITY BANK PLANNING HOUSTON SUBSIDIARY
description: The First National City Bank following hard on the heels of Bank of Americahas dis closed plans to open en inter national banking subsidiary in Houston.

title: BristolMyers Co. Shapes Details for Zimmer Deal
description: The BristolMyers Company is working on details of its plan to acquire the privately owned Zimmer Manufacturing Com pany. Under an agreement in principle, announced this week end, BristolMyers would pay $79million in stock for Zimmer and operate it as an autono mous unit of the Bristol Lab oratories division.

title: Pants Maker Finds No Slack in Demand
description: Fortymillion pairs of pants later, Jack A. Winter, the Milwaukee pants tycoon, is still making them. Only now, with the twin popularity of pantssuits and hot pants, he is putting them out in 10 dif ferent lengths.

title: Pfizer, Inc., Elects Director
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, a general partner in the investment bank ing firm of Lazard Freres & Company, has been elected to the board of directors of Pfizer, Inc., it was announced over the weekend. Mr. Rohatyn, who is 43 years old, joined Lazard Freres in 1948 and is a director of several companies and a gov ernor of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lindsay's Burden
description: New York City Mayors have tended through the years, remarkably, almost uncannily, to personify their times.

title: COL. AUBREY M. BOBBITT
description: MANILA, Aug. 29 (AP)Col. Aubrey M. Bobbitt, commander of Clark Air Force Base, died this morning at the base hospi tal, apparently of a heart at tack. He was 51 years old.

title: Drive Fails to Halt Drug Sale in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26. Heroin remains as readily available to Americans in South Vietnam today as it was before the widely publi cized measures against its sale and use were initiated early this year.

title: MILESTONE NEARS FOR INDONESIA OIL
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 29 Indonesia is expected to be gin pumping her first offshore crude oil for export this week.

title: Cerf's Funeral Is Shifted To a Chapel at Columbia
description: The funeral service for Ben nett Cerf, book publisher and television personality, will be held tomorrow at 12:15 P.M. in St. Paul's Chapel at Colum bia University instead of at Frank E. Campbell's as pre viously announced.

title: TV: View of Prison Through Eyes of Black Men
description: Last April, National Edu cational Television's Black Journal wound up its sea son of monthly programs with an offering called Jus tice? Filmed in California, the hourlong study took a black perspective on the fate of blacks in American courts and prisons. That question mark in the title sums up and underlines the program's negative conclusions.

title: Ormandy Takes Podium After Surgery in May
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29Three months to the day of his complete hip replacement surgery, Eugene Orniandy conducted his Phila delphia Orchestra at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center last night. Nearly 10,000 people attended the performance, the second larg est crowd for the orchestra In its sixth summer here.

title: Patriots' Plunkett Excels Despite Setback by Rams
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Aug. 29 Jim Plunkett served notice this afternoon as his team, the New England Patriots, lost to the Los Angeles Rams, 3121, in the new stadium here before 53,27 1. Plunkett, the Patriots' touted rookie quarterback, served notice that he's going to be a star, a superstar, to quote David (Deacon) Jones, the Rams' allpro defensive end.

title: Miss Yurdin Bride Of Alan Lee Marx
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Miss Leona Yurdin, a lawyer with the United States Com mission on Civil Rights, was married here this afternoon to Alan Lee Marx, a lawyer with the antitrust division of the Justice Department. Rabbi Richard Yellin performed the ceremony at Temple Adas Israel.

title: Miss Simmons Wed To David Cavenaugh
description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 29 In the White Plains Com munity Church today, Miss Wendy Margot Simmons, a graduate of George Washing ton University, was married to David Newcomb Caven augh, a graduate of Oberlin College. The Rev. Dr. Peter Samson performed the ceremony.

title: Hopper's  Last Movie at Venice Avoids SonofEasyRider Tag
description: VENICE, Aug. 29  Dennis Hopper's new feature, The Last Movie, had its world pre miere at the Venice Film Fes tival tonight. Ever since his first movie, Easy Rider, struck gold and revised Hollywood thinking, there has been wide speculation as to what Mr. Hopper would do next. He re ports that his producers are disappointed.

title: Darts Subdue Stars, 54
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) Secondhalf goals by Flash Woliviera and John Kerr gave the Washington Darts a 54 victory over the St. Louis Stars today in a North American Soccer League game.

title: Graebrzer Downs Parun, Barthes Beats Riessen in Eastern Tennis Semifinals
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 29Pierre Barthes of France, outclassed in the first set, made a strong comeback to defeat topseeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., 16, 7.6, 64, 64, in the semifinals of the $25,000 Eastern grasscourt champion ship at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today.

title: Driver of Gypsy Cab Slain, Another Shot In 2 Bronx Incidents
description: A gypsy cab driver was shot to death early yesterday morn ing in the Bronx and another gypsy driver, in a separate in cident in the Bronx, was shot and seriously wounded.

title: Hearing on Heart Disease
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (UPI) A Senate committee will hold extensive hearings on heart disease Sept. 814. Sen ator George McGovern, Demo crat of South Dakota, said that his Select Committee on Nutri tion and Human Needs would pay special attention to the influence of diet on heart ail ments, along with hyperten sion, heredity, cigarette smok ing and lack of exercise.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The harbinger of each new football season has become a book, often muckraking, usually by a disaffected player, contending the game is irrelevant or dehumanizing or racist or brutal or antithetical to a rational society. These books tend to rhetorical shrillness, if they are intellectual, and nasty innuendo, if they are not. But they all basically enhance the proposition that pro football is an important force in American life. It is possible, for example, to read Dave Meggysey, believe every word and enjoy your next game even more, because you think you are also watching the decline of the West.

title: 2 Thugs Hold Up and Bind 14 Men in Chinatown Club
description: Two gunmen with paperbag masks held up 14 men in a social club in Chinatown yes terday and escaped with $1,700 after spending 45 minutes ty ing the hands of all the victims and searching them.

title: Hunting Italian Style: Many Guns, Little Game
description: SUBIACO, Italy, Aug. 29 It was still dark at 4:45 A.M. today when Duccio Fantana, who all week long sits at an accountant's desk in Rome, fired his first round into the un derbrush of the Sabine Moun tains.

title: BRENTWOOD PRIZE TO SPRINGBOARD
description: BRENTWOOD, L.I., Aug. 29  Doug Jones's Springboard captured the preliminary jump er championship at The Knoll Farms Horse Show today even though he didn't win a class.

title: Meskill Has Stormy Nine Months
description: HARTFORDIn the nearly nine months since he took of fice as first Republican Gover nor of Connecticut in 16 years, Thomas J. Meskill has steered one of the most turbulent courses in the history of Con necticut politics.

title: Romans Pray for Rain
description: ROME, Aug. 29 (AP)Pray ers for rain were raised in Ro man churches today as a pro longed drought gripped the city and much of Italy for the 72d day. Pope Paul's vicar of Rome had called for the special pray ers, saying God's intervention should be implored for the lamentable situation that raised concern above all for the harvest of crops.

title: Justices' Stock Poses a Quandary
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29The Supreme Court appears to be approaching a new ethical quandary, posed by an increas ing tendency of the Justices to disqualify themselves from cases because they own stock in corporations that might be affected by the decisions.

title: Miss Moore Wins Jumping
description: ST. GALLEN, Switzerland, Ang. 29 (Reuters)Ann Moore of Britain today won the wo men's European showjumping championship after winning the third leg on Psalm, 3 points ahead of a fellow Briton, Alison Dawes.

title: Federal School Lunch Plan Fails To Help 1.9 Million Poor Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29To day, nine months after Presi dent Nixon's target date of Thanksgiving, 1970, for extend ing the school lunch program to reach all needy children, 1.9 million children of the poor get none of its benefits.

title: Advertising:
description: For many years, the Sat urday and Sunday morning network television programs have been heavily oriented to children. And much of the sponsorship of these shows has been taken by manufac turers of the most children oriented products of all toys.

title: Alberta Oil Output Ebbs
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Aug. 29 (Canadian Press)  Crude oil production in Alberta averaged 927,524 barrels a day during the wee kended Aug. 23, the Alberta Energy Resources Con servation Board estimated to day, down from the previous week's 1,001,700 barrels a day.

title: LANDLORD'S RIGHTS IN FREEZE CLARIFIED
description: Two men attached to the Of fice of Emergency Prepared ness, the enforcement agency for the wageprice freeze, said yesterday that landlords could refuse to issue a lease on a de controlled apartment but could not increase the rent.

title: Screen: 'Samurai Assassin,' Among Best of Its Kind:Mifune Is the Unwitting Murderer of Father Feature at Bijou Was Directed by Okamoto
description: Among the countless samurai dramas to have played in the current Bijou Cinema Japanese film series, Kihachi Okamoto's "Samurai Assassin," which opened yesterday, must rank among the best. By no means great moviemaking, and overly given to that tiresomely artful manipulation of deep perspective that seems the fatal temptation of every second Japanese director, it is nevertheless a work of considerable craftsmanship with excellent performances and a rather pleasant regard for what may be done in a film that is understood as deriving from the art of fiction.Like a good many samurai dramas, "Samurai Assassin" builds upon historical event, and, as in a good many samurai dramas, the actual event doesn't matter very much. Indeed, the film is at painSatos to rewrite history as it tells how in the early spring of 1860 the Tokugawa First Minister Ii was ambushed outside the palace gate by a group of samurai working for the Mito clan and was beheaded by one Tsuruchiyo Shinno (Toshiro Mifune), an aspirant eager to test himself, who did not know that he was in fact Ii's illegitimate son.Shinno is of course fictional, but the film approaches him through the investigation of his personal history, which brushes tragedy as we learn that he intends to prove the nobility of his unknown parentage by killing his father, and then declines into bitter irony because there is finally no recognition, and he remains ignorant of what he has done to the end.Although the climactic ambush is well and modestly handled (Mifune is never outnumbered by more than 6 to 1) and the revelation of tragic potential carries considerable structural interest, "Samurai Assassin" is much the best in its earlier parts, as the Mito men investigate their strange, unkempt new member and in bits and pieces report his story back to their leader. It is a cold, wet spring as the assassins huddle near the palace gate or sit in their rooms waiting for the time to strike, and the gloom seems concentrated in the intelligent, brooding, ugly face of their leader (Yunosuko Ito), who presides almost as a spiritual presence over the unfolding story and the moods of the film.In the treatment of the exposition, and in the fine performance of Ito, the film develops a kind of reflective, low-keyed tension that does not so much pack its revelations together as allow them the time, and indeed the spaces, in which to spread out and so become the evocation of an atmosphere that is, as much as anything else, the meaning of "Samurai Assassin." For everything that is learned serves to deepen the mystery  until the pattern of discovery very nearly does conform to the intricacies of a life.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
Webster, Lab Tests Over, Will Switch to Regulars
description: The experiments are over, said Coach Alex Webster of the New York Giants. What ever he was going to learn in training camp and in the first four exhibition games, all ingloriously lost, he has learned. Now it's time to scrape the gook off the lab ofatory floor and walls, clean up the broken beakers, air out the place and get down to work.

title: Albany Beset by Vacation Doldrums
description: The halls of the Capitol in Albany, scene of the most rancorous legislative session in years, are silent these days and the relentless mimeo graph machines are no longer grinding away at full speed.

title: U.S. Pressed on Tactics in U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 Efforts to save Nationalist China's seat in the United Na tions may fail if the United States does not decide imme diately on its diplomatic tactics in the forthcoming session of the General Assembly, in the Judgment of foreign diplomats, who are friendly to the Ameri can position.

title: Computer Snag Forces OTB Into Bookie Role
description: The Offtrack Betting Cor poration played bookmaker again Saturday, the closing day at Saratoga. It booked $52,665 in wagers on three races, an exacta and the daily double.

description: WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 29 The Jewish Community Cen ter of White Plains was the setting today for the mar riage of Miss Libby Sue Git litz, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gitlitz of Brooklyn, N. Y., to Robert Hardie Yunich.

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 29 Alarmed by the deterioration here of traditional sentimental attachments to Britain, 351 prominent Australian politi cians, businessmen and others have formed an lite organiza tion to combat the drift.
