description: BACLIEU, South Vietnam, Aug. 29On this election day, monks threw the ballot box in the, river, Government troops fired on a Government helicop ter,.and a province official who tried to immolate himself was jailed on charges of attempted arson.

title: Meany Criticized by G.O.P. For Fighting Nixon Program
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) The Republican National Committee accused George Meany today of opposing Presi dent Nixon's new economic pro gram to help the Democrats and to assure himself a voice in selection of that party's Pres idential candidate.

description: STOCKHOLMWhen I went to the jail at Danbury, Conn., to visit pris oner 23742145, Daniel Berrigan, I had with me a yellow chrysanthe mum from Block Island, where he had been arrested a year earlier. It was sent by his two friends on the island.

The army said one soldier had been killed and one wounded.

title: Bridge: Circumstances Often Lead To Choice of Inferior Play

description: TOKYI, Monday, Aug. 30 Finance Minister Mikio Mizuta called on the people of Japan yesterday to endure a period of glorious suffering to over come the effects of the yen dollar crisis and become a truly strong nation.

description: Two meetings totaling eleven minutes between Red Cross officials from Seoul and Pyongyang do not amount to reunification of Korea, but the first prospect in a quartercentury that a modus vivendi may emerge on the Korean peninsula is welcome news. No bastion of the cold war has ever seemed more difficult to dismantle.

description: The New York Mets pulled the old twooutsintheninthin ing trick again yesterday and it worked for the second day in row when Tommie Agee pinch hit a single that defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 43.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29A State Department spokesman said today that the United States played no part in last Sunday's change of government in Bolivia, where antiCommu nist rebels ousted the leftist regime of Gen. Juan Jos Torres Gonzales.

description: PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 Drastic inventory cutting con tinued in steel markets last week.

description: Hank Aaron broke an other record yesterday, and while the baseball world gets excited about Ms continuing feats, the 37yearold Atlanta Braves' outfielder dismisses them, saying: It just means that I've been playing for a long time.

description: NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 29 (UPI)  Kerry Melville won her first major professional grass tennis tournament today, defeating Francoise Durr of France in the $20,000 Newport Virginia Slims final, 63, 67, 76.

title: Brush Fire Under Control
description: SANTA BARBARA, Aug. 29 (UPI)  A brush fire that burned 2,010 acres in the Los Padres National Forest was brought under control today by a force of 750 men. A force of 200 men was left to tend the stillburning fire. It'll probably be a week before it's completed out, the Forest Service said.

title: Girl, 12, Seeks Paper Route
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP)The Pennsylvania Human Relations Commission has served a complaint to the Al lentown CallChronicle news papers for refusing to give 12yearold girl a paper route. The complaint, filed by the Rev. John D. Ickes on behalf of his daughter, Joan, contends the newspapers discriminate on the basis of sex. The news paper officials say they are just obeying the state child labor law.

title: G. M. Sees Record Sales For the 1972 Model Year
description: The General Motors Corpora tion projected this weekend rec ord sales of passenger cars in the 1972 model year of more than 10 million, including im ports, with 10 million clear ly possible if consumer confi dence is restored in the months ahead.

Dr. Kenneth D. Arn of Dayton re ceived the award at the con gress on occupational health sponsored by the American Medical Association.

title: 2,000 Elderly Found Lacking Care or Housing Yearly
description: A special task force, formed three years ago to find alter native care for feeble elderly patients no longer admitted to state mental hospitals, es timates that 2,000 of such per sons a year are unable to find care or housing.

title: Associated Press
description: DONG HUNG TAN, South Vietnam, Aug. 29M. Sgt. Le Dinh Quang, who is not a timid man, was uneasy today in the voting booth, one of dozens set up in, the Quangtrum basic training center. Although the sergeant is in his mid40's and is an experienced soldier, he felt overwhelmed as a voter in the elections for the National Assembly.

The pro gram, one of the VideoEx change series, was divided into two parts, each performed by Miss Dean. In the first she danced in silence, and in the second she was accompanied by Steve Chambers, pianist.

title: 2 U.S. Attacks in North
description: SAIGON, Monday, Aug. 30 (AP)The United States com mand today announced two American air strikes inside the northern half of the demilitar ized zone, which straddles the border between North and South Vietnam. In one case two F4 fighterbombers op erating in Laos attacked an. antiaircraft site that had fired; on them, the command said. In the second strike, Ameri can artillery blasted a rocket site that had been firing into South Vietnam.

title: In East Hampton, a Serious Antiwar Gathering
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 29The committee was de termined that it wasn't going to turn into, or be labeled, one of those radical chic parties.

title: MISSION TO HANOI LISTED BY SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Monday, Aug. 30 The Soviet Union announced this morning that President Nikolai V. Podgorny would head a party and Government dele gation to North Vietnam in early October.

title: GEORGE R. BECKHAM
description: George Robert Beckham of Canton, Mass., a former pas senger agent of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad who had re cently operated the Boston Travel Service, died Saturday in Canton. He was 67 years old.

title: Private Power vs. the Public
description: The notice given by Secretary of the. Treasury Connally that industry and labor must reconcile themselves to living with a new concept of public responsibility after the present ninetyday wageprice freeze can scarcely have come as a surprise to either power center. Even under a President firmly committed to free market prin ciples, the Government has an inescapable obligation to protect the total community against excesses by big business or big unions in areas where they exercise monopoly control over vital services.

title: INMATE'S ABDUCTION IS FOILED BY SHERIFF
description: BAXLEY, Ga., Aug. 29 (UPI) A husky Georgia sheriff, who though unarmed took a shotgun away from a wouldbe kidnapper and foiled an at tempt by an armed group to abduct a mass murder suspect, held six men today he said had taken part in the plot. More arrests are expected, he said.

title: Arson Blamed in Ohio Fire
description: CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (UPI) Arson was blamed for a fire that knocked out telephone service for 100,000 persons and temporarily forced several television and radio stations off the air last night. A spokes man for Ohio Bell Telephone said that the fire had destroyed ?? telephone cables.

title: U.S. INCOME AND G.N.P. EXPECTED TO GROW
description: Americans can expect higher personal income and a better standard of living by the end of the decade, according to a re port released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SAMUEL C. WHITMAN
description: Samuel C. Whitman, a law yer, who was vice president and a director of the Morris (N.Y.) National Bank, died yes terday in Booth Memorial Hos pital, Flushing, Queens. He would have been 75 years old Wednesday. His home was at 16401 Cryders Lane, Beech hurst, Queens.

title: WEAVER 11 BEATS RODGERS IN FINAL BY 6SHOT MARGIN
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Aug. 29 After six years without vic tory, DeWitt Weaver, a 31 yearold golf professional from Atlanta, became the national matchplay champion today.

description: MOSCOW, Aug. 29A young Soviet physicist who had for eign friends, listened to over seas broadcasts, and who read and distributed underground publications, was sentenced last week to eight years in prison camp for attempting to leave the Soviet Union with Swiss passport.

description: We'll have to cancel the show if the audience can't behave, said the young woman master of ceremonies, talking into a rubber leaf.

description: HONOLULU, Aug. 28Waikiki restaurants serve New York steaks and fresh oysters on the half shell. Islanders find their customary weekly 25 pound bag of rice plentiful on supermarket shelves, although some familiar brands of can ned foods are missing.

Rabbi Reuben Slonim performed the ceremony at the Sutton Place Hotel.

description: The busiest man with the largest responsibilities in Washington's new John F. Kennedy Center for the Per forming Arts, which is swarming with busy people preparing for its opening weeks next month, is unques tionably Julius Rudel, the mu sic director.

title: Carolina Schools Guarded
description: HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Aug. 29 (AP)National Guard men were ordered today by Gov. Robert W. Scott to pro tect Henderson County schools against what the police believe is an arsonist. Three schools in the county have been dam aged by fires during the last two weeks, and the police said they believed all fires were deliberately set.

Percy, Republican of Illinois, said to day that tension on the Indian Pakistani subcontinent poses the gravest single threat to peace in Asia. He made the statement on arriving at Dacca, the East Pakistani capital, from India on a twoday factfinding mission.

title: Invisible Federal Parole
description: The inadequacies and mysteries of the Federal parole system are underscored in the casesworlds apartof James R. Hoffa, the former Teamsters Union president who is serving time for jury tampering and pension fund fraud, and Philip and Daniel Berrigan, the Catholic priests imprisoned for destroying draft board records.

title: Books of The Times
description: Although they are Unlike in significant ways, both these novels are severely struc tured, controlled in their craftsmanship and muted in their tone. And in both, the characters move with a certain fatalism to their end. There is nothing instinctive, wild or adventuresome about either book and neither will please those who want some thing with more surface excitement, some thing jazzier and keyed up. The authors are so intent on keeping their eyes on the ball that they permit nothing to come be tween the reader and what they are saying. Everything, consequently, is solid: the peo ple, the setting, the situations and the prob lems that derive from them, though these latter could not be more contemporary and immediate. There is one big difference, though. All of these devices work in the case of James McConkey's book; they don't in the case of Elizabeth Taylor's.

title: Kenneth H. Zabriskie, 71, Electrical Concern Aide
description: SUFFERN, N.Y., Aug. 29  Kenneth H. Zabriskie, retired treasurer of WatsonFlagg, New York electrical contractors, died yesterday in Good Samaritan Hospital He was 71 years old and lived here and in Boca Grande, Fla.

title: Title Underwriters Lose Appeal for Rate Increase
description: The State Insurance Depart ment said yesterday that it had rejected a request of the New York Board of Title Underwrit ers for a 29 per cent rate in crease on title insurance be cause of the wageprice freeze.

title: OPPOSITION MAKES IMPRESSIVE GAINS IN VIETNAM VOTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 31  AntiGov ernment candidates scored some impressive gains Sunday in South Vietnam's elections for a new lower house; but President Nguyen Van Thieu's supporters maintained a com fortable majority.

title: Porter Arrives in Paris
description: PARIS, Aug. 30 (Reuters) William J. Porter, the new United States chief negotiator at the Vietnam peace talks, arrived here tonight. He came direct from Washington.

title: TEXAN WILL ABIDE BY FRAUD VERDICT
description: DALLAS, Aug. 30Frank W. Sharp, a Houston real estate promoter, said today that he would not defend himself in stock fraud suit brought by the Securities and Exchange Com mission.

title: PRESIDENT TO MEET H.E.W. CHIEF TODAY
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30President Nixon will meet here tomorrow with Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to discuss what the White House called departmental controls.

title: Title Law Starts Next July 1
description: Motorvehicle owners must have a certificate of title under a new law going into effect July 1, 1972, on 1973 and subsequent models. The year 1972 was omitted in an article yesterday.

title: 100 Invade and Plunder School In Ocean Hill, Then Fight Police
description: A crowd of more than 100 people vandalized and looted a grade school in the Ocean HillBrownsville school district early today.

title: City Buys a 28Foot Boat to Help Scoop Debris From the Harbor
description: A complaint from the Con solidated Edison Company has resulted in the city buy ing a $47,137 waterpollution control boat that could cut down on the amount of de bris in New York Harbor.

title: Treasury Bills' Yields Fall at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  Yields on United States Treas ury bills fell in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm se curities.

title: Smooth Vote Pleases U.S.
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP)The Western White House expressed pleasure to day over the fact that the South Vietnamese election appears to have gone off smoothly. But there was no comment on the results.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When a fellow is battling for the most prestigious tennis championships, the one at Wimbledon, everyone assumes that he imprisons himself within a shell of concentration that walls out all extraneous thoughts. It isn't necessarily true, however.

title: Labor's Case for a Profits Freeze
description: The tradeunion movement's indict ment of President Nixon's new eco nomic policy Tests squarely on one fact: it is demonstrably unfair.

title: Youth, 19, Gets 25Year Term In 13 Robbery and Rape Cases
description: Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Andrew R. Tyler sen tenced a 19year old youth to 119 years in prison, but ordered the terms to run concurrently for up to 25 years, for his re cent conviction on 13 counts of robbery and burglary with in tent to commit rape.

title: Giants Recall Willoughby
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 (UPI)The San Francisco Giants filled their National League playoff roster today by recalling a righthanded pitcher, Jim Willoughby, from Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Rinfret Predicts Even Bigger Tax Cuts
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, sometime Presidential adviser, economist and raconteur extraordinary, predicted yesterday that Con gress would enact substantially more liberal investment tax credits and personal income tax cuts than proposed by Presi dent Nixon in his new eco nomic, program on Aug. 15.

title: Hambletonian Adds a Lost Starter for Tomorrow's Race
description: DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30 A mislaid check for $2,000 nearly kept an owner from real izing his life's dream  having a starter in the Hambletonian, which will be held here Wednesday.

title: A New Technique to Reconstitute Frozen Blood Cells Is Devised
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  De velopment of an improved and more economical process for reconstituting deep freezepre served red blood cells that are free of hepatitis and other possible transfusion hazards was reported today by an American Red Cross re searcher.

title: Housing Complex Slated For Seward Park in '73
description: Three 26story buildings providing 600 low and mod erateincome apartments will make up the latest addition to the Seward Park Urban Renewal Area, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday.

title: 3D DAY OF ATTACKS BY FOE REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 31 (AP)The allied commands reported yes terday, that enemy forces staged shelling attacks and ground thrusts in widespread areas of South Vietnam for thel third day.

title: CHARLES B. ALLEN
description: Charles B. Allen, who retired last year as head of the libretto department of the Metropolitan Opera Association, died yester day at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. He was 75 years old and lived at 210 West 19th Street and Chap paqua, N. Y.

title: GRAENER TAKES EASTERNNET TITLE
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 30  Clark Graebner of New York and petite Chris Evert of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., won the singles championships with onesided victories today in the $25,000. Eastern grasscourt tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Market Place: Western Union: A Turnaroud?
description: It was about 10 P.M. sev eral weeks ago and the caller wanted to send a telegram. The telephone numbers list ed in the Manhattan directory suggested quite a choice, but unfortunately the first three or four numbers dialed brought no response.

title: FILM FETE SET FOR LOS ANGELES
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 The First Los Angeles Interna tional Film Exposition will be held Nov. 4 to 14 at Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood.

title: Fresh From the Seas, A Fish Escapes Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)The Cost of Living Council turned today to doggerel to explain its pol icy on which types of fish and seafood are subject to price ceilings and which are not:

title: Hunt Sells His Food Business, Blaming Losses and Thievery
description: DALLAS, Aug. 30H. L. Hunt, wealthy oil man, has gotten out of the food business after a 10year losing venture in the field.

title: Lazar Insists City Run Airport Taxi Dispatching
description: The city's Taxi Commis sioner, Michael J. Lazar, said yesterday that the Port of New York Authority had thwarted the city's attempts to take over the taxi dispatching services at Kennedy International Airport and to set up a new dispatch ing service at La Guardia Air port.

title: Black Israelites Challenging Israel's Policies
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 30The question of who may claim full rights to settle in Israel is being tested by a group of American born blacks who call them selves Israelites and who charge that the authorities are dis criminating against them.

title: Museum Strikers Thwart Unloading, But Art Is Stored
description: Striking professional and oth er personnel of the Museum of Modern Art yesterday thwarted attempts by movers to unload a collection of museum paintings for storage at the Santini Broth ers warehouse at 449 West 49th Street, which has been a mu seum depot for years. Truck men, respecting a picket line formed by the strikers, moved the valuable cargo to other storage for safety.

title: Palmer House Is Sued
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (UPI) A $1.25million damage suit was filed in Circuit Court to day against the Palmer House Hotel in connection with the July, 1970, stabbing of two JapaneseAmerican girls. The suit was filed by Carol Ranko Yamada, who was seriously in jured, and Mabel Okubo. mother of Evelyn Okubo, who was stabbed to death by an unknown attacker.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times of Aug. 12 published brief but important OpEd article by Prof: John K. Fairbank, under the title Taipei Can Coexist With Peking. The facts are cogently stated, but fear that some may see an excuse for American disengagement, overlooking Mr. Fairbank's final admonition.

title: Australian Wool Unit Plans To Hold at '70 Price Level
description: The Australian Wool Com mission will hold prices to the average level in force at the close of last season, W. J. Vines, acting chairman, said yesterday in Melbourne, Au stralia.

title: CARDS DOWN METS ON RUN IN 7TH, 32
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30Lou Brock, the onetime arithmetic teacher who now steals bases for a living, led the St. Louis Cardinals to a 32 victory over New York tonight that dropped the Mets 11 games out of first place.

title: Alcoa Plans to Sell Plant
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would seek a buyer for the land and buildings of its obsolete plant at New Kensing ton, Pa., about 40 miles north of Pittsburgh. Aluminumfabri cating operations at New Ken sington have been suspended since March, but the nearby machine and research divisions will be retained and will con tinue to operate.

title: RED CROSS OFFICIALS MEET AGAIN IN KOREA
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Aug. 30Red Cross officials of North and South Korea met tact for talks to arrange com munications and reunions be tween families separated in the here today for the third time in 10 days in preparatory con two parts of the country.

title: Benguet Consolidated Profit Up 29.6%
description: Benguet Consolidated, Inc., achieved a 29.6 per cent in crease in earnings for the sec ond quarter and a 24 per cent rise for the half year, the com pany reported yesterday.

title: 3 IN BRONX ATTACK A POLICEWOMAN
description: Three men dragged a Narcot ics Division policewoman into a Bronx alley and robbed her of $135 yesterday afternoon before she was rescued by three plainclothesmen.

title: 3dMarket Broker Sharply Criticizes The Martin Report
description: A leading Wall Street brok er charged yesterday that the report by William McChesney Martin Jr. on the securities industry had ignored import ant facts and had failed to produce the right solutions to the industry's problems.

title: France Is Under Pressure to Let the Franc Float
description: LONDON, Aug. 30France, the only major country still ad hering to a fixed exchange rate, came under renewed mar ket pressure today to let the franc float upward against the dollar.

title: Production of Steel Up 15.4% in Week; More Cutbacks Set
description: Steel production rose 15.4 per cent last week from the week before, as the industry continued to move up toward normal operating levels. Pro duction in the week ended Sat urday was 65.3 per cent of the 1967 average.

title: I.B.M. Starts EarlyRetirement Plan
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has be gun a special earlyretirement program for its employes in the United States in an effort to correct a temporary imbal ance in our personnel re resources.

title: HENDERSON JURY HEARS 8 EXG,I.'S
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Aug. 30 Former members of the in fantry unit that swept through the village of Mylai 4 said today that Col. Oran K. Hen derson asked only a few ques tions about the mass slaying of civilians two days after it occurred.

title: 14 Inmates Fail in Attempt To Flee Narcotics Center
description: Fourteen young inmates of the Arthur Kill Rehabilitation Narcotics Center in Tottenville, S.I., made an abortive attempt yesterday to escape from the minimum security facility.

title: Zambia's Leader Loses a Friend and Gains a Rival
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Aug. 30Since boyhood Presi dent Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia and Simon M. Kap wepwe have been close friends and allies. They fought for Zambian independence togeth er, and Mr. Kapwepwe rose to become Vice President under Mr. Kaunda.

title: Robbins Wins at Marbelhead
description: MARBLEHEAD, Mass., Aug. 30 (AP)Knox Robbins of Mar blehead won the opening race today in the world Internation al OneDesign Class sailing championships.

title: Chiefs. Defeat Jets, 2116, in Seesaw Struggle
description: KANSAS CITY, Aug. 30  Matt Snell suffered undeter mined damage to his right knee tonight as the New York Jets lost to the Kansas City Chiefs, 2116, in a nationally televised exhibition game influenced by a total of seven interceptions. Larry Grantham, with two of the Jets' five interceptions, scored their only touchdown on an 8yard return.

title: Dominicans Are Worried Over OneMan Government
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, Aug. 29The Do minican Republic is enjoying rare combination of economic growth and political stability, but there is widespread uncer tainty about the future because the Government, though it has different branches, is actually concentrated in one man.

title: Questions and Answers on the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Following is the tenth set of official questions and answers issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on specific issues in the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Group Protests Plan on Health Offices
description: An angry group of commu nity leaders representing 200 organizations around the city warned Health Services Admin istrator Gordon Chase yester day that the operations of 30 planned local health offices would be blocked unless the offices were run by the com munities they are supposed to serve.

title: Moscow Announces Kosygin Will Visit Algeria in October
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 30The So viet Union announced today that, Premier Aleksei N. Kosy gin would visit Algeria in October, underscoring Mos cow's continuing interest in the Mediterranean area.

title: GABLE TAKES TITLE IN WORLD WRESTLING
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Aug. 30 (Reuters)Dan Gable of Water loo, Iowa, won the lightweight title in the world freestyle wrestling championships today but three of the first six titles were won by wrestlers from the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nathan F. Leopold of 1924 Murder Case Is Dead
description: Nathan F. Leopold, who with Richard Loeb kidnapped and murdered 14yearold Bobby Franks in 1924 in a vain at tempt to commit the perfect crime, died of a heart ailment Sunday night in San Juan, P.R. He was 66 years old.

title: Soviet Common Market
description: Moscow has been gleeful in recent weeks over the disruption of Western international cooperation in mone tary exchange. The voices in West Europe and Japan expressing resentment at President Nixon's unilateral decision to float the dollar obviously delight Kremlin leaders, always eager to cheer along divisive struggle among the Western allies.

title: Cleaning Up the Police
description: Any lingering doubt that Police Commissioner Murphy means business in his campaign to root out corruption in the city's police force was erased by his decision yesterday to pass over dozens of senior officials and choose Donald F. Cawley, the youngest inspector in the department, as direct commander of 20,000 patrolmen.

title: Bus Outings for Blacks Test Connecticut's Beach Rules
description: OLD LYME, Conn.  The school bus loaded with black children from Hartford rolled past the private beach sign and stopped at the foot of Saltaire Drive.

title: Prime Time for Late Show Look
description: Faces have been somewhat slower than clothes in adopt ing the Late Late Show look, but now cherryred lipstick, lots of rouge and thinner eyebrows seem to be catch ing on. Beauty houses are dropping their favorite nine teensixties wordnatural and encouraging the sort of face painting mother used to do when she was a girl.

title: KOLIUS IS AHEAD IN TITLE SAILING
description: SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 30John Kolius, a 20 yearold University of Houston junior, won two of the first three races in the Mallory Cup series for the men's North American sailing championship out of the New Bedford Yacht Club today.

title: Defection Attempt Balked
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Aug. 30A jet fighter instructor of the Pakistani air force tried unsuccessfully to defect 10 days ago by attempting to fly a twoseat trainer aircraft to In dia, the Pakistani Government said last night.

title: How the Second World War Began: II
description: MOSCOWOn March 15, 1939, Hitler flouted the Munich agreement and enslaved Czechoslovakia. Simulta neously, the Nazis floated rumors that Rumania was now in peril.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) An F.T.C. hearing examiner ruled today that the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has made exaggerated safety claims for its tires, even though they met or surpassed Government standards.

title: Gypsy Moths Causing Record Damage
description: Aerial and ground surveys completed in recent days show that gypsy moth devastation in several states has been far more severe this summer than ever before and that the pest is spreading with alarming rapid ity.

title: Conservative Party Is Apparent Victor In Alberta Election
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press)  Incom plete returns in the Alberta election tonight indicated de feat of the Social Credit gov ernment, with Progressive Con servatives threatening to be come the first oldline party in a century to rule the province.

title: London March for Jackson
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (UPI) Nearly 1,500 people marched peacefully from Trafalgar Square to the United States Embasasy today to hand in a petition protesting the death of George Jackson, an American black militant, a police spokes man said.

title: City Master Plan A ttacked By Group as inadequate
description: The master plan for New York City, which recommends municipal expenditures of $52billion in the next 10 years, lacks most of the substance of city planning, according to a critique published yesterday by the American Institute of Planners' New York Metro politan Chapter.

title: Fay Paces 5.5 Sailors
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 30  Ernest Fay of Houston re tained the lead for the United States 5.5Meter championship today after sailing his Sundance to a third place in the fourth race of the regatta. The series will end tomorrow with one race on Long Island Sound off the Stamford Yacht Club.

title: Advertising: MiniCigar Beats Broadcast Ban
description: It sort of looks like a cigarette (85 millimeters long and filter tipped), is packaged like a cigarette (20 to a soft pack) and it has a cigarettelike name (Winchester). The big difference, however, is that Winchesters can be promoted on television and radio because they are little cigars which like other noncigarette tobacco products, do not come under the eightmonthold broadcast ban.

title: 4 Union Officials Are Convicted Of Collusion With Employers
description: Top officials of a luncheon ette workers union were con victed in Federal Court here yesterday on charges that they had received illegal payments from employers.

title: Alabama Cuts 33,000 From Welfare Rolls
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.More than 33,000 people, most of them Negroes, have been cut off the welfare rolls in Ala bama in the last four months in a cutback that parallels a growing national trend to re duce aid to the poor.

title: U.S. Says Troop Withdrawals Are Running Ahead of Schedule
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30  The White House said today that United States troop withdrawals from South Viet nam were proceeding ahead of schedule, but declined to con firm reports that the President was aiming to cut the troop level to 150,000 by December.

title: CANADA IS EAGER FOR NIXON'S VISIT
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30Ottawa welcomed today the United States announcement that Pres ident Nixon would make a state visit to Canada. There was some disappointment, however, that the President did not plan to come until the spring.

title: Confederation Aimed at Foe, Sadat Says
description: CAIRO, Aug. 30President Anwar elSadat said tonight that a union of Egypt, Syria and Libya, which is to take effect after plebiscites Wednes day, was intended primarily as an Arab bastion against Israel for a conflict that might last 20, 30 or even 50 years.

title: Arab Evacuations In Gaza's Camps Ended by Israelis
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 30The Is raeli military government has stopped evacuating Arab refu gees from their camps in the Gaza Strip, the defense forces radio station said today.

title: Desegregation in North
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  This fall, for the first time, a substantial amount of school desegregation is scheduled to take place in cities outside the South and the Border States.

title: Where Surgeons Reconstruct Bodiesand Livesin Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 This is not a good place to ask ques tions.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: StoryTelling Session
description: KILLDEVIL HILLS, N.C. In the bleak light of a gray dawn, white scrolls of water unrolling, surfdriven by a strong northeast winds were all that could be seen from the oceanfront windows of the Sea Ranch Motel.

title: S.E.C. BACKS PLAN OF FUND ADVISER
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it was legal for a mutual fund adviser that is also a broker dealer to receive money in the form of other dealers' conces sions on the sales of mutual fund shares.

title: Procter & Gamble Agrees to End Use Of Certain Contests
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The Federal Trade Commis sion announced today that the Procter & Gamble Company of Cincinnati had signed a con sent order against the continu ation of certain contests that had been used to advertise its products.

title: Nixon Issues Proclamation
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI)President Nixon to day designated Sept. 17 as Citizenship Day and the week beginning Sept. 23 as Constitu tion Week to commemorate the signing of the Constitution in 1787. In a special proclama tion, Mr. Nixon said the mean ing of the spirit of the Con stitution has been dramatically renewed this year with the passage of the 26th Amend ment, granting full voting rights to those between 18 and 21 years of age.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Rye, N.Y., Aug. 30  Belle Haven Club of Greenwich, Conn., won the Malcolm Mc Intyre Trophy for the second year in a row today by defeat ing Larchmont Yacht Club.

title: Shut Eye Totes 135 Pounds to Victory
description: The Floridabred Shut Eye of the KevHill Stable won the $33,800 Fall Highweight Handi cap, the feature race on the welcome home card at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Stottlemyre Is Sidelined; To Miss Yank Mound Turn
description: Mel Stottlemyre's injury, which prevented him from gaining his 14th victory on Sunday, was diagnosed yester day as a mild pull of an abdominal muscle just below the right ribs.

title: State of Alert Lifted
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Aug. 31 (Reuters)The general state of alert imposed for one week on American troops in Vietnam was lifted at dawn today, an American military spokesman said. Individual units could be kept on alert if their command er decided it was necessary, but the 9,000 American service men in the Saigon area were free to leave their barracks for the first time.

title: Farm Prices Unchanged for 3d Month
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) For the third consecutive month national average farm prices remained unchanged, the Agriculture Department re ported today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30The law now provides that no one may con tribute more than $5,000 in any one year to a candidate for Federal office, and that no political committee shall collect or spend more than $3 million in any one year. But everyone who engages in, writes about or has any thing else to do with politics knows that these statutes are as violated as the Ten Commandments, and far more systematically.

title: NORWAY SEEKING FAVOR FROM E.E.C.
description: OSLO, Norway, Aug. 30 Norway's minority Socialist Government is appealing to members of the European Eco nomic Community to grant spe cial terms that would overcome the lastditch opposition of most farmers and fishermen to Norwegian membership.

title: LOWER RATES SEEN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The credit market, ap parently convinced that in terest rates will not rise, in creased its bets yesterday that they will work still lower.

title: MORALES, STASIAK WRESTLE TO DRAW
description: Pedro Morales of Puerto Rico, retained the World Wide Wres tling Federation championship Jest night by gaining a draw with Stan Stasiak of Buzzard Creek, Ore., at Madison Square Garden.

title: Germans End Minesweeping
description: BONN, Aug. 30 (AP)  The West German navy announced today that its minesweepers have abandoned the clearing of World War II mines from coastal waters. The Defense Ministry said in a statement that some of the 10,000 mines laid in North Sea and Baltic Sea coastal areas still remain. But tests showed the batteries had deteriorated and no longer provided enough current for detonation.

title: AUGUST SALES UP AT 6 BIG STORES
description: Strong initial consumer in terest in backtoschool needs and a good response to home furnishings promotions in Au gust helped major department stores in the New York area offset a virtual loss of last Fri day's business that was caused by a heavy downpour.

title: Alaska Atom Test Upheld as Judge Refuses to Halt It
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  A Federal district judge dismissed today a suit brought by eight conservation and antinuclear testing groups that had sought to halt the underground test on Oct. 2 of a fivemegaton nuclear warhead on Amchitka Island, Alaska.

title: OFFICIAL IN ULSTER ASKS BORDER CLOSING
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  A Govern ment security minister called today for Northern Ireland's border with Ireland to be sealed in the wake of a frontier am bush in which a British soldier was killed.

title: M'CRACKEN SAYS FREEZE WILL ADD 500,000 JOBS IN 72
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  The chairman of the Presi dents' Council of Economic Ad visers predicted today that the Administration's new economic program would add a net of $15billion to the gross na tional product next year and create about 500,000 new jobs.

title: Withdrawal of 42,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 (UPI)The United States command will withdraw 42,000 American soldiers from Vietnam during a threemonth period beginning Wednesday to meet President Nixon's Dec. 1 deadline for cutting troop strength to 184,000, military sources said today.

title: POLLUTION CURBS ORDERED BY STATE
description: Standard Brands, Inc., the food processing and packaging concern, was ordered by the State Supreme Court yesterday to begin construction by to morrow of a water pollution abatement facility at its Charles Point plant in Peeks kill.

title: Report on Laos Fighting
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 30 (Agence FrancePresse)Some 50 Laotian soldiers were killed in fighting Wednesday in Pak song in southern Laos, a well informed source said here to day.

title: School Buses in Pontiac, Mich., Are Destroyed by Fire Bombs
description: PONTIAC, Mich., Aug. 30 (AP)Ten school buses were firebombed tonight in this city, where schools are scheduled to open next week under a court ordered integration plan.

title: Notes on People
description: Roy Wilkins celebrated his 70th birthday yesterday and took the occasion to reflect on his 41 years as a member and leader of the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People.

title: Patrol Chief Typifies Murphy's New Top Aides
description: When Patrick V. Murphy replaced Howard R. Leary as Police Commissioner last Oc tober, he let it be known that a new generation of top com manders would soon be run ning the city's 32,000man police force. The Commis sioner's appointment of Don ald F. Cawley yesterday as chief of the 20,000man pa trol force was another major step in fulfilling that pledge.

title: NEW CACHE LINKED TO ILLINOIS AIDE
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 30 (AP)The Illinois Bureau of Investigation said today it had found a new cache of records belonging to Paul Powell, the late Illinois Secretary of State. Included in the four boxes were bundles of uncashed checks for license plates.

title: Firm Draws Suspension
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission today suspended the brokerdealer registration of the I.R.E. Investors Corporation, Hicksville, N.Y., for two weeks, charging the firm violated Fed eral security laws.

title: Council's Members Urged to Help Drive To Disqualify Bundy
description: Richard A. Falk, professor of international law at Princeton University, has appealed to members of the Council on For eign Relations to support a move to disqualify William P. Bundy from becoming editor of the association's journal, For eign Affairs.

title: 43 Hurt in Australian Crash
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 30 (Reuters)  Forty Sydney schoolgirls and three nuns were injured in a twobus crash in the Snowy Range today when one of the buses plunged down a 30  foot embankment and caught fire.

title: Fractured Ankle Puts Miss Wade Out of Open
description: Virginia Wade of Britain, the thirdseeded player, with drew from the United States Open tennis championships yesterday because of a frac tured left ankle.

title: Holdup Man Slays Youth
description: An 18yearold youth was shot and killed yesterday on Eighth Avenue near West 127th street Street by a man appar ently attempting to hold him up the police reported. The victim was identified as Kevin Russ of 225 West 129th Strett.

title: John Lotz Cards 289 to Win Concord Golf by 2 Shots
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 30John Lotz of Hay ward, Calif., 30 years old and the father of a 3weekold son he has not seen yet because of tour commitments, won the $60,000 Liggett & MyersCon cord open satellite golf tourna ment today by two shots.

title: 1,000 Policemen at Rites For Sergeant Found Shot
description: Sgt. Joseph V. Morabito, a quiet, 29yearold bachelor found shot to death in his car last week, was buried yester day with an inspector's funeral attended by Mayor Lindsay, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and more than 1,000 of his fellow policemen.

title: U.S. Agency Issues Rules On Auto Pollution Control
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) The Environmental Protec tion Agency issued regulations today to require auto makers to tell car owners how to main tain air pollution control sys tems on their cars.

title: Thieu's New Chance
description: The outcome of the parliamentary election in South Vietnam last weekend provides the United States with a new opportunity to assure a genuine choice in the Oct. 3 presidential election, in which President Thieu now is running alone against himself.

title: Chief of Patrolmen Donald Francis Cawley
description: In the middle of last win ter, Police Commissioner Pat rick V. Murphy dispatched tall, solidly built police of ficer to Los Angeles to study a police department that had built a reputation for aggres sive action against internal corruption.

title: Advertising:
description: Charles S. Mill, pink cheeked and gray haired, has acquired that allimpor tant talent of an association headhe can find a silver lining almost anywhere.

title: Israelis Fire at Egypt's Jets
description: TEL AVIV, Aug. 30 (AP) Israeli antiaircraft bati?? ??es fired at Egyptian fighterb??m hers flying over Israeli fortifica tions at the Suez Canal today, the military command an nounced.

title: $4.3Million Loss Reported by I.O.S. For 1971 First Half
description: GENEVA, Aug. 30 (Reuters) The deficit of I.O.S., Ltd., in the first half of 1971 narrowed to $4.3million from $25.8million in the first half of 1970, Robert E. Slater, the company's presi dent, said today.

title: Envoy of Pakistan Calls U.S. Arms Aid Since '65 Negligible
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP Ambassador Agha Hilaly of Pakistan said today he could not understand the demand in the United States for an end to all American military and economic aid to his country.

title: OBSERVER
description: Does anyone out there remember who it was several years back who notified the world, with some show of authority, that the prettiest word in the English language was cellar. door?

title: It's in a Ghost Town Miles From Nowhere, but What a Meal
description: LANDER, Wyo.,To get to what may be the most re mote dining adventure in the United States, you take a road that climbs through spectacular mountains to an obscure turnoff on the sum mit, some 30plus miles south of here.

title: Most Pupils Returning
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30Most of the South's children went back to desegregated schools today, and, in quiet contrast to past years, their first day of studies passed without major incident.

title: Judge Schweitzer to Submit To Questioning Tomorrow
description: State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer will submit to further questioning tomorrow by investigators for the New York Court on the Judiciary, his lawyer, Myron J. Greene, said yesterday.

title: Banker and Wife Hostages
description: MIAMI, Aug. 30 (AP)A bank president and his wife were seized in their home to day by a gunman who led the authorities on a 30mile chase to Miami, where he surrendered without a fight, the authorities said. The Federal Bureau of In vestigation said Mr. and Mrs. Paul Losner were unharmed. Mr. Losner is president and board chairman of the First National Bank of Homestead, Fla. Agents identified the sus pect as Dennis Clyde Bennett, 20. They said he had forced the Losners to give him $100, 000.

title: Roundup: Downing's 16th Confirms Dodger Trade
description: Life has changed for Al Downing in Los Angeles.

title: Bridge: Silence May Prove Golden For Analytical Opponents
description: The fact that the op ponents remain silent when they might be expected to bid will sometimes furnish a valuable clue in the play of the hand. It did so on the diagramed deal, which con tributed to a victory Sunday for Ron Rubin of Maple wood, N. J., Bernard Chazen of Fort Lee, N. J., Matt Granovetter of Newark and Allen Cokin of Providence, R. I., in a Swiss team event at Hazlet, N. J.

title: Worker Electrocuted
description: A 46yearold construction worker was electrocuted yester day in a freakish accident in Jamaica, Queens, the police said. The dead man was iden tified as Thomas Demeco of 8810 239th Street, Bellerose, an employee of the Ralph Tom asetti Construction Company of Brooklyn, which was construct ing sewers at 169th Street and 114 Avenue. Mr. Demeco was holding a pipe that was stuck in the ground when a cranelike device swung close to an over head electric wire. Witnesses said electricity jumped the wire to the boom to the pipe Mr. Demeco was holding.

title: Pontiac Offering EnergyAbsorbing Bumper for '72
description: DETROIT, Aug. 30  The General Motors Corporation's Pontiac Division announced today that there would be an energy  absorbing bumper on all its 1972 standard  sized cars, a forerunner of the bump er to come on the automobile.

title: AIR FORCE RACISM CHARGED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30A human relations team of the Air Training Command has submitted to its commanding general a strong indictment of leadership at Air Force training bases, especially on racial mat ters on and off base.

title: Uganda Reports One Killed In Tanzania Border Clash
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 30 (Reuters)President Idi Amin took command of the Ugandan Army today as fresh fighting was reported 200 miles south west of here on the border with Tanzania.

title: Canoeists Finish Tour of City Waters
description: A great blue heron rose from the tall grass of Ruffle Bar in Jamaica Bay just after dawn yesterday and circled the marsh with great lazy pulls of his threefootlong wings.

title: Sultan of Oman Offers Peace To Rebels but Prepares Drive
description: MUSCAT, Oman, Aug. 21 While his Britishofficered army is preparing an offensive against the Communistled guerrillas in the mountains of Dhofar, Sultan Qabus bin Said, the ruler of Oman, has outlined his plan to end the rebellion peacefully.

title: WORKMEN SEIZE 2 PLANTS IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 30 Workers seized two important industrial plants today and So cialist labor leaders threatened to occupy the telephone com pany, 70 per cent of which is owned by the International Tele phone and Telegraph Company of the United States.

title: Test Missile Downs Target
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (Reu ters)A Spartan interceptor missile successfully shot down a target warhead Friday in a test of the Safeguard antiballis tic missile system, the Defense Department announced today. It said the Spartan missile passed close enough to the tar get to have destroyed it if the missile had been armed with a nuclear warhead.

title: CANADA'S G.N.P. UP IN SECOND QUARTER
description: OTTAWA, Aug. 30 (Canadian Press)Canada's gross national product, the total value of all goods and services produced by the country, accelerated sharp ly in April, May and June to reach an annual rate of $91.01 billion, the Government's sta tistics bureau reported today.

title: ANNAPOLIS CREW LEADS JUNIOR SAIL
description: OXFORD, Md., Aug. 30 Charlie Scott, the skipper for the Annapolis Yacht Club en try, captured the opening race today in the annual Sears Cup competition.

title: FLOODING REPORTED IN NORTH VIETNAM
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. (Agence FrancePresse)  Flood waters in North Vietnam have risen to an unprecedented level, Nhan Dan, the Commun ist party paper, reported today.

title: Coast Court Questions the School Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 The California State Supreme Court, in a 6to1 decision, said today that in its opinion the United States Supreme Court would hold that California's system of financing public ed ucation violated the Federal Constitution.

title: DOW OFF BY 6I12 IN SLOW TRADING
description: Stock prices retreated yester day in the wake of weekend hints by several Cabinet mem bers that the Government ulti mately might administer some controls on corporation profits.

title: NEW FOUNDLAND BIDS FOR BOWATER PLANT
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Aug. 30 (AP)Premier Joseph Smallwood announced today the Newfoundland Government has asked the Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., in London for an option to purchase the com pany's ailing mill in Corner Brook.

title: ChildrenProof Aspirin Urged by Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration today pro posed mandatory children proof packaging for aspirin, the leading cause of fatal child poisoning.

title: News Analysis
description: Barnett Levy, a New York State assistant attorney gen eral who investigates consumer frauds, described yesterday how one of his friendsa state official whom he did not iden tifytraveled via a charter flight to London recently.

title: James Is Revised in a Movie at Venice
description: VENICE, Italy, Aug. 30The mania for improving on great authors runs rampant these days. Henry James has been re written for the screen. Michael Winner's film, The Nightcom ers, shown at the Venice Festi val tonight, relates the events that might have happened be fore The Turn of the Screw begins.

title: Two State Agencies Are Investigating Con Ed Billing Practices
description: Responding to a rising tide of consumer complaints about high electric and gas bills, both the Public Service Commission and the State Attorney Gen eral have begun investigations of the Consolidated. Edison Company's billing practices.

title: Confusion on School Rule
description: Joseph Monserrat, member and former president of the Board of Education, has at the very least acted unwisely in carrying one of his business associates on the public payroll as a $100aday consultant. The aide, Julio Rod riguez, has earned nearly $20,000 in fees since January. Since Mr. Monserrat and Mr. Rodriguez are partners in a yearold firm that specializes in public relations and gen eral consulting work, the dividing lines between their own and the board's business may too easily be blurred.

title: President to Visit Canada; Would Like to Go to Japan
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30President Nixon will visit Canada next spring and would like to go to Japan, the West ern White House announced today.

title: Ralph A. Aiello, President Of Candlemaking Firm, 66
description: YONKERS, Aug. 30  Ralph A. Ajello, president of A. Ajello & Brothers, a candlemaking company founded by his father in 1889, died today in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, after a long illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 88 Chippewa Road.

title: TWO GUNMEN ROB LAWYERS' OFFICES
description: Two gunmen invaded law offices on West 42d Street yes terday afternoon and robbed five lawyers, a secretary and two clients of $1,000 and sev eral wrist watches.

title: Mrs. Everdell Leader
description: FALMOUTH, Me., Aug. 30 (AP)  Mrs. Romeyn Shethar Everdell of Duxbury, Mass., threetime women's national sailing champion, took an early lead today in the Adams Cup races at the Portland Yacht Club.

title: MURPHY BYPASSES 72 MEN IN PICKING NEW PATROL CHIEF
description: The youngest inspector in the New York Police Depart ment, assigned for most of the last decade to combating cor ruption, yesterday was pro moted over 72 more senior officials and named commander, of the city's 20,000 uniformed policemen.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 30 (Agence FrancePresse). China protested strongly today to Uganda against an outand out lie on the part of Presi dent Amin and the Uganda radio, that a Chinese colonel had been killed in an incident on the Tanzanian border.

title: SOYBEANS RALLY AND TRIM LOSSES
description: Soybean futures declined mare than 5 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, but more than half the loss was trimmed by late buying.

title: Folk Fete Ends With Many Delights
description: UPPER SALFORD TOWN SHIP, Pa., Aug. 30The 10th annual Philadelphia Folk Fesi val, which opened in a down pour Friday night and contin ued through the weekend in a sea of mud, wound up last night in a dense fog. But despite the weather, and despite the diffi culty of reaching the festival grounds when much of the parking space on the 100acre Old Pool Farm near Schwenks ville was closed because of the mud, the largest crowd of the weekend, almost 6,000, turned out for the final program.

title: Victorious Taiwan TableTennis Team on Tour of U.S. Is Armed With Bibles and Paddles
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 30The Chinese Nationalists are trying their own brand of tabletennis diplomacy in the form of a barnstorming tour by a Taiwan team that promotes Christianity instead of Com munism.

title: B.M.W. to Lift Car Prices
description: MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 30 (UPI)Bayrische Mo torenwerke, A.G., will raise prices from 2.6 to 3.2 per cent on its cars effective Sept. 1, B.M.W. said today. The corn pony cited an increase in mate rial and personnel costs.

title: ChildAbuse Study In Upstate Areas Ordered by Duryea
description: Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea yesterday ordered art immediate and extensive legis lative investigation into the prevalence and causes of child abuse with special emphasis on why childabuse cases are not being accurately reported out side New York City.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Books of The Times
description: IN THE VILLAGE. By Anthony Bailey. 225 pages. Knopf. $5.95.

title: LOUIS ARMAND, 66, HEADED EURATOM
description: PARIS, Aug. 30  Louis Ar mand, an engineer whose wide ranging career made him one of the bestknown figures of Europe's technical and business worlds, died of a coronary thrombosis at his summer home in VillerssurMer in Normandy today. He was 66 years old.

title: Boston Police Sue
description: BOSTON, Aug. 30 (UPI)The Boston Police Patrolman's As sociation, hoping for a raise, filed a civil suit in United States District Court today seeking to have President Nix on's freeze on wages and prices ruled unconstitutional.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTONThe Bureau of Labor Statistics reported to day the following spot primary prices for the week ended Aug. 24:

title: Simon Kwalwasser, 61, Is Dead; Psychiatrist Aided the Young
description: Dr. Simon Kwalwasser, a leading psychiatrist who had contributed to the research in insulin and electric shock treatments and in the psychia tric treatment of adolescents, died Sunday of cancer in Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 17544 Mayfield Road, Jamaica, Queens.

title: Bolivia Frees 52 Students
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30 (UPIBolivia's new Govern ment freed 52 university stu dents today. They had been held in army barracks since last week's revolt for question ing about links to guerrilla forces.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Falls Again On Tokyo Market
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 31 The dollar declined again in early trading here, slipping from 342,20 yen yesterday afternoon to about 339 yen this morning.

title: The People Problem
description: The superintendent of two national parks in the Sierra Nevadas, one of this country's few remaining wilderness areas, warned the other day that it may soon be necessary to limit the number of hikers into the parks because litter, water pollution and overcrowding. A single area can take care of just so many people. That's all you can put in there without doing permanent damage, he said.

title: OTB DEBUTS TODAY ON TIMES SQUARE
description: Offtrack betting comes to Times Square today, putting legalized gambling into compe tition with the area's peep shows, pornographic book stores, skin flicks and massage parlors.

title: BuildingContract Value Rose 24% for July
description: Contracts awarded for all kinds of construction work throughout the country in July had a total value of $7,669, 734,000, up 24 per cent from $6,187,030,000 a year ago, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Sys tems Company reported yes terday.

title: Vassar Names Faculty Dean
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Aug. 30Dean Barbara J. Wells of Thomas More College, Fordham University, has been named dean of faculty at Vassar Col lege, the college announced yesterday. Miss Wells, whose appointment is effective next July 1, has been both dean and associate professor of govern ment at Fordham since 1968. She will also be professor of political science at Vassar.

title: Cahill Declares Jersey a Disaster Area, Qualifying State for U.S. Aid in Flood
description: TRENTON, Aug. 30Gov. William T. Cahill officially de dared New Jersey a disaster area today, thus qualifying the state for emergency Federal disaster aid following one of the worst floods in the state's history.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TELETHON TO HELP FIGHT ON ANEMIA
description: The first telethon to raise money for sickle cell anemia, the incurable hereditary blood disease that affects blacks pre dominantly, will be conducted Sunday, Sept. 12.

title: EXYOUTH OFFICIAL CHARGES PAY BIAS
description: Marta Valle, who resigned as city Commissioner of Youth Services last June, said yester day she had complained to the City Commission on Human Rights that $6,000 in accumu lated vacation pay had been withheld from her because of discrimination against her as a Puerto Rican.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF; VOLUME IS SLIGHT
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day in very light trading.

title: Lorry's President Named
description: Eagle Clothes, Inc., an nounced yesterday the appoint ment of Robert Wishnoff as president of B&B Lorry's, a chain of, inen's stores. Mr. Wishnoff; previously vice pres ident and general manager of the chain, succeeds Meyer Waldman who was promoted to Eagle Clothes' retail division.

title: Northern Trust Is Planning OneBank Holding Company
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (Reuters) The Northern Trust Company I said today directors had author ized formation of a onebank holding company.

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies, in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily cor respond to those in other fi nancial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: PATTON FEARS LOSS OF 4,000 PORT JOBS
description: New York City's Economic Development Administrator said yesterday that as many as 4,000 waterfront jobs in the Port of New York might be lost as a result of President Nixon's recently imposed 10 per cent surcharge on imports.

title: U.S. Buying Power Gained In '70 Because of Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (AP) Americans' buying power picked up strength in 1970 mainly because of tax cuts voted by Congress, a Govern ment survey showed today.

title: Japan Will Support Plan To Keep Taiwan in U.N.
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 31 (Agence FrancePresse) Ja pan is prepared to cosponsor with the United States a res olution terming the expulsion of Nationalist China from the United Nations an important question, thus requiring a twothirds majority at the United Nations General As sembly, it was officially stated here today.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Visit Set
description: LONDON, Aug. 30 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India will visit Britain Oct. 31 to Nov. 3, the British Gov ernment announced today.

title: PRESIDENT BROKE A BERLIN IMPASSE
description: BONN, Aug. 30When the Big Four talks on West Berlin seemed hopelessly stalled last October, President Nixon per sonally took up the matter with the Soviet Union, and the talks! were resumed.

title: Dr. Robert Guttchen Dies; Hofstra Teacher Was 45
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 30 Dr. Robert Guttchen, a mem ber of the Hofstra University faculty here since 1959 and chairman since 1967 of the foundations of education de partment, died Friday in a Ver mont hospital of burns suffered in a fire Aug. 19 in his sum mer home at Randolph, Vt. He was 45 years old and and lived at 28 Arrandale Avenue in Great Neck.

title: A CAMDEN SUSPECT LINKED TO 2D RAID
description: The man identified by Fed eral agents as the ringleader of the recent abortive raid on the Selective Service office in Camden, N. J., was named in court there yesterday as a par ticipant in the raid on the Media, Pa., office of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation in March.

title: Kennedy Center Beset by Popularity
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  With the season's first per formance at the John F. Ken nedy Center for the Perform ing Arts still a week and a half away, a wryly apologetic sign already hangs in the center's office here.

title: Carbide Plans Ohio Plant
description: Plans for the construction of a multimilliondollar liquid hy drogen plant in Ashtabula, Ohio, were announced yester day by F. Perry Wilson, chair man of the Union Carbide Corporation. The plant is ex pected to be in operation by the third quarter of 1972.

title: John H. Sheehan, 86, Dies; Assistant Postmaster Here
description: John H. Sheehan, Assistant Postmaster of New York at his retirement in 1955, died Sun day in St. Clare's Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 136 East 36th Street.

title: KAHANE BIDS 1,500 TAKE UP WEAPONS
description: More than 1,500 people packed Samuel J. Tilden High School in East Flatbush last night at a meeting called by the Jewish Defense League to organize citizen car patrols and to arm residents of the area with .22caliber rifles.

title: Grass Harp to Open Center
description: The new $3.5million Power Center for the Performing Arts at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor will open Oct. with the premiere of The Grass Harp, a musical based on Truman Capote's novel. The production is scheduled to open on Broadway Nov. 2 at the Martin Beck Theater.

title: Policeman's Killing Called Retaliation for Jackson's
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30 A San Francisco police homi cide officer theorized today that the shotgun killing of a desk sergeant last night was the lat est of a series of retaliatory acts for the death of George Jackson.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Medina Case Witness Wins Plea on Contempt
description: ATLANTA, Aug. 30 (UPI) The Army's prosecution of Capt. Ernest L. Medina in the Mylai killings received an apparent setback today when Federal District Judge Charles A. Moye ruled that a reluc tant witness could not be cited for contempt until im munity statutes were ruled upon.

title: The Stage: Britain's 8YearOld National Theater
description: LONDON  One trouble of having a National Theater is that it is unusually vulner able. Almost everything it does is subject to unkind scrutiny, and criticism, rightly perhaps, is liable to be harsh. Britain has two national thea ters, the Royal Shakespeare Company and the nominal National Theater.

title: Industrialized Nations Are Reported to Fear Nixon Business Tax Credit More Than Import Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The world's industralized coun tries fear that President Nixon's plans to grant a tax credit to businesses that buy Americanmade machinery and equipment may hurt them more than the new import surcharge imposed this month by the Ad ministration, United States offi cials said today.

title: President of Pet Predicts Rises in Sales and Profits
description: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 30, (Reu ters)The sales of Pet, Inc., will grow to $1billion annually by 1975 with equal or better growth in earnings, Boyd F. Schenk, the company's presi dent, predicted today at the an nual meeting here.

title: H. CLARK SMITH JR.
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 30H. Clark Smith Jr., senior vice president of the Wil bur B. Driver Company, New ark, a maker of alloy wire prod ucts, died yesterday in Sparta, N. J. He was 60 years old and lived at 121 Inwood Avenue and in Sparta.

title: Executive Changes
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday the election of George B. Morris Jr. as vice president in charge of the industrial relations staff and Stephen H. Fuller as vice president in charge of the personnel administration and develop ment staff. The appointments were prompted by the retirement of Earl R. Bramblett, 60, who has had the responsibility of these two staffs as vice president in charge of the personnel staf. Mr. Bram blett is retiring after more than 43 years of service at his own request for reasons of health on Oct. 31. Mr. Morris has been director of labor relations since 1968. Mr. Fuller comes to General Motors after being a professor at Harvard University.

title: Article 3  No Title
Breaks on L.I. Studied
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 30 More thin 20,000 customers of the Long Island Lighting Com pany were still without power at daybreak today, more than 48 hours after electricity went out across Long Island before the winds of tropical storm Do ria.

title: Gen. Groves Gets New Post
description: Brig. Gen. Richard H. Groves has been named to head the North Atlantic division of the Army Corps of Engineers, be ginning tomorrow, replacing Maj. Gen. Charles M. Duke, the Army announced yesterday. General Duke is retiring.

title: WALSH RESPONDS TO BEAME CHARGE
description: The city's Housing and De velopment Administrator Albert A. Walsh, denied yesterday a report made on Friday by Con troller Abraham D. Beame that Mr. Walsh's agency had cleared 21 vouchers for payment in the scandaltained Municipal Loan Program.

title: SYDNEY WILMOT
description: BUSKIRK, N.Y., Aug. 30  Sydney Wilmot, retired man ager of publications for the American Society of Civil Engi neers, died here on Thursday following a long illness. He was 83 years old and lived at Fort Hill Village, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: The President As Dictator
description: CLEVELANDTo one who has sur vived all the financial panics of this century, has known all the Presidents and has been privileged to participate in building up American industry and agriculture, the disgrace of the dollar in world financial centers is sobering.

title: Farah Mfg. Agrees To Aquire Montez
description: Merger News

title: Medieval Tombs in Original Glory
description: DIJON, FranceEver since art became a collector's game, monuments have been ripped apart and dispersed through out the world. The current exhibition at the Dijon Mu seum of Fine Arts, Mourn ers in the Medieval Art of Europe, is flagrant evidence of this. Funerary monuments, paintings and manuscripts that were once whole in the churches of Europe have now been reassembled from the collections of major museums throughout Europe and Amer ica. Thus it is possible to see for the first time some of these works in their original glory. And it is a special treat.

title: Currency Trading Here Shows Some Strength for the Dollar
description: The dollar strengthened slightly yesterday in the New York foreignexchange market, but dealers were reluctant to ascribe any special significance to the movement. The pound sterling, the Canadian dollar and the Swiss franc were all slightly lower yesterday, while the German mark was about unchanged at 29.44 cents, against 29.43 cents on Friday.

title: OUTLOOK IS BLEAK FOR CLASS OF 71
description: More than two months after receiving their college degrees, many members of the Class of '71some unable to find per manent employment, others without money for graduate schoolare growing increasing ly perplexed about their future.

title: Opposition Sweep Shows Danang's AntiThieu Mood
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 30That should explain to President Thieu how they feel up here in Military Region I, an American adviser to the mayor of Danang, South Viet nam's second largest city, said this morning when he heard the, results of Sunday's elections f:or the lower house.

title: Problem at Submarine Base
description: GROTON, Conn., Aug. 30 (AP)A threeman Department of the Navy investigating team has found a racial problem at the submarine base here that could change to critical with provocation or lack of com mand attention, according to the team's report.
